TITLE: Three Kwale PSB Officers Quizzed Over Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); COUNTIES (90%); BRIBERY (90%); INTERROGATION OF SUSPECTS (90%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (78%); JOURNALISM (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THREE Kwale County Public Service Board officials were on Monday quizzed over allegations of nepotism, tribalism and corruption. Chairman Kassim Riga, secretary Victoria Tumaini and commissioner Salim Mrina appeared before labour committee led by Swalehe Simba. Riga requested to be heard in camera as he responded to corruption allegations levelled against the board. He said the matter was very sensitive to be heard in public. Ndavaya ward representative Juma Masoud told the sitting that some people had allegedly informed him that one had to bribe the commissioners to get any job. "Is it true that no one can get a job in Kwale before he or she bribes you? Is it true that in the suspended recruitment of ECD teachers, about three people claimed they were asked to pay Sh100,000 to be picked ," Masoud said. Riga said he is willing to tell the committee everything. He said he was personally approached by one of the county leaders to give his relative a job in exchange of a beach plot. Riga told the committee he told off the leader, who he refused to name, before journalists were sent out. Sources who refused to be named told the Star that the leader is one of the MCAs. Simba said he will not discuss the issue currently until they table a report before the assembly for discussion.

TITLE: President Uhuru and DP Ruto Will Not Eliminate Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); RAILROAD CONSTRUCTION (90%); MASS TRANSIT CONSTRUCTION (90%); POLITICS (79%); CARTELS (76%); ETHNICITY (60%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (56%) Kenya; Corruption; Construction; Industry and Infrastructure
TEXT: President Uhuru and DP Ruto have announced they will proceed with the multibillion railway project from Mombasa to Malaba and those who don't like it can go and hang. Kenyans have however raised a red flag over the railway project citing irregularities that include; different figures for the cost of the project from different ministries, overpricing of the project compared to the same job done for Ethiopia and most shocking, giving contract to a company that is blacklisted by World Bank over improprieties in the Philippines. Don't we fear hunting with ogres or are we ogres too? While denying any possibility of corruption in the railway contract, President Uhuru and DP Ruto have claimed that those who are complaining against the project are holding brief for corrupt cartels in the government who were inherited from the Kibaki regime but no one is sacking them! If some leaders agree there are cartels in government seeking contracts for themselves, local and Chinese contractors, nothing should proceed before the air is cleared. But although Uhuru and Ruto deny any corruption in these deals, people have a right to be apprehensive when different leaders in the same government claim graft about the same contracts. When accusations of corruption are made, poor Kenyans must feel uncomfortable when they remember grabbing of land by Kenyatta government, Ken Ren and Goldenberg of Moi era, Anglo-leasing, Triton, loss of free education and Aids money under Kibaki and now Railway, Lapsset, Laptop and Tassia Estate of NSSF under Uhuru and Ruto. Is not, once bitten twice shy? But if overpricing of projects is not denied by Uhuru and Ruto and if the railway project goes on, it is Kenyan taxpayers who will shoulder the bill for many years. This is why Kenyans get poorer while the corrupt get richer. When corruption was exposed during Kenyatta and Moi eras, the exposures were ignored and their authors killed or detained without charge or trial. When corruption was exposed under Kibaki, it was taken as legitimate and those raising the alarms were dismissed as doomsayers, liars or the never-do-wells and Kenyans continue to pay for it. Likewise, Uhuru and Ruto have said in very forceful language that suspect projects will go on whatever anybody says. And fortunately for them, ethnic leaders have their Chinese terra-cotta warriors who will go to the grave with them, not for their innocence but shared ethnicity. The Kikuyu even say however earned, cattle in Kikuyu land are better than those in Maasai land while pastoral communities say, all cattle belong to them. How then can leadership extirpate corruption when communities justify and defend it? Kenyan leaders will not give up corruption if they benefit from it and know Kenyans support it even when they are its victims. Leaders believe political life is a gamble and the bigger the gamble, the greater the gain. To political high-stake players, a gamble of Sh400 billion is irresistible however baffling and risky. Indeed, mega corruption is the goose that lays the golden eggs and only a foolish leader will commit suicide by killing it. President Uhuru has asked people who are dissatisfied with the railway project to go to him or parliamentary committees for remedy. But how can leaders arbitrate against corruption when MPs, senators, MCAs, President and his deputy avoided vetting by shoving aside chapter six of the constitution? What corruption is President Uhuru fighting with his website when he is not fighting alleged graft in the major projects of Jubilee government? When I was in Parliament and government, I learnt Kenya is a society whose 95 per cent lies in the dark, underground of corruption and only five per cent of it is above the surface, transparent, honest and untainted by graft. From their refusal to implement annual reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General, reports of Parliamentary Accounts Committee and Parliamentary Investments Committee, Kenyan governments from colonialism to Uhuru's have never fought and will not fight corruption. In Kenya, a crusader against corruption is an enemy of government that is always a friend of graft. When I was elected chairman of PAC in April 1981, President Moi threatened to dissolve the committee if I did not resign. Corrupt civil servants protested that as chair of PAC, I would use the committee to witch-hunt them. When I refused to resign, they forced compliant members to vote me out in order to "save" the committee. Have we learnt nothing since 1981, if Uhuru and Ruto government can claim the railway deal is clean and beneficial to Kenya, claim it wants to fight corruption but give a multi-billion contract to a Chinese company that is blacklisted by the World Bank. Has Kenya not been impoverished by fake contracts with conmen-contractors because we failed to undertake due diligence on them? Is the appetite and greed of individuals to earn billions enough to mortgage the survival of the nation and entire future of our children and their children? How can Ruto and Uhuru claim Jubilee government is for development, but allow foreign contractors to overprice projects by hundreds of billions? With what shall we finance our future development if we allow corruption to bankrupt us today? To end corruption, Kenyans must stop defending graft by their ethnic elites, unite and use all the forums available to expose, rebuke, attack and kill corruption.

TITLE: ICT Board Cautioned On Corruption Temptations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); APPOINTMENTS (90%); ELECTRONIC GOVERNMENT (77%); COMPUTING & INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (74%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (73%); APPROVALS (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); EXECUTIVES (69%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (57%) Kenya; Corruption; ICT and Telecom
TEXT: ICT Secretary Fred Matiang'i has warned the nine-member ICT Authority board to be wary of corruption temptations that could come through multi-billion deals in fatty government tenders under their watch. The ICT authority is mandated to approve procurement processes of the capital intensive ICT projects including delayed Sh1.2 trillion Konza Technology City. "You come in at a very challenging time when government is investing heavily in ICT, " Matiang'i said on Thursday when he inaugurated the board in Nairobi. "Public interest must come first because there is going to be serious investment now and in future." However, the appointment of six directors by the CS on January 16 has sparked off sharp protests from ICT Association of Kenya over the procedure used and heavy public sector presence. ICTAK charged that the CS contravened legal notice 183 of 2013 in appointing some of the directors from public universities and their concurrent appointment when the law stipulates they be appointed at different times to avoid vacuum when their respective terms expires. "We are not out to sabotage anybody but the procedure should be followed," said ICTAK secretary general Kamotho Njenga. "The ministry already has a number of court cases that has slowed implementation of critical projects and the CS should revoke the gazette notice to avoid further suits. " The contested appointees from public universities are Timothy Waema and Elijah Omwenga both of University of Nairobi and Esther Kibere of Kenyatta University. Matiang'i however dismissed ICTAK protest as "petty" from "idle" people saying he went for some of the best brains. "This was deliberate because we want to take standards higher," he said. "They have engaged in...research for many years and they will come up with seamless policies. " Other appointed members are Bertha Dena of Unites States International University, David Mugo and Ugas Mohamed from the private sector. They will be joined on the board, chaired by last month's presidential appointee Edwin Yinda, by representatives of Principal Secretaries in ministries of ICT,Treasury and Lands. The authority in August 2013 assumed duties previously discharged through Kenya ICT Board, Department of e-Government and the Government Information Technology Services then under Treasury. Matiang'i however remained non-committal on when he will appoint the chief executive of the authority saying it will be done procedurally and in due course.

TITLE: Mandago Seeks Help to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); COUNTIES (92%); ETHICS (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: UASIN GISHU Governor Jackson Mandago has invited the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission to help unearth graft allegations in the county government. He said the EACC will train county workers on new policies of fighting corruption in public offices. Mandago said Uasin Gishu is among the five counties selected by the EACC under a pilot project to implement a new strategy to fight graft in counties. He was speaking during a training workshop attended by Uasin Gishu county officials in Eldoret town on Monday. EACC chairman Mumo Matemu visited Eldoret last week and said counties will be used to implement strategies in tackling corruption.

TITLE: Corruption Is Fighting Back, Says EACC Chairman
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (89%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: ETHICS and Anti-Corruption Commission chair Mumo Matemu yesterday said he has begun to "feel the heat of corruption fighting back". He told guests during the launch of East Africa Breweries Limited's Pathway of Pride on Tuesday evening that the fight back has become innovative. Matemu said the commission is being diverted into sideshows to thwart its focus on ending corruption. He vowed not to waver despite an ongoing campaign to malign the commission. A section of the media reported that Matemu was under pressure from the directors of Chaterhouse Bank to clear it of graft charges and has been meeting them. Yesterday, Matemu denied the claims referring the Star to the speech he gave at the EABL event: "I have never met any official of the said bank. I am not ready to be distracted on our main focus of fighting grand corruption. I refer you to the speech I delivered yesterday where I said they are becoming innovative in their quest to divert attention," he said.

TITLE: Corruption Is Fighting Back,Says EACC Chairman
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ETHICS (79%); INVESTIGATIONS (79%); EXTORTION (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (74%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); TAX FRAUD (73%); EXECUTIVES (72%); TAXES & TAXATION (69%); TAX LAW (65%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: ETHICS and Anti-Corruption Commission chair Mumo Matemu yesterday said he has began to feel the heat of corruption fighting back. He told guests during the launch of East Africa Breweries Limited Pathway of Pride on Tuesday evening that the fight back has turned innovative. Matemu said the commission is being diverted into sideshows as means of thwarting its focus on taming grand corruption. He vowed not to waver despite an ongoing campaign to malign the commission. "I want to assure all Kenyans that the EACC will proclaim its full constitutional mandate as an independent Commission and will be objective at all times," Matemu said. "I wish to make it clear that the commission will not succumb to any form of pressure, propaganda, coercion, blackmail, intimidation or undue influence from any person." The issue at hand, the Star established, is claims that the commission is preparing the ground for re-opening of the controversial Charterhouse Bank. A section of media reported that Matemu was under pressure from directors of the bank to clear it and has been meeting them. They quoted a letter allegedly written by an official of the bank demanding public release of a report of an investigation carried out by the defunct Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission on its operations several years ago. The bank was closed and placed under statutory management seven years ago on accusations of money laundering, tax evasion and economic sabotage. Yesterday, Matemu denied the claims referring the Star to the speech he gave at the EABL event: "I have never met any official of the said bank. I am not ready to be distracted on our main focus of fighting grand corruption. I refer you to the speech I delivered yesterday and where I said they are becoming innovative in their quest to divert attention. I have learned from my predecessors. All I can say is to invite you to keep watching this space," he said. Sources at Integrity Centre said the commission received a letter from an official describing himself as the managing director of the bank but resolved to ignore it since a bank which is already under statutory management cannot have such an official.

TITLE: Ruto Warns Leaders On Corruption
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); FUNDRAISING (78%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Deputy President William Ruto has said the Jubilee government will not condone corruption in both national and devolved funds. Ruto asked those in charge of devolution and national funds meant for development to ensure every coin is spent wisely for to achieve Vision 2030. He said the government will ensure those embezzling funds meant for development are prosecuted. "Funds must be utilised well as it is time to separate those who want to deliver from those who don't," Ruto said. He said the government is ready to work with any political party and leaders to ensure development is achieved in the country. "We were elected to help Kenyans regardless of the party and since politics is over, party politics is also over. As leaders we need to fasten our belts for development," Ruto said. He was speaking yesterday during a fundraiser in aid of Nyamutiro SDA Church in Kuria East subcounty, Migori county. Governors and senators from Nyanza and Rift Valley appealed to the communities along the borders to embrace peace and concentrate on development. Governors Zachary Obado (Migori), Samwel Tunai (Narok) and Senators Charles Keter (Kericho) and Wilfred Machage (Migori) said programmes should be put in place to end cattle rustling along the border.

TITLE: Propaganda, Perception and the Fight Against Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); CIVIL RIGHTS (89%); NATIONAL SECURITY (76%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (76%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (64%); COST OF LIVING (60%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: long arm of the law: Activist Boniface Mwangi arrested by the police. Even as Kenyans were digesting Mr. Kimemia?s words, thepolice violently moved to brutally break up a peaceful protest rally led by prominent good governance activist Boniface Mwangi, intotal disregard of the constitutional provision protecting citizens? rights to peaceful demonstrations. On the 13th of February, the National Security Advisory Committee (NSAC) issued a statement signed off by the Secretary to the Cabinet, Francis Kimemia. Reading it, it is impossible not to have a sense of dí©jíæ-vu. The substance of the statement - that a foreign government is funding organizations to destabilize the Kenya government - is not new. In actual fact this is a familiar Moi-era narrative, the timing of whose re-emergence can only be described as anachronistic. That is, of course, unless this echo of a bygone era is a diversionary tactic, intended to distract Kenyans from much more pressing matters. In a country where we are living in a clearly deteriorating security situation, it is deeply troubling that the NSAC would have found the time to be seized with, and opine publicly to, such distracting falsehoods. Troubling because all this is happening while the truth behind Westgate saga remains unresolved, questions still linger about the death of Senator Mutula Kilonzo, and 'collapsing billboards' 'exploding light bulbs' starkly demonstrate the security challenges we face. Add to this what seems to be a serious crackdown on supposed Muslim extremist elements at the Coast that could serve to further alienate a youthful, angry and hungry demographic there. Additionally, we have witnessed violence that has caused the displacement of over 50,000 Kenyans from Moyale in Marsabit County. Tensions in Tana River, Mandera, Wajir, Garissa, Bungoma, Busia, and Trans Nzoia and in the border zone of the Kalenjin and Luo communities testify to this insurgent narrative. In the midst of all this the NSAC, in an uncharacteristic statement, choose to opine on their fear of 'demonstrations' by 'activists'. Not only was the content of the statement somewhat alarming, so too was the context. Even as Kenyans were digesting Mr. Kimemia's words, the police violently moved to brutally break up a peaceful protest rally led by prominent good governance activist Boniface Mwangi, in total disregard of the constitutional provision protecting citizens' rights to peaceful demonstrations. Someone, somewhere, has their priorities upside down. Those who joined Mr. Mwangi in person or spirit were motivated by issues that all Kenyans are currently complaining about - unemployment, the high cost of living, insecurity and corruption. In recent weeks the head of state has lashed out angrily against corruption with more vigour than ever before. The rhetoric against corruption has developed a consistency that is interesting, with the President even admitting that some of the worst offenders where corruption is concerned work in his own ministry. This frankness has been most intriguing; his frustration that corruption networks threaten the efficient roll out of his government's ambitious infrastructure programme has been very evident. It is timed well because while most Kenyans complain about graft, there is a sense of fatalism as to whether the government will do anything about it. Polls conducted both within and outside the country have been consistent in demonstrating that the country has slid backwards where corruption is concerned. The massive infrastructure projects the government has embarked on have ran up against the most formidable enablers of corruption in Kenya - the giant embedded networks of graft that have had 50 years to consolidate their grip on our State. Combined, they are more powerful than the institution of the head of state. The insidious nature of these networks around the world cannot be exaggerated. Embedded corruption networks consist of four groups of players, beginning with the private sector (especially brokers whose currency is access to power), and key operatives in the banking and legal fraternities. Second, the networks always include politicians who ironically are the most dispensable of the four groups of players. Elections can be held, key political godfathers of particular deals replaced, but the deals don't die, political careers, reputations and ambitions do instead. Third, the resilient core of any powerful corruption network is the bureaucracy. Here I speak not of the permanent secretary, but those lower down the ladder who shuffle contract documents from office to office. Finally, no embedded network succeeds without the protection of security sector - police and intelligence. In some countries, for example, a couple in West Africa, the drug trade is overseen by the military. Embedded graft networks make even the most well-meaning goals of an administration extremely challenging to achieve within the time allocated and at a cost that doesn't drive the poor deeper into penury. They also poison key governance institutions such as the Security Services, Judiciary and Legislature. In an increasingly globalized world, the architecture of ripping off the poor in turn uses the same networks. So money launderers (in 2010 over US$3 billion in illicit flows passed through Kenya), corrupt officials and their partners, drug traffickers, digital era slavers who trade in people (especially girls who are now a more profitable 'commodity' for organized crime than heroin), and those who are involved in the financing of terrorism increasingly in turn also use the same networks. On the anti-corruption front, Kenya is stuck in a rut. Dealing with the powerful networks that thrive here means that that in the first instance you can't simply shut them down. One starts by destabilizing and disorganizing them via all the tools available to an Executive in its arsenal. A massive variety of technical tools exist - from procurement rules to the use of digital technology to monitor, measure and analyse graft in an actionable manner. All this presumes the Executive has the will to do this - President first. They can then be dismantled and measures put in place to limit their chances of their reconstitution. The push for major prosecutions is important but prosecution is the bluntest instrument in the fight against corruption. Indeed, all over the world the corrupt love going to Court because their lawyers are better paid; legal prosecution buys them time and allows them to probe for weaknesses in the institutions of law that can be exploited. Secondly, and ironically, one can't always fight corruption successfully using outlier bespoke institutions that came into vogue in the 1990s, such as anti-corruption commissions. These were created because of the failure of institutions such as the offices of the Attorney General and the Director of Public Prosecutions to prosecute corruption, and of the Police to investigate it. At the end of the day you can't deal with graft without the police on your side, hard as it is to reform that institution. In my experience, skilled cops when properly incentivized and with enough political cover are ruthlessly efficient against graft. Third, embedded networks revile transparency. All their letters, even those touching on the most mundane affairs of government in which they have an interest are always marked 'confidential' or 'secret'. Opening up government contracts and budgets to public scrutiny is essential to fight graft. As citizens make more use of our Freedom of Information provisions this should help. Fourth, a government in the grip of systemic corruption such as Kenya's is, needs to appreciate that corruption is 50 percent perception and 50 percent reality. The current controversies around the SGR, laptop and other projects bedevilling the Jubilee administration for example, has made the President and his administration a victim of the generalized cynical attitude where Kenyans do not believe that the government is serious even when the President says he wants to fight corruption. This is partly informed by history, the 'we've heard it before syndrome'. It is made exponentially worse by the kind of bizarre legitimacy-destroying statement the NSAC issued last week and the contradictory statements of different officials on the projects that are at the centre of public controversy. The management of expectations and communicating these carefully to a jaded public is key. President Uhuru has about a year left, if not less, to make significant headway in discombobulating then dismantling our embedded networks and replacing them with delivery systems and frameworks that are effective and transparent. Fifth, it helps when corruption is made a national security issue. The Chinese, for example, in their current five-year development plan, explicitly identify corruption as the biggest threat to the Communist Party's hold on power. Across Africa, too many intelligence agencies spend their time spying on the 'opposition', when it would do their countries well to invest their resources in also protecting the national piggy bank. Six, if you want to fight corruption, don't start a war with the media and civil society. What they say and do may bring discomfort, but their vigilance is essential to bolstering the Government's own efforts against graft. In Kenya's case, one of the unintended consequences of current official attempts at curbing the freedom of media and civil society to operate will be to further internationalize global activism against graft and human rights abuses in Kenya - both by institutions and individuals especially on social media. This is almost invariably accompanied with a personalization of the problem - i.e. 'the President did it' whether true or not. A reliance on propaganda via the gutter press, social media and online papers whose mission is to lie, apparently on behalf of the government or elements of it, also eventually backfires every time. The truth always emerges with the resultant deepening of public scepticism and cynicism. Last but not least, any effort to fight graft must have clear strategy for dealing with campaign finance. The proceeds of corruption often pay for increasingly expensive American-style campaigning. Those who contribute the largest sums are not donors but investors who expect a return. They become the preferential shareholders of Kenya Inc. Their demands and expectations are often inimical to the expressed ambitions of an administration vis-íæ-vis corruption generally. Finally, one recognizes that the most paralyzing corruption is the one that afflicts family and friends. And sadly, in terms of informing the public mood and defining the legacy of a leader vis-íæ-vis corruption, it is how one handles this that speaks loudest regarding the true intentions regarding corruption. The seminal 1996 Warioba Report on corruption in Tanzania argued that to succeed in the fight, one needs to literally transform it into a mass movement where all wananchi act against incidents of corruption that confront them personally and as families. This bottom-up approach began to take place in Kenya in January 2003. Across the country, citizens were arresting cops who sought bribes from them. Sadly, it fizzled out within six months, starved of the political will it needed to make it sustainable, but making evident two things. First, it is only a campaign of this nature, by the people, that can make a major demonstrable impact in the short to medium term. Secondly, for this to be sustained, the will, legitimacy and determination of the government's top leaders must be manifest.

TITLE: Murder of Kenya Power Staff Linked to Corruption
SUBJECT: MURDER (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SHOOTINGS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); NATURAL GAS & ELECTRIC UTILITIES (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (89%); EXECUTIVES (89%); ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING (89%); TECHNICIANS & TECHNOLOGICAL WORKERS (89%); ENERGY CONSUMPTION (89%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); MANUFACTURING FACILITIES (73%); INTERNAL AUDITS (72%); APPOINTMENTS (71%); FINES & PENALTIES (62%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (54%); AUDITS (50%) Kenya; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: TWO Kenya Power engineers murdered in the last month may have been victims of corruption in the parastatal. Yesterday Nairobi police CID commander Nicholas Kamwende said that police are investigating this possibility after the murder last Wednesday of Engineer Hannington Nyongesa Wandisi in Matasia, Ngong. Nyongesa was in charge of the Large Power section in Limuru before he was transferred to Kajiado shortly before his death. On January 23 Kenya Power engineer Francis Muchiri was shot dead in Thika. Muchiri, the KP manager in charge of Large Power in Thika region, was killed while entering his house in Ngoigua estate at around 11pm. Gunmen forced their way into his compound, shot him twice and fled. Nothing was stolen. Yesterday Thika Police Chief Paul Letin said police are yet to identify the killers. Last Wednesday Nyongesa had just arrived at a bar to watch a football match when he received a telephone call. He went outside to answer it and was shot dead as he was receiving the call. Nairobi Police commander Benson Kibue said patrons in the bar heard gunshots and found Nyongesa. The gunmen fled under the cover of darkness. Nothing was stolen from him. Nyongesa and Muchiri both worked in the Large Power department of Kenya Power which deals mainly with factories and industries. There have been rumours of illegal connections and power theft rackets saving some businesses millions of shillings per month. Yesterday Kamwende said police are also looking into possible links between the deaths of the two engineers and the alleged power theft racket. However the Kenya Power Managing Director and CEO, Dr Ben Chumo, yesterday downplayed claims that the two engineers might have been killed because of a racket between company staff and large power consumers. Unscrupulous engineers allegedly collude with large power consumers to alter power bills so that the consumer pays less than the actual power consumed, according to insider sources. The businesses allegedly pay KP employees a share of the money saved from their power bills. Chumo was appointed acting CEO of KPLC in June last year and was confirmed as the boss of Kenya Power in January. Once Chumo took over, he started a crackdown on illicit deals and slapped hefty fines on some consumers. Chumo said he did not wish to speculate on the cause of death of the two engineers as the police were investigating. He pointed out that KP stopped staff last September from reading meters of large consumers of power after installing the Automatic Meter Reading. The meters of large consumers are now read electronically from the KP head offices in Nairobi and then copied to the IT, Internal Audit and the Commercial Services departments. Chumo did not reveal how much KP might have lost before the new automated systems were installed. Yesterday Chumo confirmed that some top KP managers have gone on leave but insisted that it was for internal administrative reasons and nothing to do with corruption. He said none of them have been sacked. Those on leave include Coast Regional Manager engineer Joseph Lengaki, Manager Commercial Services Rosemary Gitonga, and Engineer in charge of Pre-paid Metering Joseph Wekesa. Engineer Sammy Muita, formerly in charge of National transmission, has become a regional manager.

TITLE: Corruption 'Taking Root in the Counties'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); COUNTIES (90%); LOBBYING (90%); INTERNAL AUDITS (86%); AUDITS (86%); EXECUTIVES (76%); EXTORTION (74%); COUNTERFEITING (65%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Corruption has increased since devolved governments were introduced, a human rights lobby has said. Haki Africa yesterday said corruption is taking root in county governments. "While huge sums of tax payers' money was being lost to the then centralised system of governance, it has now become apparent that collectively, Kenyans are losing much more through the devolved system of governance," said Haki Africa executive director Hussein Khalid in a statement yesterday. Khalid called on governor and their finance executives to be more strict and punitive against corrupt activities and individuals. He said governors must fight corruption at all costs. "In Mombasa county for example, Kongowea market is evidence of such a matter where cartels, most of them led by politicians are extorting money from business and denying the county the much needed revenue for development projects," said Khalid. He said the county loses Sh1 million from the market daily due to the cartels. Corruption allegations have been levelled against Mombasa finance executive Walid Khalid but he has since denied all of them. Walid and Kongowea ward representative Jabess Oduor have been at loggerheads with each accusing the other of propagating corruption. The executive has accused the county representative of being the leader of a cartel that operates in Kongowea market. Oduor, who has denied the allegation, has however countered saying Walid has forged documents to try and implicate him in the corrupt deals he has been undertaking in the county. Yesterday, a supposed internal audit report dated February 25 and signed by S. K. Kiragu, the interim county internal auditor, implicates Walid in a scam involving an imprest of Sh608,130 in which the executive is said to have received double payment for an official trip to Holland. The Star could not verify the authenticity of the audit report as calls to various departments and authorities either could not get through or went unanswered. The report indicates that an imprest warrant number 1798742 amounting to Sh849,591 was issued to Walid on February 3 and wired to his account through the G. Pay System on or around February 6.

TITLE: Ex-TJRC Chair Calls for War On Corruption
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (88%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Loopholes that promote corruption should be sealed, former Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission chairman Bethwel Kiplagat has said. He said run-away corruption in the government drains the meagre resources available. Kiplagat was speaking yesterday at St Paul University in Limuru during a church unity and social transformation symposium. He attributed the high public wage bill to corruption and inefficiency. Kiplagat said the government should ensure prudent use of its resources. He said it is illogical to reduce public servants' salaries and misuse the acquired money. Kiplagat said the government should bridge the gap between the rich and the poor. Stability cannot be achieved if some people earn millions while others live in abject poverty," he said. Dr Samuel Kobia, a lecturer at the university, said financial disparity in Kenya is a social concern which should be addressed.

TITLE: Jubilee Losing the Corruption Perception Battle [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (78%); LAPTOP COMPUTERS (77%); SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: A combination of the ongoing questioning of the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) project; the dismissal by the government's own leading procurement oversight agency of the laptop project procurement process as fatally flawed; and, a series of other corruption-related developments highlighted by the media have served to starkly demonstrate that for now, as far as corruption is concerned, this government has lost the battle. I say it has lost the battle; there are those who would say it has lost the plot. However, even a cursory reading of the Jubilee manifesto makes it clear that from the beginning it never had a plot when it came to corruption. In a world where GDP growth can often blast ahead, even in a high corruption environment, the hardnosed attitude of the administration has been: "do what it take to get stuff done because in the end, the critical criteria in judging success will be based on the achievement of particular goals". The assumption: a few kickbacks here or there will pale into the recesses of the collective imagination when confronted with on-the-ground realities: a gleaming new railway, a state-of-the-art port, a generation of pupils proudly carrying laptops. The Jubilee coalition's biggest promises have been about both bricks-and-mortar, and service delivery. In the past couple of months, it would seem to have become apparent to the regime that the underlying economics of these projects and Kenya's systemic corruption makes efficient delivery of all these promises at the same time - impossible. I should like to argue that a clash of cultures vis-íæ-vis the corruption inherent in the Jubilee regime has, thus far, stymied even the most pragmatic efforts to get to grips with it. Keep in mind that the current administration is more of a coalition than the last one ever was. While Raila Odinga was Prime Minister, President Kibaki's side of the coalition wielded the real power. There wasn't much Odinga could do about it but complain. The partnership between Uhuru Kenyatta (TNA) and William Ruto (URP) is a real coalition however, primarily because the union between the two principals was derived from the ICC charges they both faced going into the election. The catch however is that the two sides of the coalition are pulling in different directions. While we don't admit it openly in polite company, power in Kenya is sought primarily to eat or accumulate wealth, and/or to protect previously acquired ill-gotten wealth. Within the Jubilee coalition, a clash of cultures vis-íæ-vis 'eating' appears to be underway, if the consistency and increasing din of grumbling among the elite is to be understood in its proper context. Noticeably, there has been a more frustrated gnashing of teeth coming from the URP side of the administration than the TNA side. Some have been bold enough to call it for what it is; complaining at a perceived unfair distribution of public service positions and implicitly, the contracts that accompany these positions. The 1990s saw scandals like Goldenberg extract 10 percent of GDP in a series of transactions. When details finally emerged, it left the public dumbfounded by the sheer magnitude of what had been stolen from its coffers. Under the first President Kenyatta, graft had started out with more stealth; immediately after independence, it was specifically with regard to the dishing out of land. Under President Moi, this developed into a gigantic patronage network via which elite politics was managed. By the start of the 21st Century, several public corporations had been reduced to shells, entire forests decimated, and large swathes of state farms had been dished out to the President's cronies. This Moi-era 'let's-eat-it-all' model meant the destruction of entire institutions. There are many politicians today, in both government and opposition ranks, who cut their teeth and first made their wealth in this way. Hence the "shock-and-awe" scale of Goldenberg. One side of the Jubilee coalition reputedly seeks a return to these 'good old days'. This "termites model", devastating as it can be, is by necessity ethnically inclusive - when it rains the termites all grow wings and fly off. Every tribe's elite gets its cut. Ironically, this inclusivity makes this model far more stable politically. Under the current constitutional dispensation, making this approach work is more challenging, though it is not unlikely that devolution will see some counties exhibit its characteristics. There was a chap in the village, very much a product of the colonial period, called 'Jimmy Roger'. You could tell Jimmy Roger from a mile away. He dressed like his mzungu master: hat tipped to one side, a well-ironed shirt complete with a cravat, socks pulled neatly up to the knees, safari boots or shiny black shoes, starched khaki shorts, and a carefully trimmed thin moustache. Jimmy Roger was a happy fellow and walked with a swagger. The eating model inherited from the Kibaki regime is a sort of lassaiz-faire Jimmy Roger, perceived as the preferred modus operandi of the other side of the ruling coalition. It is corporatized, white collar, vernacular-speaking, overseas-educated, grand corruption, whose architecture is often reasonably sophisticated. Accountants, bankers and lawyers acting for 'consortiums' using a variety of financial vehicles design it. It is dependent on a powerful amalgamation of nepotism, taking conflict of interest so far to the edge of normal business practice, that it sometimes falls off. This narrative was given its policy underpinnings by the Ndegwa Commission Report of 1973 that allowed civil servants to go into business. Intrinsically, this model (dependent as it is on nepotism and conflict of interest), is necessarily exclusivist ethnically. It is therefore politically poisonous and unsustainable on the national front without generous use of the security services to manage the fallout. The Jubilee administration has settled into a model of graft that is neither of the two models and both at the same time. However, it is 50 years since independence and we are governed by a new constitution that is accompanied by more confident, urgent and impatient demands for accountability from wananchi more cognisant of citizen responsibilities. This, in part, explains what can be described as a comedy of gaffes and faux pas on the part of regime spokesmen answering questions on some of the current government's flagship projects. Secondly, as far as huge, officially sanctioned scams go, a pattern has emerged in Kenya averaging roughly one, at most two, every decade. Currently however, the media seems to uncover a new scam practically every month. And others become scams because of the inexperience, bungling and miscommunication on the part of senior officials. The multiplicity of grand policy and economic misadventures on the part of the regime is complicated by the transition to a new constitutional dispensation. The consequences have already started to manifest in political volatility, elite fragmentation and social disorganisation as we try and wrap our minds around it all. But perhaps the most unsettling current consequence is the meltdown underway on the security front around the nation. Cities like Nairobi, Kisumu, and Mombasa have been especially hard hit. Members of the middle class, for the first time sensing themselves as sustained targets of the types of crime the poor long ago became accustomed to, are disheveled but keeping a stiff upper lip. To admit it too wholeheartedly would be to accept that in the short term, it will get considerably worse...

TITLE: Corruption in State House Won't Be Tolerated, Says Lenku
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (88%); CARTELS (70%); IMMIGRATION (52%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Interior Cabinet Secretary Joseph ole Lenku yesterday warned that corruption will not be tolerated at the Office of the President. Lenku, who addressed a media briefing in Nairobi last evening said: "Corruption will not continue to be a way of life". He answered questions from Journalists over the transfer of officers from the finance and procurement departments at the President's office said "dismantling cartels aided by our staff is our responsibility". Lenku said his ministry has taken a lot of internal administrative issues to deal with corruption cases. He said some staff had been fired and prosecuted over corruption allegations. He did not reveal their identities and departments. Lenku said they are police officers and two officials of the Ministry of Immigration who were linked to fraudulently issuing ID cards. He defended his staff from allegations of corruption and said not all his workers were corrupt. Lenku said the ministry has mechanisms of knowing who among his staff members is corrupt.

TITLE: Death Penalty for Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); SENTENCING (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (86%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: You may soon be sentenced to death for corruption if parliament passes a proposed amendment to the Anti-corruption and Economic crimes act. Kiharu MP Irungu Kang'ata wants the Act amended to provide the death sentence for persons convicted of corrupt acts where the loss of public funds exceeds one billion shillings.

TITLE: LCC Plot Scam Exposes PF Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); CITIES (89%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); CONSTRUCTION (77%); INTERVIEWS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (74%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (73%); LEGISLATION (66%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (50%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (50%) Zambia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Government has said the high-level corruption exposed at the Lusaka City Council has exposed the Patriotic Front (PF) inherent appetite for corruption and warned Zambians to be wary of the opposition party ahead of the elections this year. In an interview in Lusaka yesterday, Local Government and Housing Minister Brian Chituwo said PF president Michael Sata had been accusing the Government of being corrupt but had not issued a statement to condemn his councillors and MPs. Dr Chituwo said Zambians must judge which of the two parties was corrupt following allegations that MPs who had been named in the PF shadow cabinet were named as beneficiaries of the 102 plots that were irregularly shared. The minister said the on-going investigations at the country's biggest council had revealed deep scandals apart from the Lilayi Housing project. Dr Chituwo said the team had continued receiving submissions from the members of the public on many other irregularities that were unknown, which forced him to extend the suspension from the initial 90 days for another three months. He said the Government had faced a lot of accusations that it was corrupt but the PF had failed to provide evidence for the law-enforcement officers to investigate. Dr Chituwo said the Government had operated in an open and transparent manner, which had helped raise more resources for the construction of roads and hospitals countrywide. He said avoiding corruption at 100 per cent was impossible in any government but its commitment had been shown with the enactment of new laws such as the Whistle Blowers Act and strengthening of the anti-money laundering systems. The minister urged residents to continue providing reports on what they knew about corruption at the LCC in order to improve service provision for the local government to operate efficiently. Dr Chituwo, who is MMD chairperson for local government, said people were quick at condemning the Government on the basis of the Auditor General's reports but never followed up when recoveries were made. He said the Government always ensured that people mentioned refunded the Government and where crime had been detected, such people were handed over to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC). Dr Chituwo said the PF had been malicious against the Government and wondered what answers they had over the high levels of corruption at the council. Lusaka City Council was involved in a land scam in which councillors mayors, MPs, PF officials such as secretary general Wynter Kabimba were given plots that were not advertised in line with the law. Later reports indicated that Lusaka Mayor Daniel Chisenga sold oneplot to a resident of Lusaka. The mayor was allocated 10 plots while his deputy had five and the acting town clerk received five. Meanwhile, Dr Chituwo has said the LCC will remain suspended until the investigations that were currently going on are concluded. Dr Chituwo said some of the offences that were leveled against some officials were serious, hence the need for investigations to be allowedto be concluded. Dr Chituwo, who was speaking when he featured on Radio Phoenix's Let the people talk programe on Tuesday said the Government wanted to set up structures that would protect the council from any future abuse from office-bearers. "How possible is it that one person can get 10 plots? We want to get to the bottom of this for now and for the future," Dr Chituwo said. Dr Chituwo said in the event that the investigations established that criminal activities took place within the council, the inquiry would be handed over to the law-enforcement agents for further cause of action. "I want to tell the nation that the Government is on course but the issues are complex and require time. We have to ensure that the findings are true and fair," Dr Chituwo said.

TITLE: Corruption Cases Reduce - ACC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); INTERVIEWS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); CUSTOMER SERVICE (70%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (67%); IMMIGRATION (55%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has said corruption cases have reduced due to the introduction of internal mechanisms in organisations that prevent corruption. Chief communication education officer, Festus Chipungu said in an interview at the on-going Agriculture and Commercial Show that the integrity committee had been introduced in Government organisations, agencies and private companies to monitor operations. This year's Agriculture and Commercial Show is carried under the theme, 'Shaping tomorrow's world.' Mr Chipungu said reforms such as customer service had also been set up in some organisations and had worked very well in fighting corruption in the immigration department, Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) and the Ministry of Lands. He said reforms had worked in the fight against corruption because they prevented individuals from having too much power over the clients and improved accountability and transparency. "We have set up about 15 integrity committees in more than 15 organisations such as the Government, agencies and private companies," he said. He said the introduction of the Whistle-blowers Act under the Public Interest Disclosure number four of 2010 would encourage more people to report corrupt cases to the ACC. He said efforts had also been made to widely publicise the existence of the law through the electronic adverts, information materials and lectures. "The integrity committee that started two years ago has proved to be a success in the fight against corruption in organisations," he said. Mr Chipungu further said ACC had engaged civil society organisations to supplement its efforts in fighting corruption through educating the public.ÂHe called on the public to take the fight against corruption seriously and treat those corrupt as thieves because the act took away resources, which was tantamount to stealing. He urged the public to take advantage of different materials published in all the seven major local languages on corruption so that they could fully understand its dangers to the economy. "People do not fully understand the effects of corruption. It results in lack of proper housing, no enough education and diverting of resources meant for development to private purposes. About 140 corrupt cases were reported to the ACC last year and were mostly from individuals.

TITLE: PF Adoption Marred By Corruption -- Lifwekelo
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (79%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICS (78%); DISORDERLY CONDUCT (77%); MENTAL ILLNESS (72%); INTELLIGENCE & COGNITION (67%); HOTELS & MOTELS (50%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: FORUM for Leadership Search executive director Edwin Lifwekelo has said it is obvious that the adoption of candidates by the Patriotic Front (PF) is embroiled in corruption by the party leadership. Mr Lifwekelo said there were allegations that Copperbelt and Lusaka parliamentary seats were fetching as much as K100 million, adding that it was a clear indication that democracy in PF had been subverte and mutilated by Mr Sata. And Mr Lifwekelo has disclosed that his organisation has information that a meeting took lace at the Finnish Embassy where donors expressed disgust at the PF/Post alliance. He alleged that at the meeting, Post editor Fred M'membe failed to justify his alliance with the PF and the same was described by the donors as unprofessional. Mr Lifwekelo said the donors further expressed unhappiness with M'membe's willingness to turn the newspaper into a PF propaganda machinery. Meanwhile, Committee of Citizens executive director Gregory Chifire has called on relevant authorities to establish a commission of inquiry to ascertain Mr Sata's full mental capacity. Mr Chifire said it was in the interest of the nation and that of Mr Sata that an inquiry be stablished going by a number of things that Mr Sata had been doing which were not in onformity with the behaviour of a would-be republican president. He said this at a Press briefing held at Courtyard Hotel in Lusaka yesterday. Mr Chifire said his organisation had been compelled to furnish information in accordance with the provisions of the Mental Disorder Act Chapter 305 of the Laws of Zambia to relevant authorities for the possible establishment of an inquiry into the irregular conduct which was akin to mental disorderly conduct. He alleged that Mr Sata's conduct had not only been highly disorderly, irregular and sad but it seemed to suggest that his mental comprehension was not as it should be. Mr Chifire said Mr Sata's conduct could seriously be classified under the provisions and ambit of the law, in particular the Mental Disorder Act, adding that his organisation had found it fit to classify Mr Sata as an individual well within the provisions of Section 5 of the said Act, in particular Class I and II under the Act. He said although he was not an expert in the medical profession but merely a law-abiding citizen who believed in the laws the of Zambia, he had an obligation to point out matters of nation interest such as Mr Sata's conduct that Zambians had since sadly become ccustomed to through Mr Sata's conduct. Mr Chifire said the Act clearly gives members of the public the liberty to enforce what could be termed in lay mans language as a 'citizen arrest' for purposes of ensuring that mental isorderly conduct was gagged. He said establishing of an inquiry was a safer and more dignified route that his organisation was seeking because Mr Sata had constantly displayed conduct to the general public. Mr Chifire said his organisation would rely on well-documented conduct exhibited by Mr Sata on different occasions such as the November 1, 2008 issue where Mr Sata astonished the whole nation when he allegedly went on rampage hurling insults towards international and locally accredited journalists having lost the 2008 presidential elections. Mr Chifire said the other incident was Mr Sata's alleged unwavering support for gay rights in Zambia and his unpalatable verbal rampage on August 3 this year at a meeting called by the ECZ for presidential aspirants and also the calling of a freelance journalist, Chanda Chimba II as a hyena when he was a human being. He said that the information provided in this regard was not with malice or prejudice but was advanced purely in national interest and especially to safe guard Mr Sata's personal interest and of those around him. Mr Chifire said his organisation would soon be filing an affidavit before the courts on the request for the establishment of an inquiry. But PF vice-president Guy Scott has challenged Mr Chifire to have his mental status examined before he called on Mr Sata's mental status to be examined. Mr Scott said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday that Mr Chifire should ascertain his mental ability first and see whether he was mentally fit. "That is nonsense! He should first have his mental status examined before he requests for Mr Sata's mental status to be examined. Let him do it first and show us how it can be done," Dr Scott said.

TITLE: Academics Slam MPs Sh1 Billion Tax Deal With Treasury As Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); WAGES & SALARIES (91%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (87%); ACADEMIC LIBRARIES (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); LIBRARIANS (78%); TEACHER UNIONS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (76%); CIVIL SERVICES (75%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (73%); APPOINTMENTS (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (69%); HOTELS & MOTELS (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE University Academic Staff Union yesterday termed a Sh1 billion deal between MPs and Treasury over their tax arrears an act of corruption. Union chairman Prof Sammy Kubasu said the MPs were scheming to have the already overburdened Kenyans pay their tax arrears through corrupt means. "The act is another form of corruption being introduced by MPs, selfish and an act of impunity. Kenyans should not be treated as workers and MPs as queens in a bee hive," said Kubasu. He said that MPs were doing this to beat the formation of the salaries and remuneration commission that would be charged with setting their salaries and those of other public servants. He accused MPs of being sluggish in passing the requisite laws in Parliament to facilitate the full implementation of the new constitution so they could continue practicing impunity. Kubasu was speaking at Lurambi at the weekend during the burial of George Shibanda, a chief librarian at Masinde Muliro University, who was discovered dead in a hotel room in Kakamega town a fortnight ago. He called for thorough investigation by police to establish the real cause of death of the librarian. Treasury was reported to have struck a deal with MPs to release Sh1 billion to pay for salary arrears since August 27 last year when the new constitution was promulgated. He accused Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Uhuru Kenyatta of accepting the deal in order to endear himself to MPs whose support for his bid for presidency he wants. Kubasu asked the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission to probe the deal as it means MPs taking money from Kenyans indirectly. The UASU chairman also asked KACC to probe rampant nepotism in hiring staff at the Masinde Muliro University. He suggested that KACC should also subject those seeking to be appointed vice chancellors to vetting.

TITLE: Cabinet Approves Bill Establishing New Anti Corruption Body
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LEGISLATION (90%); APPROVALS (90%); ETHICS (88%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (84%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: A new anti-corruption body to replace KACC will be formed soon following the approval by cabinet of the Independent Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission Bill 2011. The bill provides the framework for investigations, prosecution of corruption suspects and assets recovery. The new body will have a chairperson and six other members and will be headed by a secretary to the commission. The bill will now be presented in parliament.

TITLE: Lest We Forget - the Faces of Impunity, Corruption
SUBJECT: HUMAN RIGHTS (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ETHNIC CONFLICTS (89%); POLITICS (89%); HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (78%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); LEGISLATION (76%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Yesterday the Kenya Human Rights Commission launched an important and timely report, Lest We Forget: The Faces of Impunity in Kenya. The report is written against the backdrop of massive corruption and accompanying oppression, and the resulting culture of impunity that have characterised the system of politics and government since independence. Its aim is to bring to account the perpetrators of corruption, ethnic violence, land grabbing and other violations of the law, particularly human rights-a special concern of the KHRC. The ways in which these practices violate human rights of individuals and communities is obvious: poverty, exclusion, landlessness, ethnic fights threatening human security, impossibility of getting justice in the courts against the rich and the powerful, lack of a fair prosecution system, and the perversion of justice. The KHRC has hit upon an interesting methodology to seek accountability and punishment for these violations, namely by mining existing, official reports. Despite widespread impunity, a considerable amount of evidence has been marshalled against the perpetrators by official processes, through commissions of enquiry or parliamentary committees, or other forms of investigation-these implicate the highest officials, including presidents. Based on the evidence, they should be prosecuted and their ill gotten gains recovered. That this evidence can be gathered reflects one of the several contradictions of the Kenya system. The state is thoroughly criminalised. It serves to create wealth for a handful of politicians, bureaucrats and business people; and to shelter them from the reach of the law. It performs these functions by a systematic violation of the constitution and the law. Much of the edifice for this is built on illegality. But the inconsistency of these practices with constitutional values produces a fundamental contradiction. Deeply repressed, people are driven to put pressure on the government to deal with the more outrageous transgressions of rights. For the most part the government can ignore such pressure-but not always. When it cannot, it resorts to the typical device of delay, even obfuscation-an enquiry, firmly under the control of the government. The Reports examines several of these enquiries (on ethnic clashes, so clearly promoted by politicians (Akiwumi), land grabbing (Ndungu, prematurely terminated but not before the incrimination of the highest in the land), Goldenberg (Bosire), Grand Regency (Cockar), Artur Brothers (Parliament), two enquiries on the Ouko killing, the maize inquiry and more. Most were suppressed and are still "confidential" but have somehow found their way into the public domain. Another contradiction then surfaces-the framework of transparency and public participation, more so in commissions of enquiry than parliamentary committees. The enquirers cannot entirely ignore the evidence, often given in public (though they can fudge a little, and expunge names of suspects like Jomo Kenyatta and Daniel Moi). The president can lock away reports of commissions under the inquiries legislation (but not legally now under the new constitution); this is a bit more difficult with parliamentary committees, but even there intimidation or money (frequently both) can ensure no key person is embarrassed. The most wonderful and terrifying example of this-showing the enormous corruption of state institution, in this case the judiciary-concerns the way in which the wealth of a senior minister was effectively laundered through a court, by curious legal principles enabling it to re-write the commission report, exonerating the minister. Reading the KHRC Report one realises what an extensive and dense network of senior officials of every state institution operates to steal from the state and the private sector, how they mutually support and shield each other from prosecutions and other punishments (by the simple expedience of co-opting the prosecutor into their pursuits), and thus wield a firm hold over the state apparatus-no separation of powers here. The enquiries produce evidence of dishonesty, arbitrariness and thefts by presidents, ministers, ex-ministers, parliamentarians (more numerous than I had suspected), senior parliamentary staff, bureaucrats (lots of permanent secretaries), police (at the highest levels), commanders of the armed forces, district and provincial administrators, diplomats, senior officials of Central and commercial banks, and other parastatals, chief justices and other senior judges, intelligence services, mayors, town clerks and their subordinates, and the children of the above (especially presidents) and their business associates. Truly mind boggling. Among the people identified by various commissions are household names, such as J and U Kenyatta, D Moi, Saitoti, Biwott, Ntimama, I Ruto, W Ruto, Pattni, Wilson Boinett, Sally Kosgey, Henry Kosgey, Michuki, Muthaura, Hussein Ali, Mary Wambui, Balala, Okemo, Sunkuli, Kulei, Mohamed Yusuf Hajj and so on. If the allegations are justified (and remember the allegations are made after thorough inquiries, often by bodies appointed by the government), none of them would be qualified to hold public office under the Constitution's rules on leadership and integrity. Yet they currently, despite internal differences, have a complete stranglehold over the state. In these circumstances political, economic and social reforms are impossible. The KHRC calls for those against whom evidence has been found to be tried. Its recommendations for legal reform have resonances with the approach and substance of the new Constitution. And yet, one year later, it is clear that we have made no real progress in the fight against corruption and impunity. Land grabbing has increased with a vengeance, and the Ministry of Lands is able to say without embarrassment that it can do nothing about the massive corruption within the ministry that facilitates the grabbing, the falsification of titles, the forgery of deeds-and the huge sums of money that are exchanged every day to lubricate the machine that we call the Ministry of Lands. The situation in other sectors is scarcely better. The police continue to extort bribes, turn a blind eye to corruption, abduct people in broad daylight, prefer to kill rather than arrest suspects, in front of terrified spectators, secure in the knowledge that they are untouchable. Drug barons walk (or more accurately, drive in huge limousines), hobnobbing with leaders of the government s and the corporate world. The government sends innocent Kenyans abroad to be tortured without accountability to the public or the courts. The tendering process is ignored or violated daily. All these and many other violations of the constitution and the law have become central to the way the state functions. The implementation of the Constitution is in the hands of those deeply opposed to its values and procedure-and they (many of whom are listed in the enquiries) have ensured through appointing their protí©gí©es to commissions and public services that the new constitution will be rendered toothless. On the first anniversary of the constitution, it is time to turn to its real guardians, the people, victims of the harsh edge of the criminalised state, for the direction and impetus for reform. The writer is a director with the Katiba Institute.

TITLE: Germany Could Halt Funding of the Anti Corruption War If New Bill Becomes Law
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LEGISLATION (92%); ETHICS (90%) Kenya; Corruption; Europe and Africa; Governance
TEXT: Germany could revise its funding to the fight against corruption if the current Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission Bill is passed as it is. Michael Hasenau, the deputy head of mission, says they are keenly following how parliament handles the new law.

TITLE: Corruption Holds Back Battle Against Poverty, Says PLO
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (89%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); LIVING STANDARDS (78%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (77%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (75%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (73%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (72%); COMMODITIES SHORTAGES (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Sustainable Development
TEXT: THE Outgoing Director of the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission (KACC) Patrick Lumumba yesterday alleged that Kenya will not meet the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) as corruption is deeply entrenched in the society. Speaking at the at the 7th Annual International Scientific Conference held at the Moi University, Prof Lumumba lamented that realisation of MDGs will remain be a pipe dream because of lack of supporting policies as well as graft. "We must have policies that will help to empower our people economically if we are to be serious of fighting poverty", said PLO. He gave a key note address which is being hosted by Moi University. He said only two African states, Botswana and Mauritius have tried to meet the MDGs because they had put in place proper structures and policies to help quickly meet the goals and goals they have set. Lumumba questioned the government over the rising cost of inflation and living standards which he said were now a major burden to Kenyans. He said many Kenyans were unable to get access to basic commodities and food. He accused the government of not putting in place measures that will stop increased costs of essential goods. He said traders who are middle men had taken advantage of the situation to exploit Kenyans. The move has cause stress to Kenyans. Lumumba wondered why the country had many sugar factories but still faced shortage of sugar. Present also were the Moi University Chancellor Prof Bethuel Allan Ogot, chairman of university council Evans Mwai, and deputy vice-chancellor in charge of research and extension Prof Bob Wishitemi. Ogot challenged scholars at universities to help the country meet its development goals through research programmes. The conference whose theme is Knowledge Creation and Dissemination for Realization of Millennium Development Goals-will run for four days and is attended by scholars from all over the world.

TITLE: MPs Attack Kibaki, Raila Over Corruption
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); APPOINTMENTS (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (89%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (79%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); FOREIGN RELATIONS (77%); FOREIGN POLICY (77%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (76%); PUBLIC FINANCE (74%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: PRIME Minister Raila Odinga yesterday came under fire in Parliament with MPs accusing him and President Kibaki of protecting individuals implicated in corruption. MPs accused Raila of evading the request by the Speaker to make a statement yesterday on why Moses Wetang'ula was reappointed as the Foreign Affairs minister and Mwangi Thuita as Permanent Secretary before investigations into the questionable purchase of the Kenyan embassy in Japan were concluded. On Wednesday Speaker of National Assembly Kenneth Marende instructed the Prime Minister to make a statement on the Auditor-General's report tabled earlier this week. Yesterday morning Raila called Marende and they agreed that he could deliver the statement next Tuesday. The MPs yesterday also demanded that Attorney General Githu Muigai issue a legal opinion on the reinstatement of Wetang'ula and Thuita. The legislators dismissed the explanation by Transport minister and Deputy Leader of Government Business Amos Kimunya that Raila had a busy schedule as he was attending a conference on drought as well as the burial of freedom fighter Wambui Otieno. Charles Kilonzo (Yatta) claimed that government had no intention of issuing the statement arguing the two principals could not defend their action. He demanded that a legal opinion from the AG on Wetang'ula and Thuita's reappointment be issued alongside Raila's statement. He said the House needed to know if the AG did his part before Kibaki announced the reappointments. "The executive is having a strategy to avoid giving the statement in the hope that the matter will die down," said Benedict Gunda, vice chairman of the Defence and Foreign Relations Committee. George Nyamweya (PNU nominated) said the reappointment was a serious issue since Parliament had voted last year that the pair remain out of office until investigations were complete. He said Raila could have delegated issuing the statement to one of his two deputy prime ministers, Uhuru Kenyatta and Musalia Mudavadi. Bonny Khalwale (Ikolomani) said the issue had started to snowball and asked if the government was aware of the January 2011 report by the Auditor General on the purchase of the embassy building. The report by Auditor General ASM Gatumbu revealed that the government incurred excess expenditure of Sh185 million in the purchase of the embassy while Sh1.35 billion of the total price of Sh1.65 billion was paid in cash, contrary to government rules on procurement. The Auditor General has recommended that all officials and individuals involved in the acquisition of the Tokyo property be held to account. Khalwale said Finance minister Uhuru has been sitting on the report instead of tabling it in Parliament thereby violating the Public Audit Act. Khalwale said the AG also prepare a legal opinion on the Grand Regency deal and the reinstatement of Amos Kimunya into government. Uhuru denied receiving the report by the Auditor General but undertook to ask Treasury officials if the report had been sent to his office. Foreign Relations Committee chairman Adan Keynan demanded that Raila also table reports from the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission, the CID, the Efficiency Monitoring Unit or any other arm of government that indicated Wetang'ula and Thuita had been cleared. "I don't remember in the last nine months any report on the investigations touching the ministry of Foreign Affairs," he said. Aden Duale (Dujis) said the matter was of great importance and called on the Speaker to compel the executive to explain. Duale, who was relieved of his ministerial duties recently, accused Raila and Kibaki of protecting certain individuals. "The people of this country are waiting for answers," he said. Gitobu Imanyara (Central Imenti) said that if Raila was so busy, Vice President Kalonzo Musyoka should issue the statement since he was the Leader of the Ggovernment Business in the House. Marende told the House that Raila had visited his office yesterday morning and explained that he was in a dilemma since he was required to co-chair the summit on drought. Marende directed that Raila issue the statement next Tuesday.

TITLE: GG Links Brew Deaths to Endemic Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (83%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Former cabinet minister G.G Kariuki has cited corruption as the main cause of death caused by consumption of lethal alcoholic brews. G.G accused government officials tasked with ensuring that lethal drinks are not manufactured or sold to unsuspecting members of the public of sleeping on the job. Speaking over the weekend at Kiamaina village in Nyahururu, Kariuki pointed an accusing finger at law enforcement officers saying most of them have turned a blind eye on brewers and sellers of the drinks. The former Internal Security minister pointed an accusing finger at the provincial administration for abetting the vice saying they are in the know of the brewers.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Top Job Advertised
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (90%); EMPLOYMENT INTERVIEWS (89%); BRIBERY (78%); LEGISLATION (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (75%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (70%); PRIME MINISTERS (70%); FELONIES (65%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (50%) Kenya
TEXT: The job previously held by PLO Lumumba as the head of the anti-graft commission has finally been advertised. The selection panel, which is chaired by Rose Mambo, has also advertised for two other deputies as per the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission Act 2011. The Act stipulates that the new Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission shall consist of a chairperson and two other members. The new commission replaces the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission PLO Lumumba and four deputy directors ran. The deputy directors were Pravin Bowry, Wilson Shollei, Prof Jane Onsongo and Dr John Mutonyi. The five left office after Parliament passed a new law last month that demanded a fresh recruitment for the top positions to be conducted. Since their exit from office, most operations of the commission have been under the KACC Advisory Board which is chaired by Okong'o Omogeni. Lumumba's exit from office came only days after he sensationally accused Assistant Minister Cecily Mbarire and her husband Dennis Apaa of bribery attempts. The Act stipulates that a person shall be qualified for appointment as the chairperson if they meet the requirements of Chapter Six of the Constitution which deals with integrity. The candidate should also hold a degree from a university recognised in Kenya. A member of a governing body of a political party or a person who has previously been convicted of a felony, or has been removed from public office for contravening the provisions of the Constitution or any other law, is not eligible. After conducting the interviews, the panel is required to shortlist three qualified applicants for the position of chairperson and four other qualified applicants for the positions of the members and forward the names to the President. After receiving the names, The President in consultation with the Prime Minister, will be required to pick the chairperson and two members and forward the names to Parliament for approval within 14 days. Parliament will then be required to vet and endorse the names within 21 days and forward the names to the President for formal appointment through gazette notice. If Parliament rejects any nomination, the Speaker shall within three days communicate the decision to the President and request the President to submit fresh nominations.

TITLE: Corruption Commission HR Manager Quits Job
SUBJECT: MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (94%); CORRUPTION (93%); HUMAN RESOURCES (91%); RESIGNATIONS (90%); ETHICS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); EMPLOYEE PROMOTIONS (73%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (73%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: A senior manager at the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission has quit office amid claims of infighting at the institution. Human Resource Manager Amani Komora tendered his resignation notice on Thursday last week just days after reports of mismanagement at the former Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission begun filtering in the media. Komora confirmed to the Star his exit from the newly established EACC yesterday. "I have been with the commission for the past seven years and I just felt it is time for me to move on," said Komora. He is rumoured to be headed back to the Kenya Revenue Organisation where he worked before joining KACC. He denied being pushed out of the commission by latest revelations of alleged corruption from within and claims of mismanagement in terms of nepotism, favoritism and sex favours when it comes to hiring and promotion of staff.
