"Like any other organisation, there will always be politics but that is not why I am leaving," added Komora His sudden exit, according to the staff at Integrity Centre has left other senior managers in panic with fears that it might trigger more resignations. Already investigators at the commission are said to be following keenly the activities of their immediate bosses especially those in the procurement chain. Just last week, reports emerged from the anti-graft body how senior managers have been colluding to pilfer money from the institution. The reports touched on irregular rendering procedures to irregular awarding of allowances and other benefits to selected members of the Staff. Leadership crisis at the Commission started in August when Kacc was disbanded and five of its top managers sent packing. It happened after President Mwai Kibaki assented to a new law creating Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) to replace KACC.

TITLE: Clergyman Cites Corruption in Church
SUBJECT: RELIGION (94%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%) Zambia; Religion
TEXT: UNITED Church of Zambia (UCZ) Synod Bishop Mutale Mulumbwa has called for transparency in the manner members handle finances as the church should be free from underhand activities. Bishop Mulumbwa regretted that issues pertaining to church finances in some congregations were being done 'underground.' The Bishop was speaking in Ndola yesterday during a sermon at Northrise Congregation under the theme 'finding out what pleases the Lord'. He said in some instances, church treasurers and other congregation leaders did not want to make public financial positions and revenue of the church because they lacked accountability. "There is corruption in church. Things are being done underground. There should be transparency in the way things are done," he said. Bishop Mulumbwa, however, expressed happiness that at Northrise Congregation, church leaders were able to outline every income and expenditure to congregants and appealed to others to do the same. "I am happy that things here are being done transparently. The announcements about money are important. This building is beautiful because of the manner you are handling matters. I was here when it was just a plot some years back," he said. In an apparent reference to the need to contribute to the church, he said God had his own way of doing things and advised Christians to always establish what the Lord wanted. "You should pay attention to what God requires us to do. Many Christians ask God to give them what they want, but they don't want to give to God what he wants," he said Quoting from Luke chapter 6 Verse 38, Bishop Mulumbwa said Christians should give willingly to others, so that in return they would continue to receive with the blessings of the Lord. "God is not the beneficiary, beneficiaries are ourselves. People should learn to please God. Give and it shall be given to you. When you do what God wants, you are inspired," he said. He said people should not get discouraged by fellow Christians who disparage them when they contribute to the Church's development, as it is those who give in good faith that will enhance God's work. Northrise Congregation minister-in-charge, Mwape Chilombo said she was elated that the Synod Bishop found time to deliver a sermon when the congregation launched the first English service. Reverend Chilombo said the English service was introduced because the congregation had grown and some were not conversant with the vernacular language, Bemba.

TITLE: A Corrupt Regime Cannot Control Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); BUDGETS (89%); CORRUPTION (85%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (78%); ELECTORAL DISTRICTS (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (76%); WAGES & SALARIES (76%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (76%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (76%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (72%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (71%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (70%); BUDGET CUTS (70%); MIDWIVES (67%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (65%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (65%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The factory of districts and electoral constituencies is the busiest enterprise in Uganda. For every district created, the following offices are also created: LC5 chair and his/her executive, a speaker and deputy of the district council, a chief administrative officer, his/her deputies/assistants and other support staff such as accountants, personnel officers, district education officer, district agricultural officer, health officer etc. Then there is the RDC, deputies and assistants, the DISO and assistants, and the DPC. Eventually a district court, prison and prosecutors will also come. Each district will have a woman MP, so that there will be five women MPs instead of one for Bushenyi. In addition to new districts, new constituencies are also being created. For example, the constituencies in Kibaale District are being sub-divided to cater for the presidential ring-fencing policy announced sometime back. Other constituencies are tailored to individual interests. This fast-tracking of the creation of districts and constituencies is for political purposes, it has nothing to do with service delivery. The life presidency project, the number one regime priority, is increasingly untenable, and therefore to sustain it, no expenditure will be spared where there is political capital. As if to prove this point, the budget for health, education, roads and other services connected to poverty reduction and the welfare of the people are drastically being reduced in the next budget in order to cater for this increased administration expenditure, which is more vital for regime survival. Education is being reduced by over Shs70 billion, which is the amount that could increase the remuneration of all primary school teachers to Shs400,000 per month. The health budget is being reduced meaning that medical personnel will get no substantial increment. How can doctors, nurses, midwives get paid peanuts and then you turn round and complain that they are not attending to patients? How can you pay the police what is not equivalent to one night allowance of the people they guard and then you condemn them in corruption surveys that they are considered the most corrupt by the public? Go to the Ministry of Lands and ask what they are paid and you will know why there are so many titles for the same piece of land. In all government, poor service is linked to poor terms of service. All government offices are virtually computerised but what value is a modern office to the official if his/her take home pay does not uplift the welfare of his/her family? Thus the public officials have taken matters in their own hands. As political corruption has risen, so has bureaucratic corruption. As of now , the biggest investors in the country, especially in real estate, land and services, are public officials, politicians, civil servants and their cronies/agents. I have read pleas to government by donors and members of the public that something should be done to control corruption. A regime that survives on corruption, a kleptocracy, cannot do something about corruption. Corruption is embedded in every government transaction at central and local levels. Museveni demands explanation on high cost of road construction (See Daily Monitor of May 10). Then he provides an answer himself "I cannot rule out corruption as an overriding factor" and then he provides the remedial action by instructing the Auditor General "to provide value for money audits in the sector". But why in the road sector alone as if there is any sector where the public gets value for money? Has there been any value for money audit for presidential donations of land and public funds to business supporters? The presidential "pledges hit Shs4 trillion" announces New Vision of May 10. The public purse has been turned into a political slush fund. That is the root of the problem. Mr Ruzindana is the FDC deputy secretary general for policy and research

TITLE: Vaccinated Against Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BUDGETS (90%); SCANDALS (89%); VACCINES (89%); FREEDOM OF PRESS (88%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); BUDGET CUTS (78%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (77%); MALARIA (77%); PUBLIC DEBT (72%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (72%); BANKING & FINANCE (71%); NATIONAL DEBT (71%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (69%); MILITARY HELICOPTERS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Uganda could experience a period of austerity over the next couple of years. We have already had a reduction in the health budget for this year by sh1b, HIV funding from donors has reduced or at least failed to keep pace with demand and donors are critical of the Government's handling of the CHOGM funds. With the financial sector meltdown last year, foreign governments are also being squeezed, since they have large national debts to finance. One trait which I have noticed in Uganda is that we shine the spotlight our own problems, we are not afraid to wash our dirty linen in public - in the most recent case it has been the misuse of CHOGM funds. But having broadcast our failings to the world, we then make little effort to remedy them. We make a song and dance in a forum such as the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee and produce a lengthy report. The President then weighs in, stating that he is taking a strong line against any official found guilty and then what happens? Nothing. In Uganda no-one should complain about the freedom of the press; the press gives wide coverage to our scandals and inquiries and everything is out there in the public domain. Nor can we complain about the independence of Parliament. Some of the committees are definitely not pro-government and certain Members of Parliament will go out of their way to expose government politicians. The Police will investigate evidence after their usual fashion and there are various offices such as the IGG and the DPP which are there to follow up these inquiries with prosecution. But despite these good offices and after numerous inquiries over many years, only a small minority of people have ever been prosecuted. So is it a national characteristic that we say one thing - usually very loudly and publicly and then do another? We talk about corruption, we hold inquiries, we name people in the newspapers, we suspend government officials, we send files to the Police or the DPP and then sit back and wait for the next cycle of inquiries and scandals. From memory, I can think of numerous scandals and inquiries over the years - the army helicopter scandal and subsequent inquiry, the URA inquiry, the Congo inquiry, the NSSF Nsimbe Estate inquiry, the Temangalo saga, the Global Fund, the GAVI fund and now CHOGM. I don't know the average, but every year we have one or two different scandals or inquiries to keep us going. Unfortunately, while the donors are happy with the freedom of the press and the information that comes out, they are beginning to realise that we are immunising ourselves against any real consequences of this rampant corruption. The theory of immunisation is that you get a small bit of the infection in an attenuated form and this exposure makes one resistant to the real disease. In malaria, if children are continually exposed to malaria, they develop resistance and become immune. As a nation we have talked so much about corruption and had so many committees and inquiries, that we have immunised ourselves against the real thing. Therefore we can go on living with it quite comfortably. At first, the outside agencies were generously providing funds for many of our programmes in health and education, because we were so open in talking about our problems. We were so good at diagnosing and pointing out the rot, that they thought it was only a matter of time before we got the surgeon to cut it out. But over the years they have found that the surgeon has not actually been called and they are slowly coming to the conclusion that he is not coming, so some of them have decided to leave with their money. But Ugandans are generally not bothered, because they feel that if this particular stream of funding is cut off it will be replaced by another stream of oil money. But in the meantime, as we wait for the oil to flow we may have to tighten our belts.

TITLE: Northern Administrative Officers Warned Against Corruption
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVES (79%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (78%); CORRUPTION (70%); ARRESTS (65%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Chief administrative officers (CAOs) in northern Uganda have been warned against paying contractors less than is budgeted for by the Government. Simon Toolit, the MP for Omoro county, Gulu district, said this had forced the contractors to do sub-standard work. He was speaking last week during the commissioning of projects constructed under the Peace, Recovery and Development Plan (PRDP) at Gweng-Diya health centre II in Awach sub-county. "We are monitoring the PRDP activities with data from the Northern Uganda Data Centre. When we monitored Oyam and Kitgum districts, we found that contracts are awarded at less value than the money released for the construction," Toolit remarked. The MP said two health centre IIs under PRDP were demolished by the Oyam leaders because the contractor was using sub-standard materials for construction. Toolit disclosed that sh40m was released for Onono Memorial College, but the contractor was paid only sh34m. He added that sh48m was released for the construction of two units of teacher's houses at the college, but the contractor was paid only sh40m. Toolit warned that the parliamentary accounts committee will audit PRDP funds in August, saying those found guilty of swindling the money will be arrested. He attributed the sub-standard works partly to lack of supervision by district officials.

TITLE: Paidah LC3 Asks MPs to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); POLITICS (77%); LOBBYING (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (76%); LIVING STANDARDS (76%); AGRICULTURE (71%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Corruption should be stamped out in order to develop districts through better service delivery, the Paidha LC3 chairman, Godfrey Innocent Onega, has said. Onega was speaking during celebrations to mark the creation of Zombo district at the district headquarters in Paidha on Sunday. He urged politicians, especially MPs, to lobby for funds from stakeholders to supplement the few resources given by the Government. "In order to generate household incomes and raise local revenue for the district, increase food production by establishing large-scale farming and protecting the environment," Onega said. Ferua Kizito, who described himself as the grandfather of the West Nile districts, appealed for team work in delivering services to the districts. "The local government should settle the issue of allocation of funds immediately before it gets out of hand," Kizito observed. He said decentralisation would make service delivery effective and urged that the district funds be remitted properly. Kizito urged the MPs and ministers from the region to deliberate on issues affecting their electorate while in Parliament. He called for unity among leaders in order to promote development. Kizito commended the NRM government for being tolerant with the people of West Nile who have refused to vote for him. He called for unity in the districts of Nebbi and Arua. The district councillors called on the new district leadership to focus on upgrading the road network and the construction of more health centres, schools and staff houses in order to improve the living standards of the electorates.

TITLE: Let Us Play Our Part On Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (90%); SCANDALS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FORENSICS (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (70%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: What is giving people confidence to steal with impunity? In the past few years alone, we have had corruption scandals involving big money. A forensic report is released, the public reacts with a storm, Parliament adds its own hurricane and a whirlwind of revelations rises into the air baffling peace-loving citizens. Soon after, the dust settles as if there was no big deal and we sit back to wait for another scandal! That seems to be the picture from the investigations of the choppers, Global fund, GAVI funds, CHOGM report, NSSF, NFA and now KCC where sh5b is unaccounted for in only one year. It does not help the public to lift the carpet, look at the rot beneath, discuss it, point accusing fingers only to return the carpet in place, leaving the rot intact. Instead, it encourages many others to use their offices to steal more. Thus the saying that as long as it is a lot of money, don't fear to steal because you can use some of it to buy your way out of investigations. In the end, we are harvesting generations of people who get surprised when corruption is frowned upon. Redeeming that situation takes decades. What is wrong? We have many anti-corruption agencies; Police, anti-corruption court, IGG, DPP, Auditor General, President's Office, Parliament, Local Government Accounts Committee, PAC etc; why don't they bite? We need to see big names falling before we take our institutions seriously. The dogs have barked for too long; it is time to bite. The President has pronounced himself on corruption, let all agencies increase their potency. We must save our country.

TITLE: Bishop Calls for Fair Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); ETHICS (90%); RELIGION (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); INTERNATIONAL LAW (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (74%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (74%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (73%); HOTELS & MOTELS (68%); EXECUTIVES (67%) Uganda; Religion; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE war against corruption is likely to remain futile if the Government continues to shoot randomly at the vice, the South Rwenzori Diocesan Bishop has said. "There is too much random shooting at corruption. The real corrupt people are known but nothing is being done to deal with them. When is the Government going to start taking real action?" the Rt. Rev. Jackson Thembo Nzerebende asked. He challenged the Government to identify the methods used by the corrupt so that effective and deterrent actions are taken. "Corruption is being committed by circles of certain people and until these circles are broken into, the war against the vice will not succeed," Nzerebende asserted. The bishop was speaking at an anti-corruption stakeholders' meeting organised by the Kasese District Integrity Partnership Forum at Rwenzori International Hotel in Kasese Municipality. There are numerous anti-corruption laws in Uganda. Uganda is also a signatory to several international treaties inducing the UN Convention on Preventing and Combating Corruption. Ethics and integrity principal officer Kenneth Kauta said another law, the National Values Policy, was in offing. He said the policy, awaiting Cabinet approval, aims at building a values-based society by generating ethical values on which national integrity and ethical standards can be built. He said when implemented, the policy will enhance behavioural change in society to appreciate the importance of integrity and accountability. The Kasese assistant chief administrative officer, Johnson Mutungwanda, said the district was developing an anti-corruption strategy based on good governance. He said the district would also establish a suggestion box and a corruption complaints desk. The deputy resident district commissioner, Wilson Isingoma, called on public servants to develop a sense of self-condemnation if graft is to be eliminated. "If the people in public offices do not fear involving themselves in corruption acts, the immoral practice will continue," he said. The officials wondered why the ministers implicated in the CHOGM scum were not being brought to book.

TITLE: Three Koboko Officials Held Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CITIES (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); CONSPIRACY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (69%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Three top officials of Koboko town council in Koboko district were on Monday arrested and detained at the district Police station for allegedly causing a financial loss of over sh10m. The Koboko district criminal investigations officer, Francis Olugu, on Tuesday confirmed that the town clerk, Emmanuel Banya, the finance officer, Tom Adriko, and the town council LC3 chairman, Joseph Banga, were detained. "We arrested them over a case of abuse of office, corruption, causing financial loss and conspiracy to defraud the Government," he said. Olugu said after thorough interrogation and provision of substantive sureties, Banga and Banya were released on police bond and their passports retained. He, however, said Adriko was still under custody because he refused to hand over his passport and had failed to produce sureties for him to be granted bond. Olugu said the Police in Koboko and the anti-corruption unit from Kampala acted following a tip-off from residents. "We acted swiftly to ensure none of them escaped and we were successful. We shall carry out more investigations to ensure that the three are produced in court," he added. It was, however, unclear Olugu said, how the stolen money was spent since the matter is still under investigation. Last week, three civil servants in Moyo district were also arrested in connection with stealing three government solar panels from Obongi health centre IV in 2007. Among the arrested were Sunday Madrwa, a store keeper in the health department, a community development officer, and Geoffrey Tako, a night watchman.

TITLE: Kigongo Advises New Party Members to Avoid Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (72%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The National Resistance Movement (NRM) vice-chairman, Al-Hajji Moses Kigongo, has advised members who have newly defected to the party not to be corrupt like some party officials. "Corruption is like a cancer you must avoid. We want disciplined people in the NRM. Without discipline, one loses respect," he said. Kigongo was last week receiving over 300 people who defected to the NRM a few days ahead of the party's grassroots elections in Alebtong and Lira districts. He cited the National Agriculture Advisory Services which used up a lot of government funds but no credible changes were attained in the lives of the expected beneficiaries due to corruption. In a letter read by Kigongo, President Yoweri Museveni urged willing independent politicians to join the NRM, saying they were a significant force in the 2006 elections. He directed local party leaders to register them in the yellow book (the NRM register) and allow them to compete for party offices. Among the defectors was the Lira district chairperson, Franco Ojur. Together with the woman MP, Rebecca Amuge Otengo, and three councillors from the district local government, Ojur signed a memorandum of understanding with the NRM party at the president's country home in Rwakitura.

TITLE: Donors Cut Aid Over Corruption
COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); EUROPE (92%); AFRICA (91%); NETHERLANDS (79%); GERMANY (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); NORWAY (79%); DENMARK (79%); BELGIUM (79%); AUSTRIA (69%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (69%)
SUBJECT: INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BUDGETS (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (77%); BANKING & FINANCE (75%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (74%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (70%); AUDITS (67%); MANAGEMENT THEORY (66%) Uganda; Europe and Africa; International Organizations and Africa; Aid and Assistance; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Donors have slashed aid to Uganda by at least 10%, citing government failure to address high-level corruption. A statement issued by a group of 11 development partners on Monday said the action follows conclusion of an appraisal of the Government's performance in 2008/2009. "The joint budget support development partners had originally planned to provide was $360m (sh773.4b) in form of budget support for the 2010/11 financial year. But based on the results of the appraisal, a number of partners have decided to reduce or re-programme their budget support contributions," the donors said. The donors that jointly finance Uganda's budget comprise the World Bank, the European Commission and the governments of Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Norway, Netherlands, Sweden and the United Kingdom. They expressed concern over the Government's failure to take action against several high-level corruption cases, especially the recommendations from the 2008 CHOGM audit reports. They were, however, satisfied with the Government's performance in macro-economic management during the global economic crisis. The donors agreed that the Office of the Prime Minister and the Ministry of Finance had shown strong leadership in pushing for government reforms. While the donors were impressed by the progress in the health, education and water sectors, they noted that performance was weak in the areas of compliance with public financial management principles, and civil service reform, which are critical for efficient service delivery. There were also not impressed by the results in the transport sector. The assessment for the 2009/10 fiscal year will be concluded by December.

TITLE: Corruption Court Halts Onegi Obel Case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAWYERS (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); PRIVATELY HELD COMPANIES (78%); CRIMINAL LAW (78%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (73%); HOLDING COMPANIES (69%); JOINT VENTURES (64%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Court has halted the trial of Geoffrey Onegi Obel, the former NSSF board chairman, accused of causing financial loss of sh8b. Magistrate Immaculate Busingye yesterday referred the case to the Constitutional Court for interpretation at the request of Obel's lawyer Ronald Oine. The lawyer wants the court to determine whether it was right to charge Onegi Obel under the Anti-Corruption Act, which came into force in 2009, yet the charges of abuse of office and causing financial loss he allegedly committed took place between 2003 and 2005. Oine also wants the Constitutional Court to decide whether it is proper for the Inspectorate of Government (IGG) to prefer charges against Onegi Obel when the Attorney General, in his opinion to the President, advised otherwise. Sydney Asubo, the head of prosecution from the IGG's office, said Obel can be charged under the Anti- Corruption Act and the Penal Code. Asubo said the Attorney General's opinion was not biding and that the IGG could still prosecute Obel. "This is a very serious question of law. I will not go ahead to take plea from the accused until the Constitutional Court has answered the question," Busingye said in her ruling. Justice John Bosco Katutsi, on August 23, dismissed the case against Obel after the IGG failed to appear in court. It was later reinstated. Obel is accused of floating an illegal company, Premier, and pushing NSSF to venture with another private company, Mugoya Estates, to build a housing estate. Under the project, 5,000 housing units were supposed to be built by Nsimbe Holdings, a joint venture between Mugoya and Premier. The IGG said the venture was illegal because it did not follow the procurement law.

TITLE: Poor Investigations Affect Corruption Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (88%); APPEALS (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (74%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%); TRENDS (70%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Although the anti-corruption court has struggled to complete 66% of the cases brought before it, most of them have been appealed against, which has delayed their conclusion, the acting principal judge, Opio Aweri, has noted. "The impact of the Anti-Corruption Court hasn't yet been felt in the public because most of the convictions meted out have been appealed against. When one appeals, the execution of the court orders are stayed until the appeal is disposed of," Aweri said. He was presenting a paper on the opportunities and limitations of the Anti-Corruption Court in fighting corruption in Uganda, during a one-day workshop organised by the Uganda Debt Network at Kampala University on Friday. However, the judge noted that the court had successfully disposed of 66% of the registered cases, completed 16 out of 25 criminal appeals, 330 out 384 criminal miscellaneous applications, 31 out of 116 corruption cases and all the 12 criminal revisions brought before it. He said the court business is also hampered by poor investigations, which affect the final outcome of the cases. "Most of the investigators and prosecutors need training in advanced techniques of investigation," Aweri added. He expressed concern that the country's global competitiveness for investment is taking a downward trend due to corruption, which has increased the cost of doing business. "Uganda is a signatory to the United Nations and African Union conventions against corruption. There is a possibility of invoking these conventions," Aweri warned. According to the World Bank report, Uganda loses $500m (sh1.1 trillion) to corruption every year. The anti-corruption division of the High Court was set up in July 2008 to handle corruption and corruption-related cases.

TITLE: Country's Corruption Endemic - American Professor
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); AFRICA (93%); UGANDA (92%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); HOTELS & MOTELS (54%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: A renowned US professor has described Uganda's corruption as endemic. "Corruption is now taken as an accepted way of life in Uganda. Low expectation of services facilitates corruption," said Eamon Michael Kelly. Kelly, who delivered a key- note address on Inaugural Integrity and the Challenge of National Transformation, said corruption in Uganda can be addressed with political will. The lecture, which was organised by ACLAIM Africa, was held at the Kampala Serena Hotel on Tuesday. "You need a top-down approach. For integrity to be in society, we have to start from the top leadership and come down," Kelly said. He said committed leadership and tough anti-corruption laws would solve the rampant corruption. Former ethics and integrity minister Miria Matembe said implicated corrupt officials should be tried and jailed.

TITLE: Corruption Watcdog Hails Cheeye Conviction
SUBJECT: JAIL SENTENCING (90%); EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); SENTENCING (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); APPELLATE DECISIONS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); AIDS & HIV TREATMENT (88%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (75%); APPEALS COURTS (73%); AIDS & HIV (72%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Transparency International Uganda has applauded the Court of Appeal for upholding the 10-year jail sentence of Teddy Sezi Cheeye for embezzling Global Fund money meant for HIV/AIDS treatment. The local civil society organisation, which advocates for a corruption-free society, however wants the Government to punish indiscriminately all those implicated in corruption. "It will not make sense if the likes of Cheeye and other junior officers are convicted when senior politicians, who have been implicated in grand corruption in various scandals like Global Fund and CHOGM are not brought to book," said Robert Lugoloobi, the organisation's boss. He added that they are yet to see serious efforts to prosecute the 'powerful' individuals who were implicated in the scandals. Lugoloobi noted that oversight institutions like the Directorate of Public Prosecutions, the Police and the Inspectorate of Government must investigate and cause prosecution of those who are implicated. Cheeye, the former director of International Security Organisation and a former head of economic monitoring in the President's office, was on Wednesday ordered to refund sh110m of the sh120m he got from the Global Fund on top of the 10-year jail term.

TITLE: Who Will Fight Corruption? [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); ETHICS (77%); RESEARCH REPORTS (72%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (71%); WRITERS (66%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: I have been listening to what the presidential candidates told the crowds that attended the rallies after the nominations. However, I was disappointed that the media focused on who had bigger crowds and the chaos that ensued, leaving out the most critical issues that the public wanted to hear or see. I was disappointed that the public was not given an opportunity to air out its views on what they expect to see in their candidates' manifestoes. A big number of Ugandans are poor. So, the candidates should focus on strengthening existing pro-poor programmes or initiate new ones that can benefit the poor and marginalised. Most of the problems people are facing now stem from the fact that they are poor and ignorant. Another big problem we face is corruption, which has deprived people of access to good quality services. According to the National Strategy to Fight Corruption and Rebuild Ethics and Integrity in Public Office 2007, corruption in Uganda has become endemic and systemic. The Annual Corruption Perception Index (CPI) of Transparency International shows that Uganda is among the top 10 most corrupt countries in the world and third most corrupt country in Africa. The reports published by the Inspectorate of Government indicate that corruption has become institutionalised to the extent that all public offices at central and local government level are involved in one form of corruption or another. A study by Uganda Debt Network found that at least sh200m is lost in corruption every year. A number of people in the villages till the land to produce extra food for sale, but cannot deliver their produce to the markets because of the poor state of their roads. Money meant to repair these roads has been swindled by government officials. It is now time for us, Ugandans, to task our leaders to showcase how they intend to fight corruption and strengthen the already existing legal and institutional framework for tackling corruption. The current government has shown commitment to fighting corruption and promoting zero tolerance against corruption but the efforts have been undermined by the actions of some leaders. The writer is a communications officer at the Uganda Debt Network.

TITLE: Leaders Decry Corruption in Police
SUBJECT: MAGISTRATES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JUDICIAL ETHICS (78%); ARRESTS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: LOCAL leaders in Busia district have described the Police as the most corrupt institution in the district. Meeting the judicial integrity committee in Busia Chief Magistrates' court on Monday, they said the Police had continued charging suspects money to be granted bond. "Are the Police in Busia not aware that getting a bond is one's constitutional right and should not be paid for?" asked Paul Ouma, the LC1 chairperson of Nangwe-Madibira village. He said some Police officers ask him to pay for bond whenever he goes to stand as a surety for suspects. Ouma added that the trend had made the community to think that it was legal to pay for it. "When our people hear that their loved ones have been arrested, the first thing that crosses their minds is where to get the money to have them released," Ouma said. He also said the Police should stop asking for facilitation to arrest suspects. The Busitema LC3 chairman, Tom Etaru Ekisa, proposed that the Police, like the Judiciary, should set up a committee to get the public's opinion on the conduct of its officers.

TITLE: Mbabazi, Matembe Clash Over Govt Anti-Corruption Efforts
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ETHICS (90%); ELECTIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); RELIGION (73%); ELECTION LAW (73%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (65%); HOTELS & MOTELS (57%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Security minister Amama Mbabazi, former ethics minister Miria Matembe and the assistant bishop of Kampala diocese, the Rt. Rev. Dr. Zac Niringye, have clashed over the Government's efforts to fight corruption. This was during the Integrity in Leadership debate at Imperial Royale Hotel on Friday. Matembe blamed the Government for what she called a lack of political will to fight corruption. "During my tenure as minister, we caught several 'big fish', but the Government was reluctant to punish them, instead choosing to reward them," she said. But Mbabazi said the Government had done its best to fight the vice. He cited the establishment of a legal framework and the anti-corruption court, a free press and parliamentary oversight committees where he said top government officials had been summoned. Mbabazi, however, said the Government lacked the capacity to investigate all corruption cases due to inadequate resources. Niringye said although Uganda put in place good anti-corruption institutions, they had become ineffective due to weak processes. Matembe and Niringiye asked the Government to review demands for a new independent Electoral Commission (EC) and the relevant electoral laws. Mbabazi, however, defended the EC, saying it had the capacity to organise free and fair elections next year.

TITLE: Corruption is Murder, Says Priest
SUBJECT: RELIGION (92%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); ELECTION FRAUD (88%) Uganda; Religion; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE Nebbi Catholic Diocese pastoral coordinator, Fr. Lino Opio, has described people who engage in corruption as murderers. He said the high level of corruption among Ugandans had spoiled the country and only prayer could repair it. "We only need prayers to save this country from corruption. Elections are coming. You will hear complaints of vote rigging everywhere," Opio said. He was addressing a congregation during mass in Nebbi Cathedral on Sunday.

TITLE: Corruption Body Advises Against Bribery
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BRIBERY (91%); POLITICS (90%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (74%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (73%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; NGOs and Civil Society
TEXT: THE international corruption watchdog, Transparency International, wants Ugandan voters to desist from receiving bribes from politicians seeking for votes in the ongoing election period. Martin Okumu, the board chairman of Transparency International Uganda chapter, told journalists on Tuesday that it was good that all presidential candidates have promised to address corruption in their manifestos. "The manifestos highlight that indeed there is a problem, but we would like the commitments to fight corruption to be translated into reality," Okumu said. He said Uganda's second election under a multiparty political system since 2006 offered an opportunity for Ugandans to express themselves and choose their leaders. "Its up to the people to decide to reject such offers. What is important is how you are going to decide the future of the country and elect a credible, honest person," Okumu said.

TITLE: Opposition Candidate Promises to End Corruption, Rigging
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (90%); ELECTION FRAUD (89%); ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POOR POPULATION (78%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (61%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (55%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A vote for change will end massive corruption in the country and usher in good governance that will end abject poverty, the Inter Party Co-operation (IPC) presidential candidate, Dr Kizza Besigye, has said. Besigye, while campaigning in Sembabule District yesterday, observed that the incumbent government no longer serves the interests of majority Ugandans but a few in the government. He claimed the leaders in government have prioritised self aggrandisement tainting the image of all leaders. "You are lucky Ssebabule District, the list of the wealthiest people in Africa has your MP Sam Kutesa on it. However, you are also one of the poorest districts on the continent," Besigye said. "He (Kutesa) comes here and tells you, 'vote for President Yoweri Museveni paka last (indefinitely).' Do you want to continue like this?" Besigye asked. The residents anwered, "no," then applauded amidst laughter. Besigye said the poverty levels in the country have been exacerbated by the poor infrastructure like gullied-dusty roads and absence or poor quality social services. He said the roads were so bad that President Museveni has resorted to flying around the country during the campaigns and official duty. Besigye promised to establish national food stores that will act as buffers to cushion the country from vagaries of weather and price stabilisation to benefit farmers. He said a minimum price would be set for farmers so that even when there's bumper harvest they don't sell off their goods so cheaply. Besigye rebutted talk that he had a personal vendetta against the President. "I know Museveni more than people who claim to be more Movement. I campaigned for Museveni in 1980 when he, as an UPM candidate contested against Kutesa for MP and lost. I went with him to the bush (as NRA) and was his doctor. I oppose him because he deviated from the mission of NRM," he explained. He said one of the major reasons why Museveni went to the bush to wage a guerilla war was because the 1980 elections were rigged. "Isn't there vote rigging now?" he asked.

TITLE: Ssegane's Corruption Case Adjourned
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); MAGISTRATES (88%); EMBEZZLEMENT (88%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (87%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (84%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A case in which former Kampala town clerk James Ssegane is jointly accused of embezzlement with the former director of finance has been adjourned to November 24. The move is to allow the Anti-Corruption Court Chief Magistrate, Irene Akankwasa, to make a ruling on whether the matter should be referred to the Constitutional Court. Ssegane's lawyers applied for the case to be referred, saying their client is being tried by two different courts on the same offences. Ssegane and his co-accused were tried by Buganda Road Court that dismissed the case in 2006.

TITLE: World Bank Boss Warns on Corruption, Poor Service Delivery
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (90%); ECONOMIC POLICY (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); ANNUAL REPORTS (76%) Uganda; International Organizations and Africa
TEXT: Poor service delivery in Uganda, caused by corruption, is a big blow to human development, the World Bank country representative, Kundhavi Kadiresan, has said. "Are the teachers available in schools? Are doctors there in health centres? These are micro-economic issues and if a country wants to compete globally, it should get its micro-economics right," Kadiresan said. She was speaking at the launch of the first annual report on corruption in Uganda compiled by the Economic Policy Research Centre, the Inspectorate of Government (IGG) and donor agencies. The report advises Uganda to review its judicial process in fighting corruption by, among others, adapting a 60-day timeline for prosecuting corruption cases. The new report approach, called data tracking mechanism, uses actionable indicators that track specific reform and policy changes to measure progress. Produced annually, the report will avoid the one-off studies that fail to track progress. Raphael Baku, the acting IGG, said the new approach will help determine whether the legal policy and anti-corruption institutions are bearing fruit. "The purpose is to measure corruption on actual terms, not based on perceptions," Baku said at the launch of the report in Kampala on Monday. Xavier Mugisha, a senior researcher at the Economic Policy Research Centre, said Uganda had the best institutions and anti-corruption laws but lacked implementation. He cited the Global Integrity Report 2009 that indicated that Uganda had a 99% good legal framework, but scored 45% on the implementation record. Kadiresan said statistics about Uganda's poor score on corruption were not new, but what was glaring was the lack of implementation of recommendations.

TITLE: Lubega Vows to Tackle Corruption
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (90%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (88%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (86%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (86%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (69%); MINIMUM WAGE (54%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Independent presidential candidate Samuel Lubega has promised to tackle corruption among government officials if he is elected. Lubega made the remarks while addressing hundreds of his supporters during a campaign rally held at Bugiri taxi park on Thursday. He said corrupt officials swindle the huge sums of money the Government receives from donors and taxes. "I will ensure that these officials who are making our people poor are put behind bars," he said. Lubega pledged to introduce a minimum wage for teachers to ensure that they do their work better. Lubega criticised universal primary education, saying most of the learners who go through the system could not effectively read or write. He said he would provide primary schools with scholastic materials like pencils and books to ensure pupils study comfortably. Lubega made the remarks during his campaign tour of Namayingo and Bugiri districts. Lubega also addressed rallies at Lubango landing site, Nankoma, Muterere, Mayuge trading centre and Kitodha.

TITLE: Buying Votes is Likely to Breed More Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (89%); PRIMARY ELECTIONS (78%); ELECTION LAW (78%); CORRUPTION (75%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (73%); BANKING & FINANCE (70%); INTEREST RATES (50%); ECONOMIC NEWS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: ONE of the biggest achievements of the NRM is the regular elections every five years at all levels of political offices. This gives the power to the people of Uganda to elect leaders of their choice. This power mandates the people to retain those leaders who are doing well or remove those who do not live up to their expectations. People exercise that power without undue influence of any kind, but their conviction that the leaders they choose will offer them social development services and security. Good choices go with provision of services like formulation of good laws, fair distribution of resources, human rights and allows the democratic process to grow. There is a strong need for the Government to sensitise Ugandans about their right and power to elect their leaders. This can easily be done through schools, the Ministry of Information and National Guidance and the Electoral Commission. Many Ugandans are not aware of what it means to have regular elections. Some voters take it as fun; others as a time to reap money and many candidates take it as a matter of life and death. They feel they must win at all costs. Because of such a situation, candidates who lose always oppose the results. This breeds violence and discontent and makes those who have lost in the primaries stand as independents. The vice of buying votes has weakened the electoral process. One can confidently say if one has no money to give out, he/she has no votes. For the poor, good and highly qualified candidates, if nothing is done, they will never see the corridors of power in Uganda. Voters complain that after electing their leaders, the leaders do not go back to the constituencies to account for their actions as elected leaders. They tint their car windows and drive at break-neck speed to avoid voters whom they do not even greet. They do not carry out development activities either. The voters, feeling annoyed and disappointed, promise to revenge by voting them out during the next elections. The elected leaders say they borrowed money from financial institutions or sold their property to contest in the highly competitive campaigns. The borrowed money usually carries high interest rates, so the leaders need time to get money to pay back or to replace the properties sold. That is why they do not go back to their constituencies because the voters will demand more money. It is common knowledge that nobody puts money where it will not make profit. Voters and campaign managers have also changed the style of campaigning. They feel very bad if a candidate goes through unopposed because they are denied a chance to "eat". Normally, they urge candidates to join the race, assuring them of strong support. They usually paint a picture that in their areas they are the ones who decide for others and then ask for big money to grease the campaigns. Afterwards many of them vote for opposing candidates. That is why a candidate might fail to get any votes at a polling station even when he or she has more than one agent at the station. It is true money is necessary in running campaigns. However, it should only be used to cater for the campaign teams' transport, refreshments and publicity. But if voters are paid to vote for a particular candidate, then they will never exercise the power to vote for a capable leader. It is important that any form of election must be free and fair so that people accept the results and those who lose elections do not feel cheated. For example, most of the candidates who lost in the party primaries contested the results, saying the elections were manipulated. More so, many losers in the party elections have threatened to stand as independents in the general elections in 2011. This is because they think they were not counselled or given a fair hearing. This is very dangerous because it means the party supporters will be divided, which might make other parties win. As a country, Uganda needs to sensitise both the voters and the candidates and discourage them from 'politics of money'. It is a bad trend, which will ruin the regular elections in our country. NRM promoter

TITLE: Gen. Tumwiine Applauds Opposition in Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); RELIGION (89%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (78%); CURRICULA (76%); ARRESTS (67%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: GEN. Elly Tumwine has applauded the opposition MPs for their joint effort with the National Resistance Movement (NRM) members in the fight against corruption that has taken root in the country lately. "I thank the opposition for working in unity with the NRM ruling party members to fight the vice. This is the unity we need if we want development in the country", Tumwine said. He was speaking at an empowerment Christian conference at the Christian Deliverance Ministries International church in industrial area. Tumwine, who is also an army representative in parliament, said he has already started a campaign group called 'Volunteers for Anti-Corruption Campaign Africa' (VACOCA) to help government monitor various projects, organizations, government institutions for accountability and transparency. He added that the campaign is not dependant on the budget and any member of the community with a mind set against corruption can join the campaign group. The campaign group has a syllabus teaching corruption and it trains its members in different sectors like corruption in schools, organizations, government and police. He said, "Most of these forces are set to fight corruption but it turns out that these same forces are corrupt themselves". He stated that it is never too late to make amends and do the right thing in a country were the pen is used as a tool for corruption in the government and work institutions. He said "It is amazing how someone can get a pen and sell his or her own country resources!" General Elly says the campaign is making progress because there is anger against corruption among the Ugandans and also the parliament and the anti-corruption court are reforming laws against corruption. He added that 26 individuals have been arrested in Apac district through this campaign against corruption. He quoted a scripture which says that "for all have sinned and run short of the glory of God" and encouraged members of parliament, different spiritual leaders and Ugandans to join the fight for corruption. "We are willing to partner with members of the community, government, churches, mosques and other civil organizations. Our role is to educate, we are not limited and we have a sustainable basis up to the end", He said.

TITLE: FDC Seeks Foreign Support in Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (90%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); LARCENY & THEFT (89%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); PRESS CONFERENCES (77%); APPOINTMENTS (76%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (76%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (71%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (70%); ENERGY & UTILITY REGULATION & POLICY (68%); LEGISLATION (67%); ARMED FORCES (60%); HELICOPTERS (50%); EMPLOYEE TERMINATION (50%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: FORUM for Democratic Change (FDC) party has called on the International Community to support Ugandans in the fight against the corruption to recover the stolen funds. Addressing a press conference at a party's weekly press briefing at the party headquarters in Najjanankubi yesterday, the party's publicity secretary, Wafula Oguttu said all international bodies and community should join in the fight to push government take on those involved. "Many government officials have been involved in various scandals but no action has ever been taken against them nor has the money been covered. As Ugandans we need to see President Yoweri Museveni fulfill his pledge to zero tolerance to the corruption," he said. Oguttu said bodies like Transparency International and the international community should join in the fight to help Ugandans to find, recover and repatriate all public funds that have been stolen and stashed away on foreign banks. He cited that in 1999, ministers Maj Gen. Jim Muhwezi and Sam Kuteesa were censured by Parliament for corruption related offences where billions of money were lost from ministry health. He added that in the same year former Vice President, Dr. Specioza Wandira Kazibwe was also implicated in valley dam scandal where sh4b had gone unaccounted for till to date while former minister Kirunda Kivejinja was also forced to resign for allegedly diverting to personal use 2,000 liters of fuel from Uganda Railways. Oguttu said instead of taking a serious action on the culprits, President Museveni absolved and reappointed the same people on promotion to his cabinet, where some have been implicated in other scandals. He said the President's failure to ask Prime Minister, Amama Mbabazi and internal affairs minister, Hilary Onek, to step aside pending investigation into there alleged involvement in the oil scam shows no will by government to fight corruption. Oguttu said this already shows that the ongoing investigations into the oil sector are also likely to come to a naught. He said President Museveni has not taken any decisive action on these cases, which has demoralized those in struggle. "His recent opposition to the proposed law for people to declare there wealth is enough to show that his talk on zero tolerance to corruption is just empty and clearly shows that government has no will to fight corruption," he added. He said besides corruption in cabinet, actors in cases such the 2003 ghost soldiers' scam in which sh1b was lost; loss of about sh3b on purchase of army uniforms, 1998 junk helicopters' scam, remain unpunished and neither money has ever been recovered. "Given government's failure to stem theft of public funds, we are calling on all people and civil society organizations to join Parliament in demanding government to take action, to recover all the stolen funds and have culprits punished," Oguttu said.

TITLE: Opposition Commends NRM MPs in Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); BRIBERY (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); POLITICS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (75%); HOTELS & MOTELS (68%); PRESS CONFERENCES (54%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: THE Rukungiri Municipality Member of Parliament, Roland Mugume Kaginda (FDC) has praised NRM party MPs for joining the opposition in the fight against corruption in the country. "The ninth parliament is working as a team in the fight against corruption regardless of the various political party affiliations and this is a big achievement for us to work as a team to fight this vice unlike in the past," Kaginda said. Kaginda, who is also the Rukungiri district Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) Party chairperson, dismissed the allegations that they were bribed to tarnish the names of the ministers involved in the oil bribery allegations as lies, saying God was behind the unity of NRM Party MPs and opposition to fight corrupt officials for the development of the country. Kaginda said this during a press conference at Grand Holiday Hotel in Mbarara town on Saturday. He added that they were not witch-hunting the ministers Amama Mbabazi, Hillary Onek and Foreign affairs minister, Sam Kahamba Kutesa involved in the oil bribery allegations but were in the interest of saving the nation against corrupt ministers. "Am surprised there are allegations that we are witch hunting them. I don't know Mbabazi and he is not my opponent or my voter, why should I fight him. We are working for the nation and let everyone carry their own cross. They should step aside and explain to the public how they were bribed and sold our oil." Kaginda said. He was optimistic that many NRM members will soon cross to the opposition side and follow former NRM strong cadres Col. Dr. Kiiza Besigye, Col. Amanya Mushega, Maj. Gen. Gregory Mugisha Muntu, all in FDC and others if the president continued protecting the corrupt ministers and other government officials. "I see the boat sinking if president Museveni keeps on protecting Amama Mbabazi, Kutesa and Onek in this matter, there is likelihood of NRM party members exodus joining opposition either FDC party or forming their own because they have seen enough," Kaginda explained. He called upon the president to fulfill his pledge of fighting corruption during the state of nation address for development of the country. "President Museveni called the public to join him in the fight against corruption and I want him to fulfill his pledge and leave the suspected corrupt officials to carry their own cross" he added. Vicent Mujuni Kyamadidi, the Rwampara county MP (NRM), also told New Vision on Sunday that he wants the president to distance himself from the ministers involved in oil bribery debate. "I respect President Museveni as my president and my party chairperson but I don't want him to protect the suspected corrupt ministers until their issues were resolved," Kyamadidi advised. Kyamadidi added that they were also investigating funds that were given to university leaders and student leaders from other institutions to organize demonstrations in support of the embattled ministers. That said, Police has decided to continue sensitizing the public although the battle seems far from over.

TITLE: Corruption Feared in Sh28 Billion HIV Deal
SUBJECT: AIDS & HIV (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (90%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); DIVESTITURES (78%); HEALTH CARE (74%); IMMUNOLOGIC FACTORS (72%); AIDS & HIV POLICY (72%); SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASE (72%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (69%) Uganda; HIV-Aids and STDs; Corruption
TEXT: The Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Authority (PPDA) has suspended a deal where about sh28.4b was to be paid for over 200 CD4 count machines that senior officials in the HIV campaign in the Ministry of Health say were not a priority in the HIV budget. The machines, which are used to measure the immunity of a person living with HIV, were supposed to be allocated to Health Centre IVs countrywide. But officials say the money should have been used to put more Ugandans on ARVs. However, the deal was stopped over allegations of corruption. Sources reveal that the National Medical Stores (NMS) recommended a bidder whose machines were deemed inferior and yet quoted a higher figure against the bidder with better ones that cost a lower amount. Complaints about the deal led to PPDA probe and eventual suspension of the transaction. In a letter of April 8, 2011, the health ministry acting permanent secretary, Dr. Asuman Lukwago, wrote to the NMS general manager, Moses Kamabare, requesting him to utilise the money that had been saved from the affordable medicine facility and purchase 200 CD4 machines. By press time, it had not been clarified whether this was the money that had been earmarked for putting more people on ARVs being diverted to buy less urgent machines. After the tendering process, the contracts committee awarded the deal to Alere HealthCare Services Limited on May 4, 2011. But one of the aggrieved bidders then, Biomedics Products, contested the award citing unfairness and sought an administrative review of the tendering process from PPDA. In the same month, PPDA instituted an investigation. In its 11-page report, PPDA boss Cornelia Sabiiti cited irregularities in the tendering process and ordered NMS to suspend the award of the deal that they had given to Alere. PPDA recommended that the deal be re-tendered using open international bidding method with a reduced bidding period from 33 to 21 working days. Alere and Partec Munster Germany submitted bids to supply the CD4 machines to Uganda to NMS. Alere, a South-African based company, was preferred as the best bidder but officials in the health ministry, who did not want to be mentioned given the sensitivity of their positions regarding the tender, questioned the approval. They argued that the machines that Alere was intending to import had 10% possibility to abort results. Documents seen by Saturday Vision show that Alere intended to import PIMA CD4 analyser machines that use cartridges while Partec wanted to import Partec CyFlow miniPOC CD4 machines which use reagents (antibodies). Documents also reveal that Alere quoted $3.47m (sh9b) for the supply while Partec quoted $2.6m (sh6.7b). This means government was going to spend sh2.3b more than what it would have spent on Partec's machines. This is the second time NMS is recommending Alere for the tender, an issue that has raised concern once again. Alere is a much younger firm, founded in 2001 and the PIMA machines that they intended to import were going to be used for the first time in Uganda. On the other hand, Partec was founded in 1967 and has imported dozens of CD4 machines into the country before, according to the company website. Sources revealed that the committee failed Partec because their machines were heavier. Partec's machine weigh 4.9kg including an inbuilt printer while Alere's weigh 2.54kg but without a printer which is supposed to be connected externally. With the printer, the Alere machine could weigh the same as the Partec machine. Specifications also show that Alere's Pima CD4 machine has about 10% possible cases of aborted results, while the Partec machine does not abort results. "The Partec machine takes one minute to test a patient compared to 20 minutes that Alere's machine takes. Additionally, the Partec machine takes up to 250 patient samples a day compared to Alere's 20. Considering the four tests per patient annually, a Partec machine covers 12,500 patients compared to 1,000 patients covered by Alere's machine in a year," a source noted. Documents also show the Alere machine has a capacity to store data of 1,000 tests while the Partec machine stores data of over 20,000 tests. With a Partec machine, the price of a single test is 3 Euros (sh10,500) while for Alere's machine it goes at between 6-8 Euros (sh21,000 - sh28,000). Earlier, the AIDS Control Programme manager, Dr Zainab Akol, told stakeholders in the fight against HIV at Golf Course Hotel that money budgeted for putting people living with HIV on free ARVs had been diverted to purchase CD4 count machines. The meeting noted that it was a bad decision because what the country needed more was to increase people on treatment than the CD4 count machines. Research shows that access to HIV treatment results in a 96% reduction in the risk of HIV transmission through sex. Not only do ARVs improve quality of life, they also reduce the infectiousness of the HIV positive person. Akol said the Government is still relying on foreigners to treat our people. She said she was working hard to add 30,000 more people on free ARVs. Apparently, such diversion of money must be frustrating. "Currently Uganda only gives free ARVs to less than 50% of the people who need them. Why should we divert money for more ARVs to buying CD4 machines we don't really need urgently?" a senior person in HIV control at the ministry of health asked. The acting health ministry permanent secretary, Dr. Asuman Lukwago, said the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL) was the one that recommended Alere's Pima CD4 machine. Tom Tenywa, the laboratory coordinator for the AIDS control programme at CPHL, confirmed that they recommend medical equipment for use in the country to the health ministry. Asked why they had recommended the PIMA CD4 machine, Tenywa, a senior laboratory technologist, refused to comment. "I cannot tell you that. It is the ministry of health which is better placed to give you that information. Our duty is to recommend on technical grounds." CPHL is the technical arm of the health ministry charged with ascertaining whether medical equipment is fit for use in the country. It is on CPHL's recommendation that the health ministry approves or rejects medical equipments. Lukwago says the deal was granted to Alere because the ministry's set specifications pointed to the ones that the company had presented. Asked why they chose a company that does not test children below seven years, Lukwago said there was already the Early Infant Diagnosis programme funded by the Clinton Foundation which was recently rolled out in the country to cater for children. "We recommended Alere over Partec which had a cheaper quotation because in procurement, there are other variables, apart from cost. Value for money does not mean you select the cheapest bid. You may go for low price and get poor quality products." He, however, said NMS was independently in charge. "NMS is a self-accounting agency and they report directly to PAC (Public Accounts Committee) of parliament although we sometimes supervise them," Lukwago explained. However, NMS General Manager, Moses Kamabare, refused to comment. But earlier, he had been quoted in the media saying Alere had the specifications that the health ministry wanted.

TITLE: Corruption - Enough Is Enough
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); BUDGETS (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (75%); EVIDENCE (74%); SCANDALS (73%); ARRESTS (70%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (65%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: As we commemorate the Anti-Corruption Week running upto December 9, a lot has happened in Uganda this year. Prior to elections, MPs received sh20m each into their accounts purportedly for monitoring government projects in their constituencies, which happened immediately after they passed a huge supplementary budget at the peak of the election campaign. Many concerned citizens termed this transaction as a bribe prompting some MPs to return the money. Former Vice-President Prof. Gilbert Bukenya was arrested for his role in CHOGM Motorcare deal that resulted into loss of billions of public funds. Ministers have taken leave following summons by the Anti-corruption court, while local government ministry officials have been suspended after their alleged involvement in a scam leading to loss of billions of shillings meant for procuring bicycles for local council members. There is also the alleged bribery in the oil sector which is now a subject of investigations. This has triggered off a public debate on whether the documents implicating the ministers were forged or not. All these are indicators of a society riddled with corruption. In some of the findings of a study carried out by Transparency International Uganda, a cross-section of people argue that if a corrupt official embezzled money and used it to develop their area, that is considered fine compared to the one who selfishly takes it all for himself. But also the public is to blame because they have time and again brought back these corrupt officials to public offices by voting them, and they hardly hold them accountable for their actions. We should always advocate transparency in all public dealings. If I might ask, what happened to those implicated in the GAVI and Global Fund scandals, with the exception of the few? Was this money paid back? Now that the Global Fund has run out of money for funding developing countries until 2014, what steps is the Government taking to ensure that drugs are available? I was at a workshop recently and Dr Diana Atwine, the head of medicines and health services monitoring unit in the office of the President, raised an important issue that, whereas she has implicated many health officials on corruption, the weak laws have frustrated her efforts and as a result those implicated are not tried/punished. She blamed the Uganda Law Reform Commission for the weak laws in our country. Such weak laws discourage whistle blowers, who fear being victimised unlike MPs who are protected from prosecution for any utterance while in a parliamentary session. Corruption at health centres and at the district level is adversely undermining effective delivery of health services to the rural poor, who need them and nothing much is being done to address the issue. Most importantly, those implicated in corruption should be forced to refund the money so that it is put to rightful priorities. President Yoweri Museveni has, time and again, advocated zero tolerance to corruption though less has been done to demonstrate commitment to that effect. There is a dire need to address impunity and guarantee sovereignty of courts by all stakeholders. The Government, Civil Society Organisations and the public should come up and fight corruption out of our society and it is every citizen's duty as per Article 17(d) and (i) of the Ugandan Constitution to fight the vice. The writer is a Communications officer, Transparency International Uganda

TITLE: Country May Be Unfairly Judged On Corruption - IGG [interview]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INTERVIEWS (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TRENDS (77%); EMBEZZLEMENT (73%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (71%); POLLS & SURVEYS (69%); HIGHWAY FUNDING (64%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (62%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (62%); ECONOMIC NEWS (51%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Today is the International Anti-Corruption Day. In Uganda, the main arm of government that fights corruption is the Inspectorate General of Government. Joshua Kato caught up with the Inspector General of Government (IGG) and below is what he said. Answer: It may not be true that Uganda is one of the most corrupt countries in the world, because Transparency International, which is at the fore front of producing these reports uses perception rather than concrete evidence. And because it is perception, even increased efforts to fight against corruption may be confused for increased incidences of corruption. At the moment for example, Parliament is talking about corruption, all radio talk-shows are about corruption and yet this was not the case before. However, discussing corruption and improving the means by which corrupt tendencies may not necessarily mean actual increase of corruption in the country. It is difficult to describe the level of corruption in Uganda because we are yet to develop a tool that can carry out specific gauging. We depend on the National Survey where we get reports from house-holds, individuals, private and public personalities, which all depends on perception. It is difficult to confirm whether corruption is decreasing or increasing if you are using such system. However, the Economic Policy Research Centre, Makerere recently helped us develop a Data Tracking Mechanism that we are now using to generate reports on corruption using constant indicators so that we can monitor the trends of corruption and get an answer whether it is increasing or decreasing. Here we ask people who have been directly been confronted by corruption. We ask them who the main subject was and that is how we determine basing on the most mentioned institution. In the last report (released in November this year) the areas that were covered included Education, Health and Law Enforcement. However, there was criticism that we should have focused on more institutions. And according to the Data Tracking Mechanism, it showed that corruption was increasing in the targeted sectors, compared to previous years. In most of Europe, only bribery is considered as corruption under the law. In Uganda, the situation is different. The Anti-corruption Act has got at least 20 cases that are considered as corruption tendencies. For example, while abuse of office, negligence of duty, embezzlement of funds, direct bribery, absence from work etc are all chargeable before the law as corruption cases. And because the Uganda Anti-corruption Act has got more listed corruption tendencies, this increases the chances of a case being reported. For example, some body may see a poorly constructed road and he concludes that the engineer must have eaten something hence the shoddy work. However, in actual sense it may be that the engineer was only lazy and did not carry out proper and effective supervision of the road works before he certified it. But the general feeling may be that he must have taken a cut. It is a major concern now, both internationally and locally. Corruption fuels other crimes, for example drug abuse and money laundering, trafficking of arms etc. It is obvious that for one person to move drugs he must have engaged some other person in a corruption tendency. Diverting national resources that are intended for development work has fuelled misery amongst the population because it affects service delivery. Corruption breeds conflicts too. For example, the current conflicts in the Arab world were caused by perceived corruption on the side of the leaders. This is why we need to focus and fighting the evil called corruption. We have had more cases reported than in previous years. We have also had more cases investigated and prosecuted than in previous years. For example in 2010, we successfully took to court 35 cases and of these we won 28, loosing just 7 cases. Comparatively, in 2009, we successfully concluded only one case, 10 in 2008 and so far 17 in 2011. One of the reasons more cases are being reported is the creation of the Whistle Blowers Act. We are getting more people reporting to us as Whistle Blowers, which is good. However, the act needs to be further taken down to the lowest people. The office of the IGG is independent, therefore there is no direct interference. However, in some cases were the subjects of investigations are politicians, the cases are politicised. Most of them claim publically that they are being prosecuted for political reasons. Surprisingly, however, none of them uses the 'political persecution' phrase in the courts as a defence. The entire process of receiving reports from reporters and whistle blowers, carrying out investigations and going to court is selective in nature. We receive more cases than what we can effectively investigate and at the end of the day, refer some of them to other bodies like the PPDA and Public Service. When we undertake cases, we have to prioritise them using several measures. For example, what will be the impact of the case to the public? Has the case got enough evidence to help us win it? Then depending on the results of the investigations, we decide on whether to go to court or not. People who complain that we are doing selective prosecution are mainly those who want certain people prosecuted because they perceive them to be thieves and yet they cannot come out with clear evidence to help us do so. The human resource base and the financial base are both low and yet corruption is widespread around the country. For example, we have this head office here, and 16 regional offices across the country. But compared to 112 districts, it means that each office is in charge of at least eight districts which is too high. The human resource that we have is not sufficiently trained to handle investigations. The public does not also take corruption seriously until it directly affects them.

TITLE: Corruption Blamed On Lack of Funds, Citizens Glorifying Vice
COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%); KENYA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (98%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); SCANDALS (89%); BRIBERY (89%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (86%); PRIVATIZATION (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (77%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); BUDGETS (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (71%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (71%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: More resources need to be made available to the anti-corruption agencies if the vice of corruption is to be wiped out of the country, Bishop Zac Niringiye, the chairperson of the African Peer Review Mechanism national governing council says. He argues that inadequate resources and funding of especially the Auditor General's office, the Inspectorate of Government and the Criminal Investigations Department has failed all effort in the fight against corruption in the country. Niringiye says according to documentary evidence, corruption is most rife in procurement, privatisation, administration of public expenditure and revenue and in the delivery of public services.
