This week from Dec 5-9 is the time when the world is celebrating the International corruption week, and the theme for this year is 'Act against corruption Today.' The celebrations are spearheaded by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and the United Nations Development programme (UNDP). Yesterday, local civil society and other movements all over the country against corruption celebrated as the culmination of the CSO national anti-corruption week celebrations. The World Bank estimates that Uganda loses over sh500b per year to corruption. (4th October 2010) Recently Transparency International an NGO in ensuring transparency in the world ranked Uganda the 33rd most corrupt country in the world. This ranking comes a time when the country is battling out corruption scandals especially CHOGM and oil. Apart from these scandals much has happened in the previous years, with the most pronounced being incidents such as MPs receiving sh20m each into their accounts purportedly for monitoring government projects in their constituencies, which happened immediately after they passed a huge supplementary budget at the peak of the election campaign. For the public this transaction was termed as a bribe and some MPs were prompted to return the money. According to a study by transparency International in Kenya on the East African countries, the vice is common because the public have failed to report corrupt people to the authorities. According to this study, the propensity to bribe and not report corruption cases fell from 64% in 2008 to 56% in 2009 in East Africa. In Tanzania only 8% of the bribery incidents were reported; indicating a lack of public confidence in the institutions which are supposed to address such complaints. In Uganda the reporting pattern was quite low with 70% of those who paid bribes failing to report the incidents. The top reasons given for not reporting bribery were a lack of faith that any action would be taken and a fear of intimidation. Despite efforts by the media in highlighting corruption scandals in the country the vice has continued taking its routes into society. The New Vision in particular has published stories on corruption as they occur. On August 18, 2009 The New Vision published an article titled 'Police officers held over receiving bribe' but the practice has remained as the police force is ranked the most corrupt institution in the country. On December 4, The New Vision published an article 'corruption feared in sh28b HIV deal'. Others stories like the follow up of the case against the Former Vice-President Prof. Gilbert Bukenya for his role in the CHOGM Motorcare deal that resulted into loss of billions of public funds have always been the lead stories of the paper. These and many other stories have been published, but not much has changed. The vice still goes on. Many local government officials have lost their jobs following their alleged involvement in the bicycle saga that led to loss of billions of shillings meant for procuring bicycles for local council members. Many scholars argue that the vice has been so pronounced in society because corrupt people are uplifted in the country. Findings of a study carried out by Transparency International Uganda, indicates that a cross-section of people say if a corrupt official embezzled money and used it to develop their area that is considered fine compared to the one who selfishly takes it all for himself. This act is glorifying the corrupt. The public here has a role to play and the leaders themselves according to Eunice Musiime the programme coordinator policy at the Uganda National NGO Forum. "The motivation for graft is largely for leaders to maintain themselves in office and they generate their resources for self-preservation through corruption," she says. She says the public is to blame for time and again they vote back corrupt officials into public offices. The public also hardly holds its leaders accountable for their actions. Many have blamed the Uganda Law Reform Commission for the weak laws in our country. They argue that such weak laws discourage whistle blowers, who fear being victimised unlike MPs who are protected from prosecution for any utterance while in a parliamentary session. According to the APRM 2009 review report, Niringiye argues that Uganda has the best and programmes to promote development, but all have failed due to corruption, among other factors. Government Institutions have been seen on many occasions trying to solve the vice by arresting those implicated, but all efforts are futile as no money swindled by the corrupt has been recovered. Recently the Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Authority (PPDA) suspended a deal where about sh28.4b was to be paid for over 200 CD4 count machines that senior officials in the HIV campaign in the Ministry of Health say were not a priority in the HIV budget. The machines, which are used to measure the immunity of a person living with HIV, were supposed to be allocated to Health Centre IVs countrywide. But officials say the money should have been used to put more Ugandans on ARVs. This is one of those effort of the anti-corruption institutions in the country. As Uganda struggles to end the vice others argue that advocating transparency in all public dealings might save the nation from this vice. They suggest that if all those implicated in the Global Fund scandals are punished corruption would not be taken for granted in society. For the CHOGM scandal many were implicated, but only one person has been placed before the court of law to answer charges. Tough measures on those implicated in corruption cases should be taken. Measures like forcing them to refund the money so that it is put to its rightful use. The Government, civil society organisations and the public need to join hands and fight corruption. It is every citizen's duty as per Article 17(d) and (i) of the Constitution to fight the vice.

TITLE: Corruption Scandals - Lwanga Calls for Calm
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); RELIGION (91%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (90%); SCANDALS (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); ENERGY SHORTAGES (87%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); EMBEZZLEMENT (73%); BRIBERY (73%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Kampala Archbishop Dr. Cyprian Lwanga has called on Ugandans to remain calm in the wake of mounting revelations of corruption. Dr. Lwanga was speaking at a ceremony in which 22 nuns of the Order of Good Samaritan Sisters took their vows at Mapeera House in Nalukolongo, a Kampala suburb. "It is with no doubt Ugandans are following events transpiring in Parliament," said the cleric, hinting on the recent debates in the House as regards bribery allegations and embezzlement. "Part of these debates will help Ugandans have an idea of what is going on in their Government and the country at large." Dr. Lwanga cited corruption scandals and the controversial proposed Public Order Management Bill as some of the highlights that can breed disorder in the community and country at large. He urged all people in their various capacities to fight corruption, which he described as a 'cancerous disease'. He advised the people to emulate the Good Samaritans by starting to help each other and subsequently stop fighting amongst themselves. At the same event, Mbarara diocese retired Bishop John Baptist Kakubi lamented the persistent power load-shedding, saying it caused numerous problems in the country. Kakumbi blamed government for failure to solve such problems for a long a time and urged Umeme to reduce on the load-shedding hours so as to curb the problem of thieves terrorizing innocent people. "Deceitful people use the cover of darkness when power goes off to mug people at night and steal their valuables," the retired cleric explained. He warned that the persistent rationing of electricity is likely to cause more chaos among disgruntled electricity users. At the ceremony, four nuns made their first vows while nine others made their final ones, vowing to observe celibacy, poverty and obedience in compliance with the doctrines of the Catholic Church. The other nine marked 25 years spent as members of the Order. The event was graced by Emmanuel Cardinal Wamala, Bishop of Masaka diocese John Baptist Kaggwa, Bishop of Kiyinda-Mityana Joseph Anthony Zziwa, retired Bishops of Hoima and Fort-Portal, Edward Albert Baharagate and Paul Kalanda, respectively, and Msgr. Mathias Kanyerezi who represented Bishop of Luweero Paul Ssemwogerere.

TITLE: Museveni Warns On Corruption
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); POLITICS (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (89%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (87%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (87%); ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS (86%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); TALKS & MEETINGS (79%); EXECUTIVES (79%); ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY (78%); BUDGETS (78%); DAMS & RESERVOIRS (76%); ENERGY & UTILITY REGULATION & POLICY (75%); BANKING & FINANCE REGULATION (75%); HEALTH CARE SECTOR PERFORMANCE (74%); ENERGY & UTILITY SECTOR PERFORMANCE (74%); HYDROELECTRIC POWER (69%); HYDROELECTRIC POWER GENERATION (69%); ENERGY SHORTAGES (69%); DAM & HYDROELECTRIC CONSTRUCTION (68%); ELECTRICITY TRANSMISSION & DISTRIBUTION (64%); POSTWAR RECONSTRUCTION (63%); HOTELS & MOTELS (57%) Uganda; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: President Yoweri Museveni has urged accounting officers in Government institutions to resist the pressures of some corrupt politicians and defend public money. Speaking at the closure of the two-day annual cabinet retreat at Victoria conference hall at Serena Hotel on Tuesday, Museveni told Permanent Secretaries, Chief Administrative Officers, Town Clerks, and Sub-County Chiefs not to succumb to any pressure. "You are the gate-keepers of the people's money. You should protect it because you are protected by the laws and the constitution," Museveni is quoted as having according to a statement issued last evening. The closed meeting was attended by ministers, permanent secretaries, district chairpersons and CAOs. It was meant to discuss and review government performance in the last financial year and chart a way forward for the next fiscal year. According to the State House release, the President also urged ministers to use their proximity to fellow Members of Parliament "and work closely with them so as to make government work easy, harmonious and efficient." The statement said President Museveni predicted that Uganda's economy will grow faster and perform better than it has been after overcoming what he referred to as "a decade of economic sabotage by the political class." "He noted that it was not surprising that the country's economy has been growing slowly having experienced sabotage in the electricity sector, more reliance on foreign funding and budgetary support and experienced a long spell of insecurity in some parts of the country," the statement said. "The President said that the country's economy suffered at the hands of political saboteurs especially those who delayed the construction of the Bujagali hydro power project affecting growth in economic areas that require power to survive." "He however, said that this will be overcome since the dam will start generating power in April next year. He said that on top of that, government has a Marshall plan to build more power dams in the country and also considering other sources of power to have a lasting solution to the problem of the shortage of electricity." According to Museveni, the above arrangement in place coupled with the prevailing peace in the entire country and the reduced reliance on foreign funding, Uganda's national the economy will grow in double digits. Consequently, Museveni tasked his Cabinet, "to always take the trouble and use the largely available mass media and explain these pertinent issues to the public because the citizens are owed accountability from leaders." The President is said to have proposed increased investment in science and technology and better remuneration for scientists. He also proposed increased investment in the health sector so as to save the estimated US$150m that Ugandans spend annually on treatment abroad. The statement also quoted Museveni as recommending that "government should make it a taboo to have scarcity of essential commodities" and said that once detected, solutions should be found quickly and without hesitation. He cited the failure by government to find a quick solution to sugar scarcity which has of recent cost the country US$40 million to import the commodity. Meanwhile, the executive made several recommendations at the end of the retreat. Some of the action points include putting a stop on supplementary budget requests because they negatively impact on budget execution and performance. A special contingency fund will instead be provided for in the next budget to cater for eventualities. The ministers also agreed to undertake a review of local governments funding and guidelines because much of the money never reaches to the common man. The meeting also agreed on the need to beef-up staffing in the local governments from the current 55% to 75% for better service delivery. On complaints from district chairmen over declining funding from the central government, the cabinet agreed to undertake a comprehensive review of sources of revenue for local governments. As part of the solutions to the high fuel prices, it was agreed that Jinja fuel storage tanks be refurbished for storage of reserve fuel which can save the nation in times of scarcity.

TITLE: Catholic Church Slams Corruption, Bad Laws
SUBJECT: RELIGION (94%); CORRUPTION (92%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (91%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (90%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (90%); ARRESTS (90%); CORRECTIONS (89%); VEHICULAR OFFENSES (89%); DRIVER BEHAVIOR (87%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); ORGANIZED CRIME (78%); SEX OFFENSES (76%); MURDER (76%); DOMESTIC OFFENSES (76%); DOMESTIC VIOLENCE (71%); TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS (71%); BAIL (65%) Uganda; Religion; Corruption
TEXT: The Archbishop of Kampala Diocese Dr. Cyprian Kizito Lwanga has criticized corruption, human rights violation and bad laws saying they do not augur well with the message of peace, justice and reconciliation brought by Christmas. "The absence of peace and justice can pave way to corruption which is so rampant in our country, domestic violence and sexual violence, mob justice, murder, uncontrolled road accidents, land grabbing etc... because we lack the spirit of love for another which deters the advocacy for the common interest," he said. He added: "If people continue to pursue their own interest, then also our country will continue to fall apart. There is a public outcry of dissatisfaction where weak are oppressed socially, morally and politically. The few who have such powers in their hands may not seem to be sensitive to the plight of the majority who seem to be craving for the help, but in vain." Dr. Lwanga made the remarks at a news conference held at his residence in Rubaga a Kampala suburb. Delivering his Christmas message, Lwanga called for political reconciliation and condemned violence. He, however, hailed the ninth Parliament for its stand against corruption and urged MPs not to give up with the fight against corruption. Commenting about the brutal arrest of a catholic priest over reckless driving, Lwanga condemned the manner in which the priest was arrested and bundled onto police pick up like a chicken thief. Police on Tuesday arrested a priest suspected to have knocked dead a police-man near River Katonga on the Kampala- Masaka road. He was charged with reckless driving and remanded to Buwama prison but was granted bail by Grade 1 Magistrate Catherine Agwero the following day. Bishop Lwanga said the priest was accused for a crime he did not commit. "I talked to the priest and he explained that he was not the driver of the ill-fated car. None the less his stint in prison helped him know the appalling conditions in prison," Lwanga said.

TITLE: President Al-Bashir Calls for Establishment of Commission for Transparency and Combating of Corruption to be Formed from Civil Society Organizations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (74%); RULE OF LAW (72%)
TEXT: Khartoum, Feb. 3 (SUNA)- President of the Republic, Field Marshal Omer Al-Bashir, has affirmed establishment of a commission for transparency and combating corruption, stressing the keenness of the government to apply the punishment on any one who is convicted in a corruption case, and referred to the steps adopted by the government in this respect. Interviewed by the Blue Nile TV, Al-Shirouq TV, the National TV and the Sudanese Radio Friday evening, President Al-Bashir said that any who has evidence on corruption of any official shall provide this evidence to the concerned authorities, stressing that no one is exempted from the rule of law. He said that any official in the state is obliged to present a declaration of wealth, indicating that these are around 90,000 declarations of wealth at the Attorney General. President Al-Bashir said that the number of cases of violation against public money, according to the report of the General Auditor, were 39 cases, and the violated fund was 5.208 million pounds.

TITLE: Political will needed to fight corruption in government
COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); NIGERIA (93%); HONG KONG (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); PAPUA NEW GUINEA (79%)
ORGANIZATION: WORLD BANK GROUP (55%); INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORP (55%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (88%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); WOMEN (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); BANKING & FINANCE (76%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (76%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (76%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (73%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (73%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (72%); AUDITS (72%); RELIGION (50%)
TEXT: WITHOUT the political will to fight corruption, a government's legislative or executive branch might block systems and organisations put in place to hold people in public life accountable. "If there's no political will to fight corruption, you're just wasting time," said Ngozi Okonjo Iweala, former Nigerian minister of finance and foreign affairs. She was addressing the week-long Vital Voices Pan-African Leadership Summit for Women and Girls which opened in the city yesterday. "To begin to even fight it and get people to believe something is going to happen, you have to make information available (to civil society)," she added. Iweala described the publication in Nigeria of the government's revenue sources as well as officials' salaries and expenses as a "powerful force" in combating corruption. Corruption, when it existed, was often embedded in a country's economy, so fighting it was an "integral part of development efforts", she said. A neglected subject was the role developed countries played in fostering corruption in developing countries: demand from developed countries was fuelling supply in developing countries. Meg Taylor, compliance adviser/ombudsman for the International Finance Corp-oration/World Bank Group, said that in her country - Papua New Guinea - a leadership code had been set up by an ombudsmen commission. All members of parliament and those who held constitutional office were forced to sign the code. If they breached it, they could be recommended for dismissal by the commission. She added that, in Hong Kong, if a member of parliament was seen to be living beyond his or her means, the independent commission against corruption there had the power to seize that individual's financial records and investigate. Former assistant administrator for the United States Agency for International Development, Sally Shelton Colby, described the "citizen charter" pioneered by the British and Indian governments to provide services at the highest quality and lowest possible cost to the public. If such service was not received, there was a mechanism for people to complain. She also emphasised the importance of a non-political and modern audit system. Archbishop Njongonkulu Ndungane, founder of Africa Monitor set up to monitor aid to Africa and what local governments do with the money, said accountability and transparency was most effective when there was "mass ownership of development".

TITLE: Moves to let prisons' watchdog body put bite on corruption
SUBJECT: CORRECTIONS (93%); PRISONS (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (78%)
TEXT: THE Ministry of Correctional Services could consider extending the prisons oversight body's powers to include investigating corruption, in a department persistently dogged by scams. Answering a question from the Cape Times during a parliamentary briefing, Deputy Correctional Services Minister Loretta Jacobus said they were willing to consider broadening the mandate of the Judicial Inspectorate of Prisons, whose powers are currently restricted to investigating conditions inside jails. "I think as a department we would be amenable to look at that, but it should be the result of the outcome of a public process ..." she said. The report of the Jali Commission, which investigated corruption in the department, noted that the inspectorate was merely a reporting body and that, internationally, oversight bodies had much greater legitimacy if they also had decision-making powers. Judge Thabani Jali suggested that a prisons ombudsman should be established to investigate corruption. Last year, the National Assembly's correctional services committee said it would debate this suggestion. However, the head of the Judicial Inspectorate of Prisons, Judge Nathan Erasmus, warned against overloading the body with too much responsibility. Judge Erasmus said that while the inspectorate could not investigate corruption, Correctional Services had instead enlisted Willie Hofmeyr's special investigating unit to probe corruption in prisons. The Jali Commission report highlighted chronic corruption in the Department of Correctional Services. Jacobus said the report was not being ignored. "Even before the submission of the ... report and subsequent making public thereof, we had Correctional Services set up an anti-corruption unit which was headed by our former commissioner. The work in that unit is ongoing, looking into corruption generally within the department, but also looking at the implementation of the ... report," he said.

TITLE: No joy for Zuma as state vacillates on corruption charge
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); EXECUTIVES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); LITIGATION (75%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (75%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (74%); INJUNCTIONS (69%)
TEXT: DURBAN: The state has ducked a challenge by ANC deputy president Jacob Zuma to say whether it intends to prosecute him on corruption charges, saying it is "impossible to predict". In the ongoing exchange of papers between the government, Zuma and his former co-accused, French company Thint, in the legal wrangle over documents being held in Mauritius, Zuma said he was "entitled to know" if and when he would be charged again. But in his reply, Scorpions investigating officer Isak du Plooy says only: "I can confirm that no decision has been taken regarding the prosecution ... It is impossible to predict when a decision will be made." The matter is expected to be argued in the Pietermaritzburg High Court on March 22. At issue are several documents being held under court injunction in Mauritius, which the state believes are crucial to the prosecution of Zuma and Thint. They include the diary of Alain Thetard, Thint's former SA chief executive, which allegedly notes a meeting between him, Zuma and Zuma's former financial adviser, Schabir Shaik, in March 2000. The state contends that it was at this meeting that the bribe by Thint to Zuma was brokered. This, and other documents were seized in raids on Thint's Mauritian offices in 2000. Copies were made which were later used at Shaik's trial. In the interim, Thint secured a court order in Mauritius, preventing their disclosure to any other party. The state has made use of the International Co-operation in Criminal Matters Act to make the application for a judge to issue a letter of request to the Mauritian attorney-general for the originals of the documents, "for further investigation".

TITLE: facing crime and corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); THEATER & DRAMA (89%); CORRECTIONS (89%); THEATER (89%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (79%); DRAMA LITERATURE (78%); WRITERS (77%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (62%)
TEXT: Crime and corruption and the way it is destroying people's hopes and dreams is the subject of a new play touring the Western Cape this week. Written and directed by Thami Mbongo, the work is called Things are Bad - or in Xhosa, Ijumpile lendaba. "It tells the story of how young men get together and how this escalates into crime which gets even more serious when the police become involved. The men then get involved with the notorious numbers gangs," explains Maurice Podbrey, the producer, on behalf of the Canadian-funded Mopo Cultural Trust. Says Mbongo, a UCT graduate: "For me, I read every day about crime in our townships and too much about police and our government and this while we are waiting to hear who our next leader is going to be. "What is the government going to do about crime and corruption? I thought it would be a good idea to put all these things in a play, so that the play would open up discussions about all the people involved. So that people can ask themselves what role they can play to put a stop to crime." Mbongo says his play is not anti-government or anti-ANC. "The point," Podbrey says, "is what are the people in power doing about crime and corruption? "The people who put them there must recognise what's happening," Podbrey adds, saying that a discussion has been held after every show. "The response (from township audiences has been great, with the play being performed in 'tsotsitaal', Xhosa, Afrikaans and English, depending in which area we're performing, from Khayelitisha to Ocean View," Mbongo says. "The play is not so much about the 'number' gangs inside the prisons, but rather about the ex-prisoner who, after he is released, sees his family doing well, being successful, but all he has is his 'number'." Mbongo explains that people come to the play because it reflects what they have to deal with every day. Significantly, as opposed to television, the theatre experience allows them to discuss the issues raised. It would also be good Mbongo says, to have the so-called role players, such as prison warders, politicians and officials as well as policemen coming to the performances. Podbrey adds that it would be "marvellous" to have the play performed inside prisons. A central theme in the play, Mbongo explains, is the idea of individuals taking responsibility for their lives, and not pandering to the expectations placed on them, effectively looking at the negative effects of peer pressure on the youth. "Young people think it's cool to be involved in crime, but they don't know what life is like in prison,"the playwright says. "Also, young people in townships tend to think what other people expect of them and they do things to please others. "Instead one has to sit down and ask oneself 'what do I really want in life'." After the run with this production, Mbongo will go to Denmark, hosted by the Danish government, to give drama workshops in Copenhagen. The members of the cast in Things are Bad are Mfundo Hashe, Phumzile Mangali, Earl Mentor, Andile Nebulane, Mziwandile Nofemele, Amina Nordien and Asanda Rilityana, all graduates of the Arts and Media Access Centre in Harrington Street, Cape Town. l Things are Bad will be performed today at 11am and 1pm at Desmond Tutu Secondary School, Mbekweni (Paarl) and at the Mbekweni Community Hall, at 8pm. Tomorrow it will be performed at 2pm at Khayelitsha Site C in the Moses Mabhida Library and on Saturday in Nyanga at the Zolani Centre at 3pm and at 7pm. For further inquiries contact Natalie Harper on 021 465 3660, or 082 3385187.

TITLE: Study questions SA's will to stamp out corruption
COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); SIERRA LEONE (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); TOGO (92%); BURUNDI (90%); UGANDA (90%); NIGERIA (90%); KENYA (88%); GERMANY (79%); LIBERIA (73%)
ORGANIZATION: TRANSPARENCY INTERNATIONAL (83%); AFRICAN UNION (57%); UNITED NATIONS (57%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); RESEARCH REPORTS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (89%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (76%); LOBBYING (75%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (72%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (71%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (70%)
TEXT: South Africa's commitment to fighting corruption was called into question after a detailed international study found it had failed to fully implement international anti-corruption policies. Eight other African countries - Algeria, Burundi, Kenya, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Togo and Uganda - were also fingered in a study by global civil society movement, Transparency International (TI). The report said that these countries all had legal gaps regarding the provisions of the United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC) and the African Union's Convention on Preventing and Combating Corruption and Related Offences. Department of Public Service and Administration spokesperson Lewis Rabkin said yesterday that the department would comment once it had obtained a copy of the report and studied its findings. Transparency International said it had been monitoring the implementation of the anti-corruption policies since the AU convention came into effect in August. The studies, released in Berlin, Germany, analysed anti-corruption measures and highlighted the shortcomings of the reform process. TI said a common feature in most countries was the absence of comprehensive national strategies to combat corruption and a lack of real political will to implement reforms. The vice-chairperson of TI's board, Akere Muna, said yesterday that the implementation of anti-corruption policies should be a top priority and that his organisation would continue to exert pressure until it was. "The AU convention provides a very useful template to guide such a process. "In concert with civil society, TI will continue to lobby governments and legislators on how best to cope with the obvious challenges posed by this process," said Muna. Governments were required to report back on the progress made by completing a questionnaire for the next UN Conference of States Parties in February next year. However, TI also encouraged civil society organisations to use the findings of the nine country studies to complete the same questionnaire. Only 16 of 53 African countries have ratified the AU convention. TI said the record for UNCAC was slightly better, with 29 ratifications. However, a low turnout of African countries at the first Conference of States Parties to the UN Convention in December last year raised doubts about the continent's commitment to the convention.

TITLE: Audit puts spotlight on alleged corruption of R4m by officials
SUBJECT: AUDITS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); INTERNAL AUDITS (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (89%); MISCONDUCT (89%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (89%); WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (89%); LABOR MEDIATION & ARBITRATION (87%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); LABOR UNIONS (76%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (76%); INSPECTIONS (72%); MAINTENANCE & REPAIR (69%)
TEXT: AN INTERNAL audit has uncovered alleged corruption at the Department of Water Affairs and Forestry's Worcester office estimated at R4 million, including R400 000 spent on two golf carts and trailers. A copy of the confidential audit report in the possession of the Cape Times shows senior officials may have contravened the department's procurement procedures and failed to comply with the Public Finance Management Act when they authorised the purchase of the golf carts, or tunnel vehicles, for R200 000 each. The investigation was triggered by an anonymous call in 2005 to the department's hotline for reporting corruption. The probe concluded that reasonable care had not been exercised when the vehicles had been bought. The vehicles were bought for routine inspections and maintenance at Bulshoek dam but could only be used once a year and were bought from SPEC Limited, which had a two-year R2m maintenance contract with the department. It was owned by Arnold Avanant, a former employee of the department. The audit recommended that Worcester area manager Thys Fourie and chief engineer Wally Kolmeyer, who were responsible for the purchase of the vehicles, be charged with misconduct and that the two vehicles be sold to recover the irregular expenditure. But this was not done, according to the National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu). The trade union is involved in a tussle with the department after one of its members and former department employee, Raleigh Mpekula, was dismissed in the wake of the investigation. Mpekula claims he was dismissed on trumped-up charges when officials in Worcester decided he was the whistleblower. Mpekula and Nehawu took the dispute to the General Public Services Sectoral Bargaining Council in a bid to have the department release a report of its 2002 investigation of the Worcester office. That probe was apparently ordered by former Water Affairs Minister Ronnie Kasrils. Despite being ordered to, the department had failed to release the report to Nehawu and Mpekula. Nehawu and Mpekula insist the whistleblower report is crucial to Mpekula's arbitration with the department as it alleged "gross misconduct involving senior managers in the Western Cape". Mpekula wrote to current Water Affairs and Forestry Minister Lindiwe Hendricks that corruption at Bulshoekdam was being swept under the carpet. vusi.nzapheza@inl.co.za

TITLE: City clamps down on corruption, cable thieves
SUBJECT: COPPER INDUSTRY (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); INTERNAL AUDITS (76%); RURAL DEVELOPMENT (76%); COPPER MINING (73%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (73%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (72%); AUDITS (71%); CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE (69%)
TEXT: THE City of Cape Town is offering cash rewards for information about copper cable and metal theft, which last year cost the council R22 million, as part of its clampdown on corruption and theft. Four people, who asked to remain anonymous, each received rewards of R2 000 at the city's whistleblower award ceremony yesterday. The four informed the city in January of illegal water connections in Philippi. The information led to an internal audit investigation which confirmed that two Philippi farmers had made illegal connections to the city's water supply. The farmers had stolen water to the value of more than R2.2m. A complaint of theft has been made with the police and the farmers will have to reimburse the city for the stolen water. Mayor Helen Zille said at yesterday's awards: "Like the whistleblowers with us today, we will reward anyone who can give us information that will lead to the conviction of cable thieves. This city will not tolerate any form of corruption or theft." Zille said the city's task team, comprising investigators and a rapid response unit, would respond to reports of copper theft. The team, chaired by councillor Pieter van Dalen, will arrest copper cable thieves and hand the cases to the SA Police Service for investigation. "However, the city cannot fight cable and metal theft without the assistance of the other spheres of government," the mayor said. Zille said the city would join the Cape Chamber of Commerce in its appeal for a judicial commission of inquiry into cable theft and the export of copper from the province. The city would hold a summit with scrap dealers, Business Against Crime and the Cape Chamber next month to look at ways of reducing the circulation of stolen scrap metal. The Western Cape reportedly exported copper worth R77m to China last year, despite having no copper mines. "But most importantly we rely on individual members of the public to come forward with information so that we can take decisive action and stop the theft of ratepayers' funds." l The toll-free number for whistleblowers is 0800 222 771.

TITLE: Water Affairs probing corruption after tunnel vehicles' purchase
SUBJECT: INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); INTERNAL AUDITS (90%); WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (90%); AUDITS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (72%); BRIDGES & TUNNELS (72%); DISMISSALS (70%)
TEXT: AN INTERNAL investigation is yet to be finalised into allegations of corruption at the Worcester offices of the Department of Water Affairs and Forestry (DWAF), including the purchase of two tunnel vehicles. DWAF Western Cape director Rashid Kahn would not say when it would be done. He added that the findings would not be available to the public: "We get tip-offs about allegations of corruption and we act on them accordingly but we do not make them public." The Cape Times last month published the outcome of a confidential probe by the DWAF internal audit directorate which concluded that senior officials had not taken reasonable care when buying two tunnel vehicles from a company called SPEC (Pty) Ltd. SPEC managing director, Arnold Avenant distanced the company from the allegations and said the tunnel vehicles were bought for R268 000 and not the R400 000 quoted in the internal audit report. Avenant also said the vehicles were meant for inspection work at the Riviersonderend tunnel that takes water from Theewaterkloof Dam to Cape Town. He said the vehicles could only do the inspection duty once a year because it took three days to empty the 24km tunnel and three more to fill it up again. Avenant said the audit had nothing to do with the sacking of Raleigh Mpekula, a former department employee believed to have blown the whistle on the purchase of the tunnel vehicles. Mpekula is contesting his dismissal from the department. vusi.nzapheza@inl.co.za

TITLE: Eighty-two corruption cases reported per month in civil service
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONS (90%); ETHICS (73%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (73%)
TEXT: The number of alleged corruption cases in the public service had increased over the past three years with an average of 82 reported a month, according to a Public Service Commission report released yesterday. A total of 4 182 cases were reported, of which 2 296 were corruption-related and 1 105 related to service delivery complaints. The cases were reported to the National Anti-Corruption Hotline between September 2004 and November 2006. The PSC found that the majority of reported cases (320) related to unethical behaviour by public servants and included the abuse of power and non-compliance with official working hours. A total of 234 cases related to procurement irregularities, 233 to the abuse of government vehicles and a number of other complaints concerning the mismanagement of school funds and irregularities around the allocation of housing subsidies were also received.

TITLE: Former Zambian minister faces corruption charges
COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (95%); NAMIBIA (94%); MALI (92%); ERITREA (79%); ETHIOPIA (79%); SOMALIA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ELECTIONS (78%); VOTERS & VOTING (78%); ARRESTS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); MARINE MAMMALS (77%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (77%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (69%)
TEXT: Former Zambian land minister Gladys Nyirongo, who was sacked by President Levy Mwanawasa in March, has been arrested and charged with corruption and abuse of office involving the allocation of land, an official said. She is expected to appear in court on Thursday. Namibia plans huge seal cull to save fishing industry Namibia has sanctioned the cull of 86 000 seal pups each year for the next three years, claiming the move is critical to protecting its key fishing industry. The sharp increase in the seal population is endangering the fishing industry because the seals kill about 900 000 tons of fish each year, the government said. Malians voted yesterday in parliamentary elections expected to keep an alliance of more than 40 parties backing President Amadou Toumani Toure firmly in power. The polls, in which about 1 500 candidates are standing for 147 seats, come just over two months after Toure won a second five-year term of office. Explosions and gunfire rocked Mogadishu yesterday, hours after President Abdullahi Yusuf promised to stem a bloody insurgency against his government and bring back stability to Somalia. Eritrea has scoffed at comments by Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi that his neighbour and arch-foe might be considering an invasion, saying such talk was a smokescreen to cover "domestic chaos".

TITLE: Contact corruption hotline to report bribery, refugees urged
SUBJECT: REFUGEES (90%); CORRUPTION (86%); POLITICAL ASYLUM (77%); TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT (71%); BRIBERY (69%)
TEXT: department's offices organised themselves into four queues, so that it would be easier for their applications to be processed. The queues were for first-time applicants, those with appointments, those wanting permit renewals and those wanting asylum. But he said department officials told them to form new queues, saying that only staff could organise the queues. However, for a fee of R900 or more, refugees could buy a permit. Steven said: "The officials create confusion (in the queues) so that we will pay them for the permits." A Zimbabwean refugee said he had been trying since last year to get a Section 22 permit from the department. He said he was told that there were only seven officials at the office who could each process 10 applications a day. The refugee said he had temporary work and while his employer understood that he was waiting for the department to issue his permit, he had been given until the end of the month to get the document. "People back home think its all roses here. But it is very painful. Even security (staff) beat up people." Asylum-seekers complained about the abuse that many had experienced at the department's offices. Some claimed they had been pushed and beaten, sometimes with key rings, while others were sprayed with pepper spray. Mashapu said the department had stepped up security measures and urged refugees being offered permits for money to contact the corruption hotline. anel.powell@inl.co.za

TITLE: Nigeria strips corruption busters of their powers
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); REFUGEES (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LAND USE PLANNING (85%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); EMERGENCY SHELTERS (75%); FLOODS & FLOODING (75%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (73%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (72%); REFUGEE & RELIEF CAMPS (71%); WEATHER (70%); RELIEF ORGANIZATIONS (70%); PEACE PROCESS (55%)
TEXT: The Nigerian government has stripped its anti-corruption agencies of powers to prosecute suspected corrupt public officers. In future they can only initiate criminal proceedings with the consent of the attorney-general, said presidential spokesperson Olusegun Adeniyi. Long-delayed elections in war-divided Ivory Coast could take place in December, President Laurent Gbagbo said, ahead of a schedule set by a March peace deal which reconciled him with former rebel foes. At least 17 people were killed in flooding in central Nigeria's Plateau state while more than 200 houses were washed away. Mohammed Abubakar, chairperson of Wase local government council, said by telephone that a river burst its banks and swept away 13 villages in the early hours of Monday morning following torrential rains UN agency urges refugee status for Chadians Sudan should grant refugee status to tens of thousands of mostly Arab Chadians who have fled into Darfur to escape violence in their country, the UN refugee agency said. But the United Nations urged Sudan to clarify land issues so Chadians do not settle on property abandoned by Darfuris who have themselves fled conflict for shelter in refugee camps.

TITLE: Corruption causes staff vacancies at home affairs
SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (79%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (79%); PROPERTY VACANCIES (78%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (78%); DISMISSALS (78%); REFUGEES (77%); EMPLOYEE TURNOVER & RETENTION (75%); REFUGEE & RELIEF CAMPS (70%); WAGES & SALARIES (70%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (60%)
TEXT: CORRUPTION at the embattled home affairs department has reached such an alarming level that officials are being fired faster than the department is able to fill vacancies. This was one of a number of revelations made by senior officials from the department during a briefing to parliament's home affairs portfolio committee on Friday. Chief of immigration, Yusuf Simons, told committee members that "as soon as we fill vacancies our counter- corruption strategies create new vacancies - so staff turnover continuously takes place". Simons also admitted that infrastructure problems, limited resources, poor management and the growing influx of refugees and immigrants - legal or otherwise - from the rest of the continent were placing a huge strain on immigration services. Committee chairman Pat-rick Chauke called the department's immigration services a "shameful embarrassment". "With the birth of Zimbabwe in 1980, the majority of the white Zimbabweans did not go to Britain. They came to South Africa ... There were no refugee camps," he said. "We as South Africans have a responsibility to make sure the welfare of our neighbours is taken seriously because the condition they find themselves in is the legacy of colonialism and apartheid." Director-General Mavuso Msimang also appeared before the committee to explain what steps had been taken to rectify problems at the Marabastad immigration centre in Tshwane since committee members dropped in unannounced at the beginning of the month. "Appalling", "chaotic", "un-friendly" and "filthy" were some of the remarks that committee chairman Patrick Chauke used on Friday to describe what he had seen at the centre. The health department had even condemned the centre as a "slum" and a serious health risk. According to Msimang and Simons, much has since been done to improve the situation. Committee members complimented the department on its thorough feedback and undertook to visit the centre again in mid-October. l According to the department's annual report for the period April 1, 2005 to March 31, 2006, 73 disciplinary hearings were finalised over this period and 70 officials were found guilty of an offence. In 30 cases the offences involved "aiding and abetting corruption", while 27 officials were charged for bribery and 16 others for fraud or making false statements. In the salary band classified as "highly skilled supervision", 292 out of 673 posts remained unfilled - a vacancy rate of about 56%. To fill these posts, regulations required that each post be evaluated. According to the department's own figures, only 13% were evaluated during this time.

TITLE: Security 'overspending' leaked to AG to hide officials' corruption - Rasool
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); FORENSICS (71%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (71%); APPOINTMENTS (70%); SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT (69%)
TEXT: INFORMATION about over-expenditure on security at Community Safety MEC Leonard Ramatlakane's home was handed to the Auditor-General (AG) irregularly and possibly to deflect attention from employees who had defrauded his department of more than a million rand. This was part of Premier Ebrahim Rasool's response during question time in the provincial legislature yesterday where he said an independent investigation by Sonnenbergs had exonerated Ramatlakane of fraud and corruption. Sonnenbergs's findings, Rasool said, corroborated the AG's, that the overspend resulted from communication lapses between Ramatlakane's department and the Department of Transport and Public Works (DTPW), and system weaknesses in supply-chain management, among others. In response to DA MPL Robin Carlisle's questions on how the executive dealt with the issue, Rasool said after Sonnenbergs presented its report in March, disciplinary steps were taken against five employees - four in DTPW and another in Community Safety. "In addition it came to my attention that the upgrade of the MEC's residence, was not part of the AG's original sample, but was handed to the AG outside the normal communication. This was a worry to me, as the AG's office had for three years not picked up accumulated fraud and corruption in excess of R1 million where syndicates of employees had systematically defrauded the Department of Community Safety. "The coincidence of these two facts led me to prepare a tender for a further forensic investigation to determine whether the operation of the AG's office could have been compromised by having been fed information of a high-profile nature, and whether it was meant to distract the AG from finding the actual syndicated fraud and corruption," Rasool said. "Given the possible connection between the deliberate handing over of this and other matters to various bodies, including the AG, the fraud uncovered and the fact that we have procured an investigation to determine whether the AG may have been compromised - it was not possible to divulge this sensitive information and to communicate it openly," Rasool said. Newly appointed department director Gilbert Lawrence conceded in July to the provincial standing committee on public accounts that the supply chain management was a "high-risk" area. A provisioning clerk, Priscilla Fulemeni, and her boyfriend, Vusumzi Mvundlela, have been charged with defrauding the department of R800 000. aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: Commissions and corruption
SUBJECT: SPORTS SPONSORSHIP (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (79%); PUBLIC FINANCE (79%); CORRUPTION (73%); SOCCER (73%)
TEXT: FINANCE minISTER Trevor Manuel is correct to sound a warning bell about the payment of hefty commissions to a handful of football administrators. Manuel wrote a letter at the weekend to Absa chief Steve Booysen taking issue with the proposed payment of some R50 million to five Professional Soccer League (PSL) officials - Irvin Khoza, Kaizer Motaung, Manto Madlala, Trevor Phillips and Peter Mancer - who secured a R500m sponsorship from the bank. Some might say that the target of the ministerial annoyance should be the PSL, rather than Absa, which has said that it did not agree to the payments. Certainly the league must be called to account, especially since the payment of enormous commissions on deals negotiated by officials seems somehow to have become routine. Such commissions, as Manuel said, may indeed be "wrong, morally reprehensible and corrupt". The same five administrators - who comprise the league's sponsorship committee - lined up for R30m each a few months ago when they secured a five-year R1.6 billion broadcast rights deal with SuperSport International. But Absa should not be let off the hook either. The bank must take some responsibility for the way in which the sponsorship is to be handled. The bank could have made it a condition of the sponsorship, for instance, that no commissions are paid to officials, who, in any case, are simply doing what they are elected to do. Khoza said yesterday that the payment of the commissions had not yet been finalised. Perhaps there is still time to set the matter right. If not, both the league and Absa will have some explaining to do when the chairperson of the National Assembly's sport committee, Butana Khompela, calls them before the committee, as he has said he will do.

TITLE: How greed and corruption help turn one of nature's miracles into a tragedy
SUBJECT: MAMMALS (90%); WILDLIFE (90%); CORRUPTION (82%); PRIMATES (76%); LAND USE PLANNING (76%); RIVERS (74%); LAKES (74%); MALARIA (72%)
TEXT: THERE is an image that will stay with me as long as I live. We had been in the Serengeti for several weeks at the height of the great wildebeest migration. This was quintessential Africa: vast plains of tawny grass dotted with umbrella trees, a sea of milling wildebeest and zebra, grunting and snorting in a mad bedlam of insane noise. We followed the migration out of the park and into the Grumeti conservation area, a corridor of protected land where nomadic pastoralists and wildlife live side by side. An hour before sunset, we set up camp at the foot of a small koppie looking down towards the Grumeti River. We were in the Garden of Eden. Spread before us on the plains was one of the greatest wildlife spectacles on Earth: thousands upon thousands of animals, wildebeest, zebra, giraffe, ostrich, kongoni, elephant, lion, Thompson's gazelle. They moved unquietly back and forth, politely keeping a hundred metres from our camp. Late into the night the grunting and groaning continued, singing us to sleep. We woke to silence. The plains were empty. Not a single animal remained. They had ghosted off in the night, leaving us wondering if we had imagined it all. That is the miracle of the great migration that moves restlessly back and forth across the vast plains of East Africa. The migration is a fickle thing and totally dependent on rainfall - and hence grass growth - patterns. In a perfect world, the wildebeest, zebra and gazelles start migrating west and north in search of sweeter grazing from May through to July, moving from Seronera through the Western Corridor, then outside the park to the Grumeti, arriving in the Maasai Mara in Kenya by late July through to early September. By October or November, they are drifting back to Seronera, and spend the long rainy season in the Serengeti grasslands. With plenty of time and a fistful of dollars, it is possible to witness both ends of the spectacle, following the migration almost to the shores of Lake Victoria, then across the border into Kenya and down the Soit Olol Escarpment into the Mara. That's the way we did it - with plenty of time and almost no dollars at all. We bush camped wherever we ended up for the night, moving with the vast herds, from Lake Manyara in the east, down into the Olduvai Gorge, then across the Serengeti, through the Grumeti and down the Soit Olol into the Mara. It was an extraordinary journey, battling cotton mud and swarms of malarial mosquitoes, with regular visits to our camps by curious lions and marauding baboons. The apex moment was when we got to the Mara, Talek and Sand Rivers and watched over several days as tens of thousands of wildebeest and zebra milled and charged into the waters, often into the jaws of the waiting crocodiles. Those in front have no option but to jump as the pressure builds up from behind. This is one of the most exciting wildlife spectacles on earth, an extraordinary experience that cannot be described in words. But this year was different. East Africa has been pounded by torrential rains, and last Friday the Mara River burst its banks. Conservationists estimate that as many as 20 000 wildebeest were swept away and drowned as they tried to cross. The crocodiles, hyenas and marabou storks will be fat and bloated this year. And while the heavy rains are partly to blame for the unprecedented deaths, there is a more sinister, man-made reason behind the floods, and it is twofold. First, the Maasai Mara lies spread out in the southern shadow of the mighty Mau Escarpment, one of Kenya's most beautiful and rugged Afromontane ranges, a range that creates its own micro-climate. But illegal logging, often by companies with close links to ruling party politicians, and mass clearing of forest for coffee and tea plantations, have stripped vast areas of their indigenous forest. Second, while the Serengeti is, in the main, vast and trackless, the Maasai Mara is criss-crossed with illegal vehicle tracks made by unscrupulous safari mini-buses trying to get their mostly foreign clients close to the lions. Erosion dongas and desertification of the grasslands are a massive problem. Combined with the hugely increased runoff from the Mau Escarpment, runoff that is unchecked by the once mighty forests, the Maasai Mara has long been an ecological disaster waiting to happen. And Friday's mass drowning of the wildebeest could well be an ominous harbinger of far worse things to come. tony.weaver@inl.co.za

TITLE: 'corruption uncoverer' suspended
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); MISCONDUCT (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENTS (76%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (75%); JOURNALISM (75%); EXECUTIVES (74%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (74%); FORENSICS (69%); WRITERS (68%)
TEXT: THE CapeNature Board's suspended deputy chairperson, Yasmina Pandy, has accused Environment, Planning and Economic Development MEC Tasneem Essop of "poor governance" and has called on Western Cape Premier Ebrahim Rasool to "spend time ... educating" his cabinet on issues of good conduct. On Friday, Essop issued a statement announcing that Pandy had been suspended. In the statement, Essop also said she intended "removing (Pandy) as a board member for disclosing confidential information in an unauthorised manner and contravening a signed confidentiality agreement between (Pandy) and the CapeNature Board". The embattled conservation agency made headlines after it was revealed that an independent forensic investigation had uncovered numerous instances of financial misconduct by senior managers. The report was leaked to members of the province's standing committee on environment and community development and journalists. Early last month, Essop took charge of the investigation into financial misconduct and started an investigation into the leaking of confidential CapeNature documents. On September 20, the Cape Times received copies of two documents, both authored by Pandy. The first, dated September 3, contained board meeting minutes, and e-mails between board members. It was addressed to standing committee chairperson Zodwa Magwaza.The second, dated September 19, called on Magwaza to investigate the board's alleged "cover-up ... regarding poor governance by (Essop) and the acting CEOs". "I would like to inform the committee that I have become extremely uncomfortable about the behaviour of members of the board of CapeNature," said Pandy in one of the documents. Ten days ago, three senior managers were suspended and nine staff members received written warnings. Speaking to the Cape Times yesterday, Pandy said she had found out about her suspension on Friday after reading newspaper posters. She had seen headlines announcing her suspension before she returned home to find an official letter from Essop. She said the MEC was "only concerned about (media) leaks" and was not investigating issues of financial misconduct. Pandy flatly denied that she was responsible for information leaks. In her letter to Rasool, Pandy asked why Essop was not investigating the conduct of acting CapeNature CEO Nazeem Jamie and members of the board. Pandy, a devout Muslim, was also furious that Essop had issued the notice of suspension just one day before Eid. In a letter addressed to Essop, Pandy said she found it "strange" that she was being suspended. "I am the person responsible for uncovering the corruption and financial mismanagement at CapeNature," Pandy said in the letter. Essop's spokesperson, Nils Flaatten, said Pandy needed to provide evidence to back up her claims. "This is not a media slugfest," said Flaatten. "(The MEC's office has) been very candid, we have explained the processes that are under way." "In those processes, Pandy has the opportunity to make representations." Flaatten said Pandy had until the close of business on Friday to explain to the MEC why she should not be removed from the board. Pandy, who has been a board member for three years, said she was "most definitely" fighting her suspension. A spokesperson for Rasool could not confirm if he had received Pandy's letter. natasha.joseph@inl.co.za

TITLE: 'Lethal cocktail' of corruption mars HIV/Aids plan
SUBJECT: AIDS & HIV (96%); ANTIVIRALS (90%); PREVENTION & WELLNESS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); BUDGETS (78%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (78%); AIDS & HIV TREATMENT (78%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (77%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (73%); POLITICS (67%)
TEXT: STOLEN anti-retrovirals, the lack of financial monitoring mechanisms, dire poverty and a lack of accountability all make up the "lethal cocktail" hindering the prevention of HIV/Aids in South Africa. This is according to the latest study by the Institute of Security Studies (ISS), entitled "A Lethal Cocktail: Exploring the Impact of Corruption on HIV/Aids Prevention and Treatment Efforts in South Africa", that was launched yesterday at the Centre for the Book. The report was compiled by ISS researcher Collette Schulz-Herzenberg, who says the ability to control corruption in the prevention of HIV/Aids is as dramatic and clear-cut as a choice of life over death. "Corruption in the HIV/Aids sector is largely unreported. Where corruption exists, it appears to be a result of several factors such as weak institutions and a lack of enforcement of policy and regulations. "Abuses of political power occur where the relevant political institutions are either too weak or unwilling to curb them. Corrupt activities, particularly among HIV-infected people, appear to be a direct result of high poverty and inequality", states the report, which looks at why, despite large amounts of money being pumped into the prevention and treatment of HIV/Aids, results have been slow and minimal. Schulz-Herzenberg said there were "significant challenges" in the distribution of funds towards treatment and prevention, which was one of the stumbling blocks. Her findings indicate that budget-tracking mechanisms appear to be lacking in terms of what is being spent and where it is going - resulting in some international donors withdrawing their funding. There was also no clear database of donor funding, posing a risk of duplication of resources and efforts between the government and NGOs. The lack of accountability was particularly a "source of concern", coupled with the "lack of transparency". "The more loose and unregulated the system for the provision of funds and services, the greater the chance of corruption."

TITLE: Roles of patronage, corporate gain are underestimated in fight against corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (89%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (89%); LEGISLATION (88%); ETHICS (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); RISK MANAGEMENT (78%); BUSINESS ETHICS (77%); ACCREDITATION (62%)
TEXT: Great strides have been made in managing and preventing public sector graft. The Department of Justice and Constitutional Development has, among its primary objectives, combating, preventing and mitigating risk in relation to the resources and responsibilities we manage on behalf of the citizens of our province and country. We continue to find ways to integrate our anti-corruption policy with our risk management profile and to ensure a collaborative onslaught against corruption and bad practices that rob our people of a deserved service excellence. We recognise that the value system underpinning the public sector needs to be corruption resistance, as corruption impedes the capacity of the government to deliver justice services to our customers. Corruption is almost universally defined as "abuse of public office for private gain". The difficulty is that such definitions ignore and downplay the role of patronage, and underestimate the extent to which corporate gain motivates acts of corruption. Concerted state intervention is needed to redress the legacy of apartheid. The use of the state to redirect accumulation processes and to ensure redress of historical imbalances heightens the risk of corruption. Thus, there is a demand for high levels of integrity, to prevent empowerment strategies from being compromised by patronage and personal enrichment. Corruption drains state resources and weakens capacity to meet the needs of its people. It hampers the state's ability to create opportunities for advancement and growth. Our new democratic government has, in recent years, introduced a number of measures to fight corruption and bring to justice those who engage in corrupt activities. The 2004 Anti-Corruption Conference highlighted the need to raise public awareness about corruption. Sixteen resolutions were passed, with the main focus on the National Anti-Corruption Strategy, community understanding, stakeholder commitment and the participation of civil society in fighting corruption. At the national conferences, a number of resolutions were passed on oversight, accountability, whistle-blowing, co-ordination and the challenges of dealing with corruption. The following actions were initiated by government: l We have implemented stringent screening mechanisms for all Department of Justice employees and have deployed draft legislation to regulate post-public sector employment of possible corrupt individuals. l Accredited ethics officers have been appointed to ensure all departments have adequate capacity to fight corruption. Programmes for anti-corruption practitioners, including staff and prosecutors, have been implemented. l A major achievement has been the expansion of our legislative framework. The Promotion of Access to Information Act of 2004 was supported by the Protected Disclosures Act. The main piece of legislation, though, is the Prevention and Combating of Corrupt Activities Act, 2004. This replaces the 1992 act and produces a wider net by providing specific categories of offences involving corrupt activities. According to the act, any person who gives or accepts gratification in order to act in an improper exercise of a duty or a power, is guilty of corruption. l Other notable achievements include the establishment of a specialised commercial crimes court for corruption cases; the National Anti-Corruption Forum, a multi-sectoral co-ordinating group to help develop a national anti-corruption programme; the Directorate: Special Operations (of the National Directorate of Public Prosecutions), to focus on organised crime; and the Assets Forfeiture Unit, which is making serious inroads into recovering the ill-gotten gains of criminals and corrupt officials. In trying to prevent corruption, we have made it compulsory for all departments to conduct risk assessment and implement fraud prevention plans. We have also opened anti-corruption hotlines and have introduced procedures to institute disciplinary action against corrupt individuals. We will pursue disciplinary procedures against any staff member charged with corruption. Accounting officers of government departments have also been given the responsibility of implementing risk management plans. This is necessary to ensure risks that could impede the strategic objectives and achievements of a department are identified and adequately and effectively mitigated. Section 38 of the Public Finance Management Act of 1999 further requires accounting officers to maintain an effective, efficient and transparent system of financial and risk managements and internal controls. The Department of Justice and Constitutional Development is committed to strengthening the integrity of our courts, and ensuring that leadership by court managers is clearly demonstrated through a commitment to a value system based on the fundamentals of honesty, integrity and fairness. We will carefully measure the standards for each of the services we deliver, and spot checks and inspectors will be used to assess general compliance with the principles of Batho Pele. Corruption of any kind will not be tolerated. As we fight the pervasive cancer of corruption, we will continue to rely on our accountants and ourselves as patriotic managers to help our country and people to eradicate corruption. l Advocate Mohamed is the regional head of the Department of Justice and Constitutional Development, Western Cape. This is an edited version of an address delivered at a provincial workshop for court managers in Cape Town recently.

TITLE: Corruption|case prepared|against|Ramatlhodi
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (78%); CONTRACT AWARDS (77%); POLICE FORCES (74%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (65%)
TEXT: Gauteng Scorpions head Gerrie Nel has finally prepared a prosecutable corruption case against former Limpopo premier Ngoako Ramatlhodi, four years after it was announced that the ANC leader would be charged. Ramatlhodi is a member of the ANC's national executive committee and national working committee. The Cape Times has reliably learnt of a Scorpions report, signed by Nel, laying out a case against Ramatlhodi and the intention to charge him. The charges relate to alleged social grants payment tender kickbacks amounting to R785 000 Ramatlhodi received during his tenure as premier. City Press reported yesterday that the corruption charges concern payments allegedly made by Nicoh, a company that was awarded a tender to distribute social grants. Ramatlhodi questioned why the Scorpions and the National Prosecuting Authority had to charge him through the media. He was unaware of any impending charges. NPA spokesperson Tlali Tlali could not be reached for comment. In 2006, the Scorpions raided Ramatlhodi's residences in Polokwane and Tshwane, and he had since said his case was motivated by the succession divisions in the ANC. Nel, who was recently arrested and then released without charge, is leading an investigation into suspended national Police Commissioner Jackie Selebi.

TITLE: World experts meet to combat corruption and fraud in international fishing industry
ORGANIZATION: INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE & NATURAL RESOURCES (84%); WORLD CONSERVATION UNION (91%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); FISHERIES (91%); FISHES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); SHELLFISH FISHING (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); FINFISH FISHING (89%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (89%); BRIBERY (89%); COMMERCIAL FISHING (89%); MARINE VESSELS (89%); FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION (78%); IMMIGRATION (78%); SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES (78%); FISHING LAW (78%); FOOD EXPORTS & IMPORTS (73%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (72%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (71%); EXPERIMENTATION & RESEARCH (70%); FINES & PENALTIES (70%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (68%); PLEA AGREEMENTS (68%); JAIL SENTENCING (66%); ARRESTS (66%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (55%); SATELLITE TECHNOLOGY (50%)
TEXT: DURBAN: Fish experts from around the world are meeting this week to find better methods to halt widespread corruption and fraud in the international fisheries industry. According to the World Conservation Union (IUCN), several heavily exploited fish species are being illegally re-labelled as "ecofish" to pass them off as common or abundant species. Accurate records on the number of fish hauled out of the sea were also being distorted, making it difficult for scientists to set sensible recommendations on sustainable catch rates. A briefing paper to be presented to a meeting at the World Bank in Washington today notes that China is being used extensively to "launder" fish which have been caught illegally or unsustainably, while land-locked nations like Mongolia are providing flags of convenience for hundreds of sea fishing boats. Researchers from the University of British Columbia say several cases of corruption have also been documented in South Africa. One of the most highly publicised examples involved Arnold Bengis, a wealthy dual citizen of South Africa and the United States who bribed 18 South African fisheries officers to conceal exports of illegal rock lobster and Patagonian toothfish. Bengis and his son, David, were arrested in August 2002 following a three-year investigation involving the Scorpions and the US Department of Customs and Immigration. Bengis was eventually jailed for 46 months and fined $5.9 million following a plea bargain agreement before the US Attorney's Southern District of New York. During one of the illegal shipments from South Africa to the US, a large consignment of illegally caught Patagonian toothfish was hidden below a thin layer of rock lobster and other fish. More recently, in July 2005, the captain of a South Korean fishing vessel was caught trying to bribe a South African fisheries observer who had video-taped the crew chopping the fins and tails off sharks and then tossing their bleeding bodies back into the sea. Globally, it is estimated that 20% of all fish which enter the market have been caught illegally or in an unregulated manner. According to Dr Cathy Roheim of the University of Rhode Island, US, large volumes of illegally caught fish are being laundered through China, where processed fish are labelled legally as "product of China". Elsewhere, Patagonian toothfish are labelled as "sea bass" or cut into fillets to deceive customs agents. Roheim has suggested that governments should rely more on electronic documentation rather than paper documents, which are easily forged. She has also called for a worldwide ban on fish trans-shipments at sea to prevent legally caught fish being mixed up with illegal cargoes, out of sight of inspectors. Carl Gustav Lundin, the head of the IUCN Global Marine Programme, will also be calling for satellite tracking of fishing vessels, better labelling protocols for fish and better enforcement of current rules. However, officials note that the problem of illegal fishing and corruption is especially prevalent in many small island nations which rely heavily on a fisheries economy. Australian academic Martin Tsamenyi noted in a briefing paper that several Pacific islands depended heavily on foreign aid money, while senior government officials also granted permits to foreign fishing fleets to operate within their exclusive economic zones. Another briefing paper notes that in return for aid money, Japan bribed several poor nations in 2001 to buy support for its stance on whaling at the International Whaling Commission.

TITLE: Mbeki 'knew about Selebi corruption case'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); MISCONDUCT (78%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (78%); SEARCH & SEIZURE (77%); WITNESSES (77%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (72%); NATIONAL SECURITY (72%); PRISONS (71%); CORRECTIONS (71%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (71%)
TEXT: JOHANNESBURG: Ten meetings with prosecuting boss Vusi Pikoli - as well as a "top secret" letter - did nothing to convince President Thabo Mbeki there was a corruption case against National Police Commissioner Jackie Selebi. In an explosive affidavit filed yesterday, acting prosecuting head Mokotedi Mpshe has also revealed that Pikoli informed six top government officials, including Justice Minister Brigitte Mabandla, Safety and Security Minister Charles Nqakula and Defence Minister Mosuioa Lekota, of the "serious" graft claims against Selebi. Mpshe's statements that there was "constant communication" between Pikoli, Mbeki and Mabandla about the Selebi investigation could cast serious doubts on Mbeki's claims that he was ignorant of any alleged wrongdoing by Selebi. Earlier this year, Mbeki told the media: "I have said this before, many times, that if there was anybody with information that shows National Commissioner Selebi has done wrong things, I would act on it. "Nobody did, nobody came to me." Mpshe has, however, stated under oath that: "The president himself has been kept fully informed of both the fact of the investigation against Selebi and the nature of the allegations against him ... there was indeed information and evidence communicated to (Mabandla) and the president." He went on to state that Selebi's claim that "advocate Pikoli had simply informed the president of Selebi's alleged involvement in organised crime but failed to provide him with detail of such alleged misconduct is ... not correct". In a direct challenge to Selebi, Mpshe also invited the police commissioner to explain how he obtained a draft copy of Pikoli's "top secret" May 7, 2007 letter to Mbeki, in which he asked the president to persuade the police to allow the Scorpions to carry out search and seizure operations at police headquarters and at Selebi's home. Mpshe's affidavit has also exposed how Pikoli's two-dozen "Selebi" meetings with government bosses, which included Correctional Services Minister Ngconde Balfour, were met with less than enthusiasm.

TITLE: Former ambassador named in Zuma corruption case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); FORENSICS (72%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (72%); WITNESSES (71%); POLICE FORCES (71%); DEFENSE CONTRACTING (64%)
TEXT: JOHANNESBURG: Papers filed by the Scorpions in support of fraud and corruption charges against Jacob Zuma name former ambassador to Paris Barbara Masekela as having received money from Jurgen Kí_gl, the businessman they suspect laundered R500 000 alleged to have been paid to the ANC leader by an arms company. Kí_gl is also listed as a state witness in the Scorpions' case against police chief Jackie Selebi. Scorpions boss Leonard McCarthy alleged that payments had been made to Zuma by Cay Nominees, a company owned by Kí_gl. He said there were "indications" that the payments might be linked to the arms company Thompson-CSF and the undertaking that investigators alleged it made to pay Zuma R500 000 a year in return for protection in the arms deal probe. Details of the payments made by Kí_gl and his companies are listed in a KPMG draft report, "The State vs Jacob Zuma and others: forensic investigation", dated September 2, 2006. The report says that Kí_gl managed funds on behalf of a number of "government officials and/or politicians", including Masekela. In an interview with the Sunday Times, Masekela said then-deputy president Thabo Mbeki had met Thompson-CSF representatives on December 17, 1998. Mbeki, who was then chairing the interdepartmental committee overseeing the arms deal, has said he cannot recall such a meeting. Masekela told the paper she had arranged a "courtesy call" meeting between Mbeki and Thompson-CSF. It took place a year before Thompson was awarded an arms contract. Masekela insisted that there was nothing untoward about it. "There is nothing wrong with a

TITLE: 'corruption' dogs ndabeni matter
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); CITIES (76%); TRUST ARRANGEMENTS (75%); RELIGION (60%)
TEXT: THE Western Cape, which has completed 16 000 of the 17 000 land claims lodged since the restitution process started in 1998, is now battling to finalise the remainder. Those remaining claims are unlikely to all be dealt with before the deadline set for the end of this year, provincial land claims commissioner Beverly Jansen said. Included in the unsettled claims are Ndabeni, where controversy and allegations of corruption continue to bedevil restitution, and District Six, where the city council and the District Six Beneficiary Development Trust are embroiled in a legal battle.
