The latter claim is expected to progress following the formation of a task team that includes national and provincial government officials, the national lands claims commissioner and the city. "Remaining claims are most difficult because they are affected by conflict - whether in a community or in families. The original deadline to complete restitution was 2005 and has since been changed to 2008. "Many people are concerned about it, but we won't leave any claims unsettled (just) because we are driven by a deadline," Jansen said, adding that it was Parliament's prerogative to extend the deadline. She said the availability of land was proving to be the biggest hurdle, as municipalities and government departments had their own priorities for use of land they owned. "We know land is scarce and expensive, but we are entirely dependent on municipalities and government departments that own land. "We tell departments that they've got land of the dispossessed and we want it back. "The matter is then negotiated and in some cases we've been working with municipalities for more than two years. "Many claimants do not understand that it can take so long. There are legalities to be followed before land can be disposed of," explained Jansen. While the District Six trust had a successful annual meeting yesterday, the police commercial branch was still investigating corruption complaints in the Ndabeni land claim and has approached the state for a decision to prosecute. The trust told 500 people at yesterday's meeting that the city council owned District Six land, accessing it was out of the trust's hands and the task team would deal with the issue. Chairperson Anwah Nagia said the trust's mission was to get people home. "Soon we will be discussing the next step to build 4 000 houses. Claims involve not only owners and tenants, but also mosques and churches. Don't give up now," he said. Many praised trustees for their efforts, but individuals in the audience criticised the trust and accused it of not representing them. Amendments to the trust deed and eight additional trust members were accepted unanimously. Asked how her office had dealt with the Ndabeni matter, Jansen said: "There are different groups claiming to be the rightful representatives and there has been constant conflict and one group accused another of fraud." "It has been alleged that one of the groups had already sold a portion of the land to a developer. My job is to protect the claimants because that is state land." She said there were moves to arbitrate the Ndabeni dispute. If all parties did not accept the outcome, her office would ask the courts to decide who the rightful representatives were.

TITLE: Corruption and governance issues problematic
CITY: HARARE, ZIMBABWE (79%); CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA (79%); LONDON, ENGLAND (52%)
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EMBARGOES & SANCTIONS (89%); ARMS EMBARGOES (89%); ARMS TRADE (87%); NOBEL PRIZES (78%); RELIGION (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS (72%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (70%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (67%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (65%)
TEXT: IN ADDITION to urging African leaders to ask Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe to step down, Nobel peace laureate Archbishop Emeritus Desmond Tutu says many of SA's current problems stem from questionable governance and burgeoning corruption. Tutu said that the aftermath of elections in Kenya and Zimbabwe showed what happened when incumbents refused to concede defeat and were prepared to cause destruction in their own countries. "All of this just to satisfy their power-hungry egos," he said yesterday when he addressed the Stellenbosch University's seboka (Sotho for getting together on common issues) on higher education and ethical leadership. "I'm calling on African leaders to persuade Mr Mugabe to step down and say to him that he does still have the chance of redeeming, of salvaging some of his legacy and could be provided with a soft landing. If he continues and remains as obdurate as he appears to be, then clearly people are going to be saying 'no, he must ultimately be arraigned for all of the human rights violations he has perpetrated'," Tutu said. Tutu also called for an arms embargo on Zimbabwe in order to avert the escalation of violence in the troubled nation. He appealed to world leaders to use the United Nations to stop the supply of weapons to Zimbabwe, which is currently in a political crisis following last month's disputed elections. "I join the worldwide calls to stop the supply of weapons to the country - by land, sea or air - until the political crisis is resolved," the former archbishop of Cape Town said. Tutu said the UN should agree on a binding arms embargo on Zimbabwe after a Chinese-owned ship was forced to abandon a planned delivery of weapons to the Harare regime. "It is obvious that supplying large quantities of arms at this stage would risk escalating the violence, perhaps resulting in the large-scale loss of life," said Tutu. But, speaking in London, ANC president Jacob Zuma said yesterday it was not yet the time to impose an arms embargo on Zimbabwe in the wake of its undecided presidential election. Zuma said dockers in Durban had "correctly" refused to unload the weapons destined for Zimbabwe. "That was a very appropriate response," Zuma said, but added he would not currently support any moves for an arms embargo against the country. Turning to SA, Tutu said given the events before and after the ANC conference in Polokwane, many people wondered what a good leader was. Tutu saluted former SA president Nelson Mandela's leadership which had former oppressors and their victims participate in reconciliation. "We entered into striving to be non-racial and non-sexist with some gusto. It is less so now. We are fractious, our morale has taken some body blows. We are apprehensive, we don't hold up our heads quite as we used to. We have been buffeted by odd policies on the devastating HIV/Aids pandemic; we have been deeply distressed by our positions on Zimbabwe, on Burma, on cluster bombs," he said. SA's challenges included poverty, housing, education, crime and unemployment yet: "A huge part of our problem stems from questionable governance. We're seeing a burgeoning in corruption, of many engaging in self-enrichment sprees whilst the gap between the rich and the poor widens so that we are sitting on a powder keg - a deeply worrying, volatile situation waiting to be ignited," he said. Tutu criticised the treatment given to MPs involved in the Travelgate scandal and said public confidence in state institutions had also been eroded amid suspicions of the arms deal and the intended shutdown of the Scorpions. Asked for his impression of Tutu's address, former chief justice Arthur Chaskalson said: "I thought it was an extra-ordinarily powerful speech with the warmth and humour one associates with him and the depth of his vision. It was a wonderful presentation which very importantly was drawing our attention to some of the issues that are of fundamental importance to our country." aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: MPs lock horns with Home Affairs DG over corruption allegations
SUBJECT: TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); EVIDENCE (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); SPONSORSHIP (68%); WRITERS (60%); SMART CARDS (53%)
TEXT: IT WAS a tense encounter yesterday when straight-talking Home Affairs director-general Mavuso Msimang and members of the National Assembly's home affairs portfolio committee locked horns over allegations that members of the committee were "colluding" with suspended department officials accused of corruption. The Speaker has now been asked to intervene. Msimang stuck to his guns when he faced MPs who summoned him to appear before the National Assembly's home affairs committee to provide evidence to support the |allegations. During yesterday's meeting, Msimang also repeated what he said at a previous committee meeting - that a visit to a German company in June last year by the committee had the potential to compromise tender procedures. The visit was partly sponsored by MAN Ferrostaal, a company with an interest in the smart-card technology for which Home Affairs will soon invite tenders. Msimang said the department's legal team conducting the disciplinary hearings had evidence but said he wasn't aware that he had to bring physical evidence to the meeting and therefore he couldn't substantiate the allegations. Had he known that the meeting would have been "so legalistic" and complicated, he would have brought his own legal team. The committee eventually resolved to refer the matter |to the Speaker of the National Assembly for further |investigation. On the alleged collusion between MPs and suspended officials, Msimang said there were glaring similarities between a statement made by ANC MP Kgoloko Morwamoche and evidence given by one of the suspended officials during hearings. Msimang said Morwamoche's comment that the department was removing the officials "so corruption can continue", was "tantamount to defamation". "I would think the committee would be worried about this (corruption). It's a matter that should interest the committee. I would think that bothers you. "The efforts expressed here seem to be extremely hostile," said Msimang. He said the similarities between what Morwamoche said and what the suspended official said were "too much of a coincidence". "There is a direct link in the position taken by the member and the suspended official," said Msimang. The DG also mentioned how shocked he was when at a previous home affairs committee meeting, he received a scribbled note stating that the department "has absolutely no chance of winning its case against one of its suspended employees". Msimang said the author of the note "was none other than (ANC MP Patrick Chauke)". He called on Chauke to explain what he had meant by the note. But Chauke refused to confirm that he had written the note. Chauke then reminded Msimang that he was not the equal of MPs and accused him of attempting to avoid being accountable to the committee. babalo.ndenze@inl.co.za

TITLE: 'Corruption keeps oil wealth from the people'
COUNTRY: EGYPT (94%); AFRICA (93%); LIBYA (92%); ETHIOPIA (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ELECTIONS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); LIVING STANDARDS (72%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (69%); CHILDREN (67%)
TEXT: Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi accused a "corrupt" government of failing to manage the country's oil wealth and ordered it to hand out oil money directly to the country's 5 million people - to improve their living standard using soaring oil revenues. The 53 nation African Union will hold its next summit in the Egyptian resort of Sharm El-Sheikh on June 30 and July 1. Increasing the supply of drinking water will be the key theme, the AU said yesterday. Benin's electoral commission yesterday delayed the result of local elections in the west African state, seen as a test of its reform-minded president. The results had been due to be announced on Tuesday. Britain said yesterday it will give Ethiopia £133 million this year to help the Horn of Africa country try to achieve the UN Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Some of the money will be used to send one million children to school. An Egyptian court has fined a leading independent Egyptian editor $2 000 for publishing a report in the daily al-Badeel on labour problems inside the nation's state-owned news agency.

TITLE: Police divisions must unite to fight members' corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLICE FORCES (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); CRIME PREVENTION (73%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (69%)
TEXT: SAPS and Metropolitan police departments should work together to fight corruption in law enforcement, according to the SA Crime Quarterly. "Important issues that need to be addressed are the disciplinary code within the metro police departments, the lack of investigative powers granted MPD (metropolitan police department) officers and SAPS's failure over the past seven years to effectively implement any relevant strategies," the report said. It also said that the police organised crime unit which replaced the Anti-Corruption Unit (ACU) in 2002 did not live up to the work of the ACU. "Data available from 2006/07 show a total of 222 members suspended for corruption and fraud that financial year. This must be compared with the 1 048 corruption arrests and 193 convictions led by the ACU in 2000." SAPS spent between 2001 and 2007 developing The Corruption and Fraud Prevention Plan. It only began being rolled out in September 2007, and is still incomplete. The "obscene" delay, which "combined with the misleading approach to reporting, raises serious questions about political will to tackle corruption in the organisation", the report stated. However, it "must be viewed in a positive light," it said. "One of the most exciting aspects of the plan is its leaning towards public education on police corruption. Through as yet undecided means, the SAPS hopes to educate the public about police corruption and the mechanisms it will put in place to combat it." The plan will include a SAPS anti-corruption hotline. "Other promising new tools include exit plans to members whose hands are already dirtied by corruption. courtney.brooks@inl.co.za

TITLE: Province to probe corruption in Western Cape Taxi Council, says Fransman
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); MISCONDUCT (78%); TAXICABS & LIMOUSINES (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%)
TEXT: THE department of transport and public works is to probe allegations of corruption and abuse of resources by the Western Cape Taxi Council, MEC Marius Fransman said yesterday. Briefing the media on the ongoing problems plaguing the council following the expulsion of its chairman Junaid Peters and the dissolution of its executive, he said he had also ordered officials to reopen its Athlone offices today after they were closed for about four weeks when members of rival taxi associations Cata and Codeta stormed them. Last week, the taxi industry called for an urgent conference after the removal of Peters. Peters was expelled by the SA National Taxi Council (Santaco) for failing to fulfil his national duties as chairman of the Western Cape council. He has also been expelled from the Mitchells Plain Taxi Forum for serious misconduct. "We will be investigating allegations that people (wanting to recapitalise their old vehicles) are paying the taxi council. The allegations are that people are paying R12 500 to taxi council members," said Fransman. The department is also going to investigate allegations that council members are abusing resources and money for their own personal gain. "We are going to investigate all those issues. There's a lot of smoke and mirror stuff here and things that need explaining," said Fransman. Fezile Mbambo, an official in the department said the council would also have its own investigation. Fransman added that he fully endorsed and recognised the "democratically" elected council and its structures and also understood the frustrations faced by members on the ground. "I've got full confidence in the council until their term of office ends and it can end at any time. I've also got full confidence in Cata, Codeta and the Mitchells Plain Taxi Forum. My focus is not on individuals. My focus is on the bodies and council," said Fransman. Asked what his position was on the allegations by the Mitchells Plain Taxi Forum that Peters was behind the recent taxi conflicts in the area, Fransman said the matter should be left to the police to investigate. babalo.ndenze@inl.co.za

TITLE: Rasool praises civil servants for 'thankless job well done', dismisses corruption claims
SUBJECT: CIVIL SERVICES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (69%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (68%); BACK OFFICE OPERATIONS (61%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (52%)
TEXT: DESPITE the job being a thankless one, honest and hardworking public servants should be saluted for their efforts to improve the lives of citizens and not be tarnished with an incorrect image of a corrupt service. These were the messages Premier Ebrahim Rasool and public service commissioner Norman Maharaj conveyed when a number of civil servants and government department heads gathered in the city yesterday to celebrate Africa Public Service Day. Rasool praised public servants for enduring severe pressure in their daily work and for their service to the public. The celebrations also presented them with an opportunity to reflect on their tasks and to measure the expectations of the service, he said. Rasool said that with a few exceptions, African countries had prospered over the past 10 years; their average economic growth stood at 5% and that all this was thanks to the hard work of people in the public service. "Elements of non-democracy are eliminated all the time. Some resist democracy because they want to rule on and on, but those are the dying kicks because they know their time has come," Rasool said. He condemned the recent xenophobic attacks as un-African and said it came as a huge shock, given that South Africa was behind the notion of the African Renaissance. "But if that was the negative, then the positive was that South Africa's public service, together with NGOs and churches and other people rallied to this tragedy and disaster to give of themselves, to give their time, sacrificing their comfort, to rise to the challenge as the police did. "That's the pride we carry with our work. Imagine what it means to feed 19 000 three meals a day at 76 locations in a politically contested environment. But that's the work that you have been able to do - seeing to the comfort of people and then the hard work of persuading people to be re-integrated and going back to those communities," Rasool said. Maharaj said there has been huge improvement in the public service over the years and that a general perception of a corrupt service was wrong. He praised civil servants for the work they did and said they should regard their roles as important, irrespective of the functions they performed. "Both sides play an important role. The people in the front line and the people in the back offices, people in management . All of us play a critically important role in terms of keeping the public service together. We work as a team," he said. aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: ANC women will be behind Zuma in his corruption trial
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (90%); ELECTIONS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (73%)
TEXT: ANC president Jacob Zuma will enjoy the full backing of the ANC Women's League (ANCWL) during his upcoming corruption trial, newly elected league president Angie Motshekga has announced. The Gauteng Education MEC pointed out that ANCWL members were "ANC members first" and therefore bound by the party's resolution to "find ways of expressing support" for Zuma. Voting was closer than many predicted, but in the end Motshekga triumphed over outgoing league secretary-general Bathabile Dlamini by 295 votes in an overnight ballot at their national conference in Bloemfontein. Motshekga, who also serves on the national executive and national working committees, takes over from Home Affairs Minister Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula, who did not stand for re-election. The outcome now sees both subordinate structures of the ANC - the youth and the women's leagues - positioned firmly behind Zuma. It also completes the purge of supporters of President Thabo Mbeki from top party structures. The scene was set for a two-horse race after former league president Winnie Madikizela-Mandela failed to make it on to the ballot. Her popularity did not translate into votes and she failed to get the 889 (25%) votes required. Only 427 of the 3 409 delegates supported her comeback bid. The announcement of Motshekga's victory was met with a spectacle reminiscent of Zuma's triumph in Polokwane. Thousands of delegates erupted into euphoric singing, dancing, ululating and whistle-blowing. Pleas for order were drowned out as hundreds of delegates swamped the stage, some waving hastily made placards of derision or support. This, despite repeated warnings that such "unofficial canvassing placards" would not be tolerated. Officials even threatened on Saturday to disqualify a candidate in whose name such behaviour took place. Nosipho Ntwanambi was elected deputy president; South Africa's ambassador to the Netherlands, Hlengiwe Mkhize, was made treasurer general; and Sisisi Tolashe was voted into the post of secretary-general.

TITLE: Judge's findings on corruption in Eastern Cape 'part of political smear campaign'
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); JUDGES (89%); ELECTIONS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (75%); EXECUTIVES (71%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (70%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (63%)
TEXT: Pretoria: Top politicians fingered in an explosive report on corruption in the former administration of the Eastern Cape say the "findings" are nothing more than a political smear campaign by political enemies out to discredit them. Three of the four ANC top brass named in the report are foes of Eastern Cape Premier Nosimo Balindlela, who meanwhile is poised to be axed from her post at the behest of the ANC's national executive committee (NEC). The report, compiled by a commission headed by Judge Ronnie Pillay, reportedly implicates the former chief executive officer of the Eastern Cape Development Corporation, Mcebisi Jonas; Sports Minister Makhenkesi Stofile, who is also a former Eastern Cape premier; Eastern Cape ANC chairperson Stone Sizani; and ANC NEC member and former economic development MEC Enoch Godongwana in multimillion rand irregularities. They demanded a retraction of the allegations by noon yesterday, pointing out they had not been afforded an opportunity to answer the accusations, but this deadline passed without a word from Pillay. "It (the report) was an attempt to sustain a particular image of certain individuals and deal with them politically and it's really sad," Jonas said yesterday. He said it was very suspicious that the report was leaked at the time that there was tremendous upheaval taking place within ANC structures in the Eastern Cape. The report was "leaked" on the eve of last weekend's critical NEC meeting that mooted getting rid of Balindlela, who is a staunch ally of President Thabo Mbeki and is blamed for failing to come to grips with chronic problems of maladministration in the impoverished province. Sizani, too, backed Mbeki, but is understood to have mended fences with the so-called Zuma camp in the region during the past few months. Ironically, Jonas is tipped as a possible future premier of the province and while some view Godongwana as a contender to take over from Balindlela, he is thought likely to be destined for a national Cabinet post after next year's elections. The men's legal representative, Lister Nuku, confirmed yesterday that Pillay had not retracted the allegations contained in the report. He earlier threatened to launch an urgent court application for "appropriate declaratory relief" and punitive costs if the allegations were not withdrawn. Pillay himself declined to comment on the matter, stating that the report was there "for everybody to see". The Daily Dispatch newspaper, meanwhile, quoted presidential spokesperson Mukoni Ratshitanga as saying the premier had to refer such allegations to a law enforcement agency that could then decide about the "admissibility and veracity of information contained in the report". The Pillay report, which contained extracts from an earlier investigation by the Auditor General's office, found that loans were granted by the Eastern Cape Development Corporation "without adhering to the prescribed policies". The report also noted that outstanding balances on these loans were written off. Cosatu said yesterday that while allegations of corruption must be taken seriously, the circumstances under which the information had come to light could also not be ignored.

TITLE: 'Scorpions needed to fight police corruption'
CITY: PRETORIA, SOUTH AFRICA (90%); CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); PUBLIC HEARINGS (67%)
TEXT: Pretoria: Police corruption is likely to sky rocket if the Scorpions are closed down, the Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation (CSVR) said in a submission to Parliament that calls for the elite crime-fighting unit not to be disbanded. "The SA Police Service is already riddled with corruption and is very bad at addressing the issue," CSVR senior researcher David Bruce argued. He said corruption in the service could only be properly addressed if investigating units, with the "investigative sophistication" of the Scorpions, remained independent. Their dissolution would undermine public confidence and the effectiveness of the criminal justice system. The CSVR submission is one of many the chairperson of the National Assembly's safety and security committee, Maggie Sotyu, expects to be waiting for her when she returns to Parliament on Tuesday. The public has till Monday to make submissions on whether the Directorate of Special Operations (Scorpions) should be closed and merged into the South Africa Police Service. l Sotyu and her justice committee counterpart Yunus Carrim plan public hearings in Cape Town from August 6 to 8.

TITLE: Corruption is on the decline, says government
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%)
TEXT: Johannesburg: Government rejected allegations by the Public Service Commission that it was riddled with corruption, arguing instead that there had been a decline in graft. Public Service and Administration director-general Richard Levin said: "Our actual experience of corruption is that it is marginally on the decline," he said adding that the "public sector was no more unethical or corrupt than the rest of society was." His minister, Geraldine Fraser-Moleketi, also argued that the government's multi-sectoral approach to fighting corruption had contributed to anti-corruption reforms in South Africa. - Political Bureau

TITLE: Summit focuses on ethics to curb corruption
SUBJECT: CHILDREN (91%); ETHICS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); PRICE FIXING (90%); ANTITRUST & TRADE LAW (87%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (78%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (77%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (77%); CARTELS (71%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (69%); WAGES & SALARIES (65%); UNEMPLOYMENT RATES (65%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (65%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (54%); INTEREST RATES (51%); ECONOMIC NEWS (51%)
TEXT: JOHANNESBURG: The only way to teach children ethics is by example. "Children learn about ethics and values primarily through observation of adult behaviour," said honourary professor of education at Wits, Jonathan Jansen. "The kind of husband my daughter will choose will depend crucially on how I love her mother, not on a module," he told the third National Anti-Corruption Summit in Boksburg on Tuesday. He questioned what children were learning from the corruption trial of Jacob Zuma. Jansen noted that the "iconic picture" for his generation was that of dying pupil Hector Pieterson being carried during the 1976 school uprisings, but warned the iconic picture for this generation was that of a Mozambican burning in xenophobic attacks. He was "bitterly disappointed" with the lack of leaders speaking out against those attacks. Deputy Education Minister Enver Surty emphasised the need both for role models and for more than just speaking about values. The president of the National Professional Teachers' Organisation, Dave Balt, said teaching ethics meant infusing ethics into the practice of teaching". The summit strongly criticised price-fixing and business collusion. Black Sash national advocacy programme manager, Nkosikhulule Nyembezi, said price-fixing and cartel activity took place amidst unemployment, low wages, higher fuel prices and interest rates and chronic poverty. Participants at the summit resolved to call for laws to block companies found guilty of price fixing and collusion from state tenders. Delegates also reiterated a call for the Competition Act to be changed to hold individuals accountable for such behaviour.

TITLE: ANC audit finds corruption and fraud with membership and AGMs
SUBJECT: AUDITS (93%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%)
TEXT: forms were not audited as some were attached to renewal forms. l In the Overberg, four branches doubled or trebled their membership immediately after their launch AGMs. In their summary, the audit team also said: "The draft audit report in terms of the outcome clearly points out corruption and fraud regarding membership, branches went to AGMs without achieving quorums and payment of membership. "In the Boland, this happened mostly after the disbandment of the REC (regional executive). Out of the 39 branches formed, 37 were approved under the supervision of the dissolved REC. "Clearly, we welcome the draft audit report. In fact, it endorsed our argument that a team from national must be deployed as a matter of urgency to legitimise the process leading up to the two outstanding regional conferences and the provincial conference." The report, leaked to the Cape Times, came in the wake of accusations that branch and regional AGMs had been rigged in favour of Skwatsha being elected provincial chairman. Meanwhile, Boland's regional conference was postponed for the fifth time at the weekend. No date has yet been set for the Dullah Omar region as it is struggling to have the required 70% of its branches hold AGMs. Regional conferences must be held before the provincial elective conference can take place. aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: ANC national audit finds corruption and fraud in province
SUBJECT: AUDITS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); INDICTMENTS (53%)
TEXT: AN ANC national audit committee has recommended that the Western Cape Provincial Executive headed by Mcebisi Skwatsha should be dissolved because of corruption and fraud. The audit also found that the party's provincial secretariat should be held responsible for the party's sorry state of affairs. It also wants two outstanding regional conferences and the provincial conference to be run by the ANC national office instead of Skwatsha and the provincial executive, "to legitimise the process". These findings are in a summary by an ANC national audit team - Errol Present, Mandla Dlamini and Mandla Twala - which earlier this month investigated the party's membership and branches in the province. Messages left for Skwatsha were not returned. "There is no need for the PEC (provincial executive committee) to operate further; (it) must be dissolved because the audit report is an indictment against the PEC. "The (Western Cape) provincial secretariat must take full responsibility for the sorry state of the organisation in the province," the committee stated in its findings. The team found that there had been widespread corruption and fraud regarding membership and that many branches held annual general meetings (AGM) without achieving quorums, among other things. During auditing from August 5 to August 9 at the ANC provincial offices, the team found: l Some branches were launched and held AGMs with participation by under-age teenagers. l Some membership application forms were tampered with or not signed by members themselves. l Some AGMs were held without the chairpersons, secretaries or their deputies present. l There were no deposit slips as proof of payment for membership and 70% claimed to have made a bulk payment. l Expired membership

TITLE: Traffic officials warned of price of corruption if found guilty of bribery
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); ROAD TRANSPORTATION SAFETY (89%); TRANSPORTATION LAW (78%); DRIVING & TRAFFIC LAWS (76%); EVIDENCE (73%)
TEXT: COMMUNITY Safety MEC Patrick McKenzie says he has received several complaints about alleged bribery of traffic officials and warned that if arrested and convicted of such a crime, they will pay a "very high price for such negative behaviour". In a review of Transport Month and the ongoing work of the Department of Community Safety, McKenzie appealed to commuters, road users, drivers and passengers to be extra careful when on the road. "Let us ensure that every day and night is road safety. An ideal situation is for there to be no accidents and no deaths on our roads and for us to reach this goal we must take control of our safety which means driving within the road limit, not under the influence of alcohol or drugs, no speeding and for commuters to also respect road signs and crossings designated for road users," said McKenzie. He said road traffic law enforcement officers had a large responsibility to implement the laws which ensure safer travel. "I want our law enforcement to at all times ensure that the safety of our road users is ensured and for this to be carried out effectively they must implement the laws of road traffic usage and safety. "However, I am also aware of verbal complaints of alleged bribery involving police and traffic officers and, while I may not have factual evidence of such, it does not mean that either the Department of Community Safety or myself as MEC of Community Safety ignores such allegations. "I can assure you that government treats this very seriously and we do look at strategies at eradicating corruption and bribery deals. "I must say that this is no easy process and it starts with us as people not to be involved in bribery as this crime impacts negatively on our road and traffic safety," McKenzie said. He appealed to law enforcement officers is to wear their badge and uniform "with respect and dignity" and not to "bring dishonour upon yourselves" by being corrupt. "If arrested and convicted of such a crime, then you will pay a very high price for such negative behaviour." People may report crime or corruption on 08600 10111, the Community Safety Department on 021 483 4332 or national government's toll- free number 0800 701701.

TITLE: Balfour tried to halt prisons corruption probe - claim
SUBJECT: PRISONS (92%); CORRECTIONS (92%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (73%); APPROVALS (72%)
TEXT: CORRECTIONAL Services Minister Ngconde Balfour is alleged by a high-ranking officer to have ordered his new director-general, Xoliswa Sibeko, to halt a probe into two regional commissioners her predecessor, Vernie Petersen, suspended pending the findings of a corruption probe. Balfour denied the allegations yesterday. An MP, who has asked not to be named, has said that he has received similar information from other officials in the department, while James Selfe (DA) says the allegations are so serious he will be writing to Speaker Gwen Mahlangu-Nkabinde. "The (portfolio) committee on correctional services must meet as a matter of urgency to discuss the allegations," Selfe said. But ministry spokesperson Simphiwe Xako said last night: "We deny that the minister is interfering in the department's administrative processes. "As a political principal of the Department of Correctional Services, the minister fully respects and recognises the powers and functions of the new national commissioner. The minister believes in (Sibeko's) autonomy." The high-ranking Correctional Services officer, who has also asked not to be named, alleges that Balfour tried to stop the investigation into the suspended regional commissioners and to reverse the transfers of senior managers effected by Petersen. It is understood that Sibeko told Balfour she needed time to study the facts before taking any decision on halting the probe into the regional commissioner for Mpumalanga, Limpopo and North West, Andrew Gillingham, and the regional commissioner for the Free State and the Northern Cape, Zacharia Modise. They were suspended by Petersen two months ago on the grounds of a preliminary report from the Special Investigating Unit, which is investigating the alleged rigging of Correctional Services contracts worth millions of rands. Sibeko, formerly the director-general of sport, and Petersen were swopped two weeks ago in a controversial move approved by Deputy President Baleka Mbete while she was acting president and President Kgalema Motlanthe was out of the country.

TITLE: Former ANC premier to face charges of corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BRIBERY (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (75%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (73%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (50%)
TEXT: PRETORIA: ANC heavyweight and former Limpopo premier Ngoako Ramatlhodi will face charges of corruption. This was confirmed last night by National Prosecuting Authority spokesperson Tlali Tlali. "The Scorpions took a decision to prosecute Mr Ramatlhodi. He, however, has made representations which are being considered by the acting National Director of Public Prosecutions, advocate Moko-tedi Mpshe," said Tlali, who would not elaborate on the nature of the charges at this stage, other than to confirm that it involved alleged corruption. Ramatlhodi, a member of the ANC's national executive committee, earlier applied to the Pretoria High Court for the second time to be admitted as an advocate. His first bid was in 2004 when it was rumoured that he was due to take over from the then prosecutions head, Bulelani Ngcuka. A corruption probe involving Ramatlhodi had already been ongoing for a few years. In 2004, Judge Hekkie Daniels postponed Ramatlhodi's application to be admitted as an advocate indefinitely and ordered that the matter may not be enrolled for hearing until such time as the probe involving him (Ramatlhodi) had been disposed of. Now, nearly four years down the line, Ramatlhodi has once again turned to the court in a bid to be admitted as an advocate. This time however, the Pretoria Society of Advocates asked the court for leave to intervene, stating in an affidavit before court that "from enquiries made to the office of the National Prosecuting Authority, a decision has been made to proffer criminal charges against the applicant (Ramatlhodi)." Ramatlhodi's application earlier this month was removed from the roll by Judge Dion Basson but he can still enroll the matter at a later stage. In his latest application, Ramatlhodi had cited the Directorate of Special Operations as an interested party. In an affidavit signed by him in September this year, Ramatlhodi denied any wrong doing. "From press reports, the serious allegation is made that I received a bribe of R5 million and that I have an interest in an entity which acquired a contract from the provincial government of Limpopo while I was Premier. These are scurrilous allegations without any thrust whatsoever."

TITLE: Opposition parties hail ruling on corruption charges, call on ANC president to step down
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (55%)
SUBJECT: POLITICS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); CONSPIRACY (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (89%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); RULE OF LAW (78%); CRIMINAL LAW (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%)
TEXT: OPPOSITION parties made maximum campaign mileage out of the latest blow to hit the ruling party's president. Jacob Zuma's supporters however stuck to their conspiracy claims. The DA insisted that the ruling party should, on "moral" grounds, reconsider its decision to make Zuma its presidential candidate. DA leader Helen Zille called on Zuma to step aside as presidential candidate. "The NPA must immediately dismiss speculation that it is willing to drop the charges against Zuma and broker a special deal for him. If he (Zuma) is to honour the undertaking in the ANC's manifesto to step up the fight against corruption in its ranks, he should renounce his candidature for the presidency." The breakaway Congress of the People questioned the ANC's political maturity. "Today's decision by the SCA indicates to the nation that the ANC failed to provide mature political leadership and has set a very dangerous precedent in which a sitting head of state could be removed at any time depending on the whim and mood of the party's executive committee," Cope said. Although Zuma's allies - including Cosatu, the SA Communist Party and the Young Communist League (YCL) - vowed to respect the decision, they are unyielding in their insistence that their candidate for the country's top job is innocent and the victim of a political conspiracy. The SACP also called for an investigation into the "behaviour of the National Prosecuting Authority over the past eight years in the manner in which it has handled this case including political interference by past and present political office bearers" as part of the government's overhaul of the criminal justice system. The allies vowed to continue demanding that charges against Zuma be dropped because they were "convinced" that Zuma's prosecution was "politically motivated". YCL spokesperson Castro Ngobese urged the NPA to join efforts to find a "political solution" to the matter. IFP president Mangosuthu Buthelezi said it was "vital" that Zuma had his day in court to remove the "Sword of Damocles" hanging over him. "Unless this matter is now dealt with swiftly and the rule of law is allowed to take its course, our country will be subject to a seemingly perpetual political crisis. There cannot be a political solution to a judicial question", Buthelezi said. UDM leader Bantu Holomisa said the ruling "restores the credibility of the NPA and puts the post Polokwane ANC lynch-mobs to shame". "The voters of this country must ask themselves whether they can afford to see Mr Zuma taking an oath as a new President at the Union Buildings while he is a wanted man," he said. Independent Democrats leader Patricia De Lille appealed to ANC supporters to respect the decision and said the judgment helped deepen our democracy. "The principle of innocent until proven guilty also applies here but at a moral level the ANC must reconsider whether putting Zuma up for the presidency of the country while being prosecuted won't impact on their election campaign," said De Lille. ACDP justice spokesperson Steve Swart suggested that the ruling "exonerated" the Cabinet, former justice ministers Penuell Maduna and Brigitte Mabandla, along with Mbeki - who was axed by the ANC on the basis of Nicholson's finding. Political analyst Somadoda Fikeni said the ANC was under renewed pressure to present Zuma as a "credible" candidate for the presidency.

TITLE: Corruption horror
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL ASYLUM (90%); BRIBERY (78%); HOMELESSNESS (76%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (66%)
TEXT: I would like to express my horror at the corruption mentioned in the article "Asylum seekers still face long delays at Nyanga centre" (January 15). Why are Home Affairs officials simply watching it and not trying to end it? Why are the police not arresting people who are demanding bribes from asylum seekers? I work for an organisation called |U-turn Homeless Ministries in Claremont, which helps rehabilitate homeless people. On two occasions I took a young Zimbabwean man to the Nyanga Home Affairs office in order to get his asylum-seekers' visa. On both occasions the goal was to sleep overnight on the street so he would be at the front of the queue. On both occasions he was denied entry to the building due to the corruption mentioned in the article. This has been going on for months, ever since asylum seekers were forced to apply at the Nyanga Home Affairs office. This corruption is literally happening in broad daylight. Foreigners are forced to go to a recent xenophobic hot spot, to risk their lives and to be intimidated by corrupt individuals to obtain their documents. Why will nobody act on this? Sean Parker U-turn Homeless Ministries Claremont

TITLE: Nurturing values in public service a vital part of fight against corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (89%); ETHICS (78%); REGULATORY COMPLIANCE (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ELECTIONS (77%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (77%); POLITICS (77%); LEGISLATION (76%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (71%); AGENCY RULEMAKING (63%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (60%)
TEXT: Perhaps things really do have to get a little worse before they get better. Worse in the sense that public-sector corruption has taken its toll on public trust and better in that political leaders come to realise their achievements are short-lived if the citizens do not trust their institutions and elected leaders. This possibly explains why the ANC has re-opened the debate on corruption in the public sector before a crucial national election. And a good thing, too, since the need for a renewed focus on ethics in public life is vital to any maturing democracy. Serving the public interest is fundamental to public office. Public officials are always required to assess whether they are in a situation where their private interests might improperly influence the way they perform their job. And public trust is often said to be the cornerstone of good governance. Certain conditions provide an enabling environment for conflicts of interest situations and corruption to transpire. The conflation of party and state provides numerous opportunities for elected and unelected officials to take advantage of their public positions for personal benefit. Black economic empowerment (BEE), designed to promote black ownership of the economy, while relevant and necessary, has also been criticised for its unintended consequences. These being nepotism, cronyism and the creation of a small but wealthy politically connected empowerment elite. The ruling ANC stands accused by opposition parties, but also by its tripartite alliance partners, of allowing members to use the party as a means to business success. In addition, despite their public positions, many elected and non-elected officials possess private business interests in the form of shares, directorships and partnerships. In a 2006 report, the auditor-general found significant overlap between public life and private business interests, with six out of 10 civil servants holding private business interests in South Africa. These situations create huge potential for conflicts of interest. When public officials are distracted from their jobs and the greater public interest, or corrupted by their private interests, resources are diverted away from service delivery, with the poorest and most marginalised citizens in our society bearing the consequences. South Africa's politicians unwittingly contribute to their own demise and that of their institutions and the public good when they refuse to regulate their own behaviour. If citizens believe that their elected officials fail to act for the public good, or that they misuse their office to benefit themselves, the public trust vital to the wellbeing of institutions is eroded. Without strong motivation for self-regulation, there is a greater need to tighten regulations. And in this regard, there is reason to be cheerful if one looks to the recent commitments made towards cleaning up public office. The Public Service Commission has drafted new regulations that will deal with bribes and kickbacks in the public service to ensure that tendering processes become more transparent. Legislation to regulate the conflicts of interest of judges was passed last year and should be implemented soon. And, in a revealing moment, the ANC president, Jacob Zuma, recently placed corruption at centre stage at the ANC 2009 manifesto launch in the Eastern Cape when he promised to run a graft-free government and root out corruption within party and government. He circuitously questioned the party's deployment practice, which places loyal members in key public sector positions, stating that public servants should rather be in the correct positions and that we should not deploy our friends. The ruling party's manifesto is somewhat thin on the fight against corruption but does promise new measures to prevent procurement and tendering corruption. But are all these pre-election promises sufficient? Widening the scope of regulations and introducing harsher penalties for breaches is only part of the solution. Regulations and penalties are important because they act as deterrents and, importantly, they help to guide the behaviour of public officials to make the right choices. However, a less tangible factor crucial to realising cleaner government involves self-regulation. The success of our democratic institutions in meeting their obligations to citizens depends in part on a dedicated and incorruptible team of public officials who embrace the spirit of public service. This involves placing the public interest before narrow self-interests, regulating one's behaviour and removing oneself from conflict of interest situations as they arise. South Africa's codes of conduct that establish and inform ethics in public life focus largely on compliance to a set of rules and limitations, such as the disclosure of financial interests. Yet this "top-down", compliance-based approach places little emphasis on the over-arching values that ought to guide the behaviour of people in public positions. If public officials do not own these values they come to view conflicts of interest regulations, like asset disclosure, as an imposition on their individual freedoms, or simply as cumbersome bureaucratic necessities of public life. Instead, a values-based approach can play an important role in the moral life of institutions by laying the foundations for ethical conduct and informing members of the rationale for such behaviour. In South Africa, the compliance-based approach has constituted the first step towards deepening ethics in public life. And, to a large extent, it has been successful in its implementation. However, as democratic institutions mature it becomes increasingly important that broad consensus about societal values is reached - especially with respect to our expectations of people in public positions. Without consensus as to what constitutes principled and ethical behaviour, there is little to guide public officials. However, when a core set of values is established, these questions are more easily addressed, and a suitable pattern of behaviour becomes entrenched. l Schulz-Herzenberg is a senior researcher on the Conflicts of Interest Project at the Institute for Security Studies (ISS) Corruption and Governance Programme in Cape Town.

TITLE: rules favour informalisation, corruption
SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); EMPLOYMENT (90%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (78%); REFUGEES (78%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (77%); PUBLIC POLICY (76%); UNEMPLOYMENT RATES (75%); ECONOMIC NEWS (75%); LABOR SHORTAGES (73%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (73%); MINIMUM WAGE (72%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (72%); CITY GOVERNMENT (72%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%); LICENSES & PERMITS (70%); NURSES & NURSING (64%); CITIES (61%)
TEXT: SOUTH AFRICA can gain from offering more resources and legitimacy to immigrants, academics suggest, but the country's citizens meanwhile suffer from restrictions on the rights of foreign nationals. According to a draft submission by the Forced Migration Studies Programme at Wits University to the United Nations Development Programme's Human Development Report 2009, South Africa's immigration policy should be revised if the country is to maximise the benefit of having migrants. According to Loren Landau, director of the Wits programme and one of the paper's co-authors, migrants could uplift the South African economy if they were permitted to develop and use their skills. While immigration generally helped development, keeping migrants illegal, he said, "has harmed the country in a number of ways". For example, the paper reported, "Many foreign citizens without the right to work - but with the skills and willingness to do so - accept positions where they are paid below the minimum wage |or work in inhumane |conditions". And many with work permits were still turned away from jobs for which they were well-qualified. As a result, current policy was driving processes of "informalisation and illegality", including corruption, depression of wages and poor working conditions, which harmed South African workers and undermined unions. Meanwhile, South Africa's shortage of skilled labour could be alleviated by employing qualified immigrants. Landau cited teachers and engineers among those currently forced to work well below their abilities. And, despite South Africa's "acute" nursing shortage, "thousands of refugee nurses remain unemployed because they cannot prove their qualifications", the paper reported. Scapegoating of foreigners persisted, and risked preventing South Africans from holding government responsible "for their shortcomings and failed promises". An exclusionary approach would also limit immigrants' investment in their communities, commitment to improving them, and even civil order. "People who do not feel welcome in South Africa's urban society are less likely to respect the rules and institutions dedicated to governing it." Rather, South Africa would benefit from "an approach that aims to improve the entitlements and capabilities of all residents, regardless of their origin", which would allow the country to better address the unemployment and inequality it currently faced. Therefore, immigrants should have easier access to documentation and social services, and skilled workers should be fast-tracked for South African certification. Future regulation would also depend on increased co-ordination among government bodies, which currently suffered from "a paucity of |collaboration". The paper cited apparent unwillingness on the part of Home Affairs to disclose data on migrants to municipalities, for example, which could hamper city planning efforts. Landau said ultimately, migration policy should recognise the interconnectedness of the entire region's economy. "Until a line connecting (South Africa and Southern Africa) has been made, South African migration policy is never going to be quite right." christina.taylor@inl.co.za
