TEXT: A Spanish judge has named 37 people as suspects in a corruption investigation involving the main opposition Popular Party. They will be questioned on suspicion of tax fraud, influence peddling and bribery in business deals involving town halls. Nine people are missing in Tartagal, Argentina, after a mudslide and flooding swept away a railway bridge and dozens of houses. A ship detained off Cyprus has breached a United Nations ban on Iranian arms exports, Cyprus's Foreign Minister Markos Kyprianou announced, refusing to specify what had been found on the Cypriot-flagged Monchegorsk, which United States officials suspect was delivering arms to Hamas militants in Gaza. Taiwan's former first lady Wu Shu-bian has admitted laundering $2.2 million and forging documents, in a judicial process that has seen her husband stage a jailhouse hunger strike. A German court has ruled that a Jewish man from Florida, Hans Sachs, is the rightful owner of a rare poster the Gestapo seized in 1938 - setting the stage for the return of the collection of 12 500 posters taken by the Nazis, now worth at least $5.85 million. More than 350 European cities - including London and Paris - have signed an European Union climate change agreement to cut carbon dioxide emissions by more than 20% by 2020. The Cern giant particle collider built to reproduce the "Big Bang" will be restarted in September to allow time for repairs.

TITLE: Picture President Zuma on a state visit, trying to fend off questions on corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (90%); SCANDALS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); TESTIMONY (89%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); INDICTMENTS (77%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); WITNESSES (77%); CONSPIRACY (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); SUITS & CLAIMS (76%); MONEY LAUNDERING (72%); CROSS EXAMINATIONS (68%); LIBEL & SLANDER (62%)
TEXT: Jacob Zuma's statement the other day that for him to step down as the ANC's presidential candidate (in the light of the corruption charges he faces) would set a bad precedent is, frankly, nonsense. The opposite is the case. It would set an excellent precedent, showing that Zuma placed the interests of his party and his country ahead of his personal ambitions. As it is, it appears almost certain that we are going to have a new head of state who is an accused, facing 16 charges of fraud, corruption, racketeering and money laundering. Israel's departing prime minister, Ehud Olmert, is going for precisely the same reason. He stepped aside from last week's Israeli election because he is to be indicted for illegally accepting "cash envelopes" from a New York businessman while he was mayor of Jerusalem. Like Zuma, Olmert insists he is innocent, but he says he is "proud to be a citizen of a country where the prime minister can be investigated like any other citizen". There's no hint of a bad precedent in that, no suggestion that anyone is conducting a conspiracy against him or has "thrown a dark cloud" at him with the aim of demolishing him, as Zuma has put it. Olmert is simply doing the right thing. The mistake Zuma and the ANC are making is to imagine, as his metaphor suggests, that the case against him is an insubstantial thing, a cloud that will blow over with time. It won't. Scandals don't go away if they are not resolved. They live on and periodically surge back to life as new bits of evidence are unearthed. As long as there is an unfinished story, there will be people who will keep digging and who will keep on exposing, so that the scandal will keep on suppurating and poisoning all around it. Even if Zuma and his supporters succeed in getting rid of the prosecutors in this case and installing a tame successor to Vusi Pikoli who will dutifully drop the charges against Zuma, it still won't go away. In Judge Chris Nicholson's wise words in his otherwise flawed judgment, if no proper investigation is held into the arms deal, "a cloud of scandal and suspicion" will remain. Just think on this: wherever Zuma goes, as president of South Africa, he will be unable to protect himself against accusations that he is a corrupt leader. Because he will not be able to bring a legal claim of libel or slander against any accuser, for to do so would involve having to go to court to testify and face cross-examination on the subject - which is precisely what Zuma has fought so long and so hard to avoid. Such an inability to defend one's integrity will surely be a most uncomfortable position for any head of state to be in as he travels. Many arguments are being advanced by Zuma's supporters to justify scrapping the charges against him. One is that the returning ANC exiles found themselves in dire financial circumstances, with no jobs and no homes to come back to, and that they had no choice but to seek help from business tycoons who were only too ready to ingratiate themselves with people they knew would soon be governing the country. This is certainly true, and no doubt many did seek and receive such help. One can also sympathise particularly with the position Zuma found himself in, with his multiple wives and many children and the fact that he was initially deployed to the provincial legislature of KwaZulu-Natal, at a lower salary than MPs received, so that he could help negotiate an end to the terrible political warfare raging there. But there is a critical difference between accepting such financial aid and misusing one's political position to secure contractual advantages for one's benefactors, which is what Zuma is accused of having done. Then again, it is said that Zuma was "small fry" in the arms deal compared with others who have not been charged. Maybe, but then the fault lies in the failure to pursue the other, bigger fish, not in the fact that Zuma and Schabir Shaik have been charged. It is also pertinent to ask, how small is small in this sprawling affair? Zuma is charged with having received 783 payments from Shaik totalling R4 072 499.85 between October 25, 1995, and July 1, 2005. The payments are itemised in the indictment in a 17-page "schedule of |benefits". As Paul Holden puts it in his excellent little pocketbook on the arms deal, if that schedule is ever presented in court and proved valid, it will indicate that Shaik was supporting Zuma's business affairs and lifestyle for almost a full decade, even after Zuma became deputy president with a substantial salary and for a full month after Shaik himself had been found guilty by Judge Hilary Squires. As Squires put it in his judgment, the two were functioning in a state of "mutually beneficial symbiosis". And the deals involved were certainly not small fry. The contract for the combat suites for the German corvettes cost us taxpayers R6.2 billion, and the asset forfeiture of R34 million provides a yardstick for the profits Shaik got out of the deals. Which of course is why he was sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment. Another suggestion is that the National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) should suspend charges against Zuma on the specific condition that the government institutes a full commission of inquiry into the arms deal immediately after assuming office after the election. It's an interesting suggestion, but there is one problem: the arms deal itself covers only about one-quarter of the charges against Zuma. The rest relate to other alleged deals in his 10-year relationship with Shaik. Willem Heath has published an article urging the NPA to ask itself whether it is in the public interest to continue with the prosecution of Zuma. Given that the country is in a state of transition and facing serious challenges, he clearly thinks it is not. A more objective question might be to ask whether it is in the public interest for someone facing such serious criminal charges to become president of the country in the first place. Particularly since there is a perfectly capable incumbent. l Sparks is a veteran journalist and political commentator.

TITLE: it's time to put the focus back on tackling corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATION (90%); POLITICS (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (72%); POLITICAL PARTIES (72%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (72%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (71%)
TEXT: The ink has barely dried on the legislation President Kgalema Motlanthe signed into law last month providing for the dissolution of the National Prosecuting Authority's Directorate of Special Operations (DSO), or Scorpions, and the establishment of a new anti-corruption unit within the South African Police Service (SAPS). Yet, as the nation's political parties unfurl their election manifestos and rally their bases, the DSO remains the focus of passionate, at times vituperative, debate on the boundaries of prosecutorial authority in the fight against public corruption. Opposition parties continue to accuse the ANC of dismantling the DSO to subvert investigations of corruption within the party's ranks, and have pledged to reinstate the unit if elected. The ANC, in kind, has reiterated its assertion that the DSO vindictively targeted ANC members, overstepped its mandate and used media leaks to tarnish the party's highest officials. In the wake of legislation terminating the unit, many questions remain, not the least of which concern the fate of its ongoing action against suspended national Police Commissioner Jackie Selebi. Yet while new challenges loom, the political discourse on the fate of the DSO appears trapped in stasis, locked in a debate over what the unit "was" without concomitant focus on the institution set to replace it - the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation (DPCI). Throughout this election season, the parties have variously assailed phantom versions of the DSO and DPCI - the former "unbridled" in its attack on the ANC, the latter "neutered" by its subservience to the SAPS - without crediting the changes incorporated into the bills during the legislative process, or conversely, the concerns they still fail to rectify. This may prove costly. Instead of laying the foundations for an anti-corruption regime capable of securing broad public support, this divisive discourse undermines the potential of any subsequent model (including a reincarnated DSO) to secure the public buy-in it may need to succeed. In truth, the legislation signed by Motlanthe includes safeguards absent from its first draft, yet insufficient to ameliorate concerns that it undermines the independence of the nation's anti-corruption bodies. This acknowledgment lacks the impact of competing pronouncements that the disbandment, or continued existence, of the DSO will precipitate a crisis, yet warrants recognition in any evaluation of the new unit's prospects for success. The overarching argument against the bills when they were introduced in May 2008 - that disbanding the DSO and reconstituting it under the SAPS would disrupt the prosecution-led "troika model" credited for the unit's success and usurp its institutional independence - remains cogent. Yet many of the supporting arguments proffered as evidence of the DPCI's inadequate design no longer apply. Those arguments rested on the contention that the bills concentrated undue authority in the national commissioner of police - an office called into doubt, if not disrepute, by the DSO's corruption charges against Selebi. In its initial form, the SAPS Amendment Bill empowered the national commissioner to appoint the head of the directorate, relegated that head to a lower rank than his DSO predecessor and eliminated the unit's authority to initiate investigations without a referral from the national commissioner. None of those provisions survived intact. The final legislation provided that the minister of safety and security, not the national commissioner, shall appoint the head of the directorate, elevated his rank to deputy national commissioner, and authorised him to initiate investigations without awaiting a referral. Taking cues from the Khampepe Commission, which sharply criticised the ministerial co-ordinating committee's efforts to facilitate the unit's co-operation with other law enforcement bodies, legislators also provided for a joint operational committee to monitor the unit's secondment of outside officers, and a retired judge to review complaints. Notwithstanding these changes, concerns regarding the new unit's independence and insulation from executive pressure persist. First, as deputy national commissioner, the head of the DPCI remains answerable to the national commissioner of police. The national commissioner, in turn, enjoys less protection against presidential removal than the national director of public prosecutions (NDPP), rendering him - and his selection for DPCI head - more vulnerable to executive pressure than his National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) counterpart. Second, under the new legislation, the national commissioner will function as the DPCI's accounting officer, thereby retaining control of the unit's finances and further circumscribing its independence. Third, public sparring between the DSO and SAPS over their respective mandates - and more recently, over the execution of subpoenas against the police in the Selebi investigation - renews concerns over the practical restraints prosecutors seconded to the new unit will face. The new legislation requires the NDPP to maintain a "dedicated component of prosecutors" to assist the DPCI in its investigations. It prohibits these "investigative" prosecutors, however, from participating in the subsequent prosecution of their targets. Whether this bifurcation of duties will relieve the turf wars between the SAPS and the NPA or merely restrict prosecutors' capacity to pursue public corruption without fear or favour remains to be seen. These are valid concerns. The problem is that rather than address them in a manner that acknowledges the bills' moderate improvements and existing shortcomings, the parties regress too easily into a debate over the fallibility of the DSO, or the forces that brought it down. This may not surprise; critics are loathe to cede credibility to the process that begot the bills, and proponents may fear that acknowledging the virtues of the DSO's independence will lend legitimacy to its pursuit of Selebi and Jacob Zuma. Neither does pre-election rhetoric generally err towards nuance. Nevertheless, the current discourse debilitates either unit's post-election sustainability by framing the debate in terms that predispose the "losing" constituency to deem the surviving body illegitimate. Each side's focus on curtailing the sins of the other tends to blur the distinction between the structural weaknesses of South Africa's anti-corruption framework and the failures of those individuals charged with implementing it. While the two certainly bear some relation (as inadequate safeguards foster conditions ripe for abuse by corrupt individuals), sustainable reforms must be designed to outlive any one set of "bad apples", a point often lost in the flurry of cross-accusations over corrupt police chiefs and overzealous prosecutors. More troubling still, the current discourse does not simply reinforce public divisions over the criminal justice sector; it appears to deepen them. Though ostensibly voicing structural concerns, the parties' words demarcate more contentious fault lines - the DSO vs ANC, the NPA vs SAPS - that leave increasingly little room for common ground. Those who support the DSO harbour a racist agenda; those who support the DPCI condone "crony politics", and "success" requires one side to vanquish the other. This cannot serve the country's anti-corruption interests. That conflicting views of the nation's law enforcement bodies will persist goes without saying. Yet debating the country's anti-corruption unit in terms that necessarily diminish, rather than develop, our mutual investment in its success does that unit a disservice. In the name of building public trust and legitimacy, it renders both more elusive. If the new administration, to be elected in April, is genuine about building a system of national integrity that tackles corruption in the public and private sector, then it has to prioritise the strengthening of the new anti-corruption body. This has to happen away from the electioneering and focus on individual politicians which clouded the debate on the dissolution of the DSO. Rather, it requires a renewed effort by the ministries of Justice and Safety and Security to recommit to integrity and build support for the DPCI by both directly engaging the concerns of its critics and supporting the institution in its investigation of corrupt elites. l Quarcoo is a research volunteer in the Corruption and Governance Programme, Institute of Security Studies, Cape Town, and a Harvard University Sheldon Fellow.

TITLE: I have a feeling corruption in football goes right to the top
SUBJECT: SOCCER (91%); SCANDALS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SPORTS OFFICIATING (90%); SPORTS TAMPERING (78%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); FINES & PENALTIES (75%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (74%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); TOURNAMENTS (71%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (57%)
TEXT: IN 2006 the football world was rocked by the Italian football scandal, which involved some of the country's top professional clubs. The scandal was uncovered in May 2006 when Italian police implicated then-league champions Juventus, AC Milan, Fiorentina and Lazio after a network was detected that showed corrupt relations between team managers and referee organisations. The clubs were accused of rigging games by selecting favourable referees for their matches. Juventus were stripped of their title and were demoted from the Serie A and the other clubs were fined and points were deducted in the outcome. AC Milan were banned from playing in the Champions League, but won an appeal and consequently went on to win the tournament by beating Liverpool in the final. Not so long ago South African football was rocked to the core by Operation Dribble. More than 40 people ranging from referees, linesmen, club owners and match commissioners were initially arrested. But, unlike than in Italy, only a couple of scoundrels were convicted - relatively small fry compared to some of the people who were investigated by police. It left everybody wondering what happened. Was this the only outcome of the scandal? Last week, two of South Africa's top referees, Jonas Nhlapo and Peter Mabuza, had polygraph tests. Mabuza passed his test, but Nhlapo failed and was subsequently suspended after failing to appear before a Safa hearing to explain the irregularities in his test. I believe a sane man with nothing to hide would have appeared at the hearing to explain himself. I am not an expert in the art of the polygraph test, but from what I have heard it could also respond negatively to nervousness. But Nhlapo never pitched to explain and something smells very fishy. Although the standard of refereeing has improved over the last couple of seasons, it was shocking in the past. But now, seemingly, with more games on television then ever before, the standard has improved immensely. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying everybody cheated when there were no television cameras around. On the contrary, I think the standard of refereeing has improved because of the hard work put in by Safa and its referee body. However, where there is smoke, there normally is fire. And in Nhlapo's case, it looks like something is about to explode and this might be the platform for the PSL, Safa and the police to redeem themselves after the horrendous mess they made of Operation Dribble. I have a feeling the corruption (and I believe there is) in our football probably goes right to the very top. And I have a feeling that the police know it too. I have a feeling Safa might be shell-shocked by Nhlapo's failed test. They have only said he is suspended because he didn't pitch for the hearing and I don't think they know the way forward. But I can show you the way ladies and gentlemen: time for another full-scale investigation into corruption in football. It's time to take the bull by the horns, forget about who you are investigating and throw the book at them. I have a feeling the outcome could be very big and could tarnish our already fragile reputation before next year's World Cup tournament. And that's maybe why they are stalling. Imagine if a scandal brings our football to its knees weeks before the opening game of the biggest sporting showpiece in the world. But the truth will have to come out somewhere, somehow; otherwise nobody will take this league seriously anymore and we will destroy everything that is good about it. hhhhh Meanwhile, Manchester United and Tottenham Hotspur square up in one of the most low-key League Cup finals for some time. With the league being so tight at the bottom, everybody, including Spurs, are focusing all their energy on the job of surviving. The high-profile Champions League fixtures earlier this week also took some of the gloss off the final. But Spurs, who beat Chelsea in last year's final, will be up for this game because a spot in the Uefa Cup is up for grabs. They won't qualify for Europe next season by ending high up on the log, so all they have to do is beat United. So I'm going with Spurs to surprise United on Sunday! john.goliath@inl.co.za

TITLE: Fighting corruption to be a priority at all levels for ANC, Zuma tells rally
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (89%); VOTERS & VOTING (87%); CORRUPTION (74%)
TEXT: seizure at the rally and was also treated at the hospital, Maxon said. Speaking after order had been restored, Zuma, with a garland around his neck, said the ANC would ensure that those included in its election candidates lists would not be slackers. "We will fight against laziness. We will fight against this from the national government down to the ward councillors," he said. "We won't stand people who think they are important after being elected. We will be answerable to our people." Speaking while rain lashed the stadium, Zuma also pledged that it would be a priority of the next ANC administration to fight corruption inside and outside the government. Many ANC supporters - including Zuma's daughter Duduzile, who was seated at the front of the stage - unfurled umbrellas and continued to cheer their leader on. "It's a time when the citizens of the country realise the power they have, the authority they have," Zuma said. "They have the power to put in and remove a government if they don't do what they are supposed to." There were "good reasons" why people should vote for the ANC, he said. "It has a vision, it has a future ... and it is in government." Zuma said making a cross for another party would be "a wasted vote". ANC policies were designed to remedy "weaknesses and loopholes". The ANC's manifesto was one for "the people of South Africa", Zuma said. The ANC would ensure that the resolutions taken at its national conference at Polokwane in December 2007 were implemented, Zuma said. Cosatu president Sidumo Dlamini called for peace and tolerance during the elections. The union federation would send the "bravest and most courageous comrades" to all voting stations to ensure the ANC's victory, he said. The retrenchment of workers, particularly those in mining, would be tackled. "We trust the ANC under the leadership of Zuma, who will rise up and (deal) with the problems we are facing," Dlamini said. Members of the ANC would not be intimidated, the party's provincial chairman, Zweli Mkhize, said. "Everyone has a home in the ANC - whites, blacks, Indians and coloureds. We will go to every area to campaign and will not be intimidated by anyone."

TITLE: 'no evidence of any corruption'
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FOOD BANKS & SOUP KITCHENS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); INTERVIEWS (75%); SUITS & CLAIMS (73%); LITIGATION (73%); LIBEL & SLANDER (73%); ELECTIONS (70%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (64%)
TEXT: Heinz Park soup kitchen organiser and pensioner Rosie Claasen, who the Democratic Alliance accused of forcing poor people to join the ANC in return for food, has been cleared of wrongdoing after an inquiry by the Department of Social Development. Western Cape Finance MEC Garth Strachan ordered the investigation immediately after DA MPL Alan Winde made the accusation in an open letter to him on Monday. It came as a blow to 64-year-old Claasen, who wept during an interview with the Cape Times and said that, while she she was an ANC member, she would never exploit a community she loved dearly. "The investigation included interviews with Mrs Claasen and members of the community, and an informal community survey. No evidence of any corruption could be found, and the DA produced no evidence to support the allegation. "Mrs Claasen's soup kitchen is a recipient of funding from the Department of Social Development and is managed and run by a committee of seven people from the community. In the absence of any evidence or information to corroborate the DA's allegations, the only conclusions that can be drawn are that the DA's allegations, widely published in the media, are reckless in the extreme, have damaged the good name of the individual concerned and appear to be defamatory," Strachan said. Strachan, who is also ANC provincial spokesman, said the allegations appeared to have been a smear tactic designed to mislead voters. "The ANC is referring the matter to the Independent Electoral Commission and also reserves its right to take legal action against the DA and Alan Winde. Dirty-tricks campaigning of this kind undermines democracy," he said. Claasen said: "I heard the Department of Social Services went door to door. I trust in the only one who knows the truth - God. He is fair and merciful. I'm glad my community spoke for themselves and spoke the truth. But besides all this, we need a lot of help to run the feeding scheme." Winde said he was pleased Claasen had been cleared. "I think it is great. I don't know Mrs Claasen, but when allegations are made, I take it very seriously and I must react - therefore my letter to Mr Strachan. I must also respect the individual complainants' request that their names not be divulged for fear of retribution. "I will obviously keep a close eye on this and convey the investigation's findings to the complainants and see what reaction I get from them. If they disagree, I will try to convince them to sign affidavits," Winde said. About dirty tricks and whether he would apologise, he said: "Why would I pull a dirty trick on someone I never met? I understand it is election time, but I must do my work and react when I get a complaint. Of course I will apologise. That is a given." aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: Make public Parliament corruption report, DA demands
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); MISCONDUCT (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ALLIANCES & PARTNERSHIPS (89%); FORENSICS (89%); EVIDENCE (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CORPORATE COUNSEL (67%); EMPLOYMENT (66%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (64%); SEXUAL HARASSMENT (64%); TRAVEL AGENTS (53%)
TEXT: The Democratic Alliance plans to demand full public access to a forensics report that allegedly showed dereliction of duty in stamping out corruption that led to the suspension of Secretary to Parliament Zingile Dingani. The party's chief whip, Ian Davidson, said yesterday that he would pile on the pressure by writing today to Speaker Gwen Mahlangu-Nkabinde to ask for the release of the KPMG report. "Parliament cannot be seen to conduct its affairs in secrecy. It needs to be a beacon of transparency and good governance," Davidson said. "This is particularly so in light of the Travelgate scandal, which has left the Speaker's office reeking with the powerful stench of a cover-up, with the recent decision by the Speaker to buy up the debtor's book of one of the travel agents concerned to let the MPs off the hook." Dingani was suspended last month for failing to take action against alleged corrupt activities by Parliament's chief legal adviser and National Council of Provinces Secretary Lulama Matyolo-Dube. Matyolo-Dube had been suspended earlier. Davidson said Parliament needed to redeem its "tainted" image and that it was a matter of public interest if the highest administrative official of Parliament had been implicated in corruption. The DA also wants the Speaker to explain what action will be taken against Dingani. So far, Parliament has not released any further details of the alleged misconduct. Dingani was implicated in "conduct inconsistent" with his position and of "dereliction of duty" during an investigation into Matyolo-Dube's alleged misconduct. Dingani's disciplinary hearing started last week. Parliament has not yet given an update of the proceedings. Lebohang Nawa, a spokesman for Speaker Mahlangu-Nkabinde, would not comment on Davidson's demand. Parliament has said from the outset that it would make announcements on the suspension only once the disciplinary hearings had been concluded. Among the details that have emerged is that Dingani allegedly had upgraded his personal assistant Patty Davids, who is also his business partner, to the level of director. The Mercury has reported that evidence to the forensic investigators allegedly had implicated several other high-ranking Parliamentary officials in acts of nepotism, sexual harassment and questionable procurement and employment practices. It is understood that, among other things, Matyolo-Dube had allegedly abused her travel privileges and that her son-in-law's company had claimed two irregular payments of R342 000 from Parliament. Complaints by staff and senior managers against Matyolo-Dube about nepotism and an unpopular leadership style were allegedly ignored by Dingani.

TITLE: MEC tells residents homes on track after corruption stalls project
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); HOMEOWNERS (89%); HOMELESSNESS (73%)
TEXT: HOUSING MEC Whitey Jacobs yesterday visited homeless people in Harare, Khayelitsha to inform them of his decision taken more than a month ago to restart a housing project after it was stalled by corruption. Denying he was electioneering, Jacobs told about 300 prospective home owners that unfinished houses in the area would be completed and that another 272 of the intended 5 000 houses in the project would be built soon. He had ordered an inquiry after the project stalled. At least one former contractor has been taken to court for corruption after housing beneficiaries' subsidies were abused, he said. He said the project was one of a number that had stalled because of corrupt contractors and suppliers. The Special Investigation Unit was busy investigating about 150 similar projects across the province, Jacobs said. On Sunday, his visit to Khayelitsha was cut short by backyarders angered over corruption in allocating houses. aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: fraud, corruption charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (89%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (89%); KIDNAPPING & ABDUCTION (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); INVESTIGATIVE SERVICES (74%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (73%); EXTORTION (73%); REFUGEES (72%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (69%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (68%); JEWELRY STORES (63%)
TEXT: BARELY a week old and the police's Priority Crimes Directorate, dubbed the Hawks, has already swooped. Yesterday, officers from the unit, meant to replace the Scorpions, arrested a senior official at the troubled Department of Home Affairs refugee centre in Airport Industria. The arrest was meant to happen amid much publicity as the media, invited by the Hawks, streamed to the centre to witness the arrest. But instead, the suspect was driven out of the centre in an unmarked vehicle with blacked-out windows, foregoing the "perp (as in perpetrator) walk" made famous by the Scorpions, for which they received much flak. Police did not name her. Spokesman November Filander said the 32-year-old suspect was arrested after an investigation spearheaded by the new head of the Hawks, Anwa Dramat. The official is expected to appear in the Bishop Lavis Magistrate's Court today on fraud and corruption charges for allegedly issuing permits for payment. Filander would, however, not say how much money was involved. Because of the appalling conditions for refugees at the centre, the Cape High Court has ordered it closed by September, following an application by neighbouring businesses. Meanwhile, the Hawks have arrested two senior police detectives on charges of kidnapping, extortion and corruption. Both officers, one arrested on Wednesday evening and the other yesterday, were stationed at the Kuils River police station's detective services. The two are expected to appear in the Cape Town Magistrate's Court on Monday. Filander said the arrests followed an investigation into the alleged illegal activities of police officers after an incident in which a member of the public advertised his vehicle for sale. He said that corruption within the ranks of the police would not be tolerated and every effort would be made to root out such elements. The Hawks unit was launched at a glitzy function at Midrand's Gallagher Estate on Monday when the head of the Scorpions, Thanda Mngwengwe, symbolically handed over 288 investigations to new boss Dramat. Dramat said at the function that 1 700 officers from the police and the Scorpions had been screened to join his new unit and 1 300 would be screened over 12 months. The unit would have three divisions: organised crime, commercial crime and the hi-tech centre. "Our resolve is unambiguous: we will leave no stone unturned to bring criminals to book," said Dramat. The Hawks's first arrest was just after its launch when it arrested a Durban sangoma and two men who were allegedly planning to rob a jewellery store. Using "precision", according to senior police officer Vincent Mdunge, the Hawks arrived at the scene of the crime at 6.30am - even before it could be committed. The three suspects were then arrested. The sangoma had allegedly applied muti to the men so that they would commit the crime "safely", said Mdunge. quinton.mtyala@inl.co.za

TITLE: The price of corruption
SUBJECT: RELIGION (92%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BOKO HARAM (90%); TALIBAN (90%); AL-QAEDA (78%); TERRORISM (78%); FUNDAMENTALISM (78%); BRIBERY (76%); BUDGETS (74%); TERRORIST ORGANIZATIONS (73%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (73%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (72%); PUBLIC FINANCE (72%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (69%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (68%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (64%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (62%)
TEXT: Talk about the "Nigerian Taliban" makes for spicy headlines, but the cause of the four days of violence in which hundreds of people have died, with thousands fleeing their homes in the north of the country, is something rather different. The Islamic sect leader who died at the hands of the police on Friday as his uprising was crushed was certainly an extremist. His movement opposes everything from books to medicine, democracy to capitalism. It wants a more fundamentalist version of sharia in many northern states. But this was nothing to do with al-Qaeda. If you ask why this tiny minority wanted sharia applied more thoroughly, the answer is revealing. It is because the radical social welfare schemes of sharia were not introduced to address dire poverty. Nigeria is one of the richest nations in Africa, as well as one the most populous. But most of that huge population see none of its massive oil wealth. Nigeria is run by an elite of millionaires so corrupt and ineffective they do not deliver even basic services such as running water and electricity. Disenchantment is rife, not least among the 85 percent of graduates who are unemployed. In such circumstances extreme solutions have their attractions. But ever more extreme forms of Islam are not the answer. Good governance is. To say that is not a pious ideal. Progress is possible, as was shown when Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala was Nigeria's finance minister from 2003 to 2006. She introduced reforms and Nigeria went from the most corrupt nation on earth to just the sixth most. But the corrupt elite got rid of the reformer and things are slipping backwards. The solutions have all been set out. Nigeria needs openness about government revenues and budgets. It needs Western governments to prosecute Western firms that pay bribes there. It needs transparency in the procurement of government contracts. But above all it requires political will, both in Africa and in the West. The elites can continue to ignore all that, of course. But the events of recent days show what will happen if they do. - The Independent

TITLE: Beating corruption
SUBJECT: VEHICLE TRAFFIC (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); COMPUTING & INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (77%); MISCONDUCT (73%)
TEXT: Politicians have talked about stopping corruption for years, but never put a solution on the table. How long does it take? The traffic department is already using sophisticated cameras, and is getting new technology to help it to apprehend defaulters. Why not use technology to improve relationships with motorists and stop corruption? All that is needed is a small speaker in the officer's shirt pocket that records conversations and sends them to a central office. That would greatly help traffic officers in their work. The system can be used for different purposes, for instance for use by building inspectors, police and politicians, and for tendering. The latest technology is so advanced, anything is possible. I believe that it is the way to go to stop corruption, improper conduct and so on. Former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani introduced the CompStat real-time police intelligence computer system developed by William Bratton. He used it to measure the relative performance of different police precincts in combating crime. Let's use computer technology as the tool it was meant to be - for the betterment of society. Frank du Toit Ballito

TITLE: Database 'will curb housing list corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); PROPERTY VACANCIES (73%)
TEXT: THE GOVERNMENT is to set up a computerised database of housing waiting lists to curb corrupt officials and politicians awarding houses to people they know. Acting director-general of the Department of Human Settlements Mziwonke Dlabantu told MPs the new database would not be easily manipulated by officials wanting to give houses to associates at the expense of the poor and the vulnerable. Briefing Parliament's human settlements committee yesterday, Dlabantu said the issue was complex and a good programme was needed to ensure deserving applicants benefited. He said it was also difficult keeping track of people living in informal settlements who applied for housing as they moved from one area to another. "If you are dealing with a (densely populated informal) settlement you have a number of variables. Those things affect the way your database is structured." In the past corrupt officials and politicians had tampered with beneficiary lists and allocated houses to friends and family or people who had paid them money to get the houses. "The lists as they stand in the country are not useful (or) helpful," Dlabantu said. The fact that people living in informal settlements moved around aided corruption. Cope MP Thozamile Botha said the beneficiary list had always presented a headache for the government. In some instances houses were constructed, yet after the project was completed the houses remained unoccupied, said Botha. "You end up sitting with vacant houses and they are vandalised." Dlabantu said the age and vulnerability of would-be housing beneficiaries would be looked at when it came to determining the order of preference for people receiving housing.

TITLE: Infighting, corruption and nepotism are ruining North West, warns ANC report
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); MAYORS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ORGANIZED CRIME (78%); SOCCER (69%); DISMISSALS (69%)
TEXT: A top-level ANC report has revealed how political infighting, corruption and nepotism within its own ranks have brought municipalities in the North West to the brink of collapse. The report - a copy of which is in the possession of the Cape Times - warns that the ANC's ability to direct government in the province is under "severe threat" and urges the intervention of the national leadership. It describes how at least four factions were competing against one another in a bid for control of the province - including one it says is a "secret mafia" known as the "N4 Task Team" which was responsible for "siphoning and looting" state resources. Blame is laid at the door of the party's own top provincial officials for the infighting, fraud, corruption and nepotism which became the order of the day. The 38-page report describes how political battles between the warring factions disrupted service delivery to the extent that local government started collapsing. Service delivery was severely disrupted - igniting the recent spate of service delivery protests. The report warns that almost all municipalities in the province are in a state of crisis. "The protests and strikes led to continuing collapse in service delivery so that the municipalities reached a complete state of decay and saw the progressive collapse of governance," it states. The report was compiled by a task team deployed by the ANC's national executive committee, which completed an investigation into factionalism in the North West in May. The party's provincial executive committee (PEC) was subsequently disbanded in July and replaced by a special task team. The revelations come as the ANC this week suspended the party membership of former PEC member, Themba Gwabeni - after he was sacked as mayor of the Ngaka Modiri-Molema district municipality. The municipality is the second largest district in North West, in both size and population, and comprises five local municipalities: Ditsobotla, Mafikeng, Ratlou, Tswaing and Ramotshere Moiloa. Gwabeni was suspended after taking Provincial and co-operative governance Minister Sicelo Shiceka to court in a challenge to Shiceka's decision to put the municipality under administration. In its report, the NEC team criticised Gwabeni's decision to divert R8.7 million earmarked for water projects to fund a year-long soccer excursion to Brazil for teenagers early this year. Gwabeni could not be reached for comment. The team said the PEC was responsible allowed the formation of factions at branch, regional and provincial level. The team says the PEC ensured more than 90 percent of ANC members - who had been municipal managers, mayors, chief whips or other key municipal officials - were removed through a "systematic and executed plan of action".

TITLE: Majali faces arrest for money laundering, fraud and corruption
SUBJECT: ARREST WARRANTS (91%); MONEY LAUNDERING (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ARRESTS (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (77%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (77%); ASSET FORFEITURE (76%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (73%); LAWYERS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (68%)

TITLE: Refugee centre 'lends itself to corruption' due to inefficiency
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); REFUGEES (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICAL ASYLUM (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (89%); BRIBERY (77%); MAGISTRATES (74%)
TEXT: determination officer. "When refugees come into the office, they first see a reception officer and then move on to a status determination officer." Sikakane said he was aware of corruption within the Home Affairs office. "It's not a new thing. Ever since I joined the office, I found it to be quite a rife issue. It's normally underground and it has been for some time. "But there has been a huge outcry from the public about the refugee issue, and now we will see everything unfold." He said the allegedly corrupt officials would face an internal disciplinary process if found guilty in court of selling asylum granting papers. Legal Resource Centre attorney William Kerfoot said: "Obviously people are innocent until proven guilty, but any news that the authorities are taking alleged corruption seriously is good news." But Kerfoot said the Nyanga Refugee Reception Centre "lends itself to corruption because of its inefficiency". "People are desperate to be interviewed or to get documents and they have to wait months to do so, so it's likely that corruption will come into the picture. The easiest way to eliminate corruption would be to eliminate inefficiency by processing all applicants quickly," Kerfoot said. University of Cape Town Law Clinic director Fatima Khan said corruption at the centre was "not uncommon". Khan said: "It (bribery) has happened before and I'm hoping this time around they (Home Affairs) really get to the bottom of this and not just a suspension like in the past. We've never seen any kind of prosecution of any kind of these corrupt officials, but hopefully this time around with the new attitude and new minister there will be a conviction." She said refugees were often easy targets as they were "desperate" for asylum-granting documents. Consortium for Refugees and Migrants in South Africa advocacy officer Duncan Breen said refugees had become easy targets for corrupt officials as they "had a lot at stake". TITLE: MPs demand answers on corruption in prisons
SUBJECT: CORRECTIONS (93%); PRISONS (92%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (78%); CONSPIRACY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); PAROLE (77%); EVIDENCE (73%); ASSET FORFEITURE (70%)
TEXT: MPs have vowed to get answers within the next month about prisons corruption and tender rigging worth close to R2 billion, uncovered by a two-year probe by the Special Investigations Unit. A meeting last Tuesday of the portfolio committee on correctional services - where the unit was scheduled to present a report about its investigations - was cancelled at the last minute because of an ANC caucus meeting. DA shadow minister on correctional services James Selfe yesterday told the Cape Times that the new programme for Parliament's fourth quarter, which resumed on Tuesday, did not feature a meeting between the committee and the unit. Selfe said he would write a letter to committee chairman Vincent Smith "to request him to reinstate the meeting of the committee as a matter of urgency". He said the unit had uncovered prima facie evidence of "substantial corruption and wasteful expenditure" by the Department of Correctional Services, and the committee and public needed greater clarity on the matter. Smith yesterday said he was determined to schedule a meeting with the unit within the first two weeks of Parliament business resuming. The committee also had to reschedule last week's meeting with Judge Siraj Desai, who heads the National Council of Correctional Services and is reviewing the law on medical parole, Smith said. Meanwhile, the IFP and Cope have called on Correctional Services Minister Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula to publicly release the investigation unit's report on its probe. IFP spokesman on correctional services Koos van der Merwe said the fact that the report could implicate top officials "is no reason to delay making it public". Cope MP and former portfolio committee chairman Dennis Bloem said Mapisa-Nqakula should prove to the public "that she is serious about getting the department in order". The unit will tell the portfolio committee in its submission, a copy of which is in the Cape Times's possession, that it had found evidence of collusion between department officials and suppliers and of bidders drafting their own tender specifications for contracts they later won. These include prisons catering and security services. It has handed a copy of its report on the investigation to the National Prosecuting Authority for a decision on whether to prosecute. A copy of the unit's report, which recommends disciplinary action against 22 officials, also went to Mapisa-Nqakula. Her office said she would submit it to the cabinet first. The investigations unit said in its submission that R6.9 million had already been recovered in its probe into the 200 most expensive contracts in the department, while assets of R12m were under restraint and a R4.8m saving had been made. Further asset seizures were pending.

TITLE: Increase in crime, corruption takes South Africa to ninth place in Africa governance rankings
SUBJECT: CRIME RATES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); RULE OF LAW (90%); RANKINGS (90%); HOMICIDE (78%); ACADEMIC FREEDOM (78%); CIVIL RIGHTS (73%); HUMAN RIGHTS (73%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (73%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (71%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (69%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (64%); SPONSORSHIP (64%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (64%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (64%)
TEXT: SOUTH Africa has slipped four places down an African governance index compiled by Harvard University because of growing corruption and crime. Although still among the 10 best-governed countries in Africa, South Africa dropped from fifth place last year to ninth this year, after Mauritius, Seychelles, Cape Verde, Botswana, Tunisia, Ghana, Algeria and Namibia. S227o Tomí© and Pr237ncipe secured 10th place. Presenting the 2009 index of African governance in Joburg yesterday, Professor Robert Rotberg, of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, attributed South Africa's slide in the rankings mainly to an increase in corruption and crime, including the fourth highest rate of homicide in the world, after Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. South Africa had recently overtaken Colombia in the homicide stakes. South Africa also dropped down the rankings because of lower scores in respect to civil and political rights and the rule of law. Its lowest scores were in the categories of "respect for physical integrity rights" and for "safety and security" because of crime. The index also questioned South Africa's performance in dealing with poverty and inequality. The index ranked Zimbabwe among the worst 10 governed countries in Africa. Swaziland slid badly from 34th last year to 42nd this year. The index assesses the performance of countries in five categories, namely: safety and security, the rule of law and transparency, political participation and respect for human rights, and sustainable economic development and human development. Rotberg announced that the index, which he had founded, had severed ties with its original sponsor, multibillionaire telecoms tycoon Mo Ibrahim, because he had wanted to "control" the index. Academics felt this would violate academic freedom and integrity. Ibrahim's Foundation is due to release its own good governance index on Monday. Rotberg admitted it was "ridiculous" to have two indices covering the same ground, but said his was "the authentic index done in the way we conceived". The Harvard index is now sponsored by the World Peace Foundation. The top 10 worst performers characterised by what Rotberg called despotism, poverty and poor governance were Guinea, Zimbabwe, Angola, Eritrea, Central African Republic, Cote d'Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Chad and Sudan. Somalia was ranked last. Improving governance in Africa was the ultimate purpose of the index, as governments could use it to better their performance in specific areas while civic society could use the index to agitate for improvements in the lives of citizens, Rotberg said. South Africa had also slipped because of pre-trial detentions which had increased from 27 percent to 30 percent. Another big decline was in the category of physical integrity rights in which it fared no better than Guinea, Angola and Nigeria. Physical integrity rights cover respect for the person, including non-violence. The index also judged that press freedom had declined slightly in South Africa. But Rotberg commended South Africa for its good statistical service compared to the "appalling" statistical standards of most African states. Most of the 10 best governed countries were those with small populations. The best governed were peaceful and prosperous. They delivered goods and services to their citizens, held free and fair elections, and were less corrupt than their neighbours, the Harvard index said.

TEXT: Rautenbach allegedly committed," Selebi said. Ngcuka yesterday dismissed the corruption claim against him as "an outright lie". "I reject all these allegations with contempt. I never attempted to extort or receive bribes from Rautenbach's team or anyone else for that matter. Not then and not now," he said. Despite the existence of the "Zumagate" tape recordings, which the NPA concluded were of him and McCarthy discussing the Zuma and Selebi cases, Ngcuka said: "One would hope that the court proceeding would also prove that I was never involved in the initiation and investigation of Mr Selebi." According to Ngcuka: l He met Rautenbach's lawyer "following his request to make representations for a plea agreement". l The discussion "reached a dead end and could not reach any agreement as we, the NPA, would not settle for any penalty that excluded custodial sentence". l He had taken a principled decision not to become involved in the mining industry "to avoid any perceived conflict of interests because my wife, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, was the minister of minerals and energy at the time". Ngcuka said it was "baffling" that Selebi "did not charge me following his alleged discovery". It is the State's case that Selebi received a $30 000 (about R225 000) bribe from Rautenbach through murder suspect Glenn Agliotti in exchange for protecting Rautenbach from an arrest warrant.

TITLE: There's nothing quite like the whiff of corruption in the fresh spring air
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (90%); ETHNIC CONFLICTS (77%); SMUGGLING (76%); FAILED & FRAGILE STATES (76%); ART THEFT (76%); HOMICIDE (73%); ORGANIZED CRIME (72%); WAR CRIMES (70%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (67%); GENOCIDE (67%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (65%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (65%); PAINTING (64%); DRUG TRAFFICKING (64%); MURDER (58%); HUMAN TRAFFICKING (50%)
TEXT: A MOST curious smell is wafting through our neighbourhood. I suspect it emanates from the small dagga plantation of my odious neighbour, Gatvol van der Pomp. Is he all that he seems - a stinking hairy bigot compelled to marry his third wife (his sister) at the point of a pistol? In other words, a normal South African reptile content to watch the eggs hatch in his burrow as he gapes at thugby matches on his stolen TV set - powered by stolen electricity - and cheering the home team as they mash the opposition into the mud. If I didn't know better, I would suspect Gatvol of boiling cockroaches in methyl alcohol left over from his customary Saturday night revels. But I do know better: it's only a small step from odious to odorous, and the diffusing fug is down to the fact that he last bathed in a previous century. Still, when the former head of Interpol is on trial for corruption, it does no harm to suspect one's neighbours of being fugitives from justice. In short, is Gatvol really a scion of the Van der Pomp clan? He has the family's distinctive stigmata: not only do his eyebrows meet in the centre of his head, his eyes do so too. Unfortunately he also bears some resemblance to one of the International Criminal Police Organisation's Most Wanted list, Ermek Maratovich Abdyldaev of Kyrgystan. Interpol advertises on its website that this ruffian is most wanted for one of the following: war crimes, genocide, drug smuggling, mafia membership, stealing Van Gogh paintings, trafficking in human beings and aliens, political graft, serial killing and/or rape. I am forced to remind myself that we all look guilty of something, and probably are; and that Gatvol's resemblance to Ermek is of no more significance than, say, Jackie Selebi's to a cornered rat. But even a failed state has its standards and we must all be on the lookout for worms in bad apples. Selebi's tenure as President of Interpol - less than four years before conscience led him to resign - was in the great tradition of that august law enforcement entity. For some years (again, in a previous century) the top job was held by such notables as SS General Reinhard Heydrich and Einsatzgruppenfíhrer Arthur Nebe, who while only personally responsible for murdering 46 000 people was a notable shrimper, or toe-sucker. You don't enter such ranks for nothing - not even a slap-up million-rand dinner for the big Interpol knobs paid for by Brett Kebble, the late art lover and free marketeer. And who was Brett Kebble, you may well ask since all our news and information is fished from the stagnant pond of the SABC? In consequence, our memories are threadbare. Well, before he was executed (possibly by a Scarface clone, the weepy Glenn Agliotti), Brett was famous as a nerd and fraud. In the great tradition of Anglo American, if he needed a good press, he bought it. So he bought Finance Week and two prominent hacks, Dave and Nigel, to run it. Today Nigel hunts foxes in rural England. Dave could be anywhere. But all that is history, along with forced removals and crony capitalism. Besides which, Heydrich & Co had the endorsement of that nice Mr Hitler. Strange how such chains of names link our present with our past. Mulling over this, I wobbled to the smelly Van der Pomp residence. Like a towering anthill, most of the activity is underground and secretive. Drunk as a judge in a warren of cobwebs, mongrels, open paint cans and displaced wives and kiddies I found Gatvol straddling a potjie, stirring away with an elderly SAR&H soup spoon - huge really, and chunky as all aged things are. He saw me in the gloom: "Sorry about the stench, Bru. I'm just making a curry and fishpaste stew for the usual security okes. They call in every so often for freebies - and I have to give them something or they might shoot me. I'll keep the stew warm over a burning Bic8482 lighter." So. I and the neighbours will just have to get used to the permanent whiff of corruption in the fresh spring air.

TITLE: OPPOSITION ALLEGES COVER-UP Land Bank corruption probe under way - Hawks
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICS (89%); EXECUTIVES (75%); FORENSICS (73%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%)
TEXT: Hawks spokesman Musa Zondi insisted yesterday that investigations were under way into the alleged ransacking of a R100-million BEE fund meant for poor farmers and financed by the taxpayer, as opposition parties accused the government of a cover-up. Zondi said there was was "pressure" from stakeholders to expedite the investigation. He refused to identify them, however. He also refused to say when the investigation was launched or when it was due to be concluded. The Cape Times reported in July that arrests were imminent after Land Bank chief executive officer Phakamani Hadebe told MPs information about irregularities had been handed to police. A report in the Sunday Times yesterday alleged that former Gauteng housing MEC Dan Mofokeng, former Land Bank executive Phil Mohlahlane, his sister-in-law Jessica Mojanaga and a Hazyview doctor had benefited from the fund to the tune of millions. It was also alleged that, although information about alleged irregularities had been available to law enforcement agencies for at least a year, formal charges had yet to be laid. Hadebe said the Land Bank had paid out money towards expediting the forensic investigation. "We would really like to see this thing (arrests) happening soon because we have gone the extra mile in achieving that," he said. "We are helping the police by getting additional resources at the cost of the Land Bank to move this thing speedily." The Land Bank wanted all former executives implicated in wrongdoing to face the music, Hadebe said. "All those that were implicated within the bank are no longer there. We got rid of them. "But acting on the allegations is the job of the police and they are running a number of investigations. They are on top of it and we are not sitting on our side not doing anything," Hadebe said. The National African Farmers Union (Nafu) called for action, saying farmers had been "short-circuited" because funds meant for poor and emerging farmers were used to fund lavish lifestyles of those who were politically connected. Nafu president Otto Mbangula said farmers were "severely" affected because of past corruption at the bank. "We are totally unhappy at the way the bank was conducting business. But now the bank is turning the corner. It has failed African farmers because, in the past, black and emerging farmers were being short- circuited. "Getting a loan from the bank was a mountain, particularly for black farmers, because money was spent on non-core agriculture. Those involved in corruption must face the law. The Land Bank (executives) and their friends were buying golf estates and spending the money on themselves and football clubs," said Mbangula. Democratic Alliance agriculture spokesman Piet Pretorius said dragging out the investigation suggested there was a cover-up to protect those involved. "If the government is serious about rooting out corruption and if the official excuse is to be believed that investigating authorities are still considering the reports, then government must ensure that its investigating authorities get their acts together," he said. Independent Democrats leader Patricia De Lille said the allegations made her "sick to my stomach". "If true, these latest allegations show that some of those right at the top of the institutions tasked with supporting emerging farmers would rather rob our people blind than make the kind of difference our country needs," De Lille said. The Financial Intelligence Centre, which analyses dubious financial transactions, was working with other law enforcement agencies, spokesman Themba Hlengani said.

TITLE: Ministerial team to come up with anti-corruption plan
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%)
TEXT: THE cabinet has instructed a team of ministers to come up with a plan to deal with corruption in the public service, which is hurting the country's reputation and draining billions in taxpayers' money. The team, to be headed by Minister in the Presidency Collins Chabane, is expected to present the cabinet, at its lekgotla in January, with a "concrete strategy" for dealing with the scourge. President Jacob Zuma would give details of the plan in his State of the Nation address in February, government spokesman Themba Maseko said yesterday. A report by the Public Service Commission on corruption in the public service had been the "tipping point" that led to the decision. The team would include the ministers of Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs Sicelo Shiceka, Public Service and Administration Richard Baloyi, Finance Pravin Gordhan, and Social Development Edna Molewa. "South Africa takes very strong exception to corruption as this is a matter that has a negative impact on the country's reputation."

TITLE: 'no more corruption' Central Cape database will ensure fair housing lists
SUBJECT: HOUSING ASSISTANCE (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); HOUSING SHORTAGES (90%); APPOINTMENTS (77%)
TEXT: HOUSING waiting lists of municipalities across the province were going to be updated, verified and linked to a central provincial database to ensure houses were fairly allocated, beneficiaries were properly profiled and corruption was eliminated, Housing MEC Bonginkosi Madikezela said. Cape Town was excluded from the exercise because, unlike those of most municipalities, its database was up to date, he said. Tenders had been invited and an independent service provider would be appointed soon to conduct the project. The estimated 450 000 housing backlog has been a bone of contention for a long time and many people have complained about waiting for up to 28 years while people who have applied much later have received houses. In December, 2007, hundreds of families, fed up with the wait, illegally occupied incomplete houses in Delft. Madikezela said yesterday that people who had already benefited from housing opportunities, but whose names re-appeared on updated lists, would not have another chance to get a house as they would be removed from the provincial database. "We want to take a very strong stance on this. There are people who have benefited before and either sold those houses or rented them and moved back to shacks," Madikezela said. The new database would help establish a more accurate picture on issues such as income levels and whether people lived in informal settlements, backyards or overcrowded formal structures. The provincial housing chief director for planning and development, Jacqui Samson, said various databases and housing allocation systems at municipalities would be streamlined to help improve transparency and ensure fair allocation of houses. Information collected would assist planning and determine what type of housing was required in various areas. The project's first phase, expected to take four months and for which R2.5 million had been budgeted, would assess how the councils' housing management systems worked and data was collected, she said. In April phase two would see the design of a strategy to support municipalities to improve their systems. The provincial database, which would be open to the public, would to be linked to a national database to ensure people who had obtained houses elsewhere in the country were not considered for houses in the province. Madikezela said: "Central to this is public access to the information. It will help stop corruption." aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: Italian government's slide into nepotism and corruption an object lesson for SA
COUNTRY: ITALY (94%); UNITED STATES (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); HOLY SEE (58%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); APPOINTMENTS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); PRIME MINISTERS (89%); POLITICS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); LEGISLATION (77%); US PRESIDENTS (76%); INDICTMENTS (73%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (73%); PUBLIC FINANCE (73%); RELIGION (69%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (69%); WORLD WAR II (68%)
TEXT: JACOB ZUMA, like Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, has a propensity to break into song and dance. Both have faced corruption charges. But while Zuma's legal case was dropped, Berlusconi has had to pass legislation to keep himself out of the dock. Recently, with speculation rife that Zuma may grant Schabir Shaik a presidential pardon, Berlusconi proposed more laws to quash lingering, serious fraud indictments against himself. Frankly, if the ANC really wants to peer into the future it should send a fact finding mission to Rome to study the fate of the Democrazia Cristiana (DC) party, which once seemed set to rule (in Zuma's phrase) "until Jesus comes". For even though they had the backing of the Vatican, rather than Pastor Ray McCaulay, the once seeming invincible DC imploded virtually overnight. Just like the ANC, its strength was its greatest weakness. The Italian Christian Democrats had such a broad constituency, from far right to extreme left, that at one point the party had six separate HQs in Rome, representing the separate factions. The only thing that kept this disparate organisation together was the glue of power. It also practised "deployment." Party loyalists were appointed to government agencies, state television and the powerful Italian parastatals. Even minor appointments were often political. The consequence was paralysis, nepotism and rampant corruption. Ministers were appointed in order to keep the different factions happy rather than for ability. As a result there was a revolving cabinet carousel, with the same dull faces appearing year after year in different posts. No one was ever sacked for incompetence. As with the ANC, party factions were often more at war with one another than they were with the opposition. The different groupings often traded insults openly and fought bitter internal battles for positions of influence. Frequently, as has proved the case here with intra-ANC battles, the state's spy agencies were abused to settle party scores. The major difference, however, is that the South African Communist Party is an integral part of the governing alliance, even if it is one that yaps at the heels of the ANC. On the other hand, the only ideological aim of the Christian Democrats, apart from maintaining a clammy grip on power, was to keep the Italian Communists out in the cold. Yet even here there are instructive similarities. After World War 2, when the Christian Democrats came to power, they were briefly forced to include Communists in a unity government. However Communist ministers, exactly as in South Africa today, soon discovered that they had to demonstrate their moderation. In 1947, as the Italian prime minister prepared to fly to the US to meet President Harry Truman, Communist Finance Minister Mauro Scoccimarro stayed up all night to prepare a budget to show how under "red" control finances were being responsibly managed. In fact the prime minister was flying to Washington to discuss with Truman how to dump the Communists. The reason why all this would repay close study is that many of the tensions that confronted post-war Italy were precisely the ones that face South Africa today: the tension between modernity and tradition, and the dramatic and seemingly intractable rich/poor split. And, of course, the sheer ruthlessness of organised crime. The way that the Italian ruling class went about tackling these crucial social dilemmas would present a master class in exactly how not to solve such problems. But the ANC is repeating many of the same, potentially ruinous mistakes. Zuma's appointment of the government "yes man", Menzi Simelane, to head the National Prosecuting Authority, for example, appears to be a move of Berlusconian opportunism. The DC ruled for nearly 50 years, finally collapsing in the early 1990s in a putrid swamp of corruption. It only clung to power for so long by playing on the Communist scare. Ironically, this party disintegrated at the very same time as its red bogeyman. The fact is, inventive Italians only managed to thrive despite their governments. The danger for the ANC is to follow a similar route: gradually becoming ever more sclerotic and attracting only cynical careerists with an eye to looting state resources. But perhaps the greatest warning is what follows such a final collapse: in the subsequent vacuum the worst elements rise to the surface. In Italy, the greatest beneficiary of the rampant corruption of the 1980s and 1990s, Silvio Berlusconi, bizarrely became prime minister on a wave of populism, governing with neo-Fascists and strident xenophobes. The equivalent scenario in South Africa would be: after his early release from prison on "health grounds", Schabir Shaik is not only pardoned but survives into grand old age - long enough not only to outlive the ANC and its demise, but to become president. Don't laugh. It happened in Italy. l Rostron is a freelance writer and author. He reported from Italy for several years. His latest novel, set in Cape Town, is Black Petals (Jacana).

TITLE: Vavi calls for lifestyles audit to root out corruption in government ranks
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (94%)
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE (72%); GOVERNMENT HEALTH INSURANCE (72%); JOB CREATION (65%); MORTGAGE BANKING & FINANCE (64%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (63%); INFRASTRUCTURE (53%); HEALTH INSURANCE (50%)
TEXT: Cosatu general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi has called for a wealth audit of the country's political leaders, a move likely to rattle the alliance cage. He said he was disappointed that President Jacob Zuma did not announce measures to deal with corruption and "crass materialism" in government ranks. "He should have announced a lifestyle audit to dispel a deep-seated belief that the levels of corruption and abuse of state power to advance the commercial interests of some in the cabinet and among directors-general leave much to be desired and are putting South Africa on a route to (becoming) a predator state," Vavi said. While Cosatu "generally" welcomed the contents of the State of the Nation address, it was unhappy about some aspects, particularly Zuma's failure to articulate the government's position on the restructuring of the economy. His speech had, however, reassured Cosatu that the government was being guided by priorities spelled out in the ANC's election manifesto. "In pursuit of these priorities we therefore warmly welcome, among other (things), the recommitment to extending the public works programme and congratulate (the government) for nearly realising its target of creating 500 000 jobs. The government has created 480 000." Also welcomed were the extension of social grants to two million more children and the commitment to introducing a national health insurance. Noting that the government was to set up a R1 billion fund to guarantee private sector loans for people earning too little to qualify for bank mortgages, Vavi said Cosatu was disappointed the money would not be provided as direct subsidies. Cosatu was also disappointed that Zuma had not acknowledged that the country faced a "structural unemployment crisis". "Failure to reiterate the ANC's commitment to restructuring the economy may have given a false hope that we will address structural unemployment, deep-seated poverty and growing inequalities through the piecemeal measures announced."

TITLE: Corruption can be beaten - as long as civil society rises to the challenge
COUNTRY: SOUTH AFRICA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (89%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (89%); SCANDALS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); EPIDEMIOLOGY (88%); BUDGETS (76%); PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (75%); CANCER (75%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (74%); PUBLIC FINANCE (74%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (72%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (71%); HISTORY (70%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (70%); EPIDEMICS (68%); MUMPS (68%); INFECTIOUS DISEASE (64%); PREVENTION & WELLNESS (63%); INFANT MORTALITY (53%)
TEXT: In the throes of the day-to-day details of various corruption scandals, it's good to step back and remind ourselves of the big picture. Why is corruption a problem? We shouldn't think of opposing corruption because we're goody-goodies and corruption is wrong. We fight corruption because it hurts what we most want to achieve in society. Corruption slows economic progress. Axel Dreher and his colleagues estimate that corruption is responsible for a reduction of 63 percent in per capita income in sub-Saharan Africa. My research with Johannes Fedderke of UCT shows that, other things being equal, countries with more corruption have less investment, and each dollar of investment has less impact on growth. Daniel Kaufmann and his colleagues find bad governance has direct and negative effects on long-term outcomes such as infant mortality and educational attainment. Two more points, and listen up ANC: corruption hurts the poor, not the rich. Corruption undercuts democracy. As John T Noonan has said, dictatorship and corruption are the two great sins of government. Can anything be done about corruption? The short answer is yes. Around the world, you find cities and towns, ministries and agencies, and countries making progress in the fight against corruption. Not everywhere, to be sure, and even with the success stories progress is not overnight. The battle against corruption is never complete, and "re-corruption" is always a threat. Despite success stories in reducing corruption, it's surprising how cynical people can become about corruption, to the point of fallacy. "Corruption has existed throughout history. Every country has corruption, even the most advanced. So, what can be done about it? Nothing." To see the fallacy clearly, substitute "disease" for "corruption." No one would conclude nothing can be done about disease, that there is no use for public health programmes, doctors, hospitals, or medicine. Like disease, corruption comes in many forms, some cancerous, some mild. Like disease, corruption can be widespread like a pandemic or occasional like the mumps. Like disease, prevention is important, and so is treatment of diseased members of the body politic. And now to the most important part of the big picture. You in South Africa are at the point of making progress against corruption. And if you don't lose heart, you can do it. Yes, you still have and will continue to have scandals ranging from tendering to social services, with accusations and counter-accusations of corruption and being framed for corruption. But consider your progress. The very fact so much evidence has recently been uncovered is a good sign. Your investigators and auditors are mobilised. Your press and media are staunchly against corruption. The finance minister highlighted the fight against corruption in his budget speech. Arrests are being made. Lifestyle audits are being debated as never before. And the government is better organised, at least in theory, thanks to the inter-ministerial committee on corruption set up in November. How can South Africa do even better? As a long-time visitor to your country, but only a visitor, my advice can only be suggestive. Drawing from the experience of other countries, I believe South Africa's continued progress depends on three things. First, anti-corruption is only partly about enforcement. It is also about prevention. Hong Kong's famed Independent Commission against Corruption was created with three wings - enforcement, prevention, and popular participation. The prevention wing contained management consultants, IT experts and accountants, who worked with various ministries to analyse vulnerabilities to corruption - and then to help reduce those vulnerabilities. Prevention goes beyond vigorous inspections and audits. Systemic reforms are also required. There is a formula for corruption: C = M + D - A. Corruption equals Monopoly plus Discretion minus Accountability. If a person has monopoly power over a good or service, has the discretion to decide how much you get, and faces no accountability, corruption thrives. To fight corruption, monopoly power has to be leavened and competition increased. Discretion in official actions must be limited, and the rules of the game must be clear. Accountability must be enhanced, through performance indicators and feedback from citizens, businesses, and public officials themselves. Here is where my second point comes in. To enhance accountability, South African civil society must be more vital and effective. The business community can do even more to help diagnose corrupt systems and then to take effective action. Business people do not like to pay bribes or be extorted. They may find in some cases that corruption is necessary to win a tender or to avoid crippling red tape.
