Businesses have it in their interest to move to a different equilibrium, where corruption and influence-peddling are greatly reduced - and where companies can spend their time innovating, cutting costs, and improving quality rather than figuring out how to cultivate political connections or evade extortion. Third, education is crucial. South Africa's schools and universities can do even more in the fight against corruption. South Africa should declare education as a corruption-free zone. You can follow the example of Indonesia's Paramadina University, which requires all undergraduate students to take a course in anti-corruption. You can support research on anti-corruption efforts, ranging from evaluations to prevention studies. South Africa is one of the most important countries in the world. The world is watching - and hoping you succeed. As you create a peaceful and diverse society, a flourishing democracy, and a country where corruption is not "the way we do things," you will be leaders in the 21st century. l Klitgaard is professor of economics at Claremont Graduate University in California and the author of eight books, including Controlling Corruption and High-Performance Government. Formerly a professor of economics at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, Yale, and Harvard, he is spending six months of sabbatical leave in South Africa.

TITLE: Conviction of Mozambican minister for corruption is the exception in Africa
COUNTRY: MOZAMBIQUE (94%); AFRICA (94%); ZAMBIA (93%); ETHIOPIA (92%); KENYA (92%); NIGERIA (92%); ENGLAND (91%); UNITED STATES (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); NEWS BRIEFS (78%); POLITICAL VIOLENCE (78%); SENTENCING (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (77%); APPOINTMENTS (77%); BRIBERY (77%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (76%); CORRECTIONS (76%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (76%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (73%); JAIL SENTENCING (72%); ACQUITTAL (72%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (72%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (71%); GOVERNORS (71%)
TEXT: Among the usual gloomy records of death and warfare which dominated the daily news highlights put out by the African Union's situation room in Addis Ababa yesterday, one report stood out, not only because it was good news but because it was rare. It said that Mozambican judge Dimas Marroa had sentenced former transport and communication minister Antonio Munguambe to 20 years in prison for stealing state funds, the highest-level corruption conviction ever in the country. The report prompted the thought: when was the last time one of Africa's "big fish" was convicted of corruption? Nothing recent came to mind. Second perhaps only to political violence, corruption is bleeding this continent dry. After some promising initiatives over the last two decades or so, the fight against it seems to be flagging. Former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba was for the last decade or so perhaps the biggest fish in the dock for corruption. His successor, the late Levy Mwanawasa, put him there for stealing $500 000 out of the public coffers, small change for the man later convicted by a British court of stealing nearly $50 million in public money during his decade in office. But in August last year the Zambian courts acquitted Chiluba, despite the fact that his wife Regina had already been convicted of receiving some of the stolen goods from him. Meanwhile in Nigeria, the granddaddy of Africa's corrupt states, Nuhu Ribadu, whom former president Olusegun Obasanjo had appointed as the first head of the country's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission, was sent on a one-year training course in December 2007 by Obasanjo's successor Umaru Yar-Adua, after his agency charged a wealthy, politically connected former governor for bribery. Ribadu got the hint and fled to England on return from his training course, telling the New York Times rather pertinently: "If you fight corruption, it fights you back." Ribadu's fate echoed that of John Githongo, Kenya's anti-corruption chief, who also fled to England in 2005, after going after some big fish. In these countries, as often elsewhere, anti-corruption efforts are usually launched by the current leader against his political enemies and, when power changes hands, the efforts are dropped. That, depressingly, is a pattern that has also been followed here at home, of course. The dropping of charges against President Jacob Zuma last year disturbingly puts us in the same boat as more infamously corrupt countries like Kenya and Nigeria. If anything tells us we are increasingly becoming part of the continent, rather than some quasi-Western bridging nation attached to its lower extremity, it is this. The New York Times has quoted Daniel Kaufmann, an authority on corruption at Washington's Brookings Institution, as saying: "We are witnessing an era of major backtracking on the anti-corruption drive. And one of the most poignant illustrations is the fate of the few anti-corruption commissions that have had courageous leadership. They're either embattled or dead." This is true. A study by Transparency International has shown that none of the anti-corruption agencies launched with fanfare in countries like Nigeria, Kenya, Tanzania or Uganda has any independence from the government. Their heads are appointed by the president and may be fired by him. That is the critical failing, of course. Without such independence, anti-corruption easily becomes just another arrow in the already-crowded quiver of powers the typical African president commands to persecute his enemies. Is the Munguambe conviction different? It seems so. He was elevated from deputy minister to full minister by current President Armando Guebuza in 2005 after he took over from Joaquim Chissano. If there are no underlying political rivalries which the outside observer has not detected, Guebuza will stand out as a rare leader on this continent; a genuine enemy of corruption.

TITLE: Farmer challenging suspension now probed for corruption
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TEA (90%); TEA FARMING (90%); EXECUTIVES (89%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (89%); LITIGATION (89%); AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (78%); SUITS & CLAIMS (78%); FORENSICS (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); BUSINESS FINANCIAL TROUBLE (71%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (53%)
TEXT: A ROOIBOS tea farmer who is challenging his alleged unlawful suspension as managing director of a state-funded tea enterprise that uplifts emerging farmers in the Nieuwoudtville area is being investigated for alleged corruption. In December, the board of directors of Nieuwoudtville Rooibos Pty Ltd suspended its managing director, Tobie Nel, with full pay, and prohibited him from entering his office or from keeping his laptop. The company has since appointed forensic auditors Ernst & Young to investigate whether Nel had bought in rooibos from other areas, undermining the company and its multimillion-rand, government-sponsored empowerment project for the Hantam District. The allegations were made after a fact-finding mission by the Northern Cape Department of Agriculture. A forensic report is expected within two weeks. Nel, however, alleged in court papers that he suspected his suspension was related to his alerting the Northern Cape government to the company's financial crisis. He said he had begged for assistance to save the project, but none had been forthcoming. All he had received was resistance from the government official who had, since his suspension, stepped into his shoes. Nel challenged his suspension in an urgent application in the Western Cape High Court yesterday. His counsel, Ray McClarty SC, argued that Nel was entitled to a spoliation order that would entitle him to go back to work and get back his work keys, phone and laptop. McClarty said Nel was suspended without warning and prohibited from going back to work under the threat that if he did, he would face disciplinary or legal action. McClarty said it was unlawful for a board of directors to suspend a director, as only shareholders could do this. He had a right to return to his fiduciary duties of managing the company. It was not correct of the company to say that he was not entitled to spoliation because he did not resist the suspension and prohibition. Although he did not chain himself to his desk, he did not consent to suspension and immediately sought legal help, McClarty said. Advocate Guy Elliott, for Nieuwoudtville Rooibos, said the board was entitled to suspend Nel because he was, by legal definition, a senior emplo-yee, not a director. Elliott ar-gued that Nel had not dealt with his suspension in two months, therefore it created the impression that he passively complied with it. Judge Willem Louw reserved judgment. karen.breytenbach@inl.co.za

TITLE: Goodwood constables to appear in court on corruption, theft rap
SUBJECT: SHOOTINGS (92%); ARRESTS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); MURDER (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); GUNSHOT WOUNDS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); DRIVING WHILE INTOXICATED (73%); CHILDREN (72%); HEAD INJURIES (70%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (51%)
TEXT: TWO Goodwood police officers will appear in court today on charges of corruption and theft, bringing to 11 the number of officers arrested in the Western Cape this year. And an Ocean View police officer shot dead his wife in their Paarl home before turning the gun on himself. Neighbours had heard them arguing. When police officers arrived at the Polonaise Street home on Saturday night, they found the body of Antonet Scheepers, 34, in the lounge with a gunshot wound to the head. The body of her husband, Constable Wayne Scheepers, 35, was found in the kitchen, also with a gunshot wound to the head. His service pistol, a 9mm Z88, was lying next to him. The couple's two young children were not in the house at the time of the shooting. An inquest and murder docket has been opened. The two Goodwood police constables due in court today were arrested by colleagues on Thursday on charges of corruption and theft. Police said it was alleged the constables had arrested a man for drunk-driving on March 28. They allegedly took his cellphone and bank card, and withdrew money from his account. They bring the total of arrested police officers this year to at least 11, their charges including theft, defeating the ends of justice and attempted murder. A number of police reservists have also been arrested. michelle.jones@inl.co.za

TITLE: Let's build systems to prevent corruption before it becomes organised crime
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); BUDGETS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); MAYORS (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); AUDITS (89%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INSPECTIONS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (72%); WAGES & SALARIES (71%); CITY LIFE (69%); WRITERS (66%); INJUNCTIONS (60%); IRRIGATION (51%)
TEXT: In the battle against corruption, finding corruption is step one. Consider South Africa and Peru. In his budget speech, Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan cited the discovery of corruption amounting to more than R2 billion. In five months, South African investigators identified 1 200 officials "as having participated in tender fraud or having received money and not paid taxes on it". Meanwhile, in Peru, the Comptroller of the Republic, Fuad Khoury, recently talked about that country's corruption investigations. " 'Commissions' of 10, 15 or 20 percent have been talked about before," Khoury said, "but we have found squandering of almost 100 percent." Beginning last August in Peru, 120 investigators made unannounced audits in four regions. They found "very important evidence of corruption". The tricks were the same ones found throughout the world. Projects and purchases have price tags far above market prices. Salaries are paid to phantom personnel. Unauthorised advances are paid. Money is stolen, with pretend receipts. Sound familiar? But the Peruvians may be even bolder than elsewhere. In Ancash, regional president Cí©sar 193lvarez created a project to improve the Wecrococha-Pochgoj irrigation canal, which is located, as one Peruvian journalist put it, "in the middle of nowhere." The project was budgeted at over $1.5 million (R10.87m). The regional government cashed cheques for $1.25 million. Investigators visited the middle of nowhere and found that absolutely no work had been done. Or how about this case of political contempt overwhelming internal controls? In the town of Pallasca, the mayor paid the equivalent of R2.4m for the delivery of a front-end loader and a mixer that cost less than R1.1m. The town's treasurer told investigators that he brought this difference to the mayor's attention. "Just write the cheque, dammit!" the mayor replied, after threatening to fire the treasurer. Note this, South Africans. Despite uncovering such egregious cases, the Peruvian investigations have already sparked resistance and excuses. Regional president 193lvarez complained that the investigations were "impeding the continuity of the Ancash regional government's activities, paralysing its administration and management." On January 8, at his request the Second Joint Court of Huaraz passed an injunction suspending "surprise investigations". In both South Africa and Peru, inspections and audits are bearing fruit. Anti-corruption leaders in government are providing strong direction. In both countries, newspapers and magazines are ardent opponents of corruption. And in both countries, despite some arrests being made, no "big fish" have been fried. Now both countries must move from finding corruption to fixing it. This will require both preventing and subverting corruption. Prevention means making government systems, such as tendering, more resistant to dishonest officials and bribe-giving business people. To fight corruption, monopoly powers have to be reduced and competition increased. Discretion in official actions must be circumscribed. Accountability must be enhanced, through performance indicators and feedback from citizens, businesses, and public officials themselves. Conflict of interest is an urgent area for reform. No political party should own a company that participates in public tenders. No government official or party leader-or their relatives-should participate in tenders. With the huge numbers of cases of corruption reported in these countries, the right metaphor here is not cowboy corruption but organised crime. Once corruption becomes systemic, you have to go beyond prevention to subversion. Subverting corruption means understanding corrupt systems, identifying their weak points, and going after them using the tools from fighting organised crime. First you have to understand how organised corruption works. Take tendering, for example. How are corrupt buyers and sellers found and matched? How do they make and enforce their implicit contracts? What footprints do their illicit transaction create, and how do they try to cover them up? To find the answers, ask the people. Citizens know where corruption affects them, from getting drivers' licenses to receiving public services. Lawyers understand the workings of corruption in legal systems. Accountants know the illicit games played with audits. Business people understand how corrupt systems of tendering work. Surprisingly, in my experience public servants will explain how corrupt systems work, as long as your questions focus on systems and not individuals and as long as they can tell you confidentially. The trick is to find out what all these parties know without putting them at risk. You can survey people anonymously, asking them where corruption takes place. You can interview insiders individually and confidentially, asking them how a corrupt system works. For example, a study of tendering should lay out the various steps: prequalifying bidders, establishing technical criteria and their weights, judging the bids, making post-award changes, and paying the contract. Each step is susceptible to corruption. Interviewees are asked, "Here is how things are supposed to work in prequalification. In your experience, what problems tend to emerge? How prevalent do you guess these problems are? What distortions are created?" The results of many such interviews (perhaps 15) can help you diagnose a corrupt tendering system. With this information, you go after the corrupt systems. You use undercover agents and electronic surveillance. You induce key insiders to become state witnesses. You can document extortion by using hidden video cameras, undercover agents, and confidential exit interviews. South Africa and Peru are finding lots of cases of corruption. This is good news for both countries. Investigations are good. Enforcing the rules is good. But the next step in the battle against corruption must move beyond investigations, necessary though these are. l Klitgaard is a professor at Claremont Graduate University and is the author of eight books, including Controlling Corruption and High-Performance Government. He is currently on sabbatical in South Africa. robert.klitgaard@gmail.com

TITLE: Cancer of corruption now in ANC's bones
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (89%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (77%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (77%); POISONINGS (76%); RACE & RACISM (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (71%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (71%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (70%); DIVESTITURES (67%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (64%); CONTRACT AWARDS (63%)
TEXT: The extent to which the ANC has lost its hold over its own core principles is astonishing. The rot has been evident for some time, spreading ever deeper into the very soul of the organisation, but the speed of its acceleration over the past few days with the consummation of the biggest corruption deal yet, with new injections of malevolence from the toxic Youth League leader Julius Malema and the resurrection of white racist extremism through the murder of Eugene Terre'Blanche, has poisoned the national atmosphere to a degree not seen since pre-democracy days. I don't believe Malema's insistence on singing that "shoot the boer" song had any direct role in Terre'Blanche's murder. But the fact that the two coincided has inflamed racial passions. Thanks to Malema, the faded and farcical Terre'Blanche's racist cause has found a new lease of life in his death. All of which means we have gone backwards on the two core principles that carried the ANC through all the long years of its liberation struggle, through the tough constitutional negotiating process and into the dawn of the new South Africa - the principle of non-racialism and the principle of clean, honest government that would deliver a better life for all. We have become a corrupt country. The Eskom expansion deal, which the World Bank consummated last Friday with a $3.75-billion (about R28bn) loan, stood to make the ANC a cool R1bn thanks to its 25 percent shareholding in Hitachi Africa to whom Eskom's former chairman, Mohammed Valli Moosa - a member of the ANC's National Executive Committee - conveniently awarded the contract. The ANC's Treasurer-General, Mathews Phosa, has now jumped in belatedly with an attempt at damage control by saying the party intends disinvesting from Hitachi Africa. At least that shows a degree of sensitivity to public outrage, but the fact remains that the ANC will still make a handsome profit from the sale of its shares in a company that has been gifted such a huge contract. Moreover, the Public Protector's highly questionable legitimising of the deal still stands. That gentleman found last February that Moosa's role did indeed constitute conflict of interest, then bizarrely declared that this didn't affect the contract. So it's OK for the ANC in its capacity as controller of the State to hand out hugely profitable contracts to the ANC in its capacity as a political party. I reckon that makes the ANC a "tenderpreneur". Which surely gives an official licence to all other tenderpreneurs. Two other windfalls have come the ANC's way. First was the arms deal which brought in millions. The second was Oilgate, in which our state-owned fuel corporation, PetroSA, effectively gave the ANC a buckshee R15 million to help it pay for its 2004 election campaign. In other words we, the taxpayers, effectively funded the ruling party's election. Why is all this happening? Why has corruption become so endemic? Why has it taken so long for the leadership of the ANC to crack down on Malema, whose persistent verbal abuse amounts to a form of corruption? As President Jacob Zuma has now pointed out, the Youth League is not an independent organisation but part of the ruling party. So why did the president not act long ago to stop Malema poisoning our racial atmosphere, insulting people, disparaging our courts and our constitution and the role of opposition parties and the media in a democracy, or call him to order for flying his own policy kites in conflict with those of the government, for interfering in a delicate foreign policy issue and publicly embracing a neighbouring tyrant? Why instead of doing any of that did Zuma actually praise Malema, describing him as a potential future leader of the ANC, thereby not only condoning his behaviour but emboldening him to become even more outrageous. The answer lies in what might be called the Law of Creeping Corruption. If corruption, verbal or monetary, is not dealt with the moment it manifests itself, the corrosion will spread. And the more it spreads the harder it becomes to stop. The arms deal was the ANC's original sin. One can see how it came about. The ANC leadership returned home from exile and prison after having been outlawed for 30 years. Most of the returnees had no homes to go to, no jobs to sustain themselves and their families, and the ANC itself had no premises to occupy or money to build up an organisational structure and prepare for its first election. So the need for money was acute. And as anyone with any knowledge of the ways of the world knows, the place to get quick money is in the arms bazaar. The big arms manufacturers pay fat kickbacks to secure government contracts for the supply of weaponry. And their own governments turn a blind eye to the corruption involved, for the contracts boost their budgets. So that's where the ANC went, with the thin cover-up of what were called "offsets", meaning an undertaking by the suppliers to invest in South Africa and help create jobs. A phoney justification because the fact is we didn't need most of those weapons, some of which have still not been delivered and many are unused. But the real crime was the cover-up which began when the scandal became public and has continued ever since. The right thing would have been for the government to institute a judicial inquiry immediately, bringing everything into the open and presenting its own urgent need for money to recover from the crime of its 30-year banning as a powerful mitigating factor. The whole thing could have been run on the lines of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with an exchange of amnesty for truth telling. There would have been a national uproar for a few days, then the scandal would have been over - forever. Instead the facts were covered up so that they festered, periodically breaking out with new revelations and ultimately poisoning the whole body politic with its infectious suppuration. To switch the analogy, the primary cancer should have been surgically removed early. The failure to do so has allowed the cancer to metastasise to the point where the whole body politic is now riddled with it. Eradicating it now is difficult, for we have reached a kind of corruption gridlock. When so many people in high places have the dirt on each other, no-one dares blow a whistle. When the president of the country has managed to get off the hook on a major corruption case, how can he crack down on corruption anywhere else in his administration? When he rewards the acting prosecuting chief who got him off that hook with a judgeship, how can he expect to have a clean civil service all the way down to municipal level? And when it comes to Julius Malema, how can Zuma - who has turned his own machine-gun song into something of a presidential anthem - make Malema stop singing his "shoot the boer" song? It all boils down to a question of leadership. Good leaders lead by example. Uphold your principles and the rest will follow. Condone and cover-up and things fall apart. l Sparks is a veteran journalist and political analyst. His latest book, First Drafts, is published by Jonathan Ball.

TITLE: statistics 'SHOW tip of the iceberg' Zille plans law to cut corruption in province
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); LEGISLATION (89%); ETHICS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); HEALTH CARE (73%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (73%); ACCOUNTING (72%)
TEXT: PREMIER Helen Zille says the Business Interests of Employees Bill, the first major legislation under the DA, would significantly reduce the scope for corruption in her administration. Introduced yesterday, it seeks to prevent provincial employees from owning a stake of more than 5 percent in companies doing business with the province. Under consideration is a two-year "cooling off" period for provincial employees which would prevent them from participating in provincial government tenders. Although this has not been illegal in the past, it is considered unethical and comes on the heels of the Western Cape's introduction of its own ministerial handbook. The handbook limits spending on official vehicles to R510 000. This follows the public outrage over the extravagant spending by some ANC ministers on their official vehicles. Recently it also came to light, during the disciplinary hearing of two Transet employees, that Communications Minister Siphiwe Nyanda's security company GNS (General Nyanda Security) received a tender of R55 million despite having no employees and not being registered with the security regulatory authority. The bill states that before the provincial government enters into any contract "with an entity for the sale, lease or supply of goods or services, the entity must provide an affidavit... disclosing any business interests that an employee or family member of has in the entity". Companies which failed to comply could see their contracts cancelled and damages claimed by the provincial government. Employees and departmental heads of any provincial entity could face disciplinary action which could include dismissal. Exceptions would be made for the health sector and current contracts. Zille said the absence of restrictions on state employees doing business with the government was a "key driver" for corruption. "State employees with an interest in companies that tender for goods and services have a clear conflict of interest, yet this has never been regulated," said Zille. The DA leader challenged President Jacob Zuma and the eight other provincial legislatures to pass similar legislation. In August, 2008, Auditor-General Patrick Nombembe found that between April, 2005, and January, 2007, more than R540m of business was conducted between provincial governments and businesses owned or part-owned by provincial employees. Zille said this was only "the tip of the iceberg". "At national level, between August, 2007, and July, 2008, 49 state employees were identified as directors of companies that did business with national governments to the tune of R35.7m," said Zille. She said although Zuma had acknowledged the problem nothing had been done about it at national level. Sixty-five employees of the provincial government have been subjected to an audit of their interests. quinton.mtyala@inl.co.za

TITLE: special unit KEPT BUSY Municipalities investigated for corruption and fraud
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); MAYORS (89%); CONTRACT AWARDS (89%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (79%); INTERNAL AUDITS (79%); ETHICS (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (77%); AGREEMENTS (77%); POLLS & SURVEYS (75%); CRIME PREVENTION (74%); AUDITS (64%)
TEXT: FRAUD, corruption, the irregular sale of council-owned property and the illegal awarding of lucrative tenders have characterised some of the biggest municipalities in the Western Cape, now under investigation by the Special Investigating Unit (SIU). These included Theewaterskloof, Witzenberg, Bitou, Stellenbosch and Oudtshoorn, Local Government, Environmental Affairs and Development Planning MEC Anton Bredell said in a statement yesterday. But Stiffie Cronje, deputy director of the Theewaterskloof manager's office, rejected Bredell's statement. He said the corruption referred to by the MEC in his statement was by a previous administration. Because the statement did not make clear this context, Theewaterskloof wanted Bredell to withdraw it because it was causing irreparable damage to the municipality's reputation. Bredell said that so determined was his department to stamp out fraud and corruption, it was to conduct a survey in a further 29 local and district municipalities to check whether government rules and regulations were being adhered to. Bredell said the investigation of the municipalities was a clear sign that corruption would not be tolerated at local government level. "While certain municipalities presented no irregularities or instances of fraud, the investigations have, in some instances, led to criminal charges against municipal officials for other offences," said Bredell. l In the Bitou Municipality, findings were made and the department laid criminal charges against former municipal manager George Seitisho and former mayor Euan Wildeman. Their next court appearance will be on June 22. l In Stellenbosch, the third largest municipality in the province, the SIU is busy investigating cases of fraud, corruption and maladministration that were revealed by the municipal audit committee. l In Oudsthoorn - where the municipality's former executive mayor Jeffrey Swartbooi, of the Independent Democrats, was expelled for his involvement in an irregular tender contract - alleged corruption was brought to Bredell's attention by the acting municipal manager. "I immediately instructed the SIU to assist the Oudtshoorn municipality. "The investigation is underway and an outcome is not yet available," said Bredell. l At the Theewaterskloof municipality, allegations of irregular tender procedures and the sale of property in Middleton, Grabouw, Greyton, and the Caledon Airfield Development were investigated by the SIU. The Special Investigating Unit also probed allegations of irregular appointment of contractors on housing projects in Caledon. It found that there were no service level agreements and no supporting docu- ments for transactions, among others. l At the Witzenberg municipality the SIU was asked to identify and investigate irregular transactions relating to funding amounting to R860 000. "In the coming year, the department will conduct a Fraud and Ethics Survey for 29 local and district municipalities. "It will also conduct a two-day workshop with 11 municipalities to assist with the implementation of fraud prevention plans. "To further fight corruption, we will strengthen internal audit units in municipalities together with provincial Treasury, because they can play such a vital role in preventing and detecting corrupt practices," said Bredell. babalo.ndenze@inl.co.za

TITLE: housing corruption purge 1 500 officials caught, R38m recovered so far - Sexwale
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); BUDGETS (90%); REAL ESTATE FRAUD (78%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (78%); PROPERTY VACANCIES (78%); RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); PUBLIC HOUSING (78%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING EXPENDITURE (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (75%); LOW COST HOUSING SCHEMES (75%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING (72%); LAWYERS (71%)
TEXT: MORE than 1 500 corrupt government officials have been caught for housing corruption since November, and the government recovered R38 million, Human Settlements Minister Tokyo Sexwale said, tabling his R16 billion budget in Parliament yesterday. "Corruption has become endemic in our society and needs to be rooted out. This much must be clear. We are undeterred in our resolve to eradicate this plague, which is so debilitating to society at large," he said. Collaboration with the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) had netted 1 570 government officials abusing the low-income housing subsidy scheme. Of those caught, 1 189 were charged and convicted, and the government had recouped about R38m in the process. Sexwale told MPs five lawyers had been struck off the roll for their involvement in housing fraud, and he expected other corrupt lawyers to suffer the same fate. Sexwale said the SIU was working with the auditor-general's office and the national and provincial housing departments to identify corrupt officials. "The team is hard at work tracking down those responsible for corruption, abuse and malpractices," he said. Sexwale also announced that since he became minister, his department had saved millions by cutting back on travelling (R20.6m), advertising (R24.4m), operational expenditure (R53.2m), administrative fees (R3.3m) and freezing posts that were considered not to be critical (R31m). He said the department had also saved R34m by reducing transfers of funds to institutions it administers. "We have also looked at not necessarily filling vacant posts - yet without undermining service delivery. These posts will remain vacant until proper realignment has been done, in line with our new human settlements mandate," he said. Business class travel was banned and the number of officials who travelled was reduced, as were subsistence allowances. An initial assessment of the 2009/10 expenditure showed the department had saved R53.2m in operational expenditure, including R20.6m saved through less travel and subsistence allowances for travelling officials, R24.4m saved by cutting down on advertising and R3.3m saved in administrative fees. It emerged in November last year that the department had overspent its advertising budget by R40m and that R22m of that was pumped into a housing awareness play called A re ageng Mzanzi (Let's build South Africa), commissioned by former housing minister Lindiwe Sisulu. A war of words erupted between the two ministers after Sexwale cancelled the production and told a Gauteng-based talk radio station: "I have no time for plays." A fuming Sisulu blasted him in an angry statement - which was later blamed on her spokesman - saying Sexwale had failed to come up with new programmes and was claiming credit for initiatives she introduced. Since taking office, former businessman Sexwale has led from the front, flying economy class and eschewing government-issued vehicles, preferring to use his own cars. Responding to Sexwale's budget speech, the DA alerted him to information the party had obtained to the effect that the acting CEO of the National Home Builders Registration Council - an agency responsible for preventing shoddy workmanship in the building of houses - had entered into a R78m contract with the Gauteng Housing Department to build 1 431 RDP houses. Sexwale urged DA housing spokesman Butch Steyn to bring evidence of corruption to him. He said he would take up the matter with the council's board.

TITLE: Countering corruption is all about balancing foes with friendly felons
SUBJECT: FELONIES (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); JOURNALISM (78%); PRESS CONFERENCES (78%); FOREIGN POLICY (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%); ROBBERY (71%); BANK ROBBERY (70%); WRITERS (69%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (67%); HEDGE FUNDS (54%); MUSHROOM PRODUCTION (54%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (50%)
TEXT: SOME YEARS ago, as a parliamentary scrounger after news, I was summoned to a press conference in the sacred hall;. My fallible recollection is that in a dingy cupboard on a tripod awaited Willie Hofmeyr, excited as a basset with a new bone. He and his legion of ferrets were planning to set up special units to sniff out the affairs of criminal swine and steal back what these bastards had stolen in the first place. In time Willie became the head of both wings of an FBI-style gangbuster operation. This made him a feared figure in the dark hearts of felons who had previously shielded their misdeeds from scrutiny - whether as bank robbers; people stealers; managers of hedge funds reporting to Goldman-Sachs; and even illegal mushroom growers such as my smelly neighbour Gatvol van der Pomp (Order of the Cold Bath). A scary event. One asked: would it even be possible for admired members of community-based associations - the 27s, 28s, 29s, etc - to put aside personal interests and take command of altruistic outfits like the Girl Guides, the Office of the Presidency (street address: Lot 5b, Stikland Meat Market) and the Rondebosch Bowling Club & Massage Parlour? Who exactly would leave behind content and idleness for the rarefied air of high office? Hofmeyr's looming shadow cast a volcanic blur over the green sprigs of our nascent democracy. The nation shivered as it went about hoarding unreturned library books, stealing electricity from looping pylons and winning tenders for building bridges made from wet cigarettes in rural areas. In time, though, the sombre, granitic, swivelling features of Willie - not unlike those of the truly famous extraterrestrial in Steven Spielberg's movie - seemed everywhere. His eyes were as blazing beams penetrating the rattiest recesses in quest of wrongdoing. Then when he found it, he pounced: snatching up illegal Jacuzzis, impounding decorative peacocks, tortoises and Mercs in the shady lanes of scumlord estates in Bishopscourt. By air, land and sea his minions swept out filth. Fearless, his tentacles tugged fatty wallets from the corrupt. Naturally he made enemies. But unlike the esteemed dwarf J Edgar Hoover, he failed to balance his foes with some friendly felons in government. Recall that Hoover made sure he could never get fired by keeping secret records, pics and diaries about such egregious politicos as JFK (the Don Juan of Washington) and LBJ (who once explained foreign policy to a journalist while peeing on a grave). They wanted to cut Hoover's twirling legs off, but never knew how much he knew. And it was "Tricky Dicky" Nixon's chief of staff, Charles Colson, who summed up the very nature of power with the pithy aphorism: "If you have them by the balls, their hearts and minds will follow." Willie really did not bear this in mind. So he has let himself and us all down. He has been axed from one wing of his foggy legal pursuits while left with the other - and what bird can fly on one wing? He can no longer go it alone - taking away free movie tickets and meal vouchers from MPs who put racehorses down as expenses and eat them if they come last. And it seems he now has to report directly to the chief induna. He also has to approach the King on all fours, licking the dust and woofing plaintively. Yet - as always in in our plucky land - some good has emerged from the general shake-up of our ancient judicial system. Someone called Jeremy Gauntlett will not be allowed to become a judge. No such luck for him; perhaps he can run a weekly 15-minute law focus on eNews, or judge beauty contests in the North-East-by-West Province. The road to legal omniscience is now clear for (whom else?) Gatvol van der Pomp. While he awaits the call to fame, my drunk neighbour will be tending his mushrooms. Especially the ones with red dots up their smooth, faintly oily stems. They say that if you eat them (preferably with bacon, fried eggs and polony) you receive strange visions of the future in which Fifa soccer balls plus logo deck the halls of folly, in exchange for politicians selling their buddies short. I certainly believe it.

TITLE: SABC calls in Special Investigating Unit to probe corruption and mismanagement allegations
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (94%); CORRUPTION (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BROADCASTING INDUSTRY (90%); PUBLIC BROADCASTING (89%); EXECUTIVES (89%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (89%); MISCONDUCT (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (74%); HUMAN RESOURCES (71%); PUBLIC FINANCE (71%); APPOINTMENTS (69%)
TEXT: HEADS may roll at the SABC as the public broadcaster's new board, chaired by Ben Ngu-bane, has roped in the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) to investigate allegations of corruption and financial mismanagement amounting to hundreds of millions of rand. SABC spokesman Kaizer Kganyago said yesterday that a team of investigators from the SIU, headed by state crime-buster Willie Hofmeyr, started work at the Auckland Park head office in Johannesburg, on Monday. Their probe was expected to continue for the next few months. Kganyago said the new board had felt the expertise of the SIU was needed to help investigate outstanding cases identified by the Auditor-General in his report on the embattled corporation last year. The Auditor-General's probe was at the request of the National Assembly's committee on communications, prompted by a dossier of alleged wrongdoing by senior officials submitted by communication unions. That investigation led to the suspensions of senior officials, including chief financial officer Robin Nicholson, head of audience services Anton Heunis, head of procurement Mabela Satekge and former head of content enterprises Mvuzo Mbebe. Nicholson and Heunis were given final written warnings by a disciplinary committee, while Satekge's hearing continues. Mbebe, whose disciplinary hearing had yet to be concluded when his contract expired two months ago and was not renewed, has since taken the public broadcaster to court. He is arguing that he should no longer be subjected to the hearing as he is no longer an employee of the corporation. Kganyago said the SIU would follow up on all the issues raised by the Auditor-General and submit recommendations to the board. "They will focus on issues of corporate governance, commercial enterprises, content enterprises, financial systems and human resources policies and procedures... in relation to compliance with the Public Finance Management Act," said Kganyago. He said the board had set no timeframe for the SIU but he hoped the probe would be finalised in the next few months. Kganyago said there were cases, arising from the Auditor-General's recommendations, which had been reported to the police. It was up to the police to act on the information against the implicated individuals. The chairman of the communications committee, Ismail Vadi (ANC), welcomed the decisive step taken by the board. "From the time of the Auditor-General's report the committee has insisted that they proceed on outstanding matters. "If it warrants a criminal investigation the law enforcement agencies must proceed. The fact that the (SIU) is investigation is on is a positive thing," said Vadi. Recently, the SABC suspended former acting group chief executive officer Gab Mampone on allegations of misconduct. Mampone, who returned to his position of group executive for commercial enterprises early this year when Solly Mokoetle was appointed the CEO, was suspended in February.

TITLE: Vavi hits out at Zuma for not acting on corruption
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (93%)
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (77%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (71%); FAMILY COMPANIES (69%); HOTELS & MOTELS (55%)
TEXT: COSATU general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi has hit out at President Jacob Zuma and his cabinet for not taking "decisive action" against "corrupt" ministers. Vavi said there should be an investigation into allegations that Co-operative Government and Traditional Affairs Minister Sicelo Shiceka had misrepresented his academic qualifications on his CV and had been spending department money improperly, while his wife had been driving an official car. He said Communications Minister Siphiwe Nyanda, who spent half a million rands staying in luxury hotels in Cape Town while his official residence was being renovated, should also be investigated. "There have also been allegations that he used his position to unfairly get tenders for his companies, and this needs to be investigated," Vavi said. Nyanda is said to own a 50 percent stake in GNS (General Nyanda Security) Risk Advisory Services, which has at least five contracts with government agencies. It has been alleged that with some, proper procedures were not followed. Asked whether he thought Zuma was hesitant to act against ministers because he might feel compromised because of his own or his family's business dealings, Vavi said: "I don't know, but we expect him to act like a leader." Zuma had promised repeatedly that corruption in government would be dealt with decisively. This was also one of the ANC's key election promises. Vavi said Cosatu's central executive committee had "reaffirmed its determination to fight relentlessly ... the cancer of corruption". "Corrupt individuals" would be targeted. "The central executive committee expressed regret that the government had not inspired confidence through more decisive action against people perceived to hold power in government," he said. He said allegations that his wife Noluthando's business dealings with SA Quantum constituted a conflict of interests for him as Cosatu leader and spokesman were a deliberate attempt by "tenderpreneurs" to smear him. Vavi also spoke out against a "new tendency" by "a faction without any particular political ideology" to take control of the movement "for its narrow programme of accumulation of personal wealth". Echoing a phrase used by ANC Youth League leader Julius Malema last month, Vavi said: "To this faction there are no permanent friends or enemies. "(Thabo) Mbeki was an enemy only because he consistently raised the use of leadership positions for ... crass materialism. President Zuma will be an enemy if he takes action against the use of our structures for personal accumulation."

TITLE: Selebi corruption defence costs taxpayers R14m - so far
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (77%); WAGES & SALARIES (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (67%)
TEXT: TAXPAYERS have paid R14.5 million for former top policeman Jackie Selebi's legal fees during his four-year battle against corruption charges - but the final tally could be higher. Police Minister Nathi Mthethwa revealed this yesterday in a written reply to a parliamentary question by Freedom Front Plus MP Pieter Groenewald. Selebi will learn his fate when Judge Meyer Joffe hands down his judgment in the South Gauteng High Court in Johannesburg on July 1. Mthethwa said that, while no legal costs were outstanding "at present", the case against Selebi had yet to be finalised "and further accounts are expected to be submitted for payment". The costs paid so far related only to Selebi's legal fees. The state picks up the tab as the alleged crimes were committed while he was commissioner of police. Selebi earned his full salary after being put on extended leave in January, 2008. Selebi's trial on one count of defeating the ends of justice and two of corruption, relating to his friendship with convicted drug dealer Glenn Agliotti, finally started in October. He allegedly received at least R1.2m from Agliotti and others.

TITLE: Stellenbosch corruption case for trial in August
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CONSPIRACY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TESTIMONY (78%); RELIGION (70%); CONTRACT AWARDS (67%)
TEXT: THE corruption case against a former Stellenbosch mayor and five co-accused is to go to trial next month after a lengthy investigation by the Hawks. Controversial former mayor Patrick Swartz and his co-accused - former deputy mayor Cameron Mcako, councillors and officers Fred Mkhontwana, Mvuyisi Badi and Sandile Swartbooi, and alleged co-conspirator Lindikhaya Maqeba - are charged with corruption. On their first appearance in May, scores of devoted supporters gathered at the court, where they prayed and defended the accused. One supporter stated: "They will be revived like Jesus and come back twice - even three times - as strong." Others had crammed into the courtroom draped in Black Leadership Forum Flags. Some wept. But yesterday, as the six accused stepped into the dock, one wearing a flashy Pringle jersey, another in a smart check suit, only a handful of supporters, among them a minister of religion, were present. It is believed that the charges are related to alleged fraud linked to World Cup tenders to the tune of R67 million for nine sites that were to be erected as public viewing areas around the province. Senior state prosecutor Zama Matayi said R75 000 was paid into Maqeba's account for a tender awarded to Themba Mpela. Matayi confirmed that Mpela would testify for the State at the trial. Five of the accused were employed by the Stellenbosch Municipality, which has been rocked by allegations of corruption and tender irregularities. In 2008, the ANC-controlled municipality fired Len Mortimer, who was the corporate services

TITLE: President seems to be impotent in cases of corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%)
TEXT: It was recently reported that the president is planning to launch an agency to fight corruption within the state and government. At face value, this is really commendable as our country seems to be wallowing in an ocean of corruption with no land in sight. We seem to be getting deeper in every day and for every moment that passes we do not seem to know which way to swim. So, maybe an anti-corruption agency will act as our navigator and show us a way to shore. However, it would be naive to take this planned launch at face value. It is my belief, as a wise man once wrote, í¢[#x20ac]oethe sum of decisions we have made in the past make us who we are todayí¢[#x20ac]. This could be no more true than in the case of electing governments. Governments, at least those appointed under democratic processes, are elected based on the promises they make to the people. As in most Western democracies there seems to be a growing tendency to not trust, let alone believe, what government officials say to the general populace. This is a bad omen for democracy. Those not interested in its prosperity will be happy with this state of affairs as it will ensure their continued stay in power, up to a point where calling the election process democratic will be a charade. All of this starts with unfulfilled promises and then trying to cover up the lies or threaten those trying to expose the lies, or both. At this stage there is no distinction between those who are members of your own party and those outside; all those trying to expose the truth must be dealt with. This puts into the spotlight the governmentí¢[#x20ac][TM]s imminent launch of the anti-corruption agency. I believe it is important to ask how did we get to this point? It seems so far in the past that former president Thabo Mbeki launched the crime-busting agency called the Scorpions. In the eyes of the public the Scorpions were seen to be effective enough in their jobs and inspired confidence. At least they had no sacred cows and were prepared to carry out their duties without fear or favour, including investigating the highest office in the land. This has to go down in our democratic history as one of the glorious moments of South Africa. So why were the Scorpions so unceremoniously disbanded and their most effective personnel scattered all over the place so as to render them ineffective? The reasons given for this hasty action remain vague and mysterious to this day. Would it not be nice if the ruling party would have the same zest for improving things like education and health as they had for disbanding the Scorpions? In the place of the Scorpions a new agency called the Hawks was installed with all the promises of even better and more efficient and unbiased investigation abilities. The Scorpions were indeed biased í¢[#x20ac]" they were biased against crime no matter where it manifested itself. This clearly was discomforting to the ruling party. Why now do we need another crime- fighting agency? It is obvious that the Hawks are out of their depth as crime within government continues to spiral. The president appears to be scared to act against his fellow comrades and he therefore becomes a lame duck. Are we now expected to believe that the new crime-fighting agency will succeed or is it another money- and time-wasting act of government? Sipho Puwani Cape Town

TITLE: Party takes a tough stance on corruption and xenophobia
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (91%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (77%); CRIME RATES (76%); SPORTS & RECREATION (76%); CRIMINAL LAW (76%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES (75%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (74%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (74%); SOCCER (71%); FORENSICS (69%); SOCCER TOURNAMENTS (52%); FIFA WORLD CUP (52%)
TEXT: THE ANC is toughening its approach to fighting corruption and xenophobia, pushing for the establishment of two regional courts in each province to handle corruption cases while suggesting that courts prioritise cases of attacks on foreigners. This comes a week after President Jacob Zuma announced the establishment of an anti-corruption task team - comprising the law enforcement agencies - to oversee and prioritise cases of graft. The issue of the courts will form part of discussions at the September's ANC national general council (NGC) in Durban. ANC secretary-general Gwede Mantashe told journalists yesterday that the party wanted to address challenges facing the criminal justice system, which include high crime levels coupled with weak forensic, investigative and prosecution capacity. "There are challenges of beefing (up) our courts and stepping up prosecution and conviction of cases of corruption. The discussion paper proposes the establishment of regional courts in each province to deal with corruption cases based on the experience and lessons learnt from the dedicated 2010 Fifa World Cup courts," Mantashe said. Meetings to deal with the issue of case backlogs and delays in the processing of cases are proposed. The document also moots a similar approach, to that announced by Zuma, of setting up a task team to handle corruption cases. Turning to xenophobic attacks, the document calls for the prioritisation of cases of crimes against foreigners.

TITLE: Zuma orders huge crackdown on corruption, irregularities
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (54%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MISAPPROPRIATION (91%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (79%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (74%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (70%)
TEXT: officials alleged to have misappropriated funds for special projects since 2006. Some of the money was earmarked for events, art venues and theatres. Last month, Minister of Arts and Culture Lulu Xingwana axed several national and provincial officials on graft-related charges and called in the SIU. The Eastern Cape Education Department probe is to focus on the procurement of goods, losses through mismanagement, theft and fraud, the mishandling of employees' benefits, and the failure to take steps to recover incorrect payments, and deviations in staff recruitment. Zuma has broadened an SIU investigation into nine major contracts involving about R1m awarded by Gauteng's Health Department. Audits last year found unauthorised spending of more than R1 billion. The Housing Department investigation is to be the continuation of a probe into the allocation of houses to false beneficiaries. Deputy Police Minister Fikile Mbalula said yesterday that corruption was "counter-revolutionary". The ANC did not want "tenderpreneurs" and "corrupt people" in its midst. Cosatu urged the SIU not to spare any effort in uncovering "any corruption or misuse of public funds".

TITLE: 2 000 government officials arrested in Sexwale's crackdown on corruption
SUBJECT: ARRESTS (94%); CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION (90%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); LITIGATION (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); CONTRACT AWARDS (77%); CONSUMER LAW (75%); CONSTRUCTION (75%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (74%); CONSUMER WATCHDOGS (70%); CONSUMER PROTECTION (70%)
TEXT: A CORRUPTION crackdown by the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) and the Human Settlements Department has led to the arrest of nearly 2 000 government officials and the recovery of millions of rands, while the focus will now turn to 20 "dodgy" contractors who won tenders worth R2 billion. The investigation, one of the biggest the unit has undertaken in recent years, was announced by Human Settlements Minister Tokyo Sexwale in Pretoria yesterday. It was also announced that the National Home Builders' Registration Council, the country's consumer watchdog body for the home building industry, was being investigated. Both Sexwale and SIU head Willie Hofmeyr said corruption and fraud in provincial governments and municipalities was "endemic", with corrupt officials abusing the housing subsidy. Sexwale said that of 7 353 government officials identified by the auditor-general for suspected subsidy fraud, 930 had been arrested, 761 were found guilty and R21.7 million was recovered. He said the SIU identified an additional 25 689 civil servants suspected of subsidy fraud, of whom 634 were arrested, 385 found guilty and R15.4m was recovered. At municipal level, the auditor-general had ordered that 6 974 council officials be investigated, of whom 346 were arrested, 151 found guilty and R7m was recovered. Of these, 76 cases were still pending, the department's director-general, Thabane Zulu, said. In total, 1 910 crooked officials had been arrested for unlawfully receiving housing subsidies, while 1 297 were successfully prosecuted. Zulu said disciplinary proceedings against the officials were under way and that more arrests were expected in the next few weeks in connection with several syndicates after three arrests were made in KwaZulu-Natal. These involved an attorney, who had been charged with 142 counts of fraud, while a contractor and an engineer were facing two criminal charges for defrauding the KwaZulu-Natal Human Settlements Department of R10m, said Zulu. He said 40 contractors would be restricted from doing business with the government. Zulu said political office- bearers were also involved. Regarding the unit's investigation of 20 contractors, Hofmeyr said the R20 million it received from the department would be used to employ 50 investigators, lawyers and data analysts. Hofmeyr said in many cases the government had "been taken for a ride" by contractors with the collusion of public servants. "The average contract we are talking about here is R100m per contract so we |are not talking about small amountsí¢[#x20ac]_ fairly large companies are involved." Hofmeyr believed that most contractors being investigated would face criminal charges, hence "a very thorough investigation is required". Sexwale said: "We are very determined and steadfast in our campaign to fight corruption, so the crackdown does not cease and our resolve does not change. I wished that what we are going to present would be the end of the story, but in our country corruption is so endemic. "It's spreading so much that it disturbs one to say that this is not the last presentation..." He said the department and Hofmeyr's unit were working closely with Parliament and the office of the auditor-general to root out corruption. "We want to send a message." Also of concern was an increase in the number of housing syndicates operating mainly in Gauteng, North West and KwaZulu-Natal, where sophisticated criminal groups sold and rented state-owned houses with the help of government officials. Sexwale said a lot more "finesse" was needed to investigate the syndicates.

TITLE: Bold new|alliance|against|corruption
CITY: JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH AFRICA (92%); PRETORIA, SOUTH AFRICA (92%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); AGREEMENTS (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); JUDGES (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); ASSET FORFEITURE (76%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (72%); APPROVALS (72%); INVESTIGATIONS (71%); SPORTS & RECREATION (70%) News.SouthAfrica
TEXT: FOUR of the country's top corruption-busting units have met to thrash out the details of a closer co-operation agreement to clamp down on corruption, Justice Minister Jeff Radebe has said. He revealed to journalists during an ANC briefing at Liliesleaf Farm in Johannesburg yesterday that the Hawks, the National Prosecuting Authority, the Asset Forfeiture Unit and the Special Investigations Unit met in Pretoria yesterday to finalise the "model" of their multidisciplinary anti-corruption task team, which was likely to be announced next month. He added that dedicated - and highly praised - World Cup courts were to be converted to hear and fast-track corruption cases. He said he had signed a performance agreement with President Jacob Zuma on the matter. One of the targets of the Asset Forfeiture Unit would be to convict at least 100 people with combined assets of more than R5 billion by 2014. "There is a problem in South Africa that there is a lack of will to deal decisively and effectively with corruption in the system," he said, adding that corruption within the police and courts would also be urgently addressed. Radebe also said more judges would be needed to staff the country's revamped, more accessible courts in future. He said more judges would soon be needed in provinces like Mpumalanga, Limpopo and the North West when high courts were brought closer to rural areas, but any new appointments would need to be included in the department's mid-term budget first. Radebe also revealed that steps were already under way which would put the administration of the courts entirely in judicial hands, as anticipated in the Superior Courts Bill, which was approved by the cabinet in May and which still has to be discussed in |Parliament. "We have seconded more personnel to the office of the Chief Justice (Sandile Ngcobo) to help judges to administer their own courts. "This will require more personnel and more judges," he said. When the bill first saw the light in 2006, it caused a storm, as it put the administration of courts, including finances and the assignment of cases, in the hands of the department. Judges protested, as they saw this as an assault on the independence of the judiciary. The bill makes the Chief Justice responsible for the running of the country's courts, including the magistrate's courts, and it rationalises the composition, areas of jurisdiction and structures of the superior courts. It also did away with "artificial distinctions" between judges and magistrates, Radebe said. These would, in future, be known as high court judges and lower court judges. Radebe said the ANC's views on the transformation of the judiciary were based on the constitution, and did not differ from it.

TITLE: Courageous top officials can help fight against corruption in public entities
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); POLITICS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); DEFENSE SPENDING (76%); DEFENSE INDUSTRY (75%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (73%); THIS DAY IN HISTORY (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) Opinion
TEXT: Patricia de Lille's name has become synonymous with fighting corruption. Her shift to the benches of the Western Cape provincial legislature will certainly leave a vacuum in the National Assembly. For it was De Lille who arrived at the opening of Parliament in 2000, wearing a sweater emblazoned with the words: "The arms deal is out of my hands." By eschewing the fancy attire of her fellow MPs, De Lille focused attention on the multibillion-rand deal. At the time the defence procurement package was off the radar of the majority of citizens. Today more than 10 years later, the arms deal of 1999 is mostly equated with corruption, inducements and conflicts of interest. At the height of the joint investigative team's investigation into the arms deal, Idasa said that the way in which our institutions and politicians dealt with allegations of corruption surrounding the deal would be a "litmus test" for our democracy. Our institutions of democracy were severely tested as political pressure mounted on the investigative authorities and on Parliament to make the allegations go away. The chair of the standing committee on public accounts (Scopa) charged with monitoring public expenditure, Gavin Woods, found himself unexpectedly in the political hot seat. The arms deal investigation set in motion a process that would tear Scopa asunder and would eventually lead to both Woods and Andrew Feinstein's resignation. Scopa has never quite recovered, though under the current chairmanship of Themba Godi it is hesitantly trying to find its feet many years on. So recently it felt like a blast from the past when Scopa was briefed by head of the Hawks Anwa Dramat on the ongoing investigation into the unanswered questions regarding corruption in the arms deal. The elite Scorpions, replaced by the Hawks, were another indirect casualty of the politics related to the arms deal. For years since the investigative team's report, rumblings of further investigations have been doing the rounds but no one, not even the most optimistic among us, believed that there was any serious appetite for the controversial investigation to be reopened. The essence of Dramat's presentation was that the Hawks lacked the capacity both financially and otherwise to pursue the investigation. There were more than million documents in relation to the alleged acts of corruption in relation to the BaE and German Frigate Consortium deals which needed to be sifted through. One person has been assigned to do so. Sifting through the documents, he said, would take about three years. Only then might decisions about further charges be made. In addition, the British and German governments were not being as co-operative as they might. In a supreme act of first world hypocrisy it was in fact Tony Blair who shut down the UK Serious Fraud Office investigation into BaE's involvement in the arms deal. Scopa seemed dissatisfied with some of Dramat's assertions, yet what is to be done? Given the scars it still carries from the last investigation, it is highly unlikely that Scopa will again open up this Pandora's box. Dramat told the committee that he had not had discussions with the president about the matter. The allegations of corruption into the arms deal reach uncomfortably to the highest echelons of government. The president himself has been tainted by his association with the corrupt Schabir Shaik. President Zuma's political position will always be precarious for as long as his name has not fully been cleared of corruption charges which were levellled at him. Societies sink further and further into indifference about corruption when leaders are unable to lead with conviction because they themselves are too tainted by allegations. Scopa is caught between a rock and a hard place. For no matter how good its intentions are, it was compelled to defer to Dramat's assessment of the situation: too much paperwork, too little money and capacity to take this further. Dramat did not say this explicitly, but it was implicit in his briefing. But if Dramat's presentation to Parliament was disheartening, then Cheryl Carolus's detailed briefing to the same committee two weeks ago on the steps SAA was taking to deal with the acts of fraud and mismanagement by former CEO Khaya Ngqula was a copybook example of what a briefing to Parliament should look like. It also made one wish that there were more bold board chairs of parastatals like Carolus. Tough and direct, Carolus does not suffer fools and one gets the feeling that there will be no safe haven for corruption within SAA. Carolus has that rare commodity that creates integrity in public life - courage. It is a commodity in short supply in many of our public institutions and without it the arms deal and other such deals tainted by corruption will continue to haunt us and undermine our efforts to create a just society. l February is manager of Idasa's Political Monitoring and Information Service.

TITLE: Cosatu to step up anti-corruption campaign
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (84%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ELECTIONS (89%); LABOR UNIONS (78%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); STRIKES (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICS (76%); INTERVIEWS (76%); NATIONALIZATION (75%); LIBERALISM (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (60%) News.Politics
TEXT: Vavi also said the labour federation would step up its campaign against corruption by building an anti-corruption institution of civil society, or "corruption watch", to fight the scourge. He did not mention the names of those he accused of buying youth support. In recent months, the league has started to identify individuals it would support in the party's 2012 leadership elections. ANCYL president |Julius Malema has threatened that the league would only support those who supported the league's stance on the nationalisation of mines. President Jacob Zuma has fiercely reprimanded the league for "holding the party to ransom", instead of engaging in real debates. He also said in a recent interview that the league was employed by leaders outside |it to advance their own |agendas. League spokeswoman Magdalene Moonsamy yesterday denied that league members were being "bought", because, she said, the league had "never raised a name in terms of the succession debate". She denied that Malema had previously repeatedly expressed the league's support for Deputy Police Minister Fikile Mbalula in public. She said the media and the alliance were mistaken about this, but she admitted that the issue of generational mix within the ANC's leadership had arisen. This was an ideological issue and succession preferences would only be raised by league branches "when the time comes". Vavi, who toned down his language yesterday, but not his message, after warnings by |the ANC last week about public spats between alliance partners, warned that there was still "a risk of implosion" at the upcoming alliance summit if the ANC insisted that it alone was the political centre of the alliance. Vavi told delegates that the labour federation was "disappointed" that the ANC had insisted on this view at its NGC. Vavi said the neo-liberals in the party, "the remnants of the 1996 class project", as well as those bought by the tenderpreneurs, who were part of "the new tendency", wanted to "collapse the alliance" by excluding Cosatu from decision-making in government. "They mean that there should be no programme, |no consultations on any |matter, as they read any form of consultation as giving too much to Cosatu and its communists, and they want to |continue to place all faith in government leaders and technocrats to take the key decisions," he said. Vavi repeated Cosatu's threat that it would not support "corrupt or lazy" candidates for next year's local government elections, even if they were from the ANC. He also gave an overview of the negotiations during the recent public service sector strike, which he labelled a "success". He rejected claims that he and other trade union |leaders had been trying to |further their own political ambitions during the strike, which took place in the weeks leading up to the NGC.

TITLE: Fraud and corruption probe of Stellenbosch|Municipality widens
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (91%); MAYORS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CONSPIRACY (78%); SEARCH WARRANTS (73%); CONTRACT AWARDS (68%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: THE Special Investigations Unit (SIU) has been given carte blanche to investigate allegations of maladministration, fraud and corruption in the Stellenbosch Municipality. The town's mayor, Cyril Jooste, and Local Government MEC Anton Bredell said in joint statement yesterday an initial SIU inquiry into allegations a Khayamandi developer made in 2009 had been extended after further irregularities had been uncovered. Stellenbosch spokesman Vernon Bowers confirmed that the initial investigation delved into fraud linked to the 2010 World Cup to the tune of R67 million for nine sites that were to be erected as public viewing areas around the province. Former mayor Patrick Swartz, former deputy mayor Cameron Mcako and councillors Fred Mkhontwana, Mvuyisi Badi, Sandile Swartbooi and alleged co-conspirator Lindikhaya Maqeba have already been charged in connection with alleged fraud. In court last year, State prosecutor Zama Matayi said R75 000 was paid into Maqeba's account for a tender awarded to Themba Mpela, a developer from Khayamandi. Mpela is to testify for the State. Bredell and Jooste announced that a presidential proclamation was granted on January 14 giving the SIU full powers to investigate the municipality. "The SIU can request any reasonable information required (without needing a search warrant), order any person to appear before the unit and to produce specified documents. "Any member of the SIU can enter any premises and attach any documents necessary to further investigations, and members of the SIU can instruct members of the SAPS to assist them," the statement read. Asked what new irregularities had been uncovered, Bowers said he did not know. Tania Colyn, head of communications in Bredell's office, said: "We can't go |into the details because of |the sensitive nature of the |allegations." aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: Nation needs 'a culture that says no to corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (91%); POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); POLITICS (90%) News.Politics
TEXT: POLITICAL parties are unlikely to fight corruption of their own will, and need to be pushed by citizens to do so, former National Assembly speaker Frene Ginwala has said. Speaking at the launch of pressure group the Council for the Advancement of the SA Constitution's (Casac) campaign to "red card" corruption at Liliesleaf Farm in Johannesburg yesterday, Ginwala said the political will to fight corruption "does not exist in a vacuum and governments are not made up of saints, no matter which political party they belong to". "No party is going to do it on its own. You need a culture that says no to corruption," she said. Businesses could start by publishing in their annual reports all their donations, including to political parties, even though there were no laws in place at present to enforce transparency on party political funding, she said. Casac chairman Sipho Pityana said the council proposed the setting up of a body on corruption, with an independence similar to that of the judiciary.

TITLE: Anti-corruption record defended
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAWYERS (71%); ASSET FORFEITURE (56%) News.Politics
TEXT: THE cabinet has defended the government's anti-corruption track record in a direct response to criticisms from the Council for the Advancement of the South African Constitution (Casac) and the launch of its campaign to "red card" corruption. It cited measures including the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) probes into various departments, the Finance Ministry's working group to tighten procurement systems, the anti-corruption task team of the police's elite Hawks unit, asset forfeiture lawyers and the SIU, which was established in July 2010, and the Public Service and Administration Department's special anti-corruption unit to ensure effective disciplinary steps against those involved. "The government does acknowledge the need to fight corruption in our country. Government is also aware that corruption is a global problem that South Africa is not immune to ... We have elevated the fight against crime and corruption as one of our five key priorities," it said. At the launch on Wednesday, Casac hauled the government over the coals for not doing enough to stop corruption. Casac chairman Sipho Pityana said the council had submitted a report to the government highlighting weaknesses in current laws. "Casac ... knows very well that it should report any allegations of corruption to the relevant institutions for investigation," the cabinet said.

TITLE: Huge delay in tender |corruption probe at Correctional Services
SUBJECT: PRISONS (92%); CORRECTIONS (92%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CONTRACT AWARDS (78%); EXECUTIVES (76%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (75%) News.Politics
TEXT: CORRECTIONAL Services Minister Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula has denied sitting on a damning Special Investigating Unit (SIU) report - which exposed high-level tender corruption in her department - since it was handed to her in September, 2009. City Press reported yesterday that an SIU investigation found that former prisons boss Linda Mti - who left in 2009 to become chief of security for the 2010 World Cup - received financial benefits from a company that won more than R1.5 billion worth of tenders during his time at the department. The report recommends that criminal charges be brought against Mti, former chief financial officer Patrick Gillingham and the Bosasa group of companies for alleged tender corruption. The SIU found an "improper and corrupt" relationship existed between senior Correctional Services officials and the Bosasa group, which has over the years won government tenders worth billions of rand. Mapisa-Nqakula's spokesman, Sonwabo Mbananga, yesterday denied claims that the report had been gathering dust since 2009, saying it was "immediately" passed on to the police for further investigation. He also said the minister had already acted on a number of the report's recommendations, such as tightening up controls in the department's procurement procedures. But Mbananga emphasised that the report would not be made public. Mbananga said it was up to the National Director of Public Prosecutions, Menzi Simelane, to decide whether prosecution would follow. Police Ministry spokesman Zweli Mnisi yesterday confirmed that the matter was being investigated and that a report had been sent to the Directorate of Priority Crime Investigation (Hawks). "There were some allegations which still required further probing, so the investigation is ongoing as we speak," he said. National Prosecuting Authority spokesman Mthunzi Mhaga said he could not comment as the matter was "still in the investigation stage". The SIU is understood to have found that Bosasa funded Mti's luxury mansion and a car.
