TITLE: Absent MPs hamper passage of corruption bill
SUBJECT: LEGISLATION (92%); ELECTIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); POLITICS (89%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); CITIES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); EXECUTIVES (77%); MISCONDUCT (73%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLITICAL DEBATES (73%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (61%) News
TEXT: TRUANT MPs have halted the progress of a new law designed to prevent corruption at municipalities - just weeks before local government elections are due to be held across the country. Parliament could not vote on the Municipal Systems Amendment Bill, which among other things aims to professionalise municipal management, because 231 out of 400 MPs went awol yesterday. This left the House with 32 members short of a 50 percent plus one voting quorum. All parties participated in a debate on the bill, but when it came time to vote, DA chief whip Ian Davidson pointed out to deputy Speaker Nomaindia Mfeketo that the chamber looked pretty empty. An electronic count soon revealed that 231 MPs were absent. To make matters worse, yesterday was the last scheduled sitting of the National Assembly until April 12. And next week has already been set aside for committee meetings. If the ANC wants the bill passed and enacted before municipal elections on May 18, a special sitting of the National Assembly will have to be arranged for next week. Those MPs who will not already be in Cape Town for committee meetings will now have to make their way back to the Mother City - at taxpayers' expense - from their constituencies across the country to vote on the bill. Hailed by the government as a "ground-breaking event for local government", the bill will make it illegal for political-office bearers to serve as municipal managers - or managers who report directly to municipal managers, such as chief financial officers. The bill defines "political office" as any position of chairperson, deputy chairperson, secretary, deputy secretary, treasurer or any equivalent position - irrespective of what the party chooses to call such a post. It also gives the Minister of Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs, Sicelo Shiceka, the discretion to prescribe the set of "skills, expertise, competencies and qualifications" required to manage a municipality. And the minister will be required to keep track of disciplinary actions taken against municipal managers to avoid those found guilty of unlawful conduct offering their services to other, unsuspecting, local councils. If a manager is found guilty of an offence, he or she will be prohibited from being employed at any municipality for the next 10 years. Opposition parties have broadly welcomed the new law. However, the ID and Cope warned that only time would tell if political parties had the necessary will to enforce the bill, while the DA said the law did not go far enough to depoliticise the management of municipalities. Acting Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs Minister Nathi Mthethwa - Minister Shiceka has been off sick since early this month - said yesterday the bill would change the way municipalities were run. "Our view was that local government is functional, but there are critical areas that require our urgent attentioní¢[#x20ac]_ We have realised that some municipalities, regardless of the political party in leadership, are staffed by employees who are not qualified to undertake their duties," he said. "The days of appointing bookkeepers, teachers and social scientists as chief financial officers (at municipalities) are over," he added. Mthethwa emphasised that the bill was not aimed at micro-managing municipalities from Pretoria, but that certain steps had to be taken to improve municipal management and services. DA MP and local government spokesman James Lorimer said the bill "ticks a number of boxes about what is wrong in municipalities", but suggested it did not go far enough. He joined a number of other opposition parties in blaming the ANC's cadre deployment policy as the cause of weak management at many municipalities. "Are there other people outside the ranks of the ruling party who could help put these dysfunctional municipalities back together? Yes. Are they likely to be appointed? No. Thus you can have all the rules you want, but if you don't have the people who are able to carry out the work, nothing will get fixed," he said. ID parliamentary leader Joe Mcgluwa said the fact that such a bill was required at all "demonstrates the consequences of the ANC's cadre deployment policy across the country". "While we welcome this bill we think that what is also required is for the ANC to finally end in its entirety this devastating policy of cadre deployment," he urged. Freedom Front Plus MP Pieter Groenewald went further, saying "if local government was a patient, it would be lying on its deathbed". Mthethwa acknowledged that the ANC had "made mistakes" in some instances, but denied that cadre deployment was the source of the problem.

TITLE: Corruption bombshell
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); OFFICE PROPERTY (76%); PROPERTY LEASES (76%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (76%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (76%); RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (76%); RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION (76%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (73%); PUBLIC HOUSING (73%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (72%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (72%); COMMERCIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (71%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (66%); INFRASTRUCTURE (64%) News.Politics
TEXT: THE Special Investigating Unit (SIU) yesterday provided a rare glimpse into rampant corruption in the government when it told Parliament that 16 departments and public entities were under investigation for fraud, corruption and maladministration. National police commissioner Bheki Cele, who is already under fire for his role in a multibillion-rand headquarters lease in Pretoria, faces new questions after the SIU revealed that the construction of 33 police stations - valued at more than R330 million - was under investigation for "significant irregularities". The SIU has prioritised investigations into the Pienaar, Hazyview, Brighton Beach and eSikhawini police stations after an initial probe revealed fraud and corruption that included SAPS officials having undeclared interests in suppliers awarded work by the police; the lowest quotations not being accepted; no quotations received from winning bidders; and actual payments far exceeding budgeted costs. SIU chief Willie Hofmeyr told visibly shocked MPs from the National Assembly's justice committee yesterday that more than half of the government's approximately 10 000 subsidised housing projects were suspect. This included instances where "contractors were paid for building houses which may not exist at all; were extensively incomplete; seriously defective; or were paid for more houses than were built". He said the investigation by public protector Thuli Madonsela into the Pretoria and Durban police office leases was "only one part of a far wider investigation" into the police's procurement division. So widespread is corruption at this department that the SIU has been forced to prioritise only the 20 "top cases", which alone total over R2 billion. At the SABC the SIU uncovered that between September, 2007 and March last year, about 20 employees had undeclared interests in firms that did business with the broadcaster to the tune of R2.4bn. This follows an earlier auditor-general investigation that uncovered corruption involving 20 SABC employees to the tune of R3.4m. According to Hofmeyr, a joint investigation with the Brixton commercial crimes unit had so far resulted in eight criminal cases, of which five had been referred to the National Prosecuting Authority. "There is serious criminality that is being investigated at the SABC," said Hofmeyr. The Department of Public Works is being investigated after the SIU discovered that R35m had been paid to entities in which department officials had undisclosed business interests. A contract issued by this department for the construction of "accommodation" at an undisclosed border post - valued at R375m - was also under the microscope. The public protector has already slammed Public Works Minister Gwen Mahlangu-Nkabinde for "unlawfully" entering into the police headquarters lease in Pretoria. Now the SIU is looking into another Pretoria lease, this time for a single residence which the department had leased as "residential accommodation" at an astronomical R217 000 a month - without "relevant approval". The contractor had been "positively linked to a DPW official". The Department of Arts and Culture is being probed for misusing funds ring-fenced for the 2010 World Cup. The Tshwane Metro had paid R185m between 2007 and 2010 to businesses in which 65 municipal staff members had

TITLE: I think we should all accept that corruption is a serious problem in our country - Hofmeyr
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CITY GOVERNMENT (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); RURAL DEVELOPMENT (90%); EXECUTIVES (77%); COMPUTING & INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (75%); FULL TIME EMPLOYMENT (69%); ASSET FORFEITURE (65%) News
TEXT: either had undisclosed interests or, brazenly, were the vendors doing business with their own municipal council. Further procurements of R80m were also under investigation. Ten waste management tenders at the Ekurhuleni Metro - valued at R500m and involving 19 different contractors - were under investigation. In one of these, payments totalling R37.8m had been made to service providers without delivery notes and no one at the metro could confirm whether the goods were ever delivered. Also in Ekurhuleni, information and communication technology contracts worth R32m had been awarded to a company with which the municipality's executive director of IT services had an undisclosed relationship. "He has since resigned and is now employed full-time by the company," Hofmeyr said to astonished gasps from MPs. And the municipality's director of infrastructure had admitted to approving invoices valued at R12.4m for services that were never delivered. The Department of Rural Development and Land Reform is being probed - at the request of minister Gugile Nkwinti - in what is likely to be the country's biggest-ever "data uplifting project". So far, fraud and corruption charges have been laid against three officials and a KwaZulu-Natal businessman relating to land reform grant fraud totalling R50m. And working with the Hawks and the Assets Forfeiture Unit, the SIU has seized KwaZulu-Natal farms worth a further R50m. The SIU can only investigate at the request of a department or government entity - and only after the president has signed a proclamation authorising such a probe. President Jacob Zuma has signed 16 proclamations for the 2010/2011 financial year, including one proclamation to investigate all 23 municipalities in North West. Asked by one MP whether South Africa was losing the fight against corruption, Hofmeyr said: "I think we should all accept that corruption is a serious problem in our country, but I am hopeful that we will make good progress over the next few years." He also said he was encouraged by the fact that the president had issued 16 SIU proclamations - the most in a single year - and that "significant resources" were being devoted to the problem.

TITLE: Corruption in|civil service no|surprise - Cosatu
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (94%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); LEGISLATION (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); POLICE FORCES (88%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (78%); PUBLIC HOUSING (73%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (70%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (69%) News
TEXT: COSATU has expressed shock - but not surprise - at the widespread corruption in the public service following reports that the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) is probing more than 16 government departments and public entities for fraud and corruption amounting to billions of rand. And the DA has proposed a new law to help stamp out corruption in the public service. "(Cosatu) is shocked, yet not surprised, at the SIU's reportí¢[#x20ac]_ "We congratulate the SIU for its determination to tackle what is clearly a massive and widespread growth of the cancer of crime and corruption within our public service and state-owned enterprises," federation spokesman Patrick Craven said yesterday. He said it was "particularly disturbing" that the police - "one of the very institutions which are supposed to be fighting crime and corruption" - were among those being investigated. On Wednesday, SIU chief Willie Hofmeyr told Parliament that national police commissioner Bheki Cele had asked his unit to investigate irregularities in the police's building programme. Initial investigations have revealed that projects to build or renovate at least 33 police stations across the country have fallen victim to some form of fraud, corruption or maladministration. Hofmeyr also revealed that more than half of the government's 10 000 subsidised housing projects were suspect, a situation Cosatu described as "blatant theft from the poor, who are being denied desperately needed houses and being forced to go on living in shacks". "We urge all workers to take heart from the strong stand being taken by the SIU and to report any acts of corruption and maladministration which they uncover at work. "We demand that the authorities guarantee them protection from those they accuse," Craven said. He encouraged federation members to "rally behind the SIU and government" to rid the country of a "culture of greed and self-enrichment at the people's expense" and to build a public service "which exists solely to serve the public". Meanwhile, DA chief whip Ian Davidson has called on the ANC in Parliament to support a new bill his party proposed to the committee on private members' legislative proposals last week. The DA-sponsored law would prohibit government employees or their direct family members from owning more that 5 percent of any entity that does business with the government. It also recommends that any company wishing to do business with the government should provide an affidavit disclosing whether or not it is owned or part-owned by employees of the government. And it would require all public servants to periodically disclose their business interests in the same way that cabinet members are required to do. Since 1994, the ANC has blocked every significant legislative proposal by the opposition, in most cases citing the rule that allows such proposals to be rejected if the government itself plans to introduce similar legislation in the short term.

TITLE: Cycle lane evidence of corruption by DA, says Ehrenreich
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (94%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); CITIES (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); MAYORS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (71%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (66%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: Cosatu provincial secretary Tony Ehrenreich has called for the City of Cape Town and the DA to be charged with corruption for "spending public funds on their friends" by constructing bicycle lanes in Blouberg. In February, Ehrenreich hit out at the city's dedicated bicycle lanes from Table View to the city, calling them "a great gimmick for the wealthy - while the poor have to hang outside of trains". Yesterday he again attacked the city over the lanes, saying its priorities were misplaced. "Cosatu will be filing corruption charges against the DA for spending public funds on their friends in wealthy areas when there is such a desperate need for services in poor communities," he said. "Cosatu has been made aware that influential DA officials live in the Milnerton Blaauberg area and that this is the reason why the bicycle lanes were built in that area." He said this amounted to corruption "because the DA had promised to deliver services to the poor and had instead focused on the wealthy ex-white areas". "The non compliance with election promises amounts to fraud and fraudulent behaviour is also a form of corruption. Cosatu will be calling on the South African police to investigate these allegations and to bring criminal charges against the perpetrators in the DA and the city administration," said Ehrenreich. The outgoing mayoral committee member for transport, roads and stormwater, Elizabeth Thompson, said she was "confused" by Ehrenreich's statements. Thompson said bicycle or Non-Motorised Transport (NMT) lanes were first introduced in Gugulethu, Athlone and Symphony Way in Belhar long before Milnerton. "I get confused when Tony makes these statements. He needs to understand that the plan is to integrate Phase 1A with non-motorised transport (and other forms of transport). I'm very passionate about NMT," said Thompson. babalo.ndenze@inl.co.za

TITLE: Cope would halt corruption - Lekota
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); POLITICS (78%); MAYORS (73%) News
TEXT: KIMBERLEY: Cope president Mosiuoa Lekota has gone on the attack over corruption and poor service delivery on the campaign trail in the Upper Karoo in the Northern Cape. Lekota visited De Aar, Philipstown, Petrusville and Strydenburg, where Cope councillor candidates were introduced to communities. The party has yet to announce its mayoral candidates. Lekota told voters that Nelson Mandela "would never support corrupt leaders", going on to refer to the ANC's Northern Cape chairman, John Block, who is facing charges of fraud and corruption. "The money that is meant for roads, houses and the development of our communities is not getting to the people who need it most," said Lekota. "Corruption hurts everyone, regardless of their political affiliation. Another five years of the ANC in charge of our municipalities is a lifetime too long." Lekota said promises of a better life for all had become a case of a "better life for some" thanks to corrupt leaders. "Instead of involving communities in development, the ANC chooses to dump food parcels on people just before every election. We don't just get hungry every time there is an election." Lekota said Cope aimed to stop corruption, appoint skilled officials in municipalities and involve communities in development through partnerships. "Few people realise the importance of this election, especially in this province. "We are calling for partnerships between taxpayers and poor communities, because the mismanagement of our municipalities hurts everyone."

TITLE: Hessequa mayor refutes DA claims about corruption
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); MAYORS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); CITIES (76%); BIODIVERSITY (76%); BUDGETS (74%); DIVESTITURES (73%); INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING (72%); CONTRACT AWARDS (70%); ENVIRONMENT & NATURAL RESOURCES (60%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: The ANC-run Hessequa council in the Southern Cape has come out with guns blazing in response to accusations by DA leader Helen Zille that it is corrupt and failing in service delivery. Zille made the allegations in an election campaign speech in Heidelberg last week and posted the text on Facebook. Hessequa is one of the largest municipalities in the Western Cape, stretching from the Breede to the Gouritz rivers on the coast and taking in Witsand, Slangrivier, Heidelberg, Riversdal, Stilbaai, Albertinia and Gouritzmond. The ANC won it from the DA in the last municipal election. In her speech Zille charges that the Hessequa municipality is running out of money and will soon be unable to render services. And she says the mayor is corrupt because of a letter he wrote to local businesses earlier this year asking for donations to the ANC. She also makes comparisons with adjacent Mossel Bay, run by the DA - "a municipality that works," she says. A row erupted in February when it surfaced that Hessequa mayor Chris Taute had written to businesses asking for donations, pointing out they had been awarded contracts by the ANC-run council. The DA, claiming the letter was an official council communication on a municipal letterhead, reported Taute to the Public Protector. Zille said it was unclear whether Taute had met the April 8 deadline to respond but it was "likely he will drag this out until after the election so it does not hurt his chances of re-election". Taute, who denies he used an official letterhead or threatened or tried to influence anyone into making donations, said he had replied to the Public Protector on time and was eagerly awaiting her response. He said his letter was in Afrikaans and the English translation was deliberately misleading. Also, he had used his own letterhead, designed himself on his own computer, which stated it was "From the office of the Executive Mayor". The official Hessequa letterhead was quite different. He said the Hessequa council was the first in the country to adopt an anti-corruption strategy and no councillor had ever been found guilty of corruption. Taute denied Zille's claim that Hessequa would have exhausted its capital reserve by next year, saying the council had in fact added R39 million to the fund in the current budget year. He said that while Mossel Bay had sold off all its assets and would have exhausted its capital reserve by 2013, Hessequa had a policy not to sell land under market value, to develop assets to earn sustainable revenue and to hold on to property until the market improved. Taute said he was mystified by Zille's statement that Hessequa "could join other municipalities in the region which regularly scoop up awards for service delivery" as Hessequa had already won the VUNA award for best public participation, the CAPE biodiversity award for environmental management and green vision and was rated 12th in the entire country by the Municipal IQ Survey which monitored local government. Mossel Bay was rated 16th. "Interestingly, (DA Western Cape leader) Theuns Botha himself said recently that Hessequa is the best run municipality in the country. "Perhaps Ms Zille should ask him why they have such opposing views or perhaps she is just misinformed," Taute said.

TITLE: DA councillors in Eden District guilty of corruption over vote bribe
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); VERDICTS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); ELECTIONS (78%); DUE PROCESS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); WITNESSES (77%); TESTIMONY (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); CITIES (73%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: A disciplinary tribunal has found three DA councillors in Eden District guilty of corruption for trying to bribe an opposition councillor to vote for the DA in the fight for a top position two years ago. Disciplinary hearing prosecutor Anton de Swardt yesterday confirmed that DA district councillors Henry McCombi, Patrick Murray and Johan Koegelenberg had been found guilty of offering National People's Party councillor Anthony Ewerts R20 000 to vote for McCombi in an election of the council Speaker in 2009. De Swardt said a recommendation for the dismissal of the three councillors would be forwarded to the council. Asked for comment, the DA said it would challenge the guilty finding and the constitution of the disciplinary tribunal in the high court. The chief witness in the hearing was Deon Nomdoe, a former Eden official who was convicted of bribery in a criminal case and fined R6 000 for his involvement in the attempt to bribe Ewerts. Nomdoe said he was shown R20 000 in cash by Murray, Koegelenberg and McCombi and told to offer it to Ewerts in exchange for his vote. "They said I must tell him there is a certain way he must draw his cross on the ballot," Nomdoe said. Nomdoe also played to the hearing a recording of what he said was a conversation between him and McCombi, in which McCombi had revealed that he had discussed the alleged bribe with DA Western Cape leader Theuns Botha. On the tape, McCombi tells Nomdoe that Botha had got a big fright when he learned that money had been involved. McCombi said Botha had expressed disbelief, to which McCombi had said "there was really money involved in this thing". McCombi also advised Nomdoe to resign before he could be brought before a disciplinary hearing, warning that he would be "torn apart". Nomdoe has since been included on the ANC's candidate list for the upcoming municipal elections in George. Ewerts testified that Nomdoe had called him to his office on July 30, 2009 to show him the money. "He showed me a plastic bank bag with R200 notes in. The rest of the money was in an envelope and he told me each of the two contained R10 000. He said if I drew my cross in a certain way, the DA would know that I had voted for councillor Henry McCombi." Ewerts said he did not vote for McCombi and was not paid any money, but McCombi was still elected Speaker. Ewerts said it was later established that former ANC councillor Berenice le Roux had voted for McCombi, breaking the deadlock that had confounded a number of previous attempts to elect a Speaker. Botha described the disciplinary hearing as "a lot of nonsense" and an attempt to "witch-hunt the DA". He said the tribunal had been set up without due process. "We will overturn this in the high court as fast as you can say Jack Robbins (sic)."

TITLE: 'We can't ever let our struggle be robbed by corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%) News.Politics
TEXT: 1994, but some of us in the struggle are today still down and out. We recognise there are people who were never in the struggle, but are closest to the table today." He urged people to take a stand against corruption, and to "out those people". Those who had fought in the struggle had won a non-racial, non-sexist democracy. Anyone who tried to take this away was attempting to take away the blood and sacrifice of the struggle. "We can't ever diminish the sacrifices of the struggle and convert it into something driven by tenders. "We can't ever let our struggle be robbed by corruption, not now, not ever. When people are corrupt, they don't steal from the rich, they steal from the poor," Manuel said. Freedom Day was a time to remember the sacrifices people had made in the fight for democracy, but also to recommit to the beliefs of the struggle. "We took on the might of the apartheid regime when we had no power, we had no money, we had |no businesses, we had no public |servants. "We had only ourselves and our beliefs, and the strengths of our beliefs carried us. "Day after day, we were prepared to get up and give every part of ourselves to the struggle because it was all we had."

TITLE: Corruption is biggest threat to delivery
SUBJECT: REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); COMPANY STRATEGY (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); STRATEGIC PLANNING (77%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (73%) TitleSites.CapeTimes
TEXT: A major operation was undertaken during the second term of democratic governance to perfect the structures of local government to make them as efficient as possible in delivering services to the people. The major challenge became capacity to implement the policies, decisions and strategic plans of government. The challenge manifested itself in the form of lack of management skills (strategic thinking, planning and management experience), shortage of specialised skills (engineers, etc) and general experience in running a local municipality. In this regard rural and remote municipalities suffered more than municipalities in the main cities since most skilled personnel preferred to work in urban areas. The challenge of capacity to implement was exacerbated by employment and deployment strategies which tended to be influenced by political considerations rather than ability to do the job. Unfortunately, our new democracy in some instances mixed up political deployment (at the level of elected political office bearers) and employment in specialised public service positions. This was understandable though in the light of the pervasive apartheid structures and institutions the new democratic government inherited. As a result the transformation of this system had unfortunately to be political and not based on skills and capacity in some instances thus affecting the capacity of the municipality to deliver services. The greatest challenge of all was corruption in all its manifestation. The employment of friends and members of one's political faction irrespective of skills and capacity, the choice of service providers on the basis of political considerations, friends and faction, who have no capacity to deliver the services they are contracted to deliver, tender allocations to companies which are not able to deliver the service but benefit those who make such decisions, and corrupt officials who steal and defraud the state and therefore the people. The one fatal mistake we made in this regard was to believe that the cadre moulded by the gallant struggle for liberation would be incorruptible when in government. There are three things that we missed. The first was the point that after sacrificing so much in their lives they would have an urge to live a normal life as well, like other citizens. Second, the material conditions that produced quality, selfless leaders, such as Oliver Tambo, Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu, Govan Mbeki, and many others, were radically different from the material conditions of those who have to run or work in government. In the struggle for liberation there was nothing to live for except making sacrifices (even unto death) to liberate the people from an evil apartheid system. In doing so there were no rewards except detention, torture, imprisonment or exile. Third, we also failed to understand that however idealistic comrades were and however much the struggle for liberation made them selfless and committed to the cause to liberate the people, the material conditions of being in government would change their character and personalities radically. Put simply, we failed to understand that comrades were just as human as any other human being. In this regard we must be vigilant and understand that it does not matter who is in power or employed in government, the material conditions there are bound to reshape them to behave just like any other human being. What we need is to create mechanisms to make this type of behaviour an aberration rather than the way of life. And this is the greatest challenge of our society today. We need to crowd out corrupt leaders, officials and business people who are collaborators in this crime against our people. We must make sure corruption does not pay by making their lives miserable and not leave them to live in comfort. The problem with corruption or corrupted systems is that they affect the poor more than they do the rich. The service delivery crises we face affects in the main poor communities. In a crisis situation rich people can always survive, but poor people die. When there is shortage of water poor communities go without water while rich communities turn to their boreholes. When there is no sewerage system rich people create such facilities for themselves, while poor people live with the risk of serious health hazards. When there is no electricity rich people generate their own electricity, while poor people survive by whatever means they can find. When electricity is turned off rich people's generators turn on, while poor people just go cold. It is thus not surprising that all service delivery protests take place in poor communities or where services are not available or not provided for. For a start we must accept that communities which are not given the quality services they deserve have a democratic right to engage in any form of protest, especially when they have exhausted all other avenues to remedy the situation. They are expected, though, to do so within the law as well as respect other people's rights. Based on my experience most service delivery protests relate to: 1) Failure of the council or government to deliver basic services. 2) Unnecessary or unexplained delays in delivering such services. 3) Failure of the councillors to interact with the community, keep them informed about what the council (or government) is doing about matters that affect them as well as involve them in some of the projects where it is possible. 4) Visible or known corruption cases which enrage the community especially when these are perceived as robbing them of their right to such services. There is another set of reasons for service delivery protests which are more complex and in some cases even unjustified. Some are part of the manifestation of corruption and unethical behaviour. These include protests triggered by one party to discredit another or one faction of a party against another as part of a power struggle. These struggles at times are about positions within the council or at higher levels. At other times they involve disputes about tenders or the quest to control the decision-making processes on tenders to benefit themselves. Often a legitimate course is used to achieve this objective. Although the motive might look unsavoury the course is legitimate from the community's perspective. There is one thing I feel very strongly about in relation to protests. One cannot express one's rights at the expense of the rights of others. I find it difficult to understand why people who are angry and protesting, destroy the products of poor street vendors and traders who have nothing to do with what they are protesting about. Nor does it make sense to stone cars along the highway because one is angry about one council or another in townships along those routes. There is nothing revolutionary about these acts except that they discredit the cause of the protesters. In fact I would like to submit that this behaviour is reactionary and counter-revolutionary. We need to ask ourselves what we can do as faith communities to make sure citizens of this country, especially the poor, get the services they deserve. The latent power of faith communities or churches, which has not been tapped, is their presence in every ward or community. I am sure there are many churches in Moqhaka Municipality in the Free State and in Khayelitsha who should have been the first ones to see the open toilets even before the projects were completed. These churches should have been the first to raise the alarm well before the politicians began to debate about them as a party political issue. If we are called to minister to the people we should be the first ones to make sure that: 1) People without proper documents (IDs, birth certificates, etc) have them. 2) People who deserve grants from government (old age, disability, children, etc) get them. 3) Where there is no proper sanitation the government is called upon to take care of it. 4) Where there is no water, the government should be called upon to take care of it. 5) Where a school is dysfunctional, the parents of that school and the education department should make sure it is functional. 6) Where a hospital or health facility is not providing proper health care services, that the hospital management and the health department be called upon to address the challenges. We have a responsibility and an obligation to the communities we live in and minister to. Religious communities have a tradition of offering emergency services to communities where governments failed to do so. We did this during the days of apartheid and there is no reason we cannot do it now. l Reverend Chikane, the former director general in President Thabo Mbeki's office, is president of the Apostolic Faith Mission International and a Visiting Adjunct Professor in the School of Public & Development Management at Wits University. This is an edited version of a talk, Making sense of the service delivery protests: A faith perspective, delivered on May 16 in St George's Cathedral, Cape Town.

TITLE: Social Security Agency loses R238m in grant funds to corruption and fraud
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); GRANTS & GIFTS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); CHILD CARE (53%) News
TEXT: THE South African Social Security Agency (Sassa) has lost over R238 million to corruption and fraud since its establishment in 2005, but has also recovered over R85m from those who abused the system. Of the 21 817 cases of social grant fraud Sassa has opened, 17 908 were brought to court between June 2005 and December 2010 - leading to 15 004 |convictions. Social Development Minister Bathabile Dlamini said in a written response to a parliamentary question from DA MP Patricia Kopane that each person found to have defrauded the social grant system signed an acknowledgment of debt and repaid it with interest of 15 percent. The repayments were managed by the Special Investigating Unit, which has for years been investigating fraud at the agency. The unit then pays the department, which in turn pays the funds to the Treasury. About 15 million citizens now receive support - from child care grants to disability grants and pensions - at a cost of R97.5bn this financial year. According to the response, KwaZulu-Natal suffered the highest losses due to corruption and fraud since 2005 (R88.9m), followed by the Western Cape (R34.9m), Gauteng (R28.6m), Mpumalanga (R24.2m), Eastern Cape (R18.46m), Limpopo (R14.98m) and North West (R13.9m). However, the amounts lost due to fraud and corruption have consistently decreased year-on-year in all provinces, except KwaZulu-Natal, where losses increased steadily, from R5.9m in 2005/06 to R14.2m in 2009/10, before rocketing to R25.8m in the last financial year to December alone. Correspondingly, KwaZulu-Natal leads the provinces with the highest number of social grant fraud cases reported: 5 390 since 2005. Gauteng follows with 3 340 cases, then the Eastern Cape (2 829), Limpopo (2 599), Western Cape (2 331), Mpumalanga (1 816) and North West (1 800). Dlamini said Sassa was implementing a more comprehensive anti-fraud strategy from this financial year, including closer working relationships with Home Affairs, law enforcement agencies and traditional leaders. "The partnership has been useful in assisting Sassa to effectively identify, combat and prevent further social grant fraud," she said. She added that if a person defaulted on his or her repayment schedule, the defaulter was taken back to court, while the agency was also exploring the use of garnishee orders to prevent defaults and guarantee the recovery of the fraudulently paid grants. A total of R214m in acknowledgments of debt was outstanding as at December 31 last year, while R61.6m in interest was recoverable. Other attempts to boost the integrity of the system included "continuous interrogation" of data to pick out suspicious grants. Meanwhile, the 2011 Estimates of National Expenditure says the department is saving R870m, mostly in administrative expenses related to the payment of social grants. - Political Bureau

TITLE: What's a few dozen cases of fraud,corruption to a nation?
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); MISCONDUCT (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); ETHICS (75%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (66%); SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT (65%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%); APPOINTMENTS (50%) Opinion
TEXT: THE way some people are carrying on, you would swear we were a nation of thieves and con artists. And, unfortunately, such ugly insinuations are not just coming from the usual bunch of whingers. Last week, for instance, the Treasury issued a detailed set of instructions to all government departments and public entities as part of what it described as an attempt "to improve transparency and combat fraud in institutions". This is a completely over-the-top reaction to the instances of fraud and corruption that do occur here and there. For its part, the Treasury itself could identify only 120 companies it found to be unsuitable for doing business with the state. Out of how many? Thus, far from being confirmation of widespread skulduggery, the blacklisting of a mere few dozen companies shows instead that corruption is not quite as rampant as we are often told by the rumour-mongers. Yet, in its wisdom, the government has decided that tackling corruption is now one of its 12 key objectives. As a result, its departments and institutions will have to jump through even more hoops before it can spend amounts above a certain level. As if this were not enough, the Finance Ministry also established a Multi-Agency Working Group to investigate supply chain management practices linked to corruption. This is bureaucracy gone mad, and will no doubt result in serious under-spending. And surely under-spending is just as bad as over-spending. The result is pretty much the same: fewer resources to those who need it. What will make the situation even worse is the increasingly interventionist role of the Office of the Public Protector. Thuli Madonsela, by her own admission, made recommendations to various state entities since she took office two years ago. However, she recently moaned that certain state entities were deliberately ignoring these recommendations to implement remedial actions - "even in cases of conduct failure, as in cases involving corruption, unethical conduct and abuse of power or of state resources". This disregards the fact that, in the long run, such officiousness may paralyse the work of government and its various organs. As Bongi Luthuli of the SA Board of Sheriffs pointed out: "We do not accept your report in total ... without being disrespectful, your report is not capable of being implemented." But, once again, the powers that be are deaf to such protests. Instead, the Public Protector may be given even more teeth. A new set of rules is currently under discussion in government and may be finalised within a matter of months. Yet such attempts to appease the government's critics aren't good enough for the likes of the DA. It also wants government to take action even before there is any hard evidence of corruption. Take the case of Zanele Hlatshwayo, the former Msunduzi mayor recently appointed as a manager in the KwaZulu-Natal health department. The DA went ballistic: "Msunduzi was brought to its knees by rampant maladministration and corruption. As former mayor and Exco chair, Hlatshwayo still has a great deal to answer for regarding her |disastrous tenure as political head of that municipality." Fortunately, despite such hysterical outbursts, Hlatshwayo's position is safe. Thank heaven there are still some sensible folk out in the provinces, who don't all agree with the ANC's national leadership on the scale of corruption in South Africa, nor on how best to deal with it. This is bound to result in tension and infighting within the ANC. No doubt the DA will benefit most from this. Because while we do indeed have the occasional problem with corruption, it can't be quite as bad as the DA makes it out to be. Surely?

TITLE: Corruption probe 'subverted'
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CORRUPTION (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION (78%); LITIGATION (77%); SUITS & CLAIMS (73%); EMPLOYMENT SEARCH (71%); WAGES & SALARIES (71%); EXECUTIVES (54%) News.Politics
TEXT: A WOMAN who headed a probe into claims of corruption at the National Home Builders' Registration Council (NHBRC) has herself become the focus of an investigation after she allegedly colluded with the head of the housing watchdog she was meant to be investigating. Human Settlements Minister Tokyo Sexwale said yesterday the woman, Vanessa Somiah, had been entrusted by the Special Investigating Unit (SIU), where she held a senior position as head of housing probes for the past five years, to investigate allegations of corruption within the NHBRC. It had now come to light that Somiah, during the investigation, had been offered or had applied for a senior post in the NHBRC, allegedly in collusion with the chief executive officer of the council, Sipho Mashinini, who was among those she was supposed to be investigating. Both are now being investigated by the SIU. Following the revelations, Mashinini had been given a final written warning pending an NHBRC board decision on whether the allegations against him warranted dismissal or possible legal action. Further allegations have been levelled against him, but the chairman of the NHBRC board, Vukile Mehana, said he could not elaborate as the matter was sub judice. Somiah, who is now employed by the NHBRC and earns R1.6 million - almost twice her salary at the SIU - is on special leave with pay. She is being investigated for conflict of interest and |corruption. Sexwale said he regarded this as "not only devious, but also shocking to realise how some of those who are supposed to be in authority in our campaign against corruption can undertake such reprehensible measures to undermine this fight". "In my book, this is inducement and corruption. Bribery takes many forms and this is bribery," he said. The department had mandated the SIU to investigate corruption within the housing sector and it had been examining "questionable" housing contracts totalling R2 billion. Sexwale said it was clear that Somiah's report - which found that allegations of corruption could not be substantiated - was "whitewashed".

TITLE: Hats off to Cosatu's stand on corruption
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (93%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); MURDER (76%); CRIME RATES (76%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); EMINENT DOMAIN (71%); LARCENY & THEFT (71%); NATIONALIZATION (67%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%); AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (52%) Opinion
TEXT: All power should go to Cosatu! Not only is the labour federation pronouncing often about rampant corruption in our country, but it is now forming an independent structure to fight the scourge. Indeed, corruption is threatening to overwhelm us and corrode every effort we might want to make to develop our society. In addition to the actual theft of public money and property, corruption does lead to the death and injury of people. The community demonstration that led to the murder of Andries Tatane in Ficksburg is traceable to corruption in that municipality. The death of a Zimbabwean national in Extension 75 in Seshego recently, and the injury of many others, had a corruption element. Residents say they had been complaining to the police and the municipality about a racket that has seen a lot of RDP houses occupied by Zimbabweans, either on rental or unknown basis. But nothing was done. As we all know, RDP houses are built for poor citizens of South Africa. Obviously, some people in positions of authority are illegally making money from the plight of both citizens and foreign nationals. The poor are put on a collision course with one another by the grubby hands of the connected. A rather daunting prospect is the possible descent of cynicism upon the population, an affliction that could drain us of all confidence in public affairs. Social cohesion disappears when most of us start looking askance at public initiatives and activities, suspecting corrupt motives at every turn. We have so far soiled every noble venture meant, ostensibly, to benefit society and the country. Just a few examples would do: Affirmative action, which is mandated by the constitution and geared towards rectifying the denial of skills and opportunities for the majority in our population, thereby deliberately impoverishing them, is being debased by only "affirming" friends, business partners and family members in a drive to loot public resources. This is so widespread in the public sector that it is no longer subtle. Crooked schemes are hatched to start businesses that would then tender for work that would be adjudicated by partners in theft. With crime levels so high in the country and policemen and women battling so hard to stem the ugly tide, who would begrudge them suitable headquarters from which to do their work? Who in his or her right mind would quibble with the need for them to have a police day set aside so that they could be recognised by management and have a bit of fun with their colleagues? But how are citizens supposed to feel when they learn that there are shenanigans in the provision of the headquarters of their police and in the arrangements relating to the celebration of police day? Were these initiatives conceived to serve the police or were they contrived in order to facilitate the rape of state resources? It is indeed tragic that such notions are planted in our heads. Nationalisation of mines and the expropriation of land are raised as some of the possible routes to take in our quest to build a more equal and just society. These are not trivial matters. They require a sober, honest and sincere debate by all of us. But there are already suggestions to the effect that those championing these routes with the shrillest of voices are motivated by gigantic greed. Although it is difficult for most of us to imagine anybody trifling with such weighty national issues in this way, it just goes to show how corruption can mess with the psyche of a nation. In circumstances where corruption rules, we would not be able to engage in any national projects in a serious and effective way. For instance, we would not be able to purposefully consider and take forward the work of the National Planning Commission in the absence of social cohesion and honesty in our public life. According to reports, Cosatu is so alarmed by the appalling low levels of ethical behaviour and morality in our society that it has decided to move beyond condemnation of corruption by establishing a structure to fight this demon. As I understand it, the labour federation is creating a stand-alone unit which would be tasked with monitoring corruption, receiving reports from whistle-blowers and passing these to the relevant authorities and exerting pressure, where necessary, to ensure that appropriate action is taken. Cosatu deserves national support for this commendable effort. May they enjoy strong winds in their sails!

TITLE: Now senior corruption buster under scrutiny over procurement by SIU
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (86%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (76%); ARRESTS (73%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (68%); EXECUTIVES (56%) News
TEXT: DURBAN: In a week of sensational claims that the Public Protector is facing a criminal probe, another top corruption buster is also the subject of an investigation. The Mercury, the Cape Times sister publication, can reveal that Special Investigations Unit (SIU) head Willie Hofmeyr is the latest crime-fighter under scrutiny. Daggers have been drawn over procurement issues relating to the SIU, after former chief financial officer Veronica Marshsmit was suspended and later resigned. Last night, Hofmeyr confirmed that he was under investigation. He said: "It is to be expected that, among those dealing with serious corruption, there will be efforts to discredit them, and this has happened in the past. "One just has to be tough enough to deal with it when it happens. This was a phenomenon common in developing countries, and even in developed countries. "We are all equal before the law and I cannot expect to be given special treatment. But I do expect to be treated fairly." As an anti-apartheid activist, Hofmeyr was arrested and detained many times. He believed the new fight in a democratic South Africa was against corruption. An SIU spokesman said the unit had been alerted some time ago to rumours to the effect that a criminal complaint had been laid against its head, regarding a contract for the refurbishment of its main office building. An initial contract had been awarded after a formal tender process, and an additional contract was awarded for work not included in the initial tender. Immediately after it became aware of the allegations, the SIU brought the matter to the attention of its audit committee, which consists of a majority of representatives from outside the SIU.

TITLE: Mayor 'not worried' about corruption charge
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); MAYORS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ELECTIONS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: CONTROVERSIAL Hessequa (Riversdale) Mayor Christopher Taute says a criminal complaint of corruption against him lodged by the DA's federal chairman, Wilmot James, had no merit and did did not bother him. This comes after Public Protector Thuli Madonsela found Taute had acted illegally and improperly, and abused his powers as mayor. Hessequa's council has been given 60 days to respond to Madonsela's findings. The findings followed a complaint by the DA in January after a letter written by Taute and carrying the municipality's letterhead was sent to businesses contracted to |the council, requesting they contribute towards the ANC's local government election |campaign. Yesterday, Taute was unrepentant, attacking the DA and disputing whether his actions were worthy of a criminal investigation by the police. "The DA are using this (Madonsela's findings) for political gain and they must make of it what they want," Taute said. He was re-elected only two weeks ago after a coalition deal between the DA and Cope fell through when the latter's sole councillor refused to co-operate, instead choosing to side with the ANC to form a majority in the 15-seat council. Asked whether he had been contacted by the police, Taute said: "I've not heard anything from them. What have they got to investigate?" But the DA last week claimed the criminal investigation was being hampered by businesses which received letters soliciting funds for the ANC being reluctant to be interviewed by the police. "They fear that their businesses will suffer, as the municipality is, in many cases, their biggest client," James said. The DA says it is confident that it will take over the municipality this week when Cope's "rogue" councillor, Johan Fienies, is officially booted from his party. "One of its first actions will be to dismiss Christopher Taute," James said. quinton.mtyala@inl.co.za
