TITLE: Cop cleared of corruption gets his assets back
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ASSET FORFEITURE (90%); ILLEGAL GAMBLING (89%); EVIDENCE (89%); WITNESSES (89%); BRIBERY (89%); LARCENY & THEFT (88%); SENTENCING (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); EXTORTION (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (73%); POLICE FORCES (73%); ACQUITTAL (71%); HEARSAY (71%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (66%); APPEALS (65%) News
TEXT: DURBAN: Cars and household goods belonging to former police organised crime unit boss Piet Meyer, seized 11 years ago in a blaze of publicity in one of the country's first asset seizures, will be returned to him. The State will have to pick up the hefty tab for storage and curator's fees - which earlier this year stood at R360 000. The former senior superintendent will get his assets back, including proceeds from the sale of his Umkomaas home, but he says they are "virtually worthless". While there is provision in law for the State to make good on this, he does not have the money, or the will, to continue fighting. Meyer, who is now farming near Klerksdorp, was once the blue-eyed boy of the KwaZulu-Natal police service. He fell from grace when he and others in his unit were charged with corruption. It was alleged that he had taken bribes from illegal casino owners in return for not raiding them or shutting them down. He was convicted in the Durban Regional Court of two counts of corruption and one of theft of furniture and sentenced to an effective 10 years. He was acquitted of all but the theft charge on appeal. He then began his fight for the return of his household goods, a Nissan Sani, a Jeep, a trailer, R86 000 from the house sale and R67 000 in interest. Unrepresented, he came to the Durban High Court last year, wanting the civil court - where the "balance of probabilities" test is less onerous than in a criminal court - to further clear his name. Acting Judge Fazal Moola did just that in a judgment handed down late last week. The judge said great reliance had been placed on the evidence of Meyer's ex-wife, Tokkie, who said during the trial that he had started bringing home large amounts of cash; the evidence of witnesses (the illegal casino owners) that he had received between R' 000 and R490 000 from them as protection money; and the evidence of investigating officer Herby Heap that Meyer was living beyond his legitimate means. Regarding Tokkie Meyer's evidence, the judge said it was common cause that there was animosity between her and Meyer because of his infidelity and their subsequent divorce. Her evidence was not only uncorroborated but was contradicted by the evidence of the witnesses he allegedly bribed, Judge Moola said. The judge could not find the affidavits of the illegal casino owners in the original forfeiture application papers. References to them by Heap were therefore "hearsay evidence". He said Heap had not conducted a full audit of Meyer's expenses and earnings. The items seized were the sort one would expect to find in an average household and there was nothing to suggest they were proceeds of illegal activities. "Certain items, such as the Nissan Sani, raise certain suspicions, which would have justified a referral to oral evidence, but this has not been requested," he said. The judge directed the curator to return the property and the State to pay his fees and all associated costs. Meyer said he was pleased to have been exonerated again. While the goods were not worth much, "the money will help", he said. "The judge could have ordered that the State return the goods in the same condition in which they were taken, but the judgment is silent on that. I won't take it furtherí¢[#x20ac]_ I am just tired of this whole thing."

TITLE: Trio accused of R600m corruption deal off the hook
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); AGREEMENTS (88%); TRUST ARRANGEMENTS (87%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: THREE people accused of fraud and corruption in a |R600 million deal that saw them attempt to sell land at Wingfield - earmarked for people evicted from Ndabeni years ago - walked out of court free men yesterday. In 2007, a member of the Ndabeni Communal Property Trust, which was serving about 500 claimants at the time, asked police to probe the circumstances that led to a pre-sale agreement to sell the land near Maitland for commercial and residential use. Then trust chairman Amos Silinga, trustee Mxolisi Gquma and Kent Khil, a director of several companies, were allegedly involved in a pre-sale agreement to sell the land near Maitland for commercial and residential use. The City of Cape Town and the Land Claims Commission vowed to stop the deal. The case was withdrawn yesterday, owing to problems envisaged with the State's case. - Staff Writer

TITLE: Poor are the real victims of corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CONSPIRACY (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (75%); WRITERS (73%); DEFENSE CONTRACTING (72%); ENGINEERING (71%); ANTITRUST & TRADE LAW (69%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (60%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (50%) Opinion
TEXT: Most South Africans have corruption fatigue. Reading about corrupt government and ANC officials has become like reading about floods in Bangladesh. Is corruption really something that we as citizens should worry about? Could it be that there is a bit of a white conspiracy to show that blacks are a bunch of incompetent skelms? On your behalf, I've read the boring, repetitive news reports on corruption involving the South African government and ANC politicians, so let me give you a few recent highlights. I'll stick to the simple cases and not even refer to shady property deals involving the police, the Public Works Department and the Department of Justice or court cases in Kwazulu-Natal and Northern Cape involving senior provincial ANC leaders. Highlight 1: The German arms manufacturer Ferrostaal has not denied a German newspaper report last week that it had paid R300 million in bribes to South Africans to secure contracts to supply submarines to the tune of R5.4 billion. Highlight 2: Shortly before this revelation, the Swedish arms group Saab admitted that R24m had been paid to South Africans by its former partner, BAE Systems, to secure a deal involving 26 Gripen fighters. So now we know that at least R346m - I'll bet my bottom dollar the real amount was a lot higher - was paid to politicians and officials to lubricate the R60bn-plus arms procurement deals. Investigative reporters believe a sizeable chunk of this money was paid into the coffers of the ANC, which more or less guarantees that there will never be a proper investigation. Highlight 3: With the help of the investigations of City Press and the Mail & Guardian we also know that the president of the ANC Youth League, Julius Malema, is the director of the Ratanang Trust and that at least one businessman says he paid a large sum of money into this trust because Malema helped him to secure a state tender. We also now know that Ratanang Trust is a shareholder of On-Point Engineering, which is in charge of allocating Limpopo provincial government tenders worth more than R4bn. Just these three highlights should cause us grave concern that corruption and fraud could be in the process of becoming institutionalised, becoming the "normal price of doing business with the state". The argument gaining currency very fast is that these revelations are made by the media puppets of white monopoly capital in order to paint black politicians as lazy and corrupt. The only way for black people to make money is through the state, says columnist Eric Miyeni to great applause, clearly implying that tenderpreneurship is a legitimate way of securing "economic liberation in our lifetime". On radio and in print in the past week, Miyeni and Malema were the strongest voices demanding the speedy eradication of poverty. They stated that white theft and selfishness were the root of black poverty. That is the extent of the madness that is loose in our society. Some of those well-connected to the ruling party now believe they have licence to defraud and steal from the state in the name of black economic liberation. And they're not only getting away with it, they have elevated themselves to leading a crusade against "white capital" and white South Africans in general. The simple truth is that these tenderpreneurs are stealing not from the white rich but from the black poor. Every cent lost through corruption could have been spent on job creation projects, education, housing or health care. These self-styled "champions of the new struggle for economic liberation" are in reality the enemies of the poor. If they get their way and if they continue like they are, the poor will become poorer and there will be more of them. The official reaction to the growing corruption has been denial and empty assurances. As I write this, Malema is appearing before an ANC disciplinary hearing - but not to answer questions about his lifestyle as a multimillionaire with an average salary, nor about the Ratanang Trust and On-Point Engineering, but about a statement he made about Botswana. If the revelations about his private affairs are true, Malema should go to jail for a long time. But it is appropriate to remember that President Jacob Zuma had equally serious charges made against him, and these were dropped in a highly suspect way. Corruption in the name of liberating blacks and punishing whites is still only corruption. It will not liberate more than a handful of blacks and it won't only punish the whites.

TITLE: Corruption threatens our dream
SUBJECT: RELIGION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (88%); CORRUPTION (87%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (78%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (75%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (75%); POLITICS (73%); RETIREMENT & RETIREES (72%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (69%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (50%) Opinion
TEXT: In the past, churches and faith communities shared a burning desire, with liberation movements, to replace apartheid with constitutional democracy. Now the challenge is how to make this transition into a practical reality for all South Africans. As the former UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, has said: "No one is born a good citizen; no nation is born a democracy. Rather, both are processes that continue to evolve over a lifetime." In South Africa, we are still learning how to become a democracy, and still feeling our way into the new relationships appropriate to constitutional democracy. Government, political parties, the private sector, academia, the media, civil society, faith communities and so forth, now each have our distinctive contributions to make to the life of the nation as a whole. We are still learning where we should stand in solidarity, and where we should be critical; what it means to hold and to exchange legitimately diverse perspectives; and how to deliver and receive criticism that is constructive. The way to pursue such maturing democracy is to abide by our constitution. I want to look at what this means for all of us. As a faith leader, I firmly believe it when God says that people matter. God cares that his beloved children should all have adequate food, shelter, clothing and so forth. God cares that everyone should be treated with complete respect by everyone else, with no one marginalised, excluded or voiceless in the ordering of our common lives. This is what democracy is all about. As Anglicans we are in solidarity with the needs of the poorest, the most vulnerable, and the most marginalised; including the strangers, the foreigners, in our midst. We are in solidarity with available, affordable health care for all. We are in solidarity with effective rural development. We are in solidarity with education for all that truly equips our young people to be responsible citizens, able to face the challenges of adulthood. On the other hand, we are critical of a response to crime that leads to escalating deaths among both police and suspects. We are critical of inadequate social support, and of continuing delays faced by too many of the most needy, especially paperless orphans and pensioners - though I recognise that there are some improvements. We are, and you all should be, concerned with honour and respect, with freedom, with unity and diversity, with healing, with democratic values and social justice; with human rights, with quality of life and liberating potential, for every single one of us. To be subject to our constitution means to breathe life into these commitments to one another. We are here because many of us believe that corruption - in government and in business and in our communities - is endemic and is eating at the very moral fibre of our nation and its democratic values. Corruption threatens the dream of rooting out residues of apartheid and creating the South Africa we would all be proud of. That is what makes the Red Card Campaign an urgent and important effort. I call on all South Africans not only to sign the pledge but also to inscribe it in our daily lives. The pledge has two distinct and important parts: 1. It calls upon government to establish a strong, independent, anti-corruption body to investigate all acts of corruption and bring the perpetrators to justice; and 2. It calls upon us to pledge that we will neither take nor offer a bribe, and we will report any such incidents to the relevant authorities. But there is much more at stake here. The Council for the Advancement of the South African Constitution (CASAC), which has gathered us here, places before us a challenge: "A complacent citizenry remains the greatest threat to our constitution. As responsible citizens we should assert our right to actively campaign for the realisation of rights enshrined in the constitution." We in South Africa have a constitutional democracy for which so many struggled and for which many died. We cannot step back from doing what we can for the realisation of the rights promulgated in the constitution nor can we relinquish the responsibilities that come with democracy. An active and alert citizenry is foremost among those responsibilities. As we all lend our support and work for the public/common good, let us never tire of "red-carding"|corruption. However, it is the responsibility of governments - more than any other body, and more than any other objective - to pursue the public good. In particular, government must prioritise the needs of those who are least able to achieve their own wellbeing - the poor, the marginalised, the disadvantaged, and the vulnerable. The Golden Rule calls us all to care for others as we would like to be cared for ourselves. It seems so simple and yet we experience it to be quite difficult at times. Indeed, the history of our country would be quite different if we had begun long ago to live by this rule. But there is nothing to stop us from making the "golden rule" our baseline in addressing corruption. Many South Africans acknowledge having offered or having been offered a bribe. Certainly, highly publicised examples of corruption and claims of corruption are the centre of conversation in many circles. As I said during the funeral of Mama Albertina Sisulu: "We see examples of where many have used political power to enrich themselves and their relatives and friends, sometimes through blatant corruption - and so betray the legacy for which the Sisulu family has striven." Beyond being illegal and immoral, when money is misused, its potential to be utilised in constructive and helpful ways is lost. Housing, education, health services and social development cry out as obvious examples where we can least afford this. Corruption also causes costs to escalate and often new programmes are sidelined. Money to employ badly needed personnel "disappears", and resultant understaffing leads to poor services, worsening results, and a continuing downward spiral. Corruption at this macro level is the point at which many people get most upset. But we must not forget corruption at the lower level. One can imagine situations involving traffic officers and speeding fines and other tickets where one might be tempted to cross the line. Corruption at a lower level - sometimes where the currency isn't even money, but dishonesty about work done or left undone - has an insidious effect on the type of society we are building, which seriously concerns me as a person of faith. The ability of us all, especially those who are most disadvantaged by society's injustices, to always "do the right thing" is further undermined when it seems that dishonesty by those in positions of power and influence goes unchecked and unpunished. Therefore, let us recall the words of the preamble to our constitution: "We, the people of South Africa, recognise the injustices of our past; honour those who suffered for justice and freedom in our land; respect those who have worked to build and develop our country; and believe that South Africa belongs to all who live in it, united in our diversity "We therefore, through our freely elected representatives, adopt this Constitution as the supreme law of the Republic so as to heal the divisions of the past and establish a society based on democratic values, social justice and fundamental human rights; to lay the foundations for a democratic and open society in which government is based on the will of the people and every citizen is equally protected by law; to improve the quality of life of all citizens and free the potential of each person; and to build a united and democratic South Africa able to take its rightful place as a sovereign state in the family of nations. May God protect our people." These challenging but cherished words are not to be taken lightly nor forgotten. The task of making the preamble of our constitution a reality is considerable - but this cannot be a reason to side-step or seemingly "redraft" it. We must continue to press ahead together. We can take another important step forward with the Red Card Corruption campaign. Through this we can say an emphatic NO to corruption which slows our pace of development as a nation and weakens the moral fibre of individuals and society. Let us not forget the challenge CASAC has put clearly before us: "The constitution is our social contract based on democratic values, social justice, human rights and the improvement of the quality of life of all South Africans. We cannot progress and prosper through greed. An act of corruption is a crime against us all." We call upon the government to establish strong, independent, anti-corruption bodies that can investigate all acts of corruption and ensure those that those who commit corrupt acts are brought to justice. We must stand up, blow our whistles and Red Card Corruption. Please join me as we pledge together: "I/we pledge neither to receive nor pay a bribe; and to report any attempt to solicit a bribe from me, and other corrupt activities to the relevant authorities." l This is an edited version of the keynote address delivered by The Most Revd Dr Thabo Makgoba, Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town, at the launch of the Red Card Corruption campaign at Walter Sisulu Square, Kliptown, Soweto. For persons interested in signing the pledge, go to www.casac.org.za

TITLE: MEC to investigate allegations of corruption in low-cost housing project
SUBJECT: HOUSING AUTHORITIES (90%); LOW COST HOUSING SCHEMES (90%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PUBLIC HOUSING (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FAMILY (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: Western Cape Human Settlement MEC Bonginkosi Madikizela is to investigate allegations that almost half of people living in a low-cost housing project in Eerste River are not the rightful beneficiaries. Madikizela on Wednesday announced he would gather affidavits from backyarders who allege that two leaders in the Our Pride Housing Project in Elsies River have been involved in corruption related to the project. This comes after a group calling themselves the Gugulethu Concerned Backyarders went public this week with allegations of corruption. The Gugulethu Concerned Backyarders, now numbering 48 after four of their members died, are the remnants of a 300-strong group called the Gugulethu RDP Housing Project, which formed in 2001. They appointed Phumla Dlokolo as their chairperson and approached the provincial Housing Department with their savings in 2006. Dlokolo had told them that R2 500 was required for a two-room house, and up to R5 000 for a larger house. Upon their submission to the department, then under MEC Richard Dyantyi, erven were obtained in Eerste River and an 821-unit housing project, named the Our Pride Housing Project, was given the go-ahead. The first phase was completed at the end of last year. However, the 48 remaining Gugulethu members have still not received houses and it has emerged that the housing department never required money from beneficiaries to be paid over. Dlokolo has stated she is repaying those involved, but backyarders say they have received no recompense from her. On Wednesday, Madikizela asked the Gugulethu Concerned Backyarders to provide him with sworn affidavits to enable him to investigate. The backyarders undertook to provide their statements by Monday and Madikizela said he would accompany the Special Investigating Unit (SIU) in conducting a door-to-door inspection to find out whether anyone had benefited from the project illegally. The backyarders allege that Dlokolo placed her family members, including seven of her children, on the beneficiary list and sold houses that were assigned to beneficiaries who have since died to friends and foreign nationals. "I want to find out what happened to the houses of the people that are now deceased," said Madikizela. "We need to get to the bottom of this and if we find that there are things that went wrong, we need to deal with that. There is a lot of corruption happening in our housing projects." Gugulethu backyarder Malusi Msesi, who attended the meeting, said to Madikizela that Dlokolo deleted his name from the list because he "did not have the R2 500 required". "I told her I won't pay because I qualify for a free house," Msesi said. Another backyarder, Mhlayivayo Qabaka, said he was expelled from the group by Dlokolo after she told him he had missed numerous meetings, which Qabaka denied. Qabaka said their preliminary investigations had revealed that people living in the houses at the Our Pride Housing Project came from Mfuleni, Khayelitsha, Delft, and were also African foreign nationals. "I don't understand how this is happening under your nose," he told Madikizela.

TITLE: MEC to take action against corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: HUMAN Settlements MEC Bonginkosi Madikizela has promised Makhaza, Khayelitsha residents that he will go door-to-door with a list of legal home owners and take action against people occupying state-supplied houses illegally. This comes after residents complained about corruption in the allocation of houses. About 200 people gathered on a field in the area yesterday to demand answers to a number of grievances. They said many houses were occupied by people who were not legal beneficiaries. Madikizela was also accused of not addressing people's needs effectively. Resident Lwazi Ngwane told Madikizela: "You, together with (DA MP) Masizole Mnqasela, are dividing the community. You don't intervene when it matters most." Madikizela admitted that as leaders they were not united and that it affected the delivery of services to the people. He urged anyone with evidence of corruption to come forward. He promised to go on site with a list of the houses' legal beneficiaries next week. "Everyone who occupies a house, but is not on the list, will have to explain how that happened," he said. Residents were not happy that Madikizela only took two rounds of questions at the meeting. - Independent Cadet News Agency mzoxolo.budaza@inl.co.za

TITLE: Police corruption isn't new
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); POLICE FORCES (89%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); SCHOOL SAFETY & SECURITY (78%); BRIBERY (78%); APPOINTMENTS (75%); CAMPUS SECURITY (73%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (60%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) Opinion
TEXT: Early this month the South African Police Service attacked a report on police corruption by the Institute of Security Studies (ISS) as unfair, one sided and another attempt to discredit the police. The report said the SAPS was struggling with one of the major occupational hazards of policing: the abuse of power. "While progress has been made since the outright brutalities of apartheid-era policing, corruption is one of the biggest challenges facing the SAPS." In response the SAPS said: "While the report points to common problems, it fails to acknowledge the achievements and significant milestones by the SAPS under the leadership of General Cele who has been at the forefront of fighting crime and rooting out corruption with the SAPS ranks." Three days later, the SAPS issued another statement announcing the arrest of a Durban senior police officer for attempting to bribe the KwaZulu-Natal head of the special crime unit, the Hawks, with R2 million in return for documents relating to a case being investigated by the Hawks. The arrest of the senior police officer can be read in two ways: It proves the ISS right as much as it does the SAPS. It shows, as the ISS has argued, that police are corrupt, but it also shows, as the SAPS has said, that not all apples in the police barrel are rotten. After all, it was a fellow police officer who blew the whistle and had his colleague trapped and arrested. Where the ISS report trumps the police rebuttal is in its characterisation of the police profession as one which is "particularly prone to the problem of corruption". The ISS is backed here by an article by Martin Innes - director of the Universities' Police Science Institute at Cardiff University - who said that at the heart of policing were a set of defining tensions that have to be reconciled. "The police are agents of the state, and yet need to be politically independent to command public respect. They are authorised to use coercive force to stop violent disorder," wrote Innes. "They are in close contact with criminality, but need to preserve their integrity and resist corruption. They must uphold law and order without resorting to methods that undermine it." Police corruption, Innes said, was not new. Nor was it a phenomenon of developing countries. It is to be found in the police departments of the developed countries too. Innes cited the Knapp Commission in the 1970s which found that the New York police department was systematically corrupt. At the other end of the world, Australians were at the same time investigating organised police corruption in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria. "History is scarred by such cases. The extent of the problem was summed up by Robert Mark, who upon appointment as commissioner of the London Metropolitan Police in 1972, avidly noted that it failed the test of catching more criminals than it employed," wrote Innes. As South Africa's history before and after 1994 shows, the police force has its fair share of criminals on its pay. Some join the police; others are transformed by the experience. As Innes explains: "Certain aspects of police work - combating drugs, vice and organised crime - seem especially open to corruption by virtue of exposure." That being the case, the ISS is correct in that the best way to fight police corruption is to strengthen the integrity of the organisation as well as its employees.

TITLE: Lawsuit set to fight alleged Hajj industry corruption
SUBJECT: HAJJ (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); RELIGIOUS PILGRIMAGES (91%); CLASS ACTIONS (90%); SUITS & CLAIMS (90%); LITIGATION (90%); AGREEMENTS (90%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); BUSINESS TORTS (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); PRICE FIXING (78%); SCANDALS (73%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (73%); ACCREDITATION (71%); TOUR PACKAGES (71%); VOLUNTEERS (61%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: A CLASS action lawsuit is to be brought to tackle corruption in the Hajj industry and for the disbandment of the SA Hajj and Umrah Council (Sahuc). It is to be brought by Friends of the Hujjaj, a body formed at a meeting in Athlone on Tuesday, following allegations of corruption by some hajj operators, including inflated travel packages and attempts to sell fraudulently obtained visas for R3 000. Sahuc, the body working with the Saudi government on behalf of South African pilgrims to Mecca, is under fire for failing to intervene. "We are pushing for a revolution in the hajj industry," said the National Consumer Forum's Imraahn Mukaddam, a member of Friends of the Hujjaj. This would be his second class action, the first the bread price-fixing scandal. "We are in the process of (consulting) senior council," Mukaddam said. Annually, Sahuc and the Saudi government negotiate how many pilgrims may visit the kingdom. This year's quota was 3 000 - the lowest in years. Sahuc charges pilgrims R100 for accreditation to allow pilgrims to make travel arrangements with their operator. Sahuc then gives operators accreditation letters which they present when making bookings in Saudi Arabia. Mukaddam said Sahuc's status was questionable as no local NGO should be allowed to enter into binding agreements with a foreign government, as Sahuc had done. "Sahuc is not entitled to make agreements on behalf of South African citizens," he said. Sahuc general secretary Shaheen Essop dismissed calls for it to disband. He also denied that Sahuc could not account for about R6 million it collected last year, and said audited reports were on the council's website. "Problems started when some operators took passports to obtain visas in excess of their quota. Problems also arose when some agents - to get visas, claimed some South African hujjaj were permanent residents in neighbouring countries. All this resulted in a whole fiasco. Sahuc has no control over operators. Sahuc is a voluntary organisation. It employs four people countrywide," Essop said. He said Sahuc had launched its own probe. "I'm not fazed. When there is corruption, fingers always get pointed at Sahuc. We enjoy the support of the Saudi Hajj Ministry and the South African Department of International Relations." He said monies Sahuc collected were spent on services for the hujjaj, including health care and other assistance during pilgrimage. "Friends of the Hujjaj can do whatever they want. We indicated we have launched our own investigation.They have not talked to us. There is the continual onslaught against Sahuc from its detractors," Essop said. aziz.hartley@inl.co.za

TITLE: ANC accuses DA of ignoring corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); MAYORS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); WITNESSES (76%); EXECUTIVES (73%); BANKING & FINANCE (71%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: THE ANC has accused the DA and its leaders of hypocrisy, charging that they were aware of corruption and maladministration at the beleaguered Swellendam municipality but turned a blind eye. The accusation came as members of the Provincial Legislature yesterday debated the affairs of Swellendam following recent claims by the municipality's former chief financial officer Nigel Delo. Two weeks ago Delo said under oath that ID leader and current Cape Town mayor Patricia de Lille had tried to pressure him into "easing off" his opposition to a deal whereby Swellendam's funds would be managed by a financial company with close links to the ID. The ANC's Ellen Prins charged that "the people of Swellendam had enough of the political interference by people who think they can do as they please". Swellendam was previously run by a coalition of the DA and the ID. Since May's election it has been ruled by the DA-ID and the ACDP. The DA's Johan Visser said the ANC, in calling for a debate on Swellendam, was trying to deflect attention from its own failings in government. The police's controversial lease deal which saw national commissioner Bheki Cele suspended was one such issue. But the ANC's Pierre Uys charged that Visser's comparison was irrelevant, and asked deputy Speaker Richard Majola to confine matters to Swellendam. But Visser would not relent, saying Prins, in calling for the debate, was misleading the House. Asked to withdraw the statement by Majola, Visser refused and was eventually ordered to leave the House. The ANC's Max Ozinsky said Premier Helen Zille had to hold Swellendam's officials to a similar standard to that demanded of other levels of government (controlled by the ANC). "This is a botox premier, its all nice and shiny (at the beginning) but over time it falls down," said Ozinsky. He said evidence of interference was contained in leaked e-mails between ACDP provincial leader Grant Haskin and its sole councillor in Swellendam, Julian Matthysen. In the e-mail, Matthysen is being reigned in and threatened that if he ever delivered any "surprises" he would be removed by the ACDP. Haskin's e-mail in August came after Matthysen had defied party orders and voted with the ANC on the sale of municipal land which was opposed by the DA. quinton.mtyala@inl.co.za

TITLE: Corruption lawyer sees police bribery first-hand after landing at OR Tambo
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (90%); LAWYERS (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); HUMAN RIGHTS (78%); ROADSIDE SERVICES (75%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (71%); ROAD TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (68%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (57%) News
TEXT: JOHANNESBURG: Fatima Hassan is a human rights lawyer whose work is to often fight the injustices caused by corrupt police officials. At the weekend, she became a victim. But she decided to fight back - with her cellphone camera. On Friday night, Hassan flew into Johannesburg from Cape Town. She was travelling alone and had hired a tour company shuttle bus to drive her to the city. "I was sitting in the back when were were flagged down just after we had left OR Tambo (airport)." The police officer spoke to the driver. He pointed to the vehicle's licence disc and told the driver it had expired, and that the windscreen was cracked. He told the driver he had to pay R200 or he would call a tow truck company. This would have left her and the driver stranded. Hassan said the officer didn't have his name tag on. "I told him he must issue a ticket, but he continued saying he would call a tow truck company," she said. He threatened them with jail. Eventually, her driver paid R40. Hassan took photographs of the policeman as he allegedly solicited a bribe from another motorist, who paid up. After tracing the driver's particulars, she found he worked for a firm owned by a police reservist. Hassan was reluctant to open a case as she feared she would be victimised.

TEXT: ENDEMIC corruption is turning politics into a selfish and, at times, murderous pursuit of power for the sake of wealth at the expense of the poor, Cosatu general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi has warned. Unless they were stopped, he said, these gatekeepers would gorge themselves on much of the formal economy. "(Political) factions these days are formed not around ideologies or political views, but for access to government power that brings its leaders closer to state (contracts). "Honest and talented individuals who cannot play this dirty game í¢[#x20ac]_ get sidelined and fall by the wayside as slate politics í¢[#x20ac]_ imposes the |worst, most inefficient and corrupt individuals on us. "The mistake we keep on making over and over again in our politics of divisions is to keep replacing a corrupt faction with another equally corrupt faction who, as soon as they occupy office, embrace the 'it is our turn to eat' mantra." But Vavi emphasised that "this is not a march against the ANC". "The ANC is everywhere and we are the ANC. The ANC is absolutely opposed to corruption and fighting corruption is one of the government's five priorities. TITLE: Former league leader takes aim at corruption, racism - and Malema
SUBJECT: YOUTH SPORTS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (78%); COMMERCE DEPARTMENTS (78%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (68%)
TEXT: POLOKWANE: Militants in the ANC Youth League could be seen as anarchists because they lacked the discipline and patience to achieve economic freedom, Public Enterprises Minister and former league president Malusi Gigaba said yesterday. "Military and discipline are two sides of the same coin, you can't push democratic national revolution unless you want fundamental change í¢[#x20ac]_ But a militant who has no discipline is an anarchist," he said while delivering the OR Tambo memorial lecture in Polokwane. "Militant is what makes you think deeper, which makes you want to be radical and seek far-reaching change. Militant does not mean swearing, it does not mean insulting fellow comrades, it does not mean throwing chairs and stones at fellow comrades and it does not mean jumping on top of the table with your pants down," Gigaba said. The crowd responded by calling out the name of embattled league president Julius Malema, who has repeatedly called league members "economic freedom fighters" who want the nationalisation of mines and want to take the country's economy back from "white capital". Gigaba said OR Tambo was a disciplined and patient leader of the league. "OR Tambo once said, 'The youth are correct to be impatient for victory, but they must delay because you must never act contrary to what people see is their interest'." He said a love of money among members was killing the ANC. "We must switch off taps of corruption and arrest those who are involved in corruption," he said. He also criticised Malema for chanting slogans that promoted racism and were anti-ANC. "You can't go and be ANC Youth League and become anti-ANC Youth League at the same time."

TITLE: My time in Cope showed me that there is corruption in all parties, says Dexter
SUBJECT: POLITICS (90%); RESIGNATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (75%); CAMPAIGN FINANCE (74%); POLITICAL PARTIES (69%); RULE OF LAW (66%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (64%) News
TEXT: COPE has taken the resignation of its national spokesman and MP, Phillip Dexter, on the chin, wishing him well and resisting the urge to fight fire with fire after Dexter said the party he had helped to form was a "failed experiment". Dexter announced on Tuesday that he had rejoined the ANC - the party he served for most of his life but left amid acrimony in 2008. "We will always be grateful for his valued contribution in ensuring that Cope became deeply rooted in South African society," said the party's acting general secretary, Deidre Carter. Dexter's future at Cope became uncertain after the leaking of his scathing critique, written in May. In it, he lambasted his fellow Cope members for "manipulating" election candidate lists in the 2009 and 2011 elections and alleged that party funds were "routinely abused". This is not the first time Dexter has slammed his organisation - and with apparent impunity. When he resigned from the SACP in September 2008, he accused its leadership of "factionalism and reactionary behaviour" and suggested it "can never build (a socialist) future, nor does it have any desire to do so". SACP chairman Gwede Mantashe and general secretary Blade Nzimande occupy senior positions in the ANC. In his letter of resignation to the ANC in October 2008, Dexter accused the party leadership under President Jacob Zuma of "peddling lies", promoting "factionalism, tribalism, violence, misogyny" and "condoning possible criminal activity". "I have seen personal interest and ambition, revenge and vindictiveness become the main driving force of the movement. Dishonesty has become the order of the day," he wrote to Mantashe. Dexter said yesterday he had "exaggerated quite a lot" in his resignation letter, had apologised to the ANC for any offence caused and was ready to answer for his past criticism of the party. Asked what had changed in the ANC since he accused its leaders of being "in the forefront of undermining our constitution and the rule of law", Dexter said the party's 2007 Polokwane conference - at which Zuma replaced Thabo Mbeki as leader - had been a "painful experience for many". His analysis had been "clouded by the political moment". "I have been pleasantly surprised by the way in which the ANC has dealt with a number of things, including the disciplinary processes (against ANC Youth League leaders) and trying to tackle corruption - even if only in certain parts of the government," he said. His time in Cope had taught him there was corruption in all political parties. He had not yet discussed his future in the ANC.

TITLE: DPP to appeal 'light' corruption sentence
SUBJECT: FINES & PENALTIES (90%); SENTENCING (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); GUILTY PLEAS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (78%); APPEALS COURTS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); APPEALS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (77%); RESORTS (72%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (70%); STUDENT EXPENSES (69%); CHILDREN (64%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (50%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: THE Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) is to appeal the "lenient" sentence of a Hessequa Municipality employee who was convicted of 39 counts of corruption for taking a kickback for tender deals. Denvor Fielies, the former head of streets, stormwater, parks and resorts at the Riversdale-based municipality, received a R350 000 kickback to secure tenders to the tune of almost R650 000 for a man named Paul Fischer over a two-year period. Fielies pleaded guilty to 39 counts of corruption in the Specialised Commercial Crimes Court in Bellville. On October 25, 2010, he was sentenced to a R60 000 fine and one year's imprisonment suspended for five years. Had he failed to pay the fine, he would have to serve two years. But the DPP in the Western Cape took the matter to the Western Cape High Court in a bid for leave to appeal the sentence, which it considered to be inappropriately lenient. Judge Andre le Grange has now granted the DPP leave to appeal Fielies's sentence. In Le Grange's judgment, he said the magistrate had considered that Fielies was a first offender who had pleaded guilty to the charges. He had also admitted that he had helped Fischer draw up quotations to ensure that Fischer's company was the successful tender bidder, and that he had asked Fischer to submit quotations on behalf of other service providers without their knowledge. Weight was also placed on Fielies's personal circumstances. He was married with two children, aged 20 and 11, and had a number of expenses, such as R4 650 a month for rent, his son's college fees of some R6 700 a month and almost R3 000 a month for his daughter's school fees. "I am of the view that the imposed sentence by the magistrate is not consistent with reported judgments of our higher courts in similar matters," Le Grange said in his judgment. "The magistrate clearly overemphasised the personal circumstances of the accused in this matter." leila.samodien@inl.co.za

TITLE: Fishy business as minister announces probe into tender corruption
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CONTRACT AWARDS (91%); FISHERIES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LITIGATION (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); NATURAL RESOURCES (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); MARINE RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (77%); MARINE VESSELS (77%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: EMBATTLED Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Minister Tina Joemat-Pettersson has announced an independent inquiry to probe alleged corruption in her department's awarding of tenders. This came after the scrapping of a multimillion-rand tender to police SA's fishing stocks. The tender had been awarded to an empowerment company with close links to the ANC and the government: Sekunjalo, headed by Iqbal Surve. After the tender was awarded, it emerged that Surve had paid for additional security at the home of International Relations and Co-operation Minister Maite Nkoana-Mashabane. Sekunjalo was awarded an R800 million tender to police SA's marine resources and to manage and operate four marine patrol and research vessels. But the tender was withdrawn in the face of litigation against the department by the current tender-holder, Smit Amandla Marine, whose contract expires at the end of this month. The company pointed out that there was a conflict of interest due to Sekunjalo's ownership of Premier Fishing, a major player in the fishing industry. Joemat-Pettersson has since alleged that the awarding of the existing and previous contracts to Smit Amandla Marine may also be suspect. Yesterday Fisheries spokesman Lionel Adendorf said a new entity to replace Smit Amandla would be operational by April 1. Joemat-Pettersson said the process in awarding the tender to "an innocent company", Sekunjalo had been flawed. "The reality is that, based on legal advice, it was our processes and procedures that failed." She said she had decided to scrutinise "broadly" all current and past tenders awarded by the fisheries branch of her department. The probe would focus on whether government employees or those from the private sector were responsible for fraud, corruption or maladministration in the awarding of tenders. She hoped it would be in place at the start of April. quinton.mtyala@inl.co.za

TITLE: This corruption is so frustrating and so unfair

TEXT: THIS is so frustrating as its gets worse and seems like nothing is being done. I went for a driving test at Randburg testing station and was offered a guaranteed pass if I paid R2 000.The money is used to pay all the instructors on duty that day, money is split and they can't accept a lesser bribe because then it's not worth it.
