That most black females are doing their Code 10 licence is purely because there is no parallel parking in the test, which is one of the reasons why most of them fail, but it's not fair on the rest of us, we try so hard. - Carmelita

TITLE: Private party funding breeds suspicions, private interests and corruption
BYLINE: This is an open letter |from Zackie Achmat and |Yoliswa Dwane to ANC |secretary-general|Gwede Mantashe
SUBJECT: POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); POLITICAL PARTY DONATIONS (89%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICS (89%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: Dear Comrade Mantashe, At a recent Cape Town forum, you took the principled position that SA must urgently consider regulating private funding of political parties in order to protect our young democracy from corruption and conflicts of interest. "The debate is long overdue," you told the audience. "It shouldn't wait for next week or next month; it should have started already." Your statement is welcome. Regrettably the debate over party funding has languished for years because vested interests in all political parties have continually shut it down. Nevertheless, we accept your invitation to begin the debate today so that we can overcome the critics' claim that South African political parties are for sale. We refuse to believe that our liberation movement - which overcame apartheid and led the establishment of multiparty democracy for all people - has become beholden to private interests. We have all sacrificed too much on behalf of the struggle and democracy to let even the appearance of corruption remain. No comrade can deny the unfortunate fact that so long as the funding of all political parties - not just the ANC and DA - takes place behind closed doors, public faith in the integrity of parties is undermined. When the people see some of their leaders driving fancy cars or flying in private jets while poverty continues around them, and then read in the press that certain companies connected to public officials are receiving state tenders, they will doubt not just the integrity of the officials concerned but that of government and the ANC. Parties depend on funding to fulfil their obligations under the constitution, but secret donations by private companies and foreign states threaten public confidence in democracy itself. Regrettably, more people say they distrust the president, Parliament, opposition parties, and their local government rather than trust these vital institutions, according to the latest AfroBarometer survey. Less than half of the people say they are satisfied with democracy and are willing to try something different if it fails to bring improvements to their daily lives soon. And fully 83% say that corruption of money and politics has become a way of life in SA, according to a 2012 TNS survey. All democratically elected governments must continually earn and keep the public trust: just as justice must be seen to be done in the courts, so must democratic accountability be seen and felt in the public square. ANC supporters and the broader public are ready to work with you and all interested parties to bring private funding of South African politics into the light of day so that people can have their faith in government restored. As you said in your remarks and as we have long agreed, the debate over party funding must centre on ensuring that there is "transparent declaration of the interests of all political parties and the funding thereof" and ensuring that parties have sufficient state funding and other resources to meet their responsibilities within a multi-party democracy. All parties have agreed in the past that transparency and increased public funding are important, although all have yet to act. Accompanied by comprehensive regulation of private party funding, such reforms can offer a real solution to the public's growing concern over corruption and conflicts of interest in our government. Time and again, our party has taken the principled position on party funding reform, even as the pace of change has been slow. In 2007, the ANC committed at Polokwane to "champion public funding of represented political parties (and) effective regulation of private funding... to enhance accountability and transparency to the citizenry." You yourself wrote in 2009 that, "the biggest threat to our movement is the intersection between the business interests and holding of public office." And our President Jacob Zuma has boldly stated that, "When money changes hands in the battle for personal power and aggrandisement, where is the movement built around membership that joins without motives of material advantage and personal gain?" Thank you for reminding us of the urgent need to resolve this difficult challenge and ensure transparency and accountability in the funding of all political parties. With your leadership, we can finally give South African the debate they deserve on party funding reform. The time for Parliament to act against the threat of corruption in party funding is now. l Achmat and Dwane are political activists and ANC supporters and write in their personal capacities.

TITLE: Corruption is an evil society must root out
SUBJECT: RELIGION (90%); CORRUPTION (87%); ROBBERY (74%); PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION (68%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (67%); BRIBERY (65%); WATER CRISES & SHORTAGES (63%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: There we were, at a funeral at a village near Polokwane a few days ago, multitudes of us. The deceased had succumbed to cancer of the throat and all those who were close to him, especially his family, were expressing more relief than sorrow at his passing. They saw him in excruciating pain, unable to eat, going in and out of hospital and being reduced to mere skin and bones. "He has escaped pain; he has rested; it is better this way," they said variously. The family belong to one of the charismatic churches and a brother of the deceased is a pastor in the same church. Ministers of religion were there in full force and shared the priestly duties seamlessly. The sermons, both at home and at the graveyard, were as vigorous and inspired as they were eloquent, with the mourners participating by occasionally raising their hands to the heavens and shouting their appreciation of the utterances of the preachers. As we trudged our way back home from the graveyard, I expected nothing other than the customary refreshments, handshakes and the small talk that are usually part of funerals. A few of us were shepherded into a large room and as we commented about the viciousness of cancer, the chatting, rather imperceptively, shifted to the cancer of corruption in our country. The passion and insight with which people spoke on the topic took me by surprise. Two men took the lead in the discussion, speaking in tandem, but others chipping in approvingly. Corruption is a cancer that is ravaging the country and according to them, it is unstoppable and incurable. It is just about to overwhelm our society. Apparently, the village suffers from a chronic shortage of water. Several years ago, water pipes were laid to solve the problem. But no water has ever flowed through those pipes. Recently, another contractor arrived in the village and started digging to lay new pipes. When the villagers protested, saying pipes are already in the ground, they were told the new pipes would give them water. After the completion of this project, there is still not a single drop of water coming through. This was just another case of the crooked giving one another tenders to make money. They talked about a contractor who was given a contract worth tens of millions of rand to tar a road in their area, despite the person having no capacity to do such a job. The road crumbled within a year. Their examples were local and apparently well known. They referred to school feeding scheme tenderpreneurs who short-change the tiny tots of food; classrooms, school books and desks that are not provided because money has been stolen; a granny removed from the database and then asked to pay a bribe to some official for her name to go back into the system; and a well-known thug whose armed robbery case collapsed because the docket disappeared. Who would lead the fight if the previous and present commissioners of police are linked to corruption - the former doing time in prison and the latter facing a public inquiry? Another senior cop, Richard Mdluli, is on suspension due to allegations of murder and other shenanigans. What kind of country would we be if citizens do not trust politicians, the police or the judges - and educational certificates cannot be accepted at face value? Scary, is it not? Suddenly, all eyes were on me when one of the "preachers" asked me directly: "Having been a politician, an MP and a minister, how do you suggest we handle this dire situation?" Fortunately, before I could open my mouth, another man rescued me. "That's where you make a mistake. This is not something that should be left to politicians, police or judges. It is a societal thing. It is society as whole that bears the brunt of this scourge. It therefore requires the involvement of society as a whole," he said as heads nodded all round. Others bolstered this line of reasoning by suggesting that we mobilise our churches, mosques, temples, political parties, trade unions and any other form of societal organisation to fight this scourge before it devours us. More importantly, it was said, individual citizens should be encouraged to report incidence of corruption to the police, the public protector, Corruption Watch, the media or any other structure or person who might be able to do something about it. I left the village on a high, encouraged by what I had heard.

TITLE: Health care riddled with corruption, says watchdog body
SUBJECT: HEALTH CARE (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); INTERNET & WWW (86%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ANTITRUST & TRADE LAW (77%); PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS (71%); WEB SITES (69%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (67%); SUBURBS (62%); MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS (54%) CapeTimes
TEXT: THE newly founded Corruption Watch will soon release a report on the "corruption free-for-all" in SA's health care system, particularly about corruption in the allocation of tenders. Corruption Watch head David Lewis, who chaired the Competition Tribunal from 1999 to 2009, told the Cape Town Press Club this week that probably the greatest number of complaints their organisation had received since it began eight weeks ago dealt with corruption in the health care system. "We've heard about doctors getting paid by the public sector and working in private companies . . . But it is no surprise that tender procurements in health care are particularly leaky. "It is undoubted that global companies are very skilled in dealing with local officials. "The fact that (health care) is run by the provinces has made some contribution to this," Lewis said. The report, which will be released in a couple of months, will go first to the authorities before being made public. "Our approach is not to begin from an adversarial standpoint, but to say to the state: 'Here it is, tell us if you think we are wrong.' "I think from certain institutions of state we will get a very sympathetic response, because they have encouraged us to do this. But from others, not." The first report Corruption Watch will release will be into the corruption in the Johannesburg Metro Police, an "acknowledged site of virulent corruption". Lewis said the responses they had received from the public had shown that concern about corruption in SA was widespread and came from people in all walks of life. People could report corruption on the organisation's website or via an SMS. About 85 percent of the internet complaints on the website were from African middle class people, and 100 percent of the SMS complaints were from black people, particularly from rural areas and marginalised communities. "The problem of corruption has been presented for so long as a suburban issue, and an anti-government sentiment. "It is gratifying that this is not the case at all. Corruption in rural towns or informal settlements is a very visible phenomenon to people living there." In the first eight weeks of its existence, Corruption Watch had received 1 200 complaints. "They were not all about corruption, but there were also allegations of very serious tender fraud. In the middle there were complaints about corruption in traffic departments and licensing departments. What we're trying to do is to discern hot spots of corruption and disseminate this. "We will have to gather a lot more data before patterns become apparent. "We're also doing investigations into systemic corruption." One of the fears was that using the internet would attract "nutters", as talk radio did. However, Lewis said this had not been the case. Corruption Watch was not interested only in the corruption that involved "money changing hands in a suitcase", but what Lewis described as "influence-peddling corruption". "This in many ways is where the real destruction of the system of governance is, not necessarily a prosecutable case, but conduct unbecoming that is really corrosive."

TITLE: It's time to deal with scourge of corruption: Public Protector
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: CORRUPTION is at a tipping point and SA needs to deal with the scourge decisively, says Public Protector Thuli Madonsela. "If it is correct that we all want an accountable state that operates with the highest level of integrity while being responsive to the needs of its citizens and residents, then we should all play our part to contribute," she said, addressing the 13th International Winelands Conference in Stellenbosch yesterday. "When we get out of the conference, the trajectory of our country depends on what each of us does. We have the power to determine the next phase." The theme of this year's conference was Integrity and Governance: What is wrong? What is good? What is next? About 100 people gathered at the Stellenbosch Institute for Advanced Studies yesterday to hear Madonsela speak. Throughout her 45 minute speech, she referred to a statement made by Nelson Mandela. While addressing the opening of Parliament in 1999, Mandela said that when someone in power used public funds for his or her own benefit, "then we must admit that we are a sick society". "Our hope for the future deeply depends also on our resolution as a nation in dealing with the scourge of corruption. "Success will require an acceptance that, in many respects, we are a sick society," Mandela had said. Madonsela said SA was in need of "selfless, committed and unwavering" leadership. "That is what President Mandela was calling for," she said. "Corruption is endemic in our country, both in the public and private sectors. "If we don't deal with corruption decisively, it will not only impact on good governance but has the potential to distort our economy and to derail democracy. "We are at a tipping point and President Mandela's warning remains valid." She said it was appropriate that Mandela had likened corruption to a sickness. "Indeed, others have called it a cancer. If we candidly view corruption as a cancer, we empower ourselves to deal with it as a nation the way we would deal with it if it were a cancer afflicting our body. "We would isolate it and do all we can to get rid of it, with a view to saving ourselves from death or disability." Madonsela said the public protector was an important, but not central, player in the fight against corruption. She said her office sought to address specific allegations of maladministration and also to act as a catalyst for systemic transformation in pursuit of good governance. Madonsela said she had recently been asked what it would take to end corruption. After some pondering, she had come up with three essential factors: l Strengthening public accountability by empowering civil society to ask questions and promoting good leadership. l Transparency, without which accountability would be impossible. l Strengthening communication among enforcement or accountability agencies. She also added that impunity must come to end. "Otherwise all anti-corruption and anti-maladministration efforts are useless. There shouldn't be protected people or holy cows." Madonsela left without taking questions. michelle.jones@inl.co.za

TITLE: DA lodges complaint over housing corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (57%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: THE DA has lodged a formal complaint of corruption with the City of Cape Town against ANC councillor Thobile Gqola. The DA alleged Gqola had given a "guarantee" of state-subsidised houses in Philippi East to Crossroads residents for R7 000 each. Speaker Dirk Smit received the complaint. Contacted by phone and by e-mail, Gqola failed to reply, but ANC council chief whip Xolani Sotashe said the complaint had been brought to the attention of the ANC. When ANC members put the corruption allegations to Gqola, he denied it, Sotashe said, adding: "If the councillor is found to be guilty the ANC is definitely going to act." Six Philippi East residents had approached the DA with the allegations of corruption, said Geordin Hill-Lewis, DA MP for Greater Philippi. He said the six had lodged corruption complaints against Gqola with the police, but police were unable to confirm the claims. The complaint, filed yesterday, requires the city to investigate Gqola and remove him from his position if |he was found guilty. The investigation is "separate but parallel" to the police's criminal investigation, said Hill-Lewis. The development, Philippi East Phase Five, will house close to 600 residents when it is completed later this year. About 560 homes are already occupied. "With the corruption, one can't be sure if (the houses) are filled with the people who deserve them," Hill-Lewis said.

TITLE: Murdoch case has laid bare the corruption that prevents quality reporting
SUBJECT: JOURNALISM (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); NEWS REPORTING (89%); NEWS CORP PHONE HACKING SCANDAL (78%); LAYOFFS (77%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (76%); POLITICS (76%); COMPANY EARNINGS (76%); WRITERS (75%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (75%); CLIMATE CHANGE (72%); BUSINESS INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (72%); POLITICAL SCIENCE (71%); INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (71%); RULE OF LAW (71%); CLIMATOLOGY (68%); EARTH & ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCE (63%); MAGAZINE PUBLISHING (62%); GLOBAL WARMING (50%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (50%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: Last week we awoke to a headline as sensational as anything the now-defunct News of the World might have printed: "Rupert Murdoch not fit to run a major company." It was quite the fall for someone whose hope, reportedly, was "to conquer the world". Murdoch's protracted tumble from the top has exposed the incestuous relationships between the media and the political and financial elite of England, and the corruption that imperils the very institution of British journalism. But, in the US, where accountability journalism is also under siege, we would be wise to see the crisis across the pond as a cautionary tale. The decimation of American newspapers is well documented; last year alone, over 3 700 newspaper jobs were eliminated. To stem profit losses, media conglomerates that once greedily bought up every paper in sight are now dumping them at an alarming rate. Take the Tribune Company, which slashed staff and destroyed much of the value of the Chicago Tribune, the Los Angeles Times and others, but doled out $100 million for performance bonuses for its executives. Never mind that those executives drove the company into bankruptcy. Citizens of this digital era have access to more platforms and channels than before. But the quality journalism that checks our leaders, that holds accountable the powerful and influential, is in jeopardy. Under the crushing pressure of commercialism, where speed is prized over thought, reporting deteriorates into a feeding frenzy of the 24-hour news cycle. The void of accountability journalism has too often been filled by liars and charlatans peddling fairy tales: "President Barack Obama is a Kenyan-born Muslim"; "global warming is a worldwide conspiracy of greedy climate scientists"; "the financial crisis was the result of government regulation". The result is what John Nichols and Robert W McChesney call "the most serious threat to self-government and the rule of law". It's not simply that newsrooms lack resources, or that aggregating sites that prioritise dancing kittens get so many hits. It's also that in a high-minded effort to impartially represent all sides of a story, reporters often give more credence to an argument than the facts warrant. But, as political scientists Norman Ornstein and Thomas E Mann recently wrote in The Washington Post, "a balanced treatment of an unbalanced phenomenon distorts reality". The role of journalists is not to give every party equal space, or accede to the red herring of false equivalence, but to pursue and publish the truth. I am the editor of a magazine of opinion and news. We value intelligent arguments and we value accurate reporting because, as the late Daniel Patrick Moynihan was fond of saying, we are entitled to our own opinions, but not to our own facts. At the national level, several newspapers and magazines like ours continue to provide quality coverage where others have fallen short. But the same can't be said of the empty pressrooms in capitals and city halls across the country - and the implications are dangerous. "People do awful things to each other," veteran war photographer George Guthrie says in Tom Stoppard's play Night and Day, "but it's worse in places where everyone is kept in the dark." There are rays of hope. It was, after all, superior investigative journalism by a newspaper that exposed the Murdoch empire's web of corruption. As Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger has recounted, when veteran reporter Nick Davies received a tip about phone hacking, he doggedly chased it, despite the risks - financial and other - of pursuing an almost omnipotent corporation. We can still see the embers of this kind of accountability journalism in the US. Last week, I had the privilege of presenting the 2012 Hillman Award for Newspaper Journalism - which honours journalism promoting the common good - to the Atlanta-Journal Constitution for its groundbreaking investigation that uncovered cheating on standardised tests in the Atlanta Public Schools. Corporate interests threatened to pull business if the cash-strapped paper ran the resulting articles. Yet the paper stuck with the story. This type of reporting is increasingly rare. Yet there is enormous potential to build up a new journalism in the public interest, and non-profit models like ProPublica are laying the foundation. But there is much more to do. A 2009 Columbia Journalism School report, The Reconstruction of American Journalism, co-authored by former Washington Post executive editor Leonard Downie jr, explores how the federal government can help sustain public and community media. If we are to successfully combat the corporatisation and gutting of media, we must develop new public funding sources for accountability journalism and train the next generation of reporters to honestly and boldly seek the truth. This is not a radical proposition; other countries, including those at the top of The Economist's index of free and democratic states, publicly fund independent journalism. But necessary change will not come until an engaged society demands it. - The Washington Post l Editor/publisher of The Nation magazine, Vanden Heuvel writes a column for The Washington Post.

TITLE: Government leases to reveal corruption
SUBJECT: RENTAL PROPERTY (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); LEASE AGREEMENTS (90%); LEASING INDUSTRY (90%); PROPERTY LEASES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INTERVIEWS (90%); BUDGETS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); BANKING & FINANCE (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (75%); POLICE FORCES (75%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (70%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: A REVIEW of government property leases worth around R3 billion a year is expected to uncover widespread corruption, says acting director-general of Public Works, Mandisa Fatyela-Lindie. In an interview yesterday Fatyela-Lindie said the review of the leases was already indicating collusion between landlords and banks and she expected it would uncover deep-rooted corruption in the property and financial sectors. Among leases signed by the department were controversial leases for SAPS headquarters buildings in Pretoria and Durban. In an investigation into disgraced police chief Bheki Cele's involvement in the SAPS leasing saga, Judge Jakes Moloi found Cele to have a "questionable relationship" with Roux Shabangu, the property baron who owned, among other buildings, Pretoria's Middestad building earmarked as a regional headquarters for the police. The department will soon face off with Shabangu in the North Gauteng High Court in Pretoria in an attempt to have the R500-million SAPS Middestad lease declared null and void. Fatyela-Lindie was appointed acting director-general this year and is expected to spearhead the department's turn around strategy announced by minister Thulas Nxesi in his budget vote speech last month. "We know there is a lot of anxiety in the property industry about the public pronouncements by the minister on the review of the leases. We also know that there has been some collusion between certain banks and some landlords to conclude leases which are irregular," she said. "We are shaking up a very powerful industry and we are expecting them to fight back. "You cannot run a property business that is based on corruption, where the cost of leases is inflated because somebody needs to benefit under the table," said Fatyela-Lindie. Nedbank is party to the High Court case between the department and Shabangu, as the bank lent him the R248m he needed to purchase the Middestad Building. "This is a very powerful industry that we are taking on and we know that they are gearing up for us because we are coming close to uncovering a lot of corruption. "Those who do not want to be exposed will be running to the media making all sorts of claims about not being paid. What they will not be declaring is that they do not even have valid contracts with the department, they have been

TITLE: Police investigative unit to probe complaints of Khayelitsha corruption
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CORRUPTION (92%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (91%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); MISCONDUCT (78%); BRIBERY (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (77%); APPOINTMENTS (77%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (73%); LARCENY & THEFT (68%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: THE Independent Police Investigative Directorate (IPD) is to probe complaints of police corruption in Khayelitsha which has been blamed for provoking a spate of vigilante killings. This emerged when the directorate met Khayelitsha residents yesterday to listen to their concerns about policing. It follows a request from the Social Justice Coalition (SJC) seven months ago to Premier Helen Zille to appoint a commission of inquiry to investigate the breakdown in policing in Khayelitsha, approved in principle by the provincial executive. But when national police commissioner General Riah Phiyega was appointed recently she asked Zille to hold off while she probed the complaints. Zille is awaiting her report. IPID director Francois Beukman said some of the residents claimed that police in the area had not given them proper information about their cases, were corrupt and accepted bribes from criminals. Beukman said after recent vigilante attacks, in which 14 suspected thieves and robbers have been killed by mobs in four months, they decided to step in to investigate. "We have seen the number of mob justice attacks in the area and that shows us there is a problem here. The number of complaints that we have received from the area is also very high. We will investigate all the cases," he said. A deadline for the investigation has not been set. The SJC yesterday welcomed the probe. "We think that it is an important intervention and hope something will come of it," co-ordinator Gavin Silber said. "However we still feel that a commission of inquiry will be an important step in solving this problem. (IPID) fixing their department would be blocking a small problem in the system. "The reason we called for a commission is because we feel that the system is broken. It is not just about the police, it is about the courts failing the people. We hope that their intervention will bring some changes to some of the complaints we have submitted." Silber said they had met the directorate yesterday to discuss the complaints they had submitted to Zille, including: l Police misconduct l Lawless behaviour l Abuse of power l People saw police as aggressors instead of protectors. Zille's spokesman, Zak |Mbhele, also welcomed the IPID

TITLE: The ANC turns a blind eye to corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); EVIDENCE (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (78%); SEWERAGE SYSTEMS (74%); MONEY LAUNDERING (74%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (70%); MAYORS (69%); CONTRACT AWARDS (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: Corruption is a problem, yes, but at least the government is doing something about it, we hear. In fact, from President Jacob Zuma and ANC secretary-general Gwede Mantashe down to the ordinary ANC faithful, we are told that eradicating corruption is a primary ANC goal. No it is not. The evidence before me suggests loyalty to comrades and support for one or other faction is far more important to the top brass in the ANC than acting against corruption. Stealing public money really hurts the poor first. If we had no corruption, we would have had more than enough money to upgrade our schools and hospitals, train and appoint more doctors, teachers and nurses, and supply more people with potable water, proper sewerage and electricity. The stark reality is that through tolerating, sometimes even encouraging, corruption and tenderpreneurship, the ANC is showing a thick middle finger to the very same people they claim to have liberated. So what is the evidence I'm talking about? I could point to the R50 billion arms deal where hundreds of millions landed in the pockets of politicians and ANC-connected middlemen. I could remind you that there was strong prima facie evidence of corruption, fraud and racketeering against Zuma himself, but in a highly suspicious move the charges were dropped. I could point out that the ANC chairman in Limpopo and close buddy of expelled ANC Youth League leader Julius Malema, Cassel Mathale, has been associated with many allegations of tender fraud in the province he is also premier of, but was re-elected nevertheless and is still a member of the ANC's national executive. I could add that the chairman of the ANC in the Northern Cape is suspected of corruption, fraud and money laundering, but he was recently re-elected. Several newspapers have reported that ANC stalwart Mac Maharaj had irregularly awarded huge tenders to companies belonging to convicted fraudster Schabir Shaik and was allegedly rewarded with money in his wife's account and an expensive US holiday. He was still appointed the official spokesman of the president. I can add many other similar stories of corrupt or allegedly corrupt ANC officials who were never prosecuted and remained in their positions in the party. But I would prefer to move away from allegations and newspaper reports and tell you about evidence accepted by a court of law that shows clearly how casually the ANC leadership treats corruption. In 2008, two ANC councillors of the Rustenburg municipality, Alfred Motsi and Moss Phakoe, became aware of serious corruption involving the ANC mayor, Matthews Wolmarans. Wolmarans is a close associate of the chairman of the ANC in North West, Supra Mataboge. The two councillors compiled a detailed dossier on the corrupt dealings. They raised it in the council, but there was no reaction. They took their dossier to the police. Nothing happened. The two men travelled to Johannesburg to see Mantashe and left copies of the dossier for him. Mantashe dismissed the two as troublemakers. In December 2008, Motsi and Phakoe went to Nkandla to see Zuma. They explained their dossier and pleaded for action. A month or two later they took their evidence to a meeting in Potchefstroom with Zuma, deputy president Kgalema Motlanthe, ANC treasurer Mathews Phosa and North West premier Thandi Modise. They handed their dossier to the minister then in charge of local government, Sicelo Shiceka, during a meeting in Rustenburg which mayor Wolmarans also attended. Phakoe afterwards told Motsi: "This might be my last day." Two days later the mayor's bodyguard, Enoch Matshaba, shot Phakoe in his parked car at his Rustenburg home. Phakoe died on the spot. Motsi's crusade led to his suspension as chairperson of the MK Veterans Association - he abused his position, it was found. Wolmarans was the obvious suspect, but the officer in charge of the investigation accused Motsi of the murder. Only last year, when the Hawks raided crime intelligence boss Richard Mdluli's office did they find the dossier and charged Wolmarans and his bodyguard. Two weeks ago, Judge Ronnie Hendricks found that Motsi was a truthful witness. He sentenced Wolmarans to 20 years and Matshaba to life in prison. Shame on you, Jacob Zuma. Shame on you, Gwede Mantashe.

TITLE: We can all still learn from the Indian masters of corruption
CITY: KOLKATA, WEST BENGAL, INDIA (58%); DELHI, INDIA (58%)
SUBJECT: BRIC COUNTRIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (76%); PUBLIC POLICY (73%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (72%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (71%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (67%); CIVIL SERVICES (66%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: YES, we all know that South Africa is riddled with corruption, but it could be worse. As in our Bric partner India, for instance. I have just been re-reading James Cameron's wonderful memoir An Indian Summer. In 1972 he returned to the sub-continent, having spent 25 years revisiting the country countless times as a foreign correspondent and conducting with it, as so many of us who know it have, a love-hate relationship. This time, however, it was as the newly-married husband of an Indian woman, which helped to give him more of a personal pride in India's achievements, and disappointment in its shortcomings. No shortcoming was more obvious, 25 years after independence, than the scale of its corruption. The totality and pervasiveness of Indian corruption was "almost a matter of national pride, sanctified by the oldest of traditions and denied by nobody". The process was acknowledged and ratified: "It is ordained that every official can be bribed, every commodity can be adulterated, every scarcity can be exploited, every contract can be fiddled, every privilege can be bought, every examination can be wangled, every bureaucrat must be paid not just to expedite the application-form but specifically not to obstruct it." Maybe we are not quite as bad as that, yet. But there are other similarities. The Indian government then had 510 ministers - 55 in Delhi itself, and the others in the various state legislatures. There are probably more now. They each earned 800 times more than the average Indian income and lived in opulent homes. Cameron writes: "One would mind less about their lifestyle did they not protest that they represented the destitute and needy." At its existing rate the government's constitutional policy of equality and social justice "would take about 40 million years to achieve". Nearly 40 years after the book was written I found myself chatting to a couple of civil servants on an overnight train to Kolkata. They wanted to know about corruption in South Africa's then 14-year-old democratic administration. I said yes, we also suffered from it, but give us time. Time wouldn't improve matters, they insisted. "We've been independent for 60 years, enough time for corruption to be perfected." And if we think our education system is a disaster after 18 years, 25 years after independence 70 percent of Indians were still illiterate and "the college system was in such a calamitous mess that there were even illiterate graduates". So no need to worry too much, especially about corruption and the 20% of all government procurements totalling billions of rand reported missing each year, either stolen or unaccountable through negligence. Or the Arms Deal which made politicians and their cronies hundreds of millions richer. Or the fact that Public Protector Thuli Madonsela says endemic corruption is at tipping point. Or that Archbishop Desmond Tutu believes President Zuma and his government no longer represent him - "you represent your own interests". We still have some way to go before we reach India's state of corrupt perfection. johnvscott@mweb.co.za

TITLE: Former MEC appeals corruption ruling
SUBJECT: SENTENCING (92%); JAIL SENTENCING (91%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (90%); LITIGATION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); CORRECTIONS (78%); ORGANIZED CRIME (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); EXTRADITION (77%); POLITICS (75%); FUNDRAISING (74%); ACQUITTAL (71%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: IN 2006, former Western Cape environment and planning MEC David Malatsi was sentenced to five years behind bars for corruption after pocketing a R50 000 bribe. But up to now, he maintains: "I did nothing wrong. I was not influenced by the money." Malatsi appealed his conviction and sentence in the Western Cape High Court on Friday. On December 11, 2006, he was sentenced to five years behind bars in the Bellville Regional Court; however, Malatsi's jail time has been put on hold pending his appeal. His then-co-accused, former Western Cape premier Peter Marais, was acquitted. It was found that Malatsi had received R100 000 from Italian businessman Riccardo Agusta in April, 2002 for the R550-million golf estate at Roodefontein, outside Plettenberg Bay. Agusta, the owner and developer of the golf estate, gave him a cheque for R100 000 as a "donation" to the New National Party (NNP), of which Malatsi was a member. Half of the money - R50 000 - was deposited into Malatsi's personal bank account. It also emerged that alleged Mafia kingpin Vito Palazzolo was key in the decision-making surrounding the Roodefontein development. Palazzolo is presently in jail in Thailand, awaiting a decision over whether he will be extradited to Italy to serve a nine-year sentence. On Friday, Malatsi's advocate, Andre Botha, said his appeal boiled down to whether or not the regional court was correct in rejecting Malatsi's explanation that he had not been influenced by the money. He said his client held a fund-raising position within the NNP. Malatsi's receiving the cheque, he said, had therefore not been unlawful, as he was expected to raise funds for the party. The question was whether Malatsi had allowed the money to influence his decision on the Roodefontein project, which had gone in favour of the developer. Botha acknowledged that when Malatsi was given the cheque, he knew it was in respect of Roodefontein. Judge Patrick Gamble asked whether he had known it was a bribe but accepted it anyway, saying that though he took the money, he had still done his job properly. Judge Gamble also questioned Botha on whether the correct thing for his client to have done was to tear up the cheque. Botha confirmed that his client knew it was intended as a bribe. "(Malatsi) says in hindsight, he should have torn it up but he banked it. He did not try to hide the money; it's there in his bank account, but he did not disclose it." Malatsi had not disclosed the R50 000 in his account to his party superiors because in the political climate at the time, it would have created a "huge, huge problem" for him. However, the State's advocate, Louis van Niekerk, said every decision Malatsi had made concerning Roodefontein had been guided by his desire to satisfy his "paymaster". Judges Elizabeth Baartman and Gamble reserved judgment. leila.samodien@inl.co.za

TITLE: Religious leaders vow to fight corruption
SUBJECT: RELIGION (96%); CORRUPTION (96%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (89%); MAYORS (78%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (78%); BRIBERY (78%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (77%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (77%); CITY GOVERNMENT (77%); POLITICS (76%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: IN ONE of the strongest stances yet taken against corruption, people of all faiths came together in Khayelitsha yesterday to launch an anti-corruption campaign led by the Western Cape Religious Leaders Forum. The forum is supported by Kairos Southern Africa and the SA Council of Churches. Religious leaders in the city, headed by Anglican Archbishop Thabo Makgoba, issued a stern warning to political leaders about their reluctance to deal with corruption. This and the public's silence would lead to society crumbling, they said. The launch of the campaign follows the religious leaders' Anti-Corruption Summit in June where they heard testimonies from communities, social justice activists and the office of the public protector on the cost of corruption and pledged to join the fight against it. They said the corrupt pursuit of money and power was threatening SA's young democracy and robbing the poor of their basic needs and opportunities. Speaking at Look Out Hill in Khayelitsha yesterday, Makgoba said corruption had a serious effect on how society, the government and the public sector operated. He said that if good men and women remained quiet, the country would have failed to fight corruption. Religious leaders should take it upon themselves to fight corruption, he said. "We as religious leaders are still learning to speak truth to power but are afraid to speak truth to our friends who are in power," Makgoba said, adding that corruption in whatever form was not right. He said their call against corruption was not limited only to those in power but was also addressed to members of the public. Those ordinary citizens offering or taking bribes, regardless of how small they were, were fuelling the problem, Makgoba said. Pastor Xola Skosana of the Way of Life Church in Khayelitsha said the discourse on corruption should not be limited to maladministration or procurement. It should also speak to the inequalities in our society. He issued a challenge to mayor Patricia De Lille, Western Cape Premier Helen Zille and President Jacob Zuma to focus on the gap between those in affluent areas and those in the townships. "They manage and preside over a corrupt and fraudulent political system. "That in itself opens up a breeding ground for all types of corruption," Skosana said. Catholic Archbishop Stephen Brislin said that in recent times, corruption had broken the trust between members of the public and their leaders. He said the situation in Marikana, where more than 30 people were killed in clashes between miners and police, was only a symptom of what was happening in the country Brislin said there was a lot of anger over corruption. Chief Rabbi Warren Goldstein said the moral regeneration of society required that children should learn the bill of responsibility at school. Doing so would instil a |culture of responsibility. "If the schools are not teaching it, take it up with the principal. If the principal is not responsive, then take it up with the MEC of Education," Goldstein said. He encouraged people to use platforms such as Corruption Watch. A declaration for the call to end corruption was signed by 18 religious leaders in Cape Town and 44 other signatories. The campaign plans to hold dialogues on corruption across the country. It will conclude in a national "preach and teach" event on International Anti-Corruption Day on December 9. xolani.koyana@inl.co.za IN ONE of the strongest stances yet taken against corruption people of all faiths came together in Khayelitsha yesterday to launch an anti-corruption campaign led by the Western Cape Religious Leaders Forum.

TITLE: It is every engaged citizen's business to fight corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LETTERS & COMMENTS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (71%); RELIGION (71%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (71%); POLICE FORCES (68%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (67%); ASSET FORFEITURE (66%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (58%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: Your editorial and two of the pieces on the facing leader page of August 23, "Stop theft from our people" and "We've done it beforeí¢[#x20ac]_" focus on the topic of corruption, its endemic nature and the real and immediate threat it poses to our nascent democratic order. There is a culture of impunity flourishing in our society that complements what religious leaders call "a growing sense of entitlement among rich and poor alike". Countering the spread of the cancer of corruption ought to be a national priority that is taken far more seriously than is at present the case. It is internationally recognised that the best means of acting against corruption is through the establishment of an independent anti-corruption entity (ACE). The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development research identifies specialisation, training, guaranteed resources and security of tenure of office for personnel as the applicable criteria for a successful ACE. The Scorpions had some of these characteristics but were disbanded following a resolution taken by the ANC at Polokwane in 2007. Their replacement, the Hawks, or Directorate of Priority Crime Investigation, have been found wanting by the Constitutional Court. The Hawks are insufficiently independent to be an effective ACE. They do not specialise in corruption, their training is inadequate and, as a unit in SAPS, their resourcing leaves much to be desired. The Hawks are headed by a deployed cadre of the ANC and do not enjoy security of tenure any more than the Scorpions did. In these circumstances it is small wonder they do a mere fraction of the work done by the Scorpions. According to Martin Plaut's analysis of the relevant official statistics: "The number of new investigations fell by 85% while the value of contraband seized fell by a staggering 99.1%". [Who Rules SA page 299]. Now Parliament, as ordered by the court, is deliberating upon remedial legislation and the future of the Hawks. Instead of making a clean break with what is clearly not working, the deck-chairs in the SAPS and the Hawks are being rearranged in a manner that offends the constitutional precept that the chief of police controls the SAPS. Civil society attempts to persuade Parliament that there are better ways of combating corruption fell on deaf ears and a new challenge to the constitutionality of the purportedly remedial legislation looms. It does not have to be like this. An active citizenry, led by religious leaders who do more than talk among themselves and their followers, could put pressure on the authorities to pay due heed to the warnings given by those who are not coping with the tidal wave of corruption. Advocate Willie Hofmeyr of the Asset Forfeiture Unit has announced that he doubts that the target of a mere 100 corruption convictions involving more than R5 million within five years is attainable. The public protector warns of a corruption "tipping point" and calls for enhanced public accountability, greater transparency via the work of free media and a countering of the culture of impunity. The establishment of a proper ACE is within the means and the power of the state; all that is missing is the necessary political will. The time has come for Parliament, as representatives of the people, not deployees of the political parties, to reject the executive's plans for the Hawks and to insist upon the establishment of a new Chapter Nine institution to tackle corruption. This might head off future Marikana massacres and more crooked arms deals. The task can not be left to courageous individuals like the Glenisters, Crawford-Brownes and Youngs of SA. It is every engaged citizen's business to speak up and act against corruption. The passage of the SAPS Amendment Bill affords an opportunity to do so. Seize it. It is possible to "stop this theft from our people". Paul Hoffman SC Director: Institute for Accountability in Southern Africa Cape Town Your editorial and two of the pieces on the facing leader page of August 23, "Stop theft from our people" and "We've done it beforeí¢[#x20ac]_" focus on the topic of corruption, its endemic nature and the real and immediate threat it poses to our nascent democratic order.

TITLE: Fisheries probe finds 'corruption and fraud'

TEXT: A FORENSIC investigation into Smit Amandla Marine's management of the state's marine vessels has revealed "widespread complicity and corruption" among government officials, and multi-billion-rand defrauding of the government, the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries announced yesterday. The forensic investigation, conducted by Ernst & Young, was commissioned by the department to probe tender processes at its fisheries branch. Smit companies have had the contract to manage the state's marine vessels since 2000. The investigation found that documents had been moved to a warehouse in Paarden Eiland, apparently to hide evidence, said the department. But Smit Amandla Marine's director, Sithembiso Mthethwa, yesterday dismissed "these outrageous allegations". "[We] note with dismay that after more than six months, Smit Amandla Marine has not been approached by either the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries or any investigating body to respond to these allegations, despite numerous requests for dialogue. TEXT: we reiterate our company's willingness to participate in an open and transparent investigation into our business practices," Mthethwa said. The department yesterday said the investigation had shown the agreement between fisheries and Smit in 2005 to manage the vessels, and later extensions to the agreement, had failed to comply with tender board regulations, with procurement policies, National Treasury and income tax regulations and the Public Finance Management Act. A contract worth millions had been extended by a letter. Contracts signed in 2000, 2005 and 2010, amounting to between R1.6bn and R2bn, were irregular and drafted to have maximum benefit for Smit, the department said. The vessels include the fisheries research vessels and offshore patrol vessels. Smit lost the tender to manage the vessels last year. The department said there was "substantial evidence of defrauding of the state". Evidence against Smit and officials in the Department of Environment Affairs and the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries was "overwhelming, indicating widespread complicity, corruption and deliberate entering of contracts unfavourable to the state", the department said. It said the state had been defrauded of about R1.6bn through duplicate payments and invoices without tax or VAT. The investigation found that "parties associated with Smit" had moved documents to a warehouse to prevent the department and investigators from finding evidence. With law enforcement agents, the investigators were able to prevent the destruction of "valuable data and contracts from government systems and |computers". In some cases the department said the state had been billed for tens of millions of rand at a time when there was no evidence of Smit having provided any service to the state. "There are instances where monies owing by Smit Amandla Marine to the state have been deliberately withheld with the assistance of complicit state officials in the Fisheries Branch," the department said. The former Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism had entered into the contract with Pentow Marine and Smit Marine, but there appeared to be no valid agreement between that department and Smit. The Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries took over the contract in 2011. melanie.gosling@inl.co.za

TEXT: THE Department of Agriculture Forestry and Fisheries appears to be backpedalling on its claim that a forensic investigation had "confirmed multibillion-rand corruption" by Smit Amandla Marine in the management of the state's marine vessels and had uncovered evidence of "widespread corruption" among officials from their department and the Department of Environment Affairs. TITLE: Cosatu will have to use its power in the ruling alliance to fight corruption
ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS OF SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE UNIONS (94%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); LEGISLATION (89%); POLITICS (89%); CAMPAIGN FINANCE (78%); ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (76%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%); ADMINISTRATIVE LAW (74%); LABOR UNIONS (73%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (71%); CARTELS (64%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%); RELIGION (52%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: The Cosatu congress was billed as an historic event which will enable organised labour and civil society formations to work together on efforts to promote public accountability and human rights in SA. Public platforms such as Parliament and the provincial legislatures are democratic spaces that belong to the people of SA. This sentiment was displayed in the resolutions dealing with efforts to combat corruption which is threatening our collective efforts to eliminate poverty and inequality in our society. There is a breakdown in trust between citizens and the political elite, who have failed to live up to election promises. This is particularly true of those corrupt elected representatives who have used public office to enrich themselves, as manifested in the increasing number of reports of corruption, nepotism, financial mismanagement, tender fraud and administrative inefficiencies that cripple so many of our government departments and municipalities. Sadly, those involved in these corrupt practices come from the ranks of organised civil society formations, and the ANC-led alliance which Cosatu is part of it. Our participation in this congress as organised civil society formations and faith-based organisations was motivated by a vision of active citizenship partnership to strengthen the voice of the poor and the marginalised on issues such as the regulation of political party funding, the creation of a national framework to protect whistle-|blowers, the institutionalisation of an independent investigating authority to fight corruption, and the implementation of policy and legislation to deal with cartels and tender-rigging. The first welcome outcome of this congress is the reinforcement of the call for the regulation of political party funding in SA. This call is informed by the realisation that private money in politics is a critical site in the struggle for accountable governance. When wealthy elites can purchase power by secretly funding political parties in exchange for benefits - such as favourable legislation, policy choices, public tenders or administrative action - the poor and marginalised disproportionately pay the price. The ongoing debate affirms that political parties play a critical role in forming and representing democratic political will in our constitutional dispensation, as they do in all democracies. It also acknowledges the democratic imperative that political parties require sustainable sources of funding to undertake their legitimate and necessary tasks in an open and competitive democracy. However, the lack of political party funding regulation and disclosure, combined with parties' increasing demand for funds, has created in SA, as elsewhere, an unhealthy alliance between some in government and some private interests. And this is democratically unaccountable and provides fertile ground for corruption. For SA to meet the challenge of political and economic corruption, and to live up to its promise of |political equality and economic opportunity for all; it must combine strict, independent enforcement of existing anti-corruption laws with fundamental reform of the still-unregulated space of private funding of political parties. The second aspect of the debate is in relation to promoting and strengthening existing protection measures for whistle-blowers. The protective scope of existing laws is too narrow. Whistle-blowing is regulated by a splintered series of laws that apply varying obligations to public and private entities, and different levels of protection for different categories of whistle-blowers. The Cosatu resolutions will add weight to the current legislation reform process that will ensure a framework that includes bodies and organisations that could also effectively deal with complaints, but are outside the ambit of the offices of the public protector and the auditor- general. This will enable ordinary citizens at local level, including union members of the Cosatu affiliates, to engage actively in the fight against corruption. The test for Cosatu, an alliance partner of the ruling ANC, will now be on its ability to assert its |influence within the alliance, |especially in the area of fighting corruption. The result should unlock the impasse on issues such as the crippling delay, largely due to lack of "political will", in the implementation of the Competition Amendment Act 1 of 2009. Investigations by the Competition Commission since 2006 found that representatives of some companies have held telephone discussions and meetings prior to the submission of their respective tenders. In these "private chats" they collaborated over their responses, and discussed and agreed on prices. This concerned the manipulation of prices of basic food items, pharmaceutical and hospital products. In an environment where government is involved in the procurement of goods and services, and where the possibility for collusion and uncompetitive behaviour by companies applying for tenders is high, it is important that strong institutional checks and balances, as envisaged in the Competition Amendment Act, are implemented. Over the past years, Cosatu and civil society formations such as the Black Sash have taken a commendably strong stance against corruption, collusion and uncompetitive behaviour through submissions to the Competition Commission, Parliament, and the launch of the bread price-fixing class action case in the Western Cape High Court. The renewed commitment at this congress will enhance Zwelinzima Vavi's leadership role of the National Anti-Corruption Forum and the collective efforts of civil society, business, and government to combat corruption. It will also assist the African Union's Peer Review Mechanism in the fight against corruption in the continent. l Nyembezi is a Policy Analyst |and Advocacy Programme Manager for Black Sash.

TITLE: How the seeds of corruption find fertile ground with greedy B&B guests
SUBJECT: BED & BREAKFAST INNS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); RESTAURANTS (87%); FAST FOOD (75%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: DEAR Public Protector, You are quite right to be deeply concerned about "false billing" - making the state pay for goods and services that were never supplied. And you're right that the system of away-from-home accommodation for state employees needs a total overhaul. In our little Free State dorp we've seen any number of illegal practices. And it's not just here: people who do the books of accommodation establishments in other parts of South Africa tell me that some B&B owners, gradually drawn into corrupt deals, now find they can't escape. There are long-established practices for guest-management transactions, whether the person comes directly or through a travel agent, that ensure everything is above board. But when guests don't stay as private individuals - when someone else is paying the bill - it's easy to "fix" the system, and the problem is most acute when government employees are involved. Smithfield, where I live, often hosts people on official short contracts. I became aware of the problems that could arise from the story of my neighbour who had a few such guests staying with her. Meals had become an issue: she's a good cook but the guests constantly moaned. She realised it might be a scam when they demanded she hand over the "food money" she would otherwise spend on their meals. By then she'd had such a rough time that she was happy to deliver the cash so the problem would go away. Next on the slippery slope are guests whose employer specifies a meal allowance: they will pay accommodation plus a certain amount for meals. Now some guests are routinely demanding this cash be handed over in full. It's a common, virtually standard practice for such guests to buy bread and chips for meals and pocket the balance. Other times guests whose employers stipulate a restaurant meal allowance to a certain amount insist on bringing a friend to meals. They ensure their combined bill is no less than the daily allowance. A colleague in the Eastern Cape tells of a common practice there: the relevant department covers her accommodation rate plus a R200 "meal allowance" that's way out of line. A couple of cold drinks plus a three-course meal cannot come to more than R130, even at the best eatery in town. The guest then buys cigarettes, cold drinks, takeaways, hamburgers - I kid you not, even though they have just eaten a full meal - to the value of whatever remains so that the money is all used. My worst experience concerned a group of young professionals who came to "get a quote" for an upcoming tour of duty in the town. Halfway through the negotiations, it became clear there was a subtext. They seemed to be suggesting that my rate was "too low" - a novel problem. It turned out they knew the highest amount payable for accommodation by their department. They had already obtained a quote from the most expensive places in town where the bill would be almost exactly the accommodation allowance. But they specifically wanted to stay at a place with a significant gap between the bill and the maximum allowed. Don't think they wanted to save taxpayers' money: their plan was to be billed for the utmost the department would pay and for the difference between my "genuine" bill and the "false bill" to be split between them and me. One of the guys said he chose where his team stayed when they were away on a job. If we could do this deal and make it an ongoing arrangement, he would make sure they always stayed with me in future. At this crucial point he had to leave, but he said he'd be back for my answer. So much money was involved that I expect he thought it was a done deal. I would have loved to see his face when he read my SMS saying he should immediately stop his illegal deal-making or I would report him. As he and his group were in town the next week on their assignment I presume he found a place more amenable to his proposals. What irked me most was this, however: they were employees of the Department of Justice - accountants, no less - in town to ensure the books of the local department were in order. Our message to you, Madam Public Protector is this: get cracking, find a way to stop these practices. We'll all be in your debt. Carmelrickard.posterous.com

TITLE: ANC trains|sights on|corruption|in its ranks
SUBJECT: FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (92%); MISCONDUCT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ETHICS (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (78%); BAIL (73%); ARRESTS (70%) News
TEXT: MANGAUNG: The ANC has taken steps to clamp down on corruption within its ranks, deciding that members convicted of financial transgressions will be expelled. Collins Chabane, chairman of the party's committee that deals with its constitution, said members would be expelled if found guilty of fraud, stealing money, corruption, money laundering, racketeering "or any other act of financial impropriety". Northern Cape provincial chairman John Block's head could - if he is convicted - be one of the first to roll. Block, Social Development MEC Alvin Botes and ANC MP Yolanda Botha were released on bail of R50 000 each last month after their arrest on charges of fraud, corruption and money laundering to the value of R49 million. The ANC has also decided to set up within three months an integrity commission made up of veterans who would act as custodians of the moral values of the party. It would have the power to call before it any member, and any member could report unethical conduct. In an attempt to improve accountability, changes to the ANC's constitution include requiring members placed in government posts to sign contracts with the party. A member suspended from a government job and facing charges of financial misconduct will also have to undergo an ANC disciplinary hearing to determine whether their deployment contract with the party should be terminated. This rule will also apply to accounting officers guilty of irregular expenditure in every sphere of government, "if it reaches the point of criminality".

TITLE: Veteran hopes for unity, end to corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (75%); SENIOR CITIZENS (70%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: CAROLINE Dunga joined the ANC seven years before it was banned and has been through good times and bad with it. Her hope is that this year President Jacob Zuma will stamp out corruption. "We don't like what is happening, people killing themselves to get positions in the ANC. People should not be joining the party to get jobs, but want to join because they love the ANC and want to advance its values," Dunga, who is the provincial deputy secretary of the ANC Veterans League, said yesterday at a rally in Philippi celebrating the ANC's 101st birthday, Asked about factions pulling the party in different directions, the 82-year-old pointed to a message on the back of an ANC T-shirt that read: "Comrades, let us not divide the ANC." She said: "We in the Veterans League think that if comrades can unite and be disciplined, this can build the ANC." Dunga said the newly elected leadership should consolidate the party's support nationwide and provide education and jobs for the youth and housing for the poor. She also wanted the party to look after its veterans and senior citizens. Dunga joined the ANC as an activist opposed to the arresting of women who had moved from the Transkei. She was detained several times for refusing to reveal underground ANC operations. "I was harassed quite a lot by the police because I was always in the front line at protests against the state. Back then things were really tough and the ANC was the home in which we could seek cover." Dunga was deployed in Mdantsane, East London, when the ANC was unbanned. Despite its divisions, she thinks the ANC will lead South Africans as it did in the past. xolani.koyana@inl.co.za

TITLE: Parents, |teachers|involved in|corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (90%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (79%); BRIBERY (79%); ELECTIONS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (72%); CITY GOVERNMENT (69%) CapeTimes
TEXT: CORRUPTION in schools, where teachers and principals rip off state funds allocated to educate the nation's youth, was the third highest type of corruption reported to the Corruption Watch last year. David Lewis, head of the independent organisation, which is a year old this month, described this as the "most disturbing form of corruption" reported to them last year. "This involves theft of funds, goods and equipment by principals and teachers. Even more disturbing are cases which indicate that parents, through school governing bodies, are also involved in corrupt awarding of tenders." Lewis said fighting corruption in schools would be a key focus this year. "We are asking the public to tell us more about what is happening at schools with regard to corruption. We would like to promote awareness and work together with communities to deal with this type of corruption." Corruption Watch was launched in response to the rising number of corrupt acts reported to civil society organisations, and focuses on the abuse of public money by those in government and business. In a statement summing up the year's work, Lewis said the organisation had received 3 223 reports last year. While the corruption reports it had received could not on their own be taken to represent the state of corruption in the country, they did give insight into the nature and ways in which corruption manifested itself in people's lives. The highest incidence of corruption, which was among municipal officials, dealt mainly with the abuse of power and resources by public officials, particularly in the procurement of goods and services. They had reports of people channelling government money to their personal accounts, putting pressure on others to cover up their corrupt acts, and handing out money and food to secure votes in local elections. Reports of bribery in traffic departments dealt mainly with bribery on the roads and corruption in the licensing of drivers. The highest number of reports on corruption came from Gauteng, the region where Corruption Watch had been most active last year. Reports from small towns made up 42 percent of the total number of incidents reported to the organisation. "It is the high number of reports from small towns that has been a concern. We believe that the reason for this is a lack of options and channels that people have for reporting and fighting corruption. There is limited access to media or to supportive NGOs and legal resources in those areas," Lewis said. Most people reported complaints using the SMS hotline (45 percent), and 34 percent reported on the Corruption Watch website. Most people who reported online did so anonymously and left no contact details. Lewis said the disadvantage of this was that it limited the organisation's ability to take the reports further. "However, we understand why many of our reporters want anonymity and we have committed ourselves to protecting our whistleblowers." For further information seewww.corruptionwatch.org.za

TITLE: Tax reform, jobs, corruption crackdown, youth subsidy on Budget 'wish lists'
SUBJECT: TAXES & TAXATION (96%); TAX REFORM (92%); JOB CREATION (91%); TAX LAW (91%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (91%); BUDGETS (91%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (90%); PUBLIC DEBT (90%); ECONOMIC POLICY (90%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (78%); TAX RELIEF (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); TAX INCENTIVES (78%); COMPANY STRATEGY (75%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (74%); TAX INCREASES (73%); FUEL TAX (73%); SMALL BUSINESS (67%); CREDIT BUREAUS (54%); STADIUMS & ARENAS (50%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (50%) News
TEXT: SIMPLIFY the tax system, cut government debt and focus on job creation. These were some of the key elements on the "wish lists" of economists and opposition parties for Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan's Budget tomorrow. Describing the tax system as "extremely complicated", at least three leading economists called for an overhaul leading to a number of taxes being dumped. The DA called for an overhaul of the taxation system and a realignment of expenditure priorities aimed at putting South Africa on a path of job-creating growth. DA finance spokesman Tim Harris highlighted a number of policies to support 12 strategic focus areas of the National Development Plan and to respond to the concerns of credit rating agencies. These included a reduction in government debt to levels close to 35 percent of GDP in the long-term through an aggressive process of fiscal consolidation, recovering nearly R30 billion in revenue by streamlining the government and stamping out public sector corruption, and boosting the job-creation potential of small businesses through a stimulus package, including R9.4 billion in tax cuts and R3.7bn in additional support programmes. The DA reiterated its call for implementation of a youth wage subsidy. UDM leader Bantu Holomisa called for action on infrastructure development. "Hopefully the minister will come up with a map and timeframes for this infrastructural development. The only infrastructural programme we have seen recently is the building of highways and stadiums for 2010. Where is this money being spent?" he said. Cope MP Nic Koornhof said his party's main wish was to avoid a "surprise Budget". "Second, the minister must concentrate on changing domestic sentiment about South Africa. We want to make sure that companies, which sit on almost R700bn savings, are happy to invest." Koornhof added: "We will definitely not support any tax hikes. We also call on the minister not to increase the fuel levy this year..."

TITLE: Arrested lawyers 'found gross corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ELECTIONS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (89%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); REFERENDUMS (77%); LAWYERS (76%); PRIME MINISTERS (73%); WRITERS (69%) News
TEXT: HARARE: A new political crisis sparked by increasing police pressure on the Movement for Democratic Change is set to undermine Zimbabwe's journey from a difficult inclusive government towards fresh elections in June. At least seven staffers from MDC Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai's press and research office have been arrested as well as top human rights lawyer Beatrice Mtetwa who was representing them. MDC insiders say the researchers were arrested as part of a faction fight within Zanu-PF. The team is believed to have uncovered gross corruption by some Zanu-PF ministers, and are suspected of leaking information to a daily newspaper and the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission. Another faction is accused of funding some connected to the commission and of "sweetening" some local journalists. Much of the drama and allegations of corruption surround the so-called "indigenisation" programme which has, so far, failed to materialise in real terms. The 51 percent shareholdings to be transferred to black Zimbabweans have to be paid for, and so far locals have not found the money to buy their majority shares in companies such as platinum giant, Zimplats, which is owned by South Africa's Implats. The police are also set to accuse the MDC of running an office funded by a US-funded NGO. This new crackdown on the MDC which was delayed until after a referendum on a new constitution, comes as President Robert Mugabe is expected to dissolve parliament in the next few weeks. His Zanu-PF justice minister Patrick Chinamasa says the elections must be held by June 29, when the present government expires. Chinamasa scoffed at speculation that the inclusive government would, in some way, be extended. "It is imperative to have the elections by June 29 because we will no longer have a parliament by then and a country cannot be run without a parliament," he said. "As the Minister of Justice and Legal Affairs, I am not entertaining the holding of the elections after June 29 unless circumstances beyond my control happen," he said.

TITLE: The government must stop dithering and deal decisively with corruption
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (89%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (87%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (87%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); FOREIGN POLICY (78%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (78%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (72%); EMPLOYMENT (71%); TAX LAW (70%); CORRUPTION (65%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (64%); TAX CONSULTING (63%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: One wonders whether many presidents would have survived the return of 13 soldiers in coffins after what seems like an ill-thought-through foreign policy jamboree by the SANDF in the Central African Republic (CAR). Yet, President Jacob Zuma, the "teflon man", survives repeatedly, protected by his party. We seem nowhere nearer to the truth than when the news first broke of our compatriots dying in far-off Bangui. From media reports it seems our troops were in trouble before the battle, or at least sensed something dangerous coming. Their messages to loved ones are poignant. Parliament, ever on the back-foot, can hardly be described as having exercised its oversight reactively in this matter. Even last week, the joint standing committee on defence cut its meeting short because MPs had "planes to catch". Clearly a national crisis - which is what these deaths are - cannot move parliamentarians from their executive-minded inertia, even with the minister of defence present. The DA's David Maynier seems to be the only MP who really wants to get to the bottom of the sad saga. The minister appears before the committee again on April 23. As citizens we deserve answers but most of all the families of the 13 dead deserve answers. Yet it seems as if our government is loath to be subjected to the accountability the constitution demands. But these are difficult times where in William Yeats's still apt but over-used words, "The best lack all conviction, while the the worst are full of passionate intensity...' We read a City Press article in which phone records seem to reveal a conversation between Sars Commissioner, Oupa Magashula and a woman. Magashula seems to be in the company of a drug lord and allegedly makes the woman a job offer. Sars in its statement says it has "no reason to doubt the integrity of the commissioner". It also went on to confirm the authenticity of the recording which may turn out to be problematic for Magashula. Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan acted quickly, announcing his intention to appoint a retired judge to investigate the matter. Gordhan must be livid that his commissioner has found himself in such a seemingly compromised position. Whatever the disagreements about policy, Gordhan, Trevor Manuel and Maria Ramos turned South African finance around and managed to fit all the crucial pieces of the jigsaw together into a competent revenue service and increased tax compliance. As long as there is increased compliance, a revenue service with integrity and a ministry of finance capable and skillful, we will be in a position to weather global financial storms. And that has proved to be largely so since 2008. The investigation into Magashula needs to happen swiftly and if the allegations are true, he must be dismissed without delay. South Africa can ill-afford a rotten Sars. Once the chink in the armour arises at the top, corruption and cronyism filters down to all levels. The credibility of Sars is at stake and the implications of a lack of credibility will affect business confidence and lead to increased arbitrage. Gordhan has acted more swiftly than his boss has against Minister of Communications, Dina Pule. She is presiding over a mess. Several members of the SABC board resigned, tales of nepotism and corruption abound with a ministry which seems no nearer to fulfilling its policy mandate than the day Pule took the job. Word has it that the directive had come from the bowels of Luthuli House for board members to resign. Whatever the truth of the matter, there is only one casualty and that must be the SABC and its mandate as a public broadcaster.
