The SABC remains a powerful tool for the government and the ANC, and so it comes as no surprise that there is meddling in its affairs whether overtly or covertly. A few months ago rumour had it that Zuma was about to axe Pule. Allegations against her include the awarding of a contract for "management services" to her boyfriend who also appears to be running the ministry from Sandton with a heavy hand in |appointments. Despite the allegations, nothing happened and there has been no investigation into Pule. Zuma is not known for his speed in these sorts of situations. Yet leaving this matter to linger is doing untold damage to an already battered ministry. l Judith February is executive director: Democracy and Governance at the HSRC. The views expressed are hers.

TITLE: New anti-corruption bureau will protect whistle-blowers
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (74%); INVESTIGATIONS (73%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (72%); INFORMATION SECURITY & PRIVACY (71%); BUDGETS (60%) News
TEXT: THE government's new anti-corruption bureau will be up and running as early as next month. The unit will have wide-ranging powers to clamp down on corruption across all spheres of government. It will also work hand in hand with other law enforcement agencies and have the power to protect whistle-blowers. And former National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) boss Menzi Simelane is instrumental in setting it up. This emerged in Parliament yesterday when Public Service and Administration Minister Lindiwe Sisulu briefed MPs. Briefing Parliament's oversight committee on public service, Sisulu said this was part of the ANC's determination to crack down on corruption. She added that the scourge of corruption was particularly prevalent in governments that were still in transition. The bureau will: l Investigate corruption-related matters in all three spheres of government. l Conduct investigations and institute disciplinary proceedings on corruption-related matters in the public service. l Co-ordinate the conduct of disciplinary hearings on corruption including the appointment of presiding officers and employer representatives at hearings. l Provide specialised technical assistance and advisory support. l Manage, co-ordinate and protect information and sources. l Facilitate the protection of whistle-blowers. l Refer evidence of criminality to the NPA. Sisulu said the bureau was proof that President Jacob Zuma's government was serious about fighting corruption. The department's special anti-corruption unit would be disbanded to make way for the new entity. Sisulu said the anti-corruption bureau was the answer because her department's "small entity" did not have the capacity and legal authority required to fight corruption effectively. Public Service and Administration head of governance, Dr Alex Mahapa, said that the Tanzanian model was chosen as the best model to fight corruption. Mahapa said the bureau, for which her department would be responsible, was looking for a "high-profile" corruption buster to lead it. DA MP Nicolaas du Toit called on the department to emphasise "credibility", not "high profile", when hiring the bureau's new leader. MPs also raised concerns at the bureau's budget of |R17 million, which was considered too little considering that state corruption amounted to billions.

TITLE: Six refugee centre officials suspended and face allegations of corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); REFUGEES (94%); BRIBERY (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); MISCONDUCT (78%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: SIX Home Affairs officials working at Customs House refugee centre have been suspended for alleged corruption, the department's provincial head Yusuf Simons said yesterday. Refugees have alleged that corruption at the centre is rife, saying a bribe of between R200 and R500 can get you to the front of the queue. Refugees said bribes worked by an "agent" writing a code on a refugee's hand after payment, which meant they didn't have to wait in the queue but would be fast-tracked. The centre was also the scene of tense confrontations between security guards and refugees in recent weeks. On Tuesday afternoon some refugees threw rocks at the building's entrance, some of which were yesterday still lodged in the reinforced glass of upper-storey windows. The police later used pepper spray to push the crowd back. Simons said the six officials, who were suspended recently, faced allegations of corruption, misconduct and dereliction of duty. Internal disciplinary hearings will be finalised in the next two months. The hearings will be conducted by the department's counter-corruption unit and labour relations team. If found guilty, the officials face dismissal. Three officials from this, the Western Cape's only refugee centre had been dismissed early last month on charges of fraud and corruption following disciplinary hearings, said Simons. The former head of security had been suspended for alleged corruption last month. He worked for Mafoko security services, a private company that controls the hundreds of refugees who queue at the centre daily to

TITLE: Corruption Watch wants commission to be tougher
SUBJECT: AGREEMENTS (90%); ANTITRUST & TRADE LAW (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); DAMAGES (90%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (90%); SETTLEMENT & COMPROMISE (90%); GUILTY PLEAS (88%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (88%); CARTELS (88%); MISCONDUCT (85%); LAWYERS (75%); ADMISSIONS & CONFESSIONS (71%); CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTING (67%) News
TEXT: An appeal has been made to the Competition Commission to make provision in future settlement agreements for the "naming and shaming" and prosecution of individuals for contraventions of the Competition Act. Nicola Whittaker, an in-house lawyer at Corruption Watch, also called on authorities to lay criminal charges against those people who had contravened the Prevention and Combating of Corrupt Activities Act and the companies involved, and getting back bonuses of present and past directors who had personally profited from the unlawful conduct. She was addressing the Competition Tribunal yesterday about settlement agreements reached between the commission and 15 construction firms related to bid rigging and collusive tender infringements. Corruption Watch also recommended the trebling of damages for corruption-related offences, including bid rigging. However, Whittaker said the commission had secured admissions of guilt from implicated firms, which opened the way to civil damages claims by those directly damaged by the cartel.

TITLE: Two cops face charges of corruption, theft
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (90%); EXTORTION (88%); POLICE FORCES (88%); BAIL (73%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (69%); CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE (54%); DIGITAL CAMERAS (51%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: Two police officers accused of corruption appeared in the Bellville Specialised Commercial Crimes Court in Cape Town yesterday. Siyaza Patrick Siyale, 51, and Wilfred Arno Mentoor, 29, formerly from the Woodstock police station, were not asked to plead to charges of corruption, theft and defeating the ends of justice. Siyale alone was charged with extortion involving R1 800, but was not asked to plead to this count either. According to the charge sheet, they profited from a scheme in which DRC investor David Kilato duped the president of the French-SA Chamber of Commerce and Industries, Nicodemus Solly Moeng, into making various payments totalling R300 000 towards a "lucrative investment". Prosecutor Denver Combrink alleged that Siyale and Mentoor demanded money in order not to arrest Moeng for the scam, and then searched his house, allegedly seizing R400 as well as a digital camera and a book titled The Story of Jackie Selebi. Siyale is out on R5 000 bail, and Mentoor is out on a warning. Both will appear again on August 19. - Sapa

TITLE: Hawks lack claws to fight corruption, say lawyers
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); LEGISLATION (89%); POLICE FORCES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (87%); LAWYERS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (77%); VETO (77%); APPOINTMENTS (76%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: ELITE crime-fighters the Hawks do not have the "clout" to combat corruption, according to a legal team for businessman Hugh Glenister. In two applications before the Western Cape High Court, Glenister and the Helen Suzman Foundation are challenging the SAPS Amendment Act, which effectively amended the South African Police Service Act last year. This came after Glenister successfully challenged a part of the SAPS Act, with the Constitutional Court allowing 18 months for the legislature to fix it. But yesterday, advocate Paul Hoffman, SC, acting for Glenister, argued before a full Bench of the high court - made up of judges Siraj Desai, Andre le Grange and Judith Cloete - that even though the legislation governing the Hawks had been amended, these "tweaks" remained incompatible with the constitution. That anti-corruption entity, he said, needed to be free of executive control, more specifically that of the minister of police, as was the case for structures such as the National Prosecuting Authority and the Independent Police Investigative Directorate. Hoffman argued that the Hawks, tasked with investigating allegedly corrupt citizens, fell under the management and control of the national commissioner, whose direction came from the minister. In order to secure the necessary independence, he said, the anti-corruption entity needed to be "impregnable" to undue executive interference. "The scheme of the 2012 legislation does not achieve a state, a structure or an operational environment in which the Hawks are so 'secured'. This is unconstitutional," one of Hoffman's documents read. "They 'fall under' the police hierarchy and are not adequately independent." He further said that in terms of the Concourt's ruling, the "factual circumstances" of the executive, the Hawks (pre-2012) and the police service needed to be taken into account when determining what the appropriate degree of independence was. The Helen Suzman Foundation, which is taking a different, more narrow legal approach, is arguing that the amendments to the SAPS Act still fail to meet constitutional standards with regard to an independent anti-corruption entity. Advocate David Unterhalter, SC, for the foundation, has so far argued on the issue of the appointment of Hawks members. The appointment of the head was a ministerial decision based on the minister's discretion, he argued, and Parliament had no power to veto, scrutinise or reject the appointment. Unterhalter questioned whether there could be satisfaction that such an appointment was free of any taint of ministerial preferment. He is to continue his arguments today. The respondents, including the offices of the minister and the president, are yet to argue. leila.samodien@inl.co.za ELITE crime-fighters the Hawks do not have the "clout" to combat corruption, according to a legal team for businessman Hugh Glenister.

TITLE: Mr President, it's time for you to prepare your corruption defence
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); APPEALS (60%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%) CapeTimes.Opinion
TEXT: Let's assume the best legal scenario for the Zuma camp in the spy tape inside the corruption case that refuses to go away. In other words, assume for a moment that the Hawks or Scorpions or Ants or Tripe or whatever biological creature investigated President Jacob Zuma were taking orders from his political enemies. They wanted him to never ever become president of South Africa. That was their chief aim. What, legally, follows from this? Nothing dramatic follows. A political motive behind a legally winnable corruption case should mean that the case can still go to court. This is because society has an overriding interest in not being stolen from, not being broken. This social interest is surely greater than the potentially corrupt individual's irritation with the motive of some of the investigators, especially if the investigators sit on real evidence of prima facie corruption. And we know, in fact, they do have such evidence in this case because before the charges were dropped against Zuma the prosecuting authority told us it had evidence of a quality good enough to justify bringing the charges. The only thing left is to spell out more precisely why a political motive behind a winnable case is irrelevant (for the benefit of one Mokotedi Mpshe who dropped the charges). I confess I also once held the mistaken view that if there's a wicked motive behind a case (that is, a motive not related to the pursuit of justice), then the case should be dropped. My instinct was twofold: wickedly motivated cases incentivise investigators to abuse the legal system if we do not throw such cases out when they come to light. Furthermore, the integrity of the justice system requires that the system operate on the basis of honourable motives just as society is expected to behave. And, obviously, the prosecution of people on the basis of non-legal motives undermines the integrity of the legal system because it erodes the honour at the heart of the system. Or so I argued a few years ago. I have no clue if this is what Mpshe thought also. He cited some dodgy Hong Kong case as an authority on which he relied for his decision. It turned out, of course, that that was a case that was actually overturned on appeal (and this fact, by the way, is itself a good reason why Mpshe's decision should be set aside!) But let's say, for argument's sake, Mpshe also actually holds the twofold reasons that I did a few years back. Here is why he would be wrong, just as I have turned out to be wrong upon reflection. The "integrity of the legal system" must be weighed against the need for justice on the part of the aggrieved party. In this case, the aggrieved party is society, from whom possibly billions had been stolen. It would be weird to have a blanket rule that says one should always drop cases that stem from non-legal motives and ignore the right to access justice on the part of individuals, or society, who had been wronged. The question then is one of how to weigh the need to ensure we don't encourage the abuse of the legal system for political purposes, while allowing society to exact justice from corrupt individuals. Well, in this particular case, and no doubt in many similar cases, it makes sense to push ahead with the main corruption case despite the political motives of investigators. This is because the legal system, overall, contains mechanisms that Zuma can appeal to in order to deal with the political motive part of the saga. First, and something Mpshe should not have missed, nothing stops Zuma, say, from suing the state or anyone out to damage his name or career illegally. A case of this kind would ensure Zuma gets compensated for any illegal actions against him. But this case could run at the same time as a case in which Zuma faces evidence of prima facie corruption. Then Zuma can get justice and society can get justice. The integrity of the legal system would be ensured, and society's intrinsic interest in substantive justice would be protected. Second, if there's a case to answer in law, then the political motives of some investigators do not undermine the legal system's integrity fatally - not to an extent that justifies pretending there's no case to answer. Third, from Zuma's perspective, the only good legal complaint would be a fear that he will not get a fair trial. But because the politically motivated investigators are not the judges who decide the case, no basis for fearing a fair trial exists. Mpshe exercised his discretion for sure, but his reasoning lacked sufficient legal merit. I predict our highest court will eventually say so too.

TITLE: Mthethwa lashed over corruption, police inefficiency
SUBJECT: TALKS & MEETINGS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (89%); POLICE FORCES (79%); PUBLIC HEARINGS (78%); DRUG POLICY (77%); SHOOTINGS (66%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: POLICE Minister Nathi Mthethwa bore the brunt of public dissatisfaction with the police at a meeting in Mitchells Plain yesterday with residents complaining about inefficiency and corruption. Mthethwa was in Mitchells Plain to launch an anti-drug campaign and held a community meeting at Spine Road High School. Present at the meeting were Mthethwa's deputy Maggie Sotyu, Community Safety MEC Dan Plato, provincial police Commissioner Arno Lamoer and mayoral committee member for safety and security JP Smith. Activist Fikile Mbambi told Mthethwa he had attended many of the minister's public meetings, complaining about police corruption and brutality, but the minister was yet to take up any of those issues. Gadija Skippers, who lives in an open field near the Kapteinsklip train station, said she lived in fear for her children. They live with relatives in Rocklands, not far from the field. On Monday there was a shooting incident in the street where they live. "I was running there and all the people were running for safety. My brother-in-law tried to prevent me going in the direction of the bullets but I had to protect my children," Skippers said.

TITLE: Minister lashed over police corruption in city
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); GANGS (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); ARRESTS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (77%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (77%); FIREARMS (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (73%) NotForWeb
TEXT: She said most of the time when police were alerted to a shooting-in-progress they arrived late or did not respond at all. Responding to accusations of corruption and police inefficiencies, and to questions about his plans to tackle gangsterism in Mitchells Plain, Mthethwa said of 4 976 people arrested for drug-related crimes in Mitchells Plain since January, 184 were minors, some as young as 13. They had been arrested for possession of illegal firearms and drugs. He said they were affiliated to gangs, something which could be avoided if their parents played their role. "It's well and good to say authorities must do something but we must also pose a question: what happened to us as parents that we go to bed at night and our 10 or 11-year-old is not around at home? Should that be the responsibility of the government? This problem is big and needs all of us to work together," said Mthethwa. The problem of gangsterism and drugs could not be solved by the police, and the provincial government should take responsibility for providing basic services to communities affected by gangs. "You are not going to send the police and the army to deal with 16-year-olds and 14-year-olds." Mthethwa said under Lamoer's leadership, a number of police officers had been arrested and prosecuted for corruption and relationships "with criminals". Detailed complaints about specific officers involved in corruption were always welcomed. xolani.koyana@inl.co.za

TITLE: House to mull IEC|'corruption' options
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (78%); OFFICE PROPERTY (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (68%) News
TEXT: THE fate of Pansy Tlakula, chairwoman of the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC), is now in Parliament's hands. Yesterday Parliament officially received the report by Public Protector Thuli Madonsela, in which she said Tlakula had played a "grossly irregular" role in procuring the Riverside Office Park building in Centurion for the IEC's head office. Madonsela recommended that Parliament consider taking action against Tlakula when she released her report on|Monday. But Parliament will take action only once the National Assembly has adopted Madonsela's report. "Parliament has today received the report from the Public Protector, advocate Thuli Madonsela, on the investigation into allegations of maladministration and corruption in the procurement of premises to accommodate the head office of the Electoral Commission," read the statement issued by Parliament. It said the report would now be tabled and then referred to a "relevant oversight committee" for consideration. "The committee is required to report back to the National Assembly and recommend a course of action," read the|statement. ANC chief whip Stone Sizani also waded in, slamming opposition parties for making public statements on Madonsela's report on the dodgy IEC lease tender. He said the House was the final arbiter on the public protector's report and, ultimately, Tlakula's fate. "We call upon all parliamentary political parties to respect this process and desist from making statements that seek to prejudge the matter," said Sizani.

TITLE: China cracks whip on oil bosses in move to fight corruption
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (90%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); POLITICS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); EXECUTIVES (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (78%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (77%); PUBLIC POLICY (73%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (69%); DISMISSALS (63%); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT (60%); ECONOMIC NEWS (54%) Business.News.International
TEXT: Jiang Jiemin, a former PetroChina chairman who oversees the country's biggest state-owned enterprises, was being investigated by the Communist Party anti-corruption watchdog, the official Xinhua news agency reported yesterday. Jiang, a director of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission, was being probed for "serious disciplinary violations", Xinhua said, citing the party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. Jiang is the highest-profile official investigated since President Xi Jinping took over the ruling party in November last year, vowing to crack down on graft which he said threatened its six-decade hold on power. Focusing on the oil industry and the state-owned companies Jiang oversaw might help Xi and Premier Li Keqiang push through economic policies at a November conclave, said Willy Wo-Lap Lam of the Chinese University of Hong Kong. Lam said: "Because there is so much money around, it is not surprising that the oil industry is perhaps fertile ground for corruption. Xi and Li will subject these huge conglomerates to more intense scrutiny - this is a way to impose some sort of discipline." Zhou Yongkang, a former China National Petroleum Corporation general manager in the 1990s who until last year oversaw the country's internal security forces, was also being investigated, the South China Morning Post said at the weekend, citing unidentified sources. Jiang and Zhou's career paths crossed in the oil industry, where they worked for more than three decades. Other officials being investigated by the discipline commission include Liu Tienan, the vice-chairman of the country's planning agency, who was expelled from the party in August last year after being fired in May after a probe began. Li Chuncheng, a deputy party secretary of Sichuan province, was put under investigation in December, Xinhua reported at the time. Party leaders agreed to investigate Zhou because of rising anger in the party at the scale of corruption and the vast fortune amassed by his family, the South China Morning Post said. Jiang is not the first top oil executive to face punishment. In July 2009 Chen Tongkai, the former chairman of Sinopec, was given a suspended death sentence after he was convicted of taking 196 million yuan (about R329m) in bribes. - Bloomberg

TITLE: 'Imagine SA free from crime and corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); AIDS & HIV (83%); AIDS & HIV TREATMENT (67%) News
TEXT: MTHATHA: Imagine a South Africa in which citizens are free from oppression and exploitation, crime and corruption and have access |to quality education and |health care. Agang SA leader Mamphela Ramphele feels this is the best way to honour the legacy of Steve Biko, who was killed by the apartheid security police 36 years ago. "We pledge to build a united and democratic South Africa in which we can all finally realise true freedom for all," Ramphele said yesterday. Her visit coincided with reports that the health system in the Eastern Cape is teetering on the brink of collapse. She asked: "What, indeed, is the meaning of freedom if you can't get life-saving HIV/Aids medication? "... What would Steve Biko think of this betrayal of the ideals that he and many other heroes of the Struggle died for? "Unless we deal with corruption, we can forever say goodbye to the promise of freedom in our lifetime," Ramphele said.

TITLE: Malawi's corruption-buster sent|to SA hosital after being shot
SUBJECT: SHOOTINGS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); GUNSHOT WOUNDS (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); BUDGETS (89%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (77%); APPOINTMENTS (73%); POLICE FORCES (73%) CapeTimes.World
TEXT: Blantyre: Gunmen have shot and severely wounded a senior Malawian government official who was on a corruption-busting crusade. Paul Mphwiyo, budget director in the ministry of finance, was shot three times as he was driving into his compound on Friday night, the office of the president and cabinet said yesterday. "Mr Mphwiyo was severely wounded and was evacuated by the government and is in hospital in South Africa in a critical but stable condition," it said. "The government wishes to notify the public that it strongly believes Mr Mphwiyo's shooting was not just any robbery, but a... targeted attack aimed at silencing him and the government in the fight against high levels of corruption and fraud. "The president and the government therefore wish to assure all Malawians that the fight against corruption and organised fraud in government, which had become entrenched in the past years, will in no way be deterred by this shooting. "It will be sustained to ensure that these evils are rooted out of the government and the nation at large." Lilongwe police spokesman Kingsley Dandaula said Mphwiyo was shot in the face, shoulder and chest. "We are investigating, but we have yet to establish the motive for the shooting." The US-trained technocrat was appointed by President Joyce Banda to overhaul Malawi's porous finance systems. Corrupt government officials and businessmen have exploited its numerous loopholes to siphon money. Mphwiyo has cancelled several dubious contracts, involving millions of dollars, between companies and the government. This has made him unpopular with other government officials and their business associates. He recently confided to friends and family that he was receiving anonymous phone calls warning him that he was "marked". "He had told us that he was receiving death threats, but he never thought it was serious," the Nation newspaper quoted one of his associates as saying. Former director of public prosecution Fahad Assani is on record as saying more than 30 percent of the national budget is lost to corruption.

TITLE: Religious leaders lash out at corruption
SUBJECT: RELIGION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); POLITICS (89%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (79%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (79%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (76%); CHILDREN (74%); JEWS & JUDAISM (74%); HINDUS & HINDUISM (74%); INFECTIOUS DISEASE (71%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (71%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: RELIGIOUS leaders have come out strongly against government corruption, criticising leaders for putting their own selfish desires ahead of the needs of those who voted them into power. Representatives of all the major faith communities, including Christianity, Islam, Judaism, Hinduism and |Buddhism, attended a meeting at the Muir Street Mosque in District Six yesterday to debate the post-apartheid relationship between religion and state. The session was held to|discuss the role of religious leaders ahead of next year's elections. Peter Storey, former Bishop of the Methodist Church of South Africa, delivered the hard-hitting keynote address to which Mpho Tutu, who heads her parents Desmond and Leah Tutu's Legacy Foundation, responded. Storey said less than two decades into democracy, South Africa's new flag had "already gathered numerous grubby stains due to the actions of a democratically-elected government". He pointed to a number of choices which had affected the lives of millions, including: l The Arms Deal which cost "untold billions that could and should have been used for lifting our people out of poverty". l Aids denialism under former president Thabo Mbeki. l An Education Department which produced new "lost generations" caused by failure in leadership and teachers who placed their own interests ahead of their pupils. "Looming over all these, of course, is the most intractable issue of them all: poverty and joblessness, exacerbated by the pandemic crime wave visited upon private citizens in townships and suburbs, and the looting of the public purse through corruption." Storey said the official response had been troubling. "We wait in vain for just one word of inspiration, direction and leadership, to address these crises, but government invests its energies in protecting itself from exposure." He hoped a new generation of spiritual leaders would hold the government accountable. "The first flush of democracy has faded and the tawdriness and venality of much of our present political scene is undeniable. Corruption is a direct robbing of the poor and can no longer be ignored." Storey said as the elections approached, politicians would come "shopping for votes". "Our concerns will suddenly become important again, candidates will attend houses of worship and demand to speak. Some weak-kneed clerics will let them, others will have the backbone to say, 'No'." He encouraged fellow theologians to not be seen favouring a political party as the election loomed. Tutu said gains had been made in the delivery of basic services. "But at the same time we have witnessed many of the very politicians whom we believed could virtually walk on water sinking in the quicksand of personal aggrandisement and greed. "Many South Africans continue to live miserable lives; infants die preventable deaths due to poor sanitation - no women or children are safe from the scourge of sexual |predation that seems to have beset us." Tutu said it was the role of religious leaders to criticise and applaud politicians where appropriate. "But our applause is only meaningful when it is trustworthy... it is impossible to trust the words of faith leaders who speak from the back pocket of a political party rather than as representatives of the community, particularly the most marginalised." Rashied Omar, chairman of the Western Cape Religious Leaders Forum, said it had sought this year to clarify its role as "free of government or party political interference". Omar spoke during the AGM ahead of Storey and Tutu's comments. He said the forum had been involved this year in "raising the alarm about the growing trend of corruption in South African society". michelle.jones@inl.co.za

TITLE: Police auditor 'will tell all about corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LABOR & EMPLOYMENT LAW (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); WITNESSES (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); TESTIMONY (89%); AUDITS (89%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (89%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); INTERNAL AUDITS (78%); LABOR UNIONS (77%); COSTS & ATTORNEY FEES (77%); POLICE FORCES (67%) News.SouthAfrica.WesternCape
TEXT: THE Crime Intelligence case in which allegations of corruption and fraud within the division have surfaced is set to go to trial in three months' time in the Johannesburg Labour Court. Trade union Solidarity, representing the colonel at the centre of the case, Johan Roos, said yesterday that his trial testimony would include details about investigations he was involved in "and the corruption that these investigations exposed". A Solidarity statement said: "An ex-member of the Scorpions, two members of the Hawks and several SAPS|members have been summoned to testify in the controversial case." Roos, previously an internal auditor in Crime Intelligence and responsible for auditing the Secret Service account, wants to be reinstated after being transferred to another section in the division. According to court papers, he discovered fraud relating to the Secret Service account and after initially being authorised to investigate it, was instead transferred. Earlier this week, while Solidarity had been ready for a trial, police asked that the case be postponed. The application for the postponement was heard yesterday and a decision on whether or not a settlement could be reached was expected. Afterwards, Dirk Groenewald, head of Solidarity's Centre for Fair Labour Practice, said: "The Labour Court granted the application for a postponement and set the case for trial from 10 to 21 February 2014." The court also ordered that police pay the legal costs Solidarity incurred as a result of the postponement. Groenewald said it was "clear" that former Crime Intelligence head Richard Mdluli, previously suspended for matters relating to his time as the division's head, would be the police's chief witness. Solidarity's statement said: "Colonel Roos, who has worked for the SAPS for 26 years, is currently stationed at the inspection and evaluation division of the Crime Intelligence Unit. "This division was never functional and is currently closed. Roos was moved to this division by (Mdluli) after he had made a protected disclosure in which allegations and proof of corruption in this unit were brought to light." In an affidavit, Roos said he had uncovered fraud involving undercover state vehicles. Other allegations contained in court documents include a special intelligence unit ignoring procedures, the apparent cover-up of a death and "gross abuse" when it came to filling 250 police posts. In an affidavit in support of the case being postponed, acting Crime Intelligence head Bongiwe Zulu said that evidence from Mdluli and Mulangi Mphego, Crime Intelligence's acting head before Mdluli's appointment in 2009, would be "critical". Zulu's affidavit said police were opposing Solidarity's application for Roos's reinstatement and denied he was a whistle-blower. caryn.dolley@inl.co.za

TITLE: Nkandla upgrade 'fraught with corruption'
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); POLITICS (78%); POULTRY (77%); ASSASSINATION (73%); SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT (68%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (65%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (63%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: THE R206 million upgrade at President Jacob Zuma's private residence was fraught with corruption - with several companies and persons awarded tenders without going through the requisite security clearance. Even the coops and kraals for Zuma's chickens and cattle had been identified as potentially high security risk in "a politically volatile" Nkandla. These are some of the findings of a special report by the Joint Standing Committee on Intelligence into the Nkandla security upgrades, which was released yesterday. The findings were drawn from the Department of Public Works Task Team report into the controversial upgrades. It was released hours before the security cluster ministers abandoned their court case against Public Protector Thuli Madonsela, which was supposed to have been heard today. The 36-page report paints a disturbing picture of the flouting of mandatory procurement requirements, with a number of companies having been awarded tenders without going "through the security clearance process". "Supply chain management policy and prescripts were not fully complied with (in) the procurement of goods and services related to the project," the report reads. The committee said it was concerned that people without the necessary security clearance had been involved in the Nkandla project. "This was a serious contravention that should not have been permitted since the safety of the president could have been compromised." According to reports, Zuma's private architects, Minenhle Makhanya Architects from Durban, who had no security clearance, were entrusted with managing the Nkandla project. This has raised questions about whether he might have misled Parliament in June when he denied that he had anything to do with the Nkandla upgrades. Presidential spokesman Mac Maharaj could not be reached for comment yesterday as his cellphone was on voicemail. He did not respond to |e-mailed questions or an SMS. The committee report confirms the R206m spent on the Nkandla upgrades, but exonerates the department. "There is no evidence that the department paid for the construction of houses of the president," the committee found. The committee condemned the launching of "parallel" investigations, saying unnecessary costs were incurred as the department had already launched internal investigations. The report is mostly dedicated to justifying and listing "compelling" crime factors - especially rape - for the Nkandla security upgrades. "Rape is reported as being particularly on the rise, among other crimes. This is but one of the factors that necessarily place an obligation on government to tighten security even more." It also raises fears of a political assassination because of "a volatile political situation" in Nkandla. In addition to the bullet-resistant guard houses and high-security fences with detection system and cameras, other security upgrades listed include an amphitheatre, "high security cattle culvert (kraals) and chicken roosting areas". Among its recommendations the report calls|for the powers of the Public Protector to be curtailed. "Institutions... should not be inappropriately motivated or influenced to launch into an investigation on a matter which has already been assigned to another entity."

TITLE: ANC is trying to silence me, says Malema of his corruption trial
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); NATIONALIZATION (76%); MONEY LAUNDERING (72%); TRUST ARRANGEMENTS (50%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: PRETORIA: Economic Freedom Fighters leader Julius Malema has accused the ANC of trying to silence him by bringing fabricated charges against him. "They accuse me of stealing because they are failing to match my thinking capacity," he told his supporters outside the Polokwane High Court yesterday after his corruption trial was postponed to next year. They thought arresting me would silence me... They are arresting me with the hope that nationalisation would die... They say we stole money in the Department of Roads and Works. I have never worked there." He described the ANC as the "apartheid ANC". He thanked those who came out to support him at court. "Comrades who came from all different areas to give me support, I salute you." The former ANC Youth League leader appeared in court after it was alleged that he made nearly R4 million from corrupt activities. He is on bail of R10 000 and faces charges of fraud, corruption, money-laundering, and racketeering. Malema's co-accused are his business associates Kagisho Dichabe, Lesiba Gwangwa, Helen Moreroa, and Makgetsi Manthata. They are on bail of R40 000 each. The State alleges Malema and the others misrepresented themselves to the Limpopo Roads and Transport Department, leading to a R52m contract being awarded to On-Point Engineering. According to court papers, Malema had business ties with Gwangwa, a director of On-Point Engineering. Malema's Ratanang Family Trust was an indirect shareholder in On-Point. The department paid the company R43m. According to the charge sheet, Malema substantially benefited from this payment, using it to buy a farm and a Mercedes-Benz. His trial has been set down from September 30 to October 31 next year. Malema, however, will make representations to a judge next Thursday and Friday in a bid to get the charges dropped. - Sapa and Own Correspondent

TITLE: Malawi's Banda puts fighting corruption ahead of elections
COUNTRY: MALAWI (97%); AFRICA (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (91%); SUDAN (79%); KUWAIT (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); EMERGING MARKETS (77%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (77%); INFLATION (77%); ECONOMIC NEWS (77%); BUDGETS (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); POPULATION SIZE (76%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); ECONOMIC STIMULUS (72%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (72%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (72%); FORENSICS (70%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (67%); TOBACCO FARMING (63%) Business
TEXT: Malawi's President Joyce Banda would push ahead with rooting out corruption even if it spoilt her chances of returning to office after elections in May next year, she said this week. Foreign donors, including the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the British government, have suspended aid that finances about 40 percent of the nation's budget after reports of rampant corruption and abuse of public funds. The scandal, dubbed "Cashgate" by local papers, led Banda to dissolve her cabinet on October 10 and appoint international investigators to probe the allegations. "This is my fight, this is our fight as a nation, as Malawians," Banda said in an interview in Kuwait after attending an Arab-Africa summit. "We intend to implement it with or without donors because it's our nation, our people that suffer as a result. This is a cancer." The scandal and suspension of aid threaten to derail an economic revival that has been under way since last year when Banda succeeded Bingu wa Mutharika, who died in office last April. The IMF said it had delayed the disbursement of $20 million (R203m) to Malawi "until the fiscal situation could be clarified and necessary corrective measures put in place." Economic growth would probably be curtailed to 5 percent this year from an earlier forecast of 5.8 percent, while inflation was projected to average 28.5 percent, she said. In May next year, Banda and her People's Party will contest presidential, parliamentary and local government elections against Peter Mutharika's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, the United Democratic Front and the Malawi Congress Party. "I have been told by my colleagues that I'm out of my mind to be tackling corruption six months before elections," she said. "I told them I'm leaving it in their hands. If I don't go back to State House because I was trying to do this, that's fine. I've placed this before my political career." Banda said about 30 percent of the nation's resources were being stolen through corruption. The Cashgate scandal had led authorities to arrest 68 people, open 18 court cases, freeze 33 bank accounts and conduct a forensic audit, she said. "Whoever takes over must continue this fight. If we don't, Malawi shall remain where it is." Malawi is Africa's top exporter of burley tobacco, a low- grade variety of the crop. Limbe Leaf Tobacco, a unit of US-based Universal, Alliance One International and Japan Tobacco are among the buyers. About half the 15 million population live on less than $1 a day, the IMF says. Malawi's kwacha has slumped 18 percent against the dollar this year, making it the worst-performing African currency after the Sudanese pound. It fell 1.5 percent to 410 to the dollar in Lilongwe yesterday morning. - Bloomberg

TITLE: SA slips down corruption index zz Ranking falls to 72nd out of 177
COUNTRY: AFRICA (93%); RWANDA (79%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (79%); BOTSWANA (79%); SOMALIA (79%); SERBIA (73%); AFGHANISTAN (53%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (78%); EXECUTIVES (73%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (72%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (69%) Business
TEXT: South Africa continued its slide down the international rankings of perceived corruption but had managed to slow down the pace of its decline as the public were more vocal about corruption, Corruption Watch said yesterday. "SA's stable index scores can be attributed to the level of outrage expressed by the public in the form of service delivery protests and eagerness to report corruption to independent civil society-based organisations like Corruption Watch," the organisation said. "The perceptions are also indicative of a public that has become intolerant of the abuse of public resources and is losing trust in political, public and business leadership." The Corruption Perceptions Index compiled by Transparency International revealed yesterday that South Africa fell to joint 72nd out of 177 countries this year from 69th last year. A country's score indicates the perceived level of corruption in its public sector on a scale of zero to 100, where zero means the public sector is perceived as totally corrupt. The rank indicates a country's position relative to other countries surveyed for the index. South Africa scored 42 points in 2013, below the minimum acceptable score of 50 and down from 43 last year. The report said 90 percent of African states and two-thirds of all countries scored below 50, indicating a "serious, worldwide corruption problem". The index ranks countries by the public's perception of public sector corruption and is the most widely used indicator of official graft globally. It made use of data from reputable organisations such the African Development Bank and the World Bank through the use of 13 surveys to compile the report. South Africa was on a par with countries such as Brazil and Serbia, but scored lower than other African countries such as Botswana and Rwanda. Somalia, North Korea and Afghanistan were the nations perceived to be most corrupt, scoring 8 points. Corruption Watch executive director David Lewis said corruption had negative impacts on the country's international image and also on sentiment among citizens. "Over the last couple of years the levels of corruption have increased dramatically, but if you wanted to be optimistic you could say it's the first time the perception of corruption seems to be stabilising," he said. Lewis said the direct costs of corruption were the money lost to it, including impacts on investment. The indirect impacts were the decline in trust of leaders and a general acceptance of the situation as it is. "One of the biggest drivers of corruption is the poorly managed procurement system," he said. He said that apathy among citizens was a danger because "once people accept corruption then nothing can be done". South Africa is no stranger to corruption controversies in the public sector with scandals that have seen many public officials stand trial for crimes related to mismanagement and self-enrichment. Renovations to President Jacob Zuma's homestead in Nkandla to the tune of R208 million are also alleged to be marred by corruption leading the saga to be dubbed "Nkandlagate". Corruption charges against Zuma were dropped by the National Prosecuting Authority. In July Transparency International released the Global Corruption Barometer, revealing that 47 percent of South Africans had paid bribes over the past year against a global average of 27 percent. Last month the auditor-general's report for the year to March showed that there were "small improvements" in government spending patterns. Unauthorised expenditure totalled R30.8 billion, which was almost R3bn better than the previous year, auditor-general Terence Nombembe said.

TITLE: Dissent rocks Amcu's rank and file; zz Allegations of corruption and violence drive worker anger
SUBJECT: MINE WORKERS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PLATINUM GROUP METALS MINING (90%); MINES & MINING (90%); LABOR UNIONS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); LAYOFFS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); WAGES & SALARIES (72%) Business
TEXT: A STORM over the airwaves this weekend revealed that the Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union (Amcu) is losing its grip on power in the platinum sector. A call was made on Metro FM for the formation of a new labour movement by disgruntled Amcu members, who have accused the union's leadership of derailing the course of workers. Instead they were driving a union marred by corruption and violence, and a cozy relationship with employers. Thebe Maswabi, Amcu's chairman at Anglo American Platinum's Thembelani mine, speaking on the station, said workers were mobilising for a new union that would have their interests closer to heart. In reference to Amcu president Joseph Mathunjwa, he said: "Why are we paying Mathunjwa a salary? He is using the workers to enrich himself. He is not helping the workers; they are suffering. The workers need support and direction. They are tired and they need a leader who can speak for them and Mathunjwa is not doing his job properly." Amcu national organiser Dumisani Nkalitshana hastily convened a belligerent press briefing, at which he hit back at those making accusations against Mathunjwa. Nkalitshana blamed Maswabi and disgruntled union members from Lonmin and Impala Platinum for sabotaging the union. "People must understand that Amcu never promised anything but providing services to help members in instances of unfair labour practices, and so far we have delivered on our mandate." The call for a new union comes as Amcu, the biggest union in the platinum sector, squabbles for membership with the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM). Workers had become disillusioned with both the unions, analysts said. Amcu members behind the call for the formation of a new union were calling themselves a workers' committee and wanted more control and transparency in the union, Terry Bell, a labour commentator, said yesterday. The union was unlikely to have an impact on the labour movement in the mining sector because most of its members were retrenched workers who were bitter about their job losses. "There will be no immediate impact if a new union is formed. We are going to find a continued weakness in the NUM, and a further weakening of Amcu. This will only benefit the National Union of Metalworkers of SA [Numsa]," Bell added. In Rustenburg and Carletonville, disgruntled Amcu members have alleged favouritism and corruption. Weizmann Hamilton, of the interim committee of the Workers and Socialist Party, said: "Amcu has turned what was a historical decision by mineworkers to abandon the NUM into a missed opportunity. Members are finding that the union is not what they were hoping that it would be." There was a strong possibility that mineworkers would join Numsa, which had broken ties with the ruling party.

TITLE: Madibeng 'corruption': DA vows to bring in the big guns
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (88%); WOUNDS & INJURIES (77%); SHOOTINGS (77%); GUNSHOT WOUNDS (74%) News
TEXT: MADIBENG: DA parliamentary leader Lindiwe Mazibuko has vowed to rope in Public Protector Thuli Madonsela to probe "rampant corruption" in the Madibeng municipality. Mazibuko made the pledge after she visited the families of the victims of the Mothutlung police killings at their homes, accompanied by her party's provincial leaders and the DA's caucus leader in the Madibeng municipality, Leon Basson. Osia Nkalane Rahube, Lerato Seema and Mike Tshele - killed last week during service delivery protests in the area - were buried at the weekend. Mazibuko also visited the wife of the fourth man to die, Enoch Seimela, who succumbed to his injuries on Sunday night. Seimela was in a coma for six days at the George Mukhari Hospital in Garankuwa. Mazibuko told the families their loved ones were killed by the police protecting corrupt ANC officials. The families were told that the ANC councillors were refusing to make public a report that former Minister of Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs Richard Baloyi had commissioned on Madibeng. The report had uncovered a series of corrupt acts, the DA in Madibeng said. Mazibuko said she would personally ask Madonsela to force the municipality to make the report public. Meanwhile, North West Premier Thandi Modise called for the Independent Police Investigative Directorate to expedite its investigation into the circumstances that led to the fatal shootings.

TITLE: Corruption led to artistic contempt
CITY: CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA (92%); JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH AFRICA (90%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ARTISTS & PERFORMERS (90%); PAINTING (90%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (90%); WRITERS (89%); EXHIBITIONS (89%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POLITICS (78%); VISUAL ARTISTS (78%); CELEBRITIES (78%); COMIC BOOK & GRAPHIC NOVEL PUBLISHING (77%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (77%); CENSORSHIP (76%); PUBLISHING (76%); BOOK PUBLISHING (76%); INDECENT EXPOSURE (75%); VANDALISM (75%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); DRAMA LITERATURE (72%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (69%); CEMETERIES (68%); POETRY (67%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (67%); ARRESTS (53%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: CONTROVERSIAL Cape Town satirical artist Brett Murray, who caused a political storm with his painting The Spear, says his disappointment with some in the government led him to express his contempt through his artworks. This week Murray, a former social activist during apart-heid, launched his self-titled retrospective which features photographs of his artwork through his 30-year career. Near the end of the book is the original artwork of The Spear - the painting of President Jacob Zuma with his genitals exposed which unleashed a political uproar. The painting was exhibited at Johannesburg's Goodman Gallery in May 2012. It prompted responses from political parties and scores of individuals who labelled it racist and a violation of Zuma's right to dignity. Zuma and the ruling party applied for an interdict to have The Spear portrait removed from the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg and two men were arrested for defacing the painting. At the beginning of the chapter "Hail to the Thief", Murray wrote that government corruption had led to the exhibition, which included The Spear, of the same name. Murray, whose iconic artwork and poster images were used widely by anti-apartheid organisations during the 1980s, said: "It was with equal measures of disappointment and anger that I have expressed my contempt for some in the new regime who are undermining the victories that have been achieved through their corruption and guile, and who are effectively desecrating the graves of our Struggle heroes. Their persistent venality exposes a callous disregard for the continued poverty of many South Africans." He defended his right to use satire to comment on the government. "Political correctness and self-censorship are not cornerstones of effective political satire. If they were it would not be called satire, rather 'Ironic Praise Singing'. "Parody is part of the satirist's arsenal and it is through this that I hope to expose the new pigs at the trough.." Murray wrote: "That some temporary custodians of our constitutional democracy saw fit to jackboot through a gallery space and call for the burning of an exhibition and suppress a newspaper editor's independence and by proxy attempt to censure the ideas of artists, playwrights, poets, film-makers, social commentators, stand-up comics and the like - and coming so soon after the apartheid regime's endeavours to do the same - was eye opening, reckless and ultimately chilling." Murray, at the launch of the book, thanked Zuma for his fame. "A few years ago I might have called (book publishers) Jacana and asked if they would be interested in publishing my coffee-table book. They would have asked: 'Brett who?' "So it's ironic that I have the current leaders of our democracy to thank for the leg-up they've given me," he was quoted as having said by The Times yesterday.

TITLE: Corruption rife in most of EU, survey finds
COUNTRY: EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (95%); EUROPE (94%); BELGIUM (92%); SPAIN (92%); ITALY (92%); GREECE (90%); DENMARK (90%); ROMANIA (79%); CZECH REPUBLIC (79%); FINLAND (79%); LITHUANIA (79%); NORDIC COUNTRIES (58%)
SUBJECT: EUROPEAN UNION (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); EUROPEAN UNION INSTITUTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (78%); POLITICS (76%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (72%); RULE OF LAW (72%) News
TEXT: BRUSSELS: Corruption is a problem for almost half the companies doing business in Europe, a survey by the European Commission has found, and an increasing number of EU citizens think it is getting worse. The report casts the EU, often portrayed as one of the globe's cleanest regions, in an unflattering light. Among businesses, the belief is widespread that the only way to succeed is through political connections. Experiences of corruption vary across the 28-country bloc. Almost all companies in Greece, Spain and Italy believe it is widespread, according to the report, the first by the commission. Corruption is considered rare in Denmark, Finland and Sweden. This mirrors the finding of Transparency International's corruption perception index. It named Greece as the worst performer in the EU, sharing 80th place with China. Denmark was seen as the least corrupt. "Corruption undermines citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and the rule of law, it hurts the European economy and deprives states of much-needed tax revenue," said Cecilia Malmstrom, EU Commissioner for Home Affairs. Construction companies, which often tender for government contracts, are the most affected. Almost eight in 10 of those asked complained about corruption. Forty-three percent of companies see corruption as a problem. The cost to the European economy is estimated by the commission to be e120 billion a year, almost the size of the Romanian economy. The report says belief that corruption is commonplace is also widespread among EU citizens. A growing number believe it has become worse in recent years. They think Greece, Italy, Lithuania, Spain and the Czech Republic are the most corrupt. Citizens also suspect that corruption is common in business. Eight in 10 believe close links between business and politics lead to corruption.

TITLE: Hundreds turn to Corruption Watch as official avenues fail
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (75%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (65%); LABOR DISPUTES & NEGOTIATIONS (52%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: MORE than 2 000 reports of alleged corruption were received last year - most of them from people employed in the public service, Corruption Watch reported yesterday. It said that since January 2012, it had received 5 485 reports of alleged corruption, with 2 262 of these cases reported last year. Corruption Watch said that its report last year profiled the extent of corruption based on information provided by the public and gained through a survey of people who contacted the organisation. "The number of cases representing actual corruption - understood as abuse of public power and resources for personal gain - increased from 38 percent in 2012 to 58 percent in 2013." The increase in the number of reports was not surprising, Corruption Watch executive director David Lewis said. "In our first year, in 2012, we had 3 223 reports, which mostly fell outside of our area of focus. The latest data indicates that people understand that Corruption Watch is here to amplify the public's voice on abuse of public resources instead of dealing with consumer or labour disputes." About 77 percent of people who came to Corruption Watch did so because they did not know of any other body to report to. "Close to 53 percent had presented their cases to organisations such as national and provincial government departments and, most commonly, the public protector or police, but did not receive the assistance expected." - Staff Writer

TITLE: Corruption Watch finds bigger proportion of cases relate to abuse
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (91%); ANNUAL REPORTS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FINANCIAL RESULTS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); TRENDS (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (77%); TEACHING MATERIALS & MEDIA (77%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (75%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (74%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (74%); POLLS & SURVEYS (73%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (72%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (63%); MAINTENANCE & REPAIR (60%) Business
TEXT: The proportion of cases representing actual corruption reported to Corruption Watch increased from 38 percent of all cases reported in 2012 to 58 percent last year, the organisation says in its annual report published yesterday. Corruption Watch defines actual corruption as abuse of public power and resources for personal gain. In a survey last year, Corruption Watch found that more than 90 percent of those who reported corruption to the organisation were African, 81 percent were between the ages of 30 and 59, and 74 percent were men. The average person who files a report is self-employed or employed in the public sector and lives in Gauteng. They have completed secondary schooling at least, and are likely to have obtained a tertiary qualification. The group said: "Because our corruption fighters like to get their information through radio, television and internet, it is probable that they heard about Corruption Watch from those sources." Corruption Watch is a non-profit organisation that was launched in 2012. It relies on the public to report corruption to it and uses the reports as an important source to fight corruption. It investigates selected reports of alleged acts of corruption and hands over its findings to the authorities to take further action. The annual report says the reporting trends from 2012 and last year by province have slightly shifted, with Gauteng topping the charts at 38 percent, down from 46 percent in 2012. KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape followed closely at 13 percent, up from 10 percent and 8 percent, respectively. The Free State was the province with the most significant increase, from 7 percent in 2012 to 14 percent last year. In 2012, South Africa was ranked 69th out of íÁ countries on Transparency International's Corruption Perception Index, which measures perceived levels of public sector corruption in a number of countries. Last year, South Africa slid down to 72nd out of the 177 countries. Corruption Watch said of this: "This may not be a massive fall but it is an indicator of a steady decline and South Africa's tarnished reputation for corrupt behaviour." The organisation says the landscape of corruption in the government shifted significantly last year. Reports of corruption in local and national government make this an area of concern for Corruption Watch. It says since its inception in 2012, 661, or 12 percent, of the reports it received related to allegations of corruption in schools. Reports indicated that principals, school governing body members and to an extent teachers, were manipulating and abusing the school system and processes to enrich themselves. Concerns reported ranged from abuse of public funds received for infrastructure maintenance and upgrading to sourcing of learning materials, funding of feeding schemes and more.

TITLE: Graft at schools is rife - Corruption Watch
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (89%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (89%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (87%); ANNUAL REPORTS (78%); PRIVATE SCHOOLS (78%); EDUCATION ADMINISTRATION (78%); TEACHING MATERIALS & MEDIA (78%); FAMILY (75%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (68%); MAINTENANCE & REPAIR (65%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (65%) CapeTimes.News
TEXT: ALMOST four in 10 cases reported to Corruption Watch last year involved schools, with most of them involving financial mismanagement. "Worryingly, this year we uncovered mass evidence of corruption in schools and as a result, the melodious school bell has become a bellowing siren," said the civil society organisation in its annual report which was released |yesterday. The organisation, which "gathers, analyses and shares information on corruption in South Africa", received 2 262 reports of corruption last year. It defines corruption as "the abuse of public resources to enrich or give unfair advantage to individuals, their family or their friends". The top four sectors which featured in corruption reports last year were schools (38 percent), traffic and licensing (10 percent), health care (3 percent) and water (2 percent). "Since our inception in 2012, 661 (12 percent) of the total number of reports received by Corruption Watch related to allegations of corruption in schools. A substantial 554 (84 percent) of these reports were categorised as corruption as per our definition. "Reports indicated that principals, school governing body members and to an extent, teachers, were manipulating and abusing the school system and processes to enrich themselves. Concerns reported ranged from abuse of public funds received for infrastructure maintenance and upgrading to sourcing of learning materials, funding of feeding schemes and more." Most cases of corruption at schools emanated from the Eastern Cape (20 percent), Gauteng (19 percent) and Free State (18 percent). The top types of corruption at schools were: l Financial mismanagement (44 percent); l Theft of goods and funds (24 percent); l Corruption in procurement processes (16 percent). The organisation conducted a survey via online messaging service Mxit and sampled 3 284 respondents. "More than half of this sample, between 13 and 34 years of age, believed that corruption in schools is on the rise. Almost half of the respondents were learners at school or at an FET college, while 31 percent were family members of a school learner. Most learners (30 percent) were from public schools and just 8 percent were from private schools." It also found the selling of test and exam papers occurred in Mpumalanga (23 percent), while the misuse of school money or property was a problem in the Free State (30 percent) and North West |(31 percent). The school principal was singled out as being behind corruption in 47 percent of cases followed by teachers in 31 percent of cases. Corruption Watch noted that those who reported corruption were concerned their comments were falling on deaf ears. "A lack of action by a government is seen as a sign of a further corrupt relationship between officials and principals, or a lack of concern by the department." The majority of corruption allegations came from Gauteng (38 percent), followed by Free State (14 percent), and Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal (13 percent). Most cases involved provincial government, followed by local and national government. michelle.jones@inl.co.za

TITLE: Concourt challenge delays R144m corruption case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); POLITICS (77%); LAWYERS (74%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (73%); CRIME PREVENTION (73%); ASSET FORFEITURE (73%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (73%); HOLDING COMPANIES (72%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (71%); TRANSCRIPTS (63%); TEXT MESSAGING (50%) News
TEXT: DURBAN: First arrested in 2010, the remaining accused in the R144 million "Amigos" provincial government racketeering, corruption and fraud trial are in for the long haul, with their case now adjourned until January next year. The delay is partly because the Constitutional Court has yet to rule on a challenge brought by the main accused in the matter, Cape Town-based billionaire Gaston Savoi, against the constitutionality of the Prevention of Organised Crime Act and, specifically, its racketeering provisions. Savoi argued that these were vague and open to "personal and political manipulation" and used as an example the withdrawal of charges against his co-accused ANC politicians, Mike Mabuyakhulu and Peggy Nkonyeni. The court heard argument in November and reserved judgment. It is believed that Savoi has also launched a separate application for a permanent stay of prosecution, and this may also need to be decided before January next year. As at the last brief appearance in the Durban High Court in July, Savoi and his business associate in his company, Intaka Holdings, Fernando Praderi, were absent, by arrangement with the prosecution. Savoi, Praderi and Intaka are standing trial with 11 others, including former provincial treasurer Sipho Shabalala, his wife Beatrice, former health heads Busisiwe Nyembezi and Ronald Green-Thompson, former health officials Victor Ntshangase and Alson Buthelezi, advocate Sandile Kuboni and his former law firm, Kuboni Shezi. Savoi is accused of paying sweeteners to officials to score contracts for the supply of water purification and oxygen plants to the departments of health and local government. In documents in support of an asset forfeiture application, the State put up transcripts of text messages in which some of the accused referred to each other as "Amigo".

TITLE: Kenyan central bank governor opposes corruption charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ECONOMIC POLICY (91%); ECONOMIC NEWS (91%); BANKING & FINANCE (90%); CENTRAL BANKS (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); EMERGING MARKETS (79%); MONETARY POLICY (78%); INFLATION (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (76%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (74%); ARRESTS (73%); APPOINTMENTS (72%); INFORMATION SECURITY & PRIVACY (71%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (71%); COMPUTER SOFTWARE (71%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (66%); GOVERNORS (58%) Business.News.International
TEXT: Kenya's central bank would maintain monetary policy continuity in the "likely" event that governor Njuguna Ndung'u was suspended over corruption allegations, Eurasia Group said yesterday. On Tuesday Kenya's public prosecutor recommended that Ndung'u be prosecuted after the country's anti-corruption commission said he should be charged in connection with a tender for security software that resulted in a loss of 400 million shillings (R50m) of public funds. Ndung'u said on Wednesday that he did not approve nor award the tender. "Ndung'u is more likely than not to be suspended, despite his move to stay corruption proceedings in court," Clare Allenson, an associate at the US-based Eurasia research group, said. His deputy, Haron Sirima, would take over while the case was completed and "would provide policy continuity", she said. Ndung'u, 54, is scheduled to step down from his second term as governor next year, having been appointed by former President Mwai Kibaki in 2007. His policies helped reduce inflation in east Africa's biggest economy to 5.7 percent last year, compared with 9.6 percent in 2012, while economic growth has averaged 4.7 percent over the past five years, Bloomberg and International Monetary Fund data show. Four of the last six governors of Kenya's central bank had stepped down prior to completing their terms, Allenson said. A Kenyan court would hear Ndung'u's application today to halt his arrest, the Nairobi-based Daily Nation newspaper reported yesterday, citing Justice Mumbi Ngugi. - Bloomberg

TITLE: Nigeria suspends anti-corruption Central Bank governor
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CENTRAL BANKS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); ECONOMIC NEWS (89%); INFLATION (78%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (77%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (76%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (73%); APPOINTMENTS (73%); BOND MARKETS (72%); CRUDE OIL & NATURAL GAS EXTRACTION (71%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (71%); POPULATION SIZE (70%); GOVERNORS (58%) News
TEXT: LAGOS: Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan suspended Central Bank governor Lamido Sanusi yesterday, removing an increasingly outspoken critic of the government's record on tackling rampant corruption. Several dealers said Nigeria's foreign exchange, bond and money markets had stopped trading because of the uncertainty and volatility created by the suspension. Sanusi, who was due to end his term in June, had been presenting evidence to parliament that he said showed the state oil company, Nigeria National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), had failed to remit $20 billion (R220bn) that it owed to federal government coffers. NNPC has repeatedly denied Sanusi's allegations. Deputy governor Sarah Alade was appointed acting governor, the presidential spokesman, Reuben Abati, said. "Lamido Sanusi's tenure has been characterised by various acts of financial recklessness... inconsistent with the administration's vision of a Central Bank propelled by the core values of focused economic management," Abati said, without providing details of the acts. Sanusi told CNBCA that he was proud of what he had done, and he hoped the economy would not be hurt by his suspension. Asked whether it was politically motivated, he said: "It's not for me to comment. I think the answer to that is obvious." Analysts predicted that foreign investors would now be active sellers of assets in Nigeria's economy, just when it was attracting more interest than ever for the huge potential of its 170 million population and a backlog of work needed to update its inadequate infrastructure. "The suspension will come as a significant shock to foreign portfolio investors, whose willingness to invest in Nigeria was very much influenced by the transparency and anti-inflation credibility associated with Sanusi's policies,"|said Razia Khan, head of Africa research at Standard Chartered. If Jonathan wants to remove Sanusi entirely, he needs the consent of a simple majority of the Senate. The Senate could also vote to reverse the suspension, though that looks unlikely, since the ruling party has a comfortable majority in the Senate, and Sanusi was also a vocal critic of wasteful spending in the National Assembly.

TITLE: Corruption, inequality and climate top issues in global poll
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLLS & SURVEYS (89%); CHILD TRAFFICKING (89%); GENETICALLY MODIFIED FOOD (89%); BIODIVERSITY (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); ENDANGERED SPECIES (77%); GENETICALLY MODIFIED CROPS (77%); PLANT CONSERVATION (76%); SLAVERY (76%); WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (76%); HUMAN TRAFFICKING (76%); WOMEN (73%); GENETIC ENGINEERING (71%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (71%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (67%); SEX TRAFFICKING (66%); FEMINISM & WOMEN'S RIGHTS (63%); ECONOMIC NEWS (52%); SYRIAN CRISIS (50%) News
TEXT: Fighting political corruption, economic injustice and catastrophic climate change are the issues that matter most to people worldwide in the largest global poll ever carried out, it has |been revealed. About 116 000 people in 194 countries responded to the online survey by Avaaz, the social-activist network, also calling for action to tackle slavery, genetically modified food and the protection of endangered species. At a time when participation in traditional politics and membership of parties is declining, support for petition-organising groups such as Avaaz has soared in the past two years. Last year, membership of Avaaz was 17 million worldwide; it has now nearly doubled to 33 million. Campaign director Meredith Alexander said the network was "taking the world's pulse". For the survey, members were asked to pick their top three priorities for this year. The latest figures show that people care most about "fighting political corruption, including corporate capture of our governments", a priority backed by 49 percent. Some 38 percent chose having an "economic policy that benefits the common good over the elite few", while 37 percent wanted action on "preventing catastrophic climate change". The next priorities were "tackling slavery and human trafficking", backed by 36 percent, "safeguarding our health and food, including from GMOs", by 27 percent of people, and "protecting endangered species, including biodiversity", also backed by 27 percent. Perhaps surprisingly, "ending the war in Syria" was a priority for only 15 percent of people - perhaps because citizens view this as an issue that can be dealt with by governments and international organisations - while 21 percent backed "defending women's rights". Of the top specific campaign ideas where people wanted to see action, 40 percent wanted "education for all - get the international funding needed to put every child in school"; 33 percent wanted "end the rape trade - offer rewards for info leading to arrest of corrupt officials who help sex trafficking"; and 33 percent backed a campaign to "challenge Monsanto - create a seed bank to offer farmers an alternative to GMO seeds". Some 32 percent supported the "100 percent clean - push |UN climate summit to commit |to a goal of 100 percent clean energy". A global survey by Avaaz last year also put fighting corruption at the top of the list.

TITLE: Savoi loses his case with Constitutional Court and will face corruption charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CRIMINAL LAW (90%); APPEALS (89%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); EVIDENCE (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (78%); JUDGES (78%); NEGLIGENCE (78%); ORGANIZED CRIME (78%); LEGISLATION (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); POLITICS (73%); CRIME PREVENTION (72%) TheStar.News
TEXT: DURBAN: He won a battle, but yesterday he lost the war. That is the upshot of the outcome of court challenges made by Cape Town-based businessman Gaston Savoi in his bid to have racketeering and corruption charges against him quashed on the grounds that organised-crime legislation in South Africa was unconstitutional. Savoi is one of the accused in the so-called Amigos case. He is facing trial in the Durban High Court along with several former KwaZulu-Natal provincial government officials on charges relating to alleged R144 million tender corruption and fraud in the departments of health and local government. Savoi, in his challenge to the racketeering provisions contained in the Prevention of Organised Crime Act, argued that these were vague and open to "personal and political manipulation". He used as an example the withdrawal of charges against his co-accused, ANC politicians Mike Mabuyakhulu and Peggy Nkonyeni. He obtained partial success in the Pietermaritzburg High Court, where Judge Isaac Madondo said the words in the act, that an accused "ought reasonably to have known", were a stretch too far to pass constitutional muster. But yesterday, the Constitutional Court unanimously rejected this and, in effect, gave South Africa's severe anti-organised crime laws a clean bill of health. In a judgment penned by Justice Mbuyiseli Madlanga, the court found that the definition of "pattern of racketeering activity" was quite clear. While laws must be written in clear and accessible terms, this did not require perfect lucidity. The acceptable standard was no higher than reasonable certainty. The court also ruled that "overbreadth" was not grounds on its own for challenging the constitutional validity of a statute. And the phrase, "ought to reasonably have known", said the court, captured the idea of negligence, and there was nothing constitutionally objectionable about it. The criminal case will be back in court in January next year, when a trial date is expected to be set. It is believed Savoi might apply for a permanent stay of prosecution before then.
