It is the abuse of the single sourcing process which is used by those in charge of the procuring of goods and services to corruptly raise funds for themselves or even raise "contributions" to fund political parties. This may be done by asking the chosen and preferred supplier of goods or services to quote for the services to be provided then add a markup which is later given in cash to those who facilitated the contract award, that way it is difficult to trace these corrupt dealings. And yet no stake holder has openly acknowledged the reality of this practice. Appointment of consultants is sometimes based on technical and financial proposals where a decision is made depending on the financial bottom line. It is then possible, with a little help from a cooperating adjudicator, to submit an unrealistically low financial proposal to provide justification for the award of the contract with no intention at all of sticking to the submitted figures knowing very well that over claims will be made during the process of the project either directly or indirectly through connivance with the contractor/client project representative either through persuasion or appointment made through similar manner. An examination at the end of such executed projects would reveal that the so called lowest bid at tender evaluation stage has ended up with a tender sum much higher than the highest received tender sum at tender evaluation stage. This method of siphoning money out of a construction project may be applied at both consultancy stage and at project execution stage involving either the consultant or the contractor even the client or client's representative may have an active role to play in facilitating this process, all of course at a fee. Turning a blind eye to either defective work or nonobservance of specifications and contract clauses can lead to very significant "cost savings" which savings do not accrue to the client but becomes additional profit to the contractor most likely to be shared with the consultant who has suddenly developed technical blindness for a fee. The simplest example is where a contract agreement has included a clause on liquidated and ascertained damages to apply where a contractor delays completion of the project within the agreed contract period and instead of invoking this particular clause the consultant decides to turn a blind eye either by cooking up seemingly valid reasons to justify the extension of the building period or ignores to refer to the clause altogether. And yet consultants and contractors are not openly condemning this practice. A construction project would describe in advance the total scope of works to be executed for the stated tender amount. A possible loop hole is to adjust downwards the initial scope of works without similarly adjusting the tender sum for instance a road construction project may involve construction of the actual road, construction of a pedestrian/cyclist path and construction of, say, stone pitched storm drains. After commencement of construction it may be decided either officially or by deliberate omission to exclude works related to the pedestrian/cyclist path, for instance, but without making a similar adjustment in the tender sum meaning making a payment to the contractor including works he has not executed. This over payment may also come in the form of Contingencies; this is where an amount of money is allowed at tender stage to cover possible unforeseen works emerging during the construction period where if no unforeseen works emerge the amount allowed for contingencies must not be paid to the contractor since he has not executed any works under this item. And yet this practice may have happened on a number of projects and no condemnation has been made from consultants. There are a number of building contract agreements being used on various construction projects some of which have not been tested in courts of law and contain various grey areas even though there are court tested building contracts available on the Zambian building market. There are various clauses that address the issue of how payments for executed works would be made during the construction period and it is important to understand the implications of each of these payment clauses to appreciate potential loopholes that may be available as possible avenues for corrupt practices meant to unfairly relieve the client of his project funds. Most projects proceed to construction stage on the basis of construction tender documents including bills of quantities which comprise a full description of the scope of works to be executed for which a contractor submits the accepted tender sum and parties agree in advance on how this money will be paid as works progress. One method of making progressive payments to the contractor is by evaluating the quantity of builder's works satisfactorily executed based on the agreed pre-contract building rates minus any agreed deductions such as retention funds or advance payments made at the commencement of the project. There is a recent tendency to draw up contract agreements that stipulate payments to be made based on a per centum basis even though tender documents include priced bills of quantities. Such payment clauses may include terms like "twenty-five per centum of the contract price shall be paid to the contractor upon completion of half of the project" On the face of it this is a seemingly clear clause but it is, in actual fact, a potential area of abuse because while it is very easy to calculate twenty-five per centum of the contract sum assessing what comprises half of the scope of works may not be that easy. It is this grey area where a contractor may be paid, by connivance, more money than is actually due to him. In short there are potential areas of corruption in the construction industry which have been taken advantage of over the years. Just as the Acting Chief Justice has done as far as the judicial system is concerned, it is equally important that key players in the construction industry must accept, to start with, that there is rampant corruption in the construction industry which is depriving the nation of the much needed resources. Secondly stakeholders must make public measures they plan to take to curb the scourge; meaning the Road Development Agency, The National Council for Construction, the Zambia Institute of Architects, Consulting Engineers of Zambia, Quantity Surveyors of Zambia, Procurement Agencies and Association of Building Contractors in Zambia must accept that corruption is a reality in the construction industry and also outline corrective measures they will individually and collectively take. The Anti Corruption Commission should not adopt a position of waiting in offices for whistle blowers to submit cases of suspected corruption but rather be proactive and engage all stake holders to sensitize them on dangers of allowing corruption to take root in the industry and persuade the councils of these bodies to follow up and conclude cases of corruption or unprofessional conduct reported to them because a number of such cases have been frustrated by the same people entrusted with the responsibility of enforcing professional conduct. It is economically profitable for the nation to prevent corruption rather than prosecute offenders after resources have been squandered.

TITLE: CCPC Director Nabbed for Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ARRESTS (90%); CONSUMER PROTECTION (88%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (88%); CONSUMER LAW (86%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (86%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has arrested Competition and Consumer Protection Commission (CCPC) director of legal and corporate services Maureen Mwanza, for corrupt practices involving K50, 000. Ms Mwanza 37, of house number 21 Ngulube Road, Prospect Hill, Lusaka, is charged with one count of conflict of interest contrary to the Anti-Corruption Act number 38 of 2010. ACC corporate affairs officer Jonathan Siame confirmed the arrest of Ms Mwanza in a statement yesterday. Between October 1, 2010 and November 30, 2010, Ms Mwanza did not declare interest in the processing of a loan facility worth K 50,000 to Beta Brothers Enterprises Limited, a company in which her husband, Ben Mwanza is director and shareholder.

TITLE: Women Must Join Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); BRIBERY (78%); POLITICS (71%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (71%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (67%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (67%) Zambia; Women and Gender; Corruption
TEXT: AS women toast their day today, it would be pleasing if they used their powerful voice to highlight corrupt practices that appear to be an everyday phenomenon at the grassroots level. Corrupt behaviour is wrong, so everyone agrees, because the vice is often integrated in the essential aspects of the economic, social and political system. This is why corruption poses a danger to development as it threatens to sap the nation of economic resources. As a result all people desire to have it wiped off the face of society. When people talk of corruption in Zambia, like many other countries, eyes are often focused on the technocrats and, most importantly, political decision-makers. Corruption emanating from especially the latter - this powerful group of people - is called political corruption and mainly occurs when the laws and regulations are abused, side-stepped, ignored, or even tailored by those in high offices to fit their interests. This is where such things as Government contracts are illegitimately given to private individuals, usually not on merit but precisely because of the connections they have with those awarding them as they try to amass wealth for themselves. One of the end results, as often stated in the Auditor-General's report, is misallocation of resources. There is also what is commonly known as petty corruption, which is bribery in connection with the implementation of existing laws, rules and regulations. Technocrats and just ordinary citizens are mostly involved in this vice. Some people call this 'low level' or 'street level' corruption because modest sums of money are involved. Yet people experience it more or less daily. This form of corruption takes place in people's daily encounter with police at roadblocks, public administrators and service providers at such places as hospitals, schools, and local licensing or levying offices and other places. 'Low level' or 'street level' corruption, therefore, does not take place in posh offices, highways or central business districts of towns and cities. As Action for Transparency (A4T) says, this form of corruption is rife at the grassroots level, yet people who are victims of this vice do not bother to report it, perhaps because they feel it is a normal way of life. It is encouraging, therefore, to note that A4T is carrying out sensitisation activities in communities, beginning with Lusaka, educating people on the importance of reporting corrupt activities of the low-level nature and, surely, the project needs everyone's support, especially women movements whose voice is usually louder and clearer.

TITLE: Blow Whistle On Corruption - A4T
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (90%); INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%); MOBILE & CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS (71%); MOBILE APPLICATIONS (66%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (50%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: ACTION for Transparency Zambia (A4T) has appealed to communities to break the silence on corruption. A4T is a pioneering project that fights corruption and mismanagement of public funds by putting the power to monitor the vice in the hands of citizens through the use of latest technology. The project is funded by the Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA) and managed by Fojo Media Institute at Linnaeus University. A4T coordinator, Andrew Miti said many people, especially at the grassroots, were afraid to report suspected corruption because of fear. He said as part of the activities, the project was carrying out awareness activities in Lusaka communities, educating people on the importance of reporting corruption in their communities. The ground-breaking project is being implemented in the health and education sectors in Lusaka District only but may be rolled out to the rest of the sectors if successful. Mr Miti explained that people could now report suspected corruption in an efficient and anonymous manner by visiting the A4T official website at (www.actionfortransparency.org) or downloading for free the project mobile app. "By visiting the A4T website, people can know how much has been allocated or spent on their schools and clinics. Equipped with this knowledge, they can question or even report suspected mismanagement of public funds or corruption by using a mobile phone. "The report will then be published on our website, facebook or even on the Transparency International website. Prosecution authorities such as the ACC may even take action," Mr Miti said. The project is being implemented by the Zambia Institute of Mass Communication Educational Trust ZAMCOM in collaboration with the Anti-corruption Commission (ACC) and Transparency International Zambia (TIZ). The project has already conducted sensitisation activities in Linda, Mandevu and Kabanana townships, and more would follow in other townships, and the feedback from members of the public was overwhelming. Mr Miti said it had come to the attention of project officials during the awareness drives that many cases of corruption were going unreported in the communities because of fear. "This is why are equipping community members with knowledge on how to track resources allocated to clinics and schools within their communities," Mr Miti said.

TITLE: Dj Convicted for Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MAGISTRATES (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (78%); BRIBERY (77%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (76%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (73%); CITIES (70%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Livingstone Magistrate's Court has convicted a Disc Jockey (DJ) and journalist working for Zambezi FM radio station in Livingstone for engaging in corrupt practices. Danny Anakene, 39, of House Number DNB 111, Dambwa North in Livingstone was charged with one count of corrupt practice with a public officer contrary to the Laws of Zambia. Details are that between November 1, 2012 and December 31, 2012 in Livingstone, Anakene corruptly offered K4,000 to Vivian Chikoti, a town clerk then at the Livingstone City Council as an inducement for her to allocate him a piece of Land in Livingstone. When the matter came up for judgment in Livingstone yesterday, Livingstone Resident Magistrate Chinkashi Chilingala said he found the accused guilty as charged and convicted him accordingly. He said Anakene had been convicted because he acted in a corrupt manner when he offered K4,000 to a public officer, Ms Chikoti, for a plot he never applied for. Mr Chilingala said it was also overwhelming to note that the accused had not applied for a plot when he offered K4,000 and that there was no logic for the accused to seek acceptance of the money for a service that was not provided. "I am reluctant to accept the explanation by the accused person that part of the K4,000 was for the payment of the plot fee and a gift for the services which were never provided. "I am convinced that the K4,000 offer was meant to bribe Ms Chikoti and I have therefore, found the accused guilty as charged and convict him accordingly," Magistrate Chilingala said.

TITLE: Matemu Says EACC Fighting Corruption, Tells Media to Stop Speculation
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ETHICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (79%); HUMAN RESOURCES (72%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Ethics and Anti-Corruption chair Mumo Matemu said the suspension of the commission's Deputy CEO, Michael Mubea, is a "normal process" that is being handled by the EACC's management policies and human resource management. Matemu said that he is concerned with the media's speculation over Mubea's interdiction over corruption allegations. Mubea was suspended on Monday only to be reinstated the following day by the commission's CEO Halakhe Waqo causing confusion. Waqo said Matemu had not consulted with him before taking action. On Thursday, Mubea said that Matemu had no legal mandate to either suspend or fire him. "I have reported to work and, as you have seen, am from the field on official duty. The law is clear on who should sack me. The CEO has told me to resume my duties," Mubea said. In a statement released on Friday, Matemu added that contrary to media reports, the EACC is firmly focused on its mandate. "All matters that the Commission is seized of, including investigations, are proceeding normally without any interruptions," Matemu said. "We also wish to assure Kenyans that the Commission and the Secretariat are working together as one corporate body with a mandate to fight corruption in the body. For the avoidance of doubt therefore, this statement constitutes an update to Kenyans from the commission and supersedes all previous correspondences and communication," he added.

TITLE: The Monster of Corruption Must Be Weeded Out Right From the Grassroots
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); NATURAL DISASTERS (78%); BUDGETS (78%); SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); BRIBERY (72%); FAMILY (70%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (64%); INTERNATIONAL TOURISM (64%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (62%); RELIGION (53%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: orruption has a devastating effect on the nation's progress especially in public service. It costs government billions of shillings every year, through loss of revenue and revolving funds that could have been spent on delivering services. We are told that Kenya has lost an estimated Sh4 trillion to corruption since 2000. This is almost four times our current national budget and it is clear that this is money that can help us achieve the much needed development in the country. Where resources are scarce, corruption is a demonic vice threatening to tear apart our nation's economic fabric and must be exorcised from a multi-level approach through civic education, improved legal framework and strengthening of both public and private sector institutions. It seems grand corruption has become so entrenched in the Kenyan mindset that it should be declared a clear and present danger and a national disaster. No ethnic formation, interest group, religious order or geographical locale appears exempt. From Mombasa to Busia, Kisumu to Tana River, Mandera to Taita Taveta, Turkana to Kisii and all counties in between, there is a common narrative that is all-too-familiar. The press is awash with stories of government officials, constitutional office holders, former civil servants and the now infamous 'tender-preneurs' locked in a feeding frenzy to line personal pockets. It has become a national pastime to clean out the public purse through direct cash withdrawals, solicitations, unreceipted allowances, nepotism, inflating bills through a network of cronies and old school networks. Local and foreign courts are being treated to bizarre tales of brazen looting and high-level bribery, now termed euphemistically as "chicken sharing". Few and far between are such narratives as that of the late Nelson Mandela and recently, that of the 'world's poorest President Jose Mujica' retiring this week. Theirs was a humbling example to all humanity as they lived as an example to all of us who are already in leadership positions, or even those aspiring to ascend to public office. Their simplicity, respect for their subjects and family values will be sorely missed. That they were never caught with hand firmly in the public till speaks volumes about being servant leaders. Hereabouts, however, all election cycles mirror one another as all candidates pledge to fight for, and uphold national unity, promise hope and change. All political manifestos express and profess abhorrence to graft and preach a unifying agenda, all the while, vilifying the existing establishment. But once aboard the gravy train, all pretensions are cast to the four winds. No empty public space is left for its true purpose and grabbing has become endemic. Foreign trips have become the norm rather than the exception consuming taxpayer funds that would be better utilized in fighting widespread poverty, equipping hospitals with equipment and sorely-needed medicine, paying county staff, building and equipping schools, paying bursaries to needy pupils, developing roads, rail and energy infrastructure, as well as creating job opportunities to thousands of unemployed youths. Shamelessly, many public officials parade batteries of legal teams whenever various taskforce reports, peoples' watchdogs, Parliamentary committees, and annual Auditor General exposí©s expose them. Reports of billions of shillings stashed in foreign bank accounts have made us laughing stock every time we go around the world with begging bowl in hand. Not even students have been spared as we have seen incidents of exam cheating, most probably with the collusion of teachers and education sector officials. Even getting into public entities such as the police force and the military is highly ridden with corruption. These officers then spend most of their time trying to get back their money instead of serving Kenyans. The government has laid out strategies to curb this vicious and lethal practice through key constitutional bodies like Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission and the directorate of Criminal Investigations. However, there is also overriding need to develop sustainable Anti-Corruption Strategy that tries to deal with corruption in a holistic way including coming up with a toll-free anti-corruption hotline where incidents of corruption can be reported anonymously. We also need comprehensive financial audits with true reflections of the actual and strengthening investigating units to root out corruption in the pubic sector. There must be follow up and actionable mechanisms that can be used to deal with issues arising from these audits. Who will hold the moral high ground and shine the torch of shame on the dark recesses our public officers crawl through? Who among us will be the role models our gullible youth sorely need in their formative years? How punitive should our laws be in criminalising grand corruption? Even the voice of reason that should be religious leaders is tainted with leaders who preach water and gulp down the proverbial wine. Where did the rain start beating us, and where shall we find veritable public servants? It is a participatory national and collective course all Kenyans must spearhead for posterity. Corruption will continue to kill our economy if we continue to let it become a norm in Kenya, and all must work to ensure that it is eradicated. The writer is a political and communications consultant.

TITLE: We Love a Good Corruption Story [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); CHILDREN (89%); ETHICS (78%); EXTORTION (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POOR POPULATION (76%); FAMILY (76%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The Ababu Namwamba and Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) saga has captured our attention for the past two weeks. Sadly it will be forgotten in no time and those behind whatever scam and shame we are currently scandalised by will be feted, celebrated and will soon be chief guests and guests of honour, at numerous functions some of them even involving our children. Yes - we start telling our children corruption is good at a very early age. We talk about the "thieves in our living-rooms and our cars, assuming children are deaf and then in the same breath go ahead and invite said corrupt individual to officiate at a school function, a church gathering etc. We are Kenyans - we love a good corruption story, especially the ones (and we all know one) where the end of the story says "and he lived fabulously, comfortably, honourably ever-after with the proceeds of his corrupt deeds". Corruption in its current state in Kenya isn't just a way of life; it's something to aspire to. In case you missed this bold statement from Lukoye Atwoli a few weeks ago, let me give it to you once again: "We have created an environment where honest labour is punished, and thievery is rewarded. We may not like this reality, but it is the truth". Why am I even spending my time to pen this article? Because I must go on record now, so that in future should you try and call me out for not tearing into some corrupt so-and-so, I can turn around and ask your where is your stand on the issue. I'm writing this, because you and I have no intention of fighting corruption even as we ask the government to do so. I still don't get, how we don't get that government is you and I. Sawa tuu. Strangely though, we seem to be blind to the fact that corruption is a major threat facing us all. Corruption destroys lives and communities, and undermines countries and institutions. It generates popular anger that threatens to further destabilise societies and exacerbate violent conflicts. Corruption translates into human suffering, with poor families being extorted for bribes to see doctors or to get access to basic services. It derails the building of essential infrastructure, as corrupt leaders skim funds. Corruption amounts to a dirty tax, and the poor and most vulnerable are its primary victims. Corruption stinks and we don't care, in fact we love the smell of it. We like to see who will come out richer, bolder, and more brazen from their corrupt dealings. In fact we tend to find a new level of respect for people who are corrupt. We consider them daring, ballsy. Of course, many of us simply roll our eyes and say "hiyo si shida yangu". We think that corruption is a personal sin. Something the person accused needs to deal with himself. My fellow Kenyans - Corruption is a personal act that has social consequences. It is theft - fuelled by greed for wealth and power. It can lead to murder when the corrupt try to silence those who try to denounce them or in order to perpetuate themselves in power. Corruption is not only a personal act - a personal sin - it's a social sin. The minute we try to hold a corrupt individual to account, he or she instantly points fingers at everyone else, entangles as many people in this sin of theft, so much so that in the end the watching public walk away saying "si yeye peke yake. Why pick on him?" "Everybody is doing it. I might as well do it." This has become our justification. Corruption has become a way of life - something considered normal. How you noticed how the church doesn't comment on corruption anymore? It would be awkward. Knowingly or unknowingly, some members of the clergy and religious class have become beneficiaries through donations coming from those engaged in corruption. But this I know to be true - it is a grave matter, a big sin and the punishment is awful. The corrupt however are careful not to let you see how terribly they pay for their ill-gotten gains. I live in the hope that one day, in my lifetime, I will see someone go to jail and do time for corruption. It hasn't happened and it must happen. There must task us to write a new ending to the story of corruption. Currently, all our corruption stories end with the line: "and he lived, fabulously, comfortably, honourably, ever after". I want to see the day it ends with - "he served 20 years in jail for his corruption.'

TITLE: Three Kisumu MMCAs Claim Lives in Danger After Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: PETITIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); AUDITS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); INFORMATION SECURITY & PRIVACY (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); HEALTH CARE (73%); BUDGETS (73%); POLITICAL PARTIES (72%); FORENSICS (70%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (68%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Three Kisumu MCAs who signed a petition accusing Governor Jack Ranguma of graft have claimed that their lives are in danger. The leaders said they have received threats since the petition alleging corruption and mismanagement of county affairs was filed. They are Aggrey Ogosi (Seme East), Joseph Osano (Chemelil) and Elijah Omondi (Nyakach Central). The three declined to name colleagues who have allegedly been harassing them. They however told the Star on Monday that they will record statements with the police. Osano said they have been playing the oversight role since the Assembly "went to bed" with the Executive and stopped performing. The MCAs lined up 16 grounds of corruption and abuse of office, which they want authorities to investigate. They want the Auditor General to carry out a forensic audit of Kisumu's fiscal management. They also want the Commission on Revenue Allocation and the Controller of Budget to cease further disbursement of funds to Kisumu until the audit is completed. Their petition further claimed that the county's healthcare system has collapsed due to poor funding. Jaramogi Oginga Odinga Teaching and Referral Hospital was allocated Sh396 million in the 2013-14 financial year, but only received Sh72 million from the county treasury, they said. Majority leader Samuel Ongow however asked the assembly to discuss the conduct of the three MCAs, saying they used privileged information in the petition. Ongow demanded to know how the MCAs secured confidential information and other important documents in the sole custody of the clerk. He said the clerk should also be investigated, prompting Interim Speaker Samuel Ombogo to order the probe.

TITLE: Kenyans Abet Corruption, Says Uasin Gishu MCA
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BRIBERY (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Uasin Gishu county assembly majority leader Josphat Lowoi has urged Kenyans to join the fight against corruption. He said those who pay bribes are to blame for the high rate of graft. "We are the ones who give bribes when seeking employment in public institutions. We bribe public officers when seeking birth certificates and passports and other services. Until we do away with this, corruption will never end," Lowoi said. He was speaking at the assembly buildings on Monday in Eldoret town.

TITLE: EACC Could Be Disbanded Over Allegations of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); PETITIONS (90%); SETTLEMENT & COMPROMISE (89%); ALTERNATIVE DISPUTE RESOLUTION (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (74%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: THE life of the EACC hangs in the balance as the Ombudsman finalises investigations into corruption claims against commissioners. This comes amid claims from within the EACC itself of the pocketing of Kenya's single biggest bribe ever - a staggering Sh2.6 billion. The verdict from the Ombudsman, coupled with a petition sent to the National Assembly against the agency last week, could see top EACC officials prematurely sent home and even charged with corruption. Yesterday, the Chairman of the Commission on Administrative Justice (the Omudsman), Otiende Amolo, confirmed that investigations into the alleged sleaze are being finalised. "However, I will not comment on the substance of the allegations. Our investigators work independently of the commission," he told the Star. The complaint drafted last year and copied to key institutions, including the Director of Public Prosecutions office, alleges mega sleaze by top EACC officials and dubious out-of-court settlements for kickbacks. The petition, allegedly anonymously drafted by an EACC staffer, claims that Chairman Mumo Matemu is "asleep" and too worried by a suit challenging his suitability for the top job. "The managers and commissioners of the institution are no different from the robbers who raid graves to recover coffins for sale," the petition, dated May last year, reads in part. Part of the accusations against Mubea, who was recently suspended over "integrity issues", is the settling of an out of court agreement with Mombasa tycoon Rashid Sajjad after a protracted legal duel over landholdings. In March last year, Sajjad handed back 18 title deeds of public plots acquired irregularly, including recreational parks and a clinic. Ironically, inquiries by the Star indicate that the recent acrimonious falling out within the EACC stemmed from a decision to charge businessman Deepak Kamani for an Anglo Leasing-related offence when the secretariat had opened negotiations with the suspect to have an out-of-court settlement. EACC Spokesman Yassin Amaro confirmed that they received the petition and that the Amolo-led commission took over investigations. "We cannot investigate ourselves. That is why the matter was taken over by the Ombudsman and CID," he stated.

TITLE: The West Must Speak Up Against Corruption
COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); SWITZERLAND (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); AFRICA (79%); NORDIC COUNTRIES (78%); GERMANY (69%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); AGENCY RULEMAKING (90%); BRIBERY (89%); DIPLOMATIC SERVICES (78%); LEGISLATION (72%) Kenya; Corruption; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: Last week, three Western embassies based in Nairobi issued a joint statement on corruption in Kenya. In it, the governments of the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Switzerland welcomed efforts by the Director of Public Prosecutions to order prosecutions linked to the Anglo Leasing scandal. They noted that subsequent arrests of the suspects were important steps in the fight against corruption. Although couched in diplomatic language, the message in the statement was clear - it is time the Government of Kenya took a decisive action against corruption. As expected, cynics have made references to the statement as interference in Kenya's internal affairs, notwithstanding the fact that official corruption in this country is real. What the countries of the West are doing in calling for government action against corruption in this country is merely lending support to the homegrown anti-corruption crusade that has been fighting against the vice since the infamous Goldenberg scandal in the 1980s. This indigenous anti-graft crusade is again urging the government to act against the Anglo Leasing and the ChickenGate scandals. Coupled with bribery and corruption claims within our lawmaking body, the National Assembly, the situation has been aggravated. There is cause for alarm and the time for government action is now. Public support from Western governments on critical issues affecting Kenyans is not new. Morally and materially, these governments through their embassies in Nairobi supported the pro-democracy movement in the 1980s and early 1990s. The US, especially, as well as Germany, Britain and the Scandinavian countries were at the forefront in this support. Reports that some elements within the National Assembly may have been involved in bribery and corruption make the situation even worse. This is why the time for government action is now, if not yesterday. However, curbing corruption should not be left to indigenous crusaders alone. There are limitations to what individuals and civil society in this country can appeal for government action. First, Kenyan civil society, unlike in the 1980s and 1990s, has been rather timid in the fight against corruption, partly because of the uncertainty surrounding the future of a viable civil society in this country. The Jubilee government has not been friendly with civil society in the light of proposed legislation meant to curtail their activities. Secondly, ethnic support has been a hindrance against corruption. Individuals and entities suspected of corruption have sought and got the support from their communities in the Kenyan politics of watu wetu wanamalizwa (our people are being finished.) This is why just like the pro-democracy movement that was supported by external sources against a recalcitrant government, local anti-graft crusaders, without support from external sources, are unlikely on their own to win the war against corruption. This is also why public diplomacy is needed to speak directly to the Kenyan people. By applying people-to-people diplomacy, Western diplomats in Nairobi are telling Kenyans they support them in their aspirations to end official corruption. It is an issue the Kenyan government should know through government-to-government diplomatic channels. The evils of corruption are known. Corruption destabilises economies leading to, among other things, lack of service delivery and unemployment, especially among the youths. Corruption also destabilises the economies of friendly countries. Part of the reason Kenyans form long queues in Western embassies seeking travel documents is not just about student, business or tourist visas; many of these Kenyans are forced to seek employment opportunities abroad and corruption has been a contributory factor. The billions of shillings illegally acquired and stacked in foreign bank accounts could easily propel the local economy, boosting industry, production and creating employment opportunities for the thousands of Kenyans. For those Kenyans who have been unlucky to travel to the Middle East in search of job opportunities, their fate has been sealed - some of them have come back home in caskets. To be sure, corruption is not the preserve of Kenya. It is certainly a global phenomenon. It transcends borders. There is corruption even in those countries that have criticised us - U.S., Britain, Germany, Japan and in the Scandinavian. The difference is the way Kenya has dealt with the vice. In the U.S. and Britain, for example, corruption cases are swiftly and promptly dealt with, irrespective of class or social ranks of the people or entities involved. Recent examples include the Enron scandal in the United States some few years back, and the ChickenGate scandal in the United Kingdom. In Kenya, only the weak face corruption charges; the strong survive. There has not been any notable conviction of the big fish in Kenya in all cases involving corruption. This is what separates Kenya from the West and other friendly countries on matters dealing with corruption. On the Anglo Leasing scandal, the government of Switzerland has shown it is ready and willing to assist Kenya with evidence to prosecute. The ball is now in the hands of Kenyan authorities to act. The result so far has been chaos as evidenced in the split within the anti-corruption body. If the Western donor countries are serious about supporting Kenyans in the fight to end corruption, they must use the carrot and the stick -- just as these countries did when they supported the prop-democracy movement. For example, if push comes to shove, they can deny visas to corruption suspects from visiting their countries either for official or private business until they are cleared by the local courts. Britain did exactly that in the case of former Cabinet Minister Murungaru. It can be done again. On the other hand, the West should consider providing moral and material support to individuals and groups that have contributed to the anti-graft campaign. With this support, civil society groups, including the church and other faith-based organisations, can organise civic education programmes and seminars to sensitise Kenyans on the evils wrought by corruption in the society and the economy. And talking about external support against official corruption -- where are the Chinese? We miss their official anti-corruption stand too.

TITLE: Senegal Jails Ex-President's Son for Six Years for Corruption
COUNTRY: SENEGAL (99%); VIRGIN ISLANDS, BRITISH (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: JAIL SENTENCING (90%); PRISONS (90%); SENTENCING (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); VERDICTS (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (89%); CORRECTIONS (89%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (89%); LAWYERS (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (78%); POLITICS (78%); CRIMINAL FINES (78%); LITIGATION (78%); BOYCOTTS (73%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLICE FORCES (73%); REFERENDUMS (72%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (72%); APPROVALS (69%) Senegal; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A special court in Senegal sentenced the son of former president Abdoulaye Wade on Monday to six years in prison for corruption and ordered him to pay a 138 billion CFA franc ($228 million, Sh21 bn) fine, dashing his hopes of competing in elections due in 2017. Karim Wade, in detention since April 2013, was chosen by the main opposition party, the Senegalese Democratic Party (SDP), as its presidential candidate on Saturday, raising the stakes ahead of the verdict. He denies any wrongdoing. "The crime of illicit enrichment being proven, Karim Wade: six years in prison and a fine of 138 billion CFA francs," judge Henri Gregoire Diop said in the ruling, adding that Wade had hidden away funds in offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands and Panama. Opposition supporters inside the courtroom protested loudly after the verdict. "I no longer want to be Senegalese," shouted one woman. "This verdict is shameful." Karim, 46, did not attend the final session of the trial and his father Abdoulaye Wade left without making any comment to the media. Karim and his lawyers have boycotted the end of the trial after accusing judge Diop of bias, something he strongly denies. The streets of Dakar were calm immediately after the trial amid a heavy police presence to counter possible protests. Karim, who staged a four-day hunger strike in January to protest over the conditions of his detention, has repeatedly said he is the victim of a political witch hunt, something the government strongly denies. The government has said the trial signals the end of impunity for corruption in Senegal, long regarded as a bulwark of democracy in a turbulent region. "This is a historic decision not only for Senegal but also for the whole of Africa and all those who defend responsibility, citizenship and good governance," said Simon Ndiaye, one of the state's lawyers. President Macky Sall, who ended Abdoulaye Wade's 12-year rule in a hotly contested election in 2012, said last week his government would not tolerate any attempt to destabilise the West African country following the court ruling. Prosecutors had demanded a seven-year prison term and a 250 million CFA franc ($413,784, Sh38 million) fine for Karim Wade, who was known as the 'minister for heaven and earth' during his father's government as he controlled several key ministries. The next presidential election could come as early as 2017 if Sall wins approval in a referendum due next year on reducing the presidential term to five years from seven.

TITLE: Raila Should Shut Up Over Corruption, Says DP Ruto
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); SCANDALS (90%); ETHICS (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); POLITICS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (73%); FUNDRAISING (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: DEPUTY President William Ruto has asked the opposition to "shut up" about corruption, saying Jubilee is sorting out scandals started when Cord leader Raila Odinga was in government. Ruto said the Anglo Leasing scandal, the setting up of key institutions, including the IEBC and the EACC, were started when Raila and his team were either in the Narc government or the grand coalition regime. Raila was a Minister in the Narc government and Prime Minister in the grand coalition headed by President Mwai Kibaki. "We are cleaning up their mess. They should shut up. They were there when Anglo Leasing started, they there were there when the IEBC and the Ethics commission of Mumo Matemu were set up," said Ruto. He said some of the worst corruption allegations were being made in the Public Accounts Committee team in Parliament headed by the opposition. "They should start searching their souls before they start pointing fingers at us. They should join us in fighting the corruption cancer in our country," he said. Ruto said Cord has no moral authority to lecture the government on corruption. He was speaking during a fundraising at AIC Missionary Church at Kapsoya, Eldoret. Ruto defended the government and said there would be no interference in the ongoing investigations into corruption and everyone must be ready to carry their own cross when caught engaging in graft. "There are no more telephone calls and no 'orders from above'. Everyone must be accountable for what they do," said Ruto. The DP said the constitution was clear and the President should not be blamed over graft cases. He said the government made its position on management of public resources and the constitution-mandated independent institutions to fight graft in the country clear. "We have deployed sufficient resources and support to all institutions of governance, including the office of the Auditor General and the EACC, so that they run independently," said Ruto. He said the executive was clear on ensuring that those who run government institutions must be held to account. "As public servants and as individuals they will be held to account on all decisions, including procurement and other matters involving public resources," said Ruto. Meanwhile, Ruto on Saturday told presidential hopefuls that the Presidency was not vacant, and cautioned them against premature campaigns. He told those eying the presidency in 2017 to hold their horses since he and President Uhuru Kenyatta are equal to the task and will proceed to retain both positions since they have the voters' goodwill. Ruto told Kalenjin leaders who were elected in the 2013 general election to concentrate their energies on developing their region and stop politicking at the expense of much-needed services to citizens. He said it is too early for a section of Kalenjin elected leaders to start declaring their presidential candidature as if there were a leadership vacuum in the ruling Jubilee Alliance Party. "President Uhuru and I are here to stay and, come the 2017 general election, will defend our positions and win with a margin that one would never thought of," Ruto said in Kapkatet Grounds, Kericho county. After Uhuru's final term of office in 2022, Ruto told the gathering, he will succeed him as the Fifth President of Kenya, through a popular vote across the country. "Jubilee sio serikali ya nusu mkate, mimi na Rais Uhuru tuko mamlakani kwa mapenzi ya Mwenyeenzi Mungu na walio tupigia kura (the Jubilee government is no half-loaf coalition government, President Uhuru and I are in power by the grace of God and were democratically elected by the majority of Kenyans)," Ruto declared.

TITLE: I Will Not Shut Up On Corruption, Raila Tells Ruto
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); SCANDALS (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); RELIGION (76%); ETHICS (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (68%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: CORD chief Raila Odinga has told off Deputy President William Ruto over corruption, saying his statements on graft disgust, anger and disappoint the people of Kenya. In a hard-hitting statement, the Opposition Leader said the Jubilee regime has been rocked by scandals and "virtually every dawn begins with a new revelation of a new scandal - conceived and executed by government, followed predictably by warnings. "I would urge the Deputy President to stop further platitudes and statements on corruption". Raila was responding to Ruto's criticism over the weekend that the government is sorting out scandals started when the Cord captain was Prime Minister. "We are cleaning up their mess. They should shut up. They were there when Anglo Leasing started, they there were there when the IEBC and the Ethics commission of Mumo Matemu were set up," Ruto had stated. But in his response, the former Prime Minister said that Kenya's global reputation on graft had drastically declined on Jubilee's watch, adding the regime has failed catastrophically in dealing with corruption. Raila said that only two years into the UhuRuto administration, Kenyans no longer believe the President and Deputy President. Raila maintained that the two were "only barking from a distance" without taking any decisive action on runaway theft. "As Archbishop Wabukala of the Anglican Church announced last week, corruption has become a national disaster. The Jubilee government has overseen the most precipitous decline in Kenya's reputation where corruption is concerned among its own people and the international community as well," he stated. Raila said that recent international corruption indices indicate that Kenya has overtaken countries long associated with the vice in Africa. "Worse still, the ever-increasing number and scale of scandals indicate a level of impunity that is unprecedented in our history," he said. Raila maintained that he will continue to speak out, warn the government and empathise with people of Kenya as he plays what he termed "my rightful role as leader of the Opposition".

TITLE: Uhuru Orders All State Officials Named in EACC Corruption Report to Step Aside
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); ETHICS (78%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (78%); SCANDALS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); COUNTIES (73%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (73%); CIVIL SERVICES (72%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs; International Organizations and Africa
TEXT: President Uhuru Kenyatta has ordered all state officials mentioned in an EACC corruption report to step aside for investigations. Uhuru noted that EACC's latest report, which he has received, contains a "catalogue of allegations of high-level corruption" against all arms and levels of government. "I hereby direct that all officials of the national and county governments that are adversely mentioned in this report, whether you are a cabinet secretary, principal secretary, or chief executive of a state institution, to immediately step aside pending conclusion of the investigations of the allegations against them," he said. "I expect the other arms of government, namely the Legislature and the Judiciary, to do the same." He issued the directive while giving the State of the Nation address in Parliament on Thursday. Uhuru further ordered the EACC to submit the case files to the DPP without delay, stating that the exercise should be concluded in the next 60 days. "I also want to caution that this should not be an open-ended process, justice must be expeditious, as justice delayed is justice denied," he said. Uhuru said that he has attached the confidential report from commission's CEO Mumo Matemu to his annual report on Values to Parliament. He said it is Matemu's view that the institution is under siege because of the nature of the cases it is investigating. Uhuru noted that investigations into the Anglo Leasing scandal have borne fruit. In-fighting and finger-pointing in the EACC are however likely to cripple investigations and overturn the course of justice, he said. "I strongly believe that this is a further attempt to subvert the successful prosecution of the Anglo Leasing cases," he said. "I have asked the Attorney General to liaise with the Council on Administration of Justice to focus on coordination within the justice, law and order sector. The Council must ensure the efficient and speedy processing of corruption-related cases, including hearing such cases on a daily basis." Uhuru said the allegations of corruption within the government have broken Kenyans' trust. He asked MPs to restore Parliament's dignity and integrity of Parliament. He underlined that civil servants under pressure to engage in unethical or illegal conduct should get in touch with his office.

TITLE: Ababu Bodyguard Says He Initiated Recording in PAC Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (88%); TALKS & MEETINGS (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: PAC chairman Ababu Namwamba's bodyguard has admitted initiating the recording of the infamous tape he submitted as evidence in a corruption probe. Corporal Bernard Odako said he gave Ababu his phone, with the recording function turned on, during a meeting with Cord leader Raila Odinga and two MPs. He made the revelation when he appeared before the Powers and Privileges Committee on Thursday after Ababu reported that he had initiated the recording. Odako had earlier denied knowledge of the recording saying he first heard it played on national broadcaster KBC. The tape played by Ababu when he appeared before the committee on March 12 allegedly proves that Defense PS Mutea Iringo bribed four PAC members to expunge his name from the committee's final report. Iringo denied the allegations saying they are "totally unfounded and should be dismissed with the contempt they deserve." The committee is carrying out a probe over a PAC report alleging that the office of the President misappropriated Sh2.9 billion.

TITLE: Uhuru to Address Corruption, Insecurity in State of the Nation Speech
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: President Uhuru Kenyatta's state of the nation address today is expected to touch on security and corruption. Uhuru will also address the petition on the dissolution of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. National Assembly majority leader Aden Duale said the areas are critical in the country's delivery of national values and principles of governance. "We expect the President to speak on corruption now that Parliament is on the spot on the same. Though the legislature is another arm of government, it is important for the head of state to express his concern on the matter," Duale said yesterday. "The President may petition Parliament to initiate a probe into the matter," he said. The Garissa town MP said Uhuru may propose the suspension of EACC officials to pave way for detailed investigations. The president's address is the third since Jubilee came to power. The National Assembly's Public Accounts, Agriculture, Lands and Transport committees are some of the groups grappling with graft allegations amongst its members.

TITLE: ODM Hits Out At Uhuru Over Corruption List Handed to Parliament
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); ETHICS (78%); EXECUTIVES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (77%); SCANDALS (73%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (71%); PETITIONS (71%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (70%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (70%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: ODM has accused President Uhuru Kenyatta of "whitewashing corruption" in his State of The Nation. "In the President's speech, we see the clearest confirmation of what we have always suspected; that the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission is a confused and compromised institution that can no longer be trusted to fight corruption. It is instead being used to fight and fix opponents and supposed enemies of the Jubilee regime," the statement from ODM's director of communication Philip Etale says. ODM has raised objection to the report by the EACC saying that the body secretly submitted a list of alleged corruption suspects to the President who then proceeded to forward the "limited copies available" only to the two speakers who are both from the Jubilee Coalition. "As law abiding leaders, we know that EACC is supposed to arraign suspects in court, not report them secretly to the President, a member of the Executive who should have nothing to do with the EACC in the stipulated separation of powers," the party said. ODM accused the EACC of working with Uhuru secretly. "The Presidency is itself a leading suspect in the massive corruption scandals muzzling the nation. Top political leaders and technocrats in the Presidency have been linked to acts of bribery and collusion to defraud the public of money, land, playgrounds, procurement indecencies, you name it. The IEBC remains intact and does not feature in the President's list, yet its partners in crime are in jail in London. So much is going on in the Ministry of Devolution particularly at the NYS and the Ministry of Health where tenders go to the best of friends and highest bidders, yet the president is playing favourites," ODM said. The party did not produce evidence of the alleged corruption NYS and Ministry of Health. ODM further hit out on Uhuru saying that he has not spoken about what it termed the increased tribalisation of the nation where appointments are based on tribe, not ability. The party also raised objection on whether the EACC can be trusted in the fight against corruption. "We are talking about the same EACC that is at war with itself, where juniors have demanded the sacking of their boss, the chairman Mumo Matemu. That demand was equally delivered to the wrong person, the President who should by law keep EACC affair and whom the EACC should demonstrably be independent of. A petition of that nature ought to have been taken to Parliament," the party added. ODM said that the commission's CEO did not involve the organizations leaders in putting together the list. Matemu has denied reports that Uhuru's list came from the commission. ODM further said that a number of governors and other public officers named in the list have never been contacted or interrogated by EACC.

TITLE: Ruto On Corruption - Heed President's Directive and Stop Tarnishing People's Names Without Proof
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); TEACHER EDUCATION (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (69%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Deputy President William Ruto has said the government will not relent on the war against corruption in the public service irrespective of the status of those involved in the graft. Noting that all public servants entrusted with public resources must be held to account for their use, Ruto asked them to exercise a high degree of integrity to ensure that the resources entrusted to them are used for the benefit of the people. Ruto warned that anyone found guilty will be removed from the public service forthwith. "I want to make it explicitly clear that public resources are meant for the betterment of the lives of the people. We shall not therefore condone any practices that undermine that effort, " he said. He was speaking at the 45th Graduation ceremony of Shanzu teachers training college in Mombasa on Friday. The DP said no public servant should compromise on the integrity of his office. He said the government was determined to open a new chapter in public administration in the country. Ruto at the same time said the same measures would apply to those making malicious utterances on other leaders without proof. "We want to open a new chapter of integrity that will take the country forward," he added. MPs Gonzi Rai(Kinango), Peter Shehe(Ganze), Ibrahim Sane (Garsen) and the Kwale women representative Zainab Chidzuga expressed similar sentiments saying they fully supported the President's directive that those involved in graft step aside to be investigated.

TITLE: Uhuru Told to Emulate Rwanda President on Corruption Fight
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ETHICS (73%) Kenya; Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: NOMINATED MP Oburu Oginga has asked President Uhuru Kenyatta to emulate Rwanda President Paul Kagame in the fight against corruption. Oburu said Kagame facilitated the prosecution of some of his close friends found guilty of corruption. The former Bondo MP said Kagame did not mince his words in the struggle to end corruption in Rwanda. He said Uhuru is only giving lip service. "If you see a fish's head is rotten, the rest of the body is also rotten," he said. He said Uhuru's inner government circle is engrossed in grand corruption deals. He said the corrupt executive is using Parliament to conceal their involvement in underhand deals. Cord leader Raila Odinga asked Uhuru to rein in his close friends within the government perpetuating corruption. Raila spoke on Saturday before leaving for an eight-day trip to China. He said Kenya is almost going to the "dogs" due to the high level of corruption that has left the public in despair. "We are in a crisis since corruption has gone the highest notch." Raila said Uhuru should walk the talk and crack the whip on individuals within his inner circles. He cited the government, Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission, the judiciary and Parliament as areas affected by graft. Raila was speaking at the funeral of Barack Odera Odinge in Siaya County.

TITLE: Kenyans Should Support Uhuru in His War Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (99%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); FAMILY (77%); SUICIDE (65%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: All Kenyans agree corruption is today an unmitigated disaster and a millstone round their necks that unless it is dealt a death blow, it will sink them to the bottom of the sea of collective demise. Since independence, serious war against corruption has never been declared. Instead, government leaders and families have used graft to get rich. The only convincing declaration of war against corruption was made yesterday by President Uhuru in his State of the Nation address to Parliament. "Today I draw the line. No one will stand between Kenyans and what is right with the fight against corruption and other monstrous economic crimes." Will President Uhuru keep his solemn promise to fight corruption or was his speech just another public relations stunt? I give him the benefit of doubt and support him. In fighting corruption, however, there are hurdles President Uhuru must overcome. To begin with, President Uhuru must spare no one that is found guilty of graft. In drawing the line between the clean and the corrupt, President Uhuru must realise that the most difficult friends and perpetrators of corruption might come from his personal friends, political allies and even members of his family. To take his war to those who are close but corrupt, President Uhuru will need to commit class and family suicide, unless of course, his family, friends and allies agree to support his war against graft. But before Uhuru takes the war against graft to his corrupt friends and allies, he must also be ready to open himself up for scrutiny by fair and just Kenyans - whether he is himself corrupt or beneficiary of direct or indirect, old or new corruption. While the best fighters against corruption will be the poor victims of corruption, who will have the will and the reason to fight corruption, some beneficiaries of corruption through inheritance, like Fidel Castro of Cuba, could renounce inherited benefits of corruption and fight it. When people in power intellectually and ideologically turn against corruption, they fight graft with an advantage of having not just the will and reason, but also power. One can only now hope that in fighting corruption, President Uhuru will have the courage to renounce any inherited benefits of old corruption he may enjoy. This will make him a stronger and more dependable crusader against graft. In declaring his war against corruption, President Uhuru did well to announce that his war against corruption will have no sacred cows and will spare no one who is suspected of graft, quite a shift from putting suspicion at par with innocence. At this point, it pays to remind President Uhuru that the war against corruption is not just action but also the right impression. Uhuru's war against graft will lack public confidence if his vanguard does not look right to people who will support the war and want it won by people who will not sabotage it later, the way independence was sabotaged by wrong people who seemed to be fighting for Uhuru but were fighting for self-interest. President Uhuru must have the cleanest possible team to fight graft. In his last two years in power, President Uhuru seems to have been a victim of political and ethnic alliances that put him in power but also took away from him courage to send home suspects of graft for fear of offending either his own or other side of Jubilee political-cum-ethnic alliance. Now that he has a political outfit - JAP - that is not based on an obviously ethnic alliance, he must have the guns to stick to his demand that suspects of graft must step aside until investigations against them prove them innocent. So, as President promised, the country wants to see all those who are mentioned in the report annexed to his speech step aside with haste. Only that will prove that the president has turned a new leaf in his war against graft. Mr President, your war against corruption must avoid pitfalls of targeting and only fighting new graft while forgetting old corruption. While old graft may not stink as much as new, it must not be spared or it will be proof that if one hides long enough, his corruption may never be punished. Fortunately for President Uhuru, the war against graft will not be that difficult. If courts of law play their part as they should, there is enough evidence to ensure we keep corruption killed and buried forever. Accordingly, President's team on corruption should revisit reports of the Controller and Auditor General to ensure no corruption escapes prosecution. However, in his State of the Nation statement, the President forgot to focus on negative ethnicity as one of the key national problems that must be solved to win the war against corruption and propel the country forward. I want to believe that failure to mention negative ethnicity was not deliberate but an omission that will soon enjoy remedy, or else we shall soon begin to hear suspects calling to their communities to protect them against targeting, discrimination and witch-hunting. Finally, let me remind President Uhuru that his war against corruption, while noble and most welcome, it will not be won without restoration of Chapter Six of the constitution to its central place in our governance. Leaders without integrity cannot be relied upon to fight and end corruption.

TITLE: Thumbs Up Mr President for Your Resolve in the Fight Against Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); ETHICS (72%); BUDGETS (72%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: "In view of the oath of office that I took as the President of this republic, let it be known that today I draw the line. No one will stand between Kenyans and what is right in the fight against corruption and other monstrous economic crimes." - President Uhuru Kenyatta. This statement made on March 26, 2015, will forever be edged in the history of Kenya as it turned a new chapter in its resolve to have a better Kenya. It is a day that saw a Kenyan President applauded through a standing ovation as he addressed a special joint sitting of Parliament. President Uhuru summarised the country's key challenges as corruption, disunity and insecurity. He also outlined how his government plans to deal with this and gave directives to the executive. The President took an extraordinary step of suspending his own officials including Cabinet Secretaries for being implicated in corruption. Many had asked the President to stop talking and walk the talk and he did exactly that when we did not expect it. We have asked for action from the Presidency for long, and it is now clear that the President listens and has been listening. The President ordered a speedy investigation and resolution of the said allegations. The step taken by the President deserves accolades from all patriotic Kenyans who are tired of seeing the public coffers being robbed left, right and centre. It is a turning point for the country which has lost more than Sh2 trillion to corruption over the last decade. This, lest we forget, is more than our annual budget as a country, and more than can do wonders for the country. Corruption has over the years denied Kenyans key development and services as a few individuals sort to benefit themselves from public funds. The President also threw a challenge to other arms of government, as they are not immune to the vice, to follow his steps. We therefore, as Kenyans, expect heads to roll in the other arms of government with no delay. All Kenyans and especially leaders must take the President's cue and move with speed to deal with this vice and help curtail the dangers posed by it. Parliament must also, as requested by the President, look at the legislation meant to deal with corruption including the working of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. Another key highlight of the President's State of the Nation address was the apology he made on his behalf, his government's behalf and past administrations for historical injustices. The President deserves a pat on the back for this, and it is not surprising that he got a standing ovation from MPs for this too. He demonstrated the country was on the right path of development with a vibrant economy, growing infrastructure and improved services. The President deserves our support and dedication. All this development he outlined will not be possible unless we all fight corruption, disunity and insecurity. (The writer is a political and communications consultant.)

TITLE: Kenya Caught in the Eye of Corruption Storm
COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); RWANDA (79%); BOTSWANA (79%); CAPE VERDE (79%); SEYCHELLES (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ETHICS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); INDICTMENTS (77%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); CONSPIRACY (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); IMMIGRATION (72%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (72%); ACCOUNTING (71%); PROFESSIONAL NEGLIGENCE (71%); APPOINTMENTS (71%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (70%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (69%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (69%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (50%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Kenya is caught in the eye of a storm; a storm of corruption. Our past, that which we have continuously denied or discreetly swept under the carpet has caught up with us; and it is ugly, very ugly. At least two Parliamentary committees charged with over-sighting corruption, namely the Public Accounts Committee and Agriculture Committee, are themselves facing allegations of corruption. As if that is not enough, allegations of corruption have been made against our Independent Elections and Boundaries Commission, our Judicial Service Commission, Kenya National Examinations Council and, incredibly, our Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. Which way Kenya now that the National institutions created to monitor, check, eradicate and prosecute corruption are now themselves mired in graft? That they engage in the very sins that they have been mandated to eradicate is a sickening indictment as to the state of our nation. The existence of corruption in our country is no secret. Bodies like Transparency International have issued warnings regarding corruption in Kenya for decades. Indeed their index, now accepted as the international objective indicator, rated Kenya at a score of 27 out of a possible 100 on the CPI for 2013. Compared to Botswana, the best performing in Africa at 64, Cape Verde at 58, Rwanda and Seychelles at a joint 54, Kenya had flunked the test miserably. Corruption can be broadly broken down into three main categories: (a) Incidental or small-scale involving junior public officials like policemen, immigration or customs officials. It is also referred to as petty as it has little macro-economic cost. It, however, produces deep public alienation and is difficult to curb. (b) Systematic corruption which may affect whole government departments or quasi-government institutions. This may have a substantial effect on state revenue(s) and may divert trade and development thereby affecting economic growth. (c) Systemic corruption which is kleptocracy or theft by the government. In this set-up, honesty becomes irrational. One does not have to be a rocket scientist to infer that corruption has steadily grown from incidental to systemic as our legislature and executive connive and conspire to loot public funds as in the current saga facing PAC. The Speaker of the National Assembly in an attempt to save face has appointed the Powers and Privileges' Committee to investigate allegations of corruption within Parliamentary committees. Apart from being too little too late, our MPs are known to protect and defend one another hence the need for an independent investigation. Our Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission as currently constituted, does not fit the bill as it too is embroiled in internal wrangles involving allegations of malpractice and corruption. We, therefore, welcome the proposal from the Institute of Certified Public Accountants of Kenya and the Law Society of Kenya to set up an independent investigation. Civil society and the leader of the opposition coalition Cord have issued ultimatums and all manner of threats to President Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta to address official corruption or face all manner of consequences. If experience is anything to go by, this particular modus operandi was not a good idea. No President since independence has ever responded to threats or ultimatums. That aside, it is also inherently dishonest in that the imperial Presidency was removed upon promulgation of the 2010 constitution, which created specific independent statutory bodies to address corruption and other maladies. It is to these institutions that civil society and the opposition should be addressing their concerns. In event of their failure to respond or act, then there are specific constitutional provisions they should activate resulting in their removal or dissolution. Convoluting and distorting facts is in itself a form of corruption. The incident that triggered the suspension of PAC allegedly involving Defence Permanent Secretary Mutea Iringo, and investigated by Ababu Namwamba amongst others, actually took place during the term of the grand coalition government in which Raila Odinga was Prime Minister. Anglo Leasing contracts took place during the first term of Retired President Mwai Kibaki. Attempts to link these incidents to the current Jubilee government are not only far-fetched but nonsensical and hypocritical. Truth cannot be hidden!

TITLE: If Found Guilty of Corruption, I Am Ready to Be Executed - CS Kambi
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); RULE OF LAW (75%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Labour Cabinet Secretary Kazungu Kambi has reiterated that he is ready to face a firing squad if he is found guilty in the latest corruption allegation facing him and other four cabinet secretaries. Speaking in his office on Sunday, Kambi said he was innocent and that he was confident he will be vindicated. "Even though I don't know my accusers nor the accusations levelled against. For the mere mention of my name in the president's submission to parliament I have stepped aside. The move is to pave way for smooth investigations by the EACC. As a law-abiding citizen who also respect the rule of law. I would not want my staying in office to hamper the investigations," Kambi said. He also called for action taken against his accusers if they can not substantiate corruption claims they levelling against him and his other colleagues in cabinet. "I am ready to face a firing squad if found guilty but equally if the accusations levelled against me are found to be malicious and am vindicated then those who raise them should also be punished. We cannot be a country that thrives on rumours where someone just wakes up one day and levelled unfounded graft claims against another with a view of soiling his name," he said. He further called on EACC to comply with 60 day time-line to carry out and conclude investigations on those mentioned.

TITLE: Uhuru Should Have Fired, Not Suspend Ministers in EACC Corruption Report - Raila
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The state should have sacked individuals in the graft purge instead of allowing them to step aside, Cord leader Raila Odinga has said. Raila said President Uhuru Kenyatta acted as a whistle blower and did not exercise full authority over the matter. "We find the President's move, to table names from the EACC before Parliament and to seek those named to step aside, a discomforting reminder that the more things change in our country, the more they remain the same," he said in a statement on Monday. Raila said all those who have stepped aside will troop back to their seats and "make up for lost time" adding that it was a tactic of the past. "It is a method used by the past presidencies to placate public anger and not take any action. There is no difference in Kenya between the President requiring a person to step aside and setting up a Commission of Inquiry," he said. Raila said Uhuru had turned the EACC into a "bandit organisation" by allowing it to probe corruption allegations instead of handing them over to the DPP. "It turns EACC into a fire fighting tool of the Executive, at the beck and call of a besieged presidency seeking redemption by hook and crook, contrary to the constitution and expectations of Kenyans," he said. The Cord leader reiterated that the state must set up a mechanism to identify victims of past injustices and return property illegally taken from them. "Uhuru should compensate the victims for their injuries, as far as that is possible, through clearly spelled out budgetary provisions that makes the compensation a right and not a favour," he said. He further noted that Kenya needs a President with actions genuine, logical and consistent with the demands of the Constitution. Uhuru said he had received the EACC report during his State of the Nation address at Parliament last Friday. He asked all public officials mentioned in the report to step aside for investigations that he said should be completed within 60 days.

TITLE: Suspended CS Felix Koskei Appears At EACC With Five Lawyers for Alleged Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAWYERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); RULE OF LAW (90%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Suspended Agriculture CS Felix Koskei appeared at EACC offices on Monday accompanied by five lawyers, over corruption allegations. The lawyers, led by James Ochieng Oduol, presented a letter to the EACC requesting a written confirmation of the nature of allegations against their client. The letter sought a documented list of accusers, the complaints made and "any other supporting material in respect of the allegations." The Agriculture CS was the first official to comply with President Uhuru Kenyatta's directive to step aside on Saturday, but said he did not know the allegations against him. "I am not stepping aside because I am guilty, I am stepping aside because it is the right thing to do," he said. Koskei said he was not interrogated by the anti-graft commission but made the decision after his name appeared in the graft list. "It is the role of every Kenyan to respect the rule of law and uphold the spirit of constitutionalism and as leaders we have to lead by example," said Koskei.
