He will appear before the EACC on April 2 for questioning. Uhuru said he would not prejudge, but asked at government officials mentioned in the corruption report to step aside, to pave way for swift investigations. More than 175 officials are said to be on the list.

TITLE: I Am Ready to Step Down Over Corruption, Says IEBC Boss Isaack Hassan
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (77%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (75%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: IEBC chairman Isaack Hassan has said he is ready to step aside if found on the EACC graft list. The list said to have more than 175 names of public officials was handed to President Uhuru Kenyatta by the EACC, and is set to be tabled on Tuesday. "I don't feel pressure after Davis Chirchir stepped aside. He did so because of his ministerial duties," Hassan said. He spoke at the signing of an MoU with the Association of World Electoral Bodies at Laico Regency, Nairobi on Monday. Hassan has maintained that he was not involved in the 'Chickengate' scandal and has threatened to sue the media for mentioning him in it. Chirchir, the Energy CS, left office for the probe insisting that he was innocent and unaware of the accusations against him. He is among five cabinet secretaries who allegedly plan to storm the EACC headquarters demanding to what they have done wrong and who their accusers are. Hassan said the commission drew lessons from the 2013 general election and will streamline future polls. The MoU concerns training IEBC officials on ICT-dependent elections. It covers voter identification and registration, and results transmission.

TITLE: History is Replete With Countries Destroyed By Corruption - Lumumba [interview]
COUNTRY: KENYA (97%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); UGANDA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICS (90%); INTERVIEWS (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: has served as a Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission director and currently the director of The Kenya School of Law since. He spoke to Star reporter on corruption, elective politics, land and ethnicity. I feel pained as a Kenyan and as a crusader against corruption. The source of my pain is that the country is squandering her opportunity in realising her dreams as set out in the Vision 2030. We are squandering the opportunity not only for this generation but generations to come. History is replete with countries destroyed because of corruption. In Latin America before the people liberated themselves from chains of corruption, the state had been captured by individuals who wanted to make money and saw state institutions as a hunting ground where they made money for personal benefits and the State suffered for a long time. In the recent past in Africa there have been countries that have been consumed by corruption for example Uganda in the reigns of Idi Amin Dada, kleptocracies such as Mabuto Sesseko in Zaire (DRC), Central African Republic in the days of Bokasa there is no shortage of country to mention where corruption has eaten and destroyed. Corruption undermines democracy and particularly when it enters into electoral process and we know in this country it has entered in electoral process. It has enveloped every sector in the economy indeed you will remember in the run up to the struggle to a new constitutional dispensation we put premium on a constitutional dispensation that will create a hostile environment to practice of corruption and this was anchored in Chapter six that deals with integrity and leadership, but unfortunately the Chapter was watered down. The other thing that must worry us is that we the people took the view that devolution of political power and certain elements of economic governance will be migrated to the devolved units unfortunately what we seeing is devolution of corruption. We hear about corruption in the county assemblies, as well in the executive arms. We can see a sudden opulence of individuals serving in these institutions. Unfortunately Kenyans are not enraged because of the high social acceptance of corruption. As a early as 1960s the late Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere said that Kenya is a man eat man society, we didn't believe him. The late Josiah Mwangi Kariuki said we risk being a country of ten million beggars we didn't believe him either. Then we created an environment where civil servants started trading with government and we corrupted our political process and created individuals who had wealth. These individuals became political leaders and society accepted and embraced them and we have never looked back. We drank from the poison chalice of ethnicity and we are now paying the price because our cup of inequity is full and is overflowing. All of us. When Kenya goes under and I pray it doesn't nobody will be safe. That's why we can't afford the luxury of apportioning blame; our house is on fire let's not ask who started the fire. Let's all take buckets and bring the water and put out the fire we will deal with the arsonists when the fire is put out. First PAC members have themselves come out saying some within their ranks are engaged in activities that constitute graft. We even have the recording by the committee chair Ababu Namwamba where individuals acknowledge that they received some money. In other civilised jurisdictions that recording only should make people take political responsibility by saying that having been mentioned I cease to serve in this committee unless proved otherwise. Unfortunately that is not happening. Apart from PAC, the Agriculture Committee and Lands Committee have also been accused of graft. The reason is very simple when the watchman is accused of colluding with thieves the watchman no longer has the credibility and one hopes that action will be taken for the good of Kenya. On EACC it is a body with a clear mandate of educating the masses and coming up with modalities to prevent graft and recommending of prosecution of individuals engaged in corruption. The commission forms part of chain in the criminal justice system and it must play its role. I am never worried when EACC is attacked and criticised from outside. It is a norm world over-in South Africa the Scorpions were disbanded because they recommended prosecution of high ranking government officials, In Nigeria the head of Anti-Corruption Enforcement Agency Nuhu Ribadu was threatened with death and had to go to exile. To be fought by external forces is normal, but what should never happen are the internal wrangles as mandarins will use it to destroy and the body. I hope going forward EACC will learn to solve their problems internally, and be more united so as they can focus more on real issues in the fight against corruption. However I reject the Kenyans view that it is the duty of EACC to stop graft it is a duty of all Kenyans you can't tell a pathologist to stop death. You cannot tell doctor to prevent an illness. Their duty is to educate. In relation to the President's executive order to fight graft, this is not the first time we have heard the president lamenting about corruption in his government. But he seems helpless; to an extent Kenyans doubt his resolve and commitment in the fight against corruption. Do you believe action will be taken? I want to be charitable to Kenyatta, and give him the benefit of doubt. Never in the history of Independent Kenya has a president issued an order of this nature. This is the first order issued by a sitting president targeting issues of Ethics and Integrity in the public service. That is why I hold the view that this is the first step in the right direction. Now beyond this what Kenyans are waiting for is action that will give meaning to the order, and we should give the president a few more weeks. In the document there certain things that he has asked to be done in a time frame that will be running out at the end of the month. We can only begin to question or access the seriousness in which the President takes this particular document upon elapse of the dateline. Remember this is a continuous war I hope the President will take this opportunity as well recruit warriors ready to give their lives in the fight against corruption. There are individuals who I know and known to the President prepared to be in the forefront against corruption. It is under my watch that we started tackling individuals in high office, for the first time in the history of Independent Kenya we recommended prosecution of cabinet ministers and started investigating individuals in high ranking offices. Apparently that was the mistake that we made the political class of the day used the occasion to Amend the law and we were disbanded. What I learned corruption is so deeply seated in this country and it is protected by vested interests and one of the most dangerous things is that these individuals are prepared to kill and maim. The other thing that I realised is that ethnicity is a major problem because immediately an individual is recommended for prosecution people from their ethnic group say they are being 'finished.' I remember one day when we were probing a cabinet minister within ten minutes all members of Parliament from his ethnic group were in my office saying that we were unfairly targeting their tribes mate, similar sentiments were shared by the political party he was affiliated to. My response was quite clear that the corrupt belong to their own corrupt world and should be looked at as such. EACC can only do so much in terms of education, prevention and prosecution When we were making the constitution we were very clear in our mind that public land will be vested in the National Land Commission (NLC) because it will be a professional body that is not subject to political machinations. There is need for clarity that the mandate of NLC is to be the custodian of all public land. That the ministry will only provide policy guidance so once the roles are distinguished in that way, I am sure there will be no conflicts. Currently everybody is competing for territory even though law has to be clear as it was intended. Land is the last colonial question and the make or break issues if we don't deal with it well. If not handled well we will be inviting more conflicts and undermining investor confidence because land is a major a factor of production. It is a potential area of danger and left unchecked can destroy the country as it breeds impunity. First of all I believe that KSL is only school that trains advocates to join the legal profession we have about 14 law schools now and with strained resources. Now we have 1800 young men being trained to be advocate it is not easy you can see every often we are accused of disobeying court orders which is untrue what we are trying to do is to ensure that certain standards are met. We receiving graduates not only from Kenya but from the region and even UK and US but we are working closely with the Counsel of Legal Education which is the regulator that tells us this is the university whose students upon qualification can be admitted to law school but of course in every institution there are challenges and those will always be there. It is a major problem that has arisen because expansion of universities and number of students graduating with law degrees. In the olden days only University of Nairobi offered law and admitted not more than 85 students today we have over 14 universities offering the same course and at the same time admitting about 1000 students, who all end up here, and seek for pupillage from few law firms. It has been the practice that in order to take students in for pupillage one must be an advocate who has practiced for more than five years, must have space and a library, this has been limiting in some way in terms of number of placements. But going forward we are working on recognising more placement centres. I have established in my office a placement department to help students in securing pupillage places and I am happy during this year we did liaise with LSK secretariat and sent out the names of all those they can pick. We have been talking with Secretary Counsel of Legal Education with a view of reviewing the curriculum because the one we running now is seven years old. As we speak I have constituted a committee to look at the manner in which we deliver the curriculum to report to me by April 9. It is important to know that under miscellaneous amendments undertaken by Parliament last year in December, it is now true that in order to join the school from January next year, every applicant will be subjected to a mandatory pre-entry examination and that is law now. With the Council of Legal Education we have put together a committee headed by Jacob Kagere to come out with modalities on when and how those exams will be administered and look at what are the implications. It is a good thing to instill merit. The pre-bar exams give the institution an opportunity to access the suitability of the candidates. It is not unique to Kenya, Japan, UK and our own neighbors in the region are doing it. You can take it to the bank once my four years term end, I will never renew it. I have taken the view that once taken the baton and served you will have made the contribution it's only wise to give others a chance.

TITLE: Sexual Violence is Also a Form of Corruption, Activists Tell Uhuru
SUBJECT: SEX OFFENSES (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (90%); WOMEN (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (79%); MARRIAGE (65%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Activists under the banner Okoa Dada Kenya on Tuesday marched from Freedom Corner in Nairobi to Parliament Building calling on the government to deal with the rise in sexual violence in the country. The march follows a similar protest by activists and members of the civil society on Thursday. In a statement read on behalf of the group by activist Diana Okello, Okoa Dada said rape cases have dominated recent news reports saying that mind-sets need to change now to assure women and girls of their safety. The group said that men need to understand that rape is not provoked whether a woman is drunk, unconscious or by the way she dresses stating that "only rapists are responsible for rape," "We need to create a society where a woman can walk safely at night without the fear of being raped , we need a society that respects woman , a society that does not tolerate violence against women, a society that respects and understands that when a woman says no it means no . Today women cannot even walk on the streets in daylight without fear," the group said. "President Uhuru Kenyatta, this is also corruption," the group added. Okoa Dada Kenya further appealed to the judiciary to handle rape cases seriously and empathize with survivors. "We also call on the government to make rape within marriage an offence,punishable by law," the activists said adding that this will send the message that women are neither objects or property. The group also called on Women MPs to take action against sexual violence. "We also understand that each one of us has the responsibility to stop those hideous crimes from happening , as mothers we have to treat our children equally , we have to teach our sons that they have no special male rights , we have to abandon ancient misogyny and we have to help prevent and report any sexual violence case," Okoa Dada added.

TITLE: Read the List of Public Officers Implicated in Corruption and What the EACC Accuses Them of
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); COUNTIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (89%); MISAPPROPRIATION (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); BUDGETS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); EMERGENCY VEHICLES (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (77%); APPOINTMENTS (76%); PUBLIC CONTRACTS LAW (71%); CONTRACT AWARDS (69%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (67%); HELICOPTERS (64%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: At least 12 governors have been implicated in the EACC corruption report table at the Senate on Tuesday. Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero has been accused of abetting irregular county procurement and irregularly signing an MoU with vehicle manufacturer Foton East Africa. He is further accused of authorising a Sh4.6 billion project for the launch the Nairobi Metro Transportation system. Machakos Governor Alfred Mutua is facing accusations of single-sourcing and failing to adhere to the Public Procurement Act. He has been accused of irregular purchasing 14 Subaru vehicles for county executives. Turkana' Josephat Nanok allegedly made an irregular payment of Sh14 million to a bridge contractor despite no work done. Mombasa's Hassan Joho has been accused of facilitating the grabbing of Mwembe Tayari Market by Bawazir & Zubedi. Kilifi Governor Amason Kingi has been accused of irregularly procuring the governor's house at Sh140 million. Isiolo's Godana Doyo is being investigated over a fraudulent document purported to be a supplementary budget. He has also been accused of irregular appointing and promoting county employees. Migori's Okoth Obado has been accused of improprieties involving procurement and misuse of public funds. Isaac Rutto of Bomet allegedly irregularly hired ambulances at a monthly fee of Sh650,000 each. Rutto has also been accused of illegally accumulating wealth including 40 earth movers, tippers and graders worth Sh400 million. He is also accused of illegally buying a chopper worth Sh300 million and a palatial home in Ngong worth Sh33 million, and operating several petrol stations acquired illegally. Garissa Governor Nadhif Jama and other top county officials have been accused of engaging in unplanned projects Jama has also been accused of irregularly hiring eight Kenya Red Cross Society ambulances at a cost of Sh650,000 per month. He is also accused of irregularly hiring a helicopter for his trips to Hulugho, Modogashe, Daadab and Masalani. Marsabit Governor Yatani Ukur has been accused of abuse of office, manipulation of budget and mismanagement of office. Meru County Governor Peter Munya has been accused of abuse of office and misuse of public funds. Narok Governor Samuel Ole Tunai has been accused of irregular procurement, mismanagement of county revenue and nepotism. Machakos Senator Johnstone Muthama has been accused of misappropriating Sh57 million in CDF meant for rural access roads in the year 2012. Members of Parliament 1. Ganze MP Peter Shehe has been accused of misappropriating the Constituency Development Fund and flouting the Public Procurement Act. 2. Lamu West MP Julius Ndegwa has been accused of unilaterally awarding seven tenders to his cronies. 3. Nandi Hills MP Alfred Keter has been accused of breaching chapter six of the constitution & intimidating public officers 4. Nominated MP Sonia Birdi has been accused of breaching chapter six of the constitution & intimidation of public officers 5. Mount Elgon MP John Serut has been accused of fraudulently acquiring public money belonging to Chepkurkur SA Primary School. 6. Kitutu Chache MP Richard Onyonka has been accused of abuse of office by purchasing sugar for IDPs from Chemelil Sugar. The National Police Service Commission NPSC chairman Johnstone Kavuludi has been accused of financial impropriety and abuse of office. He is further accused of taking trips abroad without accounting for spending. Ronald Musengi, another NPSC commissioner, has been accused of the irregular procurement of a ranch in the Konza techno-city project. Commission CEO James Muhoro is implicated in financial impropriety while more than 100 officers in the police force in suspicious dealings contrary to the Economic Crimes Act. The Courts Former High Court Registrar Gladys Shollei has been accused of irregular procurement of furniture for judiciary. Shollei has also been accused of flouting the Public Procurement Act & single-sourcing for refurbishment of the CJ's parking & kitchen. Senior Principle Magistrate Richard Odenyo allegedly approved bond without proper court orders. Former senior resident magistrate Fridah Nyakundi has been accused of frustrating efforts to prosecute drug traffickers. She allegedly received Sh2.4 million in bribes from media personalities facing drug trafficking charges Kajiado Law Courts magistrate Wilson Nkunja has been accused of acquiring wealth from human traffickers of Somali origin. Others Former Kiambu county assembly Speaker Nick Githinji has been accused of spending Sh600,000 public funds on a Brazil trip without authorisation. Makueni County Speaker Stephen Ngelu and eight MCAs have been accused of financial impropriety & making unauthorized trips abroad. Former Foreign Affairs PS Thuita Mwangi allegedly participated in the irregular procurement of the chancery and ambassador's residence in Tokyo. Geothermal Development Company MD Silas Simiyu has been accused of the irregular procurement of land rigs and financial improprieties. Parliamentary Accounts Committee members have been accused of receiving a Sh1.5 million bribe from defence PS Mutea Iringo to alter a report. Members of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture have been accused of receiving a Sh60 million bribe from former Mumias Sugar managers. Chief Land Registrar Sarah Mwenda has been accused of being among top government officials who benefited from the Karen land saga. Lands Ngilu has been accused of colluding with Evason Watiki, owner of a Mombasa land parcel, to inflate its price by Sh110 million She is also accused of trying to forcefully take over a parcel of land along Statehouse Crescent from Myta Limited.

TITLE: Ababu Namwamba 'Steps Aside' for PAC Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); NATIONAL SECURITY (72%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Budalang'i MP Ababu Namwamba has 'stepped aside' as PAC chairman pending the conclusion of a corruption probe against its members. Ababu said in a letter to National Assembly Speaker Justin Muturi on Tuesday that the move is in line with his support for the anti-graft war. He noted that members of the suspended PAC have been mentioned in the EACC graft report for allegedly receiving a Sh1.5 million bribe to expunge Defense PS Mutea Iringo from it. "I do this well aware that I have not been named as an individual but I consider the probe of PAC members to be a probe into the integrity of all 26 of us," he said. In the letter copied to the EACC, he sought excusal from attending all House sessions and participating in of the House Committee on Administration and National Security. He further asked to be excused from any activities of the PAC and participating in any other business of the House and its committees. Ababu said he was ready to share with the EACC all the information he submitted to the Powers and Privileges committee. He said he is confident that he will be vindicated. This comes hours after the committee tabled documents in Parliament recommending the dissolution and fresh constitution of the PAC. It was proposed that Ababu, Runyenjes MP Cecily Mbarire, Nyatike MP Edick Anyanga and Kesses lawmaker James Bett be left out of the new PAC. The proposal is yet to be debated.

TITLE: MPs Debate EACC Corruption Report, Say List of Shame Should Not Be Politicised
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); WOMEN (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); US PRESIDENTS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); SEX OFFENSES (75%); ASSAULT & BATTERY (70%); SEXUAL HARASSMENT (70%); FEMINISM & WOMEN'S RIGHTS (69%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: MPs raised objections to a list of public officials allegedly involved in graft when the National Assembly debated on it on Tuesday. President Uhuru Kenyatta's directive for the officials to step aside should not be politicised, several leaders said. Minority leader Francis Nyenze said five MPs had to step aside due to "mere speculation". "Nobody from Ukambani is left. Ngilu is gone, Nduva, Mutua, Muthama and now you want to remove Matemu," Nyenze said. He blamed the media for creating aspersions against MPs, saying some facing sexual assault and corruption allegations have been leading "honourable lives." Nyenze said that he was happy with Othaya MP Mary Wambui's statement on alleged sexual harassment by some male MPs. Wambui said on Monday that female MPs are partly to blame for as they entertain men who are not their husbands late into the night/ "If you are a married person, you cannot stay with a man until midnight and say that you are being raped," Nyenze said. Runyenjes MP Cecily Mbarire opposed Nyenze's remark saying he cannot set moral standards for women whether single or married. "That is why we say My Dress My Choice, My Body My Choice," Mbarire said. Mbita MP Millie Adhiambo said Uhuru did not slay "the dragon of corruption" in his directive, adding that there is no legal framework for stepping aside. "He has not touched the dragon on its head and its eggs. The President has just poked the dragon with a needle, but the head and the eggs are still intact," Millie said. "I have been told my name appears due to allegations against the Agriculture Committee. Me, step aside? From where to where." Officials named in the report should have been dealt with before they were appointed to their positions, Millie noted. She also objected Nyenze's statement saying "it is obvious" that the protection of women's rights lacks seriousness. Giving IEBC chairman Isaack Hassan as an example, Homa Bay women's rep Gladys Wanga said according to the court of public opinion, some officials under investigation should have been named. Wanga noted that land grabbing matters, especially those involving school properties, were not mentioned in the report. She further said Parliament should deal with the matter of the EACC "so that we are not dealing with an EACC facing a credibility crisis". Cherengani MP Wesley Korir said investigations should have been done before the list was released. Kieni MP Kanini Kega lauded Uhuru for the directive saying corruption cannot be tolerated. Majority leader Aden Duale who table Uhuru's State of the Nation address lauded him for apologising to all Kenyans for past injustices. Duale said that the apology set the stage for national healing and national reconciliation, noting that US President Barrack Obama is visiting in acknowledgment of change. He further denied that the government doctored the report stating that even "perceived friends of Jublilee" had been mentioned. "There is no where to hide, the dye has been cast," he said, underling that it is time to separate to remove corruption from the political class.

TITLE: KAA Suspends MD Lucy Mbugua Again Over Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LITIGATION (90%); CIVIL AVIATION (88%); APPOINTMENTS (88%); MISCONDUCT (87%); SUITS & CLAIMS (86%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); AVIATION ADMINISTRATION (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ETHICS (75%); AIRPORT OPERATION (75%); PORT AUTHORITIES (74%); AIRPORTS (70%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: KAA has revoked Lucy Mbugua's reinstatement as MD following a directive for all public officers implicated in graft to step aside for a probe. Finance general manager John Thumbi, secretary Catherine Kisila and procurement manager Obadiah Orora's reappointments have also been revoked. The four had been recalled from compulsory leave on March 24, after preliminary findings exonerated them of the allegations against them. Their suspension on February 19 concerned the controversial award of a tender to run duty-free shops at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport to Dufry International. Yatich Kangugo will serve as acting MD pending EACC's decision on Mbugua's conduct, KAA chairman David Kimaiyo said via Twitter on Tuesday. Despite adhering to President Uhuru Kenyatta's directive, the Kenya Airports Authority board is facing a lawsuit over Mbugua's reinstatement. Activist Okiya Omtatah, who filed the suit on Monday, said it was unconstitutional to withdraw disciplinary action against her. "KAA effectively violated Article 79 of the Constitution by purporting to investigate fraud allegations against the suspended MD, and clearing her, whereas the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission is the only entity mandated to investigate such allegations," he said. Others mentioned in gross misconduct allegations are

TITLE: K'oyoo Praise Uhuru for Fighting Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Muhoroni MP Onyango K'Oyoo has praised President Uhuru Kenyatta for directing individuals named in corruption to step aside pending investigations. He said this will those named do not tamper with investigations. K'Oyoo said corruption is now a national disaster. He was speaking on Sunday during a funds drive at Muhoroni Central SDA Church.

TITLE: Orengo Allegedly Took Sh5 Million Bribe to Sell Sh320 Million Westlands Plot - EACC Corruption Report
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (93%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LAND LEASES (73%); PROPERTY LEASES (73%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (59%) Kenya; Corruption; Land and Rural Issues
TEXT: Former Lands minister and current Siaya senator James Orengo has been accused of receiving a bribe to sell off public land in the EACC graft report. Orengo is accused of allegedly receiving a Sh5 million bribe for the sale of a plot in Nairobi's Westlands area to former Nairobi mayor George Aladwa. Lands commissioner Zablon Mabeya is also alleged to have pocketed Sh5 million for his part in the sale of the public land that was valued at Sh320 million. The plot of land is alleged to be on Ring Road, Westlands next to Apollo Center. The report states that Orengo further irregularly renewed a land lease for plot number No.I.R 861 in 2008 that he had initially acquired in 1975 which had expired.

TITLE: Raila's Has 'Lost It' With 'Tantrums' On EACC Corruption List, Says Uhuru's Speechwriter
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); SCANDALS (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); COUPS (65%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The state has slammed Cord leader Raila Odinga for chastising President Uhuru Kenyatta's response to corruption. It is those with "skeletons in their closets" who were the first to protest Uhuru's approach, said the Presidency's senior messaging director Eric Ng'eno. Ng'eno claimed Raila's "discomfort" has its roots in the "enormous scandals" his office faced in the past administration. "The Kazi Kwa Vijana and maize scandals are just two of these colossal frauds on the people of Kenya. Discrediting the anti-corruption process is therefore at the heart of his short, medium and long-term personal interest," he said. "In the Grand Coalition government, Mr Odinga was big on stepping aside as a remedy for perceived integrity lapses in government. All of a sudden, he sees the process as cruel and a joke." In a statement to newsrooms on Monday, he said Raila's "tantrums" indicate a leader "whose strategy and ideology on corruption have been overtaken by time". Ng'eno underlined that the anti-graft war is strong, systematic and large scale, saying the EACC's corruption report was duly submitted to Uhuru and Parliament. He accused Raila of lacking meaningful grounds for opposing the approach, adding that he is standing against the people of Kenya and has "lost it". Ng'eno said Uhuru's apology for past offenses against Kenyans, "some of which Mr Odinga is intimately associated with", was well received by the public. "The 1982 attempted coup and 2007 post-election violence are some of the matters to which closure will never happen without Mr Odinga standing before the nation and explaining himself," he noted. Ng'eno was responding to Raila's view that the public officials on the 'list of shame' should have been fired, not suspended. Raila said on Monday that Uhuru acted as a whistle blower, not an Executive authority, and accused him of breaching the Constitution by handing the report to Parliament. "By failing to sack those he has the power to sack while admonishing those he has no powers over, the war on graft has once again been cheapened and turned into a game of musical chairs," he said.

TITLE: Clean House Before Tackling Corruption, EACC Told
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: EACC commissioners should resolve their differences and unite before implicating others in corruption, an MP has said. "We are happy with the way they are tackling corruption in the country, but first they should sort out their boardroom supremacy battles for Kenyans to have trust and confidence in them," Pokot South MP David Pkosing told KNA on phone on Tuesday. Pkosing urged the commission to pursue corruption cases independently and guard against misuse by cartels out to tarnish names of public officials who may be innocent. He accused the commission of falsely implicating Water PS James Teko in graft saying the cartels are after him. "Teko worked in Central Bank for over 30 years and for all those years, he has not been mentioned in any corruption deal. I know some people are trying to destroy his name," he said. He added that Teko has ensured the supply of clean water to several areas without access in his two years of service in the ministry.

TITLE: Do Not Appear Without Summons, EACC Tells Ministers in Corruption List
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); EXECUTIVES (77%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Ministers implicated in graft have been asked to steer clear of the EACC's headquarters until they are invited. "Neither affected persons nor their agents should come to integrity Centre or other designated commission offices before they are formally invited," said EACC CEO Halakhe Waqo. The EACC has a schedule with the order in which public officials on the 'list of shame' will appear before it, Waqo said in a statement to newsrooms on Tuesday. Formal communication to individuals who have not been interviewed before will be made to each one of them within the week, notifying them of the date and time they are to appear," he added. Reports on Monday said five cabinet secretaries and state corporation chiefs being investigated for corruption intended to storm the EACC to know their alleged wrongs and accusers. The five CSs who have stepped aside to allow the 60-day probe are Felix Koskei (Agriculture), Kazungu Kambi (Labour), Davis Chirchir (Energy), Michael Kamau (Transport) and Charity Ngilu (Lands). Koskei appeared before the commission on Monday and was asked to return for questioning on Thursday. He was accompanied by five lawyers, led by James Oduol, who presented a letter requesting a written confirmation of the nature of allegations against him. Koskei was the first official to comply with President Uhuru Kenyatta's directive to step aside on Saturday, but said he did not know the accusations. The five CSs are among more than 175 public officials implicated in corruption cases.

TITLE: Ngilu Accused of Asking for Sh65 Million Bribe From Waitiki in Corruption Report Tabled At the Senate
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: Suspended Lands Cabinet Secretary Charity Ngilu has been implicated in the graft report issued to Parliament by President Uhuru Kenyatta. In the report seen by the Star, Ngilu is accused of asking for kickbacks to the tune of Sh65 million from Evanson Waitiki. She allegedly instructed valuers from her ministry to inflate the Waitiki land, plot number Mombasa/MN/1/397, by Sh110 million. The land is located in Likoni and is currently valued at Sh9.3 billion. It was purchased by the government for use in resettling squatters. Ngilu initially stated that squatters on the 930-acre land would be issued with title deeds, but later said they would have to buy the land if they wanted to live on it. On Monday she denied any wrongdoing and said she was not aware of her accusers. Others mentioned in irregular land dealings are Land ministry officials Sarah Mwenda, Geoffrey Birundu, Pauline Gitimu, Mark Wanderi. The land issue will be a major talking point as the Senate discusses the EACC report on graft. The national assembly will debate on it on Tuesday afternoon.

TITLE: MCAs Vow to Block Bills Over Corruption
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (88%); EXECUTIVES (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Nairobi MCAs yesterday said they will shoot down all bills from the executive if Governor Evans Kidero refuses to sack five county officers implicated in corruption. Speaking at City Hall, Public Accounts Committee deputy chairman Dan Mutiso said Kidero should act on their recommendations. Last Thursday, MCAs adopted a report by the committee. The MCAs want chief finance officer Jimmy Kiamba, head of treasury Stephen Osiro, head of county revenue Luke Gatimu and county secretary Lilian Ndegwa sacked for denying the Auditor General documents. Mutiso said since President Uhuru has asked all public servants implicated in corruption to step aside, the same should apply to county officers.

TITLE: KNCCI Lauds Uhuru's War on Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE (90%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (90%); ETHICS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); TRENDS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%); BUSINESS ETHICS (73%); BUSINESS ETHICS & CORPORATE CITIZENSHIP (73%); WAR & CONFLICT (72%); SMALL BUSINESS (68%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: THE Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry yesterday pledged to support President Uhuru Kenyatta in the fight against corruption. KNCCI chairman Kiprono Kittony said the President's move was bold. He said democracy must be built through openness in society and sharing information. "The momentum in the war on corruption should not be compromised and those mentioned should do the honourable thing, to step aside. Of importance is that stepping aside is temporary and not an indication of guilt," Kittony said. He said the chamber remains resolute in supporting the government's war against corruption and the trend should be followed in other public institutions. "The chamber supports calls for investigations for these allegations, as this will instill a sense of confidence to the investors and local business community. The perception that has previously existed is that the government has been soft on graft," Kittony said. He said the war against graft should be stepped up and those guilty be reprimanded regardless of their political or social status, or business associations. "Additionally, we should take responsibility to ensure our members do comply with the stipulated business code of conduct and practices. Graft is a two-way street," Kittony said. He said the KNCCI has developed a framework on responsible business ethics and practices that will encourage open and transparent business for small and medium enterprises and corporates, that all must adhere to prior signing up on membership.

TITLE: Carry Your Own Cross, Uhuru Tells Public Officials in EACC Corruption List
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); APPOINTMENTS (88%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Public officials named in the EACC corruption report can only be dismissed if found guilty once investigations are completed, President Uhuru Kenyatta has said. "An accusation is not a sentence. I am not a judge or a prosecutor, I cannot sack people if they haven't been proven guilty," Uhuru said on Wednesday. "When I take action against graft you complain. When I don't you complain. So what do you want me to do?" He spoke during the official opening of the 2015 Kenya Diaspora Easter Investment Conference at Windsor Golf and Country Club, Nairobi on Wednesday. Uhuru said the officials should carry their own crosses and step aside, whether elected or appointed, to allow the probe. "If you are found not guilty, come back, I will be the first to welcome you. If found guilty kila mtu abebe mzigo wake (every man should carry his own cross)," he said. Uhuru reiterated that his administration is committed to the fight against corruption. He issued the directive to all state officials while giving his State of the Nation address at Parliament last Friday. "I took the decision to let Kenyans know the steps we are taking to confront corruption," he said. "We are committed to fighting the plague that has affected our development. Unless it is tackled, development will not be achieved." He instructed the completion of the investigations within 60 days.

TITLE: Your Days Are Numbered, Uhuru Tell the Private on Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BRIBERY (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (79%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (79%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (75%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (73%); LAWYERS (72%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (70%); TAXES & TAXATION (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: President Uhuru Kenyatta has warned private sector entities engaging in corruption that their days are numbered. The President said there was no turning back on the anti-graft drive which he has started and the fight will address all aspects of the vice. He said corruption was not a 'one-way street' and where there is a corrupt public official there must be a corrupt private sector member. "Corruption is a two-way street. I have given directives to the Attorney General to amend our laws so that those who pay bribes are also targeted, prosecuted and jailed. The law should reflect that the giver is as guilty as the taker," he said. The President said companies that are proven to have given a bribe will be blacklisted and will never participate in Government tendering processes. President Kenyatta said the amendment will also include provisions that will allow the prosecutor to freeze the account of corruption suspects so that the corrupt do not use their ill-gotten wealth to obstruct justice. "If found guilty, a suspect's assets will be seized to recover what was stolen from the public," President Kenyatta said. The President spoke at State House during the 4th Presidential Roundtable that brings together the Executive and the Kenya Private Sector Alliance (Kepsa). The Head of State said besides the 'reality of corruption', there was the 'perception of justice' and there were companies that engage in practices that create perceptions of corruption to defeat genuine competition. Such companies include those who use courts to sabotage tendering processes where they have lost through a fair process. "If you lodge a case in court and it is proved that you filed the case just to sabotage your competitor, you will be blacklisted and you will never participate in any tendering process in Kenya," said the President. Deputy President William Ruto said the Jubilee administration was ready to pay any price to rid the Government of corruption. "Every public official must account and measure up to the integrity test. Either you work as a public servant or you go and do private things," he said. The Deputy President emphasised that there will be no half-measures in the fight against corruption and the private sector should also measure up to the integrity test. The President and the DP spoke at the end of the Kepsa Presidential Roundtable meeting whose aim is to improve Kenya's business environment. The chairman of Kepsa, Mr Vimal Shah, said the association supports the Government's anticorruption drive and was ready to play its role in making Kenya corruption free. "Investors love destinations that are corruption-free because they are assured that their money will compete in a fair environment," he said. On the agenda of the Presidential Roundtable were issues ranging from taxation on raw materials to how the private sector was benefitting from bilateral agreements Kenya has entered into since President Kenyatta came into office. The private sector, which is now pleased with the reduced cost of power, was challenged to lower the price of the products since the cost of production has gone down. The meeting was attended by Cabinet Secretaries and senior government officials.

TITLE: New Twist As Mumo Matemu Claims EACC Corruption Report Was Edited
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); RESIGNATIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); LAWYERS (74%); SCANDALS (73%); GEOTHERMAL ENERGY (50%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The EACC report was allegedly edited after President Uhuru Kenyatta demanded the names of those implicated in corruption. Commission chairman Mumo Matemu claimed two top State House officials have been interfering with their work to intimidate officers. Matemu did not name them when he appeared before the Justice and Legal Affairs Committee over his removal on Thursday. "I am not under pressure to resign but I am ready to go down for the sake of the country," he noted. He added that according to the EACC, Commissioner Jane Onsongo is only on leave and has not resigned. Commission vice chairperson Irene Keino said the two officials have been interfering with investigations. Keino said she will name them if IG Joseph Boinnet guarantees her security. She said two people asked her to quit but noted that she will fight back, adding that the "forced" resignation was aimed at disbanding the EACC. "I wish to state that there is a brazen attempt to force my resignation and disbandment of the Commission by a clique, which is a clear subversion of the constitution, she said on Wednesday. "This attempt has also manifested itself in the fueled internal feuds at the Commission and the concealment of documents." Keino said a top government official called her over the matter at about 11.30pm on Tuesday. She was allegedly asked to resign over the Anglo Leasing scam for appointment as deputy ambassador to Brazil. She further linked the advise to scandals involving the Karen land and the Mumias Sugar and Geothermal Development companies. The pressure started on Friday allegedly through Solicitor General Njee Muturi, Presidential adviser Abdikadir Mohamed and Parliament's Justice and Legal Affairs Committee chairman Samwel Chepkonga. Each of them was reportedly tasked with convincing one of the three commissioners to resign, with a message from the President that Kenyans have lost faith in the EACC and their leadership. Onsongo and Keino refused to write resignation letters, but the three high-ranking officials allegedly insisted that they had no choice, said a source.

TITLE: Disabled Back Corruption War
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); DISABLED PERSONS (88%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The National Council for Persons with Disabilities has praised President Uhuru Kenyatta for fighting corruption. Chairman David ole Sankok said the crackdown on corrupt individuals must start with top officials. In a press briefing in Narok town yesterday, he called on those mentioned to resign immediately.

TITLE: University Massacre a Result of Corruption, Says Karua
SUBJECT: TERRORISM (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); NATIONAL SECURITY (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (73%); BRIBERY (73%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (72%) Kenya; Corruption; International Terrorism
TEXT: NARC Kenya leader Martha Karua yesterday linked the terrorism attack at Garissa University College to corruption and nepotism. In a press release to media houses, Karua said the guns, bullets and explosives were brought into Kenya through the country's border points and the security agents could have been compromised through bribery. She said graft has compromised the country's security such that terrorists can move freely in the cities with the knowledge of a few individuals "whose wallets have been lined up with blood money". "Narc Kenya is deeply saddened by the massacre of defenseless and innocent students at the Garissa University by blood thirsty terrorists. We offer our heartfelt condolences to their families and our wishes for quick recovery to the injured," Karua said. She said Kenya was caught by surprise barely a day after it dismissed warning of impending attacks from friendly nations. "This clearly points a weakness on our intelligence gathering and usage. Increasing the number of security personnel alone may not be a solution," Karua said. She commended President Uhuru Kenyatta on his move to rid the government of corruption but said the move may be unfruitful if not followed by serious investigations and convictions. Karua claimed the government is making a mockery of the constitution on integrity by "recycling" individuals who should not hold public office. She said the national government should involve governors on security matters to ensure the safety of citizens.

TITLE: Siaya Politicians Raise Alarm Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (78%); COUNTIES (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (73%); CONSULTING SERVICES (53%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: TWO politicians in Siaya county have condemned the "high levelled" corruption in the county. Former Gem parliamentary candidate Elisha Odhiambo and former Alego Usonga MP Sammy Weya said corruption is an impediment to development. He said graft must be fought by both the national and county governments. Odhiambo urged Siaya leaders to unite in fighting corruption and asked Governor Cornel Rasanga to "put his house in order". He said he will not relent in his fight against corruption in Siaya. Odhiambo said Rasanga must take responsibility over corruption under his administration. "He must be ready to take responsibility and account for each coin spent in the County for thee is public funds," he said. Odhiambo spoke on Saturday during the burial of former assistant minister Grace Ogot in Gem. Weya questioned why the county spent Sh16 million in management consultancy work. "This is corruption of the highest order. Rasanga must also account for Sh21 million the county claims to have spent in putting up wooden offices," he said. Weya told teh Star on the phone that Sh54 million paid to a contractor for the design of the proposed county headquarters if too high. He also questioned how Sh3 million was spent in digging a pit latrine at the county headquarters. Bishop Joseph Otieno while speaking at Yala ACK church yesterday faulted the list of shame released last week. "It is not in order to tarnish people's names before they are proven guilty," he said. Otieno said there is need for investigations of alleged corruption before the names are made public.

TITLE: Ngilu at EACC for Grilling Over Land Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BRIBERY (90%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (72%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (72%) Kenya; Land and Rural Issues; Corruption
TEXT: Lands CS Charity Ngilu is at the EACC for questioning on corruption allegations over which she stepped aside. In the commission's graft report, Ngilu is accused of asking for a Sh65 million kickback from farm owner Evanson Waitiki. She allegedly instructed valuers from her ministry to inflate the value of the 930-acre plot, number Mombasa/MN/1/397, by Sh110 million. The land is located in Likoni and is currently valued at Sh9.3 billion. Ngilu initially stated that squatters on the land would be issued with title deeds, but later said they would have to buy the land if they wanted to live on it. Waitiki however said he is yet to receive feedback from the government on his offer to sell the property for the resettlement of the squatters. While handing over to Information CS Fred Matiang'i last week, Ngilu denied any wrongdoing and said she was not aware of her accusers. Ngilu has been in the centre of many storms since taking over the lands docket and has been on a warpath with the National Lands Commission. Others mentioned in irregular land dealings are Land ministry officials Sarah Mwenda, Geoffrey Birundu, Pauline Gitimu, Mark Wanderi.

TITLE: Ababu Links Terrorist Attacks to Corruption
SUBJECT: TERRORISM (93%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (93%); AL-SHABAAB (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); PEACEKEEPING (78%); NATIONAL SECURITY (78%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (72%); NATIONAL IDENTITY CARDS (68%); WOUNDS & INJURIES (65%); COUNTIES (52%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; International Terrorism
TEXT: BUDALANGI MP Ababu Namwamba has said terrorist attacks thrive due to corruption in Kenya. Addressing the press at his Port Victoria home on Monday, Namwamba questioned why Kenya is the only country being targeted by the al Shabaab, yet other countries had also sent peace-keeping forces to Somalia. He said Ethiopia has a higher number of Somali nationals than Kenya and was also the first to deploy its security forces to fight the al Shabaab terrorists, but no attack has taken place there. "Corruption at our entry points is to blame for the frequent terrorist attacks in Kenya. Most aliens gain access into the country after getting national ID cards through the registration of persons offices," Namwamba said. The legislator said Kenya should not ignore warnings from national security intelligence agencies. He said the state should work with county governments to improve security. Namwamba said Kenyans should be informed about the investigation of the September 2, 2013, Westgate Mall attack, where more than 80 people were killed. He sent condolences to all families whose relatives died in last Thursday's terrorist attack on Garissa University College. Some 147 people were killed, while more than 70 were injured.

TITLE: Ngilu Question By EACC Over Corruption.
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ETHICS (78%); EVICTION (78%); BRIBERY (78%); SOCIAL SECURITY (65%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (59%) Kenya; Corruption; Land and Rural Issues; Governance
TEXT: Suspended Lands Cabinet Secretary Charity Ngilu and the Chief Lands Registrar Sarah Mwendwa were yesterday questioned by the anti-graft team. Ngilu arrived at Integrity House, the Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission headquarters, just after 9am. The CS was suspended by President Uhuru Kenyatta along with five other Cabinet Secretaries to pave way for investigations over graft allegations. They were named in the EACC's list of shame. Ngilu is being investigated over allegations that she intended to get a Sh65 million kickback from the inflation of land owned by Evason Waitiki in Mombasa county by Sh110 million. "The CS allegedly instructed the valuers from her ministry to overvalue the land," the report says. It indicates that the remaining Sh45 million was to be shared by other interested parties in the transaction. Ngilu is also being investigated over allegations that there is a scheme orchestrated by Lands ministry officials to drive out the owners of a plot on State House Crescent. The Chief Lands Registrar and two staffers of the Director of Surveys - Julius Kitur and Albert Kitur - are also implicated in the scheme. Registrar Mwendwa, her deputy Geoffrey Birundi, senior deputy director of survey Pauline Gitimu and registrar of titles Mark Wanderi are also accused of being among the beneficiaries of the 134.4 acres of land in Karen belonging to Muchanga Investment. EACC has also been investigating the ownership of the 134.4 acres Karen land being claimed by Muchanga and a company associated with former National Social Security Fund managing trustee Jos Konzolo. The case is in court. Some time last year, a group of people swarmed on the land and subdivided it under the supervision of senior Lands officials, prominent politicians and businessmen before the Lang'ata police boss was ordered them evicted and secure the parcel. A contractor hired to build access roads and fence the land was later killed by gunmen as he entered his Ngong home.

TITLE: Two MPs Accuse Uhuru Over Double Speech On Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (76%); RULE OF LAW (73%); TRAVEL WARNINGS (68%); AL-SHABAAB (66%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: TWO Cord MPs have accused President Uhuru Kenyatta of abetting corruption. Speaking separately to the Star on the phone yesterday, MPs Oyugi Magwanga (Kasipul) and Timothy Bosire (Kitutu Masaba) accused Uhuru of double speech in his efforts to fight corruption. They wondered why the President ordered that 10,000 police recruits whose recruitment was stopped by the High Court over corruption report for training. Magwanga said Uhuru is not serious about fighting corruption and "he should let those who stepped aside over corruption resume their duties." "The police recruitment of the group the President is directing to go for training was marred by massive corruption and it is immoral for him to disregard the court order that stopped the process," he said. In October last year, the High Court nullified the police recruitment and barred the National Police Service Commission from issuing the recruits with appointment letters. Magwanga said the judiciary must remain independent without any interference from the executive. "The court's directive must remain so until a clean process of recruitment is conducted," he said. Bosire accused the President of "rearing contradictions" in his government and promoting anarchy. "It is unfortunate that on the one hand, this system claims to thrive on the rule of law while on the other, it thrives on dictatorship," he said. Bosire said the President should have asked the judiciary to hasten the police recruitment matter so new recruits are picked in the correct way. "Otherwise his [Uhuru's] directive manifests a leader who is incompetent," he said. The legislator said Uhuru should have sat down with his team of advisers on security matters to come up with a better position. Bosire also said the country's leadership only acts in times of crisis. He lashed out at the government for criticising travel advisories issued by the UK instead of acting on them. Uhuru last Thursday said he takes full responsibility for his directive that the recruits report for training. He gave the directive after al Shabaab militants attacked Garissa University College, killing 147 students. Uhuru said Kenya badly needs additional officers and he would not keep the nation waiting any longer. "I also assure the nation that my government has undertaken appropriate deployment to the affected area. I urge Kenyans to stay calm as we resolve this matter, and to provide the authorities with any information they may have in connection with any threats to our security," he said.

TITLE: MP Neto Hits At Governor Awiti Over Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: COUNTY GOVERNMENT (91%); COUNTIES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); NEW CONSTRUCTION (89%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); HIGHWAY FUNDING (78%); CONSTRUCTION (78%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (78%); MISAPPROPRIATION (76%); SOLAR ENERGY (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Homa Bay county Governor Cyprian Awiti should not blame anyone over the alleged loss of Sh112.5million meant for the construction of roads in the county. Speaking to the Star on the phone yesterday, Ndhiwa MP Agostino Neto challenged Awiti to tell Homa Bay residents the projects that gobbled up Sh8 billion money his administration received from the national government over a period of two years for the installation of solar-powered street lights. "The residents are only aware of the recently installed solar powered street lights in Homa Bay town. There is no tangible project the Governor undertook using that colossal amount of money. He should tell us how he spent it," said Neto. The MP said the county government has been receiving funds from the national government and the county but the economic impact of the funds is minimal. He said he is not branding the county government corrupt but it should show how tax payers money was used. "We want to see the development projects undertaken in the two years the county government has been in existence," he said. The legislator said residents are suffering because of poor state of health facilities, impassable roads and inadequate provision of clean water. He challenged MCAs to be keen in exercising their oversight role to avoid loss of funds. "MCAs should be more vigilant when approving county government projects to avoid misappropriations," he said. Two weeks ago, county assembly committee tabled a report alleging that Sh112.5 million set aside for road construction in the county had been misappropriated. However, Governor Awiti denied any loss money. He assured residents the money will be refunded through an insurance company. Awiti said the contractor had stopped continuing with the work on Gendia-Kadongo road in Kabondo Kasipul constituency because the contractor went abroad to hire more powerful machines.

TITLE: Orengo, Kambi and Nduva Muli At EACC for Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BRIBERY (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); LAND LEASES (71%); PROPERTY LEASES (71%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (68%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Siaya senator James Orengo, suspended Labour CS Kazungu Kambi and Transport PS Nduva Muli are currently at the EACC for questioning over corruption allegations. Orengo is accused of allegedly receiving a Sh5 million bribe for the sale of a plot in Nairobi's Westlands area to former Nairobi mayor George Aladwa. Lands commissioner Zablon Mabeya is also alleged to have pocketed Sh5 million for his part in the sale of the public land that was valued at Sh320 million. The plot of land is said to be on Ring Road, Westlands next to Apollo Center. The report states that Orengo further irregularly renewed a land lease for plot number No.I.R 861 in 2008 that he had initially acquired in 1975 which had expired. Kambi is allegedly linked in corruption deals at NSSF where he strongly supported the NSSF Tassia II project. Muli on the other hand is accused of irregularly disposing Kenya Railways properties in Nairobi and other cities in the country in addition to influencing procurement process. He is also allegedly involved in irregular award of SGR tender to a Chinese company.

TITLE: URP Leaders Read Malice in Corruption List
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (78%); COUNTIES (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (74%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (72%); DAIRY FARMING (64%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: THE anti-graft report was doctored to malign Deputy President William Ruto's allies, Nandi leaders have said. The leaders said yesterday, cabinet secretaries and senior government officials mentioned in the list of shame were named based on gossip and hearsay. URP MCAs defended Agriculture CS Felix Koskei and Chief of Staff in the Office of the Deputy President Marianne Keittany. They said their names were put in the list by people with ulterior motives. Addressing a press conference at URP offices in Kapsabet town, the leaders said the list stopped short of naming Ruto. "How can the anti-graft agency put people's names in the list of shame without carrying out thorough investigations on the allegations?" the leaders said in a statement. Led by county URP chairman Sammy Choge, they said they will not take the report lightly. MCAs Charles Tanui, Chris Ng'eny, Julius Menjo, David Rotich and Kipkirui Chepkwony attended the press conference. Other MCAs in attendance were Amos Korir, Charles Tanui, Chris Ng'eny, Martin Douglas and Philip Sang'. Two former chairmen of the defunct Nandi County Council, Charles Tanui and David Bett, represented the Nandi Council of Elders in the media meeting. "We are not against the fight on corruption but we want to see fairness in the manner in which it is fought. Some people are using it to wreck URP," Choge said. They said certain individuals wrote to the EACC complaining against Koskei over milk coolers his ministry allegedly bought for local dairy farmers to establish a milk cooling plant. "We want proper investigations done before anyone is asked to step aside. The list of shame was meant to taint the reputation of the CS," Ng'eny said. They said the war on corruption should be supported by all but it should not be based on lies, political malice and character assassination.

TITLE: Malombe Declares War On Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: KITUI Governor Julius Malombe has enlisted the support of ward representatives in the fight against plunder of public resources. He said his government will not condone corruption. He said there is need for concerted efforts to fight corruption. "Let us all resolve to fight corruption. Some public servants use working hours to run their errands. This is corruption," he said. The county chief said conflict of interest among public servants, political debauchery and diversion of public resources are all forms of graft. He was addressing the county assembly on Wednesday during the state of the county address. "I will stand with you in the struggle for a just society in the service of the people of this county," Malombe said.

TITLE: We Are All to Blame for Continuing Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); APPOINTMENTS (76%); SCANDALS (73%); WEDDINGS & ENGAGEMENTS (68%); RELIGION (65%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: When I listen to fellow Kenyans discuss the problems facing this nation, especially corruption, they always blame the leaders except themselves. The bitter pill of truth we should all swallow, is that we 'ordinary Kenyans' have contributed to the corruption facing our nation today. Our leaders, especially political leaders are here to address the needs of the community, county or the nation as a whole. As Kenyans, we must put the interests of the nation above our individual and selfish interests. Notably to say, many of the elected and appointed public officers are even afraid of going back to their constituencies. When people come to see them they come with all sorts of personal problems. We must understand that it is hard for a politician or leader who gives money for weddings, circumcision ceremonies, and other personal matters, to also address the important needs of the society, like education, health and jobs. Where do you expect them to get that extra money if not from the CDF kitty or sale of grabbed land? Interesting also, there's a culture, very common in many families for all the family members to rely on one able person's sweat. There is nothing wrong for a person who has the means to assist his relatives and friends. Our religions support generosity, and this should be encouraged. But that is not an excuse for them to depend on him or her to solve ALL their problems. We should learn to ask for help from others only when it is necessary. Many good people became corrupt because they wanted to satisfy the insatiable needs of their family members. We must stop asking people to do things that they can't afford within their legitimate earnings. Now Kenyans are so good at this. We always complain that our leaders are corrupt. It is true that many of them are corrupt. You have read the news headlines, watched TV and checked on the social media. All manner of corruption scandals involving our leaders. Our nation, sadly, worships and glorifies these leaders and politicians that have acquired their wealth by looting public treasury. If we continue to measure success solely based on acquisition of material things like money, land, buildings and so on, are we not promoting corruption? There is nothing impressive in stealing public funds. We must stop respecting people with questionable sources of wealth. If possible, we must condemn them to death - that is; if they would rather die than resign. It is even hard to fight corruption if we think that what is happening to our leaders or senior public servants is not important to us as ordinary Kenyans. The fight against corruption has deteriorated because of this attitude. We treat our leaders as if they are not Kenyans, as if they are small gods. Well, they may not be 'ordinary Kenyans' but at least they are Kenyans. We must understand that what affects our leaders affects everyone. Lastly, we suffer from a disease called 'Selective Amnesia'. We either forget or forgive easily. And we choose what to forget! We formally and informally make corrupt and incompetent leaders feel that they are still important. Our leaders can now do and get away with almost anything. You are free to forgive them, but don't forget. We must stop celebrating and honouring the people who created our problems, just because they have changed political parties. A bad leader is a bad leader no matter what party he belongs to!

TITLE: DP Ruto Chief of Staff Keitany, Gladys Shollei At EACC for Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (87%); MISAPPROPRIATION (83%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Former Judiciary Chief registrar and the suspended Chief of Staff in the office of the Deputy President are currently at the EACC for questioning over alleged corruption. Gladys Shollei was accused of irregular procurement of furniture for the judiciary during her term as Chief Registrar. Shollei also accused of flouting procurement procedures by single-sourcing for refurbishment of the office of the Chief Justice. Maryanne Keitany allegedly misappropriated Sh200 million from the Legislative and Inter-Governmental Relations Office. She is also accused of using public funds amounting to Sh100 million to marshal MPs in an attempt to impeach Devolution Cabinet Secretary Anne Waiguru.

TITLE: 70 Per Cent Kenyans Dissatisfied With State's Response to Corruption - Survey
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); RESEARCH REPORTS (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); EXECUTIVES (70%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Ninety four per cent of Kenyans do not report bribery incidents for fear of consequences and perceived inaction by authorities, a study has revealed. Seventy per cent are dissatisfied with the state's response to graft, said the Afrobarometer report released at Nairobi Safari Club on Tuesday. Sixty four per cent said the vice had increased over the past year, especially in public institutions. Of the 2,397 adults interviewed between November and December 2014, 49 per cent said they bribe police officers for help. Seventy five per cent said most or all police officers are corrupt, followed by the state at 46 per cent and Parliament at 45 per cent. The report found business executives to be the most corrupt among non-state officials. Forty per cent of the respondents said they gave bribes to access medical care and public school services, and to obtain identification documents, the report noted. It said most people offer bribes due to difficulties in accessing services. The report said 58 per cent of the respondents believed they could contribute to the anti-graft war. Top among the effective ways of eradicating corruption were refusing to give bribes and reporting incidents. Seventy six per cent voted the media the best tool for revealing corruption within the government and supporting the watchdog role.

TITLE: We Will Overcome Corruption and Terrorism, Uhuru Assures
SUBJECT: TERRORISM (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); AL-SHABAAB (79%); RELIGION (76%); PARAMILITARY & MILITIA (73%); WAR & CONFLICT (70%) Kenya; Corruption; International Terrorism
TEXT: Kenya will overcome all the challenges it is facing including terrorism and corruption, President Uhuru Kenyatta has assured. Uhuru said the success will only be achieved through joint efforts by the government and the public. "If we are to end terrorism, we must agree to come together as a nation that has preached and practised religious tolerance to defeat those who preach intolerance" he said. Speaking during the 21st PCEA General Assembly in Nairobi on Tuesday, Uhuru said his government will not relent in the war against the two vices. He said he will work with the church and all Kenyans to root our the vices for Kenya to rise to become a middle income nation. "If we overcome, the future of this nation is not only guaranteed but secured," he said. Noting that insecurity as a national problem, new PCEA moderator Julius Mwamba said the fight against the al shabaab militia group must continue in Somalia. "Mr President, terror can never be defeated through cowardice but by boldly facing and distinguishing the enemy," he said. Uhuru congratulated Mwamba, new secretary general Rev Peter Kania Kariuki and the new Honorary treasurer Amon Ng'ang'a on their new appointments. He pledged his support for them saying the church has been at the forefront of religious nourishment, education and health. He congratulated the church for holding peaceful elections for the positions and asked others to follow suit.

TITLE: Ababu Namwamba Suspended From Parliament for Refusing to Apologise Over Corruption Names At PAC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); BRIBERY (78%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Budalang'i MP Ababu Namwamba has been suspended for four days after refusing to apologize for making unsubstantiated corruption allegations against some Public Accounts Committee members. Namwamba said he cannot apologise for standing for the truth and offering good information to the anti-graft body, EACC, that can aid in their investigations. "I can never apologise for being correct, if you are right in any kind of situation speak your mind. My commitment is not through Kangaroo process and I will help where possible," he said during parliamentary proceedings at National Assembly on Wednesday. He said PAC had been used as a "sacrificial lamb" in the war against corruption and asked parliament not to compromise the EACC. "The information that I shared with the speaker and the EACC was good information that should be allowed to guide these investigations. If this House wishes to assist EACC then we will not interfere with the process. Let them interrogate what they have," he said. Namwamba said he respected the rules and customs of the house and has never violated any. "In my eight years of being here, I have not been found disrespectful to this House. I would be the last person to violate standing orders," he added. This comes a day after the National Assembly on Tuesday passed a report recommending the dissolution of the Public Accounts Committee. The House Powers and Privileges recommended the disbandment of the 27-member watchdog committee chaired by Namwamba. This means that Namwamba, Ahmed Abbas (Ijara), James Bett (Kesses), Omondi Anyanga (Nyatike), and Cecily Mbarire (Runyenjes) will be barred from the committee to be reconstituted for failing to substantiate the allegations of corruption levelled against their colleagues. The five members are also required to apologise from the Bar of the Chamber for having made claims resulting in imputing improper motive against their colleagues in the meeting of the PAC of February 26 2015. Those who fail to do so risk suspension from the House and committee business for four days, including the day of suspension. In passing the report, the House also dismissed an audio recording made by Ababu that captured the committee members, including him and ODM leader Raila Odinga, discussing the alleged bribery claims.

TITLE: Parliament Disbands Ababu Led PAC Over Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE National Assembly Tuesday passed a report recommending the dissolution of the Public Accounts Committee. The House Powers and Privileges recommended the disbandment of the 27-member watchdog committee chaired by Budalang'i MP Ababu Namwamba. The committee members were found culpable of breaching the privileges of the House after claims of receiving bribes to influence investigations against certain individuals. The Privileges Committee, chaired by Kuresoi North MP Moses Cheboi on behalf of House Speaker Justin Muturi, consequently recommended that another, newlook PAC be reconstituted within seven days of the resolution. But Nominated MP Zuleikha Hassan recorded a dissenting view, claiming that the dissolution may be construed as vilifying PAC members on unsubstantiated allegations. This means that Namwamba, Ahmed Abbas (Ijara), James Bett (Kesses), Omondi Anyanga (Nyatike), and Cecily Mbarire (Runyenjes) will be barred from the committee to be reconstituted for failing to substantiate the allegations of corruption leveled against their colleagues. The five members are also required to apologise from the Bar of the Chamber for having made claims resulting in imputing improper motive against their colleagues in the meeting of the PAC of February 26 2015. Those who fail to do so risk suspension from the House and committee business for four days, including the day of suspension. In passing the report, the House also dismissed an audio recording made by Ababu that captured the committee members, including him and ODM leader Raila Odinga, discussing the alleged bribery claims. The recording captured an MP claiming that they received bribes from Defence PS Mutea Iringo to influence the committee's findings on Sh2.8 billion in confidential expenditure. It also wants Ababu, Omondi, and Arama, who has since been de-whipped from the committee, to apologise for "their contemptuous conduct of discussing in the media matters related to the inquiry". The Privileges Committee members and the co-opted members who served in the committee during the inquiry will also not be considered in the reconstitution of the PAC, so as not to benefit from the watchdog's dissolution. For the purposes of preserving the PAC's ongoing work, the nominating committee will nominate at least six of the previous members of the PAC from either side of the majority and minority coalitions. The committee's papers, including draft reports, minutes, Hansard record and briefs, will be safeguarded for handing over to the reconstituted committee. "Since the Committee of Privileges did not inquire into matters outside breach of privilege applicable to members, the House resolves to refer the claims of bribery to the investigative agencies," the report the MPs adopted reads.

TITLE: Water Board Boss Blamed for Corruption
SUBJECT: MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); LEGAL SERVICES (90%); CORRUPTION (88%); MISAPPROPRIATION (88%); INTERNAL AUDITS (88%); AUDITS (86%) Kenya; Corruption; Water and Sanitation
TEXT: Some managers of the Lake Victoria South Water Services Board have accused CEO Moses Agumba of misappropriating funds. The managers said some law firms were paid yet they have not rendered services. "A law firm was paid yet during the financial year it had not been pre-qualified," said an official. The managers said the water board has lost a lot of money to ghost workers.
