In documents seen by the Star dated September 11 last year, internal auditor Mark Mwango raises concern over Sh9.1 million pay for legal services appearing in bank statements but not supported by vouchers. Agumba was unavailable for comment. A report of the Risk and Audit Committee of the board recommended on May 2 last year that Agumba and chief finance manager Jared Otieno step aside over financial discrepancies.

TITLE: I Will Storm EACC If I Am Not Summoned Over Corruption This Week, Sonko Says
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); LIBEL & SLANDER (78%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Nairobi Senator Mike Sonko has said he will storm the EACC to clear his name if he is not summoned over corruption allegations this week. Saying he had "missed serving Nairobi residents", Sonko asked the commission to expedite investigations. "Colleagues I was accused with have appeared before the EACC detectives. I wonder why they are playing delay tactics," he told the Star on phone on Monday. Sonko 'stepped aside' over allegedly influencing the award of a Kenya Pipeline Company tender for a share of a Sh1.35 billion kickback. The EACC corruption report claimed he was to share the bribe with suspended Energy CS Davis Chirchir. The commission has summoned several among 175 public officials implicated in graft. They include Chirchir, Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero, Siaya Senator James Orengo and cabinet secretaries Charity Ngilu (Lands), Kazungu Kambu (Labour) and Michael Kamau (Transport). Mombasa Governor Hassan Joho is set for grilling on Tuesday, for allegedly facilitating the irregular sale of Mwembe Tayari market. "I am looking forward to putting these malicious allegations and slander to rest so that we can continue improving the livelihoods of the people of Mombasa and all Kenyans," he said in a statement to newsrooms.

TITLE: War On Corruption Is Cosmetic - Transparency International
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); EXECUTIVES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); IMMUNITY (73%); WAGES & SALARIES (68%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: TRANSPARENCY International yesterday said the government has failed in the fight against corruption. Executive director Samuel Kimeu termed the government's latest effort in investigating corruption suspects as "cosmetic". "All administrative structures to fight corruption has been abandoned. What is happening at the anti-corruption commission is a smokescreen. We have doubt whether it will have any serious results," he said. Kimeu said the government failed to recover stolen money stashed away in foreign banks. "We have not seen any recovery of stolen public assets. What we are treated to are endless promises," he said. Kimeu was speaking in Nairobi yesterday during an anti-corruption conference organised by the Kenya Alliance of Resident Associations. "During the electioneering period, the Jubilee government had given a good blueprint on how to fight corruption. But it remained just that,"Kimeu said. He said EACC, the DPP and the AG are not working together in the fight against graft. "We are treated to a ping-pong that every office wants to be seen to be doing something. It does not help this country much," Kimeu said. He accused the National Assembly of being an 'epitome" of corruption. "Various departmental committees have been embroiled in scams and they seem to be enjoying parliamentary immunity," Kimeu said. He said the government should establish anti-corruption offices across all counties.There have been a lot of procurement malpractices across the counties. "We must hold our institutions to account," Kimeu said. Senior Compliant Officer at the Office of the Ombudsman Bob Bonoko said majority of Kenyans do not believe that they cannot access services in public offices unless they pay some money. He said many Kenya are continuously abandoning jobs at private institutions for public office not "because of salary but the allowances and kickbacks involved".

TITLE: Sonko Appears Before EACC Over Corruption, Denies Sh1.35 Billion KPC Tender Bribe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BRIBERY (90%); ENERGY & UTILITY POLICY (78%); PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION (78%); ETHICS (77%); ENERGY DEPARTMENTS (77%); DEEDS & RECORDINGS (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Nairobi Senator Mike Sonko has denied allegations that he influenced the irregular award of a Kenya Pipeline Company tender for a share of a bribe. The EACC corruption report claimed Sonko and suspended Energy CS Davis Chirchir colluded to share a Sh1.35 billion kickback. Sonko said he had filed a case against KPC and the Energy ministry on behalf of his constituents. "I don't understand why my name has been dragged into this dossier given to the Senate by the President. I cannot influence any pipeline deal," he said. "I was to negotiate with the government on how my area residents would be paid their Sh25 billion that I was claiming. It is not as alleged in the report." He addressed journalists after appearing before the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission on Friday. Sonko further refuted claims that President Uhuru Kenyatta was involved in the Waitiki land case as alleged by suspended Lands CS Charity Ngilu. He said the government chose to purchase the land to fulfill a pledge to the people of Mombasa. "Surveyors were sent to the land and identification of real owners done. We gave a proposal to the government that it should pay Waitiki Sh1 billion upfront after which he would surrender the title deeds to the government," he said. He added that the money was paid to the government , not to Uhuru. "Each squatter on that piece of land was to pay Sh200,000 and get a genuine deed from the government," he said.

TITLE: Two MPs Fault Corruption War
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); WAR & CONFLICT (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Two ODM MPs have accused the government of being insincere in the war on corruption. Speaking separately to the Star on the phone, Oyugi Magwanga (Kasipul) and Timothy Bosire (Kitutu Masaba) said President Uhuru Kenyatta's move to suspend EACC chairman Mumo Matemu and vice chairperson Irene Keino is suspicious.

TITLE: Corruption Blamed for Poverty
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); COUNTIES (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); ETHICS (88%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The government loses over Sh500 billion annually through corruption, Isiolo Deputy Governor Mohamed Guleid has said. Guleid asked leaders implicated in graft to step aside until their names are cleared by the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. He said poor planning by county governments made the locals to blame the system yet the problem is corruption. Addressing a two-day workshop on Sustainable Growth and Adaption in ASAL counties, Guleid said funds lost through corruption in 47 counties can be used to reduce poverty by 50 per cent. He said poor counting of during 2009 census wrongly place Isiolo county population at 147,000 instead of the 300,000.

TITLE: Increase in Corruption Crime Cases
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); ETHICS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ECONOMIC SURVEYS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (75%); CORRECTIONS (73%); CORRECTIONS WORKERS (71%); POLICE FORCES (68%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (63%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Kenya experienced a drastic upsurge in corruption-related crimes, painting a gloomy picture in the fight against graft, a survey reveals. According to the 2015 Economic Survey released yesterday, the number of corruption cases reported for investigation increased by 37 per cent from 1,423 in 2012-13 to 1,950 in 2013-14. Despite the high number of cases reported, only 70 were forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions for action, up from 49. The Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission also traced asserts valued at Sh7.2 billion and averted loss estimated at Sh5.6 billion in the last financial year. However, the anti-graft agency was able to recover public assets valued at Sh2.1 billion in the form of public land, government houses and cash in the 2013-14 year. General crime cases reported to police stations declined by 3.4 per cent from 71,832 in 2013 to 69,376 in 2014. Despite the decline, crimes related to dangerous drugs increased by 12 per cent from 4,316 in 2013 to 4,850 in 2014. Crimes related to vehicles thefts, theft by civil servants, robbery, stealing and break-ins recorded declines within the periods. Crimes reported in Nairobi declined from 8,929 in 2013 to an all time low in five years of 6,732 in 2014. Shockingly, the number of police officers dropped by 7.5 per cent to 39,215 last year from 42,145 in 2013, whereas the number of prison officers reduced marginally from 19,905 in 2013 to 19,587 in 2014. In 2014, a total of 180,223 passports were issued compared to 148,940 issued in 2013, while the number of new IDs applications made increased by 8.5 per cent from 843,642 in 2013 to 915,101 in 2014.

TITLE: No Devolved Corruption, Kachapin Tells Staffers
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); COUNTIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (88%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (80%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (51%); PEACE PROCESS (51%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: West Pokot Governor Simon Kachapin has warned county employees against corruption and laziness. "My administration will not condone lazy and corrupt officers. You signed performance contracts and you should execute your mandate," he said. Kachapin was speaking in the assembly during the State of the County Address on Wednesday. He said corruption "has crippled this country for a long time" and he will not allow it to be devolved. "The President has showed us the way by suspending corrupt officials. My administration will follow suit to ensure Kenyans get quality services," he said. Kachapin said the Pokot-Turkana border conflict has hindered development. He said he is optimistic peace meetings spearheaded by the Catholic church will bring a lasting solution to stop the animosity between communities.

TITLE: How Corruption in Society Becomes Cancerous [opinion]
SUBJECT: DISEASES & DISORDERS (88%); CANCER (88%); CORRUPTION (83%); BEER & ALE (78%); CHRONIC DISEASES (63%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (60%); BRIBERY (60%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The weekend eating of charcoal grilled nyama choma, loud rumba music in the background, bottles of beer on the table, is one of defining images of Kenya middle class. Even gender roles reflect our society. The person serving drinks is typically female, carrying her bottles around in a basket; while the meat is served by men with low BMI, who come to the table and cut the grilled piece of meat. Unlike food cooked at home, typically by women, grilling meat is taken to be a man's job and not without reason. Meat cooked over an open flame takes us back to the original man, who went to the supermarket with a spear. The temperature of good quality charcoal can reach 2,000 degrees Celsius, enough to melt iron. What makes the meat cooked over charcoal tastes so good is how the direct heat interacts with the meat. Unlike say, boiling food where the water is at about 100 degrees Celsius, the grill's high temperature rapidly browns the meat on the outside creating the intense flavours we desire. The skill of the person grilling the meat is then to manage the process of making sure the inside of the meat cooks sufficiently without burning the outside of the meat. The person who is able to grill well becomes a celebrity. It is therefore not surprising that when persons are named in a list of shame, they almost look forward to being 'grilled', taking on society to show that these high temperatures mean nothing to them. But like all things good, there are always risks and in the case of nyama choma, eating a lot of grilled food has been associated with various diseases, primarily cancer. Many people on reading this will sigh, but everything is associated with one disease or another, best to just live after all, one has to die of something! The challenge however is that most of us are living longer and chronic diseases such as cancer have the capacity to make the best years of our lives miserable. Avoiding them for as long as we can therefore makes sense. Cancer are a group of related diseases in which some of the body's cells divide and grow non-stop invading surrounding normal tissue. Cancer can be a solid tumour or in the blood and affect any part of the body. There is no specific cause, but four factors are commonly cited; genetics, the environment, socio-economic status' and your personal. In many ways cancer is just like corruption and it is interesting that we use many of the same words to describe corruption. The word 'corruption' is mid fourteenth century European meaning the breakdown of material things especially dead bodies but also of the soul. Today it is defined as the misuse of public office for private gain. Just like cancer, corruption is a group of practices. Four types are recognised; bribery, nepotism, fraud and embezzlement. Corruption can be grand or petty and it can be systematic where corrupt individuals dominate major institutions and the practice is integrated into the social and political system. A cancerous tumour can be benign, growing slowly and localised or it can be malignant aggressively invading surrounding tissues and spreading to the entire body. Signs and symptoms depend on the type of tumour, where it is located and whether it is malignant or not. A benign tumour can usually be removed and often does not recur. A malignant tumour usually has spread from its' original site, symptoms are varied and management requires extensive, aggressive and prolonged treatment, often at great risk to the life of the patient. Many patients do not survive the treatment. Holistic management of cancer therefore requires that we look at prevention. The problem as always is raising an alarm to something that appears invisible. But think about it the way we have managed polio. We still have in our society people who suffered polio, because it is only in the last ten years that it has been aggressively tackled globally and most of us cannot imagine that polio used to be so common. And it has been done by immunizing one child at a time. In similar fashion preventing cancer is about understanding the risk then managing our lifestyle one day at a time. By all means eat your nyama choma but do so in moderation. This quantity and type of meal that you are having is it really to be had every day? Corruption too is a big monster, but it is about daily practices. The World Bank talks about transparency and reciprocity, whether I would be happy letting others know what I was doing and if I would object if others did the same thing? Corruption does not allow us to enjoy the benefits of government because the health facility never gets built or the health worker does not get paid on time. As long as you remain healthy this might not be a problem, but one day for all us in our lives the day comes when we have to face this cancer. What then?

TITLE: Senior City Hall Officials Named in Corruption Cleared for Prosecution - EACC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); COUNTIES (88%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (88%); INVESTIGATIONS (86%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Senior Nairobi county employees arraigned in court over corruption claims have been cleared for prosecution, the EACC has said. CEO Halakhe Waqo said DPP Keriako Tobiko gave consent to charge the suspects arraigned on April 17. Waqo did not name the suspects whose file he said was among seven cleared and forwarded to the DPP for further direction He said the team formed by the EACC, the ODPP and the Directorate of Criminal Investigations has complicated investigations on 25 files so far. The files have been submitted to the DPP's technical team. Waqo assured that investigations on government officials implicated in graft are going on well. He urged those summoned in the next few days to cooperate, and students to refrain from accompanying them to the EACC. The EACC has 14 days to conclude investigations into 175 government officials named in its 'list of shame' in March.

TITLE: Here Is the Question - Are We Losing the War On Corruption? [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); ETHICS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); SCANDALS (89%); INDICTMENTS (77%); CONSPIRACY (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); WRITERS (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Our national battle against corruption appears to have entered perilous waters. Two commissioners from the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission have resigned in rapid succession, and the chairman is under investigation by a Judicial Tribunal. This surprisingly taking place shortly after the President had taken unprecedented action against his own Cabinet members and senior government employees alleged accused of corruption. In a hard-hitting statement in his State of the Nation address to Parliament, the President instructed the Director of Public Prosecutions to indict and charge the officials within 60 days, if and where there was evidence of corruption. Before the ink on the Presidential statement had dried, Parliament moved to dissolve the EACC and swiftly recommended the appointment of a Judicial Tribunal. Despite protestations by commissioners that systemic corruption, and in particular persons involved in the Anglo Leasing scandal were fighting back with the sole aim of their removal or extermination, they were unceremoniously hounded out of office. They were condemned to the same fate as their predecessors, John Harun Mwau, Aaron Ringeera and PLO Lumumba. Which brings us to the question, do Kenyans honestly and forthrightly want to tackle corruption, or are we simply engaging in window dressing? How can non-other than the President of the Republic of Kenya declare outright war on corruption, only for a Parliamentary Committee to devise a method of scuttling the same? What is the point of having an Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission that is not only toothless but is regularly and flippantly emasculated by Parliament? Or could there be a cabal of powerful individuals out to sabotage the national putsch against corruption? Conspiracy theorists including the opposition coalition Cord are on record as stating the government is insincere about tackling corruption. Some political columnists have recently had the courage to state that the EACC was created to fry the small fish, that is, petty corruption and never ever mega corruption. It was, therefore, a faí_ade to hoodwink gullible Kenyans that the state was intent on eradicating graft when in fact it was silently facilitating the same. Some EACC officials in the course of their duties either due to inflated egos and possibly illusions of grandeur, on occasion ventured beyond their unwritten and unspoken mandate leading to their immediate ouster. If any of these theories bear even a scintilla of truth then our fight against corruption faces an arduous uphill battle. Mega corruption in Kenya is thought to have begun with the Kenren Fertiliser scandal in the mid 1970s. Details of the same, however, remain scanty. The biggest scandal was Goldenberg, during the watch of retired President Daniel Arap Moi, the effects of which are felt far and wide almost bringing our economy to its knees. It was swiftly followed by Anglo Leasing which was manufactured during the same term but matured during the watch of retired President Mwai Kibaki in our third government. In all these mega scandals, the architects were senior government officials with connections in very high places, and offices occasionally colluding with corrupt and unscrupulous businessmen. The tentacles of mega corruption like the hydra of Greek mythology are multi-headed and multifaceted. They have their links across several political regimes since independence. The architects and beneficiaries of multi-corruption are extremely wealthy and powerful, and have agents in every sector of our economy including Parliament and government. Efforts at eradicating corruption, therefore, require support from the highest office in the land; otherwise they are doomed to fail. The decision by President Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta to take the bull of corruption by the horns, the political and economic interests of its architects notwithstanding, was extremely courageous and noble. It was a move in the right direction as was acknowledged by the standing ovation by Parliamentarians. Known to be fabulously wealthy and one of the few Kenyan leaders who have not engaged in or benefited from corruption, citizens have high hopes in his setting structures to eradicate systemic corruption in Kenya. The Jubilee government is perhaps the only one in recent times that has not rewarded itself with a mega-corruption scandal immediately after a Presidential and general election. Much is therefore expected of them and failure would not augur well for their 2017 re-election.

TITLE: DPP Approves Wairia, Adul's Prosecution Over Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); APPROVALS (90%); MISCONDUCT (88%); EVIDENCE (78%); ETHICS (77%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (76%); COUNTIES (76%); MISAPPROPRIATION (75%); GRANTS & GIFTS (72%); FOOD CHARITIES (52%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: DPP Keriako Tobiko has approved the prosecution of Murang'a Governor Mwangi Wairia, Kisumu Speaker Anne Adul and MPs Alfred Keter and Sonia Birdi over corruption. The prosecution commences immediately, Tobiko said in a statement to newsrooms on Monday. He said he had received 10 files from the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission, seven of which he had made decisions on. Decisions on the remaining three will be made soon, he said. Wairia is accused of swearing a false declaration submitted to the EACC on December 11, 2012. Adul allegedly contracted an agent irregularly at a cost of Sh15.4 million for 70 MCAs and county staff who travelled to Singapore,Israel and China. Keter and Adul are accused of misconduct over confronting police at the Gilgil weighbridge. Tobiko recommended the EACC refer their case to the National Assembly for disciplinary action against. He further directed EACC to initiate appropriate mechanisms for the removal of the two MPs from office. He also allowed prosecution of a Deputy county commission and a District clerk in Garissa who allegedly misappropriated relief food. Tobiko however closed the inquiry into the alleged misappropriation of a Sh15.9 million grant by the Industrialisation ministry to the EPZA over lack of evidence. He further rejected EACC's recommendation to close investigations into the Sh244 million NSSF tender allegedly awarded to Micro City computers irreguklarly.

TITLE: Kisumu Speaker, Minority Leader Charged Over Corruption, Released on Sh2 Million Bond Each
SUBJECT: POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONSPIRACY (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); ARRESTS (78%); CRIMINAL ASSAULT & BATTERY (76%); INVESTIGATIONS (75%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); POLICE FORCES (71%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Kisumu Speaker Ann Adul and Minority leader Edwin Anayo were released on Sh2 million bond each when they appeared in court over graft on Tuesday. Others granted release on the same terms were Clerk Nelco Sagwe, county assembly service board member Margaret Jobit and Mombasa-based contractors Samuel Otieno and Miriam Omondi. The accused, who denied the charges before principal magistrate Thomas Obutu, were granted an alternative cash bail of Sh1 million each. Adul, Anayo, Ong'ow, Sagwe and Jobita were accused of failing to comply with procurement laws. They allegedly single-sourced MS Factor Connect to facilitate trips to Israel, China and Singapore for MCAs and county staff for Sh17.4 million, breaching procurement procedures. Adul and her husband Elijah were also accused of conspiracy to defraud the public. They allegedly conspired to defraud the Kisumu government of Sh17.4 million for the three trips between April and July 2014. Suspended Majority leader Samuel Ong'ow also appeared in court but was ordered into custody until 3pm Wednesday for allegedly resisting arrest and assaulting two EACC officials on Monday. Ong'ow, who also denied the charges, allegedly mobilised a crowd to attack the officers whom his brother Jack was also accused of assaulting. Principal prosecutor Lameck Sirtuy had asked the court to remand Ong'ow for three days for further investigation. Ong'ow's lawyer Richard Onsongo said he later presented himself at Kisumu Railways Police Station and was released on a cash bail. The case will be mentioned on May 26 and heard on July 9.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption War - Economy Ministry Pursues Sensitisation
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (89%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (78%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (73%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (53%) Cameroon; Corruption
TEXT: The Minister of the Economy, Planning and Regional Development, MINEPAT, Emmanuel Nganou Djoumessi, has told his aides and potential users of his ministry's services that the country's objective to become a middle income economy by 2035 will only be achieved if corruption is properly dealt with. Cameroon, like many developing countries, has been held hostage by the canker worm which to Nganou Djoumessi, inhibits economic growth. Cameroon needs to protect its image by making itself investment-friendly, he explained. Emmanuel Nganou Djoumessi made the remarks in Yaounde, yesterday, December 9, 2014, as he chaired an open-day to intensify the war against corruption in the ministry and its devolved units. He challenged the Anti-corruption Unit and Regional Delegates to champion good governance as the outfit battles to process files on time, thereby propelling the country's growth drive. He hailed government, partners and civil society organisations for the fight to scale down the social vice. The President of the Anti-Corruption Unit of the Ministry, Monkam Nitcheu M.J, stressed that the objective was to rupture the graft chain by raising awareness among stakeholders on the "Zero corruption in MINEPAT" campaign. She argued that corruption impacts the economy negatively and must be stopped for the country to successfully implement its Growth and Economy Strategy Paper. On exhibition were books on corruption. Denunciation boxes were also distributed to MINEPAT Regional Delegates. They are expected to be used for whistle blowing, with the keys kept in the headquarters in Yaounde. The whistle blowing boxes will be emptied from time to time and sanctions taken against culprits. Monkam Nitcheu M.J said a brochure to sensitise personnel and the public has also been made available as well a hot line - 222 221 197 - for reporting corrupt practices.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption - Much Resistance, Many Obstacles
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (73%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (67%) Cameroon; Corruption
TEXT: The National Anti-corruption Commission yesterday presented reports from stakeholders. The Chairman of the National Anti-corruption Commission, CONAC, says there is still a lot of resistance by some government ministries to fighting the ill. Speaking at the Yaounde Conference yesterday, October 30, 2014, at the public presentation of results of the seventh phase of the campaign involving 26 government ministries, State-funded projects and corporations, Rev. Dr. Dieudonní© Massi Gams, said despite a presidential directive, some ministries were yet to engage in the fight. On the other hand, some ministries launch highly publicised, supposed anti-corruption campaigns, only to end at that level; with nothing done on the field after. He cited the glaring case of 38 stakeholders that engaged in the seventh phase of the anti-corruption drive on April 15, 2014, but 12 later dropped out for unknown reasons. Thus, only 26 stakeholders completed the Rapid Results Initiative, which entailed targeting specific aspects of corruption in their organisations and combatting them in 100 days. Dr Massi Gams acknowledged that fighting corruption in any part of the world was fraught with obstacles, adding that this should not in any way discourage stakeholders. The CONAC Chair called on the ministries, State corporations and projects, which had embarked on the fight to sustain the campaign. He expressed hope that the fight will be taken to the grassroots for Cameroonians to feel the impact, pointing out that the ultimate judge of the efforts was the public. The Chairman of the National Anti-corruption Commission was also hopeful that Cameroon's fight against the ill will ultimately yield palpable results; without which the country cannot become emergent by 2035. He said the desire was to one day become like Botswana which has been adjudged to be the least corrupt African nation. Talking about the case of the Cameroon National Oil Refinery, SONARA, the General Manager, Talba Malla, said focus this time was on curbing malpractices in the loading of oil tankers with petroleum products. Though he said an 80 per cent success rate was recorded within 100 days, there was still a long way to go as both the State and oil tanker owners needed to get their right due from such transactions. The presentation of anti-corruption evaluation results by the remaining 13 government ministries, State corporations and projects, ends today, October 31, 2014.

TITLE: TI-Cameroon Urges Women to Denounce Acts of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (91%); CIVIC & SOCIAL ORGANIZATIONS (90%); WOMEN (90%); ALLIANCES & PARTNERSHIPS (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS (77%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (73%); LEGAL AID (69%); ACTORS & ACTRESSES (64%) Cameroon; Women and Gender; Corruption
TEXT: Some women's association representatives are being trained in Yaounde by Transparency International-Cameroon. Representatives from some women's associations that advocate the promotion and protection of human rights are undergoing training in Yaounde organized by Transparency International-Cameroon on how they can actively be involved in the fight against corruption. A two-day workshop opened yesterday September 25, 2014, at the TI-Cameroon Headquarters, Yaounde to challenge them denounce corruption acts. TI-Cameroon holds that women are shy and reluctant to denounce acts of corruption that demean and push the country's economy to the wall. The international anti-corruption body challenged them to embrace and utilize its Advocacy and Legal Advisory Centre to stop corruption from spreading like cancer in the country. Opening yesterday's get-together, TI-Cameroon's President, Barrister Charles Nguini, enjoined the women to relay to the various associations and communities the need to join national and international partners in winning the war on corruption by reporting cases for exposure. They were reminded that TI-Cameroon's Advocacy and Advisory Centre is ready to assists them structure their complaints, propose follow-up to their files, analyse data and conduct advocacy for policy changes as well as work in partnership with lawyers continuously registered with the Cameroon Bar Association; in order to provide free legal assistance to victims and witnesses of corruption. TI-Cameroon reveals that out of 600 victims of corruption recorded in Cameroon recently, only 52 cases (about 8 per cent) are denounced by women. And given the preponderant role they play in the family and the education of the child, they should therefore be core actresses in the fight against corruption. Reason why yesterday's workshop that ends today September 26, 2014, is baptised: "Women and the Fight Against Corruption," to sensitise them on the importance alongside mechanisms on waging a serious war against the scourge.

TITLE: Evaluating the Cost of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); WRITERS (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (88%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (87%); NATIONAL LIBRARIES (78%); LITERATURE (77%); JOURNALISM (77%); CREATIVE WRITING (77%); LIBRARIES (71%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (71%) Cameroon; Corruption
TEXT: There is no gainsaying that corruption has already been identified as a major hindrance to Cameroon's development. The fact that the country has twice been infamously listed as the most corrupt nation in the world has not left the authorities and creative writers indifferent. And so Sammy Oke Akombi's latest literary piece, 'The Wages Of Corruption,' was launched in Yaounde on Friday, August 29, 2014, at the Contemporary Arts Gallery/National Library. Speaking at the event, the first reviewer, Jerome Ndjock, a Sub-Director in the Ministry of Communication, said most characters in the 13 stories seek to improve their livelihoods by hook or crook. He described corruption as the consequence of the deviant behaviour of Cameroonians, not a curse. According to him, the solution to the problem lies in leading a life guided by a free conscience. The second reviewer, former university rector, Prof. Beban Sammy Chumbow, described the author as an evangelist crusading against corruption. Corruption, he noted, is so endemic in the country that the stories, which he qualified as a compendium of episodes, better portray it through their true-to-life angling with which readers can easily identify. Referring to Biblical consequences of sin, Prof. Chumbow said corruption attracts curses and damnation even much later in life. "The book is well-written in simple pose, making copious use of idiomatic expressions, with the episodes believable. The author has researched well into the subject and everyone who reads it will be touched. It x-rays corruption to help the common man see it from various dimensions. 'The Wages Of Corruption' is therefore a mirror of various facets of corruption in our society," concluded Prof. Beban Sammy Chumbow. Commenting on his work, Sammy Oke Akombi, who is Director of the Buea Pilot Linguistic Centre in the South West Region, said society should not wait for things to get out of hand before taking strong action against corruption. The event also saw an ovation-reception for a recital of the poem, 'To my brother the thief,' by Sammy Oke Akombi, which was performed by a group of young boys. The chair of the occasion was Mrs. Lydia Efimba, while veteran journalist, Eno Chris Oben, served as compere.

TITLE: Britain Advocates Anti-Corruption Law
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); EMERGING MARKETS (89%); BRIBERY (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (77%) Cameroon; Corruption; Governance; Europe and Africa
TEXT: The British High Commissioner to Cameroon, Brian Olley, encouraged Cameroon to adopt an anti-corruption law as quickly as possible to curb the scourge and entice investors so as to jump start the country's economic growth. The British diplomat was speaking to the press in Yaounde on Thursday July 10, 2014 at his residence ahead of a round-table discussion on challenges in tackling corruption in Cameroon. The round-table brought together stakeholders from the government, British business community in Cameroon as well as the private sector. Brian Olley explained that corruption inhibits economic growth of countries around the globe but was proud to announce that the United Kingdom (UK) remains the lone country in the world with the strongest anti-corruption law. The 2010 Anti-bribery Act which compels British companies anywhere in the world to subject to the law has been a plus in tackling the canker worm. He therefore announced his country's willingness to share the contours of such an act with stakeholders in the fight against corruption in Cameroon so as to benefit businesses. The Anti-bribery Act in use for over four years is causing panic amongst corporate bodies in Britain and people are being prosecuted under it. The British High Commissioner revealed his determination to work with government and the private sector more efficiently. Given that corruption is one of the greatest constraints to development and that where it prevails, resources are wasted and mismanaged, potential for investments remains untapped and investors are deterred participants at last Thursday's round-table discussed how reinforced training can help reduce and why not eradicate the scourge.

TITLE: Government Pledges Renewed War Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (90%); EMBEZZLEMENT (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (88%); SENTENCING (62%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (60%) Cameroon; Corruption
TEXT: The Minister of Communication, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, read out the following statement at a press briefing in Yaounde on July 3, 2014. The Minister of State, Minister of Justice, Keeper of the Seals, The Secretary General of the Ministry of Justice, The Secretary General of the Ministry of Communication, The Inspector General, Technical Advisers, Distinguished Inspectors, Distinguished Directors and Head of Divisions, Distinguished Collaborators, Fellow Journalists, Distinguished Guests, Ladies and Gentlemen, It is with a renewed pleasure that I welcome you, once again, in this conference hall of my ministry which has become the usual venue of our meetings, to exchange, in all conviviality and frankness, on issues of major importance relating to the life of our nation and the well-being of our populations. It is about the fight against the embezzlement of public funds initiated by the Head of State, His Excellency Paul BIYA, also known as the " fight against corruption ". Allow me first of all, to acknowledge the presence, of His Excellency, the Minister of State, Minister of Justice, Keeper of the Seals, who has, in spite of his tight agenda, accepted to be here with me for this press briefing. Mr. Minister of State, you are welcome to the Ministry of Communication. Allow me also to take this opportunity to wish you all, fellow journalists, a warm welcome in this conference hall, and to thank you all, for your prompt reaction to the invitation I sent to you today. Dear Guests, Fellow Journalists As you must have noticed, for the past few weeks, there is a certain opinion restlessly working to throw doubt on the sincerity of the fight against corruption inscribed and underscored by the Head of State in his priority actions to restore good behaviours and guarantee the protection of public wealth. This opinion, widely relayed by a range of both national and international media, seems to be grounded on the commutation and remittance of sentences following the presidential decree nÁ2014/058 of 18 February, 2014 to commit and remit sentences, and which, undoubtedly for the first time, was extended to our compatriots sentenced for embezzling public funds. This opinion claims that the release of some prisoners, pursuant to presidential decree of last February 18, or even only under normal judicial procedures, would ring a death knell on the crusade against embezzlement of public funds led by the Head of State and the judicial branch of our country. This interpretation of facts, which I qualify as inaccurate, leads me to first throw light and give some details that are necessary for understanding the situation, and secondly, to express the full determination of the President of the Republic, His Excellency Paul BIYA, to relentlessly continue without any complacency, the fight against the embezzlement of public funds in our country. Regarding the decree of 18 February 2014 to commute and remit sentences, allow me to first of all underline that the Constitution of the Republic of Cameroon states that the President of the Republic " exercises the power of mercy ... ". Mercy by definition is the partial or full commutation and remittance of sentences, conditioned or not by safety measures and probation obligations. Meanwhile, mercy remains without effect on the sentence and applies only to the execution of the sentence. Pecuniary sentences (damages, cost of the procedure) remain due. This important text of the Head of State, the decree of 18 February 2014, came out in an exceptional context, full of history and significance for the life of our nation. This had to do with the commemoration of the Fiftieth Anniversary of the Reunification of our dear and beautiful country, which was an opportunity for us to celebrate the virtues of national unity, peace and tolerance, so dear to the Cameroonian people. Reacting on this issue at the end of the ceremony to inaugurate the Fiftieth Anniversaries' Monument in Buea, the Head of State seized the opportunity to explain to his compatriots the real reasons justifying his decision to sign this decree which, also, falls within the prerogatives conferred to him by the Constitution of Cameroon. Allow me to quote him once again: " With regard to the remittance of sentences, this is to show the importance for us to nurture unity. I wanted it to be a great moment of joy. And that, this joy should also reach even those who were somehow at war with the law. Some have also recovered their freedom. We want it to be a great moment of joy and happiness to enhance national unity ", end of quote. Moreover, it is worth highlighting that the decree of 18 February 2014 is a text of general scope and immediate effect, applicable to all those falling within the framework of the 13 cases targeted in the 13 paragraphs of the said decree. Regarding the persons sentenced to prison terms for embezzlement of public funds, the pertinent provisions are contained in paragraphs 4, 5 and 6 of the abovementioned decree. It therefore appears that a total of 24 000 prisoners across 77 prisons benefited from the presidential mercy. It is clear as you may have noticed that this decree was not tailored to suit specific prisoners as falsely claimed by a given opinion. Dear Journalists, Distinguished guests, Since his accession to the helm of the Nation on 6 November 1982, the Head of State has made the fight against corruption and misappropriation of public funds a constant orientation of his policy, as clearly emphasized in his different addresses to the Nation. Thus, in his very first inauguration speech before parliamentarians at the National Assembly on 6 November 1982, the President of the Republic, His Excellency Paul BIYA set the course for this relentless fight he was intending against all managers misappropriating public funds in the following terms and I quote: " In these tough times we are going through, the great and long process of nation building implies... rigour in management and perseverance in effort against manoeuvres of demoralization, demobilization and destabilization ". Since then, he has kept reasserting his firm commitment to taking repressive action against acts of corruption and embezzlement of public funds. In his end of year address to the nation on 31 December 2005, the Head of State, in a peremptory tone, firmly denounced and condemned this social ill, in the following words : " The embezzlement of public funds is detrimental to the national community. Let me very solemnly say it today, that it must stop ", end of quote. In the same vein, in his communication during the Ministerial Council of 12 September 2007, the President of the Republic, His Excellency Paul BIYA, reiterated his determination to fight this ill. Let me quote him again: " The embezzlement of public funds, no matter which form it may take, is a crime against the People that are being deprived of their resources. This must therefore be severely sanctioned ", end of quote. Such determination which, as we all noticed, is not an improvisation in the Governance policy of the President of the Republic, was translated by the creation of several institutions vested with specific missions, each one in their area of competence, and which are provided with the necessary means to systematically track down cases of misappropriation of public funds. The actions carried out by the Supreme State Audit which is the gendarme or better still the secular arm of the State in matters of control of the sound management of public funds fall within this framework. In the same vein and as far as the specific domains of money laundering and corruption are concerned, the National Financial Investigation Agency (ANIF) and the National Anti-Corruption Commission (CONAC) were set up in May 2005 and March 2006 respectively. In a certain measure, administrations like the Ministry of Public Contracts, the General Delegation for National Security, the Secretariat of State in charge of the Gendarmerie, or the Public Contracts Regulatory Board, actively participate in the fight against corruption, each one in its area of competence. All these administrations are fully operational today and perform their duties in this field on a daily basis. Today, there is no doubt on that those people who attempt to misappropriate public funds are tracked down wherever they may be, arrested and put at the disposal of the judiciary which in all independency, establishes the responsibilities of all. Dear Journalists, Dear Guests, Allow me now to give some indications on the creation and implementation of the Special Criminal Court (SCC), set up by virtue of Law nÁ2001/028 of 14 December 2011. It is undoubtedly to, first, stress on the political will to confer a specific character to the fight against corruption, and secondly, to solve the issue of celerity in the settlement of legal disputes relating to the organized economic and financial criminality, that the Head of State proposed to Members of Parliament to set up this special jurisdiction. The Special Criminal Court, which is not a court of exception, aims essentially at fighting the misappropriation of public funds whereby the prejudice incurred by the State is equal to or above fifty million CFA francs. In order to guarantee an efficient functioning of the Special Criminal Court, the President of the Republic has signed different instruments, including Decree No. 2013/131 of 03 May 2013 relating to the establishment, organisation, functioning of the specialized Corps of Judicial Police Officers of the Special Criminal Court. Moreover, the modalities for the paying back of the corpus delicti are established by Decree No. 2013/228 of 04 September 2013. This new provision, pursuant to the provisions of article 18 of the law establishing the Special Criminal Court, habilitates the Public Prosecutor at the Special Criminal Court to terminate any prosecution, upon written authorization from the Minister of Justice, when the corpus delicti has been paid back. It is worth underlining that both the courts of first instance and high courts are competent in this matter, when the embezzled funds amount to less than fifty million (FCFA 50 000 000). The whole of these legal instruments created by the Head of State are today fully functional and the processing of cases forwarded to the Special Criminal Court by High Courts has been obviously speeded-up. For instance, 119 cases from High Courts have been transferred to the Special Criminal Court. Thirty nine (39) of these cases were immediately enrolled. These cases have been subject to or are still subject to public hearings which are, and it is worth mentioning, open to all. As concerns the cases undergoing judicial investigation, to date, 19 defendants have benefited from a dismissal of charges and one hundred and seven (107) were referred back to the Special Criminal Court. As of 3 April 2014, the Special Criminal Court has ruled over fifty-two (52) cases among which 36 on the merits and 16 on the preliminaries. Twenty-six (26) defendants have been freed, and 51 sentenced. Some of them have appealed. With the effective putting in place of the Specialized Corps of Judicial Police Officers of the Special Criminal Court, some investigations have resumed. Now, as far as the sums due to the State are concerned, these are related to the paying back of the corpus delicti in cash, fines, and costs of procedure as well as damages. As for the issue of paying back the corpus delicti by some defendants who solicited the stay of proceedings, the sums already paid into State coffers and which were deposited in an account open at the Public Treasury, amount to two billion four hundred and one million two hundred and thirty five thousand six hundred and ten CFA Francs (2 billion 401 million 235 thousand 610). Sixteen arrested persons have already benefited from this measure. Concerning fines and procedure costs, these are estimated at one million CFA francs and six hundred and two million three hundred and twenty-three thousand six hundred and twelve CFA Francs (602 million 323 thousand 612 CFA Francs). To date, the Special Criminal Court has already ruled for the payment of damages worth twelve billion one hundred and sixty-four million six hundred and eighty-two thousand five hundred and four CFA Francs (164 million 682 thousand 504 CFA Francs). Dear Journalists, Dear Guests, As we all notice, the mission of the Special Criminal Court is neither to condemn at all costs, nor pronounce only acquittals, even though there is a certain opinion believing this to be the way one can truly judge the independency of the judiciary. The Special Criminal Court is a common law jurisdiction whose functioning is contingent upon sustainability and is not to be viewed in terms of " operation ". So, even if some defendants have already been sentenced or acquitted by a given partisan opinion, all of them, whoever they may be, should benefit from the presumption of innocence and we should all respect the secrecy of not only the judicial investigations but also the secrecy of preliminary investigations. Allow me to remark in relation to this, that every judicial procedure can lead either to a condemnation for proven fact, or a dismissal of charges for unproven fact, or an acquittal. In another case, every inmate may, as it was the case in February, from mercy, commutation of sentence, or remission of sentence. These of course are a prerogative of the Head of State as provided by the Constitution. It is worth mentioning that, the power of a conviction does not make it a truth. Therefore, whatever the opinion, rumour, convictions of one or others, the judge is solely empowered to pronounce the guilt or acquittal of a defendant. And if one considers his trial to be unfair, he or she is entitled to refer to appeal courts provided for by the law. Fellow Journalists, Dear Guests, The importance which the Head of State confers to fostering good morals and to the priority of the general interest in the management of public funds, which are undeniably a pillar of our development, can never be overemphasized. Therefore, on 15 September 2011, during the Third Ordinary Congress of the Cameroon Peoples' Democratic Movement, the Head of State, in his general policy opening speech, did not miss, once again, to warn CPDM militants and all managers of public wealth. And I quote: " Be aware, Ladies and Gentlemen, that my determination to fight this scourge is total and the fight against corruption will go on with more intensity, without fear and complacency, discrimination, notwithstanding the social status or the political affiliation of the accused persons. Nobody should consider himself to be above the law ", end of quote. Recently, the Head of State, in his 31 December 2013 address to the Nation, severely criticized selfish attitudes of some of our compatriots, who do not refrain from taking all necessary steps for their personal success at the detriment of the general interest. Allow me to quote him once again: " Our Administration remains permeable to selfish interest. This is most often incompatible with the interest of the national community. In a modern State, this drift cannot be tolerated ", end of quote. This determination of the President of the Republic to relentlessly fight corruption and embezzlement of public funds, which is a precondition for the effective development and emergence of Cameroon by 2035, requires the entire support of the People who vested this task upon him. The administration of justice is a mission conferred to a special corps by the Constitution. This is the reason why I invite Cameroonians of all walks of life to give entire support to our judiciary and to let the Special Criminal Court and other relevant courts to work in all serenity in order to issue fair decisions within a reasonable timeframe and as set forth by the law. Thank you for your kind attention.

TITLE: Isaac Rutto at EACC Over Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); LAWYERS (87%); EMERGENCY VEHICLES (70%); GAS STATIONS (52%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Bomet Goverrnor Isaac Rutto is at the EACC for questioning on graft claims stated in a report tabled before the Senate in March. He was with his lawyer and a bodyguard when he arrived at Integrity Centre at about 10am on Tuesday. Rutto allegedly hired Kenya Red Cross Society ambulances at Sh650,000 a month through single-sourcing. He is also accused of accumulating wealth including 40 earth movers, tippers and grades at an estimated Sh400million, and a chopper valued at Sh300million. "Rutto bought a palatial house in Ngong worth Sh33million and operates numerous petrol service stations," the report further alleges. The governor denied the claims saying his conscience is "crystal clear" and that he has never misused any public funds.

TITLE: Uhuru Gives State Organs Two-Week Ultimatum on Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (90%); EXECUTIVE ORDERS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); EXECUTIVES (79%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (78%); SCANDALS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (78%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (78%); ELECTRONIC PROCUREMENT (75%); TALKS & MEETINGS (74%); COUNTIES (73%); BRIBERY (73%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (69%); CIVIL SERVICES (67%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: PRESIDENT Uhuru Kenyatta has acknowledged that mega corruption threatens to paralyse service delivery in his administration. Consequently, he has ordered all State corporations to furnish his office with details of their anti-graft strategy - within two weeks. Stung by the runaway corruption, Uhuru, in a hard-hitting but confidential Executive Order, bitterly protested "outright theft and blatant breaches of ethical standards" by State and public officers. In a rare confession, the President said that the conduct of some State and public officers falls far short of the demands of the constitution and Kenyans' expectations. "Corruption and its network have acted as constraints to the desire of my administration to deliver effective public services," Uhuru lamented in the Executive Order exclusively obtained by the Star. "These unsavoury, unethical and corrupt practices continue to be perpetuated and thrive in spite of various reminders and warnings." In a bold move to restore confidence in the public service, the President, who flew out to Japan yesterday, instructed all State corporations to furnish his office with what he termed "a comprehensive action plan" against corruption. "The action plan must contain: express timelines, identified responsible officers and means of measurement and delivery, against which the extent of compliance and implementation shall be gauged," he ordered. The Executive Order, dated last week, was copied to all Cabinet secretaries, Principal secretaries, the attorney general and chief executive officers of all constitutional and State corporations plus county commissioners. Part of the directive is that all State corporations must within two weeks furnish his office with details of all procurement deals sealed since his administration took over in 2013 - complete with contract value and awardees. The Jubilee administration has been hit by a series of mega sleaze scams, including the Sh50 million ChickenGate affair, the Sh100 million 'Hustler's Jet' probe and a Sh2 billion Judiciary scandal. Budalang'i MP Ababu Namwamba has, for instance, linked Defence Principal Secretary Mutea Iringo to the bribery of at least four MPs in a bid to water down a Parliamentary Accounts Committee report on embezzlement of Sh2.8 billion. "At the meeting, it was agreed that Mr. Iringo would provide money and facilitate business opportunities at the Department of Defence (DoD). At least KSh 1.5 million is confirmed to have been collected in cash from Mr. Iringo," Ababu said in a letter to National Assembly Speaker Justin Muturi. Uhuru also directed all State corporations to immediately arrange to migrate their procurement systems to an electronic procurement platform. "Communication about the status of migration should reach my office within two weeks of receipt of this Executive Order. Any delay shall invite corrective action," he warned. In what appears to be a strategy to face off with corrupt officers, the President urged civil servants to directly get in touch with his office should they receive pressure to engage in unethical, corrupt or illegal conduct. "In furtherance of the mission to get rid of corruption, I am, therefore, directing all relevant institutions in the Ethics and Anti-graft War (EACC, DPP and National Police Service) to act swiftly, without fear or favour, and take necessary measures to detect, investigate and prosecute all instances of corruption in all its manifestations, irrespective of the status of the perpetrators," he directed. Uhuru warned that every accounting or responsible officer shall be held personally liable for any use or movement of public monies contrary to the law, including prosecution and recovery of any loss. Critics have accused Uhuru of failing to sack Energy Minister Davis Chirchir even after the latter's implication by a British court in the ChickenGate sleaze, one of the most well-documented corruption cases in Kenyan history.

TITLE: City Stadium a Haven for Corruption - Reps
SUBJECT: STADIUMS & ARENAS (91%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PARKING SPACES & FACILITIES (90%); COUNTIES (78%); SPORTS & RECREATION FACILITIES & VENUES (73%); SPORTS & RECREATION (55%); SPORTS (55%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Nairobi MCAs yesterday accused the county executive of condoning corruption in the renovation of City Stadium. A report on the status of the stadium shows that it is still in poor state despite so much money being spent on its renovation. "The bathrooms and washrooms are in a poor state. The stadium facility is understaffed and officers who had been trained on maintenance have been transferred to other sports facilities," said MCA Wilson Ochola. Ochola, who is the chairperson of the Committee on Labour and Social Welfare, tabled the report in the county assembly yesterday. The report said security within the stadium is not guaranteed and the parking lot is not secured nor landscaped. MCAs recommended that the shanty structures outside stadium be demolished. They urged the executive to put up modern kiosks at City Stadium. "Our planning department should review the plan of the stadiums parking lot and clearly demarcate parking lot and other designated areas for development," Ochola said. "Well-equipped security officers should be deployed in the stadium to provide security both within and without the facility round the clock. A security room should be established within the facility for the operations."

TITLE: Raila On PAC Bribery - I Have Never Condoned Corruption in My Life
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); POLITICS (75%); PRESS CONFERENCES (57%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: CORD leader Raila Odinga has told MPs to leave him out of the corruption allegations bedeviling the Public Accounts Committee. "I have never condoned corruption in my life and the issue must be dealt with holistically and investigated thoroughly," he said during a press briefing at Orange house, Nairobi on Wednesday. Raila said investigating agencies must not narrow down to one individual since corruption allegations consisted of a "receiver" and a "giver." He noted that Parliament had mentioned the receiver but said nothing of the giver. The Cord leader made the remarks amid Parliament's Powers and Privileges Committee plans to summon him to shed light on corruption allegations facing PAC chairman Ababu Namwamba. Namwamba is said to have secretly taped a private conversation between him and the ODM party leader, in which an MP admitted receiving cash to influence a PAC report. A faction of ODM leaders has called for Ababu's sacking as Secretary General of the party, citing a betrayal of trust. "If indeed it's true that Namwamba taped Raila without consent, then that smacks of betrayal of trust and a sign of bad faith whatever reason there could be," said ODM Treasurer Timothy Bosire. Last week, National Assembly Speaker Justin Muturi mandated the Parliament's Powers and Privileges Committee to probe Ababu and submit a report in 21 days.

TITLE: I'll Overcome Corruption Claims, Says Namwamba to Budalang'i
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); MISAPPROPRIATION (73%); EVIDENCE (72%); SUITS & CLAIMS (72%); LAWYERS (71%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (67%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (67%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: BUDALANG'I MP Ababu Namwamba has asked his constituents to stop worrying about tribulations he is facing in the parliamentary Public Accounts Committee. The legislator, who chairs the committee, told his constituents they elected him to represent them in parliament and not in the committee. "Whether I am in or out of the committee, I will not relent in the fight against corruption and its perpetrators," Namwamba said. He was speaking yesterday at Bunyala Model High School, Nayera, where he handed over an administration block constructed through the CDF kitty. Last week, the Speaker of the National Assembly Justin Muturi suspended the operations of the parliamentary watchdog body amid graft claims. Muturi directed the committee on Powers and Privileges to investigate the claims and report to the house within 21 days. Namwamba said his tribulations are "merely orchestrated by corrupt individuals, who are fighting back". The ODM secretary general said he is innocent and determined to soldier on. He criticised his detractors who recently sued Budalang'i CDF committee in a Busia court over alleged misappropriation of funds. Namwamba said the court threw out the case due to lack of evidence. He said he has instructed his lawyers to take action against the complainants for damaging his reputation. Namwamba rejected the recent court ruling terming the CDF Act unconstitutional. He said MPs are doing everything to ensure the kitty remains in their hands out of public interest.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Plan for Varsity
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Education
TEXT: The University of Eldoret has developed a new policy to prevent and fight corruption. Vice Chancellor Prof Teresia Akenga said yesterday the policy contains guidelines on how to handle corruption cases. "The university has attempted to identify all its corrupt-prone areas and developed a Corruption Prevention Plan," she told the Star on the phone. She said the plan highlights the role of management in mobilising resources to fight corruption.

TITLE: Corruption Hiding Behind Counties 'Political Agitation' [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (89%); ETHICS (78%); ETHNICITY (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ELECTIONS (77%); POLITICS (77%); TECHNICIANS & TECHNOLOGICAL WORKERS (71%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (69%); SURVEYING & MAPPING (66%); PRIVATELY HELD COMPANIES (66%); CONTRACT AWARDS (64%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (63%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The greatest threat to our socioeconomic development and well-being is not insecurity. It is not tribalism or negative ethnicity either. Our greatest threat is corruption. The popular narrative on corruption blames it all on the high and mighty, the so called 'political elite'. It is convenient to blame the leadership and the rich. It gives the storytellers, analysts and the general public a feel-good effect of pointing outwards to others. In any case, the rich and powerful are not exactly innocent, not all of them anyway. The truth is, corruption is endemic and deeply entrenched in the mindset, behaviour and shallow value system of the majority of ordinary Kenyans. The poor use their unfortunate circumstances to justify their attitude towards corruption. They enthusiastically support and engage in it whenever an opportunity presents itself, like during elections, when they demand bribes from all candidates without any verifiable commitment to vote for any of them, except those carried by ethnic waves. The middle-class are in a rat race to live a certain lifestyle. To them, the end justifies the means. Most corrupt deals require a significant input of technical skills from middle-class engineers, architects, land surveyors, lawyers, accountants, bankers, IT hackers, skilled politicians and businessmen. Thus corruption networks across both public and private sectors are endemic. The furore and condemnation comes only if someone is caught, but they will do their utmost to protect each other, which is often successful given their instinct for survival and their technical skills. This widespread social blight now threatens our new system of devolved government. The level of noise and confrontations at the county level is not about poor governance. It is in fact a manifestation of infighting for new corruption opportunities and self aggrandisement. We need to expose and arrest the situation urgently. Devolved corruption is now the greatest threat to our national success and well-being. The ongoing fiasco in Narok county is a classic example of how infighting for opportunities of devolved corruption has turned into political noise. The Narok government gave the job of collecting revenue from the Masai Mara to a private company with a good reputation in the private sector, where it has achieved significant success both in Kenya and in East Africa. The granting of this contract was done in a transparent, open-tender process. Some of those who lost in the tender process challenged the award at the Public Procurement Oversight Authority as provided by law. They lost. They then appealed at the High Court and lost again. But the challenge is ongoing, now disguised as noise and political agitation in Narok town. The monster that is devolved corruption is threatening to dislodge an ethical, efficient private sector company whose conduct is beyond reproach, from a business contract won competitively in an open-tender process that has been scrutinised by PPOA and the High Court. How can the people of Narok, not just their leaders, condone and support such behaviour? In Makueni, those who know the extremely stubborn disposition of Governor Kivutha Kibwana will understand that the flippant expectations of a largely corrupt group of MCAs and their cohorts have no chance whatsoever of breaking his resolve. He will not yield to corruption-driven blackmail. He would rather go home. That is why Makueni people are en route to electing a new county government. If Kibwana is reelected together with a team he can work with, it will be a huge blow to corruption, which appears to be entrenched in the minds of ordinary citizens. It is ordinary people who have to reject corruption and corrupt people. For our sake, let's hope that governors Samuel Tanui and Kibwana succeed in stemming devolved corruption now disguised as political agitation. That feat will one day have to be repeated by a President at the national level before we can claim to have a reasonable chance of slaying the corruption monster. The writer is a consultant in public affairs and policy.

TITLE: No Corruption in Kiambu, Says Kabogo
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EXECUTIVES (87%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (55%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Kiambu Governor William Kabogo has warned county staff against corruption. He said the culprits will be sacked and legal action taken against them. "I intend to make Kiambu a corruption-free zone," Kabogo said in Ruiru town yesterday during an induction workshop for new Roads officials. The 54 new officers include engineers, building inspectors, surveyors, superintendent of works and quality assurance personnel. Kabogo said he will not put up with corrupt employees at the expense of services. He said the workshop was to equip the officers with information about the department and the public's expectations. The assembly has summoned Public Service and Administration chief officer Dominic Gicheru today to explain allegations that two ward administrators paid Ngewa ward residents to protest against MCA Karungo wa Thang'wa.

TITLE: Uhuru Should Emulate Kikwete On Anti-Corruption [editorial]
COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); SCANDALS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONS (77%); CIVIL RIGHTS (76%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); CIVIL SERVICES (72%); ACQUITTAL (71%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (67%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (67%); APPEALS COURTS (67%); RELIGION (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: PRESIDENT Uhuru Kenyatta on Tuesday warned Cabinet Secretaries against corruption. The problem with corruption and Kenyan presidential administrations' declarations of intent has for 50 years been the phenomenal lack of political will to enforce them. Uhuru spoke the same week an evaluation report by the Public Service Commission showed the authorities are not doing enough to deal with corrupt civil servants. The PSC reported that 77 per cent of those accused have been acquitted. Uhuru can still become the President of Kenya who cracked the whip corruption in government by translating fine words into action. He could borrow a leaf from Tanzania's Jakaya Kikwete, who recently fired a Cabinet minister. Kikwete also accepted the AG's resignation and suspended the Energy PS in a scam that has rocked his government and severely strained relations with donors. Uhuru has invaluable Swiss assistance on the money laundering aspects of some of the worst of the Anglo Leasing scams. He can also deal definitively with the Kenyan end of the ChickenGate printing contracts scam in which a UK court has found the British players guilty of bribing specific Kenyan officials. He can stop a Jubilee era scam in its tracks before midterm in the first term -- for instance the Standard Gauge Railway scandal that has been comprehensively investigated by two committees of Parliament and the deal halted by the Court of Appeal. Quote of the day: "Nothing in the world is more dangerous than sincere ignorance and conscientious stupidity." -- US religious leader and civil rights activist Martin Luther King, Jr was born on January 15, 1929

TITLE: Fifa Shows Corruption Knows No Boundaries [editorial]
SUBJECT: SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES (91%); SOCCER (91%); ELECTIONS (90%); SCANDALS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SPORTS & RECREATION (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); ETHICS (71%); HISTORY (66%); ARMIES (54%); RELIGION (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Soccer
TEXT: FIFA vice-president Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein is to challenge Sepp Blatter in its presidential election on May 29. The 78-year-old Swiss citizen had promised to stand down after his fourth four-year term but is now seeking a fifth term. Fifa, under the leadership of Blatter and his Brazilian predecessor Joao Havelange, has ably demonstrated that corruption knows no boundaries. Fifa has suffered scandal after scandal. Last month Fifa's ethics investigator Michael Garcia resigned claiming that his report into corruption surrounding the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bids had been ignored and watered down. Change is desperately needed. Prince Ali, president of Jordanian football since 1999 and a respected army officer, wanted the Garcia report published to kick-start the Fifa clean-up. Ali is the vice-president of the Asian Football Confederation and will be supported by UEFA, the European football association. He has a credible chance of dethroning Blatter. Africa is too often unfairly tarred with the brush of corruption. Here is Africa's chance to stand up and end the culture of impunity at Fifa. All football associations will have one secret vote. Football Kenya Federation president Sam Nyamweya should use that vote to stop the rot at Fifa by backing Prince Ali. Quote of the day: "A good historian is timeless; although he is a patriot, he will never flatter his country in any respect." - French theologian Francois Fenelon died on January 7, 1715

TITLE: Corruption Impeding Progress in Siaya
SUBJECT: COUNTIES (91%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); BUDGETS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); CONTRACT AWARDS (84%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (78%); AUDITS (77%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (60%); CONSTRUCTION (50%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The delivery on the promises and expectations of devolution face a bleak future for the people of Siaya County as blatant corruption has taken centre stage in the county government, a survey finding has warned. The Siaya county Scorecard is a social audit report of November 2014, compiled from a survey carried out by the Siaya County Leadership and Development Forum through a Social Audit Panel of eminent persons and was presented to the public at Ambira High school last month. It indicated that about 50 per cent of the Sh1.2 billion development budget in 2013/4 financial year was lost through corruption. More than 250 Siaya residents participated in the survey. They rated the governor and his government 100 per cent "poor" on corruption, and "below average" on performance- covering service delivery, development and good leadership. The report further indicates that there was only a superficial involvement of the people in the preparation of the county integrated development plan (CIDP) and the county budget, as a way to fulfill the requirements from the controller of budget and hence no ownership among the people of Siaya. The public was not very involved in the planning stages due to poor mobilisation and poor attendance of public consulation meetings due to the short notices given. According to the report, the governor was violating the Constitution and the County Government Act by failing to hold public briefing sessions in town-hall type meetings after every three months. It also revealed that the peoples' project choices and prioritisation did not always hold in the final CIDP as some projects which people had prioritised at Ward level were altered by the county government in the final documents. The worst part is failure to involve people in the planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of development projects. "Corruption has hampered service delivery in the county government, and there is no doubt about the involvement of the executive because it is not taking any action," said the report. It was alleged that the governor and some MCAs actively participated in tendering processes hence flouting the tendering regulations and involving themselves in corruption. This is after reports that one contractor was allegedly asked to go with his MCA to the officer in charge of payments at the finance office. According to the respondents, most of those awarded the tenders were either cronies or relatives of the governor or certain MCAs. There were serious allegations that awarding contracts for most road construction projects was directly handled by the top office in the executive in collaboration with some MCAs, who gave contracts and tenders to their own companies or companies where they had interests, eliciting emotional reactions from the disenchanted respondents, the report further revealed. The report, corroborated by several respondents, says that a top official in the executive is known to have the habit of using the discriminative comment of "...he was not our person" or "he was not with us" whenever he hears that some contractors whom he perceives not to be politically correct are about to be awarded. Lack of fairness and indeed corruption in tendering was said to be the weakest point of the county government. "Failure to follow procedures, favoritism and blatant corruption in tendering were the worst and most glaring violations of good governance by the county government." The county project documents revealed extreme overpricing, and direct observations by the Social Audit Panel revealed poor workmanship condoned by those in charge of ensuring quality. Most projects were by far, over-priced and poorly done. "How do you justify spending Sh3 million on a two-door toilet at Nyamonye market?" posed the finding. The general feeling of most respondents further indicates that health services were at a standstill due to lack of personnel, drugs and consumables. "There is also poor reception and handling of patients at the health centres", said the report, adding that the resident felt that county government had no plan for the health sector hence the mass exodus of senior health staffs. Respondents compared Siaya with other counties and saw their county government as disappointing, citing Busia County next door, where the main referral hospital was being upgraded as one of the county's flagship projects for improving service delivery. While most respondents expressed disappointment, some gave the government the benefit of doubt because of the interruption of the governor's term when the county went for a by-election. According to several groups, the county government is performing below expectations in terms of failing to implement projects on schedule and distribution of major public service appointments. There is no unique development or poverty eradication vision to make people have hope or be inspired adding that there no visible change or improvement in service delivery. The Siaya County CEC in charge of Governance and Administration, Amos Okello, responded during the presentation that the county government welcomed such criticism. He requested that the panel share with the county government such a report in good time in future for a proper response. The Ombudsman maintained that social audit was a constitutional tool enshrined in the constitution to offer checks and balances on the use of public offices and appealed for wide participation in social audit. "Social Audit is a requirement in the Constitution, which requires for public participation on the available resources," added Amollo, saying his recommendations would be based on the interest of Siaya people. The Former Alego/Usonga MP, Sammy Weya regretted that the county government had failed in vouching for discussions with elected leaders on development agenda for the county. Weya cited over 90 per cent of funds translating to billions of shillings channelled to the county government in the 2014-2015 financial year is lying idle in the treasury as the county failed to spend it. He said such funds, through consultation with key stakeholders would have been put into viable use for the benefit of the county people who are yearning for improved service delivery.
