Weya, who was accompanied by former Siaya County Council chairman Aggrey Onyango, called for the prosecution of county leaders who have orchestrated the misuse of the taxpayers' funds for their selfish interests to the chagrin of the suffering public. Community Aid International Programme coordinator, Mwende Mutua, said their organisation was not out to fight county governments but to empower communities to play a watch dog role over their resources and public affairs. Mwende said the project was being implemented in three counties including Kilifi, Makueni and Siaya adding that similar exercise will be rolled over in other counties.

TITLE: Step Up War On Corruption, Mandago Urges Eacc Chair
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ETHICS (87%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: UASIN Gishu Governor Jackson Mandago has asked EACC chairman Mumo Matemu to strengthen the EACC regional office in Eldoret so that it can tackle cases of graft. Several senior staff of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) in Eldoret have been transferred. "Matemu should give us officers who can effectively tackle graft. The transfers were not necessary," Mandago said. Speaking in Eldoret town on Friday, he said he has already talked to Matemu. Mandago criticised graft in the issuance of registration documents in Eldoret.

TITLE: Uhuru Cautions Against Economic Vendetta in War On Graft As International Anti- Corruption Day Is Marked Today
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ETHICS (90%); STADIUMS & ARENAS (88%); EMERGING MARKETS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (73%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (71%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (68%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (67%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (67%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (66%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: President Uhuru Kenyatta has cautioned against improper use of infrastructure put in place to fight graft as Kenya joins the rest of the world in commemorating the International Anti-Corruption day. Uhuru said his government has put in place several measures to facilitate the fight against corruption such as integrated service provision under one roof and a hotline to report graft. "However, I do not expect personal vendetta or business rivalries to be the sole motivation for reporting," Uhuru said. The president at the same time announced that a National Ethics and Anti-corruption policy developed to streamline the war on graft, as well as the promotion of integrity and accountability in the public sector service provision will be ready for implementation by June 2015. Uhuru said that it is corruption and a lack of integrity that hampers the economic growth potential of countries and not a lack of resources and infrastructure. "Fighting corruption effectively requires team work. It is your duty and mine to end the vice," Uhuru said. Chairman of the Ethics and Anti-corruption commission Mumo Matemu on his part called on the signatories to the United Nations Convention against Corruption to fast-track establishment of democratic institutions that will fight graft. "It serves to remind all UNCAC signatories of their obligation to build democratic institutions responsive to the needs of their people, improve the openness and accountability of their administrations, control public spending and uphold their constitutions," Matemu said. The EACC chairman who is also currently serving as the president of the East African Association of Anti-Corruption Authorities said that the efforts being made against graft should be collective. "It is only when Kenyans at all levels commit themselves decisively to this fight individually and collectively that the country will register meaningful success in the fight against corruption," Matemu said. The Anti-Corruption body CEO Halakhe Waqo said cooperation between stakeholders both in the public and private sector will win the fight against graft. Attorney General Githu Muigai said the war against graft is a continuous endeavor that should be maintained "in season and out of season as envisioned in Article 10 and Chapter 6 of the constitution." The government is under pressure to stem corruption as a 2014 report by Transparency International Kenya chapter on the corruption perception index places Kenya at 145 out of 175 countries surveyed. The International Anti-Corruption Day will be celebrated at the Kenyatta stadium in Machakos county with other celebrations being marked in Kerugoya stadium in Kirinyaga county, Posta grounds in Bungoma county, Wajir Primary school in Wajir county, and Malindi stadium in Kilifi county.

TITLE: Lusaka Flags Off Anti-Corruption Carava
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (89%); COUNTIES (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); ETHICS (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (76%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (74%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%); SECURITY GUARD SERVICES (72%); EMERGING MARKETS (70%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (65%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (55%) Zambia; Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: GOVERNOR Kenneth Lusaka has promised to make Bungoma a graft-free county. He urged residents to volunteer information that will help his government weed out corrupt public servants. "This financial year our county has been allocated more than Sh7 billion which we want to use for infrastructural projects. We want the money to transform people's lives and not end up in pockets," Lusaka said. He said there is no room for corrupt county staff in Bungoma. Corruption is rampant in tendering and procurement processes, Lusaka said. He was speaking during the flagging-off of an anti-corruption caravan. The caravan will till next Tuesday go around the county to educate locals on the dangers of corruption. Bungoma will host regional celebrations to mark the International Anti-Corruption Day on that day. Western regional Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission manager Edwin Waundo, , judicial officers, representatives from Transparency International, Bungoma Deputy Governor Hillary Chongwony and County Public Service boss Murumba Chiuli attended the flaging off at the county hedquarters. Chiuli said the Bungoma government has a code of conduct for its workers. He said they have appointed an anti-corruption committee to restore integrity in the public service and reduce corruption. "Our government is intent on raising public awareness on the negative effects of corruption on the local economy in a bid to reduce it tremendously," Chiuli said. Waundo said the EACC will review the progress made in the fight against corruption, help county governments raise public awareness levels, mobilise the public against corrupt practices and take necessary action to eradicate it. Chongwony said corruption demeans people, compromises serrvice delivery and undermines economic growth hence the need to reduce the vice. Acting Bungoma County Commissioner Githinji Gachunga said the public has been hesitant in making suggestions on how to fight corruption. He said police officers will not go on leave this December as they will carry out day and night patrols during the festive season to enhance security. He appealed to the public to volunteer information about criminal activities to security agencies.

TITLE: Corruption, Poor Technology Keep Off Foreign SMEs
COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); UGANDA (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); KENYA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (87%); COUNTRY RISK (77%); MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS (73%) Kenya; ICT and Telecom; Corruption
TEXT: Small foreign firms looking to venture into East Africa are deterred by high business risks that include poor technology, corruption and undeveloped infrastructure, according to a report by the Economist Intelligence Unit. Foreign SMEs also said there is a general perception that multinational firms that have government backing are more welcome into the region. Roughly 40 per cent of SMEs from developed countries that were surveyed - which are plan to trade internationally in the future - said the continent offers no growth potential, indicating a hard-inked negative impression barring them from trying business in East Africa. Other challenges cited by the 480 SME executives and experts include a low average consumer spend, cultural barriers and political risk. The SMEs therefore feel it could take "too long" before they can break even. The lot also do not have adequate information on the macroeconomic situation on the African continent as a whole. Daniel Becerra, a respondent in the survey from the United Kingdom who has a business in Uganda, said that petty corruption is a reality, citing some of his friends whose cargo could not be released from customs for three months till they parted with a bribe.

TITLE: Kenya's Deteriorating Insecurity Is Due to Failed Leadership and Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: LAW ENFORCEMENT (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); NATIONAL SECURITY (89%); PUBLIC POLICY (89%); CRIME PREVENTION (72%); RELIGION (53%) Kenya; Conflict, Peace and Security; Corruption
TEXT: Deep-seated structural governance problems of the Kenya state remain serious threat to its existence. The vulnerability of the country in security is linked to highly corrupt criminalised state with weak institutions of governance that create safe haven for organised crime to thrive. Yet the solutions offered go only very little. Incremental change remains significantly ineffective to Kenya situation. Gains made in reforming state are quickly eroded. Different sustained strategy is crucial. Decisive tackling of criminalisation of politics offer critical entry point. Criminalisation of politics is the pivotal pillar that feed and facilitates the systemic decay of the Kenya state. Kenya Security Sector has irredeemably lost its reputation and credibility. Huge financial resources are allocated to security organs but there are no results. Every concerned Kenyan unequivocally condemns abominable attacks and killings innocent civilians. People must exercise great restrain from interpreting these senseless unjustifiable killings as inter-religious conflict. These are abhorrent criminal acts. The escalating insecurity is partially the outcome of institutional inertia in the absence of coherent national security policy, crime intelligence based strategy and of operational simplicity on part of the Kenya security agencies. Kenya has no law enforcement and crime prevention strategy. Overall, President Uhuru Kenyatta government must develop a comprehensive integrated law enforcement strategy. The current reactive security and law enforcement policies are ill-defined, incoherent and shallow. President Kenyatta administration mostly continues to put out immediate security fires but the overall deterrence capacity of security and law enforcement agencies remain very limited and largely unable to detect and preempt crime. The security policy reform momentum has prematurely dissipated. President Uhuru Kenyatta is offering little substantive leadership to the chronic problems confronting the country. He has wrong personnel assisting him in governing the country. However, he is the one responsible. He must be held to account to the people of Kenya and to the law of the land. If he cannot provide leadership of substance and tangible action, then he is the problem. Civil society does not accept 'fall guys' theory. It is the President culpable. Constitution introduced major governance and institutional changes in Kenya to improve accountability on public service delivery. Security sector was not spared. However, the security sector, whose reputation, credibility and professionalism was irredeemably battered, continues to operate in old model. This makes it ineffective, vulnerable and irrelevant, jeopardising the security of the people and the country. The first responsibility of any President is to protect the people and securing the country. The citizens are true owners of the state. They maintain and control the government, while the government serves the citizens and is accountable to them. Failure to meet that core duty and obligation cause government dissolution. The state's first duty to its citizens is to provide full security. The President ensures the highest standards of transparency and openness for institutions responsible for the security of the state and its citizens. Further, the President enforces highest moral and professional standards for those officials who serve there. It is the obligation of the President to ensure that institutions responsible for the security of the state and its citizens are fully depoliticised and protected from undue interference by politicians and from ruling elite influence. The President provides critical leadership and strategy to strengthen security. President must ensure the country has the prerequisite and necessary tools and capabilities to find, disrupt and destroy criminals and their hideouts. Accordingly, the constitution's framers viewed the security of the nation to be the foremost responsibility of the national government. Constitution places paramount authority for security in a single executive with clear accountability and checks. The President has the power, and bears the responsibility, to make tough decisions at a moment's notice. President Uhuru Kenyatta and his coterie of advisers have obstinately refused to take this constitutional obligation and responsibility for securing the country. Rather than addressing the constitutional obligation demands, the President is absconding. He has forfeited political legitimacy to govern. Buck stops with President The Constitution of Kenya, in Article 29(c) provides: "Every person has the right to freedom and security of the person, which includes the right not to be...subject to any form of violence, from either public or private sources..." Further, Article 131 provides that the President of the Republic of Kenya, is "the Commander-in-Chief of the Kenya Defence Forces...and is the chairperson of the National Security Council. The council, in accordance with Article 240(7), shall "integrate the domestic, foreign and military policies relating to national security in order to enable the national security organs, to cooperate and function effectively." "Consequently, the National Security Council shall "assess and appraise the objectives, commitments and risks to the republic in respect of actual or potential national security capabilities." In furtherance of the above, the national security organs primary objective is to "promote and guarantee national security in accordance with principles mentioned in Article 238(2): "The national security organs are National Police Service, Kenya Defence Forces and the National Intelligence Service. Get rid of county commissioners confusions. Inspector General of National Police Service David Kimaiyo forced resignation under pressure is welcome. However, it is drop in the ocean. The deep-seated structural and policy problems inflicting the system must the changed. There must be far-reaching systematic overhaul of the entire security system and national security policy. People of Kenya must not buy into change of guard. The President must lead with responsive, sensitive and accountable leadership. President must abandon political campaign spin. People of Kenya want serious actionable solutions of substance. President must hire competent and expertise staff from Cabinet Secretary downwards. The President must execute tough decisions and sanctions on corruption and corrupt practices inside the government and security agencies. President should engage the National Security Council and less the National Security Advisory Committee on National Security Policy, so that the government can address threats in a comprehensive manner. The effectiveness of the security sector can be improved by optimising every security sector. The National Security Council chaired by Mr Uhuru Kenyatta, Council on Administration of Justice chaired by Dr Willy Mutunga and Council of Governors chaired by Mr Isaac Ruto must work collectively to offer sustainable solution to the unacceptable and socio-political stability threatening security situation in Kenya. While building up the operational capacity of security agencies is crucial, there is need to pay enough attention to building the institutional capacity and the human capital security civilian institutions in order to sustain security over the long term. National Security Council should execute its constitutional mandate and spearhead the process of the drafting and fully implementation of the national security strategy. It should also provide policy guidance into Crime Prevention strategy to the State Department of Internal Security and National Police Service. Further, the council should set adequate and effective oversight mechanism of enforcing its decisions. The council should develop review and coordination mechanism of the Strategy and Crime Prevention policy. The National Security Advisory Committee is subordinate to the council and not policy decision-making body. Finally, National Security Council, together with State Department of Internal Security, Council of Governors, Council on Administration of Justice, Office of Director of Public Prosecutions and National Police Service should establish and strengthen the County Policing and Law Enforcement Authority. The authority should review the security policy decisions set by National Security Council at national level, specifically affecting particular county and overall, and the security concerns of the local population in order to set security and law enforcement priorities of the county. County National Police Service leadership, Command and Security spokesperson structure should be under-experienced management expertise police officer in charge appointed competitively on merit by National Police Service Commission. The officer will chair the County Policing and Law Enforcement Technical Committee. County Policing and Security Authority should be strengthened and fully operationalised under chair of county governor. The authority will review county related prioritised security issues by National Security Council and public security concerns to make its decisions. The Policing and Law Enforcement Technical Committee is responsible and answerable in implementation of authority decisions and law enforcement operations. The police officer is accountable to office of Inspector General, NPSC and County Authority. He or she should publish County Security and Law Enforcement monthly report. This ensures security and justice services are available to ordinary citizens with accountability of both national and county governments. The officer is accountable for speaking matters policing and law enforcement in the county. County commissioners cannot usurp constitution arrangement of the security. Writer is executive director, International Centre for Policy and Conflict: nwainaina@icpcafrica.org

TITLE: Close All Porous Borders, End Corruption to Win War Against Terrorism - Peter Kenneth
SUBJECT: TERRORISM (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (90%); ARMED FORCES (89%); SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGY (76%); AL-SHABAAB (75%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (75%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (73%); RESIGNATIONS (63%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The government must close all porous borders and deploy KDF soldiers to patrol them to secure the country, former presidential candidate Peter Kenneth has said. "We need a physical closure of the long boarders if that is what it will take to secure our people. KDF should ensure day and night patrols including aerial surveillance," Kenneth said in a statement on Wednesday. He asked the government to "stamp its authority and show its might" in securing the lives of Kenyans, which is its responsibility. He said the measures are necessary because the al Shabaab will not stop its attacks on soft targets for as long as KDF soldiers remain in Somalia. Kenneth also asked the government to eliminate any form of corruption in order to win the war against terrorism and related acts of crime. He said the country needs a system in which institutions in charge of security work harmoniously and not competitively, eliminating loopholes that would result in corruption. "A system that provides a joint action in order to prevent or counter any attack is what the country needs," he said. "A country can have a very competent head of an institution but the performance of that individual will remain questionable if the system is broken," he also noted. The former Gatanga MP also welcomed the changes President Uhuru Kenyatta made in the security docket on Tuesday, calling, however, for changes in Kenya's entire security system. He said the "bigger problem" which lies in the security system should not be forgotten as new appointments are made. Uhuru sacked Interior CS Joseph Ole Lenku and nominated retired major general and Kajiado Central MP Joseph Nkaissery as his replacement. He also said that he has written to the National Assembly regarding the extension of sittings addressing the increasing incidents of terror attacks in the country. David Kimaiyo who was the Inspector General of Police also resigned from his post citing personal reasons.

TITLE: EACC's Mumo Calls for Public Support in Corruption Fight
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (77%); WAGES & SALARIES (75%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (72%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Ethics and Anti-Corruption has called for public support in the fight against the vice. Chairman Mumo Matemu said investigations take longer than expected due to lack of public support. He opened the Kilifi county head teachers' leadership and integrity workshop at Pwani University yesterday. Matemu appealed to the public to provide information and testify before the commission. "As a commission, we have done quite a tremendous job. We have reclaimed 12 acres of airport land in Mombasa and another plot in Karatina, which belongs to the police," he said. The commission is currently following up the case on 12,500 ghost workers in the public service. Matemu said the commission is investigating where the workers' salary goes to. "There can be ghost workers and ghost projects, but there can never be ghost salaries. We want to know who is getting the money," he said. Matemu denied shedding light on the 'chicken' saga involving the printing of election material by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission. He said information will be made public when the anti-graft agency is ready. "We will give a comprehensive report in the right time."

TITLE: Vehicle Checks Will Increase Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: INSPECTIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (85%); MOTOR VEHICLES (78%); POLICE FORCES (74%); EXTORTION (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (73%); RETAILERS (55%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Since its inception, the government's Vehicle Inspection Unit has been known as a hub for corruption with motorists who take their cars for checkups forced to part with kitu kidogo whether their vehicles are serviceable or not. It is alleged that to avoid the tedious and mostly ineffective inspection, many fleet and individual owners of public service and commercial vehicles choose to part with hundreds of thousands of shillings through brokers to bribe the inspection unit personnel. Inspection stickers are then delivered to them at home, shopping centres or in their offices. It is an open secret that so much money was made this way in the past that claims were made of how it made its way to the pockets of top government officials and used as handouts at harambees and to oil the election campaign machine. The senior officials would in turn protect the inspection unit staff and of course encourage them to steal even more. These units are inefficient and a lot of man-hours and money are lost as operators of public service and commercial vehicles queue for hours on end waiting for their vehicles to be inspected and re-inspected in case they are turned away to carry out repairs or replace parts. No wonder then that most would rather pay the bribe upfront and avoid the agony of the queues and the back and forth game of "repair this, replace that". If, as suggested, every vehicle that is over four years old is to be inspected, you can imagine the nightmare that would result. Kenyans would be forced to queue at these inspection centres for days on end. They would waste weeks as the inspectors take them back and forth to 'fit this and repair that'. Many of course would opt to bribe their way out of the mess thereby quadrupling the corruption. Others unable to bribe their way at the units or through brokers to get stickers at the comfort of their offices and homes, will prefer to bribe the traffic police officers and NTSA officials on the road, again adding to the graft menace. There have been rumours that a sizeable part of the bribes extorted by traffic police officers on our roads finds its way to some very high echelons of the police force. Does this then mean that a percentage of the money that would be collected by the fellows at the inspection units and by police and NSTA officers on the road, would find its way to the pockets of senior government officials? For what purpose would this money be used? Then there is the money that would be genuinely collected at the inspection units and as fines for noncompliance, which reminds me of the days when the Kenyatta International Convention (Conference) Center was being built. I am told that to raise funds for the construction, Mzee Jomo Kenyatta's regime rounded up and fined petty offenders, mostly drinkers of traditional beers. The colonial government had banned the brewing and consumption of traditional liquor, and when Kenyatta came to power, Attorney General Charles Njonjo chose to keep the draconian rule in the law books. As the story goes, police officers would on a daily basis raid muratina and busaa dens, round up revellers and cram them in cells. Others would be picked by the roadside and all charged with being drunk and disorderly, whether intoxicated or not. To avoid being locked up in remand for prolonged periods, most, if not all, pleaded guilty to the offence even if they were not and paid the fine. This tradition of Kenyans pleading guilty to petty crimes, mostly related to being drunk and disorderly, has held to date. The Jubilee government has a lot of financial obligations and unfortunately there has been a lot of wastage through the bloated government brought about by devolution. It is also true that some bureaucrats in government are trying hard to make as much money as they possibly could, with the 2017 general election at the back of their minds. Could the government then allay fears that it is trying to build another 'KICC' through the new NTSA rules? More money is being collected through the sometimes absurd 50km per hour city limit rule. Could 2017 have anything to do with it? Of course the cream of the crop in Kenya including new kids on the block in government can afford to drive off from DT Dobie in brand-new limousines, but most Kenyans import second-hand cars that are about eight years old. It would be a nightmare to inspect the thousands of cars that are more than four years old. And however well the cars are maintained, it's common knowledge that the traffic police or vehicle inspection officers will always find fault with the car, even where none exist. The writer comments on topical issues. nkihuria@yahoo.co.uk

TITLE: Corruption Kills - Look at Poison Brew [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES (91%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (90%); DISTILLED LIQUORS (90%); BRIBERY (78%); CONSPIRACY (76%); BEER WINE & LIQUOR STORES (73%); RETAILERS (71%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (55%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Kenyans were yesterday dismayed all over again by reports of the deaths of four people in Kiambu county who had taken poisonous illicit liquor. The number of deaths from inferior and illicit alcoholic drinks, mostly brews and liquors, in 2014 alone is now past the 150 mark. This is a terrible state of affairs. Illicit liquor retailers' stills and dens operate in the plain sight of administrators and police, including criminal intelligence sleuths. However, corruption keeps the trade going, with the bribes going straight to entire police and administration command hierarchies in the locations involved. The sight of poverty-stricken Kenyans periodically drinking poisonous concoctions and dying in large numbers is such a dreadful prospect that, back in May, the Kikuyu Council of Elders urged President Uhuru Kenyatta to declare the menace a national disaster. Long before the elders appealed to the President, he had given a three-month ultimatum in 2013 to administrators nationwide to wipe out the poison alcohol menace. Corrupt policing and administration and feeble laws have conspired to give Kenyans one of the most moronic situations anywhere on earth: the spectacle of illegal alcohol vendors who literally poison their customers and drinkers who seemingly do not learn from the lethal mistakes of others. Too many police and administration officers are asleep on the job. And it shows.

TITLE: Terry Now Withdraws FKF Corruption Case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ETHICS (90%); SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES (89%); SOCCER (78%); SPORTS & RECREATION (75%); SPORTS (75%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Soccer
TEXT: Former Football Kenya Federation Coast National Executive Committee member Hussein Terry has dropped the corruption case he filed against the federation at the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. "After consultations and personal reflections, I have come to realise that I was mislead as I used the wrong channel of solving football issues," Terry said. Terry has since been banned from all football related activities by the FKF after delegates sitting in an annual general meeting in June 28, 2014 accused him of maligning the federation. "I was at the headquarters of the world football governing body Fifa, Zurich, last month to seek guidance on the way forward in the wake of my expulsion by FKF from all football activities," Terry said. "It is while there that I was advised as a young and energetic football administrator, I should return home and mend fences with the local football chiefs, amicably solve the wrangles locally and work together with the current office bearers to steer the growth of the sport in the country at all levels." Terry added he was also informed he made a mistake by filing a corruption case against the federation at the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission instead of seeking other avenues. "I would like to request FKF under the leadership of President Sam Nyamweya to pardon me and consider reviewing my expulsion from the most popular sport in the country, because I believe I still have a lot to offer to the sport," Terry pleaded. "A divided house can never yield positive growth and to that effect I am willing to work with the current office to realise the growth of football in the country." Terry was banned alongside former vice chairman Sammy Shollei and former Nairobi branch chairman Dan Shikanda who were handed six year suspensions each.

TITLE: Migori and EACC to Battle Corruption
SUBJECT: AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ETHICS (70%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Migori County Deputy Governor, Maanga Mwita (in black suit), listens as a Ministry of Agriculture official (in white t-shirt) explains something at the ministry's stand during this year's ASK Satellite Show at LIchota in Migori. With him is the Agriculture Chief Officer, Easter Ogweno (in pink top and black skirt).Photo/File The Migori government has partnered with the Ethics and Anti-Corruption commission to seal corruption loopholes. Speaking during the partnership launch in Migori town on Tuesday, Deputy Governor Nelson Mahanga said the county is ready to clear all corruption deals. He said the partnership will involve all residents, irrespective of position. EACC chairman Mumo Matemo said the arrival of the commission in Migori does not mean there is anything sinister in the county. He said the programme is an institutional partnership aimed at safeguarding county resources. Matemu said devolution has come with challenges in the control of corruption. He said the challenges can be addressed through partnerships with the counties. The commission will start by educating residents for five days on graft cases and how to deal with them. Mahanga said majority of the residents do not have enough knowledge on how to deal with corruption.

TITLE: Kepsa Releases Findings On Corruption Survey
COUNTRY: KENYA (91%); EASTERN AFRICA (90%); AFRICA (78%); BURUNDI (73%); UGANDA (73%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); BRIBERY (73%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The Kenya Private Sector Alliance has launched a study on corruption risk mapping. The 36 page document contains information on perceptions of corruption in public-private sector interaction, predisposing factors that drive public-private sector corruption at various service interactions and attitude towards promoting ethics and integrity. It is based on the National Integrity Pact project lauched by KEPSA in partnership with the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission and tGerman government owned federal enterprise Gesellschaft fur Internationale Zusammenarbeit in 2011. Speaking at the launch, KEPSA director Patrick Obath challenged employers to put in place committees to improve the ethics and integrity of their institutions. According to East African Bribery Index 2011, Kenya is ranked the third most corrupt country in East Africa behind Burundi and Uganda.

TITLE: Call to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: GEM MP Jakoyo Midiwo has asked leaders to fight corruption at the grassroots level. He said: "There is no need to fight corruption in the national government and money is being swindled in your home turf." Midiwo was speaking on Saturday at the funeral of his grandmother Deborah Ocham in Nyanginja village, Siaya county.

TITLE: Under President Uhuru, the War Against Corruption Is Lost [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (74%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (72%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (71%); RANKINGS (60%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: "Where there is no vision, the people perish." - Proverbs 29-18. To avoid death, the vision of Kenya must be to develop from third, to first world. To realise the vision of development, however, there are obstacles: Negative ethnicity, which is second to corruption. The vision of developing Kenya from poverty must go hand in hand with the vision of eradicating negative ethnicity because a house at war with itself cannot stand and an economy perpetually robbed cannot grow. Indeed, elimination of negative ethnicity and eradication of corruption are a prerequisite of developing the country. Just as a robber cannot steal without arming oneself with some weapon, the corrupt arm themselves with leadership, office, influence and power to rob government and country. Just as robbing national resources requires power, checkmating corruption requires greater power, influence and leadership that only president has. Without presidential power, corruption cannot be stopped because people with lesser power than the corrupt cannot stop them from stealing. Corruption is only stopped where presidential or highest power is applied against corruption. However much the nation might wish to be rid of corruption, where presidential power is not applied against corruption, war against graft is lost. To paraphrase Malcolm X that power only respects greater power, the power of the corrupt only respects greater power of integrity. In Kenya, because power of the president has not been applied against corruption, graft has won the war with integrity. If the president agrees to pit his power against corruption and integrity wins the war against graft, credit will be his. But if the president refuses to pit his great power against corruption and graft wins the war, blame will be his too. In Kenya, the war against corruption is lost already and the people to blame are Presidents Kenyatta, Moi, Kibaki and now Uhuru. We blame old presidents for old corruption and blame President Uhuru for ongoing corruption of the last two years and some graft of the Kanu and Kibaki regimes he was part of and whose rule he approved of. Under President Uhuru as under the other presidents, corruption has been all pervasive. Government loses more than 337 billions every year. Controller and Auditor General cited CDF and Office of the President for corruption of billions. Kenya Police has been ranked third most corrupt in the world and Kenyan corporate corruption has been ranked number one in the world. Recently, President Uhuru was hailed for denouncing land-grabbing in Lamu, but that has been taken back when CS of Land Ministry Charity Ngilu exonerated old land-grabbing because it was government sanctioned. In her view, only ongoing and government unapproved land-grabbing should be stopped. President Uhuru should have rebuked this exoneration of corruption but he did not, probably in his own defence. Failure to rebuke defence of corruption was compounded by President Uhuru's denial of corruption in the Standard Railway project and paying money to Anglo Leasing project. The genesis of Uhuru's weakness in fighting corruption could be connected to President Kenyatta's regime, to which Uhuru is inexorably linked by lineage of blood, economy and politics. Unfortunately for Uhuru, President Kenyatta planted the roots of corruption when he permitted civil servants to engage in business while still in government. When people complained, Kenyatta replied: "My bird hide. If you are caught, you are not mine." Kenyatta also castigated Bildad Kaggia for not enriching himself as a leader. Apart from Kenyatta lineage, there are other reasons why the war against corruption will not be won by President Uhuru. Verbally, Uhuru condemns corruption but he is a disciple of capitalism that is the mother of corruption. Though he condemns corruption, Uhuru has not combated the evil with the power of example as Presidents General Murtala Mohammed, Thomas Sankara and Julius Nyerere almost decimated corruption in their countries with the power of example. Personally, Uhuru has not championed the war against corruption by dealing a death blow to anyone corrupt in his office, government or party. President Uhuru has not stated anywhere that his desired legacy is elimination of corruption or eradication of negative ethnicity. Whether we like it or not, to a large extent President Uhuru will be judged by characters of his personal friends, political comrades, advisers, business companions, defenders and even enemies. If any of Uhuru's associates are corrupt, he too will look corrupt. Like his father, Uhuru has not banned civil servants from doing business while in government, an activity that can only be corrupt. President Uhuru has not disassociated himself with the notion that the president or governor also owns government, country or county to eat with friends and family members. All people Uhuru has put into government have no reputation of being warriors against corruption. Despite corruption being a culture that should be uprooted, Uhuru has not championed the culture of integrity to take its place. And because negative ethnicity and graft are allies, Uhuru cannot fight graft without fighting negative ethnicity, which is the bedrock of Kenyan politics. If Uhuru embraces negative ethnicity, he cannot be an enemy of corruption. And as negative ethnicity, corruption and poverty will determine the fate of Kenya, and five years of Uhuru Presidency, without fighting graft it will be too long a respite for them. President Uhuru must fight graft or openly tell Kenyans they are on their own.

TITLE: Corruption and Anti-Terror Dragnets
SUBJECT: COUNTERTERRORISM (92%); TERRORISM (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); ALTERNATIVE DISPUTE RESOLUTION (90%); INTERNATIONAL LAW (90%); CARTELS (88%); AL-SHABAAB (78%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (77%); IMMIGRATION (77%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (77%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (75%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (74%); DEPORTATION (74%); IMMIGRATION LAW (74%); ESPIONAGE (72%); INVESTIGATIONS (68%); MONEY LAUNDERING (67%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (61%); LICENSES & PERMITS (60%) Kenya; Corruption; International Terrorism
TEXT: WHEN President Uhuru Kenyatta jetted back to Kenya after attending the US-Africa Leaders' Summit in Washington, DC, the first thing he emphasised was that investors must be assured that their investments will be protected by the recently opened international investment arbitration centre. He noted that the Nairobi Centre for International Arbitration, whose board was installed last year, will make all investors comfortable by covering all bases of dispute. Analysts were quick to note that international arbitration has become the preferred method among dispute resolution processes the world over in the early 21st century, as it saves on both time and money by delivering quicker decisions that are easier to enforce than court judgments. All this is probably news to the NIS and immigration authorities in Kenya, who automatically do not allow investors to wind up their businesses, dispose of assets, pay and collect debts before they deport them, usually on information provided by business rivals and predator corruption cartels that target certain kinds of investors. The law of natural justice requires that the accused, even on purely intelligence, immigration and counterterrorism matters, must be heard. A system that filters adverse information received by the Kenyan authorities from business rivals and extortion cartels, and indeed all other sources, must be put in place. Indeed, it is these cartels that must be disbanded without compromise. They constitute corporate terrorism. What Kenyan senior intelligence and counterterrorism officials and the agents under their command or leadership must appreciate is that anti-terrorism is increasingly a fully documented and researched process, including at university level. It is no longer just a matter of secret files that never see the light of day, even in court, or maximum non-disclosure. If you have the evidence, and it is the solid fruit of diligent spying and investigation and can indeed stand up in courts of law locally, regionally and internationally, then by all means make full disclosure, protecting only the identities of frontline agents and sources. Why is evidential disclosure so increasingly important? The deportation from Kenya in November 2013 of Pakistani businessman and long-term investor in this country Nadeem Iqbal Mohamed was reportedly on the grounds that he was into money laundering, organised crime and al Shabaab-compliant. None of these suspicions were scrutinised by a court of law. Nadeem was 'tried' entirely in the court of public opinion on elliptical, minimalist and highly suggestive grounds. It was apparently enough that he is Pakistani and Muslim. Nadeem's brother Wasim Iqbal Mohamed was left behind to continue with their business empire, built assiduously across 16 years and employing hundreds of ordinary Kenyans. The Iqbal brothers pay tax in Kenya to the tune of northwards of Sh400 million annually. They should be getting pursuit-of-excellence and prosperity awards, not long-range and intercontinental character assassination. Now Wasim is struggling to remain in Kenya and has seen renewal of his work permit denied and then permitted, and yet someone, somewhere in the NIS and at immigration is still hounding him. The intention is clearly to drive the Iqbals out of Kenya, acquire their businesses and transplant them. Also as clear as crystal, is the fact that massive raw corruption is at work here. The biggest loser in this sort of compromise is Kenya's hard-won reputation as an investment destination-of-choice country, where investors are extended every enabling environment and protection. There is a corresponding danger - if Kenya's anti-terrorism agencies open themselves to being used as extortionate bludgeons, too many national security factors will fly out every available window, leaving this country increasingly vulnerable and bereft of investors. A 2011 report sponsored by the British Equality and Human Rights Commission and published by the University of Durham, also of the UK, should be required reading for Kenyan counterterrorism officials and field agents. Entitled, 'The impact of counterterrorism measures on Muslim communities,' it was written by researchers Tufyal Choudhry and Helen Fenwick. The foreword to this landmark report was written by Baroness Hussein Ece, a BEHR commissioner. It contains the following eye-opening remarks: "The prevention of terrorism is about protecting some of our most basic human rights - a fact which sometimes get lost in the debate about terror prevention and human rights. "The question for any government is how best to provide that protection. Experience from Northern Ireland teaches us that counterterrorism measures have the potential to stigmatise whole communities, to fuel resentment and even to bolster support for terrorism movements. "There is a danger that Muslims in contemporary Britain may become the new suspect community. Policymakers and operatives are grappling with this old dilemma - it is an inescapable fact that the majority of those suspected of terrorist activities are Muslim, and that counterterrorism measures are likely to target Muslims. Clearly, however, those measures will be counterproductive if they make ordinary British Muslims, who are of course just as affected by the terrorist threat as anyone else, feel they are constantly under suspicion". For every mention of British in the foregoing, just substitute Kenyan and the message strikes home with some force. And please bear in mind that all these delicate factors and problems in Britain's counter-terror efforts are minus the corruption-Kenyan-style factor. Add raw corruption and you get a truly toxic mix. Wasim argues passionately that his brother is a victim of extortion rings that continue to harass international businesspeople who bear Muslim names in Kenya. He also speaks darkly of cartels in Kenyan ministries. He told a Sunday newspaper last week: "As I waited for the renewal of my permit between January and June, I was told by the criminal cartels that it would be rejected if I did not pay millions of shillings. It was indeed rejected". The Iqbal brothers' saga was among the last things in outgoing NIS boss Michael Gichangi's in-tray. Director General of Intelligence nominee Major General Philip Wachira Kameru would do well to get to the bottom of the shenanigans and skullduggery surrounding the massive undermining of, and the vendetta against, the Iqbals' investments in Kenya early in his tenure. Maj Gen Kameru must strive to the maximum to keep the dragon of corruption out of the process of the counterterrorism dragnet in Kenya.

TITLE: Mtwapa Residents Protest Poor Infrastructure and Corruption in Kilifi
SUBJECT: COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); COUNTIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%) Kenya; Corruption; Industry and Infrastructure
TEXT: RESIDENTS of Mtwapa town, Kilifi have protested poor infrastruture in the county. They blocked the Mombasa-Malindi highway on Wednesday. Reformed Matatu Owners Association chairman Elvis Kipkoech accused the county government of failing to deliver necessary services. He said instead county officers have engaged in corruption and mismanagement of funds meant for development. "We have waited for one year and the county government has not delivered anything. What we continue to witness is poor roads, poor health services, luck of sanitation facilities and insecurity in Mtwapa," Kipkoech told the Star during the demonstrations.

TITLE: Kakamega KNUT Officials to Sit On Hiring Panels to Stop Corruption
SUBJECT: TEACHING & TEACHERS (92%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); TEACHER UNIONS (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); CORRUPTION (87%) Kenya; Corruption; Education
TEXT: THE Kenya National Union of Teachers officials in Kakamega county have said they will sit on interviewing panels in the county. County secretary Patrick Chungani yesterday said all Knut executive secretaries at the subcounties will sit on the panels to safeguard the public's interests. Speaking to the Star in Kakamega town, Chungani said the exercise risks being flawed by corrupt education offices as was the July 14 police recruitment, which led to nullification in 36 centres. "Most education officers here are not locals.They invite their relatives from elsewhere to take up the slots," he said. The Teachers Service Commission plans to hire 10,000 teachers. TSC secretary Gabriel Lengoiboni has directed all TSC county directors to ensure strict adherence to hiring criteria and timelines. Chungani said Knut officials will take up chances provided for the public representatives on the panels. "We don't want a situation where the exercise will be nullified and restarted afresh because we need teachers in classrooms as soon as possible," he added.

TITLE: Systemic Corruption and Embezzlement Began At Independence [opinion]
COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); BELGIUM (54%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); FAMILY (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (88%); COUPS (87%); ETHICS (78%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); SHOOTINGS (65%); ARRESTS (65%); RELIGION (56%); HOUSE ARREST (50%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Indeed, from the get go, Jomo Kenyatta and his ilk were originators of our systematic corruption, gorging themselves up with the choicest pieces of the Kenyan economy. It is sad because Jomo Kenyatta was an intellectual who was counted among the Pan-African movement founding fathers of emerging independent African nations. They knew capitalism was a mortal enemy of culture and religion, and all loathed it. These men were egalitarians at heart, with Kenyatta openly declaring that our country would be run based on African traditions and ethics (Democratic African Socialism). Along the way somehow, somewhere, Kenyatta met a reality check. When addressing nervous settlers in Nakuru on being elected Prime Minister in 1963, he shocked his listeners and his advisers alike, when he told the settlers, inter alia, that he would take care of their interests and that they needn't leave the country. America had just emerged as the dominant western world power and two significant events had taken place. In 1953, America orchestrated the overthrow of Iranian democratically-elected leader (Mossadegh - who had nationalised Shell Oil) in a coup, sending a clear message to all leaders in the Middle East. Six years later, in January 1961, democratically-elected Prime Minister of mineral rich Congo, Patrice Lumumba, was similarly, through American CIA supported coup, overthrown and executed by the firing squad. Lumumba was a Pan-Africanist who had told his former master, Belgium - "We are no longer your monkeys", and had made clear his intentions to nationalise the mines because the wealth of the nation belonged to the Congolese people. During this period his counterpart to be, the future Kenyan Prime Minister Jomo Kenyatta, was under house arrest in Lodwar and was released from there in August that same year. Those shots fired at Lumumba were heard by all African leaders - the choice was theirs to make. The west had just made it clear that independence was not meant to disrupt existing western business arrangements or other interests. But the west also pacified and took care of those leaders who heeded the warning. To them was given western protection and they and their families were well looked after by the western corporations, with some of their family members sitting in western corporation board rooms. With Kenyatta's idealism dead, it was replaced by a penchant for authoritarianism, which often leads to excesses and corruption, and Kenyatta was no exception to this rule. Kenyatta was forced to surrender to the very system he had sworn to do away with. He also ignored Pan-Africanism and concentrated his efforts warding off his colleagues who wanted an egalitarian system in Kenya, while at the same time amassing enormous family fortune by virtue of his position as President of Kenya. Jomo Kenyatta's incubated mess of corruption passed over to the next two Kenyan generations. The second President whose simple philosophy was Nyayo (following footsteps), stepped right into the mess and carried it forward with excesses that were gross. The country became so corrupt and his leadership so authoritarian that you could not with any practical sense differentiate the three arms of government. Parliament had no force and the Judiciary for all intents and purposes was a department in the office of the President. All structures of government were eviscerated with all authority belonging to the President and his henchmen. It is during Moi's government that wealth replaced to a large extent the character of a person and the society lost itself in economic cannibalism. The corrupt systems of power could therefore pillage without fear of any repercussions. Today, the incubated corruption has broken out into the lawlessness, and the insecurity we find ourselves confronted with today. Uhuru and Raila are surrounded by people deep in the vice and neither can stop corruption. As a result of corruption, we are now a country constituted of two people, the haves and the have-nots. The haves have wrestled constitutional power from the people and have oriented themselves towards dominance and prejudice. The have-nots suffer from hunger and a cloud of servitude hangs over them. Half are unemployed with three quarters of this burden being shouldered by the youth. Yet one of every three shillings in Treasury is being stolen through corruption. The Githongo's and the Lumumba's of anti-corruption commissions are put in place as window dressing for no one can realistically step where the snakes coil, and that is why invariably they are all run off when they get close to the den. Our economy must stop hemorrhaging money through corruption, or we will self-destruct and join the litany of failed states. We have to affirm our civic virtue and shared sacrifice for the benefit of all Kenyans by shoring our defenses against the vice. To this end, we should take it as a duty to assist others who need to be helped to rise above ignorance and attain knowledge that supports their rightful action against the vice of corruption, and spread that "ripple of hope," for ignorance is the wall that contains people as inmates of poverty. Government business is the people's business and government budget is everybody's budget. Secondly, corruption is responsible for many deaths in Kenyan by means such as lack of health and sanitation, hunger, lawlessness and so on. In shoring up defences against it, corruption involving public funds and assets ought to be punished by reciprocating the death penalty. For reasons stated above, anti-corruption commissions can't work - in our system we may need a body that incorporates justices from outside Kenya, such as from commonwealth countries, to investigate and deal without fear or favour with our sinful happy fraudsters. Lastly, we need to return Kenya to an atmosphere of unity. Our problems will not go away unless we address the economic crimes of the past. Perhaps we could use a set up in the fashion of a truth and reconciliation commission as a starting point to right the wrongs, wherein fugitive money and investments can be returned by applying restorative rather retributive justice, without vindictiveness or bitterness. And lastly, let us remember "all that is necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing."

TITLE: Corruption Probe for Kirinyaga Executive
SUBJECT: MISCONDUCT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CORRUPTION (78%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (75%); MISAPPROPRIATION (73%); DISMISSALS (73%); HOSPITALS (72%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: A nine-member committee has been formed to probe Kirinyaga county Health executive Joyce Muriithi. She is accused of on gross misconduct, misappropriation of funds for Kerugoya District Hospital and incompetence. Nyangati ward representative Samuel Maina on Wednesday moved a motion to remove Muriithi from office.He said the docket should be headed by a professional, not a lab technician. Maina said Muriithi has been frustrating and using vulgar language on hospital directors. She is also accused of overstepping her mandate by hiring and firing staff. Maina said Muriithi has been using the county vehicle for personal use. George Kagori, a nominated MCA, said Muriithi called the county driver a month ago when directors of Kerugoya District Hospital were going for a training in Nairobi and ordered him to pick her from Embu "where she had gone for a date". She said the officers should look for alternative means of transport. "It is very unfortunate for Muriithi to use the county vehicle for her personal use when hospital officers were on a serious mission. We will ensure rats will not feast on our stores. We are ready to remove all the rats," Kagori said. Kerugoya hospital is in debts amounting to Sh200 million. Speaker Ann Wangechi gave the committee, chaired by Gudsone Muchina, until September 3 to table a report.

TITLE: Police Recruiment Experienced Corruption
SUBJECT: POLICE FORCES (90%); CORRUPTION (89%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Transparency International wants the Police Service commission to always ensure private observers are allowed to monitor police recruitment exercises. Director Samuel Kimeu says they have received many complains about the recent recruitment and wants action taken on those who flouted the law

TITLE: EACC Probes MPs Over Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); NATIONAL SECURITY (90%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (78%); APPROVALS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); WITNESSES (76%); POLICE FORCES (75%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE activities of the National Assembly Committee on Administration and National Security are under scrutiny by the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. This follows claims that the Committee bungled its probe into the multi-billion-shilling Safaricom tender, for individual financial gain. An insider at the EACC's Integrity Centre HQ confided to the Star that the Commission is compiling documentation on how the Committee handled its investigations into the Sh14.7 billion Safaricom tender deal. The deal is for the provision of a national surveillance, communication, command and control system for the National Police Service. It is meant to help the security forces to rise to the challenges of identifying criminals as well as improving coordination and rapid response to crime and terror incidents as they unfold. Though the Committee, chaired by Tiaty MP Asman Kamama, tabled its report in the House on Thursday approving the deal, EACC has commenced its investigation over claims that MPs may have been compromised. The Committee's investigations were triggered following a public uproar over the manner in which the project was given out, with claims that it was awarded in disregard of the procurement laws. "As a Commission we are relying on information provided to us by one of their own. The Commission also notes that senior individuals who were to appear before the Committee did not and instead it went on to clear the tender without the input of those who failed to appear," the official said. "It is also clear that the Committee disapproved the tender ab initio, but we want to find out whether the Committee's initial stance was an act of staking a higher bargain," adds the officer, saying that the Commission will recommend prosecution if the claims are supported. There have been complaints that MPs oppose government projects only to approve them later after "dubious and questionable" investigations. The Transport and Infrastructure committee chaired by Starehe MP Maina Kamanda is another one also being investigated by the EACC. The other committees that have come under EACC scrutiny are Energy, Information and Communication Chaired by Kigumo MP Jamleck Kamau, Labour and Social Welfare of David Were (Matungu) and Health, chaired by Rachael Nyamai (Kitui South). An MP who sits in the Security Committee and who did not want to be named said that it was indeed compromised. He said that the Committee duplicated every detail of information given by key witnesses and that it had nothing of its own. "The media is also to blame for the untoward conduct of the Committee. When the chairman launched the investigations, he spoke so tough against the tender and then potential witnesses but this fizzled out. It is the same thing that happened with the Committee and at some time you media people were locked out of the meetings - this was negotiation time if you didn't know," the MP revealed. While clearing the deal, the Committee recommended that the project should continue and that there was no ulterior motive on the choice of single-sourcing Safaricom to implement it. "The company has the requisite financial capability and the experience in providing a telecommunications network and infrastructure in the country. Given the urgency and the precarious security situation in the country, Safaricom was the most appropriate entity to implement the project," the committee recommended. The report went on to say: "The Committee was also satisfied that due diligence was carried out and that the procurement process was aboveboard, with all the necessary stakeholders consulted". The officer was categorical that EACC was not against the MPs' approving the communication and surveillance system, but the manner in which the probe was conducted. However, it will require the approval of the House if the project is to continue. Already, a section of Cord MPs have vowed to shoot down the report, or adopt it with far-reaching amendments.

TITLE: County to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (88%); COUNTIES (88%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (88%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: The Kiambu government has embarked on a new strategy to fight corruption. Speaking in Thika town yesterday, Finance executive Mary Nguli said her department will promote integrity, transparency and accountability in the management of public resources. Nguli said the county government has laid down an action plan for fighting corruption to be implemented over the next one year. The action plan specifies measures and activities for the implementation of strategic objectives, time limits, responsible entities and resources required for implementation.

TITLE: Police Corruption Causes Insecurity [editorial]
COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); RWANDA (79%); UGANDA (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); BRIBERY (78%); EXTORTION (78%); AL-SHABAAB (74%); ANIMAL POACHING & TRAFFICKING (67%); WILDLIFE (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: YESTERDAY MPs complained that officers were demanding money from applicants in Monday's police recruitment exercise. The money is not chickenfeed - it can be up to Sh200,000 per recruit. And today the Star has run a Spotlight story that police have continued to extort money from residents of Eastleigh long after the end of the security sweep that started in April. Allegedly police are rounding up children and threatening to lock them up at Kasarani unless their parents pay a ransom to have them released. Corruption in recruitment and in the Eastleigh sweep are connected. The police have to recover the investment that they made to get the job. Kenya remains far more insecure than Uganda, Tanzania or Rwanda. And, regrettably, the Kenyan police are more corrupt than their counterparts in neighbouring countries. Kenyan insecurity is correlated to corruption in the security services. Al Shabaab operatives or ivory poachers in Kenya will be given enough money to pay a hefty bribe to the police if they are caught. No wonder the security operation in Eastleigh did not net a single terrorist despite harassing residents for months. No wonder poachers are rarely caught despite the mass slaughter of our wildlife. End corruption and we will end insecurity. Quote of the day: "Things will get better if you just hold out long enough. " - Jamaican singer Desmond Dekker was born on July 16, 1941.

TITLE: Cabinet Secretaries Agree to Limit Foreign Trips, Fight Corruption
COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); AFRICA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%); MOROCCO (79%); ALGERIA (79%); LIBYA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INTERNATIONAL TOURISM (91%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); COUNTIES (90%); APPROVALS (90%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); NATIONAL PARKS (78%); ETHICS (77%); INFRASTRUCTURE (75%); ENTREPRENEURSHIP (74%); PUBLIC FINANCE (73%); AIRPORTS (71%); CARTELS (71%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (68%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Cabinet Secretaries have resolved to limit their foreign trips to only the most critical ones. During a Cabinet meeting today, the Cabinet resolved that Ambassadors and County Commissioners will henceforth represent Cabinet Secretaries where appropriate to reduce travel. The meeting also resolved to "ruthlessly" tackle corruption and unethical practices including removing individuals, cartels and enablers of corruption. "Without fear or favour. All offices involved in corruption must be dismissed and charged in Court" the Cabinet said. During the meeting the Cabinet approved amendments to the Public Finance Management Bill, 2014 for both National and County governments. Amendments to the the National Youth General Act (2009) that rationalizes membership from 24-29 years in line with financial prudence and austerity measures was also approved. The Cabinet also agreed that the construction of a road in the Southern Bypass within the boundary of the Nairobi National Park will consume 38 Hectares of the park. The Cabinet resolved however that the park will be compensated hectare for hectare. The road is expected to ease congestion in the city centre by re-routing heavy commercial and other vehicles proceeding to Rift Valley and East African Countries The construction of more digital integrated infrastructure to enhance security at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport was also approved during the meeting. The Cabinet also directed that immediate solutions must be found to curb increasing slums along the Moi International Airport in Mombasa. Cabinet Secretaries will also direct government departments down to the Counties to buy Kenyan products and services and should only resort to buying foreign goods and services if they are not available or cannot be produced in Kenya. Ministries were encouraged to challenge local firms/entrepreneurs opportunity to improve competitiveness and standard of their products instead of dismissing them at the first instant. Cabinet Secretaries also agreed to support the Regional Centre on Small Arms in the Great Lakes Region, the Horn of Africa and Bordering States (RECSA) to curb conflict in the region. Also approved was the closure of the Kenya Embassy in Libya while enabling new Missions in Algeria and Morocco.

TITLE: Cashless Matatu System to Curb Corruption On Roads
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); AGREEMENTS (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Transport and Shipping
TEXT: Public transport operators say transition into the cashless payment system of fare will reduce corruption and reduce recklessness on the roads when cash is phased out. Simon Kimutai, chairman of the Matatu Owners Association, said at least 30 per cent of daily collections never reach vehicle owners, "as it is either used in bribing, stolen by crew or pay for incidents of road mischief". "Cashless payment will therefore curb issues of carelessness on our roads. They are mostly occasioned by the mindset that the offender will pay for it with the cash they collect," Kimutai told The Star. It is estimated that more than Sh150 million is collected by matatus daily in Nairobi alone, with corruption on the roads thriving due to the free-flowing cash. Matatu owners however say the State reneged on an agreement that migration to cashless payment platform would be gradual so as to giver users ample time to understand the system's dynamics. They now want the government to drop its stance of issuing deadlines for the sector to adopt a cashless payment system. Kimutai said customer education is needed before passengers can be restricted to cashless systems to pay for fare, lest the whole process fails. A zoning approach should be used in big towns, Kimutai said, to ensure smooth transition. "We can, for example, start with a route like Ngong where the passengers are educated then assisted in acquiring the means for paying fare. We will then observe how users shift to paying and work on any teething problems before moving to another route," he said. "This way, we shall address emerging issues without necessarily abusing the innovation."

TITLE: 'Govt Must Firmly Tackle Corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (73%); LINES OF CREDIT (71%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: GOVERNMENT must urgently investigate corruption cases and take action against those found guilty in order to boost confidence among international investors, economists say. Zimbabwe has traditionally performed dismally in terms of ease of doing business rankings largely owing to poor governance, policy uncertainty and a high rate of corruption. Top local economist John Robertson told businessdigest corruption cases such as the CMED scam damage the country's reputation and reduce its chances of securing credit. Last week the Zimbabwe Independent reported that the CMED's battle to recover US$3,8 million in a botched fuel deal in which private supplier First Oil failed to deliver paid for fuel had sucked in President Robert Mugabe's office as it has emerged the parastatal, together with government's fuel distributor PetroTrade, approached officials in the Office of the President and Cabinet to resolve the matter. "There is a lot of indiscipline in government and this is bad when we are looking for lines of credit," Robertson said. He said people found guilty of corruption should be prosecuted. Economist Takunda Mugaga said Mugabe should demonstrate seriousness in fighting corruption in high offices. "Fighting graft at corporate level is proving difficult because parastatal bosses like those at the CMED and GMB, for instance, are just shadows of the bigger ghosts that are untouchable," said Mugaga. "We have heard the First lady (Grace Mugabe) accusing top officials of corruption and this damages the country's reputation so there must be investigations and perpetrators must be dealt with." Mugaga said Mugabe is in a difficult position where fighting corruption cases involving his lieutenants will likely lead to counter-accusations against him. "It will be like throwing stones when you live in a glass house, he cannot afford to fight corruption because his house is on fire because of this animal called corruption."

TITLE: Authorities Must Act On Corruption Reports
SUBJECT: ACCOUNTING (90%); ANNUAL REPORTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (89%); SCANDALS (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); AUDITS (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (75%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (75%); WAGES & SALARIES (74%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (70%); ECONOMIC POLICY (65%); ECONOMIC NEWS (65%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: NOTHING illustrates government's complicity in the corruption besieging the country more than its failure to act on the Auditor and Comptroller-General Mildred Chiri's annual reports which never disappoint in exposing entrenched graft, abuse of public resources and misgovernance at state entities. The latest instalment of the report beats a familiar path, exposing among others, massive impropriety in most government ministries, the shambolic condition of state enterprises and parastatals, non-production of asset registers and egregious disregard of clearly laid down regulations and procedures. The report comes against the backdrop of sensational media revelations earlier this year of corruption at state enterprises, parastatals and local authorities, with executives raking in "obscene" salaries despite the parlous state of their entities and the economy at large. The mildly-anticipated -- on a count of government's record of inaction -- crackdown on graft has since failed to materialise despite systematic, sustained and scandalous revelations. While scarce public funds are channelled towards producing the useful audit report, its production has become a mere ritual for, despite consistently exposing the rot and general malaise at the concerned enterprises, its findings are filed away without adopting corrective measures. During this year's Mid-Term Fiscal policy Review, Finance minister Patrick Chinamasa bemoaned the fact that most of the key public entities continued to underperform, in the process incurring deficits, thus remaining an albatross around the struggling fiscus' neck. as oft-cited in Chiri's reports, Chinamasa said the poor performance of public entities is largely attributable to weak corporate governance systems and resistance to reform proposals by management. "Challenges related to our public enterprises manifest through unsustainable salaries, allowances and benefits for top managers at the expense of service delivery; weak oversight on public entities underline ministries' purview, absence of boards to give direction to a public entity ... and corrupt practices," he said. These challenges highlight the need for government to implement sustainable and practical turn-around strategies, Chinamasa said, without divulging them. But any turnaround intervention not informed -- at least in part -- by Chiri's recommendations would be an exercise in futility. Government is aware of the root cause of the problems perennially bedevilling parastatals and state entities, but remains unmoved to act, giving further credence to the existence of a politically expedient patronage network run by the ruling elite. It is time parliament awoke from its deep slumber and played its oversight role by pressuring ministers to account. While Chiri's reports are conveniently ignored thanks in part to our shirking MPs, South Africa's Public Protector Thuli Madonsela, whose role is analogous to that of our Auditor and Comptroller-General, has given South African President Jacob Zuma and the ruling ANC nightmares on accountability issues. Madonsela reports are taken seriously, with parliament demanding answers and corrective measures.

TITLE: Evangelical Society Asks Politicians to Confess Corruption Sins
SUBJECT: RELIGION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (74%) Ghana; Corruption
TEXT: The Ghana Evangelical Society has called for the establishment of a National Week of Confession and Repentance for politicians and citizens to resign from their corrupt practices, evil and wicked ways. The national week of confession and repentance, according to the group, was a decree made by God Himself and revealed to them for the nation Ghana to observe between April and May. The society is of the view that God reigns and rules in the affairs of men, adding "except the Lord builds and watches over Ghana, the builders and watchmen of the country will work in vain for permanent peace, progress, prosperity and good of the land." The leader of the society, Rev. Prof. Enoch Immanuel Amanor Agbozo, addressing a press conference recently in Accra, believed that Ghana's woes should be blamed on individuals selfish pursuant for power, position, pleasure and money. "The Lord has asked His servant, Rev. Prof. Enoch Immanuel Amanor Agbozo, to announce and make known His first decree on godly government and the restoration of progress and glory to the country," he said. He said Ghana has come to a standstill in her development, due to the high level of corruption being exhibited by the government machinery. "The nation is afflicted by a serious spiritual and cultural malady, namely, the love and worship of money in the land. This is the core factor and prime cause of the stagnation of progress of the nation," he noted. Rev. Prof. Agbozo also blamed churches for not doing much to save the situation for which politicians to continue with the act of looting the nation. "Considering the clear devastating impact and effect of corruption, evil ways and wickedness in the pursuit of power, position, prosperity, possession and fame in church, politics and business and everywhere in the nation, we pray that the media in Ghana will do its utmost to spread, make known, and support the divine decree for the observance of the national week of confession of and repentance from corruption, evil ways and wickedness in the land," the leader pleaded. He called on the government and churches to give full weight to the national week of confession and repentance for the good of the nation and people. "We pray that Ghana will rise up in holy response in fervent prayer, honest confession and repentance unto righteousness on the part of all."

TITLE: BDCS Accuse Bost of Corruption, Mismanagement
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (90%); PETROLEUM WHOLESALERS (90%); AUDITS (90%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (89%); AGREEMENTS (89%); OIL & GAS STORAGE FACILITIES (89%); EXECUTIVES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ACCOUNTING (77%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (77%); BUDGETS (76%); OIL & GAS SHORTAGES (73%); PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION (73%); SHORTAGES (71%); PETITIONS (66%) Ghana; Corruption
TEXT: The Ghana Chamber of Bulk Oil Distributors has accused the management of the Bulk Oil Storage and Transport (BOST) of supervising massive mismanagement and corruption at the state-owned company. The accusation followed an audit report by auditing firm -Ernst & Young, alleging endemic collusion between the Bulk Oil Distribution Companies (BDCs) and some senior officials of BOST, to fleece the country of millions of Ghana cedis. The report indicated that officials of the BDCs allegedly connived with officers at BOST, through bribery and forged documents, to inflate the volumes of products in favour of the BDCs. However, reacting to the findings of the auditing firm on various media networks yesterday, the CEO of the BDCs, Senyo Horsi accused management of BOST of releasing the report to the media to muddy waters and downplay serious allegations of corruption levelled against the management.
