Mr. Horsi claimed the BDCs were victims throughout their dealings with BOST, and therefore, could not be accused of any wrongdoing. Workers of BOST are calling on President John Dramani Mahama to urgently set up an independent committee of inquiry to probe their management for involving in what they described as questionable deals, mismanagement, and corruption that were causing financial loss in millions of dollars to the strategic national asset. Some of the allegations include alleged corruption in the million dollar office accommodation rented for BOST at Dzorwulu in Accra; a shady agreement with TSL, a Ghanaian subsidiary of a Nigerian-owned firm in which BOST is to pay TSL a total amount of about $38 million for a year to operate, maintain and manage BOST's petroleum terminals in the country, as well as a budgetary allocation of $16 million for automation across all BOST depots countrywide. Mr. Horsi said the BOST management released the report to the media to cloud these serious allegations levelled against them by their own workers, and to paint a picture that it is rather some officials of the company who are engaged in corruption. The BDCs had been having a running battle with BOST since the TSL agreement was signed, with the former opposed to the deal. According to the BDCs, the whole deal was shrouded in secrecy and lacked the local content policy of Ghana. The Bulk Oil Distributors indicated they had petitioned the Minister for Petroleum and the Board Chairman of BOST one clear week before the signing of the TSL contract, but the petition was not responded to. According to them, the deal violated Ghana's local content laws and was tantamount to ceding control of a strategic national resource to a Nigerian-owned company. The BDCs pointed out the potential risks in the event of a major dispute with Nigeria, with the example of the shortfall in supply of gas through the West Africa Gas Pipeline.

TITLE: NPP to Demonstrate in Upper East - Over Mismanagement, Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (89%); JOB CREATION (87%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (72%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (72%); STARTUPS (69%); ENTREPRENEURSHIP (64%); RIVERS (50%) Ghana; Corruption
TEXT: REGIONAL EXECUTIVE of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) in the Upper East Region is to embark on a peaceful demonstration on the streets of Bolgatanga on March 26, 2015, to protest against gross mismanagement of the economy and deep-rooted corruption in the Mahama-led administration. At a news conference in Bolgatanga last week Wednesday, the executive said they wish to express on behalf of the good people of the North, their absolute disenchantment with the poor leadership of President John Mahama and his shocking indifference with regards to developmental issues affecting the North. Addressed by the Regional Youth Organizer, Mr. Bashiru Ibrahim, flanked by the Regional Chairman, Mr. Adam Mahama and other executives, the NPP said in the run-up to the 2012 polls, the main message from President Mahama to the good people of the Northern, Upper East and Upper West Regions was that, Northerners should vote for him because he was also a northerner. His message, the NPP noted, resonated with many voters of northern descent across the country, and thus, resulted in electoral advantage the NDC and President were enjoying today. The executive focused on seven key areas of concern to the people of three regions which were described as the poorest. They included the SADA saga, job creation, education, health, leadership, ethnocentrism and the US$ 27 billion Mahama administration had borrowed. On Savannah Accelerated Development Authority (SADA), the NPP recalled that Nana Akufo-Addo's proposal, in the NPP's 2008 campaign, for the establishment of the Northern Development Fund with a seed capital of US$ 1 billion. However, the NPP said President Mahama, who was then the Vice Presidential candidate of the NDC, scoffed at the proposal on the claims that it was a deception and misplaced priority and that, if Nana Akufo-Addo could raise such funds, he should rather have used it to offset the debt owed by the Volta River Authority. Mr. Bashiru Ibrahim said, upon realizing that the policy was indeed catching-up with a lot of Northern electorate, the NDC quickly made a gargantuan U-turn and proposed to establish what they called SADA, and promised to set aside a start-up capital of US$ 200 million and subsequently, inject US$ 1 million into the SADA account every year. Unfortunately, money pumped into SADA could not be accounted for; neither could projects under the authority be traced. Mr. Bashiru and his colleague executives hit hard at President Mahama and his administration for not creating jobs and to make matters worse, jobs created by the erstwhile Kufuor administration such as the National Youth Employment Programme, which was changed to Ghana Youth Employment and Entrepreneurial Agency (GYEEDA) and transmogrified into the creating, looting and sharing of taxpayers' money with impunity. Touching on education, the NPP accused the President and the NDC of short-changing northerners. According to them, feeding grants for second cycle institutions for one academic year had not been released while subventions for these institutions had also not been paid for two terms running. The withdrawal of teacher trainee allowances and the seemingly collapse of the school feeding programme was also condemned by Mr. Bashiru Ibrahim, who titled the press statement: "President John Mahama's betrayal of Northerners - the case of your own brother killing you slowly". They contended that though the NDC government under Mahama had made eradication of 'schools under trees' as one of its unprecedented achievements, there were still 22 Junior High Schools under trees in the Bawku West District of the Upper East Region. The present crises facing the National Health Insurance Scheme and the blatant untruth the President told the nation in his state of the nation address about a supposed 120-bed capacity hospital nearing completion in Garu were major issues raised under the health sector. The NPP therefore demanded unqualified apology from the President.

TITLE: Bravo! the Church Accepts Responsibility for Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: RELIGION (94%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (93%); CORRUPTION (90%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (89%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (67%); INDICTMENTS (66%) Ghana; Religion; Corruption
TEXT: It had seemed this day would never come. For decades the church in Ghana had played the ostrich, merely issuing statements to condemn continuing incidences of corruption, but not bothering as to why the tendency among most Ghanaian is to be corrupt, given half the chance. Now the Christian Council of Ghana (CCG), the umbrella union of traditional churches in the country, has started asking the relevant questions. The CCG Chairman, the Most Reverend Professor Emmanuel Martey, has called on Christians to repent, because the responsibility for the pervasive corruption in the country can only be theirs, and no one else's. "The Christian church is largely to blame for the country's current woes. "The problem comes from those who describe themselves as religious people (Christians)... there are charlatans in the church; there are thieves in the church. "The majority of the population (70%), which claims to be Christian - including all heads of state since independence - has failed the state. "If Ghana is in the state in which we are now, do you tell me the less than 30% of non-Christians are responsible for that? It is not true!" Professor Martey indicted on Joy FM's Super Morning Show on Monday. Most Rev (Prof) Martey, who doubles as the Moderator of the Presbyterian Church of Ghana, blamed the modus operandi of some pastors outside the Christian Council for contributing to the corruption rot in the country. "Some pastors are placing much emphasis on wealth through prophesies, which shouldn't be the case. Many of such prophesies are untrue. "Since biblical times, we've had false prophesies and false prophets... Not all the churches in Ghana are of God... There are satanic churches in Ghana," he stated. On the way forward, the Christian Council boss prescribed the declaration of a state of mourning, during which most Ghanaians, particularly, the Christian faith who constitute about 70% of the nation's population, would repent their involvement in corruption. "We need a sense of repentance... Now the message of corruption is being sung everywhere; let everybody hear it, and let us repent," he said. The Chronicle commends the Christian Council of Ghana for rising up to the occasion and admitting that corruption in the country is in its court. The prescription for repentance is all well and good, but it may well only scratch the surface of the problem. First, the satanic churches and their followers, if indeed they exist in the country, will ignore the call. Satan is totally beyond repentance. Congregations of the Christian Council will repent under the gaze of their reverend ministers, but the probability is that they would backslide in no time, as the tendency toward corruption is ingrained in them. We think the Christian Council needs to do more, like re-thinking about the pampering of the wealthy among its members, without bothering about their sources of wealth. That attitude to the rich pushes the have-nots to push, by hook and crook, to become rich. Though the orthodox churches do not preach that "Jesus wore designer clothes", the perception is that most of the elders in the orthodox churches are the bastion of corruption in the civil and public services. It is likely that if a census of all directors in the public sector - national, regional and district - were taken today, up to 70 percent of them, if not more, would be found to be elders and knights of the Catholic, Anglican, Methodist, Presbyterian, etc., churches. There are reports of district directors of education who have dozens of schools under them without teachers, but refuse to appoint teachers to those schools, just because the applicants are unable to pay the GH¢400 bribe they demand. The Chronicle also urges the church to begin emphasising the "reaping and sowing" aspect of the Gospel of Jesus Christ the Good Shepherd, especially, that the reaping could lead to eternal damnation. The church could also lead a crusade to re-think some the warped moral theories that underline traditional society and pre-dispose us all to corruption. It is time we rejected concepts as "one eats where he works"; "one does not stay by the river side and wash one's hands with spittle" and the like. These are clear clarion calls not to tamper with national resources that come under one's care. So long as such axioms are inculcated from birth, and there is no clearly demonstrable enforcement that visits swift reprisals for corrupt acts, the fight against corruption will continue to be lost. The time for pontification is over. It is now time to get down to the brass tacks!

TITLE: Mind-Boggling Corruption - Is the Church a Promoter or Barrier? [column]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); RELIGION (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (74%); INDICTMENTS (73%); CONSTRUCTION (73%); TALKS & MEETINGS (67%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (60%) Ghana; Corruption; Religion
TEXT: It appears from the Bureau National Investigation's exposí© at the National Service Secretariat (NSS) that the phenomenon of ghost names in the public sector has grossly been understated. With the manner in which it has been institutionalised at the NSS, all notes on corruption need to be revised for ghost names to be re-classified as the greatest waste pipe on the Consolidated Fund. And why not? GH¢7.9 million monthly, GH¢94,970,400 annually at only one of the over 500 ministries, departments and agencies of state? It may not happen to the same degree everywhere, but the incidence of ghost names must surely cut across the boards of state enterprises. The total rakings from all the traditional sources of corruption in the public sector that come from public funds - inflated contracts, kickbacks on construction contracts - pale into insignificance, compared to the proceeds from ghost names. Consequently, The Chronicle calls on all the multifarious anti-corruption Civil Society Organisations (CSOs), which, for the moment, at least, seem more interested in noise-making than taking concrete action to stem corruption, to re-focus their lenses on uprooting the canker of ghost names from the public service. Our indictment of the anti-corruption CSOs stems from their loud inaction over the illegal payments to Subah for no contractual work done. The Subah case stands out from most other public shenanigans: Whereas most often there is nothing really concrete for one to put one's figure on, here we have an admission by competent authority that indeed GH¢75 million was paid over three years to Subah, when it had not met the conditions precedent to merit such a payment. And yet, none of our CSOs could summon the courage to fire off a simple petition to ask the Commissioner for Human Rights and Administrative Justice to investigate. Pity! From where we sit that will remain a permanent blot on the vaunted anti-corruption credentials of the CSOs. The breaking of the NSS rot coincided with an appeal by CHRAJ to faith-based organsiations to help deter corruption. This was at a CHRAJ-organised engagement meeting in Bolgatanga that brought together pastors and leaders of the church, Muslim clerics and leaders of other faith-based institutions under theme of "Building Broad Coalition for Combating Corruption and Enhancing Integrity in Ghana", designed to encourage spiritual leaders to use the pulpit and other places of worship to educate and enhance the integrity of members and the public to fight corruption.. At the forum, CHRAJ Deputy Commissioner Richard Quayson said corruption, which had become part of everyday mannerism in Ghana, was of great concern to the Church and other religious bodies, therefore, there was an urgent need for those bodies to "help chart a path against the canker." That is a good move on the part of CHRAJ. But, regrettably, The Chronicle has some reservation whether the Church, as currently constituted, is a wholesome vessel for the fight against corruption. Rather, their posturing would seem to encourage corruption among their members. The radio and tele-evangelists among them preach mostly on prosperity, that encourages followers to "sow seeds" in tens of thousands of cedis and dollars, with the justification that "Jesus wore designer clothes". So they should also be able to afford designer clothes. Fine! But, are they also ready to die on the cross as Jesus Christ did? Nor do the traditional orthodox ones fare any better. Their front pews are reserved exclusively for the highest donors at harvests and other fundraising occasions. There is hardly any consideration as to the source of the funds that are so gleefully donated. If a census of the religious backgrounds of the 20 or so directors of the NSS arrested over the ghost names scandal were to be taken, it would most likely turn out that many, if not most of them, are elders of the orthodox churches. However, The Chronicle will admit that there are still religious leaders of integrity who do not put cash ahead of moral integrity, and we pray God to continually empower them to admonish their followers to thread the narrow and rough path to eternal salvation. To the glory of God Almighty. Amen!

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Toothy CHRAJ? [column]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); ANNUAL REPORTS (76%); HUMAN RIGHTS (76%); EMBEZZLEMENT (73%); EXTORTION (73%); HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS (72%); MISAPPROPRIATION (71%) Ghana; Corruption
TEXT: Parliament seems to be in some sort of confusion over which vehicle will best tackle corruption in the country. Last Thursday, July 4, 2014, it reportedly passed into law the National Anti-Corruption Action Plan. The NA-CAP had earlier been touted by no less a person than Justice Emile Short, pioneer chairman of the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice, as the antidote to our corruption woes. And Justice Short must know if anyone should! Among its virtues, the NA-CAP is said to have been designed to "ensure efficiency, accountability and transparency in both public and private sectors, by investigating and prosecuting corrupt practices". However, on July 8, 2014, less than a week after the NA-CAP was enacted, a ranking member of the Constitutional, Legal and Parliamentary Affairs, Hon. Ben Abdallah has advocated that "CHRAJ be given the mandate to prosecute cases of corruption that come before". Contributing to the debate on CHRAJ's annual report for 2010, Abdallah (NPP, Offinso South), disclosed that CHRAJ received 38 cases of corruption in 2010, with three coming from whistleblowers. "The cases included abuse of power/office, extortion of money and fraud. Out of the total number, misappropriation /embezzlement were 11, the highest", he said. Abdallah emphasized that CHRAJ did not perform as expected in the area of corruption hence the committee's suggestion to it to consider "partnering" with such agencies as the Ghana Integrity Initiative, as a way of addressing the problem of lack of resources. Deputy Interior Minister, James Agalga, in his contribution said though CHRAJ has acquitted itself creditably over the years in its human rights and administrative functions, but it was too under resourced to fight corruption Agalga (NDC, Builsa North), therefore, reiterated the call for the adequate resourcing to "fight corruption to the barest minimum". The Chronicle wonders why Parliament would enact NA-CAP anti-corruption regime and four days later asked that CHRAJ be resourced to also fight corruption. Hello, is there a suggestion here that the MPs and other politicians do not particularly like the teeth NA-CAP has been endowed with? Are they too soft or too strong? It appears to us though that Justice Short would prefer the NA-CAP as Ghana's anti-corruption vanguard. And given his CHRAJ background and his involvement in the fashioning out of the NA-CAP, we back his preference. However, The Chronicle is unhappy with the "secrecy" in which NA-CAP has been shrouded and asks that the veil be lifted today without further delay. In our editorial of July 7, we urged Justice Short to kindly use his good offices to get the full text of the NA-CAP published, possibly on ghanaweb, so that all and sundry would be enabled to know what is it with the NA-CAP that gets him so excited it. We re-iterate the call today, in case we put it too poorly the last time. Such publication will facilitate the mustering of the necessary pressure on government to implement NA-CAP expeditiously, which he has called for. Justice Short, we wait!

TITLE: Full Text of National Anti-Corruption Action Plan, Please? [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); HUMAN RIGHTS (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%) Ghana; Corruption
TEXT: The pioneer Chairman of the Commission for Human Rights and Administrative Justice, Justice Emile Short, has been going on and on about a National Anti-Corruption Action Plan, reportedly put together co-operatively about three years ago, as the panacea for the monster of corruption devouring Ghana. When he first broached the subject publicly about late last year, Justice Short pleaded with President John Dramani Mahama to the release the NA-CAP document, which was submitted to him while he was Vice-President, to enable Parliament enact it into law to boost the fight against corruption. Among the many virtues touted for it, it is said that the NA-CAP "will mobilise efforts and resources of stakeholders to fight corruption." "It also aims to ensure efficiency, accountability and transparency in both public and private sectors, by investigating and prosecuting corrupt practices." Now, Justice Short reports that Parliament, last Thursday, July 4, passed the NA-CAP Act. Apparently, President Mahama had heeded his entreaty, supported by one of our editorials, and forwarded the draft NA-CAP Bill to Parliament. In an interview with Citi News, reported on Ghanaweb, Justice short is quoted as having "advised Parliament to implement the newly adopted plan. "This is the first step, and the greatest challenge is the implementation of the plan. I think that we need to be hopeful and optimistic that the government will implement [it]. Mr. Short believes merely having a plan without implementing is of no use. According to him, the government will save more money if it takes immediate steps to implement the action plan. He, therefore, stated: "We (Ghanaians) have to be hopeful and put pressure on the government to implement the plan." Justice Short sounds so passionate in his belief that the NA-CAP is the proverbial Philosopher's Stone, or cure-all for our corruption pandemic. The Chronicle commends his unrelenting advocacy for a corruption-free Ghana, and wishes him more grease to his able elbows. However, we seem to note some sort of ambiguity. In one breath he advises Parliament to implement the anti-corruption act, and in the next, advocates pressure from all Ghanaians to get the government to implement the law. Which is which? Who has the responsibility under the law to implement the NA-CAP - Parliament or Government, or both? There is also the implication under its second aim that the operating arm or the Secretariat of the NA-CAP will be on auto-pilot in its investigative and prosecution activities, and possibly, in its financing. The wait-until-we-tell-you-to-move syndrome has been made a mess of by our on-the-make politicians, because of their parochial interests, and, in this day and age, any state institution with such a load on its neck is not worth celebrating. If the Secretariat of the NA-CAP is truly that independent, The Chronicle, The Spear of the Nation, will offer the NA-CAP Secretariat all the necessary support. But, please Justice Short, let us kindly have the full text and study it for ourselves. Such is necessary to gauge the sort of support we need to give the Secretariat. We await!

TITLE: Procurement Officers Should Shun Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (90%); BRIBERY (89%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (89%); POWER PLANTS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); BEST PRACTICES (76%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (72%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (69%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: These works range from schools to hospitals, power plants to dams, office cleaning to construction of long stretches of roads. These expenditures take up huge public resources thereby creating ideal opportunities for corruption. TI indicates that from a public contract's overall value, on average 10 to 25 per cent may disappear into the pockets of corrupt individuals in a country. In short, it undermines and compromises the quality of works and services, which in turn becomes more costly and can lead to loss of lives. Anyone involved in procurement of public goods and services, as well as tenders for works on behalf of the Government is hence a critical player. We, therefore, want to echo the sentiments of the Zambia Institute of Purchasing and Supply (ZIPS) that the procurement officers in the country should desist from engaging in corrupt activities. As already alluded to the people who are involved in procurement are susceptible to being involved in corruption and, therefore, are part of the solution when it comes to curbing the vice. Buyers or procurement officers, especially those working in the public sector, usually find themselves in tempting situations because of the amounts involved in the transactions they oversee. Instead of succumbing to the temptation, they should be in the first line of whistle blowers who should help in combating against the cancerous scourge, which is a drain on public coffers. We agree with ZIPS president George Mumba that the procurement officers should strive to fight corruption in the sector, instead of being the drivers of the vice. The officers should resist the temptation of being bribed and help bring to book the vendors who are in the habit of offering these bribes. Further, the institute should also strive to ensure that its members do not engage in dubious dealing through continuous training on best practices in the profession. As trained professionals, apart from resisting bribery, procurement officers should be guiding other managers on good procurement practices. There are, currently so many cases, which are going on, resulting from failure by some Government officials in the country to adhere to laid-down procurement and tender procedures. Year in, year out, the Auditor General's reports reveal huge amounts of funds lost by the Government through public tenders and procurements. Some of these cases emanate from sheer failure to follow the procedures. If heeded to, the advice and guidance of the procurement officers on this matter would prove to be handy in curbing this seemingly rising trend. The cost of corruption in the procurement process is high as it adds to the cost of services to the public. Ultimately, corruption is a burden on the cost of doing business in a country. Leaving it unabated would be allowing individuals to enrich themselves at the expense of the quality of public works and services. Some people in corrupt countries have paid a terrible personal price for collapsed buildings as the result of the shoddy works perpetuated by this vice. Others have lost their lives through counterfeit medicines as the result of the corruption in the supply chain.

TITLE: Nip Corruption in the Bud
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (77%); ANNUAL REPORTS (76%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLITICS (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (72%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (68%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (63%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (50%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: THE call by President Edgar Lungu for the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) to intensify the fight against graft is timely and must be adhered to. Corruption deprives ordinary people of basic services and undermines the country's development. It is, therefore, the duty of every Zambian to contribute to the fight against graft. ACC is at the moment dealing with 413 cases of suspected corruption received in the first quarter of this year alone albeit only 129 reports contained substances of graft. Corruption is not only unacceptable, it is a crime against development and the consequences are borne by marginalised people. But reports of corruption in the public and private sector are a growing concern even when it was expected that by now, the loopholes should have been sealed. There seems to be no 'immediate' action to the glaring financial irregularities revealed in the Auditor General's Annual reports published in the recent past few years, for instance. Punitive measures must be taken against erring officials including civil servants perpetuating the loss of public property, a scourge which is seemingly at an alarming level. This is one of the ways the public can have confidence that the tax payers' money is being put to good use. Government must put in place long lasting measures that will curb the abuse of public funds. The Government funded programmes such as the Social Cash Transfer Scheme, Youth Development Fund (YDF), Constituency Development Fund (CDF) are meant to benefit the people, but how are these funds monitored? Do the Ministries of Community Development, Local Government and Youth and Sport, have a monitoring system to ensure that the funds are used as intended? Concerns have also been raised about the fuel procurement process and the awarding of road contracts. Now is there a deliberate system to monitor the transparency in these processes? What about the employment processes where employers seek inducements? This is going on in our country and it must come to a stop as jobs should only be earned by merit. There is also need to step up the monitoring of how donor funding was being utilised particularly in community schools and health centres. Year on year donors are giving Zambia money and it is only appropriate that there is a strict monitoring measure of how these funds are being utilised. Our country cannot succeed in the fight against poverty if people continue to dip their fingers in public or private coffers and that is why the corruption must be put to a stop. Government should consider the establishment of a fast-track court on corruption to ensure that cases of graft are disposed off in good time. It is sad to note that corruption cases dating back many years ago under the Task Force on Corruption are still before the courts of law. There should also be a law in place compelling all political parties to state their source of funding for the sake of accountability. ACC should not be selective in how they handle cases of corruption. The Commission should effectively deal with complaints of graft to ensure transparency and accountability across all spheres of the Zambian community. ACC should decentralise its operations to other parts of the country and introduce their services in major local languages to encourage people to interact with the Commission. Government and every other stakeholder should enhance partnerships and ensure a firm approach so that anyone caught in the act of corruption is brought to book. Send comments and contributions to jameskunda91@gmail.com or 0973182006

TITLE: ACC Records 413 Suspected Corruption Cases
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); ELECTION FRAUD (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (74%); CONTRACT AWARDS (74%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLITICS (72%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (69%); ACQUITTAL (69%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has received 413 reports of suspected cases of corruption in the first quarter of this year. ACC public relations manager, Timothy Moono said out of the cases recorded, 129 reports contained substances of corruption. Mr Moono said this during the ACC first quarter media briefing for 2015 in Lusaka yesterday. He said that of the 129 cases, 60 were authorised for investigations, while 56 reports did not have sufficient details of the corruption offences to warrant investigations to be conducted. "Currently, the commission has a total of 1,151 cases under investigation. The commission recorded 12 arrests around the country and 92 prosecution cases are before the courts of law. We recorded 5 acquittals, secured 9 convictions and 10 cases were at appeal stage," he said. Some of the ongoing matters and convictions which occurred during the quarter and those forwarded from the previous year include the arrests of Southern Province Permanent Secretary Annie Sinyangwe, Cabinet Office Permanent Secretary Annie Mwewa, and Mwansabombwe Member of Parliament Rodgers Mwewa which are before the courts of law. Mr Moono reaffirmed the commission's commitment to the fight against corruption to ensure the country yields results that contribute to good governance and national development. The ACC also carried out investigations where the commission received 3 complaints of suspected electoral corruption that were unsubstantiated. Mr Moono said the ACC had monitored various campaign rallies and activities of political parties which participated in the January 20 election to ensure they adhered to the provisions of the law pertaining to electoral corruption. On the alleged corruption in the procurement of Oil, he said that the ACC was vigorously following up the matter to take note of allegations of corruption. He said that the Commission sat on various tender committees to ensure that guidelines were followed. "The ACC acknowledged the allegations of the illegal procurement of oil as the country had a shortage and will take measures to tackle the issue. This was in public domain and we are following it up to ensure transparency and accountability," he said. On communication towers, he said that the commission was thoroughly investigating the construction of the towers and how the tenders were awarded.

TITLE: 'Fight Corruption in Procurement Process'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (91%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (90%); SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (90%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (88%); SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE (74%); RURAL DEVELOPMENT (74%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (73%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (73%); POOR POPULATION (69%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (69%); MISAPPROPRIATION (67%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (65%); POVERTY RATES (65%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (64%); HOTELS & MOTELS (55%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (50%) Zambia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: GOVERNMENT has urged the Zambia Institute of Purchasing and Supply (ZIPS) to help fight corruption in the procurement processes. Transport, Works, Supply and Communication Minister Yamfwa Mukanga said the Patriotic Front (PF) Government was determined to fight corruption and hence it was important for ZIPS to join hands in fighting the scourge. Mr Mukanga said it was high time the procurement and supply professionals started defending the profession by ensuring that the established procedures and guidelines in the procurement process were followed. He was speaking in Livingstone at Zambezi Sun Hotel yesterday when he officially opened the third ZIPS annual national conference under the theme, 'Celebrating jubilee and focusing on the economic growth beyond the jubilee'. "There will be no development without procurement and that is how important this procurement and supply profession is. "Therefore, the mismanagement of this function has always had adverse effects in the economy such as increased costs for goods and services, misapplication of funds, mismanagement of funds, lack of transparency and accountability, wastage of materials and the list is endless," Mr Mukanga said. He said the quality of purchasing professionals must change through continuous professional training, capacity building and skills improvement. Mr Mukanga said despite an impressive economic growth averaging six per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per year, the country still needs to reduce poverty levels which are high especially in rural areas. "We need to improve in agriculture and also tap into the mineral resources and place emphasis on enhancing growth and rural development," Mr Mukanga said. Speaking earlier, ZIPS President George Mumba said their role as supply chain management professionals was to support the Government in its pursuit of creating sustainable economic development. Mr Mumba said this could be achieved through adherence to procurement procedures as good governance tenets.

TITLE: Ministers Aware of Corruption
SUBJECT: EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (72%); INVESTIGATIONS (66%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; Education
TEXT: THE education ministers have admitted that funds for free primary and secondary education in the country are being misused by some unscrupulous individuals. Geraldine Bitamazire, the education minister, and her deputies Kamanda Bataringaya and Rukutana Mwesigwa, believe that some officials at the ministry and local government level have been swindling government funds. "We are aware that some officials are mismanaging government funds. This is partly because some of them do not have enough technical and operational capacity to handle these funds," Bitamazire said. She added that some schools were constructing shoddy buildings and had failed to account for public funds. The ministers said a few culprits at the education ministry headquarters, have already been penalised for mismanaging public funds. "We cannot say we have corrupt officials at the headquarters. That is the role of the ministry's accounting officer, not political heads (like us). He is supposed to account for the ministry's funds," Bitamazire explained. The three ministers were appearing before the Judicial commission of inquiry probing the mismanagement of public funds on Friday. It is being chaired by Justice Ezekiel Muhanguzi. Ketrah Katunguka, Lawrence Mukiibi and Engineer. Patrick Batumbya are the other members on the commission. The ministers' response arose from a query raised by Justice Muhanguzi, on whether they are aware of allegations that UPE funds are mismanaged.

TITLE: Country Has to Improve on its Corruption Fight [column]
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); FOREIGN RELATIONS (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (90%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (90%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (89%); CORRUPTION (87%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (77%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (77%); PEACEKEEPING (77%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (77%); BUDGETS (77%); RULE OF LAW (77%); FOREIGN POLICY (76%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (72%); BUDGET CUTS (65%); WRITERS (60%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (50%); HUMAN RIGHTS (50%) Uganda; Europe and Africa; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Uganda and the Netherlands are close friends and as with friends in real life, sometimes we agree, sometimes we disagree, but there is always a sound basis for honest and frank dialogue. Topics such as the UN Security Council issues, value for money in pursuing development results, preparations for the elections and democratic policies need frank dialogue. At the end of the dialogue you can agree to disagree, but still remain friends. Both the Netherlands and Uganda are preparing for elections. In the Netherlands these came about unexpectedly, due to a political crisis on the issue of the future of our participation in the peacekeeping mission in Afghanistan. On June 9, this year the Dutch electorate will cast their votes for the 150 Netherlands parliamentarians. Ninteen parties will contest in these elections. The Netherlands Embassy will function as one of the many polling stations. In line with the reciprocity principle, we will invite the Chairman of the Uganda Electoral Commission to send one or more observers to the vote tally on Wednesday June 9. In these elections the future of foreign policy and development cooperation is heavily contested. This will certainly impact on our presence in Uganda. One thing is clear in all political party manifesto's they all want to see a smaller and more efficient bureaucracy. The budget cuts in foreign relations will certainly affect embassies all over the world, including the one in Kampala. A second element is the clear left-right divide in the manifesto's on the future for development cooperation. The parties to the left of the political spectrum in the Netherlands want to maintain or increase the expenses for development co-operation. The parties to the right want to substantially decrease or even abolish development cooperation. So the outcome of the elections and the government formation will be very important for the future of the embassy in Kampala. Our presence in Uganda is mainly based on our development programme. Whatever government will be formed after these elections, one thing is clear, the number of countries that we are supporting at present almost 40, will be reduced. So I expect that by the end of this year, the list of partner countries will be reconstituted and Uganda will have to make it's case to be included on that list. For Uganda to succeed in the competition for funds, there will be a need to show improved performance on a number of indicators: like on achieving the Millennium Development Goals, on fighting corruption, on improving governance, rule of law and protection of human rights, and on the importance accorded to poverty reduction. Also Uganda is preparing for elections in February 2011. This will provide Uganda with an opportunity to prove pessimists ( and if you read the newspaper there are a lot of pessimists around ) wrong. I certainly plan to be around until next year to follow the developments closely. The writer is The Netherlands Ambassador to Uganda

TITLE: Ethics Minister Warns On Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); ETHICS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (78%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (76%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (76%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE ethics and integrity state minister, Nsaba Buturo, has urged Ugandans to demonstrate against corruption. "We wish to see concerned citizens demonstrating in streets against corrupt practices in both private and public offices," Buturo said while addressing Apac district leaders last week. He said corruption knows no colour, tribe, religion or political party. The minister added that whistleblowers would be given 5% of the money recovered from the fraudsters they report. "The law is clear on the protection of whistleblowers against harassment by corrupt officials," he said. Buturo blamed auditors for conniving with officers to swindle resources. "I have no respect for auditors. Some of them simply help thieves account for stolen funds," he explained. Buturo noted that corrupt officers are a threat to the development and stability of the nation. "I am happy that the new Corruption Act includes even the private sector. We shall be able to check accountabilities and activities of civil society organisations," he said. the minister said the country was facing a tragic situation as a result of corruption in public offices. "You occupy that office in public trust; you then fail to realise you are hurting your community by way of diverting resources," he said. Buturo lamented the admiration people have for the corrupt because of stolen money spent in procuring expensive cars and houses. The district chairman, Nicholas Bunga, called for concerted effort to fight corruption. "We need to join hands in the fight against graft, irrespective of political differences. The development projects whose monies are stolen are meant to benefit the community," he said. Bunga called for the implementation of corruption laws by graft fighting institutions.

TITLE: IGG Corruption Fight - Why Do Cases Fail in Court?
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (88%); CORRUPTION (88%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); INTERVIEWS (77%); EVIDENCE (75%); LITIGATION (75%); ARRESTS (74%); EXECUTIVES (73%); WAGES & SALARIES (73%); ACQUITTAL (70%); PETITIONS (70%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: In the past few weeks, most of the cases the former Inspector General of Government (IGG), Faith Mwondha, put against several local leaders have collapsed. The most high profile case was when Thomas Mulondo, the LC5 chairman of Kayunga, who was thrown out of his seat, three years ago regained it after the IGG lost interest according to a statement from the IGG's Office. A week later, former Lubaga North MP, Ken Lukyamuzi, also won a petition against the IGG. Court said he had been relieved of his duties wrongly. Other unclear cases included those of Beswale Kezaala, the Jinja mayor and Mohamed Kanakulya, an education officer in Kamuli district, who also won the case against the IGG. He was accused of using about sh1.9m, allocated for his fuel on personal businesses and employing a driver who had failed interviews which caused the district financial losses. However, Mulondo maintained that these were politically motivated cases that the IGG should have investigated more before arresting him. He says having fallen out with many political leaders and civil servants in the district, including then chief administrative officer (CAO) Maira Mukasa, he became the IGG's target. For the last few years, the IGG has led to the arrest of over 40 local leaders across the country. According to the report of January to June 2008, 133 cases were reported from districts by whistle blowers, comprising 14.5% of total cases. Cases of municipalities, which are also local governments accounted for 6.8%. In the 2009 report, local governments, were mentioned as the leading corrupt institutions in the country again, with 20% of the reports received. In the same report, Kampala had 149 complaints, Masaka 40, while Kabarole had 32. "The complaints were forwarded by many sources including district leaders and other whistle blowers," the IGG, Raphael Baku said. However, these cases rarely go through the courts of law. In most cases, the IGG recommends a course of action. In Mulondo's case, the recommendation was that he vacates office, a decision which was overturned in court. Local leaders argue that most of the cases the IGG handles have political motivation and lack substantial evidence that can see them through the courts. They cite the Mulondo and Kezaala cases as examples. And at the end of the day, it is the Government at loss as the acquitted local leader has to be paid In recent years, the only case involving local leaders that the IGG successfully prosecuted was against MP Herbert Sabila. In Mulondo's case, he is supposed to be paid all his salary and allowances which is about sh72m for the three years that he has not been in office. Lukyamuzi may be paid over sh90m, for which he was not even representing people in Parliament. Leaders lose trust in IGG During a recent retreat of IGG and local leaders from the Lango region at Lira Hotel in March, Lira mayor Peter Owiny, accused the IGG of being partisan and unable to fight corruption. "We support the IGG's fight against corruption, however, our argument is that some of the reported cases are politically motivated," said Iganga district chairman, Asuman Kyafu. They argue that although there is corruption among local leaders, most of the cases brought up are politically motivated. When Mulondo was arrested and physically molested three years ago, local politicians in the district predicted that the arrest was just another chapter in a power struggle whose dimensions change everyday. "These problems result from politicians who have failed to respect their boundaries," says Muwanga Kisaalita, then secretary for finance and administration, and councillor for Kayunga Town Council. He was later charged with Mulondo, but has since been acquitted. Just like Kezaala said during his trial, the IGG office should look beyond the mentioned cases. Local leaders argue that if the IGG worked closely with them, the results of these cases would be less embarrassing. Uganda Local Government Association (ULGA) ethics and accountability committee deputy secretary, Rose Gamwera, says the IGG should work closely with the Accountability and Ethical Code of Conduct Committee of local leaders if it is to have a headway in fighting corruption in local governments. Local leaders say the whistle blowers who the IGG depends on for information may lack the right data about a particular corruption case. "We are all committed to fighting corruption, however, it is important that the masses are given the right information about budgeting and accountability issues. Otherwise, most of the cases might be based on wrong premises and hearsay, which is why when the said corrupt local leaders are taken to court, none of the cases succeeds," explained Peter Ogwang, Speaker of Dokolo district and member of the ULGA Ethics and Accountability Committee. In various reports, the IGG argues that the office is still challenged with limited man-power to effectively investigate cases and powers to see the prosecution of corruption cases through. However, the Government seemed to have answered this by introducing the anti-corruption court that recently started hearing cases. Previously, corruption cases were heard in ordinary courts. District leaders suggest working work with the IGG in handling corruption. Gamwera says: "Our charter of ethics and accountability empowers us to work with the IGG, the Police and the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee to solve corruption in local governments. This is the best way forward."

TITLE: Corruption On the Rise
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); MURDER (90%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (90%); VIOLENT CRIME STATISTICS (89%); CRIME RATES (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); SEX OFFENSES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (77%); ACCIDENTAL FATALITIES (77%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (77%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (76%); TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS (72%); LARCENY & THEFT (70%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (55%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Corruption cases reported to the Police last year more than doubled compared to 2008, according to the 2009 Police report.There was also an increase in cases of ritual murders and deaths in accidents. The report, which was released yesterday, however, shows an overall fall in reported crime cases from 119,000 to 103,000. The number of corruption cases went up to 95 last year, up from 46 the previous year. This does not include the cases being investigated by the IGG. According to Police boss Kale Kayihura, there was an increase in the number of cases involving NAADS funds, local government funds and land fraud. "Given the pervasiveness of corruption, this number is too low. Few people bother to report to the Police for action," Kale explained. He said he had ordered Police officers all over the country to aggressively fight corruption. "We should not always wait for the President to unearth these cases for us to follow them up," the Police boss noted, adding that there was also need to wipe out corruption within the Police. Ritual murders increased to 29 cases last year, up from 25 cases in 2008. Kale, however, said, most of the people reported as missing had been found. Of the reported crime cases last year, about one third were taken to court and of these, a quarter led to convictions. Over 22,000 cases were still pending, bringing the total case backlog to 40,000. Theft was the leading crime in Uganda last year, with over 27,000 cases registered; followed by assaults (17,000) and economic crimes (11,000). Property worth sh167b was lost and less than 10% of that was recovered. Sex-related offenses on the other went down considerably, from 12,000 in 2008 to about 7,000 last year. Rape cases were 619 compared to 1,536 in the previous year. A total of 165 guns and 580 ammunition were recovered from criminals, higher than in 2008. The number of deaths in accidents continues to rise. Over 2,700 people were killed in road accidents last year, as opposed to 2,300 in 2007. No figures for 2008 were made available. Kampala continues to top the list of crime cases, with over 28,000, followed by eastern Uganda. Within Kampala, Katwe, Kawempe, Old Kampala and Kabalagala have the highest crime rates.

TITLE: Govt Lacks Will to Fight Corruption
COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (94%); KENYA (93%); RWANDA (92%); BURUNDI (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); AFRICA (92%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (69%); FREEDOM OF PRESS (63%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Lack of a political will remains the biggest challenge to the fight against corruption in East Africa, the head of a regional anti-corruption body has said. Tito Rutaremara, the president of the East African Association of the Anti-Corruptioní¢- Authorities, said many leaders have stepped up campaigns against corruption, yet the efforts have not been adopted at lower levels of governance. "Sometimes, the political will to fight corruption is only at the top and it does not trickle down to the bottom. We have good laws but without political will at the lowest levels, it is difficult to fight the vice," he said. Rutaremara was speaking on Friday in Kampala at a meeting of heads of anti-corruption agencies from Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda and Burundi. Formed in September 2007, the body brings together five anti-corruption agencies. They include the Inspectorate of Government of Uganda, Special Brigade Anti-Corruption of Burundi, Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission, Office of the Ombudsman of Rwandaí¢-  and the Prevention and Combating of Corruption Bureau of the United Republic of Tanzania. Rutaremara, who is also the chief ombudsman of Rwanda, appealed for funding from the governments of the member states to help the body buy modern equipment and recruit more technocrats. He urged the public to desist from tendencies of corruption, saying lack of awareness about corruption and its associated dangers was the reason some people have accepted the vice as noble. Rutaremara said the regional body will sensitise the public about corruption and provide joint training programmes for investigators and prosecutors of anti-corruption agencies to handle high profile cases in the region. The deputy director of the Kenya Anti-corruption Coalition, Dr John Mutonyi, warned against laws that criminalise the media, adding that it will affect the fight against corruption. "Corruption is normally secretive and people only get to know about the vice through the media. Laws should not curtail media freedom because it is one of the conduits for information about corruption," he said. Uganda's Inspector General of Government Raphael Baku said the regional body will ensure that money stolen from one country is not spent in a neighbouring country. He said member states will cooperate in investigating, prosecuting and tracing the proceeds of corruption.

TITLE: Corruption Ingrained in Ugandan Culture [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (90%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (89%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); INTERVIEWS (76%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (73%); PRICE INCREASES (50%) Uganda
TEXT: In the recent weeks, the press has been carrying stories of how the Public Procurement Body has stepped in to stop the acquisition by the Inspectorate of Government (IGG)of a sh9b office complex located in Kamwokya. The reason given for halting the deal was that there were flaws in the procurement process. The Parliament's Public Accounts Committee (PAC) has also been busy exposing those involved in dubious CHOGM deals. Unfortunately, this is only a tip of the iceberg and many questioned deals within our Government departments remain under wraps. The Government's fight against corruption reminds me of a dog chasing its tail, round and round and round. The honest answer is that corruption will never be eliminated unless the hunters walk the talk. Would these hunters pass the test in John 8:7, "Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at her". My answer is a big NO. Even at the height of President Museveni's massive anti-corruption campaign, we are still witnessing wastage of public funds under the eagle eyes of PAC and the IGG. Indeed, the efforts of these bodies are unlikely to have any significant impact in the fight against corruption unless severe reprimand and action is taken on the culprits. The public wants to see the President "cracking the whip" at those at fault. Unless this happens, anti-corruption activists like myself will not be convinced that enough is being done though none will dispute that we have gone beyond the days when the accuser would be asked to produce the evidence. The bad news is that our culture has in-built corruption, judging from the many creative ways in which 'thank-you' may be said. Ugandans tend to be very grateful and it is touching that obviously limited resources notwithstanding, they still feel able to give. They like to show appreciation, which in my view is totally okay. However (and I insist), we must know where gifts end and bribes begin. What we see today are bribes, bribes and bribes. So with the Government at risk of losing the moral high ground, it is high time that the wounded but armed hunter goes into overdrive, tightens the noose further and be seen to bite. I recently listened to an interview of David F. Meyer, the former financial controller at WorldCom. I am sure many of you recall vividly the Enron/WorldCom scandals in 2002. In the interview, Meyers confesses to using shady accounting methods to mask WorldCom's declining financial condition by falsely professing financial growth and profitability to increase the price of WorldCom's stock. Meyer agrees that when pressure is applied to a human being, one never knows what the outcome will be. It is this pressure that the corruption hunter must address first. The greed, the low pay, extravagant lifestyles, mention it. Having lived through President Museveni's 24 years at the helm and watched his demeanour for a while now, my conclusion is that the man is probably more dangerous than he appears. When he talks, it is as if he can't hurt a fly. But I have seen a few people like that whose soft exterior often belies a steely inner resolve. I have a strong belief that corruption can be fought and sooner than later the hunted may well be running for cover without mercy from his excellency. Hopefully. The writer is a director and regional leader for Ernst and Young's fraud investigation & dispute services practice in East Africa.

TITLE: Corruption - Individuals to Blame Not the NRM [opinion]
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); IRAQ (94%); WESTERN SAHARA (93%); UGANDA (92%); MOROCCO (92%); CHILE (92%); CUBA (91%); SPAIN (91%); PORTUGAL (90%); PALESTINIAN TERRITORY, OCCUPIED (79%); INDONESIA (79%); SAUDI ARABIA (79%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); TIMOR-LESTE (79%); ISRAEL (79%); SYRIA (79%); LATIN AMERICA (72%)
SUBJECT: POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICS (89%); BRIBERY (79%); ELECTIONS (77%); US PRESIDENTS (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (72%); WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION (72%); SUGAR CANE FARMING (62%); SUGAR FARMING (62%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Corruption is an economic behaviour where people are spiritually failing to live up to the desired standards of behaviour and conduct required for serving others. This behaviour is universal for instance: The former US president declared that there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq while the whole aim was to attack Iraq in order to rob oil from there. The US capitalist class is occupying Guantanamo, a territory of Cuba. The US capitalist class has turned Israel into a US client, extended territory, and springboard in order to dominate and administer the Middle East by (a) occupying Golan Heights, a territory of Syria, (b) occupying Gaza, (C) occupying Salem, all territories of Palestinians with an overall purpose of robbing oil in the region. The US is an ally of Saudi Arabia which is never elected and then talks about surveillance of Uganda's elections of 2011 to see whether NRM is fit to continue in power. The same US overthrew Dr. Allende of Chile who was broadly and fairly elected by the Communist Party of Chile when John Kennedy declared: "We prefer a capitalist dictatorship to a communist democracy." He was overthrown by CIA with 16 bullets shot in his mouth. Saharawi (Spanish Sahara) was a colony of Spain. It fought a guerrilla war against Spain since 1965 and won in 1975. Morocco never took part in fighting for the liberation of Saharawi, but immediately Saharawi became independent of Spain, Morocco declared it was its territory. East Timor was a Portuguese territory. It fought on its own to become independent from 1965 to 1975. The minute it became independent, Indonesia declared it its territory, without having contributed anything during the struggle against Portuguese colonisation. John Kennedy all along tried to assassinate the entire cabinet of Cuba through the CIA after victory over Batista, only to find that the Communist Party of Cuba was so well-grounded that destroying that particular cabinet, an exact and similar one would spontaneously arise with a similar line of the necessary social continuity. Patrice Lumumba of Congo, 1960, won broadly with his Congolese National Movement against Belgian colonialism. But Gelvin, a highly placed CIA officer in Congo was ordered by the CIA authority to provide Lumumba with toothpaste which contained poison to kill. Eventually Lumumba was killed through Belgian, French and US CIA collaboration and intrigue. Dr. Jagan of Guyana with a pro-peopIe party with a majority on the ground was undermined by John Kennedy who collaborated with Dr. Bernard to undermine a majority party. Why? Dr. Jagan hated American imperialism in Latin America while Bernard did not mind and was an ally. Guyana being a territory growing and possessing a lot of sugarcane, many black people who were working in sugar plantations were bribed by the US to support Bernard against Dr. Jagan, an Indian, on racial grounds and in favour of US imperialism. When Nelson Mandela declared that arranging South Africa under apartheid as a social system was not correct, he was imprisoned by the South African government and put on Robben Island for 27 years. His name was put on the US list of terrorists for action. It was only in May 2008 that his name was cancelled from the terrorist list. Many civil servants in Uganda are being charged for using money which is intended for public service. These civil servants are not elected by the population. They have contracts under which they work. This means whichever party wins an election will have to work with them. The only problem is that some of the civil servants are not spiritually clean. They are just like hyenas, wolves, jackals or vampires. This is the same problem the world is having with an economic arrangement like imperialism. Everyone is born in the same way like the other on a geographical item called land. But there are those who grab big chunks of land, claiming they have more power and rights above all others, which is morally ugly and uncouth. There happens to be someone who declares that he or she wants to head a government on the basis of the type of family descent which was above many other people before the present ones. That person claims that he or she has that as a right and that subjecting such a person to an election is violation of human rights, abuse of status, disrespect and corrupting the nature of the institution of his or her ancestry. Jesus Christ was against the Pharisees who were the rich Jewish class despising the poor. He was also against the Saducees who were collaborating with Roman colonisers of Judea. All these hated him. They finally decided to get rid of him. They passed through the treasurer of his disciples, Judas Iscariot. They gave him 30 pieces of silver, captured Jesus and killed him. Corruption should be understood as a universally negative social phenomenon whereby people are privately unable to know objectively what they are supposed to do, for what purpose and how. The socio-economic arrangement of the globe by the US imperialist treatment of various territories of Asia, Africa, Latin America and the Middle East is not correct. Imperialism is not a correct method of work for humanity. The money lent to heads of state of various countries has strings attached, in the sense that those heads of state often yield and succumb to the economic desires of those lending them. In the end, the heads of state and the lenders will be allies above the people of the territory, for which the money is meant to be used on. So those heads of state become agents of imperialism. These territories now become neo-colonies. The answer, therefore, can only be patriotism on the part of the civil servants, heads of state in all organs of state apparatuses all over the world. There is also the need for cadres to raise the level of social consciousness so as to form revolutionary pro-people parties. The education ministries all over the world should pay attention to the faculty of ethics geared towards realising the need for the welfare of all human beings. People should oppose capitalism as the benchmark of civilisation with all its higher stages of continuity, namely imperialism and neo-colonialism. The writer is a lecturer of philosophy at the Kyankwanzi School of Science

TITLE: Corruption Has Brought Down Many Great Nations [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (88%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (78%); CLASSICS (78%); BUSINESS LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT (77%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (77%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (75%); HISTORY (73%); RECESSION (73%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); CHILDREN (63%); TRANSPORTATION LAW (62%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Lest we forget, many great nations and empires have been brought down by corruption. Even civilisations, have undergone, owing to the sheer weight of corruption. - Rome - so powerful, so vibrant, yet so soft in the moral centre. The collapse of the Roman Empire was caused mainly by corruption in the leadership, many have argued. In Corruption and the Decline of Rome (1988), Ramsay MacMullen, a leading historian, argues that the collapse was caused by economic conflict between the upper and lower classes of the empire. - The Soviet Union - nuclear super power, puppet master of the Eastern Bloc, champion of social equality, but ultimately the real life playing out of Orwell's Animal Farm. - Some have postulated that the "coming collapse of America as we know it" will be the consequence of corporate greed and corruption. Snippets of it have been evident in the last three years, with inherent economic weaknesses in the US plunging the world into recession. Which way, Uganda? The choices are stark - either go the way of integrity in governance, or enjoy the short-term benefits of degenerate governance and social existence, while slowly but surely knotting the rope by which the country will hang itself. Corruption, with all its facets - moral, financial probity, political accountability, personal discipline, social consciousness - manifests itself fairly strongly in just about every aspect of Ugandan life. Quite apart from the usual suspects - the managers of (financial and material) resources - the custodians of public trust like politicians, the Church, educators, civic leaders and civil servants, as well as family heads, and even primary school children aspiring for class monitor, have fallen foul of the false allure of corruption. And how about the private individual who will not pay her taxes, or let alone the car owner who will not respect traffic rules? When they compiled the Uganda Country Report http://www.nepaduganda.or.ug/documents/CountryReviewReport-Uganda.zip, the Africa Peer Review Mechanism (APRM) noted that corruption was cross-cutting (that is a broad) problem shooting across the four areas of concern, of democracy and political governance, economic governance and management, socio-economic development and corporate governance. But what, then, is the way forward? Speaking in Kampala at a public lecture by Sundulos Africa Leadership Training last July, Ghanaian Prof Stephen Adei, an authority on governance in Africa, told Ugandans that "a country without think tank capacity is like a human being without a brain." Think-tank is the way to go. APRM has taken our governance issues to public discourse, in the form of the Uganda Governance Forum, where stakeholders openly discuss the day's concern and plot a way forward. The Governance Forum debate on corruption, under the theme 'Enhancing the Effectiveness of the Legal and Institutional Framework for Combating Corruption in Uganda', last month drew a diverse crowd that included the Principal Judge, the Inspector General of Government (IGG), the ethics minister, legislators, academics, church leaders, politicos and politicians of all hue and colour, students and activists, and business leaders. The IGG set the tone from the outset by emphasising that corruption needs honest discussion at all levels. The consensus is that Uganda has enough, and some even think, a surfeit, of anti-corruption laws. Witness the Constitution itself, the Prevention of Corruption Act, the Police Act, the Leadership Code, the IGG Act 2002, the Local Government Act, the Access to Information Act, among others. We could probably get the Whistleblowers Bill and a Witness Protection Bill coming through the legislative processes. So, it is not for the lack of legislation and, as the Principal Judge puts it, "we should not rely only on the law." We must, as the ethics minister says, cut out "the hypocrisy, double standards and lip-service" that has thus far characterised the anti-corruption drive. Legalism can only help so much, but we should, as well, look at the moral and other extra-judicial approaches. Noting a less-than-zealous willingness to tackle corruption, the think tank has the following recommendations: - Leadership Code - the public service should ensure that public servants declare wealth at the start of service and monitor it consistently; expand wealth declaration beyond the current pool of public leaders - Institutions - the Executive must act on recommendations of commissions of inquiry; Parliament must debate and act on Auditor General and IGG annual reports; check actual cost of services and products - Morals - faith groups must emphasise moral education; moral aptitude tests be part of recruitment policy - Judiciary - the Judiciary's role is not to fight corruption. There is a need to look beyond prima facie (first sight) evidence; get more judges and magistrates to tackle backlog; consider confiscating/recovering wealth/stolen loot of the corrupt. As Uganda seeks to transform, the Governance Forum will sit monthly, making its contribution to what management scientist J.P. Kotter calls "a guiding coalition, a coalition which at the national level is a think tank". Corruption has had its day for much too long. It is too late for the Romans, and the Soviets are but a footnote in history. Where does Uganda want to be? The writer is a media consultant

TITLE: We Should Not Lose the Corruption Fight [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); METEOROLOGY (78%); WEATHER SENSORS (78%); RADAR SYSTEMS (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (68%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (66%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: ON Wednesday members of the meteorological department appeared before the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) to answer queries raised in the Auditor General's report on CHOGM expenditures. Of particular interest was the sh600m aviation and weather radar equipment that was supposed to be installed specifically for CHOGM. Not only was the system delivered three days into CHOGM - meaning it did not serve its initial purpose, but in addition the "brand new" radar is no longer in operation having broken down last year. The officials said they did not have the capacity to get it up and running again prompting the question, wasn't there a warranty on the equipment? The PAC chairman Nandala Mafabi suggested the suppliers should refund the money and the procurement officials be penalised for buying junk and be charged with abuse of office. The incompetence of our civil servants would not be comical were it not for the fact that this country does not have enough drugs and personnel in health centres. And it totally ceases to be funny when, on closer scrutiny, this bungled contract can only point to less charitable motives on the officials part. Hopefully that will be for the courts to decide. Corruption has become so pervasive the fear is that when history is written it will be the enduring legacy of this generation. Corruption is frustrating the delivery of services, which in turn is making it impossible for the majority of Ugandans to partake of the world renowned economic growth this country is famous for. Eventually the beneficiaries of corruption subvert democracy perpetuating a vicious cycle of poverty. Time is running out for Ugandans. Either we deal with this cancer now or let the generations that come after us grovel under the heels of an oppressive minority hell bent on sustaining the status quo in order to continue feeding at the trough.

TITLE: NGO Proposes Use of Research to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (90%); PHARMACEUTICALS INDUSTRY (88%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (68%); FORENSICS (66%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (66%); HOTELS & MOTELS (53%) Uganda; NGOs and Civil Society
TEXT: There is need to carry out necessary research into corruption as one way of fighting it, the executive director of African Anti-corruption and Drug Research Initiative, Aggrey Kwikiriza, has said. He said lack of well-researched data and proper methods of tackling the problems based on detailed facts made it easy for corrupt officials escape justice. "In order for us to fight corruption we need to know where it is and its depth. We must stop assuming that it is only the politicians who are corrupt," Kwikiriza said. He added that there were many forms of corruption in public offices. "It could be a clergyman who refuses to baptise a child before some church dues are paid," he explained. Kwikiriza was last week presenting a paper in a workshop held at Hotel Africana in Kampala under the theme 'The role of research in fighting corruption in Uganda'. He said research in form of forensic investigations can go further and act as evidence in courts of law, thus contributing to the prosecution process. The participants resolved that any study intended to fight corruption, should be a high quality product in terms of purpose, methodology, content, style, language and context.

TITLE: Ogoola Wants Corruption Laws Amended
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); BURDENS OF PROOF (92%); MAGISTRATES (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); ETHICS (78%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); EVIDENCE (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ORGANIZED CRIME (78%); ARRESTS (77%); WITNESSES (72%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (66%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE PRINCIPAL Judge James Ogoola and the Inspector General of Government, Raphael Baku, have called for a constitutional amendment to shift the burden of proof in corruption cases to the accused. "Corruption is not an ordinary crime. It is complex, sophisticated and they are now stealing using cyber. It is a white-collar crime, which calls for a change of the law and a highly trained and sophisticated Judiciary," Ogoola said yesterday. He said it is high time Uganda emulated Ireland, which has shifted the burden of proof from the prosecution to the accused in cases of corruption. Ogoola made the remarks at the second Uganda Governance Forum in Kampala. It was organised by the African Peer Review Mechanism and the Inspectorate of Government. Baku concurred that corruption cases are difficult to handle, especially when judges demand proof beyond reasonable doubt, 'and reasonable doubt depends on a particular judge handling the case'. With syndicate corruption where mafia-like gangs are involved, the burden of proof must shift to the accused and not the prosecution, he noted. Baku explained that: "When you come across a syndicate corruption case you can arrest the entire group like what we did in Makindye division and Bundibugyo. Unfortunately, because all of them are under arrest, you cannot get someone to give evidence." Ogoola also commented that the creation of new districts was detrimental to the Judiciary because there are only 30 chief magistrates in the country yet each district should have one. "With only one magistrate handling a million Ugandans, can justice be seen to be done? I am not against the creation of districts, but we must look at service delivery." Ethics minister Nsaba Buturo said corruption had become a cancer which should not be politicised. He said people should work together to fight the vice. The minister, however, was criticised by the participants, especially legislators, who accused the Government and President Yoweri Museveni of defending officials implicated in corruption because they are either historicals, fought in the guerrilla war or are staunch NRM members. "Parliament has never approved Jeje Odongo as state minister for defence, but the President allowed him to get his salary. He has even let the Butabika Hospital land scandal die," said MP Ross Euku (FDC).

TITLE: Govt Pursuing Small Fish over Corruption - Besigye
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); COUNTIES (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (78%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (75%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (75%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (63%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) president, Col. Kizza Besigye, has criticised the Government for what he called harassing small officials in local government over corruption while leaving the 'big fish' to go unpunished. Besigye said the National Agricultural Advisory Services (NAADS) officials were being punished, while government officials, who have stolen colossal sums of money, remain free. "Billions of shillings are being stolen by big officials in ministries, but the Government is harassing the sub-county leaders who are receiving a smaller part of the money. This Government has no will to develop the poor," he said. "The World Bank report of 2009 said that the country is losing about sh500b to corruption each year. But I know it is more than this because we know of a lot of money which has been stolen that the World Bank doesn't know about." Besigye added that ministers move around the country telling people that their welfare has improved, yet most of them are living in abject poverty. He said the money used for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in 2007 would have been used to build about 8,000 schools. "There is no government which has stolen money like this one (NRM). The sh400b, which was spent in three days on CHOGM, can be used to build 8,000 schools." Besigye was addressing residents of Nyantozi trading centre in Masindi district. The residents had earlier complained of widespread poverty and unemployment. Besigye is campaigning to become the FDC flag-bearer during the 2011 presidential polls. Besigye, who started his campaign for the party presidency in Bulisa district last Sunday, is battling with Maj. Gen. Mugisha Muntu for the position. He also attacked the Electoral Commission (EC), saying it should be disbanded before the 2011 elections. Besigye, who has lost twice to President Yoweri Museveni in 2001 and 2006, said the EC is a rubber-stamp of the NRM and should be replaced with an impartial team. Speaking at another rally at Ikoba trading centre, Besigye said ministers wanted the Government to buy them new vehicles worth sh200m each. "We have talked to some of them and they say these are the only cars that will manage the potholes on our roads. This means they have given up on the roads," he added.

TITLE: Corruption Spoiling NRM Gains, says Nsaba Buturo
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (89%); ELECTIONS (89%); RULE OF LAW (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); ANNIVERSARIES (72%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (70%); AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (51%); ECONOMIC STIMULUS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
