TEXT: CORRUPTION has become a cancer in the country's growth and stained the achievements of the Government, a minister has said. Ethics and integrity minister Dr. James Nsaba Buturo blamed the continued theft of public funds on the lack of patriotism and fear by the public to report corrupt officials. "Corruption is a major threat to our way of life and the corrupt don't realise that they are sowing seeds of self-destruction," Buturo said. He noted that the welfare of Ugandans would be better if the corrupt were not draining public funds. "Lack of patriotism is why the stealing is rampant because people don't love their country and don't care about others," Buturo said. "Poverty would not be as big and as intense if the rampant stealing of public funds was not going on," he observed. The minister made the remarks while addressing the media about preparations for the 24th NRA/NRM day anniversary due on January 26. The festivities, to be held under the theme, "24 years of NRM governance; so much done so much to do" , will be held at Maluku district grounds in Mbale district. On January 26, 1986, the then National Resistance Army (NRA) guerrillas took power, after five years of a protracted war in the Luweero triangle, which installed the NRM government. The NRA's ascendance to power ended years of dictatorship and anarchy. Buturo listed the NRM gains in the last two decades as the creation of a strong economy, boosting security, rapid expansion of social services, protection of Uganda's sovereignty, establishment of a responsible and responsive army, constitutionalism and the rule of law, affirmative action and improved communication. "We have made progress, but my God, one big challenge is we need to protect achievements," he cautioned. As the country embarks on campaigns ahead of the general elections slated for February 2011, Buturo warned politicians from both the opposition and the Government to desist from "bad politics". He said the responsibility of holding free and fair elections lies with both the Government and the opposition. "It would be wrong to oppose everything that the Government does because you are in the opposition. You lie and work with enemies of the country... that's the bad politics I am talking about," the minister said. He called on the public to avoid confrontation with the Police. "It never happens anywhere that a civilian slaps a policeman. It happens in primitive society and the media gives it coverage. There you are, that's our standard," Buturo said.

TITLE: District Leaders Deny Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); WAGES & SALARIES (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); SCHOOL DISTRICTS (78%); BRIBERY (77%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (76%); INSTITUTIONAL CONSTRUCTION (76%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (76%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (72%); BUDGETS (68%); TEACHER COMPENSATION (65%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: FOR the umpteenth time, the Inspector General of Government (IGG)'s report revealed that the Local Government (made up of districts) is the most corrupt institution in Uganda, with Kampala district taking the lead. According to the report, corruption in the District Service Commissions (DSCs) is so high that jobs are bought and District Contractors Committees (DCCs) must be bribed for contracts to do work for the district. According to the IGG report, 20% of all complaints received were against district administration. In terms of complaints, Kampala topped with 149 complaints, Masaka had 40 complaints, Kabarole had 32. According the IGG Rapheal Baku, the conclusion that districts are the most corrupt institutions was reached because they had the highest number of complaints. Baku said complaints came from district leaders themselves and other whistle blowers. The districts receive funds from the central government every year. In the last two financial years, they received a total of sh2.5 trillion. In addition, they have internally generated revenue. However, the report says most of this money is not accounted for. This money is spent on education, health care, roads and water. "They talk about giving us money in trillions, but they do not say that over 90% of that money pays workers' salaries," says the Masaka district LC5 chairman, Vincent Ssempijja. For most districts, education constitutes over 60% of the entire district budget. Nearly all the money pays teachers' salaries rather than adding quantity or infrastructure to the schools. On the other hand, however, the district leaders think the so-called corruption is largely over exaggerated. "Yes there is some corruption, but it is not as much as the report portrays it," they argue. Local leaders add that the easiest way to determine corruption is to identify shoddy work. For example, somebody may see a classroom constructed by a district and claim it is shoddy because it is not as good as the one constructed by the central government. "But this person may not know that in costing the classroom construction, districts must pay about sh33m for two classrooms, while the central government pays sh75m for the same two classes. "There is definately a difference," says Asuman Kyafu, the LC5 chairman, Iganga. With roads, Kyafu says, while districts are supposed to pay not more than sh10m to 15m per kilometre of road, the central government pays sh25m for the same distance. At the end of the day, the roads the central government works on are better than the roads the district works on. To a villager, the fact that the district road is not as good as a central government road means that the district 'ate' some of the money. For instance, Masaka was given over sh400m to work on roads. The work mainly involves grading and applying a layer of murram on the road. The district has over 2,000km of roads that need repair. Since the cost of working on these is about sh10m and 15m, the sh400m budgeted for roads can only work on less than 300km. "When somebody says we had sh400m for roads without telling the people that we needed over sh2b to do a good job, then they are telling half the story," Ssempijja says. We asked some district leaders for their views on the allegations of corruption. While many leaders may not like being mentioned among those who are corrupt, I do not see a problem. Our mandate is to fight corruption in our districts and other institutions. I often ask people to report cases of corruption that they suspect so that they can be investigated and dealt with. We are definitely not the most corrupt institution. I want to make it clear that all the money that is sent to the local governments is conditioned or attached to a certain exercise. There may be some corruption in procurement, but that cannot qualify districts as the most corrupt institutions. It is okay to fight corruption and we concur with the IGG on that. However, the IGG should be more vigilant on the ground in the districts than entirely relying on whistle blowers, because they do not get all the details. The IGG's report is positive criticism for local governments to be vigilant in issues of accountability. However, as members of ULGA, we still question the IGG on issues of objectivity. Specific information concerning corruption should be given. Reporting cases is one thing and proving them is another. We encourage the IGG to partner with us in fighting corruption by sensitising people about being accountable. We are all committed to fighting corruption. People must be given the right information about budgeting and accountability. Some cases might be based on hearsay, which is why when the said corrupt personnel are taken to court, very few of the cases succeed. I do not agree with the findings. Many other institutions are more corrupt. How can you say that because an institution had the highest number of complaints, then it has to be the most corrupt? Kampala receives more coverage and hence more complaints.That does not make them more corrupt. We concur with the findings of the IGG report. However, there are several factors that must be proved. The IGG did not take the trouble to explain why some districts like Masaka had 40 complaints while others like Budaka had no complaint at all. Masaka was covered more by the media and other sources, which does not mean that there was no case of corruption in Budaka.

TITLE: Fight Corruption in the Land Registry [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); DEEDS & RECORDINGS (90%); REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); AGREEMENTS (74%); INVESTIGATIONS (70%) Uganda; Land Issues; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The President, in his New Year message, stated that 2010 is a year of zero-tolerance to corruption. The land registration department should be priority. The corruption in the Land Registry is a tragedy to our country! My father passed away in 1997 and left us properties which he acquired way back in 1969. However, last year, I discovered that one Winfred Najjuko had obtained a certificate of title to our land located on Block 14, Plot 401, at Kibuga in Najjanankumbi. I quickly approached the Land Registry and found that a special instrument of transfer had been issued to Najjuko. There was also a sale agreement purportedly signed by my late father in 2008. Imagine the dead signing! I was told to produce the original title, according to my claim, which I did. To my dismay, one of the commissioners responded to me in a letter, saying she noted that a special certificate of title had been issued for the above land under instrument KLA 381352 of July 10, 2008. Subsequently, a transfer was effected to Najjuuko under instrument KLA23938 of 28/07/2009. Unfortunately, she indicated that she had failed to trace the said instruments from the register and, therefore, in the circumstances, she could not authenticate my claim of the transfer and the title being fraudulent. She advised me to pursue other means, to lay my claim. In a system where individuals are supposed to be held accountable for their actions and performance, how could the commissioner fail to ask the responsible officers to trace the instruments of transfer? This calls for serious disciplinary action and immediate investigations. A transfer done in July 2008 and getting lost in November 2009 would raise lots of questions, but this seemed normal business to the commissioner. Later, the commissioner wrote a letter to Najjuko requesting her to avail the special certificate of title and a copy of the transfer upon which she was registered as the proprietor. Fellow Ugandans, are we safe with the custodian of our precious assets like certificates of title of land? Many helpless people have fallen victim to this mismanagement in the land registration department and have lost their properties. Are we allowing this dirt to continue? Isn't the above case among the many that have proved beyond reasonable doubt that the employees in that department are not performing their duties and should face disciplinary action or be dismissed? Why is it difficult to discipline these employees in the land registration department? What is keeping them there with all the stories about them? The lasting solution to this department is a total overhaul of the employees and systems. We have professionals in this country capable of designing unique systems that can capture certificates of titles and eliminate possibilities of fraud or mismanagement. We also have professional managers who can improve the conduct of the employees in that department. If the President was serious about eliminating corruption in this country, he should start with the Land Registry. I am willing to provide free professional assistance. Land is a valuable asset worldwide. It should be managed in a more transparent, fair and accountable manner by the people in the responsible offices. Only that can make Uganda a better country. The writer is a member of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development UK

TITLE: Basic education - Officials examine national corruption strategy
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (90%); APPROVALS (72%) Cameroon; Education; Corruption
TEXT: A two-day workshop on understanding and disseminating the document took place in Yaounde last week. Corruption is a scourge that has plagued the country over the past years. In other to wipe out this cankerworm, the National Anti-Corruption Commission (CONAC), launched the National Anti-corruption strategy in 2010. It is in this light that a two-day workshop on understanding and disseminating of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy in the Ministry of Basic Education opened in Yaounde last Thursday November 17. Speaking during the opening, the Minister of Basic Education, Youssouf Hadidja Alim, said on the eve of the approval by government of the strategy, it was necessary for the to organise such a seminar so that all stakeholders can better understand it. She added that if they were well informed they will be efficient in the fight against corruption in the ministry. She called on the participants to work hands-in-glove to come out with solutions in the fight against corruption. The National Corruption Strategy has five cardinal points- prevention, education, condition, indication and sanctions. The workshop brought together officials of the central and regional services from across the country.

TITLE: Cameroon to Ratify African Union Anti-corruption Convention
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); POLITICAL PARTY CONVENTIONS (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); WITNESSES (77%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (76%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); POLITICS (72%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (71%); INFORMATION SECURITY & PRIVACY (69%) Cameroon; Corruption
TEXT: The ratification will confirm Cameroon's determination to sustain the fight against corruption. Members of the National Assembly will during a plenary sitting of the ongoing November 2011 ordinary session, examine and adopt the bill to authorise the President of the Republic to ratify the African Union Convention on preventing and combating corruption. The Vice Prime Minister, Minister of Justice and Keeper of the Seals, Amadou Ali defended the bill in the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly, Saturday, November 12. The convention adopted in Maputo, Mozambique on July 11, 2003, entered into force on August 5, 2005. Government in the explanatory statement of the bill specifies that it seeks to promote and strengthen the development of mechanisms required to combat corruption and related offences in the public and private sectors; facilitate cooperation among State parties to ensure the effectiveness of measures and actions against corruption; and finally to establish the necessary conditions to foster transparency and accountability in the management of public affairs. Sectors covered by the convention, are acts of corruption among persons, influence peddling, illicit enrichment, diversion of property by public officials, money laundering and illegal receipt of property. The convention that is comprised of 28 articles, "highlights the requirement for public officials to declare their assets, as well as the need to restrict immunities granted to public officials, the need to give the media access to information and the protection of informants and witnesses in cases of corruption and related offences," government explains. Article 6 of the convention makes provisions for the confiscation and seizure of proceeds and instrumentalities of corruption". It further specifies that State parties undertake to adopt all necessary legislative measures to reinforce control measures and strengthen national anti-corruption agencies and accountability systems. The bill on the convention is timely as the Head of State, Paul Biya during his ruling Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (CPDM) in September 2011 in Yaounde, campaign messages and inaugural speech at the National Assembly after taking the oath of office on November 3, 2011, expressed government's resolve to eradicate the corruption scourge. The African Union convention to a large extent reflects Cameroon's laws and regulations, particularly Article 6 of the Constitution, the law relating to the funding of political parties and the decree to establish the National Anti-corruption Commission (NACC).

TITLE: Fight Against Corruption - Britain Pledges More Support
COUNTRY: CAMEROON (94%); UNITED KINGDOM (94%); EUROPE (92%); AFRICA (92%); ASIA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EMERGING MARKETS (90%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (90%); INTERGOVERNMENTAL TALKS (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (73%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption; Europe and Africa; Governance
TEXT: The British High Commissioner to Cameroon, Bharat Joshi revealed this yesterday after meeting with the Minister Delegate at the Presidency in Charge of Supreme State Audit. The British High Commissioner to Cameroon, H.E Bharat Joshi has said his country is looking for ways to give more assistance and support to the government of Cameroon to boost the fight against corruption. In line with what the country has been doing for the past years, Joshi Bharat in an audience with the Minister Delegate at the Presidency in Charge of State Audit, said the need to help Cameroon improve its financial management procedures in tackling corruption is primordial. He said the aim is not only to strengthen the crusade against corruption in the country, but to ensure that tax payers' money is judiciously put to use. This, he added, is geared at moving the economy and country forward. The High Commissioner noted with satisfaction efforts being made by government to put a halt to the canker worm that is holding back economic growth. He said the syndrome is not only common to Cameroon, but to the whole continent. He was however hopeful that efforts in reducing, and why not eradicate, the ill remain on track. "Where corruption is being tackled, there is fast economic growth and Africa in 30 years will outstrip Europe and Asia, the most vibrant economic powers on the planet," he underlined. To the Minister Delegate at the Presidency in Charge of the Supreme State Audit, Siegfried David Etame Massoma, Cameroon-Britain bilateral relations continue to grow. It was once more an occasion for both countries via the fight against corruption, to laud ties. "We are grateful to have received the High Commissioner so we can chart another way in the fight against corruption which is a major problem in the country," the Minister stated.

TITLE: TIC Launches Corruption Perception Index
COUNTRY: CAMEROON (94%); COTE D'IVOIRE (92%); GAMBIA (79%); SAINT LUCIA (79%); SOMALIA (79%); SAINT VINCENT & THE GRENADINES (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); CAPE VERDE (79%); JAMAICA (79%); MAURITIUS (79%); BHUTAN (79%); KUWAIT (79%); MADAGASCAR (79%); MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); HAITI (79%); AFRICA (79%); BOTSWANA (78%); KOSOVO (70%); CZECH REPUBLIC (70%); NIGER (69%); AFGHANISTAN (55%); GREECE (50%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); RANKINGS (89%); WRITERS (71%); DIPLOMATIC SERVICES (56%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The 2010 CPI shows that nearly three quarters of the 178 countries in the index score below five on a scale from 0 to 10, indicating a serious corruption problem. The headquarters of the transparency International-Cameroon in Yaounde was the venue of the official launching of the Corruption Perception Index (CPI) 2010. The event saw the participation of members of the diplomatic corps, journalists as well as guests. The 2010 CPI measures the degree to which public sector corruption is perceived to exist in 178 countries around the world. The 2010 CPI shows that nearly three quarters of the 178 countries in the index score below five on a scale from 0 (perceived to be highly corrupt) to 10 (perceived to have low levels of corruption), indicating a serious corruption problem. The 2010 results are drawn from 13 surveys and assessments published between January 2009 and September 2010. In the CPI, Denmark, New Zealand and Singapore tie for the first place with scores of 9.3. Unstable governments often with a legacy of conflict continue to dominate the bottom rungs of the CPI. Afghanistan and Myanmar share the second to the last place with a score of 1.4 with Somalia coming in last with a score of 1.1. Botswana, the first sub-Saharan African country comes at the 33rd position with a score of 5.8, followed by the Mauritius Islands at the 39th position with a score of 5.4 and Cape Verde at the 45th position with a score of 5.1. The rest of the 30 African countries considered in this ranking are below average. Cameroon and Cote d'Ivoire share the last position with a score of 2.2. The 2010 CPI covers two countries fewer than last year's edition. The slight change resulted from individual sources adjusting the range of countries they asses. This adjustment in coverage made it possible to include Kosovo for the first time but led to the exclusion of St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Suriname for which only two sources of information where available this year. Where source surveys for individual countries remain the same, and where there is corroboration by more than half of those sources real changes in perceptions can be ascertained. Using this criteria it is possible to establish an improvement in scores from 2009 to 2010 for Bhutan, Chile, Ecuador, FYR Macedonia, Gambia, Haiti, Jamaica, Kuwait and Qatar. Similarly, a decline in scores from 2009 to 2010 can be identified for the Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Madagascar, Niger and the United States.

TITLE: Anti-corruption Fight - National Strategy Goes Operational in 2011
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); BUDGETS (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (77%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (77%); EMERGING MARKETS (73%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); TAXES & TAXATION (73%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (72%); PRIME MINISTERS (72%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); BUSINESS CLIMATE & CONDITIONS (68%) Cameroon; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Cameroon's maiden National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption was validated in Yaounde on Thursday October 21. The fight against corruption in Cameroon will be institutionalised in the different sector policies in 2011 and government plans to allocate resources in the 2011 State budget for the implementation of the National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption. The Coordinator of the Change Habits Oppose Corruption (CHOC) project, Abba Sadou, speaking on behalf of the Prime Minister, Philemon Yang, made the announcement in Yaounde during a workshop to validate the country's maiden National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption. The National Anti-corruption Commission (CONAC) that drew up the strategy between June 16, 2010 to September 16, 2010, has a vision that "by 2015, Cameroon is a country where integrity constitutes an essential value for every citizen, with an economic growth equitably distributed to ensure the social welfare of all in a preserved environment". The Vice President of CONAC, Dieudonní© Massi Gams made known the vision at the Yaounde Conference Centre, Thursday, October 21 as he presided at the opening ceremony of the workshop to validate the draft National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption, and chart the way for its implementation. Considered as the compass in the fight against corruption in Cameroon, "the strategy brings in a common understanding and greater harmony in the fight against corruption" , the Vice President of CONAC said , adding that, "the roles of all actors involved in this crusade are better defined so as to ensure synergy, avoid duplication of activities, conflicts and waste of resources". More than 1500 actors took part in the process of drawing up the National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption. The actors drawn from the executive, judiciary and legislative arms of government, the civil society, as well as technical and financial partners in different sector workshops examined the manifestations of corruption and made recommendations. The strategy targets 10 sectors that include the public investment budget, public contracts, private sector and business climate, decentralisation, education, finances (Customs, Taxation and Treasury), forest and environment, mines and extractive industries, public health and transport. The strategy has as major component eight pillars of integrity which are the guarantors of the achievements of the fight against corruption and also ensures the sustainability of results obtained. The strategy lays emphasis on a methodical approach to fighting corruption that has precise tools such as prevention, education, creation of conducive working conditions, giving out incentives to the upright and meting out sanctions to the corrupt. Some heads of institutions for the fight against corruption in Central African countries present in Yaounde for a training session, also participated at the opening of the workshop.

TITLE: Embattled Oceania Chief to Help With FIFA Corruption Probe
COUNTRY: NIGERIA (92%); NEW ZEALAND (79%); SWITZERLAND (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); AFRICA (71%) Africa
SUBJECT: SOCCER (92%); SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SPORTS & RECREATION (90%); SOCCER TOURNAMENTS (90%); SPORTS (90%); FIFA WORLD CUP (79%); NEWS REPORTING (78%); ETHICS (72%) Crime and Corruption; Soccer; Sport
TEXT: FIFA vice-president Reynald Temarii welcomes a "full and thorough investigation" into newspaper claims he offered to sell his vote in the contest to host the 2018 soccer World Cup, his confederation said on Monday. Britain's Sunday Times newspaper said Oceania Football Confederation (OFC) president Temarii and Nigeria's Amos Adamu -both members of world soccer governing body FIFA's executive committee - had offered to sell their votes when approached by reporters posing as lobbyists for an American consortium. The newspaper report said Adamu was filmed asking for 500,000 pounds ($799,600) for a personal project and that Tahitian Temarii asked an undercover reporter in Auckland for NZ$3m ($2.27 million) to fund a sports academy at the OFC's headquarters. "Further to information made public by The Sunday Times, the OFC President and FIFA Vice President Reynald Temarii will cooperate fully with the FIFA Ethics Committee and the FIFA Secretary General," a statement from the OFC said. "Reynald Temarii welcomes a full and thorough investigation so that all the facts can be heard." The OFC said it would not comment further until the findings of the FIFA Ethics Committee have been released. FIFA will decide on Dec. 2 in Zurich which countries will host the 2018 and 2022 World Cups. The choices will be made by the 24-strong executive committee.

TITLE: Camerounians parliamentarians Mobilised To Eradicate Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The people's representatives acquired skills in Yaounde on ways of reinforcing the legislative system in the integrated strategy in fighting against corruption. Cameroon's members of parliament and senior officials of the National Assembly are expected to fully participate in putting place of the National Strategy for the Fight Against Corruption in the country whenever it will adopted. They were mobilised and effectively participated in identifying the means and mechanisms the legislative system can contribute in ensuring the fight against corruption within itself and the synergy with all society stakeholders in eradicating the corruption scourge. The parliamentarians and senior officials of the National Assembly, yesterday, September 16 ended a two-day workshop in Yaounde organised by the National Anti-corruption Commission (NACC) to reinforce the legislative pillar of integrity in the ongoing process to draw up a National Strategy to fight against Corruption. The Vice Chairman of NACC, Dieudonní© Massi Gams said in his keynote opening speech last Wednesday said the institution which is the leading independent agency in the fight against corruption in Cameroon, has the task of coordinating the process to elaborate and implement the National Strategy to Fight against Corruption. The workshop to reinforce the legislative system was the 15th in a series of workshops organised by NACC to ensure the complete mobilisation of all stakeholders; effective participation of all segments of the Cameroonian society in the elaboration process the national strategy and the individual and collective commitment of all Cameroonians in putting in place of the strategy. The recommendations of the workshop were intended to enable government be informed on the level and extent of corruption in the legislative system, identify the bulk of work on corruption that has to be done concerning the legislative system, identify and elaborate the mechanism of implementation of actions to improve the integrity of members of the legislative system. The workshop equally permit the government to identify the means and mechanisms of collaboration between members of the legislative system pillar of integrity and between the members and those of other pillars, put in place a network of positive actors in the legislative system , identify and design actions to strengthen the independence of the legislative system.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption in Higher Education
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (78%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (78%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (78%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (73%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (73%); PRESS CONFERENCES (72%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (69%) Cameroon; Education
TEXT: Anticorruption activists will be drilled on the various elements of corruption in universities in Cameroon. A four-day workshop on corruption and good governance will take place at the Siantou University Complex in Yaounde as from August 23 to 26. The announcement was made yesterday during a press briefing in Yaounde jointly organised by the Resident Representative of the International Governance Institute, Stephen N. Asek and the President of the Siantou University Complex, Wantou Siantou Lucien. The workshop to be organised by the International Governance Institute (IGI) and jointly executed with the Vice Rector of the Siantou University Complex, Professor Sah Leonard, aims at sensitising lecturers and administrators on corruption and good governance in Cameroonian universities. The opening ceremony will be presided over by the Minister of Higher Education, Jacques Fame Ndongo. Corruption in education is a concern that should not be over looked. It can not be avoided in the strategy of the International Governance institute IGI-Focal Integrity Team Cameroon. Siantou's interest in complementing Government efforts to combat corruption and promote good governance in Cameroon is important. Participants will be mostly activists and observers from universities of Yaounde. The workshop is expected to train the participants on the various elements of corruption and the characteristics of good governance in tertiary institutions. The workshop is a follow up project after another workshop organised at the University of Buea in 2009. IGI is a membership-driven organisation fighting fraud, corruption and the abuse of power. The organisation works through monitoring, education, training and networking, to promote a culture of transparency, honesty and accountability in public service, based on a Christian ethos. During the opening, the Minister of Higher Education will hand over the first secured end of course diplomas for BTS and HND to graduating students of the university.

TITLE: Fight Against Corruption - Rapid Intervention Unit Underway
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); PRESS CONFERENCES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); APPROPRIATIONS (75%); ALLIANCES & PARTNERSHIPS (74%); BUDGETS (74%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (68%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Vice President of the National Anti-Corruption Commission, NACC, announced yesterday during a press briefing in Yaounde. Dieudonní© Massi Gams, the Vice President of the National Anti-Corruption Commission, told pressmen yesterday at the Yaounde Conference Centre that from January 2 to December 31, 2009, NACC received 312 complaints on corruption and related offences. 238 of them have been investigated into. He also announced the imminent creation of a rapid intervention anti-corruption unit that will be expected to appear promptly on the scene of complaint to act. During his presentation, he explained that since June 16, 2010, NACC has been working with its technical partner, Change Habits Oppose Corruption, CHOC, to set up the national strategy to fight corruption that will establish a clear and common vision as well as harmony in the fight against corruption. "The methodology chosen by NACC required the organisation of sector-by-sector workshops and meetings to strengthen the pillars of integrity as an approach for the formulation of the national strategy for the fight against corruption in Cameroon," said the Vice-President of NACC. He revealed that 10 sectors of activity and six pillars of integrity were chosen as priority based on some work that had been done by NACC in the past and the perception of corruption by experts. Laying emphasis on a participative sector-by-sector programming of its activities, workshops had been organised in 2009 with the transport, education, media and the business sectors. He further explained that since June 16, 2010, NACC and the CHOC project have organised workshops in five sectors: health, forest and environment; public investment budget and public contracts; education as well as public finances. Four more workshops will be organised to target sectors like transports, decentralisation, the business climate as well as mining and extractive industries. As for the strengthening of pillars of integrity, workshops were recently organised for the civil society and the media. Four more workshops will also be organised to target the following sectors: the legislative system; the judiciary system and institutions fighting corruption; technical and financial partners and lastly the executive system. In all, 16 more workshops will be organised before September 4, 2010 so that the final document could be ready before September 24, 2010. He justified the sector-by-sector workshops approach on the need to know the manifestations of corruption in the different sectors of national life so as to ensure a more efficient fight. The conclusions of the workshop will be transmitted to the concerned ministries for appropriation, modification or eventual enrichment so as to produce a sector-by-sector strategy that will be realistic not bureaucratic. The Vice President of NACC also expressed joy that the population were mobilised wherever NACC passed and the participants in the different workshops showed satisfaction and felt proud that they too were associated. NACC officials also used yesterday's press briefing to present some of NACC's achievements in the areas of investigation, prevention and cooperation. The Vice President called on all Cameroonians to change their habits and serve the nation without requesting more in addition to their salaries. He promised that common questions in services like "where is my 30 per cent?", "what do I gain in this" will stop. "If we love this country then we must do what is right," he ended. The press briefing was held in the presence of the representative of the Prime Minister and Head of Government.

TITLE: Government to Reshape Ministerial Anti-corruption Units
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (71%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); PRESS CONFERENCES (70%); DIPLOMATIC SERVICES (67%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The anti-corruption units were created to nip the scourge in the bud. The government of Cameroon plans to undertake a reformed, broad based and multi-sector anti-corruption drive that revolves on denunciation of all aspects of corruption, information and education. The National Anti-corruption Commission (NACC) that gathers reports from all bodies in the country involved in fighting against the corruption scourge has already launched a vast programme that targets 10 sectors that deal with education, communication and transport. The Vice Chairperson of NACC, Dieudonní© Massi Gams in a press conference in Yaounde on June 16 disclosed that investigations were going on in several ministries whose results will be exploited in the broad-based anti-corruption strategy. The Prime Minister, Head of Government, Philemon Yang, hours before the NACC press conference chaired the third Steering Committee meeting of Change Habits, Oppose Corruption (CHOC) Project during which its Coordinator presented the project on the reconfiguration of the ministerial anti-corruption units. CHOC Project brings together members of government, heads of diplomatic missions, representatives of the World Bank, and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), National Governance Programme, private sector and civil society representatives. Ministries constitute the hub of corruption in the country. It was for this reason that the government set up ministerial anti-corruption units to tackle the canker warm in all sectors. The ministerial anti-corruption units function under the coordination of the ministers who authorise investigation teams to go to the field and the results of their investigation are forwarded to him. The chairperson of the Anti-corruption Unit in the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Decentralisation (MINATD), Aboubakari Oumarou, Technical Adviser in the ministry said in a chat with Cameroon Tribune that the unit is composed of nine members. Five of the members including the chairperson are senior officials of the ministry who range from technical advisers to directors and inspectors. Four other members are selected from the civil society. As to how the anti-corruption unit functions, Mr Aboubakari said they meet on a quarterly basis. He disclosed that when users of services, partners, administration and the general public report alleged cases of corruption, the unit members inform the minister. The minister after examining the allegations may authorise the unit members to carry out field investigations. The findings of the investigation team are forwarded to the minister for proper action and another report sent to the National Anti-corruption Commission. The chairman of the Anti-corruption Unit in MINATD, said they have investigated alleged cases of fraud in many parts of the country, especially in councils. The desired impact in most of the cases, he said, is achieved considering that their actions are dissuasive. As with all ministerial anti-corruption units, Aboubakari Oumarou, said their role is limited to investigating cases of alleged corruption, report to the minister who takes the final decision. The members, he added, cannot take any repressive action. The anti-corruption machine is usually slow, the units toothless bold dogs, the work of the unit hardly perceptible to the general public. Corruption is still deep rooted in most ministries and public institutions despite the existence of anti-corruption units therein. This necessitates urgent reforms of the ministerial anti-corruption units as the harmonised national plan of action piloted by NACC starts off.

TITLE: Corruption Virus
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BRIBERY (78%); CHILDREN (75%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (75%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (75%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (75%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: It is no more a secret that the fight against corruption is on. Though for now "Operation Sparrow Hawk" is landing mostly on "Big Fishes", it is great time the authorities that be, take a look at what is happening at the bottom. A may be the recent FENASSCO B games can serve as an example. This is because it is unbelievable that in a local competition like the primary school games corruption should be at the forefront. Those actively involved in the mal-practice are not the innocent pupils, but the teachers who accompany the children to the games. At the eve of the event, they start by fabricating fake school licences for non pupils of the school. During the games, they do all to make sure their teams emerge victorious. Any obstacle, they go bribing match officials or members of the homologation committee. At the end, medals are awarded to unmerited pupils and no new talent discovered. ..The million dollar question in every lips is If they can carry out these type of practices in public events what of marks during exams?... Please do something before it is late.

TITLE: Preventing Corruption in State Enterprises
SUBJECT: HOTELS & MOTELS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); HOTEL MEETING FACILITIES (78%); RULE OF LAW (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (76%); MISCONDUCT (74%); WRITERS (73%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (71%); CORRUPTION (70%) Cameroon; Books; Governance
TEXT: The book "Board Member's Corporate Government Handbook:" was officially launched in Yaounde last Wednesday. The conference room of the Yaounde Hilton hotel was the venue of the formal launching of the book titled "Board Member's Corporate Government Handbook: Corporations and enterprises of the Public and Quasi-public sector of Cameroon" by Professor Cosmas Cheka. In the "handbook" the author targets board members and managers of state corporations, advisers and collaborators with the identification and selection of those who are appointed by the authority to sit on the boards of State corporations, municipal councillors of the 374 local councils and of Cameroon's future regional councillors, the Cameroonian tax payer who is indeed the owner of all Cameroon's State corporations and librarians, students and the general public interested in questions of good governance and accountability. The "handbook" is written with a number of objectives such as to provide members of a framework of shared values and principles of good corporate governance that could enhance the checking of corporate misconduct for better performance, revive consumer and investor confidence in State corporations, contribute in enhancing the quality of oversight exercised by boards of State enterprises in the complex 21st century corporate world and present a guide to advisers charged with the selection of those who sit on the boards of State corporations. The handbook has five chapters. Chapter one circumscribes the importance and principles on which corporate governance is founded. In chapter two the powers of the Board are outlined and explained in relation to recent jurisprudence. Chapter three deals with rights and obligations, cornerstone of the integrity of the Board as well as of the rule of law. Chapter four outlines aspects of the rules governing the relationship between the board and the executive of State corporations. The last chapter is entirely dedicated to activities touching on the control of management and of the general life of the corporation by the board. Issues treated in this chapter concern essential tips for preparation and participation in board meetings and how to interpret a balance sheet. Earlier, the Minister Delegate in charge of Supreme State Control Seigfried Etame Massoma called on board members of State Corporations to make good use of the "handbook". The Board member's Corporate Handbook has 143 pages. It is written in French and English. The book is sold in all the book stands in town and it costs FCFA 6,000.

TITLE: APF Proposes Preventive Action Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); EMBEZZLEMENT (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); POLITICS (89%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (84%); ELECTIONS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (73%); INTERVIEWS (72%); GUILTY PLEAS (72%); AMNESTY (71%); CREDIT CARDS (70%); JAIL SENTENCING (67%); SENTENCING (67%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (50%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Alliance of Progressive Forces (APF) wants the Head of State to bring to book all corrupt officials. One of Cameroon's opposition parties, the Alliance of Progressive Forces (APF), has called on President Paul Biya to spare no corrupt managers and embezzlers of public funds in the ongoing anti-corruption crusade and to above all recover all the stolen funds and property. The National President of the APF, Barrister Bernard Muna during the party's second National Council meeting in Yaounde recently proposed that government should settle public bills using treasury pay vouchers and transactions abroad be made using electronic credit cards as a way of curbing corruption. "The involvement of ministers in the payment of bills with liquid money is archaic", Barrister Bernard Muna said. "The most important thing will be to negotiate for the repatriation of the stolen money stocked abroad", Mr Muna stated, wondering whether it would not be possible to envisage a total cancellation or reduction of prison sentences of the embezzlers of public funds who have pleaded guilty, accepted to pay back the money and publicly asked for forgiveness. The APF leader proposed a Truth and Reconciliation Commission, a forum within which the amnesty on repented embezzlers and corrupt officials could be negotiated and safe guards put forbidding them from all positions of responsibility. The Head of State, Bernard Muna said could also put in place a legal and diplomatic mechanism with the mission to negotiate with State and foreign banks where the country's stolen wealth is stocked for it to be repatriated and invested in a special programme for the fight against poverty. Barrister Bernard Muna in an interview said Cameroon needed patriotic and honest leaders who are full of integrity for the country's prosperity. He reiterated his party's commitment to the unity of Cameroon but said the unity is threatened by the uneven distribution of the country's wealth throughout the 10 Regions. Supporters of the Alliance of Progressive Forces used the second National Council meeting to evaluate the party's activities and adopt the road map for the year just starting. Barrister Bernard Muna said APF was created on March 25, 2007 when five political parties merged and stated that it was now made up of seven political parties. The urgent mission of the APF, he disclosed, was to rally more political parties to choose a credible and acceptable candidate to oust President Biya in the 2011 presidential election.

TITLE: Communication Minister Mobilises Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); EMBEZZLEMENT (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); CRIMINAL LAW (85%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (73%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (73%); LAWYERS (69%); POLICE FORCES (63%); PRESS CONFERENCES (57%) Cameroon; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Issa Tchiroma Bakary says the fight against corruption is permanent. Cameroon's Minister of Communication, Issa Tchiroma Bakary has said the ongoing fight against corruption will continue till the country is purged of corruption and public wealth protected for the general interest. Issa Tchiroma in a press conference in Yaounde yesterday, February 02 explained what the executive and judiciary arms of government were doing to fight against corruption. Operation Sparrow Hawk selective In answering the question on whether the current arrest and trail of corruption suspects known as "Operation Sparrow Hawk" was not selective, the Communication Minister said the fight against corruption was permanent and that no corrupt manager of public funds could escape the dragnet of the anti-corruption drive. Mr Tchiroma said President Paul Biya who is accountable to the Cameroonian people started the fight against corruption as far back as 1982 when he acceded to the Supreme magistracy. He noticed the deviant behaviour of some managers and came out with "Rigour and Moralisation" as a guide. Government, the minister said, knows where it is going with regard to the fight against corruption and the Head of State has the timing for every file at the level of the executive. Nobody can force the Head of State against his timing and once the executive arm of government finishes its own part in the anti-corruption fight, the judiciary which is independent takes over. Humiliation of suspects The Minister of Communication also answered another question that stated that the way Operation Sparrow Hawk is carried out leaves many people to believe that the suspect is already condemned. He said justice is the same for all and there is the presumption of innocence. Police officials sent to arrest people for interrogation are not instructed to humiliate them as the dignity of the suspects should be protected. Mr Tchiroma also said nobody is brought before the law courts without his or her lawyer. The protection of the citizens, the Communication boss stated, is the responsibility of the Head of State, adding that as far the anti-corruption fight was concerned nobody could dictate to either the executive or judiciary arms of government what to do and the time because there is separation of powers. Paying back the embezzled funds Issa Tchiroma was also questioned on the preference of many Cameroonians that embezzled funds be paid back instead of imprisoning the corruption officials. He said Cameroon's Penal Code allows for negotiations between the suspected embezzler and the judiciary for the money to be paid back into the State treasury, further stating that the suspects have lawyers who master the Penal Code. The minister disclosed that as at now, nobody has openly declared the readiness to negotiate. The property of some corruption officials was confiscated by the courts. In this connection, Mr Tchiroma said the property was just a tip of the iceberg of the public wealth embezzled and said government was diligently investigating where the stolen wealth was stocked. The process, he said, was delicate but government will spare no effort in going right to the end. Law on declaration of assets The Head of State, the communication minister said, was gradually applying Article 66 of the Constitution which provides for a certain category of State officials to declare their assets and property when entering and leaving office. Journalists said the inexistence of a text of application to the law was encouraging corruption. According to Issa Tchiroma, the law was not imposed on the Head of State, stating that he is applying the law through anti-corruption institutions such as units in ministries, Supreme State Audit Office, National Anti-corruption Commission, National Programme on Governance and other independent institutions. The institutions check the ostentatious living conditions of some managers of State funds. The minister concluded that Article 66 of the Constitution is producing the desired results. Anti-corruption to eliminate political rivals The Minister of Communication singling out the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (CPDM), President Biya's party and commented on statements that the Head of State was using the anti-corruption fight to eliminate his rivals within the party in the next presidential election. Issa Tchiroma said the CPDM constitution provides that the party's candidate in a presidential election is its national chairman. Since the party has only one chairman, the arrest, trial and jailing of corrupt officials, some of whom happen to be CPDM militants, cannot be considered as a means by the Head of State to eliminate his rivals. He said honest militants could still gather money not from public funds to contest for elections.

TITLE: Minister Hits Out At Govt On Corruption
SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION (94%); ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); IDENTITY SECURITY (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (77%); NATIONAL IDENTITY CARDS (77%); CITIZENSHIP (72%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (71%) Uganda; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: A minister has decried "theft and profligacy in government" which are constraining a number of initiatives, including stopping illegal immigrations into the country. The State minister for Planning, also Buyanja County MP, Mr Matia Kasaija, was responding to queries about the operationalisation of dual citizenship by the Ugandans in Diaspora in Kampala yesterday. Mr Kasaija said theft from public coffers besides porous borders was responsible for the increasing cases of illegal immigrants. "If we did something about the theft and wastage of resources in government, we would be able to channel the much-needed resources into ventures that can transform this country," he said. The minister cast doubts over the effectiveness of the national identity cards project in weeding out illegal immigrants due to graft. "Even IDs won't be able to solve this problem because leaders at local councils routinely recommend aliens for our passports for a pittance. To solve this problem requires collaboration of all stakeholders." In October, the minister of Internal Affairs, Mr Hilary Onek, said government was committed to ridding the country of illegal immigrants in a period of six months. Mr Onek said unlike other countries, foreigners had come to deem Uganda as a country of "free entry and exit" due to the laxity of its immigration policy. He said unplanned for people were hamstringing government plans by putting pressure on the country's limited resources. The Internal Affairs minister also hoped that the problem would be solved by the issuance of computerised identity cards which would come in handy in keeping proper data of bonafide Ugandans.

TITLE: Prayers Over Corruption Sound Rather Hollow [column]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (88%); RELIGION (85%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (78%); OFFSHORE OIL & GAS EXPLORATION & EXTRACTION (77%); OIL & GAS INCENTIVES (76%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (75%); DISMISSALS (75%); INDICTMENTS (74%); EVIDENCE (74%); AGENCY ADJUDICATION (73%); OIL EXPLORATION (71%); OIL & GAS EXPLORATION (71%); ACQUITTAL (67%); POLICE FORCES (63%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (62%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Many breadwinners will earn some much-needed pause in their spending strings after the year's most expensive holiday. Some deadbeats like government failed to make payroll despite Public Service Minister Henry Muganwa Kajura's reassurances to Parliament. In 2011, for a few moments it seemed the waters of the Red Sea would part with a significant body blow against corruption and graft in government. This was not to be. The year of the oil debate which, for once, startled the executive ended inconclusively. It is unlikely that the MPs will ever get the "actual" cooperation they need from sovereign governments to substantiate the allegations they made on the floor of the House. In fact, it may end in a scenario where they are reprimanded for publishing false and misleading information. The fight against corruption also left Uganda's important development partners tarnished. The United States and the United Kingdom refused to come to Parliament's rescue to aid in "oil-gate". An interesting legal fight has been going on between administrative tribunals and courts in Uganda and those overseas. Parliament has at least succeeded in halting-- for now-- the "farm-down" transaction allowing Tullow Oil to sell part of its oil exploration block holding(s) to the Chinese and Total on the basis of an expired license. Across town in Kololo; the anti-Corruption Court became a location for photo-ops. The much hyped trials of former Vice President Gilbert Bukenya and Motorcare ended with dismissals on the basis of insufficient evidence to sustain the charges requiring the Vice President to go on his defence. 48 pages of taxpayer-published indictments went to the bin after government officials exonerated the former Vice President and Motorcare from any wrongdoing in the case. Catholics, and other Christians alike, must have wondered whether the Crucifix has become the new symbol of those accused of graft. Margaret Bukenya's joy at her husband's acquittal was marked with prayers to the heavens. There are many questions that intelligentsia who run this country have failed to answer. Why so much poverty and need in an atmosphere of abundance. Why do motorists; and road users have to subsidise wages to a bloated police force on their roads and public places acting like a sort of tax and expect the country to be secure? Why do we spend so much time praying over corruption as a cancer that is threatening the fabric of society when the same people leading these prayers are consorting with thieves? Sometimes, Uganda's so called economic miracle is inflated beyond its size like a trial balloon. More than half of Uganda's administrative sub-divisions-- the sub-counties-- are more than 25-30km from a functioning hospital. Similar numbers are removed from a Class C road linking inter-district headquarters. In fact, while Kampala continues to labour under choking population growth, many parts of the upcountry are dying a slow death from a dearth of services. Centres of progress like schools, churches and trading centres in many parts of the country remain in a state of stunted growth. So does the absence of meaningful employment opportunities outside Kampala and a spattering of smaller urban centres along Uganda's major transport arteries. The government's priorities today seem to be somewhere between maintaining a large political class: the fastest and surest way to riches and moderating independent drivers of economic growth in the country. How else could an interest rate regime attempting to collect 35-40 per cent interest rate from small businesses that employ the majority of Ugandans on existing loan facilities be described in any other way other than economic sabotage? Larger economies led by the United States have been in a swift and steady path of economic decline triggered by a lending apocalypses also known as sub-prime lending: How else would smart people at the IMF allow Uganda, in necessary belt tightening, to use the most destructive tools- interest rate manipulation and defaulting on its domestic obligations to fight inflation without attacking the core political problem of expansive government and wasteful government expenditure. In 2011; we, of course, saw the worst of this trifecta- the senior IMF representative traveling to Kyankwanzi, a moribund educational institution that is a key tool used to maintain government's political patronage. We saw crocodile tears and protestations of innocence tagged to a transaction where the taxpayer lost millions of dollars. We saw a disenchanted Judge- Paul Mugamba Akiiki, bellow out a hoarse note; "Cry the Beloved Country" after seeing the IGG literally fold his tail in a dangerous game of political survival. Of course the winners were over at the Central Bank- the check of 1.7 trillion to buy fighter jets of questionable relevance cleared; so did Basajja's 100th check on the basis of comfort letters written by the Governor. Don't ask why public service pay, healthcare and education suffered! Mr Ssemogerere, an attorney and social entrepreneur, practices law in New York.

TITLE: Time Is Now for Citizens to Rise Against the Cancer of Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); WAGES & SALARIES (89%); ETHICS (78%); SCANDALS (78%); BUDGETS (77%); HEALTH CARE (76%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); PUBLIC FINANCE (74%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (73%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (73%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (72%); CIVIL SERVICES (72%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (71%); BLOOD SUPPLY (71%); CRIMINAL LAW (70%); DIVESTITURES (69%); TEACHER COMPENSATION (67%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (66%); FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (64%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: We must reflect upon our individual and collective effort towards the elimination of corruption from our midst. According to well documented World Bank statistics, Uganda loses an estimated Shs500 billion per year to corruption. And yet yearly, Ugandans continue to die because of the effects of corruption - in the form of poor service delivery. In May, the media reported that Middy Acen and Eunice Acola had died in Lira Regional Referral Hospital due to a severe blood crisis that had hit the medical facility. In August, Sylvia Nalubowa died in Mityana Hospital from complications of an obstructed labour as the hospital lacked a doctor to carry out a caesarean operation that could have saved her life. Another mother, Jennifer Anguko, also died in Arua Regional Referral Hospital in December 2010 due to a uterus rupture following 15 hours of obstructed labour. There were deaths of more mothers like Cecilia Namboozo who could not be attended to at Mbale Referral Hospital because she could not afford about Shs300,000- more than her monthly teachers' salary. While the NRM government has demonstrated its intention to fight corruption, through its rich anti corruption legal framework, the issue of political will remains a matter of serious concern. The government deserves credit for such laws as the Anti Corruption Act, 2009, the Public Finance and Accountability Act, 2003, the Budget Act, 2002, the Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Act, 2003, The Access to Information Act, 2005, The Whistleblowers Act, 2010 and the Penal Code Act Cap 120. In addition, the government has also established institutions such as the Inspectorate of Government, the Anti Corruption Court, and the Ministry of Ethics and Integrity to lead the graft fight. However, the same government has remained dead silent as its top lieutenants continue to dominate the list of officials suspected of involvement in huge corruption scandals. In addition, key government institutions and agencies have perennially topped the list of the most corrupt institutions, including the Police, Judiciary and district local governments. Uganda is also a signatory to the UN Convention against corruption and ratified the AU Anti- Corruption Convention but ironically is one of the top corrupt countries. As Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga recently said, corruption has reached a crisis level. A recent Transparency International Index on corruption ranked Uganda among the most corrupt nations in the world - and second worst in East Africa! Government efforts towards elimination of corruption must include a policy to improve salaries of government workers. The Police and teaching remain the least paid professions. Is it therefore a surprise that such institutions like the Police perennially top the list of the most corrupt agencies? The government faces an uphill task defending its leadership failures as it superintended over one of the most corrupt countries in the world. Ms Byiringiro works at Uganda Debt Network

TITLE: Western Police Officers Shifted and Suspended Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); BRIBERY (79%); ARRESTS (79%); EXTORTION (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (69%) Uganda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Police have carried out transfers and suspensions among officers in the southwestern region, citing rampant cases in crime and corruption tendencies in the Force. Mr Asuman Mugenyi, the police spokesperson, said: "The public tells us that there is corruption and inefficiency of our police officers here, so we have transferred and suspended some of them. One has been arrested." Police commandant in-charge of operations, Mr Grace Turyagumanawe, said the security situation in south western region, especially, in Mbarara District had run out of hand. The officer in-charge of the sniffer dog section has been arrested on charges of extortion and bribery. Ms Polly Namaye, the southwest police spokesperson said: "We have been told that he had been charging between Shs300,000 and Shs500,000 for the sniffer dog services which are supposed to be free." The suspect will be investigated and prosecuted and will be made to refund all the money he had extorted from the public." Meanwhile, a new police administrative unit- mid-south western, has been carved out of southwest. It will take districts of Mitooma, Rubirizi, Buhweju, Sheema and Bushenyi and is to be headed by Mr Hilary Kulayigye as the RPC, Mr Mugenyi said.

TITLE: Many Citizens Believe the Govt Condones Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: DISEASES & DISORDERS (90%); AIDS & HIV (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); POLITICS (78%); MALARIA (72%); COUNTERFEITING (60%) Uganda; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Corruption is to the country as Aids is to a human body. Since the advent of the NRM, the government, ably and transparently led by President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni has publicly campaigned against the scourge of HIV/Aids. For decades the impact and results of the government's commitment and determination have resulted in excellent dividends for everyone to see and admire. The Uganda's stand and fight against this terrible disease has been acknowledged worldwide. As a result of our excellent record on HIV/Aids, money from the Global Fund was generously donated to Uganda to help our government and people continue fighting against this incurable disease and others. Alas, those who kindly extended the hand of assistance from the Global Fund did not know at the time that government cadres and others were also suffering from another terrible disease called corruption. A lot of money donated to fight HIV/Aids and malaria disappeared into private pockets or unauthorised projects. Under NRM, the Ten Points Programme of recovery, principled, transparent and people's government, the Movement leadership, revealed good and popular policies to be embraced by the whole population in the quest for good governance. At the time, even the most severe critics of the NRM were quite impressed by its ambitious and achievable programme of national recovery, development and good governance. The projected goals of governance were; broadbased administration, transparency, and elimination of corruption, abuse of office and the principle of individual merit as a basis for election or appointment to public office. As if by design and deliberate acts, these ideals and objectives were ignored, then opposed by the NRM itself and ultimately declared to be the enemies of its leadership and supporters. The principle of broadbasedness gave way to fanatical support even if it was devoid of merit. Former allies of the ruling oligarchy who had genuine political and developmental differences were branded the enemies of the ruling party and the wretched of the earth. In order to continue in power and office perpetually, NRM leaders embraced capitalism in preference to socialism that they had passionately advocated for before. Patriotic intellectuals and peasants who reminded the NRM party of its previous stand and promises they came to power with and now deliberately ignoring or violating, were condemned as traitors and renegades. Corruption which in Uganda sustains politicians in positions of power became the acceptable norm. We do not know of any country, let alone one claiming to be fighting against corruption where a president reveals that a citizen forged documents to swindle the country and the forgers remain at large, with the police, the IGG and the DPP staring in space and doing nothing to protect the name and reputation of the President. Few citizens or few countries hear officials accusing a leader of being the ringleader of dishonest deals and the leader vehemently denies participation in the crime but officials insist it was the President who committed those offences and no one lifts a finger in the defence of the President except a columnist in a newspaper. The same officials do not offer their resignation and the police and other investigating agencies remain conspicuously silent. What reputation or honour of that leader can remain untainted for the population to admire? Has anyone heard of a political system where government sets up commissions and internal probes to investigate wrong-doing and when crimes and other offences are publicly discovered and reported with names of wrong-doers revealed and it is recommended that the culprits be indicted, investigated, must be prosecuted and punished, then everything is turned upside down so that the commissioners and investigators are placed in the dock or they constitute part of the Cabinet agenda for discussion and possible punishment. Have you ever heard of a Cabinet minister who is closely associated with suspects of crime, who orders the return of property to suspects knowing that the subject matter of her fancy is not only the subject of a court trial but the same minister had been implicated in shoddy deals involving the same property? Do our leaders no longer respect the law or know what is sub-judice, or the Leadership Code or ethics at all? You may wish to read the findings and recommendations of the commission of inquiry into Tourism. How can an official commit offences in an institution he or she heads and when a legally constituted body finds that certain government employees who were previously accused of wrong-doing were actually innocent and the accusers are the ones who have cases to answer but a minister refuses to reinstate the innocent and protects the guilty. Ultimately, citizens know that unless something is done, the system of governance which permits all the above contradictions to operate side by side will ultimately be condemned and doomed. If you doubt this prophesy, take a sampling of all the present system's cadres, both low and high, they will tell you that they are equally not happy with what is going on to-day. Should you have eavesdroppers in Cabinet and other Government fora and listen to their views in the hearing of the party leaders and their support machine, you will certainly doubt your sanity or theirs. Some African leaders declared themselves Presidents for life, others decided to squander national wealth or compromise national interests in all efforts to cling to power or to accumulate personal wealth beyond the dreams of fellow compatriots and often at the expense of the latter. Justice Kanyeihamba is a retired Supreme Court Judge.

TITLE: Kabarole Boss Reshuffles Team Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); COUNTIES (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (88%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (87%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (66%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Just six months after he announced his cabinet, the Kabarole district chairman, Mr Richard Rwabuhinga, has reshuffled his team in a bid to fight corruption. He dropped the district secretary for production and natural resources, Mr Richard Nyakaana (Busoro Sub-county councillor), who is also his former campaign manager, in connection with alleged loss of Shs8 million meant for tree planting last month. Mr Nyakaana was replaced by Ms Florence Kadoma Kanyunyuzi, the Bukuuku Sub-county woman councillor. Mr Nyakaana could not be contacted as all his known phones could not go through and he has not attended two council meetings. Mr Rwabuhinga, who has been doubling as the secretary for works, swapped docket with his vice, Mr Moses Ikagobya, who has been the district secretary for health and education. The Inspector General of Government's January 2010 report revealed that the Local Government is the most corrupt institution in Uganda, with Kampala District taking the lead. Kampala had 149 complaints, Masaka had 40 and Kabarole got 32 complaints.

TITLE: Country Needs Jesus to End Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: PREGNANCY & CHILDBIRTH (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); INFANTS & TODDLERS (78%); ORPHANS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (76%); TAXES & TAXATION (76%); JEWS & JUDAISM (76%); TAX LAW (75%); EXTORTION (70%); WITCHCRAFT (62%); ABORTION (51%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: The angel of the Lord told Joseph, "Mary will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins." (Matthew 1.21) The name 'Jesus' literally means "The Lord saves." The world into which Jesus was born was not a good place. His Jewish people did not have their own country; they were living under an oppressive, colonial government. Their Roman overlords were corrupt, harsh, and recruited other Jews to extort money from them through outrageously high taxes. Zaccheus was one of those Jewish tax collectors the Romans recruited. He stole a lot of money from his people in order to make himself rich at their expense. There was a lot of idolatry in the occupying government and among the colonialists. They burned incense to the Roman King, and even sacrificed children to other gods. There was also a lot of immorality in the world into which Jesus was born. There was financial corruption. People engaged in sexual immorality and did many sinful things to satisfy their sexual appetites. They had many sexual relations and then had abortions to kill the children conceived by those unions. There was also homosexual practice, and widows and orphans were abandoned and left to fend for themselves. The world into which Jesus was born was not a nice place. And, yet, it sounds a lot like our Uganda of today - except that we have our own independence and freedom. We no longer have colonial overlords. Instead, our corruption means one Ugandan is stealing from another Ugandan. We are doing these things to ourselves. The Uganda of today faces many of the same challenges as the world into which Jesus was born: Corruption has reached epic proportions; There has been a resurgence of idolatry, witchcraft, and human sacrifice; Sexual immorality is killing our people; Greed and selfishness are rampant and leave many people, especially widows and orphans, in helpless states. And, yet, at this time of the year, we celebrate and remember the birth of a unique baby - one called Jesus because "he will save people from their sins." As we come to the close of 2011 and prepare to enter 2012, there is still hope for our Uganda because Jesus' name still means "he will save people from their sins." There is still hope for our families and our country...because Jesus is still the Saviour of the world. Our government is very important to the proper order and functioning of our country, but the government is not the Saviour. Only Jesus is the Saviour, because his name still means "he will save people from their sins." The best our government can do - the IGG, the Anti-Corruption Court, laws passed by Parliament and enforced by our police and other agencies - is to give us moral and civil speed governors, external rules that are followed by us only because the police force or parliamentary investigative committees have been expanded to put fear into our hearts and ensure our compliance and proper behavior. But, God said through the Prophet Jeremiah in the Old Testament, "The time is coming when I will make a new covenant...It will not be like the covenant I made with their forefathers....This is the covenant I will make with the house of Israel...I will put my law in their minds and write it on their hearts." In other words, my fellow Ugandans, we must acknowledge that the problem beneath our rampant corruption, witchcraft, child sacrifice, domestic violence, and immorality is the problem of a sinful human heart. Only Jesus, whose laws of love are written on our hearts because he lives in our hearts, can solve this problem Only acknowledging our human problem of a corrupt heart will lead us to the ultimate and true solution to our problems - Jesus - because his name still means "he will save people from their sins." So, this Christmas season I want to thank our government for doing the hard work of rooting out corruption through the means available to them. Please, continue to shine light in all the corners of darkness, not just the high profile ones. And, please, follow through on all cases. But, we must never think this is the only hope available to us. There is always hope because Jesus was born and his name still means "he will save people from their sins." So, this Christmas, I want to encourage all of us to dedicate or rededicate our lives to Jesus. In the challenges of our Uganda today, which are no worse than the challenges of the world into which Jesus was born, Jesus is our only hope...because his name still means "he will save people from their sins." I send warm Christmas greetings to President Yoweri Museveni, Maama Janet and their entire family and all our government leaders. I also send sincere greetings, along with prayers for a blessed Christmas for the Kabaka and Nabagereka of Buganda, and for our Roman Catholic, Orthodox and Pentecostal brethren, and all those who have looked in hope for the coming of the One who will save people from their sins, Jesus the Christ. To God be the glory. The Most Rev. Orombi is Archbishop Church of Uganda

TITLE: Graft Republic - How Nation Discovered Its Corruption Mojo [column]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); ENDOWMENTS (77%); BRIBERY (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (70%); WIRELESS INDUSTRY (70%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (65%); MAINTENANCE & REPAIR (64%); WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIERS (60%); MYTHOLOGY (53%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (50%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: In the last year, it has been impossible to escape stories of corruption -or the denial or defence of corruption - in Ugandan newspapers. Ghost soldiers, stolen GAVI funds, the scramble to "eat" during Chogm, alleged bribes in oil contracts, theft in the national ID project, someone carrying away masts at the state broadcaster UBC and flogging its land, the list is endless. When the 38-year-old rule of KANU in Kenya ended in defeat in the December 2002 elections, and people surveyed just how much corruption had taken place over the years, one observer declared: "Kenya must be truly rich, for it to be so 'eaten', yet it still standing". The same might be said of Uganda. Less endowed country, would have bled to death from the corruption of the last 20 years. Everything that King Midas of Greek mythology touched turned to gold. Nearly everything that the Kampala government touches these days turns to rot. Still, what is happening offers us valuable insights into how power functions in Africa. The corruption we are witnessing today must be seen as the price/cost of regime that has stayed in power for nearly 30 years. The thousands of Ugandans who own cars will understand this well. You might be in love with your old car, just as some Ugandans probably still support the near-30-year-old Museveni government. But it breaks down all the time, its consumption is horrible, and it spends more time in the garage than on the road. In the end, it is always cheaper to get rid of it and buy a new one. In the years that the NRM has been in power, the average long-term car owner has had five cars to achieve efficiencies. But they have had one government and president.
