The maintenance cost of the regime is therefore higher. The problem is not the simply the NRM, because a power can renew itself. Rather that the NRM has offered the country just one leader. So what exactly makes this leadership expensive? Again, let us give an example. Mobile phone companies like Airtel, MTN, Warid more than any industry, are always giving you deals for cheaper calls. This is no accident. The sharp end of the telecom market is the young people. Huge discounts today pay off in the long term, because if you get a young person of 20 to sign up for your service, you have a chance of keeping him or her for the next 30 years. Likewise, if you take a mortgage at age 25, the cost (or at least burden of payment) is lower than when you do it when you are 60 and have few years to pay it. Thus 20 years ago, when some could still reasonably argue that the Museveni government was the future, its cost to the public in terms of corruption was quite low. The thing is that the Museveni government is no longer the future. The penalty the voters pay for keeping it in power is much higher. You know a government will unload a heavy burden on you when it can only run on its past record. How it brought security. How it rescued the economy. How it introduced UPE. How it rehabilitated roads (then they went to waste), and so on. Of course, some old things are very valuable. A vintage wine grows more precious with age. So do Rembrandt and Picasso paintings. You buy a Picasso for Shs250m today; you will sell it for Shs750m in two years. If you invest Shs250m in the Museveni government today, you will have to write off in two years. Where you make a profit of Shs500m on a Picasso painting, you lose Shs500m on the government. New leaders and their governments are cheaper because, like Museveni in 1986, money spent on them is seen as an investment in the future. Thus, in 1996, for example, the Museveni campaign did not really have to pay for votes. Instead, it was drowning in voluntary contributions by a grateful public. Compare that to the situation in February. The cost of getting votes had shot up so astronomically, that the country was virtually bankrupted to ensure victory. In this, situation accountability mechanisms and checks on corruption simply collapse. For all the noise, resignations and stepping-asides, arrests, and half-hearted trials, nothing will change, because corruption is now a political problem intricately linked to the fact that the same bunch of fellows has held power for nearly 30 years. The NRM can solve this problem, through reinventing itself and offering a new leadership. Or the people of Uganda can by throwing the whole NRM lot out of power. The Ugandan corruption monster has grown so huge and menacing, it cannot be got rid of by just pinching its skin as we are doing. cobbo@ke.nationmedia.com & twitter@cobbo3

TITLE: The Changing Faces of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); COUPS (91%); EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); ARMIES (90%); BRIBERY (89%); ARMED FORCES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); SCANDALS (79%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); MILITARY RULE (77%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (76%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (74%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (73%); ILLEGAL WEAPONS (71%); ARRESTS (71%); SMUGGLING (64%); RELIGION (50%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Corruption, when it goes from small figures and occasional breaches of the law to becoming runaway and pervasive all over the country is proof that President Museveni is not as in control of events in Uganda as has always been widely believed. The reason it is believed there has not been a military coup in Uganda for more than 26 years is because Museveni was thought to be in total control of the army, police and intelligence services. No mutineer or coup plotter in any square kilometer of Ugandan territory or even abroad could sit down and plan a coup without it somehow leaking to intelligence or being crushed by the army. No politician could stand up to Museveni for the same reason, it was assumed. This image of a president who knows where every soldier from every unit is every morning in radio calls with his headquarters and field commanders became a deterrent against a coup. For this same reason, corruption as a national way of life was not much heard of before 1990. Civil servants and government ministers, fearing this recently victorious guerrilla leader would arrest them if they dared embezzle public funds, if they were corrupt did so as discreetly as possible. Today, corruption has become "Proudly Ugandan", proudly and defiantly unashamed of what it is. Ministers accused of embezzling Global Fund money, ministers named in oil bribery scandals, publicly assert their innocence, insist they will not step down; they appear at church services and fundraisings, and social gatherings. The corrupt now enjoy high job security and confidence that by and large they will get away with their deeds. This leads us to the next question: If the head of state is not in firm control and every Ugandan, it now seems can be bribed or can steal, how secure in power is the NRM government? If bribery and large-scale corruption are now a national way of life, who is to say where this will stop? If Presidential Guard Brigade soldiers are reported several times in the media to have made off with substantial sums of money and somehow life goes on, what will happen the day a foreign government hostile to Museveni decides to place soldiers of the PGB on a secret payroll? Can Museveni's guards be bribed to turn their guns on him? Can arms be secretly smuggled onto his helicopter or jet to be used on him? Even if there are a few among Museveni's innermost circles who are still loyal to him, what guarantee is there that they can resist the bribes and mass theft that the President's own Cabinet ministers casually engage in? For Museveni to remain safe, he must now have a select group of people, both civilian and military, who are loyal to the end if need be. But those same loyalists also must be above moral reproach. They must be the type to whom $700,000 is offered but they politely turn it down. Then, on top of these rare traits, they must be trained and precise in their knowledge and skills, in electronics, bomb disposal, crowd control and other security basics. How many Ugandans are there left who can be totally loyal to Museveni, who also are not corrupt and who have the necessary technical skills to thwart any danger? When we see this rampant corruption, we cannot rule out that the sums of money are more than an individual needs, even for luxurious living. Under the guise of grabbing whatever can be grabbed, might some of this money be going to prepare for a war or some kind of insurrection? Two weeks ago, a former UNLA soldier told me the full story of the July 1985 military coup that ousted President Milton Obote. The political climate was strikingly like what we see in Uganda today, except for the corruption. There was intrigue in the army and within the ruling UPC party; intrigue between the Langi and Acholi in the UNLA army; intrigue between the Catholic Acholi and the Protestant Acholi in the army. The centre just fell to pieces. Right now, the younger NRM MPs have taken on such a vigorous public crusade against corruption that they have ended up doing even better than the opposition DP and FDC MPs in this regard. Attempts and threats at the Kyankwanzi Leadership Institute by the President to force these "rebel" NRM MPs back into the party line have failed and they are now back to a new front, this time against the Minister of the Presidency, Kabakumba Masiko. Kabakumba's almost amusing tale of having taken equipment intended for UBC radio and used it for her Kings FM radio station in Masindi is a curious one. She insists she will not resign and told Parliament that she is willing to cooperate fully in any investigation it might wish to carry out, anything to "get to the bottom of this." The story was given much prominence by the state-owned media and the police was seen to uncharacteristically move swiftly against a Cabinet minister. In this climate one wonders: did Kabakumba really steal that UBC equipment or might it have been a set up, part of the intrigue within the NRM, one faction seeking to discredit another? Was she getting close to the President in such a way that powerful forces within the NRM decided to bring her down? Watching all this, most business people have concluded that they simply don't stand a chance of making a fair profit in this trading environment by following procedure and the law, and have therefore decided that they too will bend the law. They arrange to make illegal power connections, evade taxes, inflate invoices, and this is now down to every level of society. Last week, the US ambassador to Uganda, Jerry Lainer, warned that Uganda had better be prepared for major belt-tightening because the current economic crisis in western nations demands that foreign aid be cut back and this money diverted to the millions of domestically unemployed. With corruption this rampant and donor money soon to dry up, the amount of money in circulation will increase pressure and resentment in Ugandan society.

TITLE: Activists Attack Government Over 'Soft' Handling of Corruption Cases
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); EXECUTIVES (77%); SUPREME COURTS (75%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (69%); JUDGES (69%); AIDS & HIV (53%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Anti-corruption activists have expressed disappointment over what they described as government's lack of good will and commitment to fight the vice. Speaking during the first Annual National Anti-Corruption Convention yesterday in Kampala, the activists criticised President Museveni for "his soft approach towards corrupt government officials". In a keynote address prepared by ACODE Executive Director Godber Tumushabe and read by NGO Forum's Arthur Larok, the activists advised Ugandans to look elsewhere for solutions against corruption other than from government. "The Constitution should be reclaimed. The President has an opportunity to make announcements to unlock opportunities to fight corrupt," Mr Tumushabe's presentation read in part. Retired Supreme Court Judge George Kanyeihamba said corruption has created unrest in the minds of many Ugandans, saying a government of corrupt officials will not be in power for very long. "Ugandans must have courage to speak up," Justice Kanyeihamba said. He also appealed for "a list of shame" to be adopted by the media to publish the names of public officials involved in corruption. Army MP Gen. Elly Tumwiine, also present at the meet, encouraged Ugandans to "ignore fear, intimidation" and "defend Uganda against corruption." He caused laughter when he noted that just like HIV/Aids, many a times, corruption is conceived in secret. Meanwhile, Western Youth MP Gerald Karuhanga, describing the state of corruption in government in a poem recital, said: "The behavior of our leaders in ungodly". An academic, Prof. Mwambutsya Ndebesa, called for a shift in methodology of fighting corruption to performance-based accountability imposed on leaders. He called on Ugandans to perform their roles as citizens and not as subjects of a system. Female Youth MP Monica Amoding laid blame on the last two generation of mothers who, she said, failed to instill virtues of honesty in the current crop of leaders. She said the biggest challenge lawmakers face is demand for money from their electorate. jnjoroge@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Country Falls Further Down Corruption Ladder
COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); AFRICA (92%); RWANDA (79%); BURUNDI (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); RANKINGS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); SCANDALS (78%); POLLS & SURVEYS (77%); NATIONAL IDENTITY CARDS (50%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: For the fifth straight year, Uganda has continued to score badly on corruption, according to the latest world ranking on perception of graft levels in countries around the globe. Ranked among the most corrupt nations, Uganda is at position 143 of 183 surveyed countries in the 2011 corruption perception index released yesterday by global graft watchdog, Transparency International (TI). The index, an aggregate indicator measuring perceived levels of public sector corruption, is drawn on assessments and opinion surveys with questions related to bribery of public officials, kickbacks in public procurement, embezzlement of public funds, and the effectiveness of public sector anti-corruption efforts. Countries are scored on a scale of 0(highly corrupt), to 10 (very clean). Uganda scored 2.4, down from 2010's 2.5. But government dismissed the ranking, saying it is devoid of "scientific substance" to offer accurate measure of corruption levels in the country. Only Burundi posted a worse ranking than Uganda in the East African region, at position 172, while Rwanda, one of only two African countries in the top 50 of "very clean" countries, topped the region. Mr Raphael Baku, the acting IGG, said he had "a problem" with the index because perception can often be deceptive. "They (reports) may give the impression that corruption has increased in the country just because of what is happening at the time of the surveys." But Prof. Edward Kakonge, the chairman of the Uganda Debt Network, said: "This ranking has been kind to Uganda. We are actually worse off." "Your newspaper has been documenting a lot of corruption for instance this most recent thing with the national identity cards. There is no transparency." Recent graft scandals in the country include; the 2007 Chogm scandal, the botched LC1 bicycle deal and bribery claims in the oil sector. egyezaho@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Corruption Allegations - NRM Leaders Should Allow a Smooth Due Process [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); PRICE INCREASES (89%); COMMODITIES PRICES (89%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); SCANDALS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); COMMODITIES MARKETS (77%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (77%); WAGES & SALARIES (77%); INFRASTRUCTURE (72%); FOOD PRICES (72%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (72%); AGRICULTURE (50%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: We have been reading and hearing news about alleged rampant corruption in the oil sector involving senior government ministers. The revelations, thanks to committed Members of Parliament, are shocking and have taken the country by surprise. This in a country that has impassable roads, inadequate medicines in hospitals, poorly paid teachers, rising prices of consumer goods, etc. One would have expected the President to put his weight behind investigations to get to the root of these allegations. But to everyone's surprise, the President turned judge and pronounced his ministers innocent. This and many other corruption allegation scandals have been swept under the carpet. The President has persistently declared some of his ministers innocent and hinting that they are being witch-hunted. As for former Vice President Gilbert Bukenya abuse of office allegation case, the President said he (Prof. Bukenya) was innocent. The President might be right in all these cases. However, would it be better for him to allow due process take its course? And assuming the corruption allegations were true, is the President aware of the trickle-down effects of the money that are allegedly lost or misused by the accused ministers were the funds to be properly used to fund infrastructure development, education and pay teachers a decent salary, etc? Unfortunately, most sectors in this country are mismanaged. For example, the IGG's office has variously been accused of being used by the government to fight political wars. The health, education, and agriculture sectors are in a sorry state. Economically speaking, the prices of all commodities have skyrocketed. Yet the President has been quoted as saying the rise in prices is good for the economy. With static salaries or dwindling earnings, how will Ugandans get the extra money to accommodate the rising prices? The actual beneficiary of the rising price is certainly not Ugandans. Oil is a national resource that should benefit all Ugandans. For now, it is apparent that the ruling NRM government is not ready to deliver prosperity for all. From the look of things, we are likely to see more corruption, impunity, and rising prices of commodity and food prices. Julius Warren Kule kulewarren@gmail.com

TITLE: Zero Tolerance to Corruption Is the Way Forward [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (76%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (73%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (73%); MALARIA (72%); INFANT MORTALITY (66%); FINES & PENALTIES (64%); AUDITS (63%); AIDS & HIV (53%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (50%) Uganda; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The Speaker of Parliament has in a rare frankness confessed that corruption in Uganda has reached crisis levels. Of course, this is public knowledge. But it is Ms Rebecca Kadaga's vow to guarantee that the 9th Parliament under her stewardship will ruthlessly fight the endemic worm that has eaten to the core of our government that is refreshing. This point-blank shot at corruption needs to be reinforced by all crusaders of anti-corruption -especially public servants. Anti-corruption speeches need to be streamlined without contradictory utterances from stakeholders. Unfortunate utterances by public servants, including by President Museveni that questioning sources of ill-gotten wealth of Ugandan oligarchs is bound to cripple his government is wrong. Equally injurious is the assertion by northern Uganda rehabilitation minister Rebecca Otengo that corruption is here to stay and there is no way the government, NGOs, and the public could stamp out the vice from Uganda. The two statements are ill-conceived and tantamount to abetting corruption in Uganda. They run contrary to Government efforts to stamp out corruption. No wonder, the array of machinery at Government's disposal to fight corruption remain dormant. Uganda's high maternal and infant deaths, impassable roads, poorly-stocked hospitals and more deaths from Aids, malaria and TB and other failed public service delivery are all tied to corruption, which eats up Shs500 billion yearly according the World Bank. We have failed to impose stern deterrent penalties to violators of the Anti-Corruption Act. Government has failed to act rigorously to implement the Whistleblower Protection Act to follow up leads and apprehend thieving public servants and recover stolen public funds and utilities. Even the arm of the Auditor General, which has been strengthened by the National Audit Act 2008, remains feeble as several high profile government officials implicated in misuses of the multi-billion 2007 Chogm funds have walked off scot free! But we commend minister Otengo's proposed comprehensive approach to tackling the root causes of corruption, including scrutinising some questionable donor practices. We need to move the strategies of zero tolerance to corruption forward. We may need to consider stern propositions like life in prison for verified culprits.

TITLE: Corruption Has Reached a Crisis Level, Kadaga Says
COUNTRY: UGANDA (95%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); AFRICA (92%); RWANDA (79%); SUDAN (79%); CHINA (79%); BURUNDI (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%); KENYA (79%)
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); BUDGETS (73%); FAMINE (73%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (73%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (72%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (71%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (69%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (67%); AUDITS (65%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (60%); INFANT MORTALITY (51%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: The Speaker of Parliament Rebecca Kadaga has admitted that corruption in Uganda has reached "crisis" levels but guaranteed that the 9th Parliament would ruthlessly fight a vice that has bedevilled the NRM administration. "I believe corruption is at a crisis level. It has become a malignant that all of us are used to it," Ms Kadaga said. She added that the 9th Parliament will not tolerate any corruption tendecies in government. Her comments were contained in a message read out on her behalf by Ndorwa West MP David Bahati on Tuesday at the end of the annual general meeting of the 5th East African Association of Anti-Corruption Authorities held in Entebbe. To back her claim, the Speaker said research had shown that up to 20 per cent of the budgets for the East African member states end up in the pockets of the corrupt while millions continue to wallow in poverty. She said the region is at a crossroads as corruption robs hardworking citizens of the opportunity to live better lives. "It is because of corruption that Africa continues to grapple with challenges of inadequate infrastructure, poverty, war, disease, famine, high maternal and infant mortality rates," said the Kamuli Woman MP. Discussions at the two-day conference focused on the strategies of promoting zero tolerance to corruption in East Africa. Several delegates from Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda, Burundi and South Sudan attended the conference. Despite a wide array of machinery at the government's disposal to fight graft, the vice continues to blight development in the country, delegates heard. That reality has left some like Judge John Bosco Katutsi, the former head of the Anti-Corruption Court, concluding that graft can only be solved if the culprits are hanged like it's done in China. The World Bank, a few years ago, said at least Shs500 billion is lost due to graft in Uganda annually. Ms Kadaga said Parliament had instituted measures to fight graft like the enactment of the Anti-Corruption Act, which strengthened the penalties for corruption offences. She also cited the enactment of the Whistleblowers Protection Act 2010 that provides for protection and reward of individuals who report corruption cases that result in recovery of public funds as well as the National Audit Act 2008, which empowers the Auditor General to scrutinise books of accounts of the entire organisation where government has interest. The 8th Parliament's Public Accounts Committee instituted a probe into the multi-billion 2007 Commonwealth meeting in Kampala. That probe saw several high profile government officials implicated in alleged misuses of Chogm funds. Although some of those officials have appeared in court, no convictions have been made. awesaka@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Corruption Trial of Bukedea Officials Starts
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); MAGISTRATES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); MISAPPROPRIATION (78%); WITNESSES (78%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (78%); TESTIMONY (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (75%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (70%); WAGES & SALARIES (70%) Uganda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The trial of three Bukedea District officials by the Anti-Corruption Court for alleged abuse of office and misappropriation of public funds has commenced. Mr Petero Gahafu, the former Bukedea chief administrative officer (Cao), chief finance officer Charles Ojono and Mr Johnson Opolot, the assistant Cao, are accused of causing a Shs50 million financial loss to the district. The trio appeared before the Chief Magistrate in the Anti-Corruption Court, Ms Irene Akankwasa, at the Kumi Magistrate's Court on Monday. "The accused allegedly approved and authorised cash payment of the above money to primary teachers as salary arrears, with prior knowledge that they were causing a financial loss to the Uganda government," the charges read in part. Charges Mr Opolot and Ojono are jointly charged with causing financial loss during the 2006/7 financial year while performing their duties as acting Cao and chief finance officer respectively. According to the charge sheet, the accused contravened the Anti-Corruption Act 2009. "They accessed the money by virtue of their offices, causing financial loss contrary to Section 20 of the Anti-Corruption Act 2009," the charges read. Witnesses testifying against the accused, including 15 teachers in whose names the money had been drawn, denied receiving the payment. The fate of the three officers will be decided at the next hearing in Kampala Anti-Corruption Court on November 29. editorial@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Donors Slash Government Aid Over Corruption
COUNTRY: NETHERLANDS (94%); UGANDA (94%); EUROPE (92%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (92%); IRELAND (79%); AFRICA (78%)
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); EUROPEAN UNION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); LITERACY & ILLITERACY (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); BUDGETS (89%); EURO (89%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (78%); SCHOOL DROP OUTS (78%); SCHOOL BUDGETS (78%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (73%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (50%) Uganda; Corruption; Europe and Africa; Education
TEXT: The Uganda government was last evening left searching for alternative sources of funding following the withdrawal of support to the education sector by one of its key donors. The Dutch government announced it was withdrawing funding to a tune of nearly Shs50b (14 million Euro), citing concerns over persistent corruption, poor public financial management and poor standards. Dutch Ambassador to Uganda Jeroen Verheul said it was "time to ask ourselves some uncomfortable questions," on the issue of what quality learners were getting adding that the "seriousness of this problem cannot be overstated." He was speaking on behalf of other development partners at the start of the annual Education Sector review in Kampala yesterday. He described the quality of basic education (literacy and numeracy skills), the major concerns under UPE as "disappointing." The Dutch withdrawal follows that of the Irish government which earlier withdrew from budget support to concentrate on project support. The reaction of other donors in the European Union was not immediately clear but Communications Officer at the EU delegation in Kampala Simon Kasyate said the individual member countries were taking action on their own. "This marks the exit of Netherlands as a supporter of basic education. The results we have been achieving since the introduction of UPE have been disappointing and we decided to shift our focus to productive areas like agriculture," Ambassador Verheul said. According to Amb.Verheul, they have been spending 14 million Euros (about Shs49 billion) annually since the start of UPE in 1997 to support basic education. "About a year and a half ago, we warned that there were issues with regard to public financial management, corruption, fiscal policy in terms of the choices that we make and we warned that that might have an impact on us being able to provide budget support. So this is not a surprise for the authority," he explained. Education Minister Jessica Alupo admitted that government had been alerted to the impending aid cuts and had increased the Education sector budget to Shs1.3trillion in response. Speaking in some of the most candid language a diplomat has used on the thorny issues of corruption and poor standards, Ambassador Verheul said, "literacy is the basis for the acquisition of all but the basic life skills. Right now more than 40 per cent of the ever growing number at P3 level is illiterate. They--and their fellows who dropped out of school--stand very little chance of ever making it to any form of secondary education." He said targets set between them as donors and government had not been met. Ambassador Verheul was equally livid about the lip service fight against corruption announcing a major drawback of his government's supports to Justice Law and Order Sector from the current annual Euro18m to only Euro 6million. "There have been issues in regard to procurement of text books where there are allegations of corruption," he said. He added that they will continue to support a number of project activities in primary education with an estimated 3 to 4 million euros this year. She admitted that there have been instances of "shoddy work in schools, suppliers of instructional materials not following procurement procedures, loss of funds and students losing on training because of our mistakes as technical people in the ministry." But she hoped with the launch of the ministry's client charter, it will empower the public to demand what is not being implemented in future. pahimbisibwe@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Museveni Can Still Fight Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (73%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (72%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: The political and therefore the public mood in the country has been consumed by the debates in Parliament over revelations that some Cabinet ministers were bribed by oil firm Tullow, in the process of getting its business end tied down with the government of Uganda. Two of the ministers linked to the scandal have since stepped aside from their offices to allow investigations to start. Prime Minister, Amama Mbabazi, also named in the scandal has resisted such calls. President Museveni has defended his ministers and is resisting any attempt to sack his close allies instead treating the claims of bribery as hearsay propagated by witch-hunters. Both sides of the divide in the House seem to be separated by the lack of honesty and willingness to listen but mostly accepting responsibility even though temporarily to allow investigations to take place. Moral responsibility would dictate that any public official not encumbered by self-interest and serving the nation for its own good would step aside from the public office they occupy and return once they are proven innocent. Unfortunately, President Museveni himself, a public official, seems to operate in self-interest when it comes to dealing decisively with corruption. He has in the past admonished corruption where it does not seem to suit him and yet playing defender of people on whom mill stones of corruption hung by their necks where upon such people are close allies to him. Over time however, public opinion is turning against the President's stance on how to deal with corruption in his government. Despite claims of witch-hunt, the public is keen to see those claiming to be innocent proven so through some form of statutory investigation process. Any attempt to hinder that would seem to cement the belief - true or false - that President Museveni is himself obstructing further revelations of the evil in government. But we believe the President still has the will to get rid of corruption by borrowing a leaf from other countries - they are several examples - where the President has sought to disassociate himself from his inner circle members whenever they are named in corruption.

TITLE: We Need to Know; Is Govt Oiling Development or Corruption? [opinion]
SUBJECT: OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); CRUDE OIL & NATURAL GAS EXTRACTION (89%); NATURAL RESOURCES (89%); BRIBERY (87%); OIL & GAS OUTPUT (78%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (78%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (74%); INVESTIGATIONS (60%) Uganda; Corruption
TEXT: Way back in October 2006 the Daily Monitor published an article by me with the title "Politics of oil, business and 'destroying' our environs". We have been made to believe that Uganda's modest oil resources, once exploited, will greatly benefit our economy, development and people. Lots of money was spent training human resources in preparation for a whirlwind exploitation of oil, which was believed, especially by our President, would go a long way in contributing to the resolution of our chronic fuel crisis. We are talking about some 4,000 barrels of oil per day. The ten million dollar question is, will oil really oil our economy, development and people out of poverty? Well, oil did so in Norway, but here more than 2.9 million barrels are produced per day with a great proportion consumed locally and a lot more exported to lucrative markets in Europe and the USA. With proper institutionalisation, including policies and laws that empower communities rather than dispossess them corruption, corporate greed and political gerrymandering, have been put in check. Not so in Nigeria, where it is difficult to break the symbiotic relationship between the politico-military establishment and the oil companies, especially Shell BP. Here, people die daily in oil related violence in their attempt to show their indignation that although 2.5 million barrels of oil are mined daily, poverty among the poor has been on the rise almost proportionate to governmental and individual corruption of the rulers and corporate. In Uganda, we have a formidable politico-military establishment that seems to be frantically working, not so much to make our people sovereign over their land and natural resources such as oil, as to grab whatever they can lay their hands on. They have put in place constitutional and legal instruments to disempower They have established a new ownership society of the rich and powerful that will not allow civility to reign vis-avis natural resources. We now see the Executive using every means to protect the corrupt officials accused of having taken bribes in the oil industry. We have heard once again that some MPs have been paid Shs5 million each to ensure that the oil decisions of Parliament pinning some ministers alleged to have accepted bribes from oil firms to step aside as investigations of corruption are carried out by Parliament are being rethought? The Executive, therefore, poses the greatest threat to democracy and justice in the industry, and also to the autonomy of Parliament. There are many little firms that have been created to do one thing or another in the oil industry. We do not know who the real owners of the little firms are. It is likely that they belong to some of our most powerful in the land. It is also likely the most powerful individuals have acquired large shares in those companies. Therefore, if oil in Uganda ever gets exploited the real beneficiaries will be the rulers, their spouses, family members and those who have been sucked into the long, winding patronage chain. Unless there is change of behaviour in the oil industry, like in Nigeria, it will be grief, not prosperity, for our struggling, increasingly impoverished poor, and spiraling corruption of the politico-military and corporate. Well, what else should we expect in a country that became the first truly international Bantustan at the beginning of the end of the late 1990s, and seems to be far from dropping the label for another country to take over? For now it is the President to watch. Meanwhile don't say "Oiling development"; say "Oiling corruption," with the full participation of corporate. Prof. Afunaduula is an environmentalist and the chairman of Nile Basin Discourse

TITLE: Corruption Runs Through the Veins of the Ruling Party [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); SEX TRAFFICKING (90%); POLITICS (90%); HUMAN TRAFFICKING (89%); FAMILY (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); BRIBERY (78%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (77%); BORDER CONTROL (76%); FAMILY COMPANIES (75%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (73%); CARTELS (71%); HUMAN RIGHTS (69%) Uganda; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Human Rights
TEXT: I contend that a genuine fight against corruption in Uganda is a fight against the NRM and President Museveni. This fight is complicated and is comparable to the global fight against international drug and human traffickers. Quite a complex feat interlaced, driven and sustained by high level political corruption within the party because the NRM party has become synonymous with and a prime agent of corruption. Underneath the lucrative global trafficking are networks of cartels and warloads; a network of pimps, johns and numerous trans-border traffickers, mafias, gangsters, politicians and conglomerates that operate through porous borders and corrupt migration policy enforcement to ship out and trade in humans, drugs and weapons. We can agree that most successful underground organisations involved in these illicit trades, have god-fathers. The god-father is the superimposing character - well protected and a nexus upon which the conditions and environment of their businesses are mediated. The godfathers are usually obsolete figures that are at an arm's length away from the scenes of transactions. They pull cords to control political power through bribery, coercion and indulge in procurement of allegiance from contending politicians and business people. The trading families who control large markets and many trafficking routes become the most powerful, fierce and equally respected. The family business becomes the costa nostra "our thing" and cousins marry fellow cousins to keep the wealth and power within the house. The La Costa Nostra attitude that was prevalent among the Italian mafias and others in Latin America is what now subsumes the NRM regime. The structure that the President has built in 25 years is strong but is not any different from those operated by rogue elements in illicit trades. There is no need to explicate this situation any further, but Museveni has consolidated his stronghold on the means of coercion. His rule is branded by militarised police brutality. His suspected associates relatives have consolidated their positions and privileges at the helm of the regime structure and have control of vast amount of land and other economic advantages, including ownership of lands that have minerals, fresh waters and oil reserves. In the words of Kevin Bales, the renowned anti-human trafficking author and researcher, Ugandans who are not obedient to the networks of the political family, are "disposable people". This is what became very apparent of former VP Gilbert Bukenya. Prof. Bukenya's recent time in jail over his alleged part in the Chogm scandal spoke volumes to those who have the ears to listen and the eyes, not yet bloated by the proceeds of corruption, to see. Prof. Bukenya is a typical example of an uncritical NRM outsider and a conduit. Despite his illustrious administrative competence, he was reduced to a disposable entity. The moment Prof. Bukenya tried to form political shape, he was quickly disposed of and presented as the prime agent of corruption. In reality, Prof. Bukenya is only an (in)subordinate agent. And let's put aside the two-faces that we carry. I truly felt for Prof. Bukenya as he froze in the coolers. I could not fathom the man in Prof. Bukenya so determined to remain in the kitchen sink - humiliated and humiliated again. I thought Prof. Bukenya would have listened to the messages of the mafia when his son perished in a car accident under mysterious circumstances that is only comparable to that of former Speaker Francis Ayume. Prof. Bukenya should have known that he is treading a rough path. But let's contend that the real problem of corruption in Uganda is neatly weaved and inextricable with the circumstances of President Museveni's continued tenure of office that has been translated as "our power" by the people close to him. Let's be realistic and honest to ourselves before we claim patriotism here. We are chasing our shadows in pretext of tackling corruption. The organism called NRM has mutated to have many corrupt heads. We must identify all the heads and tentacles for it to get capitulated. I believe that a genuine process of removing corruption from Uganda can only start with change. As long as Museveni is still president of Uganda, corruption will move with him for, corruption is the NRM itself! Mr Komakech is a Ugandan social critic and political analyst based in Toronto

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Fight is Fool's Gold [column]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (89%); POLITICS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (86%); ELECTIONS (79%); EXECUTIVES (79%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); HISTORIC SITES (73%); RADIO BROADCAST INDUSTRY (69%); ARMED FORCES (69%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: President Museveni, his two closest challengers Kizza Besigye and Norbert Mao have spent some time on the campaign trail prescribing and counter prescribing maladies for corruption. In any election, the issues are many - difficult to distil and some tend to be local. For example, the issue of oil and Bunyoro's lousy bargain is a big issue in one part of the country while the end of the Northern War is a big issue in another part of the country. Corruption seems to be a recurrent issue understood in fairly universal terms across the country. Each year comes with a new dimension. The historical areas of interest remain the same: Offences of procurement dating from the days of the Central Tender Board. In the military during times of war, procurement turned soldiers into owners of business conglomerates. Every so often, reminders of this era come back to the public eye. General Saleh's daughter recently lost petty cash worth Shs500m to a housemaid. In the public sector, offences of procurement are then padded with illicit acquisition of wealth, unjust enrichment, and plain theft. Procurement can be very creative like the smart idea one day that saw the Police transition from a couple of worn uniforms: duty and dress to 16 uniforms in one swoop. Many public sector executives routinely do business with the entities they run or regulate. Perhaps the only executive who has not received a business model to execute this is Allen Kagina, the chief executive of the Uganda Revenue Authority. Outgoing Kampala Mayor Nasser Sebaggala took this further after helping KCC get rid of most of its "excess inventory" by asking to take home into retirement his physical office to mark the end of the era of the executive mayor. In the political environment, the politics of giving and sharing is a bi-partisan sport. MPs currently facing re-election are strained by all sorts of financial pressures that an impoverished electorate imposes upon them. An elected official whether from the ruling party or the opposition is an important asset in the political system. He or she distributes the crumbs from the table. While public land was being parcelled out in the last decade, cronies affiliated to the ruling party always sought political cover by sharing with their opponents from the opposition. It is instructive that the worst offenders in the local governments come from both the ruling party and the opposition. During his campaigns upcountry Kizza Besigye has "failed" to address voters on several radio stations all owned by MPs. It appears to be that one of the qualifications of becoming an MP is owning a radio station starting with the Vice President Gilbert Bukenya going all the way down to junior backbenchers. Any discussion of corruption that excludes donors is a joke. The donor community serves as an important interface between the metropolitan economy represented by the first world and the third world where opportunities and markets are still being nurtured. The mechanisms for measuring leakages initiated by donor projects are not well developed. Norbert Mao has used a rudimentary mechanism to count all the foreign aid Uganda has received since 1986 with Uganda's GDP. This method may ruthlessly combine successful donor initiatives like President Bush's PEPFAR, which actually treat patients, with ponzi schemes like the Luweero Marshall Fund that never materialised in the 1980s, PAPSCA, Entandikwa, Bonna Baggagawale and the likes. In fact to add salt to the wound, the World Bank recently announced a new round of grants and development support that include a $30m cassava research programme. Teso, Uganda's former cassava granary would be happy to work on more pressing priorities which in turn would boost farmer productivity and income without spending $30m studying the problem. For President Museveni, the discussion of corruption solves two strategic problems. First, it is the only avenue he can use to universally tame his allies in NRM and the opposition. No major political figure in office can survive a major anti-corruption probe - not the likes of chicken eats an egg- Cheeye kind of trials. This litmus test applies to all sorts of individuals and potential trouble-makers from Vice President Bukenya to Trade Minister Kahinda Otafiire, former Health Minister Jim Muhwezi and now new arrival in the Movement Nasser Sebaggala. In fact, the dog and pony show in Parliament probing misuse of public funds always conducted with dramatisations for the media has created very wealthy and powerful people in Parliament; who find evidence of malfeasance, collect from the victim(s) before exonerating them. By lamenting about corruption, President Museveni gives himself political cover to pick a sacrificial lamb once in a while to keep the trains moving on time. For his opponents, they sound naí¿ve by wasting time prescribing pain killers for an increasingly deadly cancer measured now in terms of lives lost due to a crumbling healthcare system. With all the media focused on the living arrangements and lifestyles of the opposition leaders, one only sees heirs to the system rather than angels vested with supernatural powers to destroy, kill and rebuild. Mr Ssemogerere, an attorney and social entrepreneur, practices law in New York

TITLE: East Africa Roots for Tough Anti Corruption Laws
COUNTRY: EASTERN AFRICA (95%); AFRICA (95%); BURUNDI (92%); UGANDA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); RULE OF LAW (89%); ETHICS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); CRIMINAL LAW (78%); EXTRADITION (77%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (73%) Uganda; Economy, Business and Finance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: East Africa is in urgent need of strict enforcement of anti-corruption laws to boost socio-economic development in the region, an official has said. Speaking at a Democracy and Good Governance conference in Bujumbura, Burundi, Ms Beatrice Kiraso, the deputy secretary general in charge of Political Federation said the vice has undermined development and the provision of social services, which subsequently has increased the cost of doing business. She said: "Corruption is an evil that undermines development and provision of social services." The conference hosted by the East African Law Society during its Annual General Meeting brought together about 400 researchers from the East African region. Ms Kiraso briefed the meeting about EAC efforts towards ensuring democracy and good governance. The draft EAC Protocol on Good Governance covers four broad distinct pillars which are in effect inter-related. They include democracy and democratisation processes, human rights and equal opportunities, anti-corruption, ethics and integrity and rule of law and access to justice. She said a draft protocol on preventing and combating corruption has been developed covering asset recovery, forfeiture, transfer of criminals and criminal proceedings, among the key provisions. The drafted protocol provides for extradition, judicial cooperation and mutual legal assistance and establishes a financial intelligence unit within the region. Ms Kiraso said the recent increase in corruption cases in the region is not a result of lack of legal instruments but a result of reluctance in implementation and enforcement. She said lack of political will to fight corruption is one of the main challenges facing the region in eliminating the vice. The Deputy Secretary General also emphasized the role of the sector on Rule of Law and Access to Justice in the region, stating that their major focus is to promote enactment of just laws to facilitate effective administration of justice "in a manner that guarantees social justice, prevention of conflicts, peace and political stability."

TITLE: Districts Come Top in New Corruption List of Shame
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); SCHOOL DISTRICTS (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); ANNUAL REPORTS (78%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); EMBEZZLEMENT (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); BUDGETS (74%); ARRESTS (72%); STATISTICS (70%); CITY GOVERNMENT (64%); MISAPPROPRIATION (60%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A new report by the Inspectorate of Government has ranked districts among the top public institutions most frequently complained about by Ugandans due to perceptions that they are perennially corrupt. On a day the IGG, Mr Raphael Baku, released the report to the public, writers accused the ombudsman of incompetence and voiced concerns that he is shunning the corrupt "big fish" in government- entrenching corruption in the system. But Mr Baku said yesterday: "We have more people who appear to be small fish because we received more complaints from the local governments. It's not that we fear big people. As a matter of fact, we have established a directorate of operations to look for the corrupt in the central government." "We haven't been able to initiate our own investigations into some of the corruption cases in the central government because we lack adequate and professional staff to find what you call the "big fish." Most complaints received by the IGG were against district administrators which were 207 of the total complaints received. "We are already overwhelmed by the complaints we received from the public. This is an indication that people are getting involved in the fight against corruption," Mr Baku said. The districts have for the third financial year running topped the list of the most complained about institutions representing 19.9 per cent. Some 1,040 complaints were received and only 629 were investigated to conclusion in the year under review. About 109 complaints were processed and later referred to other institutions. In the previous year, the IGG received 2,933 complaints of which 288 were investigated and concluded and about 230 cases referred to other institutions for further scrutiny. Available figures from the World Bank show that Uganda loses more than Shs500 billion to corruption annually. This is more than 10 per cent of the total national budget. During the year under review, 40 public officers mainly from the local governments were arrested for various corruption offences while 66 cases are still on-going in courts of law, 11 concluded and 15 cases were appealed. The IGG blamed the failure to prosecute the corrupt on the sluggishness of the judiciary. The annual report to Parliament for the year ending June 2010 puts government officials, who according to the IGG, "have individually continued to use their office for private gain" in the second position. The common nature of complaints against district administrators includes mismanagement and misappropriation of public funds, abuse of office, embezzlement and mishandling of tenders. Also in the report, Municipal Councils/Town Councils are in third spot followed by school authorities, the Police and the Local Councils respectively. Kampala for the third time remains in the first position among the top districts suspected to be corrupt with 484 complaints followed by Masaka with 76, Jinja 68, Soroti 58, Moyo 49, Fort Portal 46, Mbale 43 and Gulu 42. Moroto remains the least corrupt district followed by Lira, Mbarara, Hoima, Kabale and Tororo. The IGG has also invited the public to take incriminating evidence against the ministers and other government officials accused of pocketing more than Shs500 billions meant for Chogm meeting.

TITLE: Our Change Politics Will Stamp Out Corruption
SUBJECT: CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (78%); PRIVATIZATION (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (78%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (78%); HEALTH CARE (75%); PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (73%); PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS (73%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (69%); NURSES & NURSING (67%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (66%); DRUG SHORTAGES (52%); AGRICULTURAL PRICES (50%) Uganda; Governance
TEXT: Inter-Party Cooperation flag bearer, Dr Kizza Besigye has been on the campaign trail hammering away at National Resistance Movement's record in government under President Museveni. He has told campaign rallies across south western Buganda where he began his campaign that the country finds itself in dire straits because of, among other things, the paucity of accountable leadership. Dr Besigye, who is running against President Museveni in a third straight contes,t holds the firm belief that one of the failures of this administration is the deliberate or otherwise inability of the regime's leadership to punish those either suspected of, or found guilty of, dabbling in corruption. He identifies one of the reasons behind this failure as being the closeness of some of the culprits to the ruling party's core - and in some instances their direct personal relationship with the President. Over the years, he continues to tell voters, delivery of proper health services has deteriorated because corruption has been allowed to eat away at the infrastructure that should ideally be in place to fight disease. The shortage of essential drugs and health manpower which, he believes is directly responsible for high maternal and child mortality, for example. There is also the point that health centres are ill-equipped to handle even the most basic of health care needs. This is compounded by the fact that even the few doctors and nurses who remain in public health service today are very poorly paid. The candidate further blames the poor transport infrastructure in an economy that has been hobbled by what he says are recklessly implemented policies like privatisation of strategic parastatals on graft. The country's poor roads have repeatedly been a subject of Dr Besigye's speeches. He has observed in far flung places like Mityana that farmers are left at the mercy of unscrupulous middlemen who refer to the poor feeder roads when setting very low farm gate prices for produce. It is this politics of corruption that has been allowed to ferment across the body-politic of the country which the IPC leader seeks to replace if elected. He makes the following proposals in his campaign manifesto: "We will fight corruption at all levels. We will have zero tolerance for corruption and all those found guilty of this offence will face severe punishment including refund. We will ensure that al organs to fight corruption are active and well facilitated. We will strengthen the civil societies and work with them in the fight against corruption. "For 25 years money has been stolen by leaders of NRM. The government has nurtured corruption as a way of life in Uganda. It's in the public sector, it has now reached alarming levels and yet those who steal public funds are promoted. This has frustrated the efforts and aspiration of many Ugandans. It has reduced the chances of delivering the public goods such as education, health and infrastructure, thus hindering progress. The IPC government will do the following to end corruption: Implement a policy of zero tolerance to corruption through making corrupt practice a high risk venture Continue to ensure that the Public Accounts Committee [of Parliament] is headed by the opposition as a check on government. Ensure that corrupt officials are dealt with promptly and firmly according to the law without fear or favour hence recover what they have stolen. Educate and empower citizens, civil society organisations, and the media on their role in fighting corruption Make the offices of Attorney General, Inspector General of government, and Director of Public Prosecution more competent, independent and better facilitated. The introduction to this piece was drawn from excerpts from the IPC leader's campaign speeches so far.

TITLE: Can Museveni Fight Corruption When Many of His Top Cabinet Ministers Remain Under Suspicion?
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); MISCONDUCT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); VERDICTS (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (89%); ELECTIONS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); CYBERCRIME (72%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (72%); RAIL TRANSPORTATION (60%) Uganda; Governance; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: At least 10 ministers accused of abuse of office or other forms of improper conduct remain in Cabinet, despite President Museveni's campaign pledge to fight corruption if re-elected in February. Mr Museveni's decision to keep the officials in Cabinet, including protecting some of them from possible prosecution, has turned corruption into one of the main campaign issues, with the President's opponents accusing him of lacking the political will to fight graft. The UK government recently announced it was cutting Shs27 billion in promised aid over what it said was less-than-satisfactory progress on investigating senior ministers accused of corrupt practice and influence-peddling over the 2007 Chogm Summit in which billions were lost in dubious deals. Government officials say the UK decision did not take into consideration the on-going parliamentary inquiry into the matter as evidence of political will to address the problem. President Museveni and the ruling NRM have, in their re-election manifesto, pledged to continue fighting corruption. Mr Museveni says the NRM is committed to a policy of "zero-tolerance to corruption" and will, if re-elected, strengthen the investigative and prosecution capacity of anti-corruption agencies to be able to handle the new and more sophisticated cases of corruption, including cyber crime. Critics, both in the opposition and civil society, however, say President Museveni has failed to act on his promises. While many of the Cabinet ministers who have been accused have not been proven guilty, the failure to investigate the allegations against them has denied some of them an opportunity to clear their names, leaving a cloud of suspicion over many Cabinet ministers. A Daily Monitor investigation also reveals that some ministers who have been found guilty of improper conduct have been reappointed to Cabinet, often on promotion. Here are the men and women who serve with the President but who have been denied the chance to clear their names in court. The Public Accounts Committee accuses Prof. Bukenya of interfering with the procurement process during Chogm, contrary to the law, leading to a Shs5.6 billion loss. Prof. Bukenya denies the allegations. He told Parliament last week that the decisions were taken collectively by Cabinet with President Museveni's knowledge. Accused of diverting 2,000 litres of fuel from Uganda Railways Corporation in 1999 to help a political ally, Mr Kivejinja resigned just as MPs prepared to censure him as Transport minister. He returned to Cabinet in 2003 and was later promoted to his current portfolio. He was also found guilty of electoral malpractices during a bitter race against Abdu Katuntu for the Bugweri parliamentary seat in 2006. The PAC report accuses Prof Makubuya of signing off advances to private hoteliers ahead of Chogm without repayment guarantees. About Shs8 billion in taxpayers' money was lost in the process but Prof Makubuya denies any wrongdoing. The PAC report accuses Mr Mbabazi, who is also the NRM Secretary General, of interference and conflict of interest in the procurement of a communication system for the security agencies through the ICT ministry. MPs have also questions why the contract came in at about Shs4.1 billion higher but Mr Mbabazi denies any wrongdoing. A parliamentary inquiry in 2008 found Mr Mbabazi guilty of influence-peddling in a transaction in which he and a business associate, Mr Amos Nzeyi, sold land to the National Social Security Fund. Mr Mbabazi was later cleared by Parliament under controversial circumstances. The top two NSSF officials were fired and former MD David Jamwa is currently awaiting trial at the Anti-Corruption Court over related matters. PAC has recommended that minister Mwesigye and other government officials should be held liable for a loss of Shs280m to government arising from a Shs7 billion contract to clean up the city ahead of Chogm. Ms Mwesigye oversaw the process in her previous capacity as State Minister for Local Government and is accused of authorising payments to contractors against the advice of ministry technocrats, and of failing to declare monies paid by exhibitors. She denies all the allegations. The 6th Parliament in 1999 censured Mr Kutesa, then state minister for planning, for conflict of interest and abuse of office after he pushed for his company, Entebbe Handling Services, to take over the lucrative ground-handling at Entebbe Airport. This denied the already struggling Uganda Airlines much-needed revenue and contributed to the collapse of the national carrier.Mr Kutesa was reappointed to Cabinet shortly after and promoted. MPs investigating Chogm accuse him of conflict-of-interest for allegedly acting in concert with VP Bukenya to ensure that a company in which the minister, until 2005, owned a majority stake, supplied cars for the summit delegates. He denies all allegations. Gen. Otafiire resigned his ministerial position in the mid-90s after he drew a pistol on Jennifer, the late wife to Foreign Affairs Minister Sam Kutesa. In the incident over a drink at Fairway Hotel, Maj. Gen. Otafiire accused late Jennifer of having "sucked" the country to its "bone marrow". A 2002 UN Panel of Experts report accused Gen. Otafiire, alongside other senior army officers, of various transgressions in the Democratic Republic of Congo (where he'd been deployed after leaving Cabinet), including working with brutal allied local militias to "plunder and pillage" DR Congo resources. Gen. Otafiire in self-defence said there was nothing worth picking from DRC, and a government created Justice Potter Commission later exonerated all Ugandan officials implicated in the UN report. He was later reappointed to Cabinet but his stints in the Lands, Local Government and Trade and Tourism ministries have been marred by controversy over the management of public assets and resources. One of the longest-serving cabinet ministers (and the longest serving in the same ministry), Eng. Nasasira is named in the Chogm report together with VP Bukenya for interfering with procurement of the Chogm cars, contrary to the law. Mr Nasasira is also accused of neglect of duty and of bending procurement procedures to favour one of the bidders. The State Minister for Regional Cooperation was embroiled in a scandal over the procurement of a National Identity Card project when a personal cheque he presented of Shs28 million to facilitate an 11-member team to visit pre-qualified companies bounced. The minister's personal involvement in the matter contravened the Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Authority regulations but he was never held accountable. The project, which was halted following complaints from one of the bidders, is yet to get off the ground. Mr Musumba is still in Cabinet. As State Minister for Tourism Serapio Rukundo solicited for $3m (sh6b) from the finance ministry to help the proprietor of J&M Airport Hotel complete it ahead of the 2007 Commonwealth summit. According to the Auditor General's report, J&M was not on the list of approved Chogm venues and no activity was supposed to have been hosted there. The government gave the hotel $1.3m (about sh2.7b) to complete 200 rooms two days before the summit.He denies any wrongdoing. Ethics minister Dr Nsaba Buturo, who has chided top bureaucrats for involving in graft came under the microscope for irregularly picking Shs20 million from Mega FM in Gulu to facilitate the making of a government documentary. He later had the money reimbursed following public outcry.

TITLE: Democratic Party Will Stop Corruption by Example
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL PARTIES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (86%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING EXPENDITURE (61%); MALARIA (60%); AIDS & HIV (50%) Uganda; Governance; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Democratic Party will ensure a transparent, accountable and corruption free government cardinal in its manifesto. We believe the political economy of Uganda, the socio-economic, socio -cultural development in this country will be achieved only with an exemplary leadership, which leadership is lacking in Uganda with the current leadership in government being suspects [of corruption]. To get the right answer, Uganda needs the right formula of tackling corruption first with stringent laws that will ensure accountability at all levels. DP will have zero tolerance for corruption and specifically; the Mao-DP administration will redistribute Executive power since we believe that the current ills in government such as corruption and non-accountability arise from the concentration of the power and authority of the state in the Presidency and the emasculation of the capability of other public institution that are intended to ensure the due checks and balances in the transaction of public affairs. Our administration will enforce autonomy of public institutions through independent vetting by commissions and Parliament. DP will institute a serious legal reform to ensure that any public official accused of corruption is immediately relieved of his responsibilities and suspended till the case is fully determined. We have witnessed government officials impeached for corruption but still enjoying the liberty of holding important offices. Democratic Party will not only make zero tolerance a swan song but rather the epitome of its first leadership credentials. The fish rots from the head; it's the head and top leadership that must stand to be counted. The idea of arresting small fish like Teddy Cheeye while dining and basking in peace with big thieves will not be tolerated. Corruption has been institutionalised in Uganda and DP will undo this. It has been breeding under weak public sector management and administration. Whereas poverty is chocking most ordinary Ugandans, a few people are basking in the national wealth. On transparency International rankings, Uganda moved from 126 to 130 out of 180 countries in their indices of 2008/2009. Corruption has flourished in the procurement and administration of public expenditure. IGG reports indicated that local governments are the most corrupt sector of government and because they are closer to the people, corruption impacts directly to the ordinary people. Thefts have always been reported but the criminals have been forgiven, even by the President. That makes him a suspect! We have witnessed corruption cases in the Purchase of junk choppers; the NSSF/ Temangalo saga, The Global Fund where victims of HIV/Aids and Malaria were deprived of their lives through theft of money meant for their treatment. The recently concluded Chogm in Kampala that saw billions stolen by government ministers. These big suspects still hold onto their offices. We won't tolerate this. There are myriads of corruption examples. In northern Uganda, the war ate billions. In 2003 alone over $1.3 billion was spent on the war under classified expenditure. The Northern Uganda Reconstruction Programmes 1 & 2 and the Northern Uganda Social Action Fund have been another den of corruption. Ugandans saw Gulu District chairman, who is DP Party President expose corruption in the Prime Minister's office when he literally broke one of the plastic pangas procured to help resettle people of northern Uganda. The perpetrators are still ministers in these offices. It is estimated that Uganda loses Shs500 billion annually to corruption according to the 2007 African Peer Review Mechanism report. DP President General, also known as Chairman Mao, was voted number two among the least corrupt Ugandans by the Anti-Corruption Coalition Uganda 2009/10. This is a precedent that Uganda needs an exemplary leader. The first victim of the demise of culture and traditions in Uganda after colonialism is the moral sense of shame! Leaders luck morals and they dress to go to office to steal but not to work. DP will heal Uganda from all forms of corruption ranging from actual theft of public funds, to nepotism in public services such as the army. This is our promise to Uganda. The medicine is Mao Mr Emmanuel Mwaka Lutukumoi, the DP National Publicity Secretary, wrote this article on behalf his party leader.

TITLE: This Country Badly Needs a Commission On Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (79%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); STARVATION (76%); WAGES & SALARIES (75%); LAWYERS (73%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (73%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (73%); CIVIL SERVICES (72%); LEGISLATION (71%); APPOINTMENTS (68%); CRIMINAL LAW (68%); COST OF LIVING (65%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Prof. Apollo Nsibambi defines corruption in the Ufahamu journal as accepting money or money worth to exercise a legitimate discretion in doing or failing to do one's duty. However, he would appear to make an exception in the case of Namunswa alya ku nswa ze. This is in reference to the king who eats on his kingdom. The national wealth is his property. However, a modern king in a democracy occupies a desired or wanted cultural position and he is appropriately paid for it. But these are kings or emperors who allocate themselves absolute powers over the national wealth which they also extend to their relatives. Mobutu of Congo and Abacha of Nigeria are examples of such dictators who drained their countries' wealth into foreign banks. Areas of corruption are many; they include: bribes, procurement of tenders, false accounting, embezzlement, diversion of public resources, influence peddling abuse of office, nepotism, false claims, creation of ghost employees, etc. The "watch dogs" over these areas are; the Solicitor General, Auditor General, Inspector General of Government, Public Procurement and Disposal of Assets and the Public Accounts Committee of Parliament. Accountable officials are the Permanent Secretaries and heads of different parastatal bodies. These officers are charged with full responsibility to account for every penny allocated to their sectors. Ministers have no responsibility whatsoever for any expenditure incurred in their ministries, unless they have specifically ordered for such expenditure in writing. Permanent Secretaries must be able to identify and follow any possible action or practice and ensure appropriate punishment for any discovered offence. There is a statutory provision for such horrid practice in the Constitution and in the Penal Code. There is even a new law which was enacted in 2009 to strengthen the power to control public property. Nevertheless, there are other necessary conditions for integrity in the performance of public affairs. A visionary leader is necessary, but he must also be supported by other necessary institutions and instruments. We have enumerated some above. The visionary leader with a set of programmes to perform will confirm those "policies, laws and programmes to facilitate administration in place." However, there are two areas that need examination and realisation. Whoever is entrusted with food should not be starving; the temptation to help oneself would be too strong and even understood! I strongly feel a salary review commission is long overdue. The last such a commission existed in 1989, 21 years ago! Since then, a lot of water has passed under the bridge. Cost of living has doubled several times. Some of those who needed such a review such as Members of Parliament have successfully manoeuvred themselves out of the order for whom such a review would be appointed. Similarly, the Judiciary believed they did not have to wait for a decision of the Executive. The civil servants like doctors and teachers are the ones suffering. The amount of money one Member of Parliament earns, can pay four Permanent Secretaries. The whole government should have one common salary structure. The supervision of the utilisation of public property is so important and extensive that it needs more than the current machinery of the Auditor General, PPDA and PAC. I therefore strongly recommend the creation of a corruption commission into active service. The commission's function would be to follow up the expenditure of every cent as allocated by Parliament or as granted by the Constitution. No more and no less. The commission would ensure that only those for whom the expenditure was intended or the service was provided for is the only beneficiary. How they would ensure that this is the only target will be for the commission to decide. There are surely several ways of doing it. It would depend on each expenditure. We are losing too much in contracts and receiving too little and too poor service. The Auditor General comes in after the mice have escaped. The Minister of Public Service or the Minster of Integrity may wish to go to Cabinet and seek approval to establish the proposed corruption commission and appoint the salary review commission without further delay. These are proposals which the public requests the Minister to accept. Mr Sibo is a former Commissioner at the Uganda Human Rights Commission

TITLE: Kisoro Magistrate Jailed Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); MAGISTRATES (92%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (92%); JAIL SENTENCING (91%); BRIBERY (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); SENTENCING (78%); LITIGATION (78%); VERDICTS (78%); CORRECTIONS (78%); ARRESTS (74%); BAIL (73%); JUDGES (73%); DIABETES (57%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A Grade One Magistrate attached to Kisoro Chief Magistrates Court, David Cheptuke Kaye, could not believe his ears when the Anti-Corruption Court sent him to jail after being convicted of corruption. Despite his plea to be given a fine on grounds that he suffers from diabetes, presiding Judge Paul Mugamba did not decided otherwise. "I have taken your mitigation of non-custodial sentence but as judiciary we should be paragon of justice. I sentence you to one year in prison," ruled Justice Mugamba. Kaye, clad in a white shirt and a black suit, was found guilty of receiving a bribe of Shs100,000 from Ms Angella Uwayezu as an inducement to release on bail her three nephews who were facing charges of malicious damage to a property. He was also ordered to refund Shs100,000 to Ms Uwayezu. Court heard that prior to his arrest, Kaye was in charge of Kisoro Magistrates Court. Court heard that Kaye committed the offence on February 12 in order to release Mr Denis Maseruka, Ms Scovia Busingye and Mr Richard Ntirengeya, who were charged with malicious damage of property. This is not the first time a court official in being jailed over corruption. Last year, Mbarara Grade II Magistrate, Moses Ndifuna, was jailed for two years for receiving a Shs200,000 bribe from a businessman. The money was meant to make the magistrate lift a court order put on some business that had been closed by the health inspector of Kakoba division in Mbarara Municipality.

TITLE: Mao Calls Museveni a Corruption Suspect
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); PLATFORMS & ISSUES (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (79%); ORGANIZED CRIME (77%); EVIDENCE (76%); PRIVATIZATION (75%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (75%); PUBLIC POLICY (75%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (72%); PUBLIC FINANCE (71%); NATIONAL SECURITY (68%); DIVESTITURES (60%) Uganda
TEXT: Democratic Party presidential candidate Norbert Mao yesterday kept the spotlight on graft as a key campaign issue, charging that it is impossible for the President to claim any commitment to fighting the rampant vice when he is himself a "chief suspect". "You cannot be the chief suspect in corruption and expect to get rid of the problem," Mr Mao said in Budaka where, although he did not provide evidence directly implicating the President in corruption, he still rejected President Museveni's renewed campaign promise to fight corruption. "The most corrupt top government officials are being shielded from being prosecuted by the President of this country while the poor continue to suffer paying exorbitant taxes which time to time are swindled," Mr Mao said. Addressing several rallies in Budaka District, Mr Mao said the ruling National Resistance Movement (NRM) is not a party but a platform for thieves who are against change knowing that once there is change, they can expect to face the law and also pay back what they have stolen from the government coffers. "The President's allies are openly swindling government funds under his watch. It's very difficult to fight corruption when he (Museveni) himself is not clean at all," Mr Mao said attracting thunderous applause. The DP leader cast himself as a candidate unblemished by accusations of corruption pointing at his leadership as Gulu District chairman which he said is free of graft. This is unlike the central government that is today struggling under the weight of the reported uncontrolled swindling of public resources. "Leaders," Mr Mao said, "must have the moral authority to discipline corrupt officials. Merely saying we shall deal with them and nothing happens is a 'mafia' style of confusing the entire electorate to think tough measures are [coming] when it is a hoax." Mr Mao cited the Shs11 billion Temangalo land scandal in which Security Minister Amama Mbabazi was named, Global fund heist in which three ministers were implicated and procurement of junk military choppers as examples of cases of corruption which costs Uganda hundreds of billions of shillings annually. "These people are walking free and continue using government facilities. As a leader, he (Museveni) would have fired these ministers instead of rotating them within his administration," said Mr Mao, adding: "All these will have to face the law once Mao is entrusted with power come 2011 election." He also spoke about his plans to shake up the country's economy from the devastation of this administration's privatisation policy that witnessed the divestiture of key state parastatals like the Uganda Commercial Bank, Uganda Railways and other valuable national assets. Taking a swipe at the opposition Forum for Democratic Change whose membership is to a considerable extent drawn from former NRM enthusiasts, Mr Mao said it would be a great mistake to vote for it since there is no difference between them. "All must be thrown out. Vote DP which is pro-people with integrity," he said. "This generation both have origins in the Luweero Triangle. They all claim that they fought to liberate this country instead they are counter-accusing each other of massive corruption and acquiring wealth in dubious deals.
