"You hear of top government people keeping billions of shillings under their beds while majority of Ugandans are wondering how to get only Shs500," he observed.

TITLE: Promise of Presidential Committee On Corruption Kills Good Manifesto [column]
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (87%); TEXT MESSAGING (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (76%); POLITICS (72%) Uganda; Governance; Crime and Corruption; Press and Media
TEXT: During a talk show on KFM on Tuesday evening, a listener sent in a text message commenting on the NRM manifesto, the subject of the discussion. He said the ruling party is better off writing a manifesto with only one sentence reading: We Shall End Corruption. The listener's understated cynicism carried meaning at a couple of levels. First, the manifesto is bulky, running into hundreds of pages. It is much longer than the 2006 one, possibly because the NRM feels compelled to make a more detailed case why it should be returned to office. Second, that the manifesto can contain endless promises but not much will come of it unless that thing called corruption is checked, possibly not ended as such. As expected, the manifesto says the NRM stands for zero tolerance of corruption. Yeah, it is not like the party would say that it stands for tolerance of corruption. In any case, the manifesto contains a strange proposal that the NRM seeks to implement in the next five years if re-elected. It says "the President will constitute a committee that investigates political leaders and senior public officers once they have been mentioned in corruption-related scandals and report back to the President within a specific time frame. If in the committee's opinion there is need for further investigation by other institutions like the IGG, then the President shall refer the matter for further investigations and ask the person(s) under investigation to step aside during the time they are being investigated". Why the presidential committee? With a fairly competent auditor general, an assertive Public Accounts Committee (PAC) of Parliament, an inspectorate of government (IGG), an anti-corruption court backed up by a strong anti-corruption law, CID, directorate of public prosecutions, why such a committee? Why? I know the answer. I know. This is a committee to protect high-profile thieves of public money. Today the IGG investigates "political leaders and senior public officers" once he receives a sensible enough complaint from whatever source. The IGG is presently prosecuting "political leaders and senior public officers" in court. The PAC discusses reports emanating from the auditor general and makes recommendations, which recommendations are almost never acted upon by the executive. Other than PAC, various committees of Parliament have tackled straight-up corruption cases but the executive, which is now so hell-bent against corruption, has done nothing about the reports. It has instead protected the sullied political leaders. It happened in the NSSF-Temangalo land transaction case. It is happening now with Chogm. We must remember that it is President Museveni who asked the auditor general to do a value-for-money audit into Chogm before the matter went to PAC. It is the same President presiding at meetings of Cabinet and the NRM caucus that are suspiciously plotting to kill the Chogm recommendations. It follows that the presidential committee will actively kill any corruption complaints against the high and mighty of the NRM, apart from usurping the powers of the various anti-corruption agencies. If not, the complaints will die in State House/Office of the President. This new committee is superfluous. It is meant to abet corruption, not fight it. It is scandalous to even suggest its creation. Better to spend the money that should have gone to this committee on funding the existing corruption-fighting bodies. And let the current system work as is. There is nothing wrong with it. What is wrong is ignoring the resultant recommendations, especially from PAC. What is wrong is President Museveni's refusal to take political responsibility and ask his ministers, named repeatedly in corruption scandals, to step aside while investigations continue. He has not done it thus far. The new committee will not make him do it. The manifesto is titled "Prosperity for All: Better Service Delivery and Job Creation." Corruption will not deliver prosperity for all any time soon. There is more to quarrel with in the NRM manifesto and we shall do so in the coming weeks and months, but there is a lot to like as well. The NRM plans to fully finance the national budget in the next five years. Now, I think I am a patriot of sorts. So I liked the sound of that goal. I just want to know whether there are any new sources of revenue. The promise to "reduce the procedures required to start and operate business and also amalgamate the 30 commercial laws into 10 so as to improve on Uganda's competitiveness as an investment destination" also makes sense. I live and work in Kampala. So when I read that "the central government will take over roads in Kampala and reconstruct all the tarmac roads that are in a sorry state and construct new ones and maintain them", I jumped. But then I remembered that I have heard that sweet lullaby before. Given that no condition is permanent, I must keep hoping. Mr Tabaire is a media trainer and consultant with the African Centre for Media Excellence

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Court Halts Gasasira's Trial
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LAWYERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (78%); JURISDICTION (78%); AGREEMENTS (76%); JUDGES (73%); APPEALS COURTS (73%); ARRESTS (73%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Court has halted the trial of the Ministry of Health Principal Accountant, Mr Nestor Gasasira, who is accused of illicit enrichment. This was after Mr Gasasira's file was referred to the Constitutional Court for interpretation of some issues cited by his lawyer Geoffrey Kandebee. Trial magistrate Emmanuel Baguma, said: "The defence lawyer has raised matters that need to be interpreted by the Constitutional Court and prosecution is in agreement, the proceedings are stayed and the accused is discharged." Mr Gasasira, 56, who was arrested on Friday by the Inspectorate of Government officials at the Kampala High Court premises, was on Monday produced before the Anti-Corruption Court for plea taking. Mr Gasasira is alleged to be in control and possession of eight apartments situated on block 220 plots 1334, 1337 and 1338 in Banda worth Shs548,205,844. The property are said to be disproportionate to his past and current known sources of income and or assets. The state also alleges that Mr Gasasira is in control and possession of residential houses situated at plot 37, Lake Drive Luzira, worth Shs330,262,946. Some of the issues raised by Mr Gasasira's lawyer that need constitutional interpretation is whether the trial court has jurisdiction to entertain a charge which arises from the investigation proceedings and report of the Inspector General of Government that had been quashed and set aside by the High Court, which proceedings are subjected to the Court of Appeal. Mr Kandebee submitted that the IGG's report findings against Mr Gasasira had been quashed in May by then High Court Judge Yorokamu Bamwine. He also said the charge sheet did not disclose the dates when his client allegedly committed the crime. However, the magistrate dismissed this defence argument. The friction between Mr Gasasira and the Inspectorate of Government began last year after he was interdicted on the orders of the then IGG, Justice Faith Mwondha, on grounds that he had violated the Leadership Code Act by not declaring his wealth. The IGG in her recommendations, wanted Mr Gasasira to be dismissed from public service for reportedly failing to explain the source of his wealth and making a false declaration related to his wealth. His property was to be confiscated by the government or he pays Shs1 billion to the government. He was also to be barred from holding public office for the next five years.

TITLE: Government Auditors On Spot Over Massive Corruption
SUBJECT: INTERNAL AUDITS (94%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (92%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ACCOUNTING (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); CONSPIRACY (90%); AUDITS (90%); BANKING & FINANCE (89%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (89%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (78%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Conspiracy by internal auditors and accountants in the government departments breeds the growing theft of public resources, according to information obtained by Sunday Monitor. Investigation carried out by this newspaper shows that audit officials are cutting deals with accounting officials instead of checking the robbery of public funds. The public Finance Act 2003 mandates internal auditors to ensure among others that before any government spending is done, all systems are followed and accountability made. But in almost every report of the Auditor General, there are always findings about public funds being spent without accountability and outside set guidelines. This has raised the question as to whether the internal auditors actually do their job. According to some of the government auditors whom Sunday Monitor spoke to, instead of exposing accounting officers who steal from the public coffers, the internal auditors have reportedly turned into 'internal consultants' who help government accountants to steal public funds. This reportedly explains the difference in findings between reports of the auditor general and internal audit with the latter usually silent on cases where huge funds were spent without accountability. In fact, sources say that most government departments don't even know the fleet of cars they own because the auditors no longer take inventory as they are preoccupied with helping the accounting officials to explain away the theft of monies. The Ministry of Finance especially the accounting officer who controls internal auditors is blamed for the laxity in supervision. A report by the African Peer Review Mechanism National Commission recently revealed that corruption and ineffective public institutions were undermining good governance in the country. And the World Bank in a 2005 report estimated that Uganda loses about $300m (sh510b) per year through corruption and procurement malpractices. Following the increased pilfering of public funds and the outcry from donors, the Finance ministry has now mooted reforms aimed at tightening the noose on internal auditors. Sunday Monitor understands that top bureaucrats in Finance were proposing changes to the Finance Act so that Parliament amends it. Some of the amendments proposed include the change of reporting lines for internal auditors from the Accountant General's Office to the Commissioner Internal audit and inspectorate. "We are aware that internal audit has not been functioning well that is why we are reforming," said Mr Keith Muhakanizi, the deputy secretary to the Treasury. Asked why the Finance ministry was only waking up too late to shake the alleged thieves after they had accumulated enough, Mr Muhakanizi said: "We are very sorry but we are going to take action." Although he declined to discuss other proposals in the reforms, sources told Sunday Monitor that the top bureaucrats now want to ensure that instead of transferring the internal auditors after at least every three years, the law should allow for less time so as not allow them "hold territories for long." Sunday Monitor also understands that they want internal auditors even after they have been transferred from a department, to explain why things went wrong if the Auditor General discovers anomalies. "We want the law to demand that the internal auditors' show evidence that they had raised those issues to the accountants if they are later discovered by the Auditor General. We want to compare the reports of the auditor general and internal audit to see who is doing a good job," a source said. However, Sunday Monitor also understands that some dedicated internal auditors were not getting support from accounting officers in some ministries, who reportedly do not appreciate their work. Instead of appreciating what the auditors say, the accounting officers reportedly blackmail them and accuse them of witch-hunt. Because of this unhealthy relationship, sources say most internal auditors have adopted the old adage: 'If you can't fight them then join them'. This has resulted into the audit department to be described as "dead". According to the Accountant General, Mr Gustavio Bwoch, the proposed amendment to the Finance Act was "to bring in more controls" because the one of 2003 appears ineffective. He said there was need to put new things in the law to ensure that auditors do risk management and internal control. Sources said the ministries which usually receive big budgets and donor funds like Water, ICT, Lands, Agriculture, Public Service and Health were mainly blacklisted for their poor use of public funds.

TITLE: 'There is No Excuse for Corruption' - Former UK Development Official [interview]
COUNTRY: UNITED KINGDOM (95%); AFRICA (93%); RWANDA (92%); UGANDA (92%); EUROPE (79%)
SUBJECT: WAR & CONFLICT (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); INTERVIEWS (89%); BRITISH PRIME MINISTERS (79%); ELECTIONS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); RESIGNATIONS (78%); EMERGING MARKETS (77%); ARMED FORCES (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (75%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (73%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (72%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (71%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (70%); HUNGER IN SOCIETY (70%); TAXES & TAXATION (64%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (60%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: UK's former Secretary of State for International Development, Ms Clare Short, who resigned after opposing former Prime Minister Tony Blair's decision to send troops to invade recently week attended the first UN Global Forum on Local Governments focusing on the Millennium Development Goals in Kampala. On the local scene she is remembered for having mediated talks between President Museveni and his Rwanda counterpart Paul Kagame in 2003 after the armies of the two countries clashed in DR Congo. No government is perfect everywhere in the world. In Uganda or any other African country, not everything has been done right like reducing poverty and hunger against all MDG goals. Some of them have made progress others have been disappointing but overall there has been some progress. And it is true in many African countries in the last 10 years, compared with the previous 20 years where things pretty went wrong. In the last 10 years across Africa there has been economic growth of about 6 per cent. But the question is that how has the money been used? The progress is not as big as you would like but when there is progress it is good. So I feel optimistic about Africa, more people are getting educated and that is good for governments. There is no excuse for corruption and it is the same story in Europe. It is not only an African disease. It has different causes for example if civil servants and the police are paid less than enough to keep the family they are going to make little charges. Now that is strictly corruption but in human terms it is undependable if you are going to work and you cannot look after your family, you have to do something. And on the other hand there are some rich greedy bloody people who take even more and more. This is not understandable and forgivable. In general to stop corruption is through moral lectures. We should all attend to our moral standards; have strong transparent systems of management, accountability and procurement that everyone can scrutinize. No contract should be given out without being published publicly. Have accountability to local people so that they can scrutinize whether they are getting services or someone is milking the system. The other thing is to make the tax system fair and transparent and not letting some people not pay tax. In some countries, the rich tend to grab more and the public has to gang up and demand for service and the media has a big role to play. I have not heard of that argument previously but all over the world the whole point of electoral commission is to be independent of the governing party. And indeed not to lean towards the opposition, it should stand up and do a good job to make sure the election is fair. I cannot comment in detail because I have no knowledge about this. I have not been following closely what happens in Uganda ever since I was out of the International Development. I believe in transparency and people in different countries in Africa say we have been given a blessing of these rich resources like mineral, oil and should not be a curse. Uganda has seen it from other countries of bad examples and should be getting it right. Transparency is the key to making sure that money is well spent. There is a global movement of all oil and mineral companies to be public on the payments they make to governments. This enables civil society to scrutinize and is a very good system to ensure that the people benefit from the natural wealth. I hope that Uganda would be transparent for the good of its people. I saw in the media that Uganda President had said Uganda would send up to 20,000 troops and of course Uganda is angry after the bomb blast in Kampala. My argument is that the western policy towards Somalia has been mistaken and Somalis have suffered and scattered all over the world. United States under George Bush administration and Ethiopia went in Somalia before and failed. The trouble still goes on in Somalia. They have to make a bigger effort from bottom-top approach so that the people themselves can make peace and the international community comes in with logistical support of food and water. If I was Uganda, I would be cautious about sending more troops because other countries have gone in and pulled out. There is a lot of killing. It is not my duty to tell Uganda what to do but I would say be careful Uganda others have been stung. I did stand down in May this year and I am here in Uganda with the African Humanitarian Action as a trustee looking at cities alliance. People are moving away from rural areas to urban centers and we are trying to make sure they have decent housing jobs and other basic necessities. This would promote more production and markets. African Humanitarian Action is based in Addis Ababa and we also look at Africa providing relief to Africans first instead of relief coming from outside.

TITLE: Are Citizens Losing the Fight Against Corruption? [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); BRIBERY (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT (88%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%); MAGISTRATES (76%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (70%); TERM LIMITS (66%); CEMETERIES (55%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: One thing about corruption is that it is difficult to define but easy to describe. So there cannot be any excuse for corruption by feigning ignorance of it. Corruption in Uganda has reached unacceptable levels. In a civilised nation, one would expect that law enforcement agencies would be the first resort in the fight against corruption. We now know that the police force is one of the most corrupt institutions in Uganda. We also know that there are more ghosts in the army than in the city cemetery. One would also ordinarily turn to the judicial system. Yet, the judiciary is only in competition with the police in perpetration of corruption. Some magistrates have been known to take bribes to muzzle cases and deliver favourable judgements. Others have been accused of forging court proceedings (for trials that never took place) leading to conviction of innocent persons at the behest of influential, well-greased "clients" . Who, then, will fight corruption? Parliament as an institution lost its respect when a large number of MPs in the seventh Parliament accepted a Shs5 million bribe to push through the obnoxious amendment that lifted presidential term limits. The population has lost confidence in law enforcement agencies. This could explain why incidences of mob action are frequent. While I would not engage in an act of mob action, I am not sure I can walk into a police station to register a complaint, for I just don't imagine I can get the help I would need. Nor can I file a case in any Ugandan court with the hope of obtaining justice. I don't think I am alone. In the good old days of the now banned Ekimeeza (field radio talk show), a participant suggested that the only way forward in the fight against corruption would be to arrest the corrupt, try them quickly, confiscate their property if found guilty, and kill them by firing squad. From the audience came a voice "like Ghana's Rawlings did", before another one said Amin yeyali abasobola (it is Amin who could manage them - the corrupt). When an adult Ugandan whose political instincts are developed enough to participate in a political radio show prays for another Amin, you know that the people are getting desperate. And here lies the risk to Uganda's democratic experiment. Not perfect by any measure, Uganda's experience with democracy was beginning to hold. Now we run the risk of a drastic undemocratic action by a possibly opportunistic group who would promise to rid the nation of corrupt people. They would then execute a few corrupt people by firing squad, and confiscate their property amidst cheers from a hitherto frustrated population. This euphoria would then last a few months, before the "saviours" degenerate into another corrupt dictatorship. A few months ago, I spoke to a group of university students. As usual, the subject of nepotism, a form of corruption, came up. They had earlier lamented that government jobs and lucrative scholarships were accessible to youths from a certain ethnic group. I encouraged them to forget about looking for jobs in government and try entrepreneurship . One female student angrily accused me of accepting the "status quo". I tried to explain to her that it was possible to wrestle government control from the corrupt rulers through democracy, by voting them out in the next elections. I thought I had succeeded. Then she shouted: "Elections? Which elections? Can there be a real election in Uganda?" she continued: "To hell with elections and your democracy. What we need is change. Not democracy". This is the extent of the cross-cutting frustration that has afflicted not only rural folk, but also urbanites and educated young people. What I know, though, is that the fight against corruption begins with you. No one else can do it for you. Mr Nnyago is a researcher and e-learning specialist, omarkalinge@gmail.com

TITLE: Attorney General Warns Lawyers On Corruption
SUBJECT: LAWYERS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (90%); MISCONDUCT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LEGAL SERVICES (90%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (78%); VERDICTS (74%); CIVIL PROCEDURE (74%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (74%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION (71%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (71%); GRADUATE & PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (71%) Uganda; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Attorney General, Dr Khiddu Makubuya, has cautioned lawyers against corruption and professional misconduct saying these acts are tainting the image of the legal profession. He said many practicing advocates are currently being investigated by the Uganda Law Council over illegal misconduct. "This matter of ethics and integrity in the legal profession is very serious and we are fighting tooth and nail to ensure that our profession doesn't become a laughing stock," Dr Makubuya said. The attorney General, who also doubles as Minister for Justice and Constitutional Affairs, said last month alone , the Uganda Law Council received 47 complaints against advocates. "All these cases are before the council's disciplinary committee and those found guilty will be punished accordingly because they have failed to adhere to the strict code of conduct laid down in the Advocates Act," he said. In the last couple of months, the media has been awash with stories of advocates being reported to the Uganda Law Council for illegal conduct. And some of the offences committed are quite mind-boggling. The minister issued the warning yesterday during the 37th graduation ceremony of the Law Development Centre. 698 students were awarded diplomas and certificates. They were part of those who passed their exams in the last academic year (2008/09) and others who re-sat various papers in previous years. Some of the notable personalities who graduated include former minister Gen. Moses Ali, former ISO boss Brig. Henry Tumukunde, Democratic Party Legal Advisor Fred Mbidde and MPs Michael Mabikke (Makindye West), Susan Nakawuki (Busiro East) and Samuel Odonga Otto (Aruu County). Dr Makubuya challenged the fresh law graduates to exhibit and uphold high professional ethics and avoid temptations to amass quick wealth through cheating clients. "The challenge you face as fresh graduates is to salvage the legal profession from corruption. Those moving to private practice should avoid acting without instruction. Keep the position of trust and never connive to cheat clients," he cautioned, adding, "You have been taught civil law here and I don't expect you to apply jungle law like some unscrupulous advocates in town." The Deputy Chief Justice Laetitia Mukasa Kikonyogo, who presided as chief guest commended the Centre for accelerating high academic and professional standards. She urged government to increase its funding to the institution to enable it facilitate its academics and developmental programmmes. LDC Director, Elijah Wante also asked government to regulate the operations of court bailiffs and auctioneers if they are to effectively contribute in the administration of justice in the country. Mr Wante said some court bailiffs were acting unprofessionally thus tainting the image of the legal profession. Court bailiffs and clerks are only trained at LDC under the Centre's short law courses. He said courses for court bailiffs, auctioneers and clerks have low intake because there are no regulations compelling persons carrying out those jobs to acquire basic training in laws and procedures relating to their work.

TITLE: Voters Must Reject Politicians Implicated in Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (90%); POLITICS (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (86%); TERM LIMITS (76%); HOUSEHOLD NUMBERS (74%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (72%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (69%); FARM LABOR (69%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (69%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (68%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (64%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (52%); HOTELS & MOTELS (50%) Uganda; Governance; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Three stories in the Saturday Vision of August 28, summarise the essence of this article. On the front page was a revelation of 187 billion lost in government companies; the second story said "Kawolo Hospital a death Trap" and the last and most absurd was "War erupts over Museveni Cash" carried in the 'Crazy Krazy World' pictures. In the pictorial, the President is pictured handing over the characteristic envelop to performers and thereafter, a war erupts over the said cash. One man is left in only underwear yet, even after losing both his clothes and dignity, this man according to the caption, did not get the money! At an average 18 per cent Vat, Ugandans pay an average of Shs450 in taxes on the basics like soap, sugar, and tooth paste. A person who uses at the lower end of 12 bars of soap in a year pays Shs5,400 in taxes and so is sugar. Meanwhile, peasants who use paraffin pay Shs250 in taxes per litre. A household that uses two litres per month therefore parts with Shs6,000 a year in taxes. If we multiplied Shs6,000 with the number of households that use paraffin in this country, it is a wholesome figure. It is not a surprise that today, the government boasts of seven or so trillion collections. However, when it comes to service delivery, the tax payer is offered 'Death Traps' for health facilities, poor education in universal primary and secondary education, mass unemployment and humiliating poverty resulting into able-bodied young men stripping each other over presidential envelops! A closer look at the loss of huge monies in government companies, poor state of health, poverty and government insistence on the current Electoral Commission reveals corruption as a linking thread. Last weekend, a group of civil society (NAFFE, NGO Forum, ACODE and PAC - Soroti), held another Citizen's Parliament in Soroti under the theme 'Tracking Corruption: one sure way to guarantee free and fair elections and accountable democratic governance in the country'. The Citizen's Parliament is a deliberate move to take the debate about public loot to the countryside because underneath Uganda's challenges is corruption with impunity. Making corruption a high political risk, these CSOs believe, may yield better results than merely begging politicians to fight the vice. In Soroti, after listening to the findings of the Chogm probe report, presented by Parliament's Public Accounts Committee chairman Hon. Nandala Mafabi, they (the people) adopted the resolutions passed by the Citizen's Parliament held a few weeks ago at Hotel Africana, they emphasised that the two - term presidential term limits be restored to avoid a situation where a regime can hold Ugandans hostage; they demanded the reconstitution of the Electoral Commission which they said was a prerequisite for free and fair elections. The current EC, they said, has been proven to be compromised. The people of Soroti also called upon political parties to front only candidates with a clear and proven track record; they said political parties should punish and recall any implicated persons from party leadership positions and that those parties that do not comply would be seen as condoning corruption. Emphasising this, they said, "We shall reject any leaders who have been implicated in corruption scandals and also reject the political parties that front them." Finally, they resolved that in picking their leaders, they would follow the Guide to Responsible Choice of Leaders that was launched by Bishop Zac Niringiye at the same function. Ms Wokuri is the interim coordinator, National Alliance for a Free and Fair Election

TITLE: Repeal Uneb Act 1983 to Curtail Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (89%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (89%); EDUCATIONAL TESTING SERVICES (89%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (88%); ETHICS (78%); MISCONDUCT (78%); PRIVATE SCHOOLS (77%); EDUCATION ADMINISTRATION (77%); SCHOOL CHEATING (77%); EXECUTIVES (69%) Uganda; Education
TEXT: The recent Uganda National Examinations Board (Uneb) report launched by the Inspector General of Government is a good start to addressing the corruption in the education sector. It is, however, not enough to stop at studies and reports. What is urgent is to repeal the Uneb Act 1983 so as to address the critical issues documented in the report. Among the 10 functions of Uneb as per the Act, Article 4 clause (i): "Uneb shall make rules regulating the conduct of examinations and for all purposes incidental thereto." However, I feel the rules therein have not addressed the prevailing examination malpractice conclusively. The rules ought to purge gaps existing in examination management ranging from setting, briefing, moderating, scouting, and monitoring, distributing, collecting, marking, releasing of results and awarding certificates. A new law should be put in place and existing ones strengthened to address flaws in examinations at all levels. This should take into account issues like the security of examination papers and supervision of exams, among others. The Act should be improved to clearly spell out the duration and tenure of officers for some key examination offices notably chief examiners, team leaders and checkers. Rotational methods and replacement of those whose terms have expired should be considered in the new law. Though there can be renewal of tenure of service, the new law should address the need to check on the unchangeable chiefs whose permanency in some positions is responsible for the various challenges and unethical conduct like favouritism extended to specific schools (both public and private). The need for regulation, redeployment and rotation of officers as a way of addressing these challenges, is urgent. Though the 1983 Uneb Act states that all proceedings of the board shall be strictly confidential, the new law should clarify what level of confidentiality to be considered as classified. Aware of the fact that Uneb continues to administer its oath of secrecy to all examiners, there is need to clarify what should be secret and what shouldn't, according to the law. This legal instrument will permanently check the abnormal and exorbitant examination fees that head teachers levy on many parents, guardians and students. The law should also take into account ways of holding accountable head teachers who collect, misuse or disappear with examination fees instead of remitting it to Uneb. Also, under the new law, officers who become members of Uneb committees must be of clean record and without private or personal businesses that can injure the integrity of the examination body. These measures, if implemented, will check corruption in the education sector. Mr Kaboyo is the executive director of Coalition of Uganda Private School Teachers Association and Board member Anti-Corruption Coalition Uganda

TITLE: Massive Corruption and the Hatred of People [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); RETAIL TRADE FIGURES (74%); SHAREHOLDERS (73%); LUXURY GOODS (73%); FARM LABOR (72%); REAL ESTATE (71%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (70%); GROCERY STORES & SUPERMARKETS (70%); REAL ESTATE AGENTS (64%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (60%) Uganda; Governance
TEXT: During the 24 years the NRM has been in power, the description of the past (and deposed) post-independence regimes as "anti-people" has been far more frequent than the charge that they were unpatriotic. This could be because "anti-people" sounds more forceful and hits directly at the body. The expression is simple and is readily understood by even those peasants who have next to no formal education. But it is also possible that NRM ideologues were genuinely trying to get to the heart of the matter; because, ultimately, what is the value of patriotism (the passionate love of one's country) if you feel nothing for the people, living organisms that think and suffer? Last Sunday, I imagined a set of shareholders and their family members who brought down their own retail trade business by stealing massively from it. I compared a set of rulers and powerful citizens who stole from their country to those shareholders. But the comparison of course is not entirely accurate. Our fictional Wochumi Supermarket would probably not survive regular thefts exceeding 10 per cent of its stock. But even with over 40 per cent reported to be the level of theft in Uganda government transactions, the country never quite shuts down. I suppose it has something to do with the movement of money, goods and services. When Wochumi is robbed, the goods and the money go elsewhere; Wochumi collapses. When the country's Treasury is directly or indirectly looted, some of the money may be siphoned to foreign destinations: banks, real estate, company shares, luxury goods stores and even gambling houses. But most of the dirty money is very likely spent or invested at home. The processes of converting it into tangible (even if redundant) wealth, of hiring labour and paying for services and utilities ensure that a lot of this money is recycled back into the national economy, with the tax-collector nibbling from it at every turn. It was probably because of this phenomenon that President Museveni once reportedly said (if I am not dreaming), that the country could develop with (or, maybe, in spite of) corruption. But either way, something very significant is happening. Instead of, say, a good 100km highway, we get a low quality 60km job. Some of the money has gone into several private mansions for the honchos who negotiated and gave out the contract. Apart from starving our infrastructure to the carcass we have, this transfer of resources from public works, health, security, education and agriculture to the private interests of the privileged translates into poverty for the masses, as they cannot access quality public services and seek costly solutions from the private sector. Many simply give up. Furthermore, the ease with which protected powerful thieves amass wealth distorts the very concept of work and reward, alienating and demoralizing the genuine worker, and accelerating the growth of the gap between rich and poor. It is a bomb that tomorrow's revolutionaries could choose to ignite. Under NRM rule, the characterisation of previous regimes as anti-people has been mainly on the basis of their violence, brutality and repression. Periodically, the present regime itself unleashes strong doses of that savagery. But as we have seen, the effects of massive corruption alone under the NRM are also blows struck against the people. From Germany to China and the defunct Soviet Union, not to mention Latin America and Africa's banana republics, every dictatorship has worked against the people in the name of patriotism. It is a camouflage that Uganda's current rulers have decided to brandish in the country's schoolrooms. But what value will the young read in the rhetoric of patriotism when the ruling class is so markedly anti-people? Mr Tacca is a novelist, socio-political commentator and artist

TITLE: Kampala Tops New Corruption List
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (79%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (79%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); MISAPPROPRIATION (78%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); WAGES & SALARIES (76%); TAX FRAUD (76%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (75%); EXTORTION (73%); TAXES & TAXATION (72%); EXECUTIVES (71%); COUNTERFEITING (69%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (60%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%) Uganda; Economy, Business and Finance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Government officials digging their hand into the till to directly pull out public funds remains the top form of corruption, the Inspectorate of government has said in a new report. At 19.4 percent of complaints recorded at the IGG, mismanagement and misappropriation of public resources is the most reported form of corruption. Ugandans also view and complain about non-payment of salaries at 18.7 per cent, followed by abuse of office at 17.8 per cent, delays in delivery of services, which often leads to solicitation and offering of bribes stands at 9.1 per cent. Property disputes, also viewed as a form of corruption stand at 7.3 per cent. The report released by IGG Raphael Baku also reveals forgery and uttering of false documents, embezzlement, tenders and contracts manipulation, bribery and extortion, victimization or oppression, conflict of interest, false claims and tax evasion among the issues that irk many Ugandans. The report details how worsening corruption is hamstringing delivery of government services to ordinary citizens and rendering key public institutions useless. The report released yesterday, covering the financial year ending December 2009, puts Kampala in the lead of most complained-about administrative units while district local governments top public institutions perceived to be corrupt. Kampala has the highest number of complaints at 418, followed by Fort Portal Municipality (56), Masaka (54), Arua (46) and Jinja (40), among others. The least complained about administrative areas are Mbale (13) and Moroto (16), implying outwardly that staff in these areas are less thieving. Mr Baku said: "The complaints in the report are just a small fraction of the problems of corruption out there. Many people [suffer silently] and have not come out to report." In the latest report, districts have for the third year running topped the list of the most complained-about institutions. This may be because ordinary citizens interface more with district, rather than central government, employees on daily basis and get first-hand brush with money-hungry bureaucrats. The IGG, for instance, reports that bidders often offer bribes to Chief Administrative Officers (CAOs) and other officials --- so in the end, service providers do substandard work which the bribe-takers ironically monitor! "Individual public officials have continued to use their offices for private gain," reads the report. Despite the establishment of various institutions, among them the IGG, the Police Criminal Investigations Directorate and the Directorate of Public Prosecutions, to catch thieves in government, critics say less political will exists to follow through arrests, prosecutions and punishments of perpetrators. The World Bank estimated in 2005 that Uganda loses about $300 million (Shs600 billion) through corruption and procurement malpractices every year, much of this being money meant for providing clean water, quality education, good roads and medicines in public health facilities. President Museveni has vowed to abolish the vice but majority Ugandans interviewed in a survey joint commissioned by Daily Monitor and European Union's Deepening said soaring corruption is NRM's biggest failure. Yesterday, Mr Baku said fraudulent contract awards, shoddy works, fraudulent recruitment and unfair administrative decisions fuel corruption in the country. That trend, he said, would only change if citizens get motivated that corrupt official they report are tried and punished. Police prominently feature in the latest report, mainly on cases of bribe-taking, mismanagement, delayed service, victimisation/oppression, conflict of interest and misconduct. In the reporting period, the IGG received a total 827 corruption-related complaints, up from 739 complaints reported between January-July 2009.

TITLE: Can God Help Uganda to Fight Corruption? [opinion]
SUBJECT: RELIGION (93%); POLLS & SURVEYS (91%); WITCHCRAFT (90%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (88%); CORRUPTION (87%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (78%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (78%); MATH & SCIENCE EDUCATION (63%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; Religion
TEXT: A recent survey by the US-based Pew Research Centre puts Uganda among the most religious countries on earth. The same survey also found that more people here got involved in the practice of witchcraft than in many other countries. Nine out of 10 people for religion (Christianity or Islam) and two out of 10 for witchcraft. Those findings are completely consistent with my expectations, as several articles in this column prior to the survey have indicated. Indeed, the actual figures for both may be even closer. Why? Because a lot of people think it is disreputable or primitive to be involved with witchcraft and only visit their witchdoctor when nobody is looking. Some of these may not have owned up when providing the research data. We are in the realm of superstition. The mindset that conjures up images of angels, resurrected super mortals and watchful saints who died way back and takes them for real is exactly the same as that in which ancestors and evil spirits are believed to be active forces affecting people's lives. If they are active and have a closer relationship with the gods than living mortals, then the believer can appeal to them to intercede for him in his quest for the blessings of the divine. When they are thought to be angry or neglected, or when their help is required in the face of a special task, it sounds reasonable to offer gifts or sacrifices - sometimes even human sacrifices - to them. In this realm, almost anything can be believed, and nothing is subject to scientific proof. I don't know whether President Museveni believes in the world of gods and other supernatural beings, but he must have noted the statistics, and as a perpetually vote-hungry ruler, he would not hesitate to tap into this pool of believers. In as much as he preaches about the value of a scientific education and science-related skills, the President has decided that his latest action over the plague of corruption would be completely unscientific. He declared a day of prayers for the country's key institutions. If there is any evidence at all, it is that the more a country prays, the greater its harvest of corruption will be. Or, maybe, the more corrupt a country is, the greater its hypocrisy; hence more journeys to churches and mosques. However, as arranged, the bad, the ugly and the horrible all came together; the executive, the army, the police, the tax collectors and so on, and it seems Gen. Museveni was a kind of high priest at the gathering, doing his own bit of praying and preaching. From what we all know about human behaviour, the bubbles of laughter from the bellies of the participants must have been suffocating under the external solemnity of an otherwise comic exhibition. You can see the palms covering their faces in prayer. Some of their fingers are slightly spread open, and through the gaps they stare as gangster after gangster rises to make confessions on behalf of their institution and to register their contrition. The very cheeky are literally on the verge of bursting with laughter. Those who didn't know were happily informed a few years ago by the First Lady that President Museveni was sent to us by God. Much earlier, with a touch of humour, the President had famously said that he was next to God. In other words, so immense was his power. But if in this special position the President cannot independently deal with his corrupt officials; if in private he trembles at the thought of punishing them; if, indeed - God forbid - if only the little finger on his left hand was ever (even once) in cahoots with them, then God can only be taken seriously as the Chief of the Universe, and a chief capable of helping Uganda, if he assigned to the country another president. Mr Tacca is a novelist, socio-political commentator and artist

TITLE: Museveni Turns to God in Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); RELIGION (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ETHICS (73%); EXECUTIVES (73%); WITCHCRAFT (67%); HUMAN RIGHTS (67%) Uganda
TEXT: Following widespread corruption, President Museveni has declared June 21, a day for prayer at the Kololo Airstrip, Kampala. The day will be used to ask God for forgiveness and pray for the country's repentance. Mr Museveni, in a press statement read for him by the Minister for the Presidency, Dr Beatrice Wabudeya, asked Ugandans to pray for the same cause. "Not withstanding the stability we have enjoyed for the last 24 years, there are things that have gone against our expectation... Like embezzlement, illicit enrichment and misuse of public funds," the statement reads. "We shall gather together for a special day of prayer and repentance so that we may thank God and seek his mercy and forgiveness for this great chosen nation." He added: "Ugandans who may not be able to come to Kololo may gather in convenient places within their locations for the same purpose on that day." The national prayers are expected to attract all regardless of political or religious affiliation. Ms Wabudeya was accompanied by Ethics Minister James Nsaba Buturo. Human rights activists said although the country urgently needs the prayers, the government also has failed in some areas. Mr Livingstone Sewanyana, the executive director of the Foundation for Human Rights Initiative, said praying to God is one thing and doing what God expects of us is another. Mr Museveni cautioned that Uganda risks losing out on God's blessings for if disobedience prevails "on the other hand, we stand to gain if, we obey God." The President cites bribery, human sacrifice, sexual perversion, witchcraft and misuse of funds as some of the immoral things that have affected the country.

TITLE: Police Uncovers Massive Corruption in Agricultural Sector
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); MISAPPROPRIATION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); AGRICULTURE (86%); AGRICULTURAL TRADE (86%); AGREEMENTS (78%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (77%); ARRESTS (76%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); POLICE FORCES (76%); LARCENY & THEFT (74%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (73%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (68%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (67%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (52%) Uganda; Food, Agriculture and Rural Issues; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: In April, the Uganda National Advisory Services (Naads) offered 20 goats, 20 iron sheets and 40 pieces of timber to a group in Buliisa District. The items and animals were intended to eradicate poverty in a district that is still struggling with its vicious circle of poverty. According to the Naads records, the items were delivered and the beneficiaries were overwhelmed by the supplies. But Deputy Police Spokesman Vincent Ssekate says that although the supplies were delivered, the supplier and beneficiaries connived to misappropriate the Naads support. "The supplier delivered the items but later connived with some of the beneficiaries and bought the supplies, which is contrary to the laws," Mr Ssekate explains. He adds that four people including the supplier and beneficiaries have been arrested and charged with misappropriation of Naads fund. However, Ssekate says that had it not been police intelligence led investigations, it would have been difficult to track the misappropriation since it was committed by the supplier and beneficiaries. According to the World Bank estimates, Uganda loses over Shs500billion every year to corruption. Therefore the president says that if police have information that some officials are stealing Naads money, they can arrest them to save such funds. General Kale Kayihura says that the area police will be given copies of the documents that state the amount of money or any kind of funding from Naads or Nusaf dispensed to the grassroots so as to monitor the implementation of the programmes. "It is now the work of the police to investigate misuse of funds by government officials in the country. It is the work of the intelligence officers and Criminal Investigations Department to investigate and produce reports on corruption before any other person does so," he says. Naads has spent over Shs48billion on agriculture programmes in 929 rural sub counties and 137 urban councils within 80 districts in the country. But often local leaders collude with suppliers and beneficiaries to meet their own selfish needs. In Lyantonde District, police investigation allegedly found anomalies in the construction of Mukokoma Market, a valley dam at Kibeija village, sourcing and distribution of 42 Boer goats, and the tarmac of Lyantonde High Street. Detectives discovered that the contracted suppliers of 42 Boer goats only supplied four Boers while the rest were local goats contrary to the agreement but the district officials sanctioned the deal. The district officials allegedly certified that the goats supplied were of a good quality yet it wasn't the case. Such misuse of funds can't be detected in instances where there is a chain of collusion. But President Museveni says that the only way such thefts can be controlled is by getting a third party which is the police to monitor implementation of such programmes.

TITLE: Government Has Exhibited the Will to Fight Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: LAWYERS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); DISMISSALS (77%); APPOINTMENTS (77%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (76%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (73%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (72%); APPROVALS (70%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (68%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (68%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The NRM government has been accused of lack of a political will to fight corruption. First the criticism has been on lack of the use of institutions. It's the NRM government that created the institution of inspectorate of government. At first it had no powers to prosecute, dismiss people or take any corrective action against officers found wanting. The powers of the IGG have now been strengthened to enforce non-compliance with the Leadership Code. The office has also powers to prosecute its own cases. When NRM came to power, the Auditor General was an officer in the Ministry of Finance. The office didn't have the independence it desired to hold government officers accountable. It's the NRM that brought reforms in the institution of the Auditor General. As a result, the office is independent of the Ministry of Finance and it is self accounting like any other government department. The office holder is appointed by the President and approved by Parliament. In short, the Auditor General is an independent institution which can carry out its mandate without fear of victimisation. This also applies to the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). In the past this office was under the Attorney General. In fact the DPP was a department under the Solicitor General as a civil servant who could be transferred by the Solicitor General to another department within the ministry. Such a person could not be independent to prosecute government officials senior to his rank like a permanent secretary or even a Solicitor General. It's the NRM government in the making of the 1995 Constitution that gave independence to the DPP and made the office holder serve on the same terms with a judge of the High Court. The DPP, the IGG and the Auditor General cannot be easily removed from office by anyone be it Parliament or the Executive. There are other institutions like PPDA which I think is doing a commendable job. In 2005 when the NRM-dominated Parliament was discussing the rules of procedure of a multiparty Parliament, it was agreed that the accountability committees like PAC and the one on local government should be chaired by opposition to give that independence to avoid a chairperson from the ruling party chairing a committee that questions his/her colleagues in government. That is why Nandala Mafabi, Reagan Okumu, Abdul Katuntu from FDC chair the accountability committees. If NRM didn't have the political will to fight corruption, it would never have allowed that. What they need is to be fair in their judgments. For instance in the much awaited Chogm report, I was amazed to read that ministers Isaac Musumba and Mwesigwa Rukutana had been condemned without a hearing. Recently, a company called Bolton bought space in the Daily Monitor clarifying on the communication equipment they supplied of which minister Amama Mbabazi is accused of having varied the price from $3.2m to $5m. They clarified that the price of $3.2m was given to police in 2004. That when contacted in 2006 with modifications to the specifications of 2004, their price was $4.8m which was negotiated downwards to $4.5m. Now what is Mbabazi's crime? The company also claims it was never given a hearing. Minister Sam Kutesa on the other hand is accused of having had shares in a company that supplied vehicles. He clarified that he had sold the said shares two years earlier. In my opinion, while we appreciate the work of PAC, their report should be sent to anti corruption institutions like DPP and IGG who have powers to prosecute any company or individual found wanting or in the case of IGG can recommend administrative action against any officer or recommend recovery of the money where necessary. Suppose now on the floor of Parliament the report is not adopted, what would be next? Mr Byaruhanga is a presidential assistant on political affairs

TITLE: Proper Monitoring System Can Check Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ETHICS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (77%); PUBLIC POLICY (76%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (71%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (71%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); ECONOMIC NEWS (64%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (62%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: While many people think corruption is a lost cause in Uganda, I have tried to remain optimistic. But lately, the one question on my mind is, are things really as bad as they appear to be? Chogm is just one of many projects that implementers have used to enrich themselves at the expense of Ugandans. I get disturbed by the level of opulence in ministries and government agencies with so many projects that have delivered so little despite lots of funding. We would get so scandalised if we considered other forms of corruption other than acceptance of bribes, say nepotistic allocations or diversion of public resources for economic or political benefit. The general violation of formal rules of conduct that occurs between public officials is almost public policy. Little wonder, some people are putting their hope in having the donors do something in order for government to make good on its pledge to fight corruption. But does government need a form of carrot and stick to deal with corruption? Where is government commitment? Members of the ruling party often argue that there is zero tolerance to corruption demonstrated by the numerous policy, legal and institutional frameworks. The Global Integrity Report 2009 actually placed Uganda's legal framework to fight corruption at 99 per cent. So why does it seem like corruption is worsening? Weak implementation of existing frameworks or legality is simply not enough to tackle corruption. So what must be done? I believe to effectively tackle corruption, strengthening citizen participation will be a starting point. Secondly, developing mechanisms for monitoring and evaluation systems, if well implemented, will reduce opportunities for corruption. I might be reminded that government has set up these systems. The Ministry of Finance Planning and Economic Development established the Monitoring and Analysis Unit in 1999 and in 2002, a Poverty Monitoring and Evaluation Strategy completely integrated with the policy process. This was in 2005 subsumed into the National Integrated Monitoring and Evaluation Framework (NIMES), not forgetting the Public Expenditure Tracking Surveys. Yet, in spite of these developments, we are told that the Poverty Eradication Action Programme which led to these developments largely failed due to implementation hitches laced by corruption. This means the M&E systems were not effectively implemented. Partly, the problem is that much of the M&E we engage in is donor driven and for them. In effect, the whole process of M&E is plagued by corruption. Officials in government largely commission consultants either working for them, or who will not damage their image in the final report and also give kick backs. We must view combating corruption as primarily government responsibility and duty to citizens rather than to donors. We must also desist from reducing corruption only to a lens through which we view activities of the state. Unless we actively reject being part of corruption as citizens, we do not have any moral justification to demand that government fights corruption or expect it to succeed in its attempt to do so. Along side an excellent and independent monitoring and evaluation system, a sound management information system accessible by the public and adequately used by the media and civil society to demand accountability will reduce corruption. Citizens can also act by electing credible leaders whose integrity can not be questioned, are mindful of their role in championing economic development, and who will rise above petty party politics on issues that derail good governance like corruption. Ms Maractho is a development economist

TITLE: Corruption and NRM - the Bond Will Live on for Ages [opinion]
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); BRITISH PRIME MINISTERS (77%); CAUCUSES (74%); CORRUPTION (66%); BRIBERY (66%); HOLIDAYS & OBSERVANCES (50%) Uganda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: When Western government officials criticise Uganda's thieving or undemocratic ways, President Museveni responds that he has nothing to learn about governance from the West. However, the recent general election in the United Kingdom could teach the rest of us a thing or two. It is not so much all that stuff about a smooth handing over of power. But there is this thing about a ruler's mortal status. I am not referring to the inevitability of death; indeed, I wouldn't care if President Museveni decided to live for ever. It is the human scale I am looking at; the scale at which the outgoing premier (Gordon Brown) and the new leader (David Cameron) have been operating. During the campaigns, the barely audible use of the word "bigoted" (moreover not referring to any of the candidates) was enough to get Mr Brown into trouble, and an apology from the then Prime Minister did not make the universe collapse over his head. Britain has huge problems, at home and abroad, but at his defeat, Brown has expressed his faith that the relatively inexperienced Cameron is competent enough to serve. On his way out of Downing Street, Brown spoke of how his office had given him access to the best in human nature, but also to human frailties, including (he emphasised) his own. Frailties? The day President Museveni speaks of his frailties should be declared an annual public holiday! One need not be personal. President Museveni is only the head of the ruling pack. Can his NRM transcend the frailties of the individuals within it and give the nation a spell of "strong, stable, good and decent government", such as the new premier (Cameron) has promised his Tory-Lib Dem coalition will try to give Great Britain? The NRM could win or steal next year's general election. To my mind, the mother of NRM weaknesses is its contempt of Uganda's citizens. If you contemplate how shabbily our people are used, robbed, bribed, insulted, told lies, how they have their constitution used like a rag, or how the opposition is hounded and the NRM caucus and parliamentary majority abused, you realise that the ruling elite can only do this because its members thoroughly despise the citizens. And as we approach the 2011 general election, the signs are that instead of trying to cleanse and renew itself, the NRM is set to continue on the path of separating power from public morality. Several weeks down the road, the NRM delegate's conference will elect its new leadership. There has been in Uganda a serious joke about a "queue" of people waiting to replace President Museveni. That could be decades away, but the very idea of a queue reflects the contempt for the citizenry that I have referred to. It implies that the NRM has laid out a plan of inheritance, quite regardless of the dynamics of a democratic process. Hence, Dr Kiiza Besigye, who wanted to become President from the opposition, was said to have jumped the queue. But now a monkey called CHOGM and the impending elections have exposed the ideological and moral bankruptcy of the NRM. The party leaders and white collar gangsters of yesterday are the same rolling in the mud today, and they are the same lined up for the leading roles in the party tomorrow. Unfortunately, or by design, there is absolutely no hint that the party Chairman and President of the republic, or the NRM party disciplinary machinery, would want any of these leaders excluded on moral grounds. If Gen Museveni "wins" again, these men and women will probably still be up there in power, strengthening the bond between corruption and the NRM government. It should be interesting to watch the first encounter between the youngster, David Cameron (43), and a "re-elected" and power hardened veteran, Gen. Museveni. Mr Tacca is a novelist, socio-political commentator and artist.

TITLE: Donors Pile Pressure On Government Over Corruption
COUNTRY: UGANDA (93%); EUROPE (93%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (91%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (89%); BUDGETS (89%); EUROPEAN UNION (89%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (71%); BUDGET CUTS (71%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (60%) Uganda; Europe and Africa; Crime and Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: The government is facing growing pressure from donors over accountability and action against corrupt officials, Daily Monitor can reveal. The donors say they will not settle for anything less than strict enforcement of recommendations of anti-corruption bodies notably Parliament's Public Accounts Committee, the Inspector General of Government, the Auditor General and the Police Criminal Investigations Department among others. The extent of donor frustration is partly reflected in a Shs8.1 billion cut in budget support, but the European Union head of delegation, Ambassador Vincent De Visscher, said more drastic measures could be seen when they hold their conference in September. While speaking on Kfm's Hot Seat talk show in Kampala last week, Ambassador De Visscher said: "We are glad the government has agreed to tackle corruption. The President has taken a zero stand on corruption but we want to see that followed by real action." "We are waiting for the results of the PAC report and we are hoping it will be debated and we will be watching for action to be taken." He revealed that if the report is not followed by action, questions will be raised by development partners. Ambassador De Visscher said his concerns are shared by other development partners and not just the European Union. He dismissed claims that some accounting officers implicated by reports on corruption were following directives from their political supervisors, mainly ministers. The ambassador said permanent secretaries should demand that their superiors first sign for money before it is released. "They should ask the minister to sign [for the money] or say they will resign other than do something wrong." "EU tax payers will not understand if money is misused and no action is taken. I have to show accountability for the taxpayers' money," he said. Ambassador De Visscher also disclosed that EU is not happy with the rampant corruption in procurement, saying it will cost the country Shs8.1 billion donation out of Shs81.7 billion in budget support. He, however, said Uganda has to compete for donor support with other countries because the terrain has changed following the effects of the global financial crisis. He disclosed that donor support will tremendously decrease as Uganda begins to reap from oil.
